The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.

div.p: THE THIRD AND Lat Volume OF ASTREA A ROMANCE WRITTEN IN FRENCH BY Mesire Honorè D' rfe; AND TRANSLATED BY A Peron of Quality.
LONDON, Printed for Hum: Moeley, Tho. Dring, and H. Herringman, and are to be old in S. Pauls Church-yard, Fleettreet, and in the lower walk in the New Exchange, 1658.

YOu have in the Epitles to the firt and econd Volumes of Atrea, the deign and tendency, as alo the advantages of it, & of works of its nature I mean Romances) 'T will therefore be unneceary to ue repetition thereof: This enuing (being the continuation and concluion of the work) expoeth it elf to publick view, as neceary to the compleating of its Individuum. I can believe it will meet with uch only, who prefer and indutrious and trict Scrutiny, before a uperficial and eaie Cenuring; uch I am ure are nearest the confines of Reaon and Civility. The floridnes of its Dicoures will Apologize for your pains in reading, and its price in your purchaing. Nor needs it other Complement to indulge and ingratiate, then its own uavity, which being deguted, will delight the pallate of the candid and ingenuous, for whom it is accommodated.

div.head: ASTREA.
Volumne III. BOOK I.
div.p: DORINDE and all thoe that accompanyed her unto Marelles, as oon as Supper was ended, were conducted unto their Chambers by Clindor and Leontidas; the time of the night, and their wearied Limbs, inviting them thereunto: But before they parted, it was reolved amongt them, that Periander, and Merindor hould preent themelves unto the grand Druide in the morning, and beeech him that he would preent them unto the Nymph; conceiving the protection which they deir'd to be o jut, as he would willingly mediate in their behalf: And afterwards, if the Nymph thought good, Dorinde would acquaint her with the caue of their voyage.

This coure being reolved upon, every one retired into the Chambers which were prepared for them: Dorinde, Florice, Palanice, and Circenea, would needs lie all together; and Dorinde who was full of perplexities, not being able to take any ret, he kept all her companions awake by asking a thouand Quetions; at lat Florice asked her this Quetion: Coin (aid he) from whence do you conceive King Gondebaut's deire of getting you into his hands, doth proceed? For truly we do not know of any interet that he has in you: Oh Florice! (anwered Dorinde and ighed) did you but know my mierable fortune, you would never have asked this quetion: I had begun to relate it unto you, but the urprial of Gondebauts men interrupted me; but let me tell you, I am ure that this Country never produced a more unfortunate woman than Dorinde is. I conceive it very neceary (aid Palanice) that your friends hould be acquainted with the tate of your fortune, that they may contribute their aitance for your preervation. Alas (aid Dorinde with tears in her eyes) had I not ome hope in the Jutice of Heaven, I hould never expect any help: And yet (aid Circeusa) you ought to help your elf as much as you can; for the Gods do betow Prudence unto men to help themelves in uch occaions: and they will ait uch as through courage toward themelves againt the blows of fortune, either by prudence or trength; Therefore (aid Florice) it is very requiite we be acquainted with the tate of your fortune, that we joyning our aitance unto yours, we may be the better able to advie you, and you alo better enabled to make ue of us: for beleeve me Cofin, two eyes ee more then one; and I conceive we cannot have a fitter opportunity of privacy then this, for perhaps your tory contains many paages nor fit to be publihed, and now all ears are aleep but ours. Dorinde, who aw a neceity of acquainting them with her Story, and that a better opportunity could not be then this; She began thus,

div.head: The Hitory of Dorinde, King Gondebaut, and of the Prince Sigimond.
div.p: SOme are uch Favorites of Heaven (my dear companions) that their happines doth trancend even their very deires; Some, on the contrary, o hated by fortune, as he doth blat them with greater diaters, then are imaginable. I may, with too much reaon, rank my elf among the lat of thee; for my misfortunes are much beyond my imagination, and of worer train then any other had: And yet, (as I hope you will judge by the relation of my ad tory) I am not in any fault, unles in that I do not put a period to my days by ome violent act.

Perhaps (my kind companions) you know as well as I, That Gondebaut had three brothers; to wit, Chilperick, Godamar, and Godegeeles, of whom none remains but Godegeiles the younget, Lord of the higher Burgundy. For the other two, having gathered together a great body of Germans poeed themelves of the Kingdom, by winning of a battle which was fought in the fields of Authuno • s, which Gondebaut and the young Godoge les lot: Thee two young ones thinking themelves now to be Kings, and all quiet in the tate, they ent away their Auxialiary Troops beyond the Rhine: Gondebaut eeing them to be diarmed, and living ecurely without any upition of h • m whom they thought to be dead he preently ra • ied together all his forces, and be ieged them in Vienna, & preed o hard upon them, as he forced the Inhabitants to render the Town and Chilperick into his hands, whoe head he chopped off the ame hour he entred the Town: he threw his Wife into the Rone, with a great tone about her neck; and afterwards burned Godomar in a Tower unto which he was retreated Chilperick left two Daughters; the elder called Mu • utuna and the other Clotilda, both o young, that the innocency of their age obtained their pardon for the offence of the father; And yet Mutucana was preently after by the Kings command, placed amongt the Vetals, there to pas away a retired and olitary life. As for Clotilda, her beauty and dicretion was uch, as got her the eteem of all, particularly of the King, who loved her as his own child; Sigimond his Son was not dearer unto him then this fair Princes. This Prince had marryed
• m • lberge, the Daughter of Thierry, King of the • trog • tt; by whom (though they lived but a little while together, for he dyed hortly after) he had yet a Son and Daughter: The Son named Sigerius, and the Daughter Amainda. I do revive your memory of thee things leat perhaps you hould have forgotten them; for the memory of them is very neceary and pertinent unto what I am to tell you.

Now, King Gondebaut after many Conquets beyond the Alpes, and Victories over the Gallo L • gurians, and other Nations, thinking he might very well devote ome, days unto Sports and Patimes, he reolved to hew the grandure of his Majety as well in Courtly exercies, as he had in Martial exploits.

In order to this deign, he made choice of the great and rich City of Lions, where he proclaimed open houe: Prepared o many Maques, Tiltings, Tourneme • ts, and Skirmihes upon the water, that the magnificence of them did atonih all thoe who out of curioity came to behold them. He having been long a Widdower, and the Princes Amalberge, wife unto the Prince Sigimond dead two years ago, there was no Ladies that lay in the Palace Royal: But the more to illutrate this Aemb;ly, he ent for the young Princes Clotilda from Viennae, where he had been educated ince the death of Chilperick her father; As for Amainda, the Daughter of Sigimond, he was yet in the Armes of her Nure; Sigerius, her elder Brother, being not above four years of age. When Clotilda came into the preence of Gondebaut, he carryed her elf o prudently and weetly, and appeared o fair in the eyes of all, as the Kings good will towards her was much encreaed,
and as if he had forgotten he was the child of Chilperick, he made no difference betwixt her and his own child. It is worth obervance, that his equal affection unto Sigimond and Clotilda, in lieu of kindling any parks of envy or jealouie betwixt them (as is very uual in perons of that age) it produced quite contrary effects in them, and tyed them together in fat knots of amity, not inferiour unto any ligaments of conaguinity whatoever.

When Clotilda was come and her lodgings prepared for her, the Court appeared in greater luter: for Gondebaut had preferred unto her ervice twelve young Ladies, the principal of all his Kingdom, called out amongt the fairet, and bet qualified in all his Dominions; It was my hap to be one of this number, choen not for any manner of merit in me, but rather for the place ake where I was born, or indeed rather to give fortune, an occaion of afflicting and perecuting me the more.

I thought that now I was quite rid of the importunities of Periander, by reaon of his levity; of Bellimartes, by reaon of his falhood: and of Merindor, by reaon of his preferring his brother in his room. But I found, that as oon as the deformity of my face was with time vanihed away, Periander was as buie as ever about me: and as if he had been only aleep all the time of my icknes, will needs have me believe that he was ever my ervant, uing all his arguments and rethorique to gloe over his levity, and paring no manner of oath and protetation to purchae belief. On the other ide, to my miery, Alderina chanced to dye, leaving the fale Bellimartes at liberty to perecute me. And to make me mot perfectly mierable, Merindor did the like; as if he had drunk of the water of oblivion, and would have me pledge him, he accoted me with a miling look, eeming to wonder I hould not be as free with him as I was wont to be before his treaon, and making horrible complaints againt my wavering and unequal humour. Oh Heavens! was ever uch impudence heard of? epecially Merindors: As for Periander, though he did quit me, yet it was after my dieae had made me ugly; and if he did return, when my dieae was over, he was in ome ort excuable, becaue it was never me that he loved, but that fading thing which the world cals beauty, o as this is ome kind of excue for him. As for Bellimartes although he did commit a mot groe fault, yet I can find ome excue for him; for though he was married, yet it was his love and eteem of me which prompted him to marry me, But for Merindor, I cannot find any collour of excue for him, but only that he is a man; and being o, he is allowed to be incontant and fale. Yet I mut needs confee, I am mot enible of his diloyalty, becaue he had leat reaon for what he did, and I a greater inclination unto him then any other.

During the time of thee Baccanalian Feates, it hapned that the King one day after he had delighted the Princee Clotilda, and the Ladies with everal hews, they went all to walk in the Athenian Gardens, where the Rone and the Arar meeting, there is a mot dilectable Ile betwixt two great Rivers, which everal Kings have imbellihed with abundance of Art: planting it with trees, and adorning it with magnificient Fountains, Walks, Turraes, and Arbors, which being contrived with excellent deign; and order out of o much confuion, does till take the eye of the walker with omthing of novelty and wonder. But indeed at that time, the trees were not decked in their mantles of green, nor cat of their gray garments of winter. Yet the King, to upply that defect; brought forth abundance of Orange Trees, which he had preerved in vaultes from the torms of Frot and Snow, and planted them in uch indutrious order, as it eemed as if the Summer had preceded the Spring.

It was at this time, and in this place, when and where Periander, Bellimartes, and Merindor, intended to renew their importunities: Periander who firt proved fale, was the firt alo that accoted me with this language. This, fairet Dorinde, is the day of your Triumph and Victories, for which way oever you cat your eye, you cannot ee any thing which does not yeild and ubmit unto your beauty. I looked coldly upon him, and then without any anwer turned the other way, and continued my walk with my Companions. But he, nothing daunted at my cold looks, followed, and taking hold of my Gown; what fair one? aid he
unto me) not one word by way of anwer? Is it unto me (anwered I very didaignfully) that you peak? Can you doubt it (replied he) ince I called you by the Epithite which is mot your due? How did you call me (aid I unto him) I called you, aid he, by your own right name; did you not hear me call you fair Dorinde? I know none of that name, replied I; for do you not remember that he dyed of the mal Pox. At this he bluht, yet anwered; yes, yes, but he is rien again: I cannot tell, anwered I, whether he be rien as to others, but I aure you, he is for ever dead as to you: After this, ay what he would, I would not turn any longer towards him. Then Bellimartes, eeing his Companion diengaged, he accoted me, and would needs take me under the arm: but I faigning that I had not yet een him, I looked him tedfatly in the face, and aid unto him, Sir, Alderina whom you look for is not here: Alderina (anwered he) was once the caue of my miery, and now he is dead, her memory I hope will not be as fatal to me as he was. The Gods are o full of all goodnes, anwered I, as that they can make the happines of one out of the miery of another: and this miery of which you complain was my happines; So as I hould be very ungrateful if I hould loe the memory of it. But in good earnet, aid he, I hope you do know that Alderina is dead, and that he will never trouble either you or me. Bellimartes, anwered I very faintly, be mot confident of this that though Alderina be dead, yet I hall never be inclinable to marry you, leat I hould be the Alderina of ome other Dorinde. Upon this Bellimartes left me, as much ahamed as Periander was, and Merindor immediately tept into his place: and I mot ingeniouly confes, as I told you before, that I was more offended againt him then all the ret. Madam (aid he unto me after a low conge) thanks be to the fates, I am now uch an abolute mater of my elf, as that I am able to aure you I am your mot humbly devoted ervant. Merindor, anwered I, is this the language which you taught your brother when you ent him unto me? Oh fair Dorinde (anwered he immediately) when I wihed that happines unto my brother, it was when I could not render you a greater tetimony of my affection: but now I am free, I peak unto you in the behalf of Merindor, who till loves and adores you, and ever hall; Thee expreions Merindor, aid I unto him in a little impatiency, might well deceive any other but Dorinde; and yet truly becaue I would be not be ungratefull, if I had a iter I would advie her to accept of your good will: but as for me, never think any more of it; for I was told by a very good Atrologer that your marriage and mine together was never made in Heaven. Then turning away towards my Companions, and declining any further talk with them, we began to dance after the Gaulih mode. Many Caveliers of the Court did hear all our dicoure, and what anwers I gave unto them: and as there are alwayes ome whoe practice is to carry tales unto the King, thereby to ininuate themelves into favour, o ome pick-thank, or other acquainted the King immediately with all my anwers; The King who was much taken with them told them again unto everal perons, laughing at thee three Cavaliers. But ee if I had not good reaons to ay that fortune which makes ome happy beyond their deires, did make me more mierable then I could imagine; for who would ever have thought that thee reproaches which I gave unto thee impudent men, hould have cot me o much miery as I have endured? And yet o it hapned that the King being pleaed with them, and hearing what great affection thoe three Cavaliers did bear unto me, he began to entertain ome good opinion of me, and from that day to this would never let me live in quietnee. Oh Heavens! how dear did his favours a while after, cot me? For, I cannot tell upon what reaon, but the King, to my miery, took a liking unto me: and I do protet, I never took any notice of it until it was too late be remedied.

Though Heaven has elevated great Princes much higher then thoe over whom they command: yet they do want that liberty which private perons do enjoy; for even as high Towers are een farther then the humble Cottages of Shepherds; o the grandure of Kings is o obvious unto all eyes, that they cannot tir a tep but they are een by all, and the very leat of their actions is ubject unto the cenure of • hn multitude; and therefore it is a thing impoible that a Lady hould be
courted by them, but all the Court mot preently perceive it. Gondebaut who knew this very well, and being deirous to apply ome remedy unto it, (for he knew that if he did not, Arcingeutorix, and the ret of my kindred would be offended; and that the Princee Clotilda would have a jut caue of complaint) and therefore his deign was to carry this courthip as covertly as he could, and with uch cloe circumpection, as hould delude the eyes of the mot clear ighted. As for me, I was altogether ignorant of the Kings deign, and minded nothing but my attendance upon that wie Princee endeavoring by my ervice to gain her favour; and I found by many of her noble expreions to me that my endeavours were not in vain; which was uch a high contentment unto me as every one might ee it in my face; o as I found the Proverb to be true, which ayes, that contentment is the bet painting; and truly me thought, that I had quite another kind of a face, and was not as I was wont to be: Alo my judgment in this was not ingular; for all my Companions thought o as well as I, even the prudent Princee her elf whoe kindnee unto me was the principal caue of it.

The King whoe deign was to render me mierable, was very tudious how to acquaint me with his intention, and was a long while before he could tell which way he hould begin the work; for eeing me to very young, he could not tell whether I had o much government over my elf as to keep ecret. But one night when we were all dancing, and when, according to the cutome, they tole her away which danced, the King in his turn, came towards me; and as oon as he touched my hand, he aid unto me, I hould think my elf more happy if I could teal away this treaure, then I am in the conquet of all Gaule. Unto which I miled and anwered, the theft Sir which you are pleaed to mention, is exceedingly mall, epecially compared unto o great an Empire. If this which you eteem o trivial (aid he unto me, and graped my hand) could be as oon atchieved, as I could conquer all Gaul, I would this very hour put on my Armor, and never put it off until I had made an abolute conquet. Upon this, not taying for my anwer, he paed on to another. I mut needs confee, that I was much urpried at this expreion; but not being able to perwade my elf that there was any thing in me that was worthy either of the eye or thought of a King, I believed it to be his cutome of peaking o unto all, and only to pae away time: o as in this belief, I grounded nothing upon thoe words.

The King in the mean time, who was very obervant to ee how I would take this expreion; hearing no more talk of it, he thought me to have more judgment, then thoe of my age ue to have: and as it is common with Lovers to Flatter themelves, o he perwaded himelf, that the knowledge which he had imparted unto me of his good will, was not dipleaing unto me. And therefore growing more confident in my dicretion, and more encouraged to dicover himelf: one day when we were all in the Athenian Gardens, and when my Companions were a little eperated from me, as I was reaching at a flower which grew upon a tree that was a little too high for my arm, he left the Princee walking and came and pulled the flower; here fair one, (aid he and gave it unto me) take this flower as a pledge of my heart which I have already given unto you: then he went preently to the Princee again. I mut needs confee that this econd declaration did open my eyes; but yet I thought it a thing o impoible that the King hould ever have any thoughts of me, as I till remained in my blindnee and would take no notice of it, nor mention it unto any. The King finding by thee two tetimonies that I could keep ecret, he thought it now high time to trut himelf wholly unto my dicretion: o as a while after, when the Princee Clotilda was making preparations to diguie herelf, and to dance in the habit of the Druyde and Nayade Nimphs, he was very deirous to ee how he dreed her elf: o as he came unto her all alone by himelf, and firt of all began to commend Clotilda very highly, who indeed was a Princee of mot rare beauty as well of mind as of body: then he eemed deirous to ee us all; and when he aw all very buie in triming up themelves, he came unto me, and aid in a low voice, as for you fair one, your beauty is o trancendent, that nothing can either be added or diminihed without doing you wrong. Shame would not permit
me to return an anwer: and he perceiving it by the bluhes of my cheek: If you be as dicreet for the future (aid he) as you have been hitherto, I will make you the greatet and mot happy of all your family; upon this he put a note into my boome upon uch a uddain, that if I had not felt it, perhaps I had never taken any notice of it.

This brought bluhes into my face as red as if my cheeks were all on fire; and a thouand to one, but it had been perceived: yet all my Companions were o buie in tricking up themelves, as they never aw when the King went out; and from that day I never doubted what the deign of Gonbebaut was, though till then, I mut ingeniouly confee that I could not imagine his meaning. My knowledge of this did not perplex me o much as did my ignorance; not knowing how to carry my elf in a buinee of that concernment. For I thought it a crime in me to hide it from the Princee Clotilda: and to acquaint her was the way to make Gondebaut my foe, and make that Princee much offended at him. On the other ide, I knew that all men were fale, and the experience which I had of it, was freh in my memory. Beides all thee coniderations, could I ever imagine the King did court me to any other end but to tain my honour? This conideration touched me o neerly, that I once intended to go that very hour unto Clotil • a, and hew her the Letter which he had put into my bret: but then conidering how extreamly it would perplex that Princee, and how it would diturb all the Jocundry of the Bacchanals I deferred it until the Feat was over, and then intended to acquaint Clotilda with it, who honouring me with her favours, would give me the bet advice he could. And leat the Paper which the King had put into my boome hould chance to be lot, and o een by ome or other. I went to lock it up in a little box where I ued to keep uch things. When I returned, I found all my Companions almot all ready to dance; and the Princee eeing me o backward, he called me luggard, and honoured me o far as to help me her elf to dree my elf.

The King in the mean time, whoe love was like unto all the ret of his ex, who are alwa • es at the firt full of raptures and impatienties, his mind was wholly upon this paion, which did encreae by my ilence: This welled him with a thouand chimeras and fancies how he hould contrive the buinee. And at lat returning one night very late from the ball, and when all were retired from him, after they had gotten him to bed, he called unto one that waited upon him in his chamber, and one whom he ued to trut in uch like occaions. He caued him to kneel down by his bed ide; acquainted him with his extream affection unto me; and commanded him upon his life to keep it ecret, and to contrive a means for his contentment. The young man, who was accutomed unto uch dicoure, did not at all wonder at the violency of his paion; for not long be ore he had een him as hot upon Cryeide; Sir, aid he unto the King) this Lady has been courted already by very many, and has been deceived b • them all, o as he will hardly ever trut any again. The King, according to the Nature of all Lovers, did flatter himelf with a conceit that I had ome good will towards him; and therefore anwered him very confidently, that he himelf had already broken the Ice, that I knew he loved me, and perhaps bore no ill will unto him: but all the difficulty was to find out a truty confident by whoe means he might let me undertand all that he de •• red I hould know: for there was o many eyes upon him that he could not peak unto me but by hort and interrupted entences, leat Clotilda or ome of my Companions hould oberve him; that this fear kept me from returning unto him any anwers, and him from coming unto any concluion with me; and therefore he propounded unto him whether it was expedient to imploy Periander, Bellimartes, or Merindor in the buinee, who might without any upition talk with me as long as they pleaed: for though they were in love with me, yet he knew they durt not contradict what he commanded them. Ardilan (for that was the name of the young man) after a ilent hearing of all this, anwered thus; I have heard Sir, all that you have been pleaed to tell me, and have thought upon a coure, by which I hope you may effect your deires. Firt, I do not like you hould imploy any of thee three Cavaliers whom you have propoed, and that
for everal reaons: for though they be all in love with her, and would marry her and dare not diobay your commands, yet you may be pleaed to conider, that Dorinde will never trut them; they have already deceived her; he hates them, and therefore he will not confide in any thing they ay: the only way to marr all, were to put it unto any one of their management; I have heard ay, that if one would obtain any favour from another, it mut be asked by one who is in favour with that party: but thoe whom you have mentioned are her enemies, or at leat, he thinks them o, and has found them all to be fale unto her. Whatoever you do, you mut not imploy any of them in the enterprie: Next, you mut be ure you never peak unto her in any place where you may be een; for if you do, then the jealouie, or rather the envy of her Companions, will make uch a noie of it in the Court, that you will be contrained upon a thouand coniderations, to make a retreat. But the only way is to gain one that is frequent and familiar about her peron; one that he dares trut: and I cannot think upon any more fit for the buinee then that maid who waites upon her in her chamber; for he has the opportunity of talking unto her at all times when he pleae: and moreover Dorinde having a great confidence in her, he may the ooner be perwaded unto what you deire: and becaue the greatet difficulty is to gain her whom I peak off, I have contrived a way to bring it about; you mut Sir, in the firt place dazle her eys with that mettle which very few have power to reit next, I am reolved to make her believe that I am in love with her, and that I will marry her; he is tollerably handome, and will be apt to believe it: for almot all women will hearken unto any commendations of their beauty and credit it: and by thee two wayes I intend to make my accee unto her.

The King hearing the Propoition of Ardilan, did like it, and think it feaable and eaie: o, as if he had already obtained what he deired, he raied himelf out of bed and embraced him aying thus unto him; I ee Ardilan that thou dot love me, and that without thee I hall never arrive at my contentment; aure thy elf thy ervices hall find an ample recompence; as I have one, the bet of ervants, o thou halt find me the bet of Maters: Then lying down in his bed, go friend (aid he unto him) contrive the buines as thou wilt; I referre it wholly unto thee, and to morrow I hall furnih thee with whatoever thou halt think fit for Dorindes Chamber-maid.

The next morning Ardilan being furnihed with all that was requiite, he ought for an opportunity of peech with Duriana (for that was the name of her that erved me) and becaue it was a eaon when every one eemed to be out of their wits, and a time when to be wie eemed to be a kind of folly, he met with an opportunity preently; for that night he and ome young men of his pack dreed themelves in the habits of women, and came unto my Fathers houe, under the notion of Mummers, as they are called.

It is the cutome of the place, and I think of all Gaul, for thee Mummers in vizards, to enter freely into all houes, none asking the quetion who they are, or from whence they came: preently they did lay upon the table a Bag of Money, which they intended to venture at play; and what they do they do all in ilence: for if they peak one word, they loe all they play for: Ardilan having thus entred into my Fathers houe, one of his company who took upon him to play, laid down his mony and dice upon the table, and everal Cavaliers who upped that night with my Father, began to play with him: In the mean time Ardilan walked half a dozen turns up and down the great chamber, looking whether Duriana was there; and at lat, he found her dancing amongt others in another room: after a while, he thrut himelf amongt them, and taking her by the hand made one with them in the dance; and becaue he danced extraordinarily well, he drew the eyes of all the company upon him, epecially Duriana, who was extreamly deirous to know who he was. The dance being done, and he thinking him to be a woman, he ate down by him, and put a thouand quetions to him, purpoely to make him peak. As long as any was o near as to hear, he made no anwers but only by igns, but when all the company was parted from her, he took Duriana by the hand, and aid unto her in a low voice; it is very
trange Duriana you hould not know that peron who loves you above all the world. She who had little or no acquaintance with him, and perhaps had never heard him peak before, he did a little wonder at his words, and not knowing his voice, he was more inquiitive then he was before, I beeech you (aid he unto him) if you do love me o well as you ay you do, why will you not let me know who you are? Becaue (aid he) I am of o little worth, that when you know me I am afraid you will corn me: I do not ue, anwered he, to be o uncivil as to corn any who are owners of o much merit, as I ee you are: upon this aurance, replied he, I will tell you that I am Ardilan, who ever ince your Mitris came to Court, is o wholly devoted unto your ervice as I cannot enjoy any contentment unles my vowed ervice find ome acceptance. But why hould I trifle away time in relation of uch things as thee? It is enough to tell you, that before they parted, Duriana who thought all in earnet, and that it would be a match very advantagious to her, he was contented to accept of his ervice, upon condition he would not deceive her, as he had een many deceive me. The ubtile Ardilan vowed and proteted fidellity; and gave her o many aurances of it as he who had no more wit then he tood in need of, was won to do whatoever he would have her: and the more to engage her, he gave her a Ring, and beeeched her to wear it for his ake; at the firt he refued it, becaue he thought it to be of too great value. But he was o urgent with her, that at lat he took it, upon condition I hould not dilike it. Fye, fye, aid the crafty Ardilan, nothing does more ruine Loves then divulging them; and if you be pleaed that you and I hould continue kind, as I do heartly deire. peak not a word of it unto any; for if you do aure your elf, ome or other out of envy will ruine our deigns. But if my Mitris hould be advertied of it by another (aid Duriana) would he not have reaon to be angry and chide me? Oh my Sweetheart (anwered Ardilan) how can he ever come to know it by any other, if you never peak of it unto any? For my part, I will et a lock upon my lips, and I beeech you to do the like upon yours, epecially from Dorinde; why hould you acquaint her? Alas Duriana he tands more in need of your advie, then you of hers and had he been as wie as Duriana is, he had never received o many dipleaures as he has, I am afraid we hould be too much oberved, and therefore I cannot now ay all I would; the next time we meet, I hall tell you more, and plainly hew you that Dorindes dipleaures proceed from her elf, and perhaps may be remedied, if he will but believe you. Upon this, he left her, and would not tay for her anwer, being very glad, and thinking he had done more for the firt time, then ever he could have hoped.

Some two or three dayes after Ardilan had talked with Duriana, my good genius put me in mind of the danger that might enue by keeping the paper, which the King gave me, any longer, I was in two or three minds, and ready to cat it into the fire, o to extinguih one flame with another; or ele to carry it unto Clotilda, and o dicharge my elf of that blame which might be imputed unto me. But as to the firt coure, I thought that if I did burn it, then if the King hould come to know it, he would be extreamly offended at this corn: and how could I anwer him, if he asked me my reaon for it? I thought it therefore better to read it firt, and then to burn it: but then, if Clotilda hould come to know of this either by the King or any other, how unkindly would he take this from me? Quetionlee Gondebaut himelf would be the firt that would tell her, when he ees I will not conent unto all that pleaeth him; or if he hould alter his humour; as to my ad experience, I find Merindor and Periander hath done; their examples teach me at a dear rate, that the contancy of a man, lats no longer then till his eyes finds an object that pleaeth him better. This Princee (aid I to my elf) does me the honour to love me, and I am mot confident of her good advice; and ay the King hould come to know that I have acquainted her, he cannot chue but know withal, that my duty obliged me unto what I did; and I am very confident that when the heat of the humour is a little over, he will eteem me more for it, and ay I did well.

According to this lat reolution, I took the Letter and went unto Clotilda
and as fortune was, found her in her Cloet, paing away the time with many of my Companions. And becaue he honoured me o far as to love me above any of the ret, as oon as he aw me he was pleaed to come unto me; and becaue all young perons have alwayes ome trivial news to tell one another, he took me aide unto a window of a little ditance from the ret of the company, where he related unto me not only all he had done ince the lat time he aw me, but alo, all her mot intimate thoughts: at lat he aid unto me, but good Dorinde tell me what you have done ince lat you were with me; come, come, give me an exact accompt not only of your actions, but even of every thought. Madam, (aid I unto her) at another time I hall mot willingly tell you what you pleae; but at this time, I beeech you give me leave to intertain you with a buinee of a very great importance; and becaue I would not have any oberve us, I beeech you go into your Inner Cloet, and call me unto you, that when we are alone, I may impart a buinee unto you, which is fit you hould know. The young Princee longing to know what I had to tell her, and being alo very deirous to give me contentment, he did as I deired her; and when we were both in the Cloet, the door bolted, he at down, and I according to my cutome, kneeled down before her, mot humbly beeeching her to think, that my deire of keeping my elf within the compae of my duty, and to carry my elf in all things according to her commands, did prompt me to impart unto her what I then would; then I did not only hew her the Kings Letter, but alo imparted unto her all the paages of my three lat encounters with Gondibaut • , which I did with that freedom, as he knew me to be in no fault. epecially when he aw the Letter till ealed, which after much commendations of me for it, he opened, and read thee words.

body.head: King GONDEBAUTS Letter unto DORINDE.
body.p: YOu cannot, Fairet, think it trange that one hould love you, ince you have already been loved by o many; but perhaps you will wonder when you conider that he whom you have captivated, was never conquered by the mot powerful upon earth. As there hath been nothing hitherto invincible unto my arms, o, Fairet, ue your conquet kindly, for unto you, I ubmit my Crown, my Scepter, and all my Triumphs and Laurels.

p.U:
tood mute, after the reading of this Letter; and after he had long pawed upon it, Dorinde (aid he unto me) you need not entreat me to conceal a buinee, which is o unfit to be publihed: and becaue you deire my advice, and I am obliged to give it, not at random, but upon mature deliberation, I will take this night to conider upon it. Thus we parted; and becaue none of my Companions hould upect any matter of ecreie to be betwixt us, the wie Princee went out laughing, and commanded me to do the like, as if we had been talking upon matter of mirth and jollity. You know, that the Prince Godomar, younger brother unto Sigimond, went to travel into the Courts of Neighbour Kings, there to learn the Cutoms, Laws, and Manners of other Countries; to be acquainted with their Countries and trength, and the better to improve himelf in his travels, he carried with him the great and wie Avitus, who had been Governour, not only unto him, but to his brother Sigimond alo. Now this young Prince was lately returned to the great contentment both of King and people; for truly both Sigimond and Gondemar being intructed by uch a Sapient Tutor, wer • both very hopeful. This prudent Governour, above all other documents, did mot imprint amity and concord betwixt them; hewing them that little
things grow great by union; and great things become nothing by dicord; he hinted unto them, the jars betwixt their father and his brothers, how their ambition and emnity did draw upon themelves the odium of the Gaules, and their own ruine: that this wound would be long in healing in their family, unlee they with a contrary deign did remedy it, to wit, by mutual love, as the others did make the wound by hatred. Thee age intructions, imprinted themelves o upon the pirits of thee two young Princes, that a greater league of Love and Union cannot be imagined then was betwixt them.

div.p: This wie man finding by the phiiognomy of Clotilda, that he would prove a mot Excellent and Wie Princee; he thought it would be advantagious unto thee two Princes to contract a league of amity with her: for conanguinity was not enough to alve up thoe ores which former dientions had made. This wie advie, together with the weet inclination of Clotilda, did make thee two Princes o exceedingly love her, that all the animoities of their fathers hatred were not only rooted out, but thee young hearts did link themelves together in uch trong tyes of affection, as each of them had as kind a care of the others good as of their own: nothing was in ecret amongt them: and knowing the humour of Gondebaut to be collerick and violent, they after conulted together what was the bet coure to be taken in any affair, and above all, they followed the Prudent advice of their wie Governour. And yet, as there is often a certain kind of blind inclination which moves ome to affect one peron above another, o this Princee had ever a kind of natural affection more towards the Prince Sigimond, than towards his brother Godomar: and this was the reaon that at this time he acquainted him only with my buinee; he related the whole paage unto him, hewed him the Kings Letter, and asked him what he hould ay unto me and what he hould do. Sigimond was at the firt extreamly atonihed; afterward he asked her, how he came to know the buinee, and how I carried my elf in it; to whom the Princee anwered, Dorinde carries her elf as he ought to do, and will not do any thing without my advice; for it was from her I came to know the buinee.

Now, oberve, I beeech you, how dangerous it is to acquaint young men with uch matters; Sigimond had never cat his eyes upon me but only by way of indifferency, as upon the ret of my Companions, had it not been for this. But dear Companions, well may we ay ome are happy beyond their hopes, and others more unfortunate then they could imagine: and I am one of thoe whom fortune has made the butt for the wort of her arrows. Could any ever have imagined, that Clotilda by reprehending the Fathers fault hould caue the Son to commit it? No certainly, and but my cros fate mut needs have it o, urely it had never been.

Now the deigns of the young Prince is wholly upon me, and becaue he did not know whether his addree would be as welcome unto me as his Fathers, he reolved at the firt, to hide his affection from Clotilda, knowing very well that he would diwade him from it if poibly he could, and perhaps divert me alo. But he did extreamly diapprove of the Kings intention, eemed to wonder at it, and to vilifie me in uch a manner as if I hould be the lat of all the Court whom he could love. Then turning his dicoure upon Gondebaut, iter (aid he, for o he called her) we mut upon any terms take ome coure or other to prevent this buinee from going any farther; for though Dorinde has hitherto carried her elf very well in the matter, yet it is to be feared that a long continuance of Courthip may make her change her mind: A place may make a brave reitance to the firt and econd aault, yet yeild at the third: beides, Love you know is a contagious dieae, and infects another party. Truly brother (anwered the Princee) I am not well acquainted with the nature of that dieae, but adhere much unto your opinion of it, and therefore I deire your advice. I hould be very reerved in giving it, (anwered the Prince) as well becaue it concerns my King, as becaue that King is my Father, but that the honour of our family, and particularly yours, dear Siter, is at the take, and therefore I hall be the more open and free in giving it. Let me tell you therefore, that conidering the Kings humour
and dipoition, I do foreee much michief may come of this matter, if you if you do not oppoe in its firt beginning; and believe this for certain, that when it has once taken root, you can never do it: or if you do, it will be with much heartburning and dicontent. Let not the dieae gather trength, it is very dangerous in all dieaes, but mot epecially in Love, above all others. This is my advice at the firt: and if we find that the dieae do yet till increae, we mut have recoure unto other remedies, which time and occaion may dicover unto us; but above all things, make ure that Dorinde do not deceive her elf, and that he do not deceive you; for Love is a thing of uch a ubtle nature, as that it does eie upon a heart unperceived; and if it do o in her, aure your elf Siter, your labour will be all lot. Such a thing may be, anwered the Princee, but I fear it not; for I know Dorinde to be o dicreet and wie, that he will never do any act prejudicial unto her elf or me.

The next morning, Clotilda took me aide, and aid thus unto me; I have thought Dorinde upon your buinee or indeed ours, for I am concerned it it, and perhaps more then you are. It is a buines wherein you mut hew both your prudence and your courage: your courage, in corning any thing that may wound your reputation, and your prudence, in doing it o that the King may not be offended either againt you, or me. Firt you mut conceive, that the King courts you only to ruine you, and that as oon as it is known, your honour is lot; think upon thoe noble Ancetors from whom you are decended; conider what abundance of hazard and pains they took in getting that reputation which they left unto their poterity. I hope you will not be the firt that for want of courage will uffer this anciently decended reputation to be tayned: as for matter of prudence, you mut Dorinde fight this enemy, not by triving and contending, but by flying from him; Love is of uch a nature as is ooner overcome by flight. then reitance; and the Love of Kings above all others; for puiant Princes are alwayes extreamly offended againt any thing which does reit them; they are jealous of their power, and will at any rate preerve it unreitable. I advice you therefore, that in the practice of this prudence, you do not reit, but flye from this enemy; that is, that you hun all occaions of being in any place where Gondebaut may have any dicoure with you; and if he chance to find uch an opportunity, eem as if you did not undertand what he aid; and be o far from being perwaded that he loves you, as to eem abolutely ignorant in all matters of love. If you carry it o, perhaps you may divert his intention, or at the leat tyer him out: and above all be ure, that I be advertied of all paages betwixt you; and be aured, that as long as you do o, I will never forake you.

This was the age counel which Clotilda gave me and which I reolved to follow mot punctually, as well becaue of her reaons which he alledged unto me, as becaue I had been formerly deceived by uch as ued the ame language, he did in his Letter. I returned the Princee, mot humble and hearty thanks for the honour of her advice, and promied all exact obervance. Afterwards I kied her hand, in tetimony of my devotion unto her ervice; and o went out of the Cloet, leat any hould oberve or upect any buinee more then ordinary to be betwixt us.

The King reted ome dayes, and never poke unto me, to ee what effects his Letter would produce. But Ardilan in the mean time was not idle; for being a ubtle and witty fellow, and having found the opportunity of talking with Duriana every morning as he went unto the Temple, he had o gained her, what by his mooth language, and what by gifts, that the wench was wholly his: and the matter was carried o cloe and cunningly betwixt them that none in the Court perceived it: The King on the other ide having dicovered himelf unto this man, and much confiding in him, he was o reerved, that had I not acquainted Clotilda with his deign, he had never taken any notice of it. Every hour in the day, he enquired of me whether any new accident had faln out, and was till giving me intructions how to behave my elf: at lat, I told her that I was in hopes the Kings mind was changed, ince he was o long ilent: ah Sweetheart, (aid he unto me) that fire which is covered in the embers, may flah out before you
be aware: never think your elf out of danger till you ee Gondebaut love another; and then I will believe it, knowing very well, that new thoughts are apt to mother the old ones: But till then, tand upon your guard, and aure your elf, that when the enemy eems to leep, then is he preparing himelf for a mot dangerous aault.

The Forret of Ereiwe, which ome call the Forret of Mars, is ditant from •• e Town about a mile and a half; Clotilda did much delight in hunting when the weather was fair, and the Suns heat would permit. My Companions and I re
• embled Harpalice, that generous Thracian Lady, when he galloped over the plains after after the lively Hart, or when with her Javelin he aaulted the furious Bore: our habits were as gay as hers, all glittering in Gold, Silver, and everal coloured Silks; our rich Scarfs waved in defiance of the wind; Diamonds did vye glitering with the Sun; and Pearles looked like o many chains of Stars about our necks; our Feathers and every thing et us out to the bet advantage: the cutome was, that we might go as bet pleaed us, either together, or everal provided it was not out of the ight of our Governee: and if any Cavalier had any dipoition to talk with us, he freely might as long as he pleaed. That day Merindor was next me, and though he received no anwers from me, yet he till continued his ordinary importunities. Gondebaut whoe eye was alwayes upon me, as oon as we were paed over the bride of Rone, and were entred into the plain, he eemed as if he did not oberve me but called Ardilan unto him, and commanded that as oon as I was lighted to go up the Scaffold where we were to view the combate between the Cavaliers and ome wild Bores which were taken in Toyles, then he hould find fault with the hooe of my hore, as if it were looe, and in taking up his foot, to thrut a nail into his hoof and make him lame: you mut alo know, that after everal combates before the Ladies, they ue to let ome Bores looe and hunt them with dogs.

After many Cavaliers had hewed much courage in the death of many Bores, the King commanded all the company to take hore and follow the chae; upon this, the Ladies and the Cavaliers all mounted, and followed the Huntmen, Merindor, as his cutome was, would needs help me up, and afterwards my Companion; I eeing Clotilda far before me, began to gallop after: but after twenty or forty paces, my hore fell o lame; that he could hardly et his foot upon the ground, and therefore we could not overtake Clotilda, who followed the chae with full peed. The King who tayed purpoly behind with a mall company did quickly overtake us; and eeming to be ignorant of my hores lamenes, did ask me how it came to pae, and whether it was by leaping over ome ditch? I told him that I know not by what accident it was, but was ure that if he continued thus lame; I hould not be able to follow the chae. The King looked about if there was any hore in the Company upon which I might mount, but finding none good enough, he commanded Merindor to ride after Clotilda and acquaint our Governee, that I could not overtake the Company, and that he hould take order for another hore, or ele to come and keep me Company, it not being fit I hould be left alone. Oh good God, how deirous ome eem to mend things, when they themelves would have them more in diorder? Merindor he et purs to his hore and rid away, and my Companion, out of repect, kept at a ditance behind, where ome Cavaliers of the Kings held her in talk. But the King, to loe no time began thus; Come fair one (aid he) what anwer will you give unto my Letter? Will you doom me to live or dye?

As oon as ever I aw the King, I expected an aault, and aw no way to avoid it; o as I began preently to conider with my elf what anwer I hould give him. I did very well remember Clotildas intruction, and was fully determined to follow them: but the grand Feat not being yet pat, and I fearing to make any blander of the matter which was principally forbidden me, I reolved to defer my anwer until another time: o as with a miling look I aid thus unto him; The anwer Sir, which you require of me, I cannot give at this time: but I mot humbly beeech you to give me the repite of fiveteen dayes, and then you hall know the reaon of my delay. I hall (anwered he) and will wait your
pleaure as long as you will; but let me tell you, that I think this delay to be to no purpoe: bu • fairet, ince you will have it o, I am reolved to ubmit; yet upon a promie now that y • u will give me an anwer then. Sir, anwered I, I do mot faithfully it. Then my fairet (aid he unto me and miled) let me tell you, that to get this opportunity of peech with you, it was I who caued your hore thus lame; and by this you may ee that my invention is not o barren, but I can find out opportunities when I pleae. Give me leave to tell you Sir (anwered I) that it was but a cruel invention to lame a poor hore, which did you no harm: Conider, fair one, replied he preent • y, that I do love you with uch a perfect affection, that I would do any thing whatoever to obtain your favour. You put your elf Sir to abundance of trouble (anwered I) for a thing that is not valuable; but Sir, ince it was you that lamed my hore I beeech you, pitty him o far as to cure him again: I poke this purpoely to interrupt him as he was offering to peak. It eems you think (replied he) that I have the ame power which you have, who can when you pleae cure the wound which you make. Oh Sir (aid I and interrupted him) I beeech you let us talk of that another time, and for the preent, talk of my poor hore who is not able to carry me. This compaion, replied he, might be better imployed another way: but ince you command it o, I will not diobay in the leat: then turning towards Ardilan, he commanded him to end for a Smith; who being brought preently, come friend (aid the King) look at the foot of that hore, there is a nail that tands higher then the ret, pull it out, for quetion lee that is the caue of his lamenes: the Smith looking at the hores foot, found it preently as the King aid; and pulling the nail out, the hore was as well as before: In the mean time Merindor delivered his meage, and the Governes returned with him bringing another hore for me; which the King eeing, farewel (iaid he unto me) all contentment for this day: and etting purs to his hore he rid away the ame way that Merindor came, leaving me alone with Companion, and two Cavaliers that tayed with us.

The King in the mean time, meeting Merindor and his Company, go, go, aid he unto him, you did not oberve that the hore was only tamped with a nail, which being pulled out, the hore will be as ever he was. The King poke this, as he galloped away, to hew that this was all he cared, and o he rode till he overtook the chae.

Conider now, I beeech you, what mortal enemies men are unto us; and what abundance of pains they will take to ruine poor women: but oh Heaven! how hard it is to avoid their treachery, epecially when we fall into the hands of a ubtle peron that has authority? I had ufficient experience of their falhood, and the wounds which their peridy had made in my oul were yet freh: I wanted not any good counel, and yet I mut confes the flatteries of Gondebaut were pleaing unto me, maugre my reolution, and I delighted the ubmiion of o great a King: o as I advie all women to beware of uch enemies, and hun them as Syrens, without lending the leat care unto them.

As oon as I was come up to the company, I acquainted Clotilda with all that Gondebaut had aid unto me, and with all my anwers, and he thought that I had done very prudently in it; but when I told her of his invention to lame my hore purpoly to peak with me, Oh Dorinde (aid he unto me) I am extreamly afraid of ome mis-fortune, and let me tell you my mind freely, that if he do not fall off as oon as you have given him his anwer, you mut marry. Madam, anwered I, I hope to carry my elf o as hall never dipleae you, but as for marriage, I mut heartily beeech you, let it be the lat remedy, for I do o much abominate all men living, that the very name of a husband is odious unto me, and I can never live with one but be mot mierable.

As oon as night came Clotilda acquainted Sigimond with the paage, who eeing the freedom of my dicoure, did plainly perceive that I had no mind to the King: but fearing leat I hould change, and deiring to prevent it; Siter, aid he unto her, I have a great deire to peak with Dorinde, I can dicover her intention better then you; for you mut know, that if he do dilike the addree of the King all his labour will be but lot; but on the other ide, if it pleae her
all our pains will be to no purpoe, and you may incur much danger. I cannot believe her o ubtle (anwered Clotilda) as to hide any thing from me; and beides, if you hould ound her, he will be much more reerued to you then to me. Refer that unto me (anwered he) and after two or three tryals, I hall tell you more of my mind.

The King on the other ide, told Ardilan, all that I had aid unto him, and it was reolved as neceary that Duriana hould be acquainted with the Kings affection unto me; for the crafty Ardilan had o tampered with her, what by gifts and what by promies of marriages, that in all likelyhood he was wholly at his dipoe. But to et a handom gloe upon the matter, they mut eem as if the Kings intention was to marry me, thinking by this gilded bait to draw both Duriana and me to wallow the hook ooner. The next morning Ardilan failed not to peak unto Duriana; after many protetation of affection and promies of marriages, Duriana (aid he unto her) to let you ee how ineperably in am yours, I will trut you with uch a ecret as if ever it be dicovered, I am utterly ruined, and I will o tye my elf unto you by this freedom, as you may ee nothing can eperate me from you. Know therefore Duriana, that the King is o extreamly in love with Dorinde, that he never enjoys any contentment or ret, but when he ees her, and yet carries it out o dicreetly, that I believe none takes any notice of it. I protet (anwered Duriana with much admiration) you amaze me in telling me the King loves my Mitris; for uch perons can hardly, love without dicovery: but I beeech you tell me, how does he take it? I cannot tell (anwered he) he has not given him his anwer; but I am ure he is ill advied if he reject uch an advantagious fortune. Advantagious? (anwered Duriana preently) how do you mean it? Without all doubt highly advantagious (replied he) and o perhaps that when you know all you will wonder more; for mot certainly, if he carry her elf towards him as he ought to do, the King will marry her. How, how? (aid he and clapped her hands together) the King marry Dorinde? and my Mitris become Queen of the Burgundians? doubtles he may (anwered he) if he will but accept of her fortune. Oh Ardilan (aid he, and took him about the neck) doubtles you but mock me. I protet before Heaven I do not mock, anwered he, and you will find all I ay to be mot certainly true, if he be well advied; why hould you think it a thing o trange or impoible? Do you not remember his affection unto Crieide, and how he would have married her? And can you think that tranger of a better family or more meritorious then Dorinde? No Duriana, believe me, the King is reolved upon it, he has told me as much, and I know his mind mot perfectly; but to tell you truly I am afraid your Mitris is not o well advied as he hould be, and in lieu of being Queen of the Burgundians, will make her elf the mot mierable woman in all the Kingdom; for if ever he acquaint Clotilda with it, mot certainly he will give her ill counel, and trive to divert her for many reaons, epecially becaue he cannot brook that a peron o inferiour hould become her Lady and Mitris, nor obey one who obayes her now. Moreover you mut know (but of this my dear Duriana you mut take no notice) you mut know I ay, that Clotilda is none of the Kings welwihers; the quarrel is irreconcilable, for Chilperick her father having uurped the Crown of the Burgundians from Gondebaut his elder brother, he took his meaures o ill, that he uffered himelf to be beieged in Vienna, where afterwards he was taken and lot his life by the Kings jut command; and though this punihment was no more then due, yet the wound marts till in the heart of Clotilda, and I do not think it will ever heal or be forgotten: o as he will mot certainly do the King all the dipleaure he can, and therefore your Mitris mut be ure to peak nothing of it unto her, unles he will ruin the whole buinee. Indeed (aid Duriana) you have imparted a thing which I am very glad to know, for it is of great importance, and I perceive by your expreions you deire I hould interet my elf in the buines, which I promie you to do, as well becaue I hall be glad to give you any contentment, as becaue if the Kings intention be o as you ay, it will be o great and honour and advancement unto my Mitris, as I mut needs ay, he is ill advied if he refue it. Within a few dayes
I hall tell you more, and in the mean time, take pecial care leat the buines be dicovered until it be fully reolved upon; for publication of it may be a great impediment to the progree.

This was the Dicoure betwixt Ardilan and Duriana, who believed all for mot infallible truths: and I have ince found the aying of my Father to be mot true; which was, that if any Prince have a deign to deceive another, he mut firt deceive the Embaadour which is employed betwixt them, becaue he once having an opinion that what is told him is true, wel invent reaons and expreions to imprint belief, better then he could if he had lyed, So Duriana, believing my marriage as a matter mot certain, and foreeeing future grandures upon me and her elf, above al hopes, I knew he watched for an opportunity of talk with me: but thinking it to be only about ome dometique affaires, and never dreaming he could know any thing of this buines, I did not give her that opportunity he longed for. Yet at night, when we were al alone, becaue I did love her for the fidelity and affection to me, and eeing her o deiring to peak unto me; wel Duriana (aid I unto her) what news have you to tel me? She anwered with a mile, news Madam unto you it may be none (aid he) but unto me it was news, and news which gave me abundance of contentment when I heard it: good Duriana (aid I unto her) what dot thou mean? for my part, I do not undertand thee: Madam, replied he, you do but diemble when you ay o: but do you think there is any under the Cope of Heaven, that loves you better then I? I protet Madam, I wil not yeild unto that love which you hear unto your elf, and yet you are pleaed to conceale your elf from Duriana: From Duriana I ay, who to erve you would forake Father, Mother, and al the kindred he has in the world: I could jutly complain againt you if I would, but I dare not in o far as to diapprove of any thing you do. I protet, aid I unto her and miled, I know of no caue you have to complain againt me: I protet, anwered he again, you do not peak as you think: but Madam, why hould you hide a thing from me, which I deire o much to know? but do you think I am ignorant of it? Mitake not your elf, perhaps I knew more particulars of it then your elf. Good Duriana (aid I unto her) what is it that you mean? Wel, aid he, ince you wil have me tel you that which you hould have told me long ince, I wil; upon condition that you conceal nothing hereafter from your mot faithful Duriana. Do you think Madam I do not know, that thanks be to God, the King is in love with you? With me, (anwered I, and laid my hand upon her mouth) be ilent you fool, and ay no more; I ee you talk you know not what: Duriana went back a pace or two; talk I know not what? replied he: Yes, yes, aure your elf I do know what I ay, and know it very wel, and mut tel you again that it is your own fault if you be not Queen of the Burgundians. At this word Queen, I bluht, and holding one hand before my face; I think (aid I unto her) that you are out of your wits, and if any heard us, they would think us both o: I ee, replied he, that none does hear us; but believe me were I in your room, the buines hould be quickly concluded: ay and do what you will, if you refue uch a favour from fortune, he wil never offer you the like again: How Mitris? May be Queen of the Burgundians and wil not? You ay I am mad, but if you refue uch a fortune, I wil ay you are ten times madder. This he continued a long while, and I eeing her affection and manner of expreion, could not chue but mile: which when he aw, he grew half angry, and haking her head, aid unto me; Wel, wel, Mitris, you laugh now at what I ay, but I dare venture a good wager that if you wil not believe me, we hal ee you ere long with tears in your eyes. I could not forbear laughing out right at this, which caued her to be angry in good earnet, and would have gone away, wearing that ince I o mocked her he would never peak to me of any buines again, nor tel me any thing he heard. But I being deirous to hear what he could tel me, and what he knew, I catched hold of her, aying, Why Duriana? wil you not let me laugh when you tel me any thing that pleaeth me? Do you think that to be a Queen is uch bad news, as to make me cry when I hear it? The truth is you tel it in uch a manner as I cannot tel whether you be in earnet or in jet; come, come, tel me
the whole tory of the buines, and how you come to know of it. Madam, replied he, let me then tel you truly, that King Gondebaut will make you Queen of the Burgundians if you will, and that preently unles you your elf hinder it. What, good 'Duriana, aid I unto her, hould I do, to bring this to pae? Only marry the King, anwered he, who loves you above his life. How came you to know thus much? aid I unto her, nay, nay, anwered he preently, you hall not know that ti • l you tell me whether you will have him to your husband or no, for if you refue the offer, why hould you deire to know any more of it? Cant thou doubt Duriana (aid I unto her) that I will not receive the Crown of the Burgundians mot willingly if there be any likelyhood of getting it? Surely I were out of my wits if I did; but the fault is not in my will but the Kings, who perhaps is only in jet. The King, anwered he is not in jet; but if you will behave your elf as you ought to do, I lay my life you will ee it come preently to pae.

This Wench poke with uch confidence, as I mut needs confee I began to believe that he knew more then I did; and preently after, ambition did o wel me, that forgetting the commands of the wife Clotilda and my promie to her, I reolved to follow the Councel of Duriana if I aw any probability in it; and therefore, after I had a while thought upon it, fixing my eye upon the ground I made her this anwer; Be ure Duriana that you peak nothing but the very clear truth; and if I do find any probability in what thou ayet, I promie to do whatoever thou wilt have me; I know thou lovet me, and therefore art deirous of my welfare and advancement. Be confidently aured Madam, (aid he unto me) that I do love you, and that I deire your welfare and advancement more then you can do your elf: I have received my education from you, and God willing Madam, I wil end my life in your ervice, and therefore you may well believe me mot deirous of your happines and advancement. Now Madam, ince I ee you inclinable to do as you ought, be pleaed to know that the King does o dote of you, that if you wil, he will marry you; and Ardilan whom you know very wel, told me as much five or ix dayes ince, and becaue I would not at the firt credit what he aid, he confirmed it with many oaths. But Duriana (anwered I, and ighed) doet thou not know that all men are fale and deceitful? What hould invite the King to this? Madam, (anwered he preently) al thoe who hath hitherto courted you, they did it for their advantage, becaue you had been a fortune to them, if you had married them; but the Kings courthip proceeds from nothing but the Love which he bears unto you, for he cannot pretend unto any advantage. Do you not remember how he would have married Cryeide, and are not you in al repects as good as he? Your beauty will not yeild to hers; your decent is before her, and your alliance alo, you are no tranger as he was; you are no captive, nor thanks be to God was ever the booty and plunder of Souldiers: and therefore Madam, ince the King took o much pains to marty Cryeide, who was every way your inferior? Why hould not he be as earnet, nay more, to marry Dorinde, who every way excels Cryeide? But, aid I, uppoe al this to be o; what would Ardilan have me do? In the firt place, anwered he immediately, he would have you love the King; next that you have a great care to peak of it unto none, epecially unto the Princes Clotilda: For Madam, you mut know that this Princes bears ill wil unto the King, becaue Chilperick her Father, who uurped the Crown, was by him put to death. Clotilda knows it, and being in his hands, dares not peak agains it, leat he hould be mued up amongt the Vetals as her Siter was; but aure your elf that if he were at liberty, he would hew the effects of her ill wil, though now he wil not hew teeth, til he be able to bite: therefore Madam, you mut conceale it from her above all others, becaue you being her ervant he wil not endure to ee you raied unto uch height as that he mut be your vaal and inferior.

Duriana did know how to repreent thee coniderations o wel, that he found a dipoition in me to hearken unto her: o as before we parted I promied to do as he would have me provided, he would have a care we hould not be deceived. Oh how dangerous it is, to place perons that are intereted, about
young women? From that time I forgot all the wie intructions of Clotilda, and all the oaths which I wore unto her; I reolved to peak unto her no more, or at leat, would tay till I aw whether the King was in earnet or jet. Duriana tranported with joy, eeing me o reolved he took my hand; now Madam (aid he) I kis this hand not as Dorindos, but the Queen of the Burgundians, for o I hold you to be already.

Thus we parted, and the next morning letting Ardilan know that he deired to peak with him, he acquainted him with all that had paed betwixt us, at which he eemed to be o well contented, that this foolih woman was more gulled by him then he was before.

The young Prince Sigimond by the advice of the prudent Avitus, had ecretly procured one of Gondebauts Bed-chamber to acquaint him with all the privacies of that King: and this not out of any ill deign, but only to prevent the fury of the Kings paionate humours when he was angry with any one, as he aw caue, or ele, to order himelf the better in matters of tate, to the contentment of Gondebaut.

Now o it fortuned, that as ubtle as Ardilan was, and careful leat any hould hear when he poke to the King of this buinee; yet o it was, that this man heard all the tory of it; and as oon as any began to be ecret with the King, he ued to creep o behind the hangings, that he could hear any thing that was aid.

This time therefore, having oberved that Ardilan was of late very cloe with the King, as oon as he aw him coming he got behind the hangings, making no quetion but the King being alone, there would be ome conference betwixt them and he was not mitaken: for as oon as Ardilan came into the room, and eeing none with the King, he went unto him; at firt he began to peak in a low whiper; but afterwards eeing the cot clear, he raied his voice and named Duriana and Dorinde, which made the man to upect ome matter of Love: afterwards as they walked up and down he heard as much as he could deire; which preently he imparted into the young Prince, which received this advertiement with much contentment: not but that it vexed him to the oul, the King hould continue his courthip, he himelf having the ame deign; but he was glad to know it, that he might ue the bet remedy he could againt it: he gave the man therefore many thanks, and after a preent of gratification, deired him to continue his intelligence with great promies of further reward when occaions preented themelves.

The next evening, when we were all in Clotildas chamber, and my Companions, very earnet at play, by fortune I was alone at the farther end of the chamber, and he came unto me; and eeing that I took no notice of him, as being wholly taken up with my own thoughts, he waved his hand two or three times before my eyes, ere I did ee him, o much was my mind ditracted another way. I perceive Dorinde (aid he unto me) that you entertain your thoughts in very erious earnet: at this voice I recollected my elf, and rubbing my eyes as if I were newly waked out of a ound leep, I would gladly have excued my fault. Nay, fair one (aid he unto me) you need not be ahamed of your contemplation, for I am mot confident it is very good, and you could not entertain your elf better then with it. Sir, (aid I unto him) I have more manners then to contradict you in any thing; but I beeech you give me leave to ay, that your language proceeds either from your exces of courteie, or from flattery. Could you but ee your elf, fairet, with my eyes (aid he unto me) you would not ay o; I aure my elf every one will be of my opinion; and if you pleae to give me leave, I dare venture a wager, that I can tell what you were thinking upon when I came unto you. Sir, anwered I, it will be very hard for you to do it, ince I can hardly tell my elf, and I dare accept of your wager without any fear of loing. You need not fear any loe by me (anwered he) but what you pleae; for I am o much yours, that none can be more, and if you would have any thing of me, though it be my life, ask, and it hall not be denied. Doubtlee Sir, aid I and miled) you are this night dipoed to jear me; but the power is yours, and I take all that comes from you with reverence and repect, as is my duty. This
Language (replied he) were fitter betowed upon another then me; I mean upon him whom you were thinking upon when I came towards you. I know not Sir what you mean, replied I, nor him whom you ay I was thinking upon; for I had no other thought but upon leep: You do diemble fair one, aid he, for you were thinking upon the Dicoure the King had with you, when he lamed your hore. At this I began to bluh, and was extreamly urpried: Nay, nay, fairet (aid he) never bluh at what I ay, for when you know with how much affection I adore you, you will not be orry that I am acquainted with the buines whereof I peak: I offer unto you my elf and ervice mot freely; and to let you ee the truth of my words, I know the Kings deign, and advertie you, that if you do not look very unto your elf, he will deceive you. Ardilan and his accee unto Duriana is dicovered in the Court, and every one thinks it tends to your diadvantage; and be aured that this advertiement which I give unto you is the bet you can receive from any.

He added unto this other dicoure, which did plainly evidence unto me that he knew all the Kings deign, and the pandarime of Ardilan; and becaue, I thought that to deny it abolutely, would but more confirm him in his belief, alo becaue I thought his advertiement not without ome colour of reaon, I anwered him thus; You tell me of a thing Sir, which if concealing it from you could hide it from my elf, I would ooner dye then confee it to you; but ince I cannot, to my misfortune make my elfignorant of it, I do confes that the King has made uch an overture unto me, and I do know that Ardilan has held more communication with Duriana, then I would have her; but Sir, what remedy is there againt all this, ince it is the King, unlee I hould get out of his Dominions o far that none who knows me hall ever hear the ound of my name, Do not think Sir, but I know, that the King is only pleaed to make himelf a little port by mocking me; but that which mot vexeth me, is, that every one will be apt to cenure as they pleae; and ince Sir your are pleaed to peak o much upon this ubject, and ince the Title of Cavalier, beide that of a great Prince, does oblige you to ait afflicted and ditreed Ladies, I beeech you tell me, what you think to be my bet coure. Believe it, fairet, anwered he, that the affection which I have unto you will not permit me to refue you the bet counel and aitance that I can give or you deire; I am afraid that too much notice will be taken of our being o long in dicoure together; all I can ay at this time, is, reject the Kings Love, for believe me it will ruine you and your honour, and above all, take heed of Ardilan.

This was the firt Dicoure he had with me, and becaue he oberved Clotilda cat an eye two or three times upon us, he went preently towards her to acquaint her with what had paed betwixt us: but he never told her what expreions he had ued of his good will unto me; only told her what he had aid unto me concerning the King, and Ardilan. And ee, how ubtil he was, to make her more zealous in diverting me from the King; he eemed unto her as if I was not o avere unto this buines as I eemed unto her; and that Ardilan was crafty and ubtil, that if good heed was not taken he would inenibly prevail with me. Clotilda who was very unwilling I hould be deceived, did promie him to have uch a vigilant eye over me, that neither he nor I hould be deceived; and he alo was very aitant in it, o as when to conjoyn the matter was not o difficult, to divert the King, and find out the ubtilties of the man.

Oh Heaven! how cruel are our ditinies, in being contrained to live amongt our enemies? For what more Tyger enemies can we have then men, ince they never ret till they ruine us? Were it not for this pittyles nature which is in them all, why hould not the King at his age let me live at ret in the ervice of that prudent Princes? Why hould Ardilan take uch abundance of paines and care to corrupt Duriana? But why hould the young Sigimond leave off o many other good imployments, to delude both Clotilda and me? When I think eriouly upon thee things, I mut needs confes the aying true, that all the univere is maintained by contrarieties: and our contrary, is man; or to ay better, that the Gods not willing we hould enjoy any perfect contentment upon earth, produced
men only to torment us. And ee I beeech you, how crafty this young Prince was; ince this day he never talked to me of any thing but expreions of his affection to me; yet told Clotilda that he poke againt Gondebaut and Ardilan. And they laboured the buines o betwixt them, that I began to enter into doubt of the Kings promies, and approve of thoe reaons which Sigimond alledged: but my greatet wonder was, the long delay of the King ince my lat anwer: and becaue I had till then concealed from the Princes, the lat dicoure which Ardilan had with Duriana, I reolved to acquaint her with it, as well becaue I feared leat the Prince hould tell her, and o he be angry with me, as becaue being confident, that the Princes loving me as he eemed to to, he would be glad of my future grandure of it came to pas, or ele would help me to undeceive my elf. One night therefore when he was in bed, and according to her cutom, called me, I aid unto her, not without a bluh; This candle, Madam, which I hold in my hand (for I alwayes ued to hold one by her as I kneeled) will let you ee that I am ahamed of what I hall ay unto you; but ince it is neceary you hould know it, my duty bids me not conceale it. Be pleaed therefore to know, Madam, that Duriana brought me a very pleaant news this morning, but truly, Madam, I cannot well tell whether I hould aume o much boldnes as to tell you: Dorinde, aid he, out with it freely and boldly, and be aured that though it make me angry with him; yet it hall make me pleaed with you: what? is it ome Letter? Oh Madam, anwered I, it is ome thing ele then a Letter: what then? (aid he) ome preent? Yes a preent, anwered I, and the greatet that could be ent; but it is only in words: But tell me (aid he) what meage did Duriana bring you from him?
