I beeech you Madam (aid I, and miled) firt laugh before I tell you, for I aure you it will make you laugh when you hear it: be pleaed to know then, that Duriana came to me in pot hat when I was in bed, to tell me that the King would marry me. How? (replied Clotilda) the King marry you? Ardilan, replied I wore it unto Duriana with a thouand oaths, and gave her in charge to tell me as much. Oh Sweet-heart (replied the Princee prenently) take heed of believing it; it is mear poyon under a gilded Pill, and will ruine you; bid Duriana return this anwer, that if the Kings intention be honourable and advantagious to you, let him acquaint me with it, and mot certainly I hall never contradict him; which if he do not do, then believe it, that he would deceive you. For why hould the King marry in ecret? Or if he would, how can he think it will be concealed? No, no, Dorinde, aure your elf, it is not the Kings deign, but only Ardilans, who cares not how he does engage his Mater, o he can but obtain his deires; and therefore my advice is, that if you do not preently ee thee words made good, to forbid Duriana trictly from having any farther conference with Ardilan, o as he may have no farther hopes of deceiving you: I wonder Duriana hould have o little dicretion as to bring you any uch meages: aure your elf this ubtle fellow has uborned her, either by gifts or ome trick or other; and if o, I advice you to be rid of her aoon as poibly you can, for there is no widom in keeping perons of that temper about one. Madam, replied I, I hall be alwayes mot obervant of all your commands: and as for Duriana, I do wonder at her as much as you, and hall keep uch an obervant eye over all her actions, as I hall dicover the truth.

Some dayes paed before I could find a heart to break off quite with the King: for hopes of grandure had o dazled my eyes as caued me to delay it. In the time the young Sigimond, who was advertied of all paages, eeming to divert me from the Kings Love, lot no occaion to expree his own, but o cautiouly that Clotilda did not perceive it, but on the contrary would ooner have believed any thing ele: but when he was in a place where none could hear his dicoure, he did nothing ele: but expres his affection: and I mut needs confes, that if I were to chue, the ons Love would have made me reject the Fathers; and therefore it was, that I never acquainted Clotilda with it as I ought, though I knew it to be my duty: for I was afraid to incene both the Father and the Son againt me at one time. One day when we were in the Athenian Gardens, for winter was then pat, and Trees began to put on the livery of the
Spring, Sigimond, who of late was continually amongt us, took me under the arm, and having eperated me a little from the ret of the Company, my dearet fair one (aid he unto me) I aure my elf that you cannot chue but ee the extream affection which I have unto you; and ince it is o, it eems omthing trange that no ymptomes of any pitty hould appear unto you. Sir, (aid I unto him) though your language he only to make your elf merry in jeting with me, yet I think my elf much obliged unto you for it; and be what it will, I take it as coming from Prince Sigimond, in uch a reverential manner as I ought to do. Did I think (aid he) that your heart conented unto your tongue, I hould extreamly complain againt you: but I know uch anwers are ordinary in the mouths of uch fair ones as you are, and therefore, I conjure you by what you eteem mot dear, to tell me whether you do not know that the Prince Sigimond is really in love with you. Your conjuration Sir, (aid I unto him) has o much prevalency in it as to draw any truth, be it never o ecret, from my oul. Be pleaed therefore to know Sir, that it is true, I think you wih me very well, but it is no more then you own unto any that honours you, as I do. Fair one replied he preently, you think a right; for there is nothing under the Sun more certain then my affection unto you; and I will ooner hate my elf then not love you in the highet degree. Thee thoughts Sir (aid I unto him) cannot avail you any thing at all, and may be very prejudicial unto me. Thee thoughts, replied he, are they which can give me the greatet contentment that I can hope for in this world, and cannot be any way prejudicial unto you; for take this as a mot infallible maxime, that nothing which brings you any dipleaure, can be pleaing unto me. I do know very well Sir, aid I unto him, that Prince Sigimond is courteie in the very abtract, and a ervant unto all Ladies in general. Truth is, replied he, I do infinitely honour all your exe: but, my fairet, it is for your ake. Good Sir, (aid I and interrupted him) conider this, that all the pains you take in your fluent Language, (admit your words to be true) is but o much labour lot; and an honour unto me, o dearly bought, as if ever it be known, will undo me: for what can you hope for Sir, from me? And if this Dicoure hould ever come to be known, it would turn to my diadvantage. Dorinde (anwered he with a more erious look) I will not ay unto you as the King does, that I will marry you, for I will never deceive you; but I will ay, and wear by all that is Sacred, that I wih with all my oul I might marry you. And I cannot think that though this hould come to be known unto the world, any would blame you for it, but rather honour and eteem you the more, and cenure it by way of advantage unto you. As for the advantage or utility which I can hope for, know this my fairet, that I do eteem you o much, that I deire no other advantage but the contentment of loving you: and if the affection be but pleaing and accepted I may ay that my greatet deire is accomplihed. I was ready to anwer him when one of my Companions came to tell me, that Clotilda would peak with me, and • our conference broke off; for which I was not orry, becaue I found that the affection and ubmiion of this young Prince, began to work upon me. But oh, how careful ought all of our age be of uch encounters? I had been already deceived by three or four mooth tongued lovers. I was not yet unfettered from thoe fallacies which the Father had laid to entrap me, and yet I know not how, I began by little and little to hearken unto the candid flatteries of the Son, and which was wort of all, I was o taken with them that I could not guard my elf from them.

Ever ince this day, that Prince did o continue his courthip, that Clotilda took notice of it; but he, crafty and wary as oon as ever he aw that, he o retired himelf, and kept uch ditance of indifferency towards me, as that opinion quickly vanihed: and beides, I did contribute my aitance towards it, and did advertie him when at any time he dicovered himelf too freely; conjuring him to keep it cloe, and to carry himelf dicretly and warily: Thee advertiements which I gave unto him, were certain aurances of the good will which I had unto him; which begot uch a confidence in him, that he began to write unto me, & preently after to end me preents under the notion of the good will he bore unto all that
waited upon Clotilda, unto whom he ent the like preents, purpoly to collour his preent unto me: He would alo play with me very often for wagers, and loe purpoely; and though his preents were never without the Princees leave, yet he did alwayes accompany them with ome ecret Letter, or copy of Veres: and I received many Letters and Papers of Veres from him, according to the ubject of the preents on the accidents which hapned; but with o much dicretion, that neither the Princes nor Gondebaut perceived them. And becaue I knew what intimacy there was betwixt Ardilan and Duriana, I kept the matter all cloe from her as from any other. For I confes that the young Prince and the weet dipoition which I found in him, had uch an influence upon me, that I fell of by degrees from Gondebaut: for beides the affection of Sigimond, Clotilda was continually buzzing in my ears the wavering humour of the King, and how reaons of tate would quite blat al thoe hopes which he had given me. I was in a long dipute with my elf; but at lat ome good genius opened my eyes, and let me ee how all that Ardilan aid unto me was only tricks and falities. I reolved therefore by the advice of Clotilda to put him to the tryal, to the end I might no longer be deluded: o one night when Duriana by the intigation of the ubtle Ardilan was harping upon the old tring, and preing me according to her cutom, to hearken unto the Kings motion. Duriana (aid I unto her) do you think. Ardilan is honet, and peaks truth? Ah Madam, anwered he, I dare wear he had rather dye a hundred deaths then tell one lye; I believe (aid I unto her) you are mitaken in him, and am confident he does but mock both you and me; and to hew you that I have good intelligence, did he not promie to marry you? Indeed he did, anwered he, but Madam, alwayes with a condition of your leave. Well (aid I) but if he be not a deluder, why does he not make good his promie? Madam, aid he, I never urged him unto it, but I believe, that as oon as I hall deire uch a thing, he will be as forward to embrace uch a motion as my elf. Well Duriana (replied I) by little things we do often come to the knowledge of the greater; if Ardilan hould prove fale in his promie to you, is it not probable he is likewie fale in all his negotiations concerning me? Mot undoubtedly true, anwered he. Then, replied I, to try whether all he has poken from the King be true, I would have you pree him to marry you; and tell him, by way of excue, that all your fellow ervants and Clotilda alo dilikes of the familiarity betwixt you, and therefore it is neceary that he either keep his promie in marrying you, or ele withdraw himelf abolutely from you; I am mot confident, that this propoition will tartle him, and make him quickly very cold in the matter. I cannot imagine (aid Duriana) that uch a man as he hould fail in his promie; that which mot grieves me, is, that I mut by this marriage loe your ervice, which is the greatet grief that can come unto me. As he uttered thee words, tears began to trickle from her eyes: and I could not chue but mile at her implicity; nay, nay, aid I, never cry for the matter, I warrant you, your marriage with Ardilan will never part us.

Now ee the conequence; Duriana poke to Ardilan the next time he aw him, as I had commanded her: and though he was as ubtle a fellow as any was about the Court, yet was he o damped at her peech, that he was not able to anwer one word; at lat, he recollected himelf, and asked her, who gave her that counel? Thoe that gave it me (anwered he) will never deceive me, and is orry to hear what reports are raied concerning our familiarity: do not think that you are exempt from cenure more then I, for they ay, you intend to deceive me which I cannot believe; but reports go that you make addree unto me, only to make me an intrument of delivering the Kings meage unto Dorinde. Oh Heavens, anwered the cunning man, certainly you have devulged the Kings ecrets unto ome or other, and by this means have for ever ruined me in the opinion of my Mater: Do not think me o indicreet (anwered Duriana) but it is true, I could not tel Dorinde thoe things which you deired me, but I mut alo tell her my Author: And is it Dorinde (replied he) who gave you counel to peak thus unto me? Suppoe it he (aid Duriana) or whoever ele, it was good; for I know that mot of my fellow ervants do grumble extreamly at our ecret familiarity.
The reaon of that is, replied he, becaue they are ignorant of our intention: Well, well, anwered he, however they have an ill opinion of me, and if you have any mind to marry me do it quickly; for to tell you truly, Clotilda is offended at me, and does not like I hould live in that manner: He tood ilent a long while, and fixed his eyes upon the ground, which offended Duriana extreamly, and moved her to ay, what is the reaon Ardilan you do not anwer me? Is the news o bad you cannot endure to hear it; I thought that when I made this motion you would have entertained it with open arms, and given Heaven thanks for it; but on the contrary, you are as mute as if you were tongue tyed. Duriana (anwered Ardilan) the ilence which you oberve in me, and which makes you upect my good will towards you, does not proceed from that caue which you imagine, but from abundance of difficulty which I do foreee in the buines, and which you your elf will confee. When I acquainted the King with my deires of marrying you, he told me, that as oon as I was once married, I would then no longer care for the love which he bore unto Dorinde; and when I vowed the contrary unto him, no, no, replied he, I know better then you do how the enjoyment of the party loved, will take up the mind of a man: and if it hould do the like by you, then I am no better then dead; for unto whom then can I peak concerning this buinee? and therefore I do poitively command you, as you value my Love, not to think upon any marriage, until mine be pat, But Duriana (aid he and took her hand) be aured that ere it be long I will give you your deired atisfaction. Duriana, melling his falhood, and not being able to diemble her dipleaure; if it be o (aid he) that the King does really intend to marry Dorinde, why does he not do it? Where is the tick? Oh Duriana (anwered he) the affaires of Kings are not o oon dipatched, as the affaires of a private peron: A great Prince has coniderations of his etate and good of his people, which we cannot dive into. Did you but know what affection the King has unto Dorinde, you would wonder at it, as I have done many a time; but he cannot nor ought not lay aide all other coniderations, and ruh hatily upon marriage: but on the contrary he is Wie and Prudent, and can lay aide his paion, until he has put every thing in order, and o as he may enjoy his contentments without any danger or inconveniency: believe it, that when the time is fit, he will not need any Solicitor, nor any to put him in mind of Dorinde, for his love unto her, is enough to bring her into his memory. Then Duriana finding that the advice which I gave her was but too true. Well Ardilan (aid he unto him) I am o little vered in the buines of State, that I will leave it unto thoe who know how to manage it; but ince you cannot marry me until the King be married; and ince his marriage cannot be accomplihed until buines of State gives him leave, I think it fit that you ee me no more, nor peak unto me concerning Dorinde until the Widome of the King hath et all his State affairs in order, o as he may have leaure to make good his word, and give you leave to make good yours. Upon this not taying for his anwer, he came into my Chamber in a pelting chae againt Ardilan, and againt the King, and told me her whole Dicoure in uch a paionate manner, that I could not chue but laugh at her anger. But ee how fortune was bent to diturb my tranquility; and to hower mieries upon me: Duriana as he talked with Ardilan, and pulled her handkerchief out of her pocket; he pulled out alo the paper of Veres which Sigimond ent unto me; and which he unknown to me had taken out of my pocket, as he looked for my handkerchief to be wahed. This paper being but little, and he half out of her wits, he dropt it on the ground as he came away from him. The crafty fellow, did preently take it up, and went away with it as fat as he could to his lodging: there uneen by any, he unfolded the paper, and read it over everal times, but could not judge who write it, nor to whom it was directed; yet he had a trong opinion that it was intended either unto her or unto me; and to which of thee two oever it was, it would erve him for a good excue to the King concerning his negotiation. To loe no time therefore, he went as fat as he could to Gondebaut, from whom he did not conceal a illable of his conference with Duriana: after a long dicoure together, and when the Kings hopes were
all blated, Ardilan continued thus; I cannot imagine Sir what divel it is, that thus thwarts your deires: I cannot think it to be Clotilda, for I hold her to be more dicreet and better advied then to commit uch a fault: and beides her obligations unto you are o great; as it were the height of ingratitude if he offer to dipleae you in any thing; but yet it is very trange yonder fool Duriana as he pulled out her handkerchief did drope this paper, which uneen to her I took up, and by it, I find that there is ome lurking Lover or other that courts either her or Dorinde: I know not the hand, but you may ee Sir whether you can pick any more out of it then I can. Upon this the King took it, and no ooner cat his eye upon it but he knew it to be the hand of the Prince Sigimond: Oh Ardilan (aid he in a great fury) wonder no more from whence the alteration in Dorinde proceeds; It is Sigimond that loves her, and doubtlee he loves him alo: heer's his hand, and from hence Durianas dicoure was grounded. Upon this laying the paper down upon the Table, and folding his arms together he began to walk a great pace up and down the Chamber, and was a long quarter of an hour before he uttered one word. At lat in a great rage, I will make them both repent it (aid he) and if I do not punih them according to their deerts, let me no longer be taken for King Gondebaut. And to begin, go Ardilan (aid he) go immediately unto Clotilda, and tell her from me that I undertand Dorindes behaviour is o candalous and hameful, as I would have her end her away this very night unto Arcingentorix her father, and let her undertand the reaon why I would not have her entertain her any longer: From thence go unto Sigimond, and command him from me to retire himelf into Gallogurio; unto which place I confine him until he further hear my pleaure: bid him begone in the morning before day, and let none een him; and that if he fail in my commands, I will put him into a place where he hall lear his duty. Afterwards, beginning to walk again, tamping his foot againt the floor, and pulling his hat over his eyes, he ued all the actions of a ditracted peron. Ardilan eeing him in this condition, he was the mot perplexed man in the world: for he foreaw, that to carry thee meages unto Sigimond and Clotilda, would be his ruine: and on the other ide, not to do the Kings commands was wore, and more certain ruine; o as he knew not which way to turn himelf, and repented heartly that ever he hewed this paper unto the King.

There was none in the chamber, but the King and Ardilan; but in the Wardrob which was cloe by, it fortuned that Sigimonds intelligencer was there, who hearing the name of Sigimond, began to hearken very attentively unto what the King aid; and heard the harh command which the King impoed upon Ardilan; of which he thought to acquaint Sigimond immediately; and in order to that he went down a back pair of tairs and ran as fat as he could to the young Prince, who he found in his Cloet.

Sir, aid he unto him, I made all the hat I could, to advertie you of a thing which your prudence mut prevent, otherwie, I fear a great torm will fall upon us. I undertand that the King is extreamly in Love with Dorinde, and Ardilan is his Agent in the buines, who brought him a paper of Veres which you had writ unto Dorinde: and becaue Duriana, Dorindes Chamber-maid, gave Ardilan ome anwer contrary to her cutom, the King conceives the reaon of it to be from Dorindes loving you: you know Sir, that no paion is more violent then jealouie in Love; and the King is entered into uch a paionate anger againt you and againt her, as he has commanded Ardilan, to did Clotilda from him, to end away Dorinde immediately unto Arcingentorix her Father, and to tell her withal that her behaviour is o candalous, that he would not have uch a one to keep her company; Is it poible (aid the young Prince) that the King hould be o far tranported with paion, as to commit o great injutice againt that wie Woman? Nay Sir, replied the man, this is not all, his anger does reflect alo upon you: Againt me? (aid the Prince) yes Sir, aid the man, againt you, and I cannot tell whether or no I dare acquaint you; Speak freely, replied the Prince, and fear not that any thing can anger me more, then the digrace which is prepared for Dorinde. Then Sir, continued the man, he has commanded Ardilan
to come unto you, and bid you from him, depart to morrow before day and confine your elf unto Gallo-Liguria, till you receive his farther commands; adding uch menace unto his meage, as I cannot well tell whether or no he be in his right enes.

Friend (aid the Prince) I hope the Kings anger will wear away with time, and haply he means not o ill as he ays; however, I thank you heartily for the pains you have in my behalf, I deire you to continue it, and believe in that I hall die very young if you die unrewarded: Go therefore, and hear what further news, and advertie me with all peed, that I may prepare as good remedies as I can.

Thus they parted; and Sigimond came to me in uch a rage againt Gondebaut, that had not I retrained him, I think he had gone beyond the repects of a on due to a Father; and I mut needs confes, that this action of this young Prince, did infinitely pleae me. Dorinde (aid he unto me, after he had told me all he heard) I ee that my affection unto you procures you all this miery, and my misfortune is the caue of yours: But let me tell you my opinion, which is. That I do not think the Kings anger proceeds only from the love he ee. I bear unto you, but much more from the good will he fears you bear unto me; and were I as happy as that his fears were true, I would give you the ame counel that I will take my elf. You may be aured, Sir, aid I unto him, that your good will has obliged me to honour you, as I ought to do. Honour (anwered he) I do look for from thoe who mut hereafter be my ubjects; but from Dorinde, I require love. If that word, replied I, were handome in the mouth of a woman, I think (to content you) I hould peak it. Dorinde, replied he preently, be aured that my affection unto you is uch, as I had rather die, then entertain any thoughts which are dihonourable to you; and ince you are pleaed to give me this tetimony of your good will, I am fully contented and hall from this hour, think my elf the happiet man that lives: and I am reolved, my Fairet, in depite of the King, never to call him Father; and will in pite of him, love you double to what I did before: and dearet Dorinde, if you do love me, put you on the ame reolution. Sir, anwered I, I do protet to love you in pite of all the world, as much as my honour will give me leave. Then did I ee in this young Prince uch a udden and great alteration, as aured me of the contentment which my words did give unto him; but the expreions which he ued at the ame time, did much more aure me. For my part (aid he unto me, and took my hand) I do promie and vow unto you, my dearet Dorinde, by all that is mot acred and holy, that I will endeavour to the very utmot of my power, never to have any other wife but you: and were it in my free dipoe, I would this very hour receive you as my wife, but ince my will does depend upon another, I cannot, unles I hould abue you, ay any more; only I beeech you (continued he, and put a Ring upon my finger) to take and keep this Ring as a pledge of what I now do promie. and more, that I will never marry, unles your bad Fortune contrain you to marry before me. Sir, aid I unto him, and bluhed for hame, though I never receive any other contentment then this honour of your love, yet I hall eteem my elf, as long as I live, the happiet woman that ever was; and in tetimony of this, I take this Ring, with the ame protetations and vows that you have made. But Sir (continued I) notice will be taken of our actions, and therefore (I beeech you) let us break off dicoure. Now, my Fairet (aid he unto me) I have o much interet in you, as I mut needs be careful of any thing that concerns you, and therefore I cannot brook that the fury of the Kings paion hould offer this injury unto you: if you think it expedient, I will tell him as much to his face, and will not tartle at all his anger; for it is no uch capital crime to love a fair Lady: I do believe that at the firt he will be extreamly angry at it, but he will cool again at lat, and become himelf; then he cannot chue but confes, that the equality of our ages pleads more reaon to love each other, then he has to think, that the flowers in your fair face will ever grow in the winter of his age. Oh Sir, aid I unto him, take heed of the fury of a King. Dearet (anwered he) we will ue all the prudence that we can; but the very truth is, I value not any miery that can full out,
o Dorinde be not compried in it. Upon this, without tay for any anwer, he went away to enquire what news of the King, who in the mean time was in cloe counel with that arch Traytor Ardilan: for as oon as ever Sigimonds intelligencer was gone, the King turning about, and eeing Ardilan till there? How now? aid he unto him, are not you gone yet whither I commanded you? Sir, anwered be, I tay to know whether you will pleae to command me any thing ele: No, no, replied he, but go immediately and execute my Will. Ardilan then drawing neerer him, But Sir, aid he unto him, If the Prince hould ask me the reaon why you end him this command, what hall I ay? Tell him (replied Gondebaut, It is for his di-repect of me in the buines concerning Dorinde; and to top his mouth if he offer to deny it, take that paper that lies upon the Table, hew it him. Sir, aid Ardilan, and took the paper, I know what anwer he will make, and if you pleae I will tell you. What anwer can he make (aid the King) but only confes his fault, or tell a lye? No Sir, replied Ardilan. not lye neither; for he will ay that he never knew of your love to Dorinde; if he had, that he would never have offered it: And truly Sir, it is impoible he hould: for the matter has been carried o cloe, that I believe none in the world knows it, but only You, Dorinde, Dariana, and I: and ince it is o, me-thinks his crime not o great, as at the firt you thought it. What then (aid the King) would you have me to do? Upon this he began to walk again, but a little more calmly then at the firt. Ardilan eeing the Kings anger begin to cool; Sir (aid he unto him and miled) I could never have believed that great Kings could ever have loved o perfectly as I ee you do; I am confident you are not a little enible of it: for I ee a little blow makes a great wound in you, ele you would never let a poor illy paper of veres, which perhaps were writ without deigne, only to pas away the time, to put you into uch a trange diorder: Pardon me Sir, if I ay you were a little too haty. Well, well (aid the King) but Ardilan, you have no reaon to blame me for a fault which you are guilty of your elf; for was it not you that told me firt, Sigimond loved Dorinde, and that this was the only reaon of her rejecting me? True Sir (aid Ardilan) I did ay o, but it was only out of opinion; and I mut confes, had I thought it would have thus offended you, I hould not have acquainted you with it, till I was better informed: for Sir, ee into what a trange confuion you are ready to bring every thing, for to ruine all your hopes in the main buines: Secondly to blat the honour of Dorinde, and all her Family. Thirdly, To candal the houe of the Princes Clotilda? And latly, To ruine your own Son. But now, I hope your goodnes and prudence, which hath furmounted the fury of this violent paion, will denote this day to be the happiet of all your Raigne; for on it you have obtained the greatet victory that ever youd id in all your life; for you have overcome your elf. Ardilan continued on his flatteries, and as we undertood by Sigimonds Intelligencer, at lat concluded thus: Now Sir, this is my opinion upon the whole matter, If you hould advertie the Prince of his affection unto Dorinde, and deire him for your ake to retire himelf from that affection, and keep the matter ecret; if he after this overture hould till continue, then had you jut caue to complain againt him for his mall repect of you: But however you have no caue, nor colour of a caue to blame Dorinde, before you know whether he loves him or no: for Lovers do often convey uch papers unto their Mitries, and they not know from whence they came: I hould advie therefore, that Clotilda forbid her from you, from having any more talk with him, or receiving any more preents from him; after this, they are both without excue if they continue.

This was the advice of Ardilan, who added till more expreions by way of explanation: and the King who had a great confidence in him, after ome conideration, did approve of it; and thereupon commanded him to go preently and put what he had propoed in execution; which he did with more alacrity then he hould the firt commands. He went therefore firt to the Princes, unto whom he made known the opinion which the King had of Sigimonds addres unto Dorinde; and to hew her upon what grounds it was, he hewed her thoe veres which Dariana lot; at which the Princes was much amazed: yet like a wie and
prudent Princes, he anwered, That perhaps thoe veres were compoed without any deigne, but however he would obey the Kings commands.

As fortune was, Sigimond was not then in the Town, being gone after dinner to hunt towards the Forret of Eri • u; and at his return, it was always his cutom to alight from his hore at Clotildas houe. And becaue it was very late before he did return, Ardilan could not peak with him that night: In the mean time, Clotilda who loved the Prince no les then he did her, as oon as Supper was done, he took him aide, and acquainted him with the Kings meage by Ardilan: Then, Brother (aid he and miled) I hould be angry with yuu, if I thought you had thus deceived me. Siter (anwered he very faintly) you have very much obliged me in this; but be pleaed to let me anwer unto this in the preence of Dorinde her elf. Clotilda who had an opinion that he would clear all doubts, did preently call me; and drawing us as far off as he could from the ret that were in the chamber, The Prince began thus, in as low a voice as he could, left any hould hear.

Siter (aid he) I had no mind to anwer unto your quetion, but in the preence of her who is mot intereed in it, to the end the anwer which I hall make may be ooner credited, and he exempted from all upition of diimulation. You are let undertand, that the King knows I love Dorinde, and that he entertains my affection, and thereupon will have you to forbid this fair one, not only from entertaining my love, but alo that I mut never peak unto her; and that the ground of all this is, ome Veres which I writ, and which Dariana lot: I think this is all the meage which the King did end unto you, upon which you have grounded your quetion, to wit, whether it be true that we do love each other or no? Unto this I can return no other anwer but this, and bid you look well upon Dorinde, then tell me whether it be poible to look upon her, and not love her. If this be a fault, Siter, it is yours, who has added unto her Beauty many excellencies and per • ections by your good education and convere: If it be a fault to love one of uch uperlative endowments then, You and Nature mut plead my excue. But I mut ay further yet, That the honour and repect which I owe unto you, hall never receive the leat blemih by this affection; Proteting by Hercules, and all that have power to punih perjury, that I had rather die, then have any attempts upon her that may in the leat degree tain her honour This Siter, in anwer to your Quetion. And now as to the Kings meage, who thinks by thee Forbiddings to divert me from this affection: I do declare unto, and I beeech you tell him as much when next you peak with him, That all the whole Univere together, is not able to hinder me from loving Dorinde; That he mut not peak unto me, but fly me, and keep at a ditance from me, this may indeed put me to abundance of grief and torment, but never whilt I breath divert me from that lating affection which I have unto her This (Siter) is a mot true anwer unto the Quetion which you asked: Now it is Dorindes part to anwer the King, as concerning her elf.

The young Prince poke this in uch an emphatical manner, that Clotilda miled. Truly Brother (aid he) a mot excellent invention to divert Dorinde from the Kings love: But you Dorinde (aid he, and turned towards me) what anwer do you give unto all this that the Prince hath aid? Madam, anwered I, and bluhed, I cannot give any anwer, but that I do not (yet I wih I did) merit o great an honour. How? replied Clotilda, Dare you preume to love the Prince Sigimond, and would have him love you again? The young Prince then interrupted, for he aw that modety would not permit me to peak. Siter, aid he, you can hardly have a more ample declaration then this Fair one hath given you; but I will make it for us both, and I think he will econd me. Then taking my hand, See Siter this Ring (aid he unto her) which Dorinde wears; I did give it unto her as a Pledge, that if I could marry her at this very intant, I would: but being under the authority of a Father, and not able to dipoe of my elf, without offence to the Laws of God and man, I will tay until I have his conent, or till time dipence with me from that duty. The Princes hearing this, tood amazed, and in uch a confuion, that he did nothing but look, omtimes upon one, and omtimes
upon another, not being able to peak one word; but at the lat after a long mue, he recollected her elf, and turning towards the Prince, Tru • y Brother (aid he unto him) were not my love above all injuries, I hould be exceedingly angry with you for thus contracting your elf with one who is in my ervice, without my knowledge. Siter, replied the Prince, If I have offended you, I mut heartily beg your pardon; and above all, I mot earnetly beeech you to let all the blame reflect upon me, and nothing upon this Fair one; and if my life, or any thing ele will expiate the crime, I am here mot ready to obey whatoever you pleae to command: only I beg of you, as you love me, not to be angry in the leat manner with Dorinde: for I aure you Siter, that if we have offended, it was only in point of time; for we were both of us fully reolved to acquaint you and put our elves into your hands. But dear Siter (continued he) mut I be o unhappy as to incur your dipleaure? I wear by the great Tautates, I never entertained the leat thought but which conducted to honour and repect you; o as hould I loe your favour, I hould think my elf undone. But Brother, replied the Prines, Why did you not acquaint me with your intention at the firt? At the firt, I could not, replied the Prince, becaue then I could not tell whether I hould love her, or whether he would entertain my affection. But ince (aid Clotilda) why did you not tell me, when you were aured of both? And he, who talked o freely with me concerning the Kings addres, why did not he as well acquaint me with yours? Siter, replied the Prince, If ever you chance to love any one, you will anwer this Quetion: You mut know, that when one loves, it is not a work that is begun with deigne: He that walks upon a piece of Ice, do you think his deigne is to fall? No, it is a urprize caued by the lipperines of the Ice: o it is in Love, When one ees a Beauty, this Beauty does urprize, and makes us inenibly glide into love, and we are become Lovers, before ere we thought of being in love. We do protet unto you Siter, and I can anwer for this Fair one as well as for my elf, that within thee two days we did not think it would ever have proceeded o far; but the Intelligence which we had that the King would by extream tyrannry break off all affection betwixt us, was the caue of our reolution to contract: and it was no ooner reolv'd upon, but we intended to acquaint you, and follow your wie and prudent advice in every thing; and orry we are you knew it no ooner. But iter, the thing is pat and done, and now all counel comes too late, and we can do nothing ele but mot earnetly beg your pardon.

Brother, aid the Princes, two things do give me great atisfaction: The one is, to ee the confidence that you have in me, in freely acquainting me with a buines, which if known to the King, would certainly be very prejudicial to you: and the other is, To ee your affection aim at a noble and honourable end; and in this I cannot charge you with any fault: But all the errour that has been committed, is in Dorinde, who knew very well that it was her duty to tell me; he could be free enough in acquainting me with the Kings Courthip, but concealed yours o ubtilly, that God knows whether I hould ever have known it, but for the foolih Duriana; yet Brother, for your ake, I will not only pardon her, but more, I promie you both to forget it; or if I do remember it, it hall be only to ait you as much as I can, for I do foreee a great controverie to enue betwixt the King and you. Siter, aid the Prince, this Fair one and I are infinitely obliged unto you for your pardon, and promied aitance; and as for the King, we have armed our elves with reolution to reit all that he can do againt us: we are not culpable of any capital crimes: If the King trangres the bounds of a Father to a Son, I hall trangres the bounds of a on to a Father; and ince we have right on our ide, we hall be more contented then you can imagine.

The Prince after this, and ome expreions of thanks, would have gone away, becaue he was weary with hunting, but Clotilda tayed him; Brother (aid he) before you go, let us advie what I hould ay unto the King concerning the meage which Ardilan brought unto me from him. Siter (aid the Prince, you may tell him, if you pleae, That you have charged Dorinde according to his command, and that he anwered, that he durt not tand mute when I poke unto her, nor
much les forbid me from peaking to her: That for her part, he would neve • court me, nor durt he hun me; for Siter, I have a great deire the King houl • peak unto me. Then prepare your elf for it, aid Clotilda, for I am confiden • that he will either end for you, or end Ardilan with a meage to you; which if he do, I beeech you conider that Gondebaut is your King, and more, that he is the Father of Prince Sigimond. Upon this he left her, and went to ret himelf, if at the leat this news would give him leave.

In the morning, Ardilan was o early at the houe of Sigimond, that he found him in bed; and aying that he came from the King, he was preently admitted. Ardilan deiring that none might hear what he aid, beeeched the Prince to command all the ervants to with-draw, which Sigimond did; and then he began thus.

I come Sir, from the King your Father, to communicate unto you ome news which he hath received from King Alerick, and which he thinks it requiite to acquaint you withal. Ardilan made this his Prologue by command from Gondebaut, who thought it good to begin with that preamble. Sigimond who was no lover of Ardilan, did anwer with a mile; I thought Ardilan your ervice of the King had been only in negotiations of love; but I ee you are become a Stateman, ince the King communicates unto you uch Forreign News. Ardilan who was doubtles as ubtle a man as any of his time, did very well undertand the Princes meaning: but eeming to take no notice of it, Truly Sit, aid he unto the Prince, you are not much beide the mark, for the meage which I am to deliver, is indeed matter of Love: for the King has received an anwer from his Ambaadors which he ent unto the King of the Viigots, to treat about a marriage betwixt you and one of his daughters; that they have received a very good anwer, and hope to bring the matter to a good concluion. Now the King who tudies your welfare and grandeur, has ent me to acquaint you with it, to the end you may prepare your elf for a voyage which he would have you make in an equipage beitting the Burgundian Prince.

The Prince Sigimond who was advertied betimes in the morning of all the tratagem, did ask Ardilan where thoe Letters from the Ambaadors were. The King keeps them, replied Ardilan, becaue (as I believe) they contain ome things which he would have kept ecret from me. How Ardilan, replied the Prince) does the King keep any thing ecret from you? Surely it is not o; for me-thinks he who does not hide his mot ecret thoughts from you, hould hide nothing ele. Does not the King Sir (aid Ardilan) hide his mot ecret thoughts from me, I beeech you Sir, who tells you thee Tales? Why all the Court can tell it (anwered Sigimond: Witnee the marriage that you did negotiate for him o lily: Witnes the poor Hore that you lamed, and witnes all your negotiations unto the Princes Clotilda, to ait you in your deigns; and would you now make me believe that the King will not trut you with a Letter? No, no Ardilan, I am too neer a neighbour to you to be ignorant what credit you have with him, I would to God his Son had as much. Ardilan hearing this, was o blank'd, that he knew not what to anwer; but like a man of a quick and preent wit, he oon recollected himelf, and thought it bet to turn all to Rallery, and o divert the dicoure. Ah Sir (aid he) I ee you are pleaed to make your elf merry thee Bacchanalian days, when every one trives to be pleaant; but I am erious, and in good earnet. Be pleaed Sir to know, that what I ay does neerly concern your etate: You have no Neighbours whom you need to fear, but Thierry, Alarick, and the King of the Franks; As for Thierry, you have alliance with him already: As for the King of Franks, he is a Neighbour to be feared, and watches his opportunity to make attempts upon your Dominions, he wants neither will nor means to do it: And this conideration invited the King your father to end his Ambaadors unto the King of the Viigots, whoe power once joyned with yours, and the Otrogots is uch, as will give a check unto all the ambitious deigns which the Franks can have againt you. Now Sir, this Treaty is brought to as good a period as you can deire; but it eems in lieu of being glad, you mock at it, as if it did not concern you. Ardilan (anwer • d the Prince in a cornful manner) I mut confes you are
a peron of great policy, and my Father does you abundance of wrong if he does not make you his prime Counellor of State: But as for me, who am not o knowing as you are, I can give no other anwer but this, that I think it more expedient for the King to negotiate his own marriage then mine; for it is but reaon he hould marry before me, being my elder: You Ardilan can bet intruct him, and tranact it for him: Upon this he drew his Curtain, turned away, and would not talk any longer with him.

Ardilan, who extreamly feared the anger of Sigimond, after he had waited a while, was contrained to go away without any dicoure of the love which he bore unto me, and much les of the Kings, unto whom he related word for word all that the Prince had aid unto him; and afterwards added, Give me leave to tell you Sir, aid he, that I think there is none can compoe thee diorders better then the Princes Clotilda: For firt, he has the ole power over Dorinde. And econdly, I ee the Prince does love her, and has a great confidence in her. If he have any power, replied the King. I make no quetion but he will employ it, when I command her, for he dare not dipleae me; he knows her obligations to me, and what good or harm I am able to do her: But my greatet fear is, that Dorinde is taken with the pringing youth of young Sigimond: and if o, then there is no other remedy but to ever them aunder.

Sigimonds Intelligence had his ear litning unto all he aid, and therefore did hear the Kings reolution, which was, that he himelf would peak unto Clotilda, and command her to divert Sigimonds affection from me. As oon as the Prince was advertized of this, he went unto Clotilda, and acquainted her with all the dicoure betwixt him and Ardilan, and afterwards added. Now Siter, the King intends to come unto you and to command you to ue your power in breaking off all amity betwixt Dorinde and me; for my part, I protet by heaven, that death hall ooner eize upon me, then any eparation from her: and yet the cunning Ardilan, who loves neither you nor me, would make the King believe, that you have the abolute power over Dorinde, and that you can do what you will with me: o as you mut take good heed of the King, for he will employ you; and if all ucceed not to his mind, he will be apt to do you ome michief; the only remedy that I know, is to prevent him, I mean, that before he come to you, end you unto him, and beeech him to let you come and communicate ome affairs unto him, which are neceary he hould know; when you are with him, I would have you make a great complaint unto him againt me, and my love to Dorinde, Beeech him to employ all his prudence in preventing it; that for your part, you have done all you can, and all to no purpoe, for when you poke unto me of it, I told you plainly that I did love Dorinde, that it was a thing impoible ever to eparate me from her; and the wort of all is, that you think Dorinde alo loves me, and that things are gone o far, that you fear there is ome promies pat betwixt her and me.

I make no quetion (continued the Prince) but the King will be very much incened againt me; but Siter, of two evils, the leer is to be choen: hould his fury be turned towards you, it would be wore; you know how he ued Chilperick, the cruel death of Godomar, the maacres of his male children, the hard uage of your Siter Mutucuna, in cloytering her up amongt the Vetals: To be brief, Siter, thee bloody cruelties upon thoe from whom you are decended, makes me extreamly fear his fury hould fall upon you: But for my part, what can he do but drive me out of his preence as he would have done before? And I protet Clotilda, that I do o much abominate his violences, as were he not my father, and o conequently I bound to honour and erve him, I hould ooner deire to be out of his ight, then any ones living; o that his punihment will be a kind of a pleaure unto me.

The Princes who did extreamly love Sigimond, as well becaue he loved her, as becaue of his many other good qualities, after many thanks unto him for his indulgent care of her, he endeavoured by all her arguments and reaons to divert him from his affection to me, demontrating unto him the great inconveniences he would draw upon himelf by it; intancing the lownes of my quality, what a digraceful
graceful alliance it would be to his Royal Family, how much it would dipleae the King, hinting unto him the duty and obedience that he owed unto him as his Father, and as his King; Briefly, he laid before him all the inconveniencies and dicontents that would enue upon it. Siter (aid he) in anwer unto all thee coniderations, I will ue but one word, and that is, I Love: and did you but know the validity, extent, and power of this word, you would confes all thee coniderations to be poor and weak arguments to divert me from my unalterable reolution. Since it is o, aid Clotilda, and ince you advie me to it. I will talk with the King according to your directions, and will let you know his anwer. Upon this, he dipatched one of her ervants to the King immediately, according as it was reolved upon.

Gondebaut hearing this meage, ent her word, that he alo had omthing to communicate unto her, and that after dinner he would come unto her. The Prince knowing this anwer, and having no mind to be in the way, he took hore, pretending to hunt; and o kept himelf out of Town all the day.

Whilt thee things paed thus, Arcingenterix my father being very old, and fallen ick of a Fever, he grew o ill, as being pat hopes of life, he ent unto Clotilda, to beeech her that I might come and ee him before he died: Upon this he commanded me to go in all poible hate, and to tell him from her, that he would end him ome things which haply might conduce to his preervation, and thereupon gave me ome excellent receipts, which I carried with me. My poor father, as oon as he aw me, and heard what the Princes had ent unto him, he eemed to receive much contentment; and taking me by the hand, I hope (aid he unto me) Tautates will provide one that will be a tay unto thy youth, for now daughter reckon your elf without a father; and therefore beeech the Princes from me, to have pity upon Dorinde, as upon an Orphan left to the wide wicked world, without any upport and aitance, but from God and her; it will be (tell her, a charitable office, and God will reward it double: after this, my father began to faint, notwithtanding all remedies that could be applied, and in the night after he died.

The King in the interim, as oon as dinner was done, failed not to go unto the Princes; and taking her aide, he began to make great complaints of the Prince; but he who had been well intructed, prevented him, and told him, that he had a very great deire to talk with him about a buines of great importance, in which he mot humbly beeeched him to take ome order: And thereupon he related unto him how he had chidden me for thoe Veres which were ent unto me and which I had received unknown to her: Afterwards he complained againt the Prince Sigimond for tampering with one of her women; nay wore, that he had dicovered an intimate affection betwixt us: Nay wore then all that, he was afraid the buines was gone o far, that the Prince had engaged himelf by ome promies.

Oh Heavens! cryed out Gondebaut, has Sigimond engaged himelf by promie unto Dorinde? Is he o far out of his wits? Sir, aid Clotilda, I will not abolutely aure you of it, but ome probable circumtances induceth me to think o; and when you know as much as I do, I am confident you will concur with me in opinion. When you commanded me to forbid Dorinde from any peech with the Prince, he anwered me, That if he came to her, he could not drive him away: And when I asked her why he received thoe Veres without my knowledge, he replied. That the good will which the Prince was pleaed to honour her withal, was to uch intentions as could not offend any. And when I urged her to tell me what thoe intentions were; Madam (aid he) the Prince can tell you better then I, if you pleae to ask him: and afterwards do what I could, I could not draw one word from her. This dicoure Sir, did exceedingly trouble me; and this morning when he was pleaed to come unto me, I reolved to peak unto him as privately as I could; when I was urgent with him to dicover the truth, and complained againt the dicoure of Dorinde, he gave a cold faint anwer, in thee terms. Good Siter, Do you love me as your Brother? And I anwering, yes; Then Siter, aid he, Love Dorinde as your Siter: Judge Sir the meaning of thee
words: For any part, I was mute when I heard them, he went preently away: and then I thought it my duty to acquaint you Sir, that you might take uch further order, as you prudence hall think fittet.

This News did o nettle the King, that though he was a man which could command himelf well enough when he would, yet could he not chue but give great igns of his dipleaure: for after he tood a while mute, he grumbled to himelf in a low voice; Is the heart of Sigimond o • ae, as to marry one; whoe highet honour is to erve uch a one as he hould marry? Dare he dipoe of himelf without me? And, if he will needs marry without my approbation, mut he needs make uch a misbecoming choice? This is uch a fault, as if I did not reent it, I might be cenured as dulpable as he is: And therefore I will make appear to all the world, that Gondebaut does not conent unto the in of his Son. Then turning towards Clotilda; I thank you (aid he unto her) and think my elf much obliged unto you for your advertiements; and to make it appear how kindly I take them, you hall obtain from me whatoever you can deire: I was very deirous to talk with you about the ame buines, though I could not imagine things to be at this height; but I ee you have prevented me, and are deirous to turn this rah inconiderate young man from his detructive deignes: if you continue thus obliging me, I hall et you in Sigimonds room, and he hall be as indifferent unto me, as the meanet man in my Dominions. Sir (anwered Clotilda, and accompanied the King, who was going away) I can never do you uch ervices as your goodnes obligeth me unto: But Sir, I mot humbly beeech you not to deprive the Prince (my brother) of the honour of your favour, for a few extravagancies of youth, which doubtles he will repent, when he knows that they dipleae you. Conider Sir, he is your on, and young, and it is unto Fathers whom God has given widom and prudence to intruct, not to detroy their children. Clotilda replied he, and took his leave, you are too wie for your young years; I would to heaven Sigimond would imitate you in obedience, or ele that he were in his grave.

Then the King went preently to his chamber, and related unto Ardilan all that Clotilda had told him: and after a thouand menaces, omtimes againt the Prince, and omtimes me, the Kings mind was o enflamed with two violent paions, Love, and Anger, that he could not poibly reolve upon any etled coure.

On the other ide, the Prince being returned from hunting, he came preently to the Princes, to know what had paed betwixt Gondebaut and her; and he relating all that was aid and done; Siter (aid he) I thank God with all my heart, that the anger of the King reflects only upon me, and that you are exempt: I hall now with a calm mind undergo whatoever he will pleae to impoe upon me for though he lay the fault upon me, yet all the world will excue me; Then asking where I was, and being told that my Father was dead: If I durt (aid he) I would go and help to lament her los, but ince that is not permitted, Siter (aid he) do you think it would be amis if I ent unto her? No, anwered the Princes, but I think it would be very prudently done. Then the Prince bade her goodnight, and went to his chamber, where he writ this Letter.

body.head: Prince SIGISMONDS Letter unto DORINDE.
body.p:
I Know very well that for the los of uch a peron, grief is o natural, that it were aburd to diwade the Fair Dorinde from it: But though it be allowable, yet it is upon an implicite condition, of being in meaure: for excesive orrow is not allowed for a Father, nor any ele, except a mot perfect Lover. Preerve thoe tears (my dearet Dorinde) untill you have uch a los, which will not be till the death of Sigimond, who loves
you infinitely beyond all dimenions, and whoe extream affection merits the like meaure of Love from you again.

div.p: I received this Letter by a ervant of the Princes, and I aure you my companions, I found the Proverb by experience true, which ays, That Phyick works good effects when the Patient has a good opinion of the Phyitian: For believing that Sigimond was the only man that did love me; or to ay better, the only man that was no deceiver, this hort letter was uch a comfort unto me, as wrought better effects upon my exceive orrow, then all other admonitions whatoever: And beides, I thought it an offence againt our amity, if I did not do as he deired me.

The King in the mean time whoe mind was all night long upon this buines, as oon as day appeared, he called unto Ardilan, who lay all that night in his chamber by expres command: and after he had complained againt the Prince and me, but much more againt me then the Prince; and after he had worn and proteted that I was unworthy of that honour which he intended unto me, he aid, that now he hated me double to his love be • ore: he asked his opinion which way he might be revenged of me, and reclaim the Prince to his duty? To which Ardilan anwered Did I think Sir, that you were fallen from your affection unto this woman, I could advie a coure which would have the two operations which you deire. Know Ardilan, aid the King, that now I do extreamly hate her; and as I thought her fair and handome before, o I do think her very ugly and ill-favoured now, inomuch as I do much admire I hould find any thing in uch a face worthy of my thoughts, and am extreamly ahamed I hould be o illy as to love her. Thanks be to God, Sir, aid Ardilan, that Truth triumphs over your paion; and to tell you truly Sir, I have admired a thouand times that you hould o dote upon a woman, who was neither fair nor wie: Alas Sir, it was not any beauty or merit in her, and a madnes in you, that blinded your eyes; and therefore you ought to render thanks unto the good genius that opened your eyes, and retored you to your enes: Now Sir, ince you are your elf again, this is the way to be fully revenged, and to recover the Prince out of that gulph which once had almot devoured you. You mut force Dorinde to marry, for if he do love the Prince, no punihment can be more harp; the Prince alo will vex to ee her whom he loved o dearly, in the arms of another, and be out of all hopes to ee her his. But (anwered Gondebaut) Dorinde will not conent unto any marriage. Sir (replied this wicked fellow) Kings are the Tutors of their ubjects; and as the Gods know better what is good for men then men themelves do; o Kings (who are gods upon earth) do know what is good for their ubjects better then they themelves; and therefore if you do provide a husband for Dorinde, who will ay that you have not provided that which was neceary for her? And if he be tubborn, and will not marry him, who will blame you if you force her. The Phyitian knows better what is good for the dieae then the Patient; ome Phyick mut be taken by force; and her father being dead, you may cover your deigne with a cloak of piety, and will not ee the childe of Arcingen • ori •
without a Guardian: Beides, there is a way to make her marry without uing your Royal Authority. There is a Law Sir, which from the Viigots is come to us, by which it is ordained, That the Father having made a promie of his daughter unto one, and die, he being unmarried, his promie hall be made good after his death.

But Clotilda told me (replied the King) that there is ome promies already pat betwixt them. No matter for that (replied Ardilan) for you mut know Sir, that there is another Law which ordains, that if a woman dipoe of her elf otherwie then as her Father would have her, both he, and he who married her, hall be put into the hands of him to whom the Father did promie her, to be old or ued as he pleaeth: Since Sir, ince thee two Laws are in force, why may not you marry Dorinde unto Periander or Merindor, ince Arcingentorix did promie unto them both: In the firt place, end unto her, and let her know, that
you will provide her a match for her contentment; that this your care proceeds from your love unto her father and her; and that you will give her the choice of one of thoe two Cavaliers for a Husband: You may end the ame meage unto others of her kinred, and o oblige them likewie; for it is no mean prudence in a Prince, to oblige many by one benefit; I am confident that if he make a dor at the motion, her friends will perwade her; and if he be obtinate, they will be the firt that will blame her, and commend you though you hould compel her unto it by force: And then God knows what will become of her, when he has none to upport her: For the Princes Clotilda, I dare ay will have nothing to do with her, he is betrer advied, and will not do any thing that hall dipleae you. The King liked this advice, and reolved upon it. He commanded Ardilan to go from him unto the Princes; who could give no other anwer, but that he would perwade her with all the arguments that poibly he could.

She ent immediately to the Prince, to let him know he would peak with him, and when he came, he acquainted him with the deigne: for though he aw much danger to her elf, he would run the hazard, rather then do any thing that hould dipleae him. Sigimond was much amazed at the deigne; and the more, becaue his Intelligencer failed him at this time; but the reaon was, becaue he was not preent at that time when it was reolved upon: but he came time enough to hear the King protet and wear. that he would marry Dorinde by fair means or by foul; and that if neither of thoe two Cavaliers would accept of her, ome other hould, though it were Ardilan himelf.

The Prince hearing this news, and eeing the King had recoure unto extream remedies, he thought that nothing would cure his extream violences, but extream reolutions. He propoed therefore unto Clotilda, for him and I to go out of Gondebauts Dominions, and there conumm • te the marriage which he had promied unto me: But he extreamly diliking this coure, thought it better for me to go alone, and hun the torm which he had threatned, but he to remain till with the King, and endeavour to perwade the King unto reaon. But when this reolution of abence was pitched upon, it was long in debate whether I hould go: for, beyond the Alpes I could not, becaue they were allied with the Otrogots; To the Franks was les likely, becaue they were all in uch combution amongt themelves, about the new election of a King, that all was in diorder there: Beides, the Queen Methina was in uch neceity of aid and aitance, as it was not probable he would entertain me againt the will of o potent a King her Neighbour. As for the Viigots, the journey was too long, for I was to pas through all Spain; beides, there being a Treaty about a marriage with Sigimond there was no afety for me in that place: At lat, they concluded I hould go into Forrets unto Amais, with whom Clotilda held much correpondency: and becaue they knew not whether the authority of Gondebaut would not deter her from giving me afe protection, they thought it expedient for me to diguie my elf in this habit wherein you ee me, to the end that if the protection of Amais did fail me, the olitary habitation among the Shepherdees of Lignon might preerve me unknown.

This reolution being taken, the Princes ent for me; and though the los of my father might well have pleaded my far longer abence from Court, yet ince he ent for me, I conceived it was upon ome important occaion. And therefore in the night time, I repaired to her, who as oon as he aw me, he carried me into her cloet; where being alone together, and eeing me weep, Dorinde (aid he) it is not now a time to weep and complain; you mut arm your elf with a more couragious and generous reolution. But conider Dorinde, that in what condition oever we be, heaven never will afflict us more then we are able to bear, and therefore droop not, but roue up your pirit, and take courage, and then you hall ee, that neither God, nor perons of honour will never forake you: The King gives you the choice of Periander or Merindor for a husband, and will by all means have you marry one of thoe two; if you will not in good will accept of this, or if they refue, he is fully reolved to make you marry Ardilan: See, Sweetheart, what need you have of courage and generous reolution. How,
Madam (anwered I, and grew as pale as death) mut I marry either one of thoe two, or Ardilan? What Law is there for that? The ame Law, replied he; that the tronger will impoe upon the weaker. He will have Sigimond marry a Princes, whom he pretends will bring great advantage; and he knows that he will never be perwaded unto it, till you be married unto another; and therefore he is reolved to acrifice you unto the marriage of his Son, and has given me in charge to tell you as much, and to know what you reolve upon. Upon death, Madam (anwered I preently) yes the mot cruel death that ever any Tyrant like himelf invented.

Upon this, the Prince Sigimond knocked at the door, and interrupted us: Clotilda not knowing who it was, went her elf to open it; and eeing the Prince, Come Brother (aid he unto him in a low voice) and ee here a poor deolate woman; and having hut the door, he conducted him unto me all in tears. My dearet Dorinde (aid he) comfort your elf with this, that he for whom you uffer this dipleaure, will help you to bear a hare, every tear you hed, is a drop of blood from his heart: But I vow by all that's acred, that neither the power of a King, or commands of a Father, hall ever make me hrink from my promie unto you. I know that Gondebaut intends to force an injurious marriage upon you, only becaue he thinks that I will never marry till then; but he is groly mitaken if he think to bring his enterpize to pas that way; for I will ooner loe my life, then conent unto it; proteting that if he do contrain you to marry againt your will, he hall not urvive an hour after I hear of it. He would have proceeded further, but Clotilda interrupted him, aying, That when things are come to that height, as extream reolutions mut be taken, then perhaps none will blame you if you do o; but yet (thanks be to heaven) they are not, and therefore it is more requiite to endeavour the prevention by prudence: It was upon this ubject I was talking to this poor woman but now, and before I gave her my advice, I asked her what he reolved upon: Upon death replied he again, and with as good a will as ever any deired to live. Death, replied the Prince, is the lat remedy; but before you have recoure unto it, as I live, half of the Burgundians hall die in defence of o jut a caue. Oh Sir, anwered I, heaven forbid I hould be the caue of a War betwixt the Father and the Son, and it were better a thouand times that Dorinde were in her grave. No, no, replied Clotilda, there is no neceity of having recoure unto death, until there be no other remedy; nor is there any neceity of ubmitting unto the unjut violences of a Tyrant, as long as they may be avoided; Heaven has given us prudence to preerve our elves againt uch deigns: Let us therefore make ue of it as we ought to do, and I aure my elf heaven will proper our endeavours.

Upon this he propoed unto me what Sigimond and he had before reolved upon; and told me, that if I took this coure, he might be much aitant to me, becaue there was very good correpondency betwixt the age Amais and her, and that if upon any conideration that Princes could not protect me, I might keep my elf concealed amongt the Shepherdees of Lignon, (Atrea and Diana) with whom I might live very happily, they being the fairet, the mot vertuous, and the bet accomplihed women in all Europe: And when I anwered, that to fly from this unjut violence which was threatned, I would not only go into Forrets, but into any other place of the world; and that my only fear was, that I hould not hit the way, or ele be taken by ome or other. The Prince anwered, I will be your guard, and ee you o afely conducted, that none dare do you any harm: Then turning towards the Princes, Siter (aid he unto he) I beeech you let her return unto her houe, to take order for her departure, before any take notice of it; for if you approve of it, I conceive it bet for her to be gone as oon as he can, nor hall I be at ret, till he be out of that place where injutice is o predominant.

The Princes who pitied my misfortune, and was a true wiher of my welfare, did willingly conent unto it; and at parting, he aid unto me, Remember Dorinde that you take your bet Jewels with you, which are mot portable, and may bet be hidden; for Neceity is a monter that has no Law, no hame, nor reaon;
and a woman above all ought to fear meeting with uch a fierce and dangerous beat. This counel caued me (as oon as I came home) to eek out the bet of my Jewels which were portable, of which I made a girdle in a linnen bag, and wore it about my Wate: and as I was very buie about it, the Prince having none with him but one man, in whom he had great confidence, came into my chamber; at which I was o urprized, as I ran into the next room, and locked up my elf: but conidering the weet and dicreet behaviour he always ued towards me, I thought this flight from him was a kind of offence unto him, and that I had no manner of reaon to fear him. I ee Dorinde (aid he unto me) that my coming does put you into fears; but know, that my coming is to no other end, but to continue thoe aurances which formerly I have given you of my unalterable affection: and to tell you, that uch is my love, as you hall never be banihed from your Native Country for my ake, without me; I mean, that I will accompany you into all places where you go, and nothing hall eparate us, but only death. Oh Sir (aid I unto him) will you go with me? What then will the King your Father ay? Let Gondebaut (replied he) ay and do even what he pleaeth, for I will not acknowledge him either for my Father or my King: I would have him know, that Kings are lords of our bodies, but not of our minds, and that nothing is more inupportable unto a generous courage, then an unjut contraint: You need not (Dorinde) refue my company; for I protet before the great Tautates, I will never deire any thing from you, until we be married together, o as I may be for ever the husband of Dorinde, and Dorinde the wife of Sigimond. Sir (aid I unto him) the hopes which you are pleaed to give me, do give me uch abundance of contentment and atifaction, that though never any other advantage befal me, yet would I not change my happines with any woman in the world: But Sir, if you intend to go with me, what will the world cenure of my flight with you? What need you care what cenures the world gives (anwered he) as long as we intend never to return till we be married together? But good Sir, aid I, what will the King ay when he ees he has lot you? If the King replied he, would have a Son without courage, let him get one who does not reemble me: and if he would have him to be a man of pirit, he mut treat him otherwie then he does me, if he deire to keep him long. But Sir (aid I unto him) is the Princes Clotilda acquainted with your intention? No, anwered he, I would not let her know it, for her affection unto you being not like unto mine, he (I know) would not approve of it: But if ever he chance to love, he will not only excue the action, but eteem me the more, and love me better for it.

Our dicoure was long upon this ubject; but at lat we reolved, that the third day betimes in the morning, we hould meet at the Temple of Venus, becaue we were to go forth of that Gate; and the firt that came there, was to conult with the Oracle, to know which way we hould go; being certain that this Goddes (who was a great favourer of Lovers) would give us good counel: and let we hould be known, Dariana and I were to be diguied in thee habits which you ee me wear, and he in the habit of a Shepherd: with him there was only that young man in whom he had o much confidence: We promied each other to tay in the Temple until five of the clock in the morning, but if that time were pat, if the one did not ee the other coming, then to tay at a little Bridge out of the Town, in the way to Ieron, until four of the clock in the evening; becaue at that place there was a thicket of wood where one might hide themelves as long as they pleaed, and that our hores hould tay alo in that wood.

This being reolved upon, and the third day being come, I failed not to rie betimes in the morning; and as oon as day appeared, I conulted with the Oracle of the Goddes Venus, which gave me this anwer:

div.head: The Oracle.
div.l: TO Forrets go; there find a Cure,
For all the orrows you endure.

div.p: I had forgot to tell you, that before I departed, I writ a Letter unto the Princes Clotilda, to dicharge her of my flight from the cruelty of that Tyrant: and I left it lying upon my Table, auring my elf it would be conveyed unto her when I was gone.

Hitherto the Prince Sigimond did make me believe that there were ome men that were not fale and perfideous: But now he made it appear, that Nature can never be o well corrected, but there will alwaies remain a mack of the old vice. Oh God! How difficult it is for a oul to counterfeit a thing long, which is contrary unto it. But where was my wits? What was become of my judgement, after three times being deceived? Had I not ufficient experience of mens falhood? And if now I have occaion to complain that Sigimond hath deceived me, of whom can I complain but my elf? Could I be uch a fool as to believe the Prince, or trut in any mortal man, after o much experience?

Well, five a clock truck, no Sigimond appeared; and ee how I was deceived by his mooth language: Though I aw he did not come according to his promie, yet I could not believe he would deceive me: Oh God! What will a good opinion which one hath conceived of another do? Though I aw he came not, yet I could not but imagine that he would come: And thus I fancied occaions of his tay o long, that but for Dariana, I had tayed at the Temple door all the day; but he perwaded me, and not without ome probability, that perhaps he was taying for us at the Bridge where we appointed to meet, and that not daring to come unto the Temple let he hould be known, he tayed for us there, where perhaps he is blaming us for that whereof we accued him.

This advice caued us to walk through the treet, not without much fear of being known; yet my fears for the Prince were double to my own, o much did his affection which I believed he bore unto me, oblige me to wih his welfare. When we were out of the Town, we were much amazed when we found our elves in the wide fields, and knew not which way to go; and that which mot troubled us, was, that all along the high way, there were o many paengers, that we were till out of our way to mis meeting with them. At lat, after much a do, we aw the Bridge, and as we thought, the Prince taying for us; this, though we were very weary, made us double our pace: But when we came there, and found no body, then were we much atonihed, epecially when we conidered that now Noon was pat: we looked many a long look back the ame way we came, and every thing we aw, eemed to be what he looked for, and at lat every thing deceived us.

The Sun began to grow very low, when I (out of all patience) reolved to return unto Lyons, to know the reaon why the Prince came not: But as I was etting forward, I aw coming the ame way that we were to go, five or ix Horemen, which contrained me to retire into the thick of the Wood, let they hould ee me. Dariana, who was alwaies of a contrary opinion, and would not have me return back; Well Madam (aid he unto me) if thee men had met you, I pray tell me in what a cae had you been in? Very true, aid I unto her, but is it not better to • un the hazard of being known, then to tay here all the night? Oh (aid he) the days are long, and it will not be night above eight hours; let us not depair, perhaps the Prince may come ome other way when we are gone; but if you be o impatient, I will tell you what I will do, I will take ome of yonder dirt, and rub my face all over with it, afterwards I will be walking up and down the high way as oon as I ee him, I will run to advertie you, by this means I hall not be known, and you may ret your elf in the Wood; o as when the Prince does
come, you may be able to go whither you will in the night.

My longing deire to ee Sigimond, made me conent unto this motion though it went omthing againt my mind to tay in the wood by my elf; yet in hopes that he would go into the Town, and make him come the ooner, and becaue I was confident none could ee me in that place, I took o much courage as to tay by my elf. Dariana then daubing all her face over with dirt, I could not chue but laugh in the midt of my miery: Go Dariana, aid I unto her, and return quickly. Did Ardilan ee me in this pickle (aid he) though he did not die before for the love of me, yet I am confident he would now die with laughter. Upon this he embraced me, and went to the place from whence we came.

Alas! Could I have foreeen the orrows which that departure cot me, I would ooner have conented unto my death then it: But Heaven, not contented only to banih me my native Country to atisfie a perfideous man, but would have me alo reent the orrows of a ad and terrible olitude: And as I had foraken all for this mans ake, o was I for his ake alo left detitute of all humane help and conolation, As long as I could ee her, I did accompany her with her eye; but when he was out of ight, then began I to be apprehenive of my fault: At the firt I went into the thick of the Wood to hide my elf, but impatience oon invited me out again, fearing let if Sigimond hould come, and not find me, he would not tay, but return back again; otherwhiles I was afraid left ome Wolf hould do me harm; omtimes I had a deign to go after Dariana, and etting forward in the way two or three times, I either aw or heard ome paenger, which made me retreat again into the Wood: Thee frights were nothing unto thoe that eized upon me when the Sun was et; and more yet, when all light was gone Oh Heavens! In what a horror was I then? The leat blat of wind made me tart, and hake like a leaf; and when any Bryer took hold of me, I thought it to be ome Wolf, or other wilde Beat that would devour me: When I heard any noie, or any Owl crick, I was ready to fall down for fear; There was not a tale of Hags, Hobgoblins, and night walkers, that ever I had heard in my life but they came all into my fancy, and eemed real unto me: And being neer a high Road, I heard Hormen pas by everal times; and God knows how careful I was then to hide my elf in the thick of the Wood. I cannot relate all the Tears, the ighs, the groans and complaints that I made againt the perfidie of Sigimond, and againt the hollow affection of Dariana, who then I believed went away purpoely to forake me in this extream neceity, becaue he would not run the hazards of this enterprize. Oh how true it is (aid I unto my elf) that every one is afraid to keep company with an unfortunate peron? Oh the miery of us humanes, that can never know our friends, till we be in adverity! And as oon as we know them, we are ure to loe them! Oh the dimal lodging of a dark wood in a cloudy night, unto one whoe pirit was o timerous and afflicted as mine was at that time! So it was, that it was day before I durt offer to cloe an eye to leep. When the Sun appeared, I was o weary with my walking, o tormented with my fears, and o hungry, having eaten nothing all the day before, that as I had taken a little better heart at the coming of day, I fell aleep, and lept o oundly, that it was late before I waked; and then eeing the Sun omthing low, fear and hunger forced me to take the next path I et my foot into, and to follow it until I came to ome Vil • age, or till I met with ome charitable peron, who perhaps out of pity would direct me in the way I was to go. Now did my tears renew and my orrows, to ee o many high hopes all dahed; and I that the day before thought of nothing ele but being Queen of the Burgundians, now aw my elf the mot mierable and deolate woman in all the Kingdom: And in this conideration, you may imagine that the Tyrannie of Gondebaut was not forgotten.

This thought brought into my memory all the fair promies of perfidious Sigimond, who as I thought, did eem to love me, only becaue he would hew himelf to be a man, and conequently a Traytor. But what a fool was I (aid I to my elf) and where was my judgement, that I hould ever believe him to be other then a Traytor if he was a man? And ince all men are o, how could I think him only to be different the ret? Could I be o illy as to think Crab Trees would bear
any other fruit then Crabs? And could I hope that a on of the perfideous Gondebaut, would not (like his Father) be diloyal? Thee ad coniderations entertained me till it was almot night, whilt I hardly took notice which way I went; at lat, recollecting my elf a little, and eeing it o late, I looked about to ee if I could py any Village or Cottage where I might receive ome conolation, and by Fortune, I aw a little houe thatch'd with traw, upon my left hand, and not far ditant from the way.
