I turned my elf therefore that way, in hopes of meeting with ome good woman, who perhaps would compaionate my cae, for I had uch an horrour againt all men that I feared meeting any, as much as the mot alvage beat in the woods. When I was come neer this homely houe, I aw ix little children about an old man, who in wooden dihes, was giving them ome milk: the eldet of them could not be above eight or nine years of age, but o cleanly and neat, as they eemed to belong unto ome better people then ued to inhabit in uch a poor place: as oon as thee little ones aw me, they left the old man, and flocked about me; the younget offered me to eat uch as they had, and the eldet invited me into the houe: The old man wondering wither his little children were gone, he looked about for them; and eeing me alone, he came preently unto me, offered me his houe, or any thing in it, and was o curteous and civil, as I thought that heaven having ome pity upon me, had moved the heart of this old man to be o kind, and though he was a man, yet perhaps I hould find him pitiful; and truly I was not deceived; for having received me with o much kindnes, and eeing by my eyes and face that I was extreamly troubled, he made me it down by the fire, offered me ome milk, and ome fruit, which hunger made me eat: afterwards eeing me cry continually, and igh, Daughter, aid he unto me (for my age will allow me to call you o) the Earth, they ay is not firm and immoveable, heaven only is o, the place where we are never rets one moment in one point; to teach us, that we mut not be too much elevated, nor too much dejected by any properity or adverity that happens unto us: for as a wheel which turns, that part which is lowet one while, is highet another; even o it is with men, as long as they are upon this incontant earth, we mut look upon properity as a thing that will vanih and fade away; and alo we mut look upon adverity as a thing which will not lat long: You ee I have lived long enough to have tryed variety of Fortunes, the wheel has often turned, and in what tate oever I was, I alwaies found the weets and bitters of this world, to be les then the apprehenions I had of them: you will think the ame of this misfortune which now troubles you; Time will tell you that by experience I peak truth But in the mean time, lift up your eyes to heaven, and believe, that the great Cauer of all things, knows what it bet for you: Mitrut not his providence, his prudence, his prudence, nor his puiance, nor grumble at any bad Fortune which he ends; for this overaign Widom knows bet what is fit for mortals: Comfort your elf therefore, and hope that in their turns you hall enjoy all delights and contentments that are neceary for you; and in the mean time, I offer unto you all the aitance that your deires and my ability can make.

The wie dicoure of this old man, made a deep impreion in my heart inomuch as I thought ome good Angel had directed me unto this place; to keep me from depair; and therefore after I had wiped away my tears from my eyes, I anwered him thus: Father, for well may I call you o, ince you betow uch paternal counel upon me; I would to God I knew the tability of heaven, as by experience I know the incontancy and intability of the earth Let the Gods do what they pleae, and give me contentment when and in what meaure they think mot expedient for me; but hitherto they have poured upon me uch torrents of afflictions, that I verily believe, but for your conolation, I had been overwhelmed with black depair. Daughter (replied the old man) I am very glad that heaven hath made me an Intrument of any comfort unto you; and ince you do find ome amendment, hope that ere long you will be quite recovered: for as you ee bodies are ubject unto infirmities, o are our ouls; bodies by enible dieaes, ouls by paions, which are moved in us by good and evil fortunes; and as the dieaes of the body have their beginnings, progres, and declines, even o it
is in the dieaes of the oul; and I have experimentally found, that when a dieae either of body or oul begins once to decline, it is preently after cured; for then the body aumes its vigour and trength, and expels thoe evil humours which caued the dieae: o likewie, when it once re-aumes it trength, it preently expels thoe opinions which troubled the oul by fale appearances: But I mut tell you withal, that dieaes are eldom cured without remed • es: and the remedy for an afflicted oul is commonly to open and reveal the affliction unto ome that can adminiter conolation: for then the oul does vomit up that obnoxious humour which offended it, and is afterwards capable of receiving the comforts and counels of a prudent friend. I know that I am not he who can give you conolation; but if you will trut me, I will try if I can give any eae unto your malady.

Father (aid I unto him) the wounds which I have received from Fortune are uch, as cannot be cured by any words; but if you be as pitiful and charitable as you eem, the bet remedy you can give, is to conduct me to my Native Country, which is Forrets, where I am mot confident of ome conolation: The Gods will recompence you for o charitable an office; and I am not in o mierable a condition, but I am able to atisfie their pains.

The old man then looking upon his children with an eye of compaion, ee what here is (aid he unto me) It is not many moneths ince my wife who was all the comfort I had, left me with thee little Infants, loadned with age and poverty As for poverty, I trive againt it as well as I can, by my wary management of that little which I have: Alas, hould I leave thee little ones but one day, they would tarve; you ee I have none but they with me; As for neighbours, I know none whom I would commit your tender youth unto, for I hould think my elf culpable, hould any harm happen unto you: What then hould I do? I am loth to leave you detitute of help, and hould I leave my little ones, I know not what would become of them. But daughter, here is my bed, which I will leave unto you, if you will but be pleaed to let two of my eldet children lie with you, and for this night let us recommend our elves unto the protection of the great Tautares.

Upon this, it being dark, he lighted a little dry wood, which erved for a candle, and tuck it in a Turnip, which upplied the want to a candletick, and etting it upon the Table he bolted the door with a Hazle-tick, and went to his homely hard bed with his little children.
As for me, I laid me down upon his bed in my clothes, and being weary with travel, alo having confidence in the man, I lept oundly.

In the morning I waked very early, yet not before the old man, had already ordered every thing for his little family, with a reolution of going with me, and not leaving me till he had hewed me Forrets; hoping (as he told me) that God would keep his children better then he could himelf, whilt he was doing that office of charity for me. I gave heaven humble thanks for moving his heart unto it; and after he had given directions unto the eldet of his children what to do, he offered himelf unto me as my guide with a promie unto them, to return before it was night; becaue (as he aid) it was not above four leagues from thence to Forrets, and that though he was very old, yet his deire of doing me that office, and returning unto his children again, would add wings unto his feet, and make him go as fat as if he were younger.

So we et forwards with each of us a taff in our hands; and becaue I deired him to conduct me the leat frequented way he could, he was o obervant of my requet, that before it was noon, without coming into any high way, unles to cros it, he brought me unto a high mountain, where taying, he hewed me the Town of Fevres not far off, and a little from thence, Marcelles, and by conequence, the great plain of Forrets: Upon this I asked him where was the River of Lignon. Yonder it is (aid he) and that which runs by that Town which I call Fevres, is the River Loire. Then cat your eye a little upon your right hand, and there you may plainly ee the River of Lignon: Yonder Town under thoe two great hills, is called Boen, and the River of Lignon wahes the walls of that Town:
From hence you may oberve its whole coure, which turning and winding it elf through yonder delectable plain, makes it the mot pleaant place in all Europe. Then the good old man deired leave to return back, let he hould be too long from his little Family: and I, taking a Ring from my finger, Here Father (aid I unto him) take this in tetimony of my thanks for your pains, and I acknowledge my elf infinitely beholding unto you beides. Daughter (aid he unto me) you take from me a greater reward which I expected from heaven; and yet I will not refue what you give me, that you may not appear before heaven ungrateful. Upon this he left me, about an hour after noon, being able to ay, that I never met with a good man but only him.

Thus ended Dorinde, not being able to with-hold her tears at the memory of thee cruel adventures. And becaue her dicoure had been long, and alo time to rie out of bed, they all gave her the bet conolation they could, and then they dreed themelves.

Adamas fearing ome urprize from Rolemas, gave trict charge at the Gates, that all trangers who entred, hould write down their names, and the place where they intended to lodge. That ame night he was advertied, that Merindor and Periander with Dorinde, and the ret of the Shepherdees and Shepherds, were in the houe of Clindor. But having paed away mot of the night with Amais, the advertiement which the Guards of that Port gave him, came very late unto him. The names of thee two Cavaliers were not unknown unto him, and knowing them to be ubjects of the Burgundian King, their arrival at that eaon made him upect left they came for the ervice of Polemas; and had it not been at a very uneaonable hour, doubtles he would have ent for Clindor, to undertand from him the caue of their coming, and what acquaintance he had with them, to entertain them in his houe.

This troubled him all the night long, and therefere he took but little ret: As oon as day appeared, he aroe, and ent for Clindor; and his chamber door was no ooner open, but a young man came and preented himelf, very deirous to peak with him. The man was not unknown unto him, for he was brought up in his houe from a childe. Sir (aid he unto Adamas) I come unto you about a bunes which may perhaps prove of great importance, and perhaps may not; But ince uch a thing came to my knowledge. I thought I hould be extreamly too blame if I did not acquaint you with it: And therefore I have made all poible hate that I could to let you undertand, that yeterday about two hours after noon, ome men who aid they belonged unto King Gondebaut, came in a body together armed, to carry away a young woman which was upon the Banks of Lignon, betwixt Julieu, and the Temple of the good Goddes: When they had taken her, another company (though fewer in number, yet much uperiour in trength and courage) followed them, and recued this woman out of their hands, and ince (as it is aid) have brought her for afety into this Town, with ome Shepherds and Shepherdees. The Combat was very hot and thoe who would have carried her away, were almot all lain, and the ret rid away.

Now Sir, it was my fortune to be there at the ame time, where many Druids, Vaces, and Eubages aembled themelves, to Interr three Cavaliers of thoe who recued the woman, and were killed. But becaue many of their enemies were killed alo, the Commander in chief, and the Ancients, thought good to bury him according to cutom, and not let their bodies be devoured by Dogs and Wolves, or lie there to infect the Ayr. As I pulled off the clothes of the chief of them, I found ome papers in his pocket, which I thought might perhaps be of ome importance to the Nymph; I found therefore this Letter Sir, which is directed as you ee unto Polemas; and afterwards, as I earched his Helmet, I found this little one, lapt up very cloe in a corner of his Helmet: This Sir, I hould have acquainted you withal the lat night, but your tay o long in the Catle, was the caue why I could not make my addres until this morning.
Adamas then taking the Letters, and eeing written upon them,
div.q: To POLEMAS, Count of the Seguians, Our Faithful Friend.
div.p: He thought as well by the Supercription as by the Seal, that they were letters from the King of the Burgundians, and that quetionles they contained matter of high concernment; yet not thinking fit the young man hould know the ditrut which Am • is had of Polemas, he eemed to take no great notice of them; only commended his fidelity, dicretion, and care, and aured him that he would acquaint the Nymph, that when time and place erved, he might take notice of his good will: Afterwards he commanded him to continue the ame upon all occaions that hould preent themelves; and above all, to be ecret; to the end Polemas hould not be advertied of it, let he hould be offended that his Letters hould be brought hither; and yet that it was neceary the Nymph hould ee them.

The man was no ooner gone out of the chamber, but Clindor entred; from whom the Druide undertood who Periander and Merindor were, and the caue of their coming to that place; for Clindor undertood it from them the night before, when they asked his advice, how they hould addres themelves to obtain audience from the Nymph.

Then replyed the Druide very joyfully) as oon as thoe Cavaliers are out of their Beds, you will do an acceptable piece of ervice unto Amais, to conduct them to her; and I will let her undertand who they are, to the end he may receive them according to their merits: And as for Dorinde, my Neece Leonide hall wait upon her unto the Catle. Upon this, hearing that Amais was by her elf, he went unto her.

When he came, he acquainted her with all that he undertood from Clindor, concerning the fortune of Dorinde, and the caue of Periander and Merindor's coming: Then afterwards continued, By this (Madam) you may ee the goodnes of Tautates towards you, in ending trangers to defend you againt the wickednes of your own ubjects; for it cannot be doubted but thee two Cavaliers will faithfully ait you againt Polemas, although they be ubjects unto the Burgundian King; their recuing this woman from him is an infallible argument of it, But (aid the Nymph) you mention King Gondebaut as if you were aured that he is no friend unto us: Do you know any thing more then yet I am acquainted with? No Madam, anwered Adamas, but I conclude by the rules of reaon that he mut be o of neceity: for it is likely that Polemas, who is a man of deep wit, and has plotted his deigne cunningly, hould not make ure of a King o potent and near: hould he commit uch an error, I hould then think him the mot illy man that ever plotted any Treaon; and I hould think it as weakly done of you, if you did not prepare your elf to find him o: I believe that I have ome letters here which will put you out of all doubt: Upon this he preented the firt letter to her, which the Nymph looked upon a while, and aid nothing, wondering at the Title of Count of the Seguians given unto Polemas; afterwards asking who writ that Letter, and where he had it; I cannot auredly tell you, Madam, anwered he, unles that Seal be the ame which Gondebaut ueth; but that CAT (aid he) with this Motto, LIBERTY, maketh me think it his: and beides, thoe who would have carried away that young woman whom I mentioned unto you, and were killed by thee three Cavaliers, did bring them, and they were found in their pockets by a young man, who brought them unto me with all peed. Upon this the Nymph broke open the Seal, and found thee words.

body.head: GONDEBAUTS Letter unto POLEMAS.
body.p: OUR dear Friend; If Clorantes the Captain of our Guard tand in need of your help, let him ee what Friendhip and Repect you bear unto his Mater: He goes about a buines which he will communicate unto you, and it is a buines of greater importance then it eems to be: If Polemas will have us think him to be our Friend, let not upon any conideration whatoever, the Bearer hereof return without that atisfaction which we expect from his Voyage.

div.p: I perceive (replyed Adamas) that this Letter, though it do ufficiently argue the good correpondency betwixt them, yet it was written purpoely to be een by any: But Madam, this other which was found in the Helmet of the ame man, I believe will peak a little more plainly.

The Nymph taking it, I know not what will be in it (aid he) but me-thinks the firt not very obcure, ince Gondebaut writes unto Polemas as if he were abolute Lord of my Dominions, and calls him Count of the Seguians; a new Title, and which appertains unto none but him w • o hall marry Galathea. Then thee words, Let him ee what Friendhip and Repect you bear unto his Mater: And afterwards, If Polemas will have us think him our friend, let not the Bearer hereof return upon any conideration whatoever; as if it were in the power of Polemas to permit or forbid any thing without my knowledge in my Dominions: After this he opened the little Note, and found thee words.

body.head: GONDEBAUTS Note unto POLEMAS.
body.p: NOw is the nick of time that Polemas mut be Count of the Seguians; I undertand that Clidemant is dead, Lindamore extreamly wounded, and almot all his Forces quandred. Now let us ee whether your Courage can equal your Ambition; and in this Gondebaut will manifet himelf to be your friend.

div.p:
Oh Heavens! cryed out the Nymph, now it is pat all quetion, the treaon is all dicovered: What human force is it that can help us? The Druide not thinking it fit to pend that hort time which they had to order their affairs, in tears and complaints, he beeeched the Nymph to call for Galathea, to advie with them upon the coure that was to be taken: And when he was come, the Druide addreing himelf unto Amais, who was all in tears; Madam (aid he unto her) Tears will not help; you mut now hew the magnanimity and generoity of your mind, and make your courage appear to all your people. The great God does promie you by me, that he will never forake you, if you will nor forake your elf: You may ee his favourable providence already towards you in ending Alcidon and Damon o opportunely hither, as if you had purpoely invited them. Periandrr and Merindor two Cavaliers very well known to be men of heroick pirits, and great valour, quetionles they will freely arm themelves in your defence, their generous behaviour yeterday is an argument of it: for Madam, be pleaed to know, that the daughter of that good old Cavalier Arcingentorix being fled into your Dominions from the tyrannie of Gondebaut, was yeterday violently taken away by ome ouldiers of his Guard, and doubtles had been carried away unto
Lions (from whence he ecaped in a diguie) had it not been for the valour of thee two Cavaliers who recued her, and brought her into this City for afety, and to beeech you that you would be pleaed to receive her into your protection. You mut Madam, put your trut in the goodnes of the great Tautates, and make it appear, that Amais is the Lady of all thee Countries, not only by ucceion, but much more by vertue and merit. The Nymph wiping away her Tears, and taking Galathea about the neck, Daughter (aid he unto her) if heaven have ordained the ruine of our Dominion, let us however do nothing unworthy of our elves, nor which may make it thought that it was our fault: Then taking her by the hand, he went into Damons chamber, where he knew Alcidon was; and the doors being hut, Adamas by her command poke thus.

Perhaps Sirs you will think it trange, after you have heard what I hall ay by the commands of the Nymph, that the Gods who ent you into Forrets to find a remedy for your mieries, hould detiny you for the preervation of that Country, which I may ay is ruined, unles preerved by your Arms and Valour. The truth is, Amais, and us all, have no hopes in any humane force but what is in you, to defend us from a hameful and inupportable ervitude, which rather then endure, we would die. This great Nymph whom you ee o much honoured by all the Gauls, and whoe vertue has been ever without the leat tain, is by the inevitable judgment of heaven, reduced to uch a point, as not only to be deprived of her Country and Dominions, but alo to have the Nymph Galat • ea (her daughter) ravihed from her, by the mot horrid treaon that ever was. 'Tis true, that your arrival here o opportunely without any other deigne but by the good will of heaven, does give us a mot aured confidence, that you will become intrumental in the preervation of o good a Princes, and in the punihment of uch wicked men as dare o unjutly attemt againt her authority. This action, Sirs, when it hall be fam'd among the Gauls, will not add a little luter unto your glory; for it will have all the qualifications that are honourable, and eteemed by perons of vertue, as well for the equity of it, as the danger, which (to any courage but yours) would be terrible, and affright them from undertaking it. He would have continued, but Damon being all impatiency, interrupted; Madam (aid he unto the Nymph) I protet and vow unto Grand Heus, never to leave you, until you be out of all danger, and will pend every drop of my blood in your ervice, againt all men in the world: and when I mut arm my elf in your defence, no wound hall keep me a minute longer in my Bed. Alcidon aured the Nymph of the ame with o much alacrity and freedom, that Amais and Galathea could not find words full enough to expres their thanks.

Afterwards Adamas acquainted them with the plot of Polemas, and the means by which he hoped to effect it. The great preparations he had made before hand, as well within and without the Dominions; his correpondency with Neighbour Princes; the authority he had cunningly uurped in the Country; the means he had ued to make himelf mater of all the Forts, and to win the good will of all the Souldiers and Officers; and briefly, that having impoverihed the Nymph of money and men, nothing did hinder him from executing his pernitious deign, but only his fears of Clidamant and Lindamore. And now the King of the Burgundians hath written unto him of Clidamants death. To be brief, he omitted nothing which he thought expedient for them to know. But all the extream dangers and perils which he repreented unto them, did exaperate their courage to undertake the defence of the Nymph: And to joyn prudence unto their valour, the enquired what afety there was for her reiding in that place, and what orders he had taken. Adamas atisfied all their demands, and aured them, that nothing would be wanting but men: As for Arms, he had a magazine tored with all orts in the Catle: As for proviion, it was not a moneth ince harvet, o as their Granaries were full: But as for men, he knew not where to have them, nor whom to trut.

My opinion is (aid Alcidon) that the way to get ouldiers unperceived, is to appoint ome publique ports, and et up Prizes, for hooting in the Bowe, for Wretling, and uch like; and when they are aembled, we hall order them into
Arms. I think Madam (aid Adamas) that the counel is good; for if there be any Traytors, they are perons of quality; it being not likely that Polemas would declare himelf unto any others; and we have an excellent pretence for it, becaue even days hence is the ixth of July, a day detined to gather the Mileto of the New year; It hall be given out, that you intend to be preent, to invite many unto it; and you know it is the cutome for every one to bring what Arms they will in honour of the Feat; when they are come together, we may cull out thoe whom we like bet.

This was the reolution, Adamas went immediately to put it in execution; and as he went out, Clindor came in, who by the Druide's command preented Merindor and Periander unto the Nymph: Amais and Galathea received them with abundance of curteie: And becaue they intimated that they had omthing to ay in private, the Nymph cauing them to it down by Damons bed, he told them that they might peak freely before thoe two Cavaliers, from whom he concealed nothing. Madam (anwered Merindor) ince it is your pleaure to have it o, we hall be obedient, although we were charged to peak unto you alone, and o we will, though it be your pleaure to hear us with many ears. Afterwards he continued thus.

div.head: The Sequel of the Hitory of DORINDE.
div.p: IF great Princes were exempted from Paion, unto which others are ubject, we might well eteem them Gods upon earth; for if their high puiance were accompanied with this priviledge, I know not wherein they would be inferiour unto Gods: And hence it is that immortals being unwilling that men, be they never o great, hould equal them, have ubmitted Princes as well as other men, unto unruly paions, which torments them.

I ue this preamble Madam, to the end that when you have heard me out, you may not blame thoe great Princes of whom I am to peak, for want of Vertue, nor Weaknes; but that you may think thee imperfections in them, to be only Tributes which they mut pay unto their humanity.

Be pleaed to know Madam, that King Gondebaut having cat his eye upon a young Lady named Dorinde, he fell o deperately in love with her, that the affection which he bore unto Cryeide, that fair Tran-Alpine, was not equal unto the affection which he bore unto her. This Dorinde was the daughter of Arcingentorix, one of the mot illutrious Families of Gaul. But as all great Beauties are ubject to be een and loved by many, o many cat their eyes and hearts upon her; and amongt the ret, Prince Sigimond; yet both the Fathers and the Sons Loves were carried o cloely, that it was long before one another, or any ele perceived it.

But Dorinde receiving the love of Prince Sigimond more favourably then the Kings, it hapned that jealouies did arie betwixt thee two great Princes; neither Father nor Son could brook any competitor, o that Dorinde was contrained to fortifie one ide by her conent. She therefore turned to Sigimond with uch a full reolution, that he who negotiated the matter for the King, had command from her to peak no more unto her concerning it, unles the King reolved to keep his promie: for Ardilan (o was he called who olicited for the King) had promied her marriage, though perhaps without any intention of his mater. This man eeing his negotiation to thrive no better, did believe that ome new Love was the caue of it; and being a ly and craty fellow, he preently after dicovered the affection of Prince Sigimond, with which (for his own dicharge) he preently acquainted the King, who was o extreamly dipleaed at it, that great diorder and inconvenience was like to enue thereupon. At lat, the King by way of revenge, reolved to marry her by fair means or foul, unto one of the Court: whereof Sigimond being advertied, and not being able to endure uch an injury hould be offered unto one he o much loved and honoured, he went unto her
houe (for her Father died a little before) and acquainting her with the Kings deigne, they reolved to go both together out of Gondebauts Dominions; and (becaue they would not be known) to diguie themelves in other habits, then to conult with the Oracle of Venus, to know which way they hould go.

The Prince would have only one man with him, whoe name was Cerates, in whom he had great confidence; and he only one woman who had long erved her, and in whoe fidelity he could not doubt. Ceraetes was to lead the hores for all four, unto a certain place which they had appointed without the Town: And the Prince with her and Dariana (for that was the name of her who erved her) were to go on foot to the place, where Cerates tayed for them. But how hard a thing it is to deaf the ears, and blind the eyes of jealouie!

The King, or Ardilan, or rather both, had et pies over the Prince and Dorinde; and therefore when they perceived that Sigimond went one evening unto Dorinde, though he carried with him but very few men, yet o it was, that one of thoe who took notice of their actions, went into the houe amongt the ret, who took no notice of him: but he carried himelf o confidently, that the Princes ervants took him to be one of Dorindes dometiques, and Dorindes dometiques took him for one of the Princes ervants. This man aw the Prince talk with great modety and repect unto the Lady, and that beginning of their talk was only condoling the death of Arcingentorix, the father of this Fair one. Afterward he oberved them to talk very low, and the Prince to be very angry; for the actions of his hands, his head, and the ret of his body, hewed as much, though he did not hear one word, unles when he bade her good night, he chanced to raie his voice, and utter thee words: Do not fail on your ide, and be ure that I will be there. Thee words were well oberved, and preently carried to the King, who entring till into greater doubts, charged ome of his confidents to have a pecial eye over all the actions of Sigimond, that they might dicover his deign. And Ardilan, who was no friend of the Princes, reolved not to leep a wink all night, purpoely to ee if he could dicover any thing. In the morning therefore he aw Cerates take Hore, and caued three others to be brought after him by ome certain boyes: He ent commands immediately to the Gates, from the King, to let none out; and in the mean time ran himelf to advertize the King, who judged thee three hores to be for the Prince, Dorinde, and Dariana; and that doubtles they had a deigne to go together. This was the reaon that he commanded all the Gates of the Town to be hut, the keys to be brought unto him, the River Arar to be blocked up with chains, and afterwards ent for Prince Sigimond and Godomar to come unto him.

By fortune, he who went unto Prince Sigimond, was the Prudent Avitus, who had been his Governour; but the commands came not o oon to the gates, but Dorinde was firt gone out: for he being more quick then the Prince, or to ay better, had les to do in ordering her dometiques, was before him. When the prudent Avitus came into the Princes chamber, he knew that his preence would be unwelcome, and that the Prince would be very buie about the execution of his deign; for the king had acquainted him with it: The age Governour loving Sigimond extreamly well; Sir (aid he unto him, and took him aide) I come to acquaint you that your intentions are dicovered, and I am orry that the King knows of it, then for the dicovery of the enterprize. What enterprize do you mean? aid the Prince. If we were in a place where our actions could not be oberved, replyed he, I would tell you. The Prince then (who had a great confidence in the widom and fidelity of this man) went half drot into his Cloet with him.

Then Avitus began thus, Sir, the King hath ent me to tell you, that he deires to peak with you, and with the Prince Godomar your Brother: In the mean time, he hath commanded to hut up all the Gates of the Town, and keeps the Keys himelf; Judge therefore whether or no he knows of your Deigne. My Deigne! replyed the Prince, what does he think it is? He hath an opinion (anwered Avitus) that you intended to go out of his Dominions with Dorinde. Who put him into that opinion? aid the Prince. Many circumtances (anwered he)
and conjectures; for he knows that you do love her. I never concealed it, anwered the Prince, either from him, or any ele; But I pray, is there any Law enacted, that one mut not love in his Dominions? No, replyed he, but he knows more then that, for he hears that you intend to marry her. If he (replyed the Prince) were a good and kind Father, he ought to give her unto me, and not thus to cros me, and deprive me of all contentment. Mot true, replyed the prudent Avitus, if you were a private peron; but Sir, as all the ubjects of the Realm are not their own, but the Kings who governs them, o the King is not his own, but the peoples over whom he rules. Great Princes (uch as you) never ue to marry to pleae themelves, but for the welfare, grandeur, and afety of their Kingdoms. Did you ever ee (aid Ssgimond) any Sacrificer to acrifice one Victime twice? That is not the cutome, anwered Avitus. Why then will the King acrifice me twice for the welfare of his Dominions? For he has once acrificed me, when he married me againt my mind to the Kings daughter of the Otrogots. That which is allowed unto women ought alo to be allowed unto men: Women marry the firt time by obedience, but the econd time by election. Sir, anwered the wie Governour, Thoe that are ubject unto the Dominion of another, never ought to ue thee terms, I will, and I will not. That is right, anwered Sigimond, in thoe that are born ubjects; but I am born the on of the King. Admit (replyed he) that you be born the Kings on, yet the King is then your Father; and does not a childe owe all duty unto a Father? Give me leave to tell you Sir, that by the Law, the Father may ell the Son in his neceity. Laws, anwered the Prince, are but Spiders webs, which hold the mall flies, but the great ones eaily break through. The truth is Father, (for o he called him ince he was his Governour) I do love Dorinde, and I will never marry any other but her. Will the King then force an unjut marriage upon her? Let me tell you freely, I cannot uffer it; acd therefore I did reolve to fly from a Prince that is o violent, and has o little regard of equity: If you do love me, as I ever thought you did, I beeech you contrive my departure, for I am as fully reolved upon it, as I am to die. The wie and prudent Avitus. eeing it was no time to pres him any further, Sir (aid he unto him) your deigne might at any other time be accomplihed, but now it cannot; for the Gates are all locked, the Guards are et in every quarter of the Town, and without wings there is no getting out: and that you may know I peak truth, Cerates cannot get out with your Hores. Oh heavens! cryed the Prince out, and what is become of Dorinde? Upon this word Cerates entred into the Cloet, and eeing Avitus there, he would have gone out again, but the Prince called him in. No, no Cerates (aid he, come in, and peak freely before Avitus, for he deires my contentment as much as I can my elf. Sir (aid Cerates with a ad look) I have been with your hores at the Port of Venus, but they would not let me pas: And becaue I thought that perhaps I might get out by the River Arar, I went thither alo; but I found all hut up, and the Keys carried to the King. Oh God! aid the Prince, and what is become of Dorinde? Sir, anwered he, I hear nothing of her. Then Cerates (aid the Prince, go as fat as you can to her houe, and if he be there till, bid her not tir till he hear from me. Then turning towards the age Avitus, I ee Father (aid he unto him) that I hall tand in need of your counel. Sir, anwered he, not only my counel, but my life, and all I have, is dedicated to your ervice, But Sir, the King has ent me to you, what anwer hall we return him.

The King (anwered he) does ue me o harhly, that I know not how to behave my elf. Conider Sir, aid Avitus, that if you do the duty of a Son, every one will eteem you; and the fault of one, ought not to exempt another from doing his due. The great Tautates, who is the univeral father of all men, is very partial in the behalf of Fathers; and therefore he has promied a greater recompence upon children that are obedient, then for any thing ele upon earth. I have often told you Sir, that a good man will not only follow vertue in things that pleae him, and are eaie, but in things that are harh and hard, though never o dipleaing: for otherwie thoe animals which are guided only by ene, and have no other light but their own appetites, might be as vertuous as men, ince they are as
prompt unto things that pleae them, and more then we are: But in things that are cros and avere to our minds, we do hew our elves rational, and not enual. Now Sir, I beeech you et thee coniderations before your eyes, and ay when you are before the King, I will do my duty Sir, though it be never o much againt my mind, becaue yon are my King, and becaue you are my Father: and you hall ee heaven will infinitely reward your obedience. Father (aid Sigimond) I will do whatoever you would have me: But truly, if the King marry Dorinde by force, I profes that I cannot uffer it; I had rather render back unto my father that which he hath given me, which is my life, then uffer uch an injury to be offered unto her. No, no (anwered the prudent Governour) the King does only make a hew of doing it, but indeed he dares not; for the Laws are abolutely againt any force in marriages: But yet (aid the Prince) he grounds upon a Law, which ordains, That if a Father promie his daughter unto one, and die before the marriage be effected, the daughter cannot otherwie dipoe of her elf; and if he marry another, they are both to be in the power of him unto whom he was promied, to do what he pleaeth with them. How (aid Avitus) does this Law concern Dorinde? It concerns her very much (anwered the Prince) or at leat they ay o; for Arcingentorix had promied her unto Bellimartes, unto Periander, and unto Merindor. She will want no Husbands then (anwered Avitus) but becaue it is impoible he hould be the wife of three, therefore the promie is null, and of no effect. But Sir, you mut know, that thoe promies which the Law intends, are uch as are paed by Writings, and parole promies are invalid; for otherwie this Law would prove a gros inconveniency: But beides all this, I have heard ay that Merindor and Periander during the life of her Father, did diclaim that marriage, and Bellimartes (who was married before) had married her, if his wife had not come in and prevented it: All thee promies were made void during the life of her father; and they may fright Dorinde and you, but no Judge will give any entence to enforce her upon thoe promies. Oh Father! replyed the Prince, had I poke with you before I fixed upon that reolution of going away, we had taken a better coure.
Upon this Cerates returned, and told the Prince that Dorinde was not in her houe, and that going into her chamber, he found a Letter upon the Table, which he preented unto the Prince.

Oh Heavens! aid he, whither is he gone? Doubtles Sir, aid Cerates, he is gone out of the Town; for otherwie, when he found all the Gates locked, he would have returned to her houe. Avitus in the mean time having opened the Letter which the Prince gave unto him, they ound thee words.

body.head: DORINDES Letter unto the Princes CLOTILDA.
body.p:
CAnnot your Candour, Madam, pardon my crime in leaving you without your leave? I hould think my elf the mot lot woman upon earth, did I not hope your goodnes will not only pardon, but pity me; and accompany my Voyage with ome Tears of Compaion: Epecially when you conider, that I had no way to defend my elf from violence: but my flight. Alas Madam, it had been enough, and too much to be deceived, without an addition of uch grand Injutice unto Treaon. I have heard ay, and I hope its true, That the Gods cannot endure any unjut Marriages. In the mean time, I will abent my elf, and ince I am born free, fly from uch cruel ervitude. I protet by all my Obligations unto you, nothing grieves me more, then my los of the Princes Clotilda:
It grieves me, as well to be out of her ervice, as that he is in a place where I fear the ins of another will be charged upon her, though innocent.

div.p: This Letter (aid Avitus preently) is a full dicharge for the Princes, if Dorinde be gone away; and I conceive it very expedient to keep it, until the truth be known whether he be gone or no, and afterwards that it be carried rather unto the King then the Princes Clotilda, to free her from any upition. To this end, let it be ealed up with ome unknown Seal, and carried to the place where it lay, to the end, that thoe who doubtles will carry it to the King, may find it there. But in the mean time Sir, I conceive it requiite that you go unto Gondebaut, without taking notice of any thing. If he ask whither Cerates was leading the hores, both he and you may anwer, that you were going to coure a Stag, and that he was carrying them to the tand; and for a better colour of it, it is expedient you put on your hunting habit.

All things were done as Avitus advied; Cerates carried back the Letter, and laid it upon Dorindes Table; in the mean time the Prince dret himelf, and preently after went to the King, accompanied with a great number of Cavaliers; who eeing men armed walk up and down the Town more then uual, and hearing that the Gates were locked, did flock unto his lodging to receive his commands, for his weetnes and goodnes made him beloved by all.

As oon as the King aw him in that habit, he asked him the reaon of it: To coure a Stag, Sir, aid he, and I was ready to take hore when Avitus told me that you would peak with me. I believe (anwered the King and miled) that you were going to coure rather an Hind then a Stag. The Prince eeming not to undertand him; That might have been Sir (aid he) if the Huntmen hould mitake the one for the other, but it was not my intention. I commanded the gates to be locked, and the Guards doubled, upon ome intelligence which much troubled me, and which I will impart unto you; and to that end, follow me into my Cloet: Upon this he went into his Cloet, and called with him none but Sigimond, Godamar, and the prudent Avitus

The door was no ooner hut, but Ardilan knocked, and Avitus by the Kings command went to ee who it was. As oon as the King aw him, he went unto him; and the Prince oberved that Ardilan talked to the King with a face of atonihment, but he could not hear a word, for he poke very low; their dicoure was very long, and in the concluion he gave the King a Letter, and went away. Gondebaut in a great ume, as one might ee by his countenance and eyes, did it him down in his chair, and hewing the Letter which Ardilan gave him, here's news of our hunting, aid he; then holding it unto Avitus, who knew it preently, he commanded him to read it, which he did; yet in reading it, did weeten the harpet places as well as he could.

What do you think Sigimond aid Gondebaut) had not I good caue to ay that you were going to coure the Hind? Do you think that any of your deigns can be concealed from me? Can you believe that I am ignorant of your fond and foolih affection, and unto what height it is grown? And yet becaue I eemed deaf unto all reports that was told me, and would not ee what all the world did, this connivance has made you forget your duty both unto me and your elf. Sir, aid the Prince, if you will be pleaed to hear my reaons without being wayed with too much prejudicated paion, you will not think me o culpable as I am falely reported to be. Can you think it poible (replyed Gondebaut) that I hould not be extreamly paionate in a thing which o much concerns you? For you have forgotten the duty of a on, yet I cannot the duty of a Father: But to let you ee how much you are mitaken in thinking me o wayed with paion, I will give half my Kingdom upon condition that I were now in the wrong, and you in the right; I had rather the fault hould be branded upon me then you; for alas, I have almot finihed the coure which the Fates have detined me to live, and for that poor pittance of time which remains for me, it is no matter what opinion is
conceived of me; but you who are beginning that coure which I have ended. O Sigimond, did you know how much it concerns you to keep an untained reputation, you would eteem your los of it by this occaion, to be the greatet of your life. I know very well Sir, replied the Prince, that I can never atisfie thoe obligations wherein I am bound unto you, and I would beeech you to add this unto the number, and tell me wherein I have tained this reputation, which I ever held o dear unto me. You have judgement enough, replied the King, to know it without my telling you, but ince you deire to have it from my mouth, is it not true that you do love Dorinde? mot true Sir, anwered he, I do love her; but I never knew that it was ever any hame to love a fair and a wie Lady. But, aid the King, he is below your quality. If Kings and Princes, replied he, ought to love none but Queens and Princees, then truly I hould confes my fault, but if it be a fault, it has been committed by example. Though it be permitted us, replied the King, to love perons of lower rank then our elves, yet their loves ought not to go o far as to marry them: for when I betowed ome good language upon Cryeide, do you think it was ever my intention to marry her? for my part Sir, aid the Prince, if ever I hould promie any marriage, I would perform it as religiouly, as if all the Druides in Gaul had married me. What? aid the King, would you marry Dorinde? I do not ay I will Sir, anwered the Prince, but I ay that if I did promie to marry her, I would perform it, though I became the pooret Cavalier in your kingdome. The King then pulled down his hat over his eyes, and aid unto him, I know mot auredly, that you have promied to marry her. Sir, anwered the Prince, you are ill informed: It is very true indeed, I did promie. that if I were at my own dipoe, I would marry her; and whether I have not in this made my duty unto you appear, I refer it unto your elf. But I hope to find you o kind a father, as not to give me any occaion to complain againt you. O Heavens! replied the King, is Sigimond of o a bae a pirit, as to marry uch a woman, if I hould give him leave, and ask wherein he has tained his reputation: Well, well, I will take an order to apply uch remedies, as hall prevent any uch inconveniencies. Uoon this Gondebaut roe up, and commanded Sigimond to his houe, and to tay there until he received further commands: then the Prince went away extremely vexed, and gave no reply.

Their dicoure had continued o long, that before they parted the un was low; and the Prince, by fortune, as he was going to his lodging, he aw a great crowd of people in the treet, which caued him to tay, as if his heart had told him, that perhaps they had found Dorinde, and were carrying her away: her thoughts were partly true, for he aw that it was Dariana, whom he knew better by his habit then her face, which was o dawbed with durt as he wondred that any hould know her, As oon as ever the Prince aw her he went unto her, took her by the arm, and by his authority carried her to his houe. The poor wench did tremble o, as caued all that aw her to pity her. But when he was in the Princes chamber, he took ome heart; O God Sir (aid he to the Prince) what do you think is become of my Mitres? where is he? (aid the Prince preently) at the brtdge (anwered he) where you aured her to be with her: And who is with her? asked the Prince: Alas Sir, aid he, with tears in her eyes, he is all alone, and if ome good Angel have not pity upon her, I cannot tell what will become of her; you mut know Si •
• hat we were up very early, we conulted with the Oracle as oon as any day app •• red, and eeing the time of your appointment pat, we thought you were gone to the bridge, unto which we went, and finding none there, my Lady commanded me to go back and ee if I could find you: and as ill luck was, I was eized upon by thoe, out of whoe hands you have recued me, who eeing me alone, and my face o dirty, did at the firt nothing but laugh at me: but afterwards, one of them looking better upon me did unluckily know me, and but for you Sir, would have et me in the stocks. By the way, they asked me many quetions concerning Dorinde, but I alwayes anwered that he was not with me, for I was come into the town to eek her. Ardilan was at the Port with the keyes of the gates when I was eized upon, and gave mot bae language againt the honour of Dorinde, which I hall never forget nor forgive: But Sir,
when fortune will run a buines, ee how all ill chances will fall upon the neck of one another: as this Traitor Ardilan was thus belching out his venome againt Dorinde, one of the Temple of Venus did ay aloud, that one in uch a habit as I had, came that morning to conult with the Oracle: Ardilan hearing this, did ask him what anwer the Oracle gave. I cannot tell (applied the man) but as I remember, the ubtance of it was, that in Forrets they hould find a remedy for what they ought after; I aw that this wicked varlet went as fat as ever he could towards the Kings Pallace.

But all this while, aid the Prince, what is become of Dorinde? Alas Sir, aid Dariana I can tell you no more, but that I left her at the bridge, hid in a buh which is on the other ide of the river. O God, cried the Prince, ome wolf will devour her. O mot cruel father (if it be lawful for me to call thee o) cant thou find a heart to murder me in this manner: upon this he was ilent, and ighed and walked up and down the chamber. Afterward he commanded Dariana to go out unto Dorindes houe as oon as it was night; he bad her fear nothing and commanded Cerates to conduct her thither in the evening.

Almot at the ame time, the Pri • ce Godomar and the prudent Avitus came in to his chamber, and told him how extreamly angry the King was that he had recued this woman out of the hands of thoe who were bringing her unto him. Father (aid the Prince unto the wie Avitus) I beeech you tell the King that I cannot endure any hould do Dorinde a dipleaure, or any that belongs unto her: I will hazard the lat drop of my blood but I will make them repent it, whooever they be, except the king; Let him not think trange at what I have done; as for this woman, he is as afe in my hands as amongt thoe varlets that ued her o ill, and when he pleaeth, I will bring her unto him: beeech him from me to trouble himelf no further, for it was I who, caued Dorinde to do what he hath done, and if he do hinder me from following her, o that any harm happen unto that fair one: Let him conider that he has no more a on of me, for I do olemnly protet, that I will not live to be his on any longer. O Sir, anwered the prudent Avitus, is it poible that paion hould have uch a power over you? Do you not conider who you are? and what duty you ow unto him: I know not father, anwered the Prince, who I am, but I know what I would be: for I wih that I had been in my grave ten years ago. Then walking up and down very fat; he did nothing for a long while together, but igh o extreamly, as if his oul were ready to depart from his body.

Prince Godomar, who loved his brother mot tenderly, intreated the wie governour to go unto the King, and allay his anger as much as he could; and in the mean time I will (aid he) ue my bet arguments to perwade Sigimond unto his duty; for I am afraid let the King, through the councel of the wicked Ardilan, hould make him take ome violent coure, if not prevented by your wie admonitions. Avitus, who thought he pake very prudently, went away without aying any thing to the Prince, whoe anger had o blinded him, as he scarly aw any thing that was before his eyes. When they were alone, the young Godomar lockt the dore, and after he had walked two or three turns with him, he aid thus: I cannot, brother, indure to ee you thus extreamly troubled: and I beeech you mot heartily to make ue of me, and believe, that no conideration whatoever, hall make me hrink from any ervice that you will require from me.

Brother, aid Sigimond unto him, pardon me if I do not anwer you, for I am o much ditracted by thee accidents, that I aure you, I did not undertand what you aid: I aid brother, applied Godomar, that I am o otry to ee you thus perplexed, as I will do you any ervice in the world you hall command me. Brother, anwered Sigimond, I never doubted your kindnes unto me: but brother, aid Godomar, if you do not imploy it in any ervice, I hall not think you love me: for I ee how much you are troubled, and when will you make ue of your friend if not now? Brother, anwered Sigimond, I will acquaint you with my perplexities and then we will conider upon the bet expedients. Brother, anwered Sigimond, you mut know that Dorinde is gone, and I hould have accompanied her, but the malice of Ardilan hath hindred me. This poor Lady had none with her
but Dariana, and he has left her as you ee, o as he is in the wild woods all night long, and knows not whither to go: but I am mot troubled that Ardilan, knowing the anwer of the Oracle, will mot undoubtedly acquaint Gondebaut with it: and he who is enraged againt her, becaue he hath preferred my affection before his, will infallibly purue her, and if he find her do her ome harm: which if he do, I vow by Hercules and all the ret of the gods, that no repect, neither of King nor father hall hinder me from taking uch revenge, as it hall forever be remembred: and that Traitour Ardilan may be ure that I will pull his heart out, though he hould hide himelf in hell. The young Godomar tood ilent a while, and then aid unto him; I do foreee brother, that all thee things which you do fear, may come to pas: for when I was lat with the King, Ardilan came unto him, and told him all that you tell me concerning the Oracle: and preently after I aw them whiper together very cloe, and at lat the King raiing his voice, he called for Clorantes the Captain of the guard, and after another cloe conultation with him, go, aid he unto him, and prepare your elf with all the hat you can, and in the mean time your dipatch hall be made. I do ingage that he ent Clorantes to follow Dorinde, you know that of all the Guard, the King hath greatet confidence in him, and he the leat repect unto us: o as if you think good, I will tell you what I will do: I will with ome of my friends take hore, and follow after him, to hinder him from offering any violence unto that Lady. O brother, aid Sigimond, may I expect o good an office from you? I am extreamly offended, anwered Godomar, that you hould make any quetion or doubt of it. Brother, aid he unto him then, I beeech you pardon my paion, I do accept of your offer, and believe it there is no other way under heaven to preerve my life; let us then ee, aid Godomar, whom I hould carry with me, and aure your elf I will guard Dorinde afe from their hands.

After ome more uch dicoure as this, they advied together which of all the Cavaliers in the court they hould chue, who would be faithful unto them; of whom they found nine, and of which number Periander, Bellimartes, Cerates, and my elf, were four: and becaue time was not to be lot, they ent for us immediately, and without any concealment of their deigne, they asked if he would accompany Brince Godomar. As for Periander, Bellimartes, and I, we anwered, that we would not only accompany him: but rather then Dorinde hould upper any injury, we would leap down the walls of the Town, and follow him, to recue her, And the ret aid the ame; and then they commanded us to arm our elves and be ready within two hours to depart, that each of us hould bring along with him a confident friend: aud for fear of dicovery, to rendezvous at the houe of Bellimartes, becaue he had the command of the Town ouldiers, it would not be thought trange to ee o many perons together, but above all, to be ecret.

Not one of us failed according as was commanded, and the young Godomar was there at the time appointed; o taking hore as oon as we were all together, (becaue we heard Clorantes was gone with a good Troop,) we came to the gate. Ardil • n who was there and very officious, would needs know whether we were going: After Clorantes, anwered Bellimartes; but the King hath commanded, aid Adilan, to let none go out. Then Godomar advancing; How dare you irrah, aid he, be o bold as to controul me and my actions? open the gates without any further replies. Sir, anwered Ardilan, I did not ee you; but ince the King hath commanded me, I hope you will not take it ill, if I do not open them without a further command from him.

Ah Traitour (aid Godomar then, and laid his hand upon a Pole-ax which he wore at the pomel of his laddle) I will with one blow, give thee the jut reward of all thy treachery; and gave him uch a blow upon his head that he clove it quite in two. Thoe at the gate were o affrighted at this man, that not one durt deny opening the gates unto the Prince: For he being very well beloved amongt the ouldiers, and Ardilan hated for his intollerable arrogancy, the gates were preently et upon: and Godomar with all his company went out without any difficulty.

As oon as we were out, it was night, yet not very dark, though the Moon appeared not: We came to the Bridge from whence Dariana came; but finding none there, we went on towards Forrets; I think we lot our way twenty times amongt the mountains, not one of us knowing the right way unto Fevres, whither we aimed to go; and therefore our hores being almot tyred, we reolved to tay until it was day at the firt villages we came unto, and to take ome guides along with us. We did as we reolved; and when we asked where we were, thoe of the place told us, that we were far out of our way, and hould have taken much more upon the left hand, and mut of neceity return back o far as within the ight of Lions; which caued the young Prince almot to depair: yet one thing was a comfort unto us; which was, we undertood that Clorantes was not far before us, and that his hores were almot quite tyred. And asking which way he took, it was anwered, that he enquired the way towards Fevres; and therefore, as oon as it was day, we departed; but becaue our hores were as ill tyred as thoe of Clorantes, it was omthing late before we et out. One paage by the way did much pleae us, which was, that we met with an old man who was coming from the place unto which we were going, and who for his age walked very fat: The Prince riding up unto him, Father (aid he) did you ee a Troop of Hore pas this way towards Fevres? No Sir (anwered he) I aw none: But I oberved all along the way which comes from yonder Town which you may ee upon your left hand, a great track of hores: yet (replied the Prince) did you come from Fevres, and meet none? I was but a league further Sir (aid he) and have been guiding thither a young woman that is extreamly ad. That's he whom we do eek (aid the Prince, and turned towards us) Good Father (aid the Prince) tell us where he is whom you guided? Sir, aid the man, you hall know no more from me, for I know not whether you intend good or bad unto her. It is for her good (aid the Prince.) If it be (replyed he) the great Tautates peed you, and guide you where he is, for he knows your intentions, but I do not, and therefore dare not tell you any more, for he is worthy of aitance; and ince he did commit her elf unto my guarding, I hould be guilty of all the harm that befalls her. The young Prince admiring the vertue of this country fellow, did put his hand in his pocket, and gave him a piece of gold, and deired him to be as wie unto all as he had been unto him: Then paing on, we had not gone far, before we found the track which the old man told us of, and we followed it unto Fevres, where night coming on us, we reolved to tay, and enquire further news of Clorantes, which we did; for by fortune he had lodged in the ame place where we took up our quarters. Godomar then knew that he had found him whom he looked for, which was no mall atisfaction unto him.

In the morning, enquiring which way he took, it was told us that he was paed over Lignon, and indeed we found again the track of his hores feet, which conducted us unto a place where there was four ways, where we perceived he had made a Halt; for the track was very freh and new: but we were mot troubled to find, that of thoe four ways, three of them were printed with hores feet, which made us think that they were divided into three Troops.

The generous Prince (who was infinitely deirous to erve his brother) was of opinion, that it was bet for us alo to divide our elves into three companies, and each company take one of thoe ways. We being unwilling to leave him o lenderly guarded, did a little dorr at it; but he perceiving it; No, no aid he, you all promied to obey me, and I had rather die then fail in this firt occaion, upon any conideration of my peron. And therefore let Bellimartes, Periander, and Merindor, with their three friends take the way that paeth over Lignon, Cerates and five other Cavaliers take the way upon the right hand, yet not to pas over the Loire, and I (aid he) with ix others, will alo pas over Lignon upon the left hand; and at three days end, we will all of us rendezvous at yonder Temple which we ee tand in the midt of that plain, that we may conult what coure we hould take. Then after we had embraced each other, he was the firt that s • t forward.

We were all forced to obey his commands, though with much orrow to part,
yet ome good angel inpired him; for Bellimartes, Periander, and our mall Troop had not marched above a League and a half, but we overtook Dorinde yet in the hands of Clorantes, who was carrying her away: Heaven was o favourable unto our enterprie, that though we were but ix, and they fifteen or ixteen at the fewet, yet we defeated them, and took Dorinde from them, although our victory was very dearly bought; for we lot there the valiant Bellimartes, Periander lot a coen german, and I a brother; yet ince the Gods had made us o happy as to erve the Princes Sigimond and Godomar, and that fair and vertuous Lady, we endured the misfortune with much patience.

Now Madam, we have brought Dorinde into this City, who cats her elf under the helter of your protection as a afe Sanctuary; we hope that you will oblige thee Princes, and hew your elf to be a pious refuge for innocents.

Thus ended Merindor; and Amais began to peak: Generous Cavaliers (aid he unto them) Dorinde is by your valour brought unto a place where he hall find no wore uage then Galathea my daughter; and had I been ooner informed of your Quality, I would not have uffered either her or you to have had any other lodging then my own houe, which I offer unto all, with as much freedom as I have my elf: Alo I conjure you by your order of Cavalry, to promie me that you will go unto Prince Godomar at Mount Verdune, for I uppoe that to be the Temple where you are to meet him, and beeech him from me, to honour me o far as to come hither; where I have a mot extream deire to render unto him uch ervices as are due unto uch a great and generous Prince. Madam (anwered Periander) I know the Prince o civil, that he will not be o neer, and loe the honour of kiing your hand; beides, I aure my elf, that when he knows Dorinde is with you, he will (in atisfaction of that duty he owes unto his brother) come and thank you for this favour.

They had no ooner poke thee lat words But Leonide did acquaint Galathea that Dorinde and her company were in the Hall; of which Amais was o glad, that he bade Galathea go and receive them, and conduct them unto her; which office Galathea undertook very willingly; for undertanding that Lycidas the brother of Celadon was there, he was extreamly deirous to peak with him: She went therefore with a great number of Nymphs, who could not chue but admire the beauty of thee trangers, though the habits of Shepherdees did much dim the luter of their faces. Galathea who was informed who Florice, Cercinea, and Palanice were, after he had complemented Dorinde, he went unto them, and treated them o kindly, as was beyond their expectation. Madonthe hearing that thee trangers of her acquaintance were o near, he went unto them, and acknowledged her obligations unto them all, epecially Hylas, Lycidas, Tircis, and Palemon, and bade them mot kindly welcome: But when he firt aw them in thoe habits, he hardly knew them; and they eeing the rank which he held, did begin to bluh, and out of repect, keep at a ditance.

But Madonthe who loved the women very well, and deired that they hould ue the ame freedom with her, which they were wont; Did I think (aid he unto them) that the gaudery of my garments would make you keep at a greater ditance from me then you were wont to do, I protet I would this very hour leave them off, and never wear them again. Madam, aid Lycidas unto her, your curteie mut not make us continue in that crime which our ignorance of you caued us to commit. Alas Lycidas, replyed he, it cannot be called any crime, for am I not the very ame I was before? Doubtles you are, Madam, replyed Lycidas, but we are not in the ame errour that we were. Shepherd (aid he) unles you will cancel all thoe obligations wherein I am bound unto the curteous Shepherds, and fair Shepherdees of Lignon, I conjure you to be as familiar with me, as you were wont to be; and then (with Galatheas leave) I will hew you what I was in quet of amongt you in my diguie. Upon this, taking Florice by the hand, and Cercinea in the other, he carried them all into Damons chamber: Amais was there, who embraced all thee fair ones, and received them o kindly, that they were all very well pleaed. But when Galathea preented Dorinde unto her, he hewed her elf more repective of her, then any of the ret, for Prince
Sigimond's ake; and carried her unto Damon and Alcidon, they, Madonthe and Daphnide, aluted her.

Hitherto neither Adrates nor Hylas had poke a word; the firt becaue he was ravihed to ee the houe adorned after another fahion then the ruty cottages wherein he was brought up; and Hylas, becaue there was none in all the company who did put him into a mood of dicoure, but Madonthe, who till then did not ee him; Oh Hylas (aid he) are you there, and I not yet paid thoe devoirs which are due unto our ancient Friendhip? What opinion will you have of me? Better Madam (anwered he) then ever I had before. And yet (aid he) my incivility does not deerve it. You are mitaken, Madam, replyed he, I have a better opinion of you then ever I had; for me thinks we two are of humours alike. Oh heavens defend Hylas, (replyed he preently) for I would not reemble you in Incontancy. Nay, never fear it (aid he) for you can never arrive at that perfection; but my meaning is, that when I have that contentment which I deire, I care for nothing ele; and me thinks you do the ame now you have found this Cavalier; and I do o like the humour of it, that I do eteem you much more. Damon who could not chue but laugh at the anwer, did ask Madonthe in a low voice, who that Shepherd was; and being informed, Kind Shepherd (aid he unto him) will you give me leave to believe what this fair Lady tells me? Sir, anwered Hylas, doubtles you may, for nothing but good can come from o weet a mouth. yet anwered Damon, what he tells me, makes not for your advantage. Perhaps Sir, replyed Hylas, you may be mitaken; the ame merchandize bears not the ame price in all Countries; That which is extreamly dear in one Country, may perhaps be dog cheap in another. But that merchandize wherewith your pack is tuffed, as he tells me, replyed Damon, is not dear in any place of the world, epecially as I have heard amongt the Shepherds of Lignon; for he tells me, that you are full of incontancy. Me thinks (anwered Hylas) that you are o much obliged unto thoe of Lignon for keeping this fair Lady o long amongt them, that you hould have a better opinion of them; for had not their curteie and civilities tayed her o long there, perhaps you would not have found her there, but had wandered God knows whither before you had met her. I do mot thankfully acknowledge my obligations unto them (anwered Damon) and hould be very orry to dipleae them; but I thought that I had obliged them by what I aid. Did you not ay, replyed Hylas, that Incontancy was not dear in that Country? I did o, anwered Damon. Why then did you as good as ay, replyed Hylas, that there is great abundance of it; for abundance of any thing, be it never o good, makes it cheap. I did not o intend it, anwered Damon; but on the contrary, my meaning was, that on the Banks of Lignon your merchandize is not a aleable commodity, becaue none ever makes any ue of it. Oh Sir, replyed Hylas, you are extreamly mitaken in that belief; for there is not a place in all Gaul where the people know better how to love then they do who inhabite about thoe happy Banks of Lignon: That is the reaon, replyed Damon, why I believed that Incontancy was banihed from thence. Nay, aid Hylas, ince you are in that errour, I beeech you tell me, is not this the quality of all thoe that love well, to change themelves (as much as poibly they can) into the humours of thoe they love? And if it be, there is not one Shepherd who is not incontant; and where can you find one Shepherdes who does not o?

Oh Hylas, aid Madonthe, and interrupted him, you know very well that now you peak againt your concience. I hope Madam, anwered Hylas, that if I prove it, then you will ay as I do. I cannot believe (aid Daphnide) that you can prove it. Then anwer me unto thee quetions, aid Hylas: You ay that Hylas is incontant; and if Lovers do change themelves as much as they can into the homours of thoe they love, is it not certain that I loved Laonice, Phillis, Alexis, Stella, and many others? I do believe it, anwered he, ince you ay it. If o, aid he, then they were incontant, or ele in loving them I was not changed into them: And Lycidas, Corilas, and many others who loved them, they alo were incontant; or ele in loving them, they were not changed into them: o likewie all thoe who call themelves lovers of thoe whom I loved, do but call them to
account, and you hall find, that they have all taken of my merchandize, Damon could not chue but laugh at his concluion But Hylas, aid he unto him, though a man do change himelf as much as he can into the humour of the woman that he loves, yet the woman loved does not change her elf into the man lover •
and therefore if Phillis Stella, Alexis, and the ret did not love you, they did not participate of your Incontancy. They did love, anwered Hylas, there is no doubt of that; but yet my meaning was, that ince in loving them I remain incontant, it is to be believed that they are incontant alo • otherwie, ince I had loved them if they had been contant, doubtles I had become contant. And therefore Madam, you mut needs confes, that all about the Banks of Lignon are of the ame humour with Hylas. However (replyed Madonthe) you do not prove unto me that all are incontant: I will only intance poor Adrates there; for he would not be in that condition he is, if he could be incontant. Oh Madam anwered Hylas, he is not incontant, becaue he is mad, as all are that are not incontant.
Damon hearing that Adrates was out of his enes, he was very deirous to know all the particulars of that ad accident; and when he undertood it, he pittied him extreamly.

Palemon then, who ilently litned unto all the dicoure of Hylas, Madam (aid he unto Madonthe) if the mierable condition of this poor ditracted Shepherd have moved you unto any compaion, I beeech you become a mediator unto the Nymph Amais for his former liberty and enes. Why Palemon, anwered Madonthe, Do you think it in her power to cure him? We are o informed Madam, anwered Palemon; and ince the tryal will not cot any thing, we beeech you to intercede in the behalf of this poor Shepherd. I aure my elf (aid Madonthe) that if it be in her power, he will not deny us. Then taking the Shepherd by the hand, he carried him to Amais, who was talking with Dorinde; and jut at the ame time as Madonthe was preenting him unto Amais, the age Adamas returned from out of the Town, where he had given orders for every thing as was reolved upon. And becaue the Nymph aw him look with a countenance of much contentment, he was exceedingly deirous to peak with him: but being unwilling to interrupt Madonthe, who had already begun to upplicate in behalf of poor Adrates; and the Druide hearing her, Madam (aid he) Madonthes deire is jut; and though this be not concurrent with the Religion of Druides, yet ince the Romans firt began it, and it has continued a cutome ever ince, it is een by experience that it cures. Oh then (aid Amais) I will do all that is in me to retore this poor Shepherd unto his firt condition. The great Tautates Madam, aid Palemon, will reward you: and for my part, I do here make a olemn vow, that if he be cured, I will grant the firt requet that afterwards hall be asked of me, if it be within compas of my power, and be lawful to be done; ince the happines which I enjoy is partly a caue of his miery.

The Druid then, eeing every one ilent; Madam (aid he aloud, and addreed himelf to the Nymph) I come to acquaint you, that there are even Cavaliers come into the town, who inquire for Prince Godomar. Do you know their names, asked Periander and interrupted him; one of them, anwered he, is called Alcander, and the other, I think, Amilear. They, anwered Periander, they are none of our Troop; but they are of our acquaintance and are our friends. Circienea, who heard Alcander named, could not chue but bluh: and Florice, approching to the Druide. Thee two, aid he, whom you have named, are my brothers, and it is the mot happy news that could come unto me; and if we heard the names of the ret, perhaps alo, we hould have interet in ome of them: you may ee that, aid Adamas (and pulled out a paper which the guard at the gates had ent unto him) then they read the lit of them, Alcander, Amilcar, Silcines, Lucindor, Clorian, Cerintes, and Beliard: O heavens! cried out the trangers, the bet news that ever came: For, aid Circinea, Silcines and Lucindor are my brothers; Clorian and Cerintes are brothers unto Palanicae. I beeech you Madam, aid Florice unto Amais, give us leave to go and meet them: for it is o long ince we aw them, that we hould be extreamly grieved, hould they go away before we peak unto them. No, no, anwered the Nymph, I will end to intreat
treat them they will favour me o far, as to come hither, if they inquire of Prince Godomar, and I am very confident, that being your brothers, I hall find them o courteous as not to deny my requet. I beeech you Madam, aid Merindor, let us have the honour to go and let them know your pleaure, for I am mot confident they will obey you. So Merindor and Periander, having the Nymphs command, did go together with Clindor.

They were not gone half down the tairs which decend from the Catle, but they met them, and being advertied of their arival, they judged it to be them, though they were armed. Their meeting was with many demontrations of good will, as if the amity betwixt them were much augmented, ince the lat ight; and Merindor, having acquainted them with the deire of the Nymph Amais, they went altogether unto the Catle where they were entertained by the Nymphs and Cavaliers, with all manner of welcome; but thoe who aw the Carees which Florice, Cercinea, and Palanice, made unto their brothers, would have thought ome greater interet to be amongt them then that of kindred.

After all complements of civilitie were pat on both ides, for the Nymph was pleaed to permit to contentment unto the three iters, though it was her preence; Alcander addreed himelf unto her and aid, Madam, we have commiion from the Prince Sigimond, who hath ent after the Prince Godomar his brother, to aure you of his ervice: and that if any occaion preent it elf wherein he may give a tetimony of his affection, he will think himelf infinitely happy to receive your commands. Sir, anwered Amais, it is the exces of that Princes civility, which makes him ue uch language: but it is no wonder in him who is uch a profeed ervant unto all Ladies, but I hould rather wonder if he did not, ince I am of that number, But we are all o much obliged unto him, that we are bound to honour and erve him, as I for my part will do as long as I live: and ince you are in quet of Prince Godomar, I am very glad that you may hear uch certain news of him here, that your journey will not be lot.

Then Periander and Merindor acquainted Alcander where he might find him in the morning; and Alcander, looking about him, he aw Dorinde. This, this, Madam, is he (aid he unto the Nymph) which is the happy accomplihment of our journey, Dorinde is he that is the principal caue of Prince Godomars departure. I aure you, Madam, that when Prince Sigimond hall be advertied of it, he will recommend her unto you with all manner of affection, and will think himelf infinitly happy he is in your hands, I do alo think my elf very happy; anwered the Nymph, that uch an occaion is preented unto me, wherein I may do him this mall ervice untill a greater preent it elf.

Whilt they were thus dicouring, one came to advertie Adamas, that a Cavalier, whoe name was Cerates, was at the gates, with twelve others armed, who deire to enter: the Druid told it unto the Nymph aloud. But Periander and Merindor, hearing the name of Cerates, and that there was twelve in his company, Madam, aid they, aure your elf that it is the Prince Godomar, who has heard that Dorinde is here. I would I were o happy, aid he, as to ee o great a Prince in my houe, that I might offer unto him all that is with in compas of my power: will you be pleaed Madam, aid Periander, to let us go unto him and command that they may have entrance: for upon our words Cerates, and all those in his company are your ervants, and come hither only to render unto you all honour and obedience. Cavaliers, anwered the Nymph, command that all whom you hall pleae may enter, for I refer all unto your dipoition. Did I think that the Prince were in the company, I would go and • eet him, and offer him my Dominion and that is in my power. Adamas hearing the opinion of thee Cavaliers, ent in all hate to caue the gates to be opened, and to advertie him, as near as could be, of the truth. When all the Cavaliers were gone, he returned to the Nymph: Madam, aid he unto her, aure your elf that God has taken upon him your defence: See what unlookt for aid, he ends you. I conceive it fit, if Alcidon and Damon approve of it, that when this young Prince is come, you acquaint him with the tate of things, as well with the death of Clidamant, as with the treachery of Polemas: For it is out of all doubt, that the correpondency which
this wicked man holds with Gondebaut, will hinder from your aitance; this action in killing Ardilan at his coming out of the gates, does hew that this Prince loves his brother better then he does his father. For my part, anwered the Nymph, I will be ruled by you in all things: and calling for Damon and Alcidon, he command the Druid to acquaint them with what he had propounded, which they hearing, they were of the ame judgement, and advied Nymph to oblige the Prince as much as he could: for mot certainly Sigimond, (he having with her two perons o dear unto him) would end her relief if he tood in need of him.

Whilt they were talking of thee things, and putting all things in the bet order they could in the Catle to receive Godamar, all the Cavaliers came to the gates of the Town, in which the Prince was already entred unknown; but when they met, their joyes were o great, as it was impoible any longer to hide them. For they all run to kis his hand with o much affection and reverence, that every one knew him to be the Prince Godomar, of which the Nimph was preently advertied by thoe whom Adamas ent thither, and he was extreamly joyed at it. At the ame time Adamas, by her command went to receive him: and he accompanied with Galathea, Madonthe, Daephnide, her Nymphs, Dorinde and all the trangers, went all to the gates of the Catle, at which he was no ooner come, but the Prince with all this Troop arived, and in uch Majety, as made him manifetly appear to be the mater of all those that were with him.

As oon as he aw the Nymphs he alighted from his hore, and diarming his head, he appeared o handome and fair, that he attracted the eyes of all the Ladies upon him: and taking a hat, he went to alute Amais with uch a grace, that every one admired his deportment.
