After ome complements of civility, to which Amais anwered with the like repect, he addreed himelf unto Galanthea, and profeed abundance of ervice unto them both: I come Madam, aid he to pay that duty which all Cavaliers are obliged unto, and to aure you that Prince Sigimond and I are wholly devoted unto your ervice, and o are all thoe that have any dependency upon us: of which number, here are ome which we offer unto you, and all mot ready to defend you againt any that hall offer any wrong unto you, upon condition (added he and miled) that you will defend us from any wrongs we may receive from the beauty of thee Ladies, whom we ee about you. Sir, anwered the Nymph, were the defence which you are to undertake, no harder then that which you propound unto us, the danger would not be great: and yet aid he (with a miling countenance) ince generous Cavaliers are obliged to take upon them the protection of Ladies, my daughter and I do accept of your offer, and we beeech you to conider that we are not able to defend you from thoe wrongs which you foreee: For it were a hame unto o brave and valiant a Prince, to look for any relief from Ladies who are feeble and o timerous as we are.

Upon this Dorinde came and cat her elf at his feet, to thank for the pains he had teken for her, beeeching him not to forake her; and I believe, the Mymph Amais had aid omething unto her which prompted her thereunto: the Prince eeing her in that habit, did hardly know her, if he had not poke; but knowing her rather by her tongue then face, he very graciouly took her up and aluted her: Fair one, aid he unto her, the Prince Sigimond has o great a care of you, that you need not doubt any of thoe who have any dependency upon him, will ever forake you: beides, you are now under the wings of this great Nymph, who is pleaed to honour you o far as to take you into her protection, as I have commiion from Prince Sigimond my brother' mot humbly to beeech her to do: Your virtue and merits will alo oblige her unto it, and us to ait you, in all that we can to the uttermot of our power; upon this turning towards Amais, he aid unto her in a loud voice: The caue, Madam, of my voyage, and why I armed my elf, was only in defence of this fair one, and mot-humbly to beeech you that you would be pleaed to let her remain afe in your dominions, and in requital of the favour, the Prince Sigimond (my brother) and I, do promie for us and all our friends, to erve you upon all occaions whatsoever. Sir, anwered
the Nymph, I do receive this fair Lady into my protection, as well for her own merits and virtue, as at the intance of two uch great Princes: I do give unto her, as much power and freedome as I have my elf, auring you, he hall ure no wore then Galathea my daughter. After uch thanks as are uual upon uch offers, Alcidon aluted Godomar, who undertanding by Adamas who he was, did receive him with o much honour and o kind an apect as from that day this Prince won the heart and affection of that generous Cavalier.

At lat Godomar, after much other uch dicoure, was conducted to his chamber, where the Nymphs left him to diarm and refreh himelf, for it was extreamly hot: and whilt his arms were taking off, he related unto Periander and Merindor, how ince they parted, he marched a long way without meeting any. At the lat, aid he, we came to the top of a hill, where we dicovered all this goodly plain; and looking about every way, we epied about half a league from us, a troop of hore, which we thought to be Cloraentes: This invited us, after we had oberved which way they took, to take the ame track: and ometimes upon a Trot, and very often upon a Gallop, we made uch hate, we overtook them, as they were paing over a little river, where they watred their hores, We found it to be the Lieutenant unto
• lorantes, with fifteen or ixteen hore; we undertood from him, that they divided their Troop where we did ours: and becaue they aid that they had commands to be that evening at the ame place where they parted; I thought it not good to leave them, ince if by fortune any one of the companies had met with Dorinde, we hould find them with their Rendezvous. Not making my elf known unto them, one of my men told them, that the king having ent us upon the ame deigne, we thought that we could not do better then to tay toge • her, and help each other if occaion were. They were very glad of the motion, and o we m • rched all the ret of the day together: At the evening we came to the place of appointment, where we found Cerates, who had met with the very ame encounter, and who told me, that Clor • ntes was killed, and almot all his Troop, as he undertood by ome wounded men that had ecaped: That Dorinde was the caue of it, and that of neceity, it mut be the Troop of Bellimartes which had met with this happy encounter. You may imagine that the Lieutenant was much atonihed at this accident: and being a man of courage, I aw him reolved to follow after thoe that had relieved D • rinde, knowing that their enemy was but a few in number, Then dicovering my face, I aid unto him nay Sir, if you intend to revenge Clorantes, never look any further, for it was I, and thoe that belong unto me, that recued this innocent woman out of his rude hands: Tell king Gondebaut, it was his on that did it, and will do o as of • as I find any Lady injured. If he complain, tell him that the order of Knighthood which he hath conferred upon me, obliged me unto this defence: if he dilike the action, let him complain againt himelf for getting uch a son that has too much courage, to uffer any woman to be injured in his preence, and he not relieve her.

The ouldiers were o damped at the ight of me, and to hear this language, that they were all ready to run away. At lat, doing me that honour which was due unto me, they excued themelves as well as they could, and were extremely glad when I gave them leave to be gone. That night they went no further then the town where we had quartered, becaue their wounded fellows were retired thither: but I aure my elf, that the next day they told Gon • ebaut uch a tory, as will not incene him a little againt me: but when the heat of paion is cooled, I hope he will think we have done no more then Cavaliers of honour ought to do. As for us, when thee men were gone, becaue it was very late, we lodged in a place which is called Ponius, where we heard the whole tory of the combate with Clorantes, and that three of our Cavaliers were lain, which grieved me extremely. And latly, that you had carried Dorinde into this Town for afety. This news, made me reolve to wend my coure this way, and not unto the appointed rendezvous.

Thus Godomar related all his adventure, and had dreed himelf, when Alcander and thoe of his company came to kis his hands: for though he had een
them, yet had he not spoke unto them. After he had imbraced them, what good fortune, my good friends (aid he unto them) brought you hither, where I am very glad to ee you? Sir, anwered Alcander, when your going out of the Town, and the death of Ardilan was nois'd about the Town, we were extremely orry that we had not the honour to wait upon you: and becaue we heard that the Prince Sigimond was detained, we had an opinion that perhaps he could tell us which way you went, to the end we might be the firt that would follow you, though we were not o happy as to accompany you. Prince Sigimond did highly commend our deigne, and • onjured us to make all the hate that poibly we could to overtake you, fearing that you might tand in ome need of our ervice; he told us you were gone towards Forrets, and we could not be long about the river of Lignon before we heard of you: that if he could, he would follow us ere long, and that however, he would end unto you all thoe that declared themelves his ervants.
The next morning we departed, though not altogether, but at everal part and without arms, having conveyed them out ecretly before.

But I pray, aid the Prince, what aid the King when he heard of Ardilans death, and of my departure? Sir, anwered Alcander, I cannot relate the bitter expreions of his anger againt you, nor his orrows for the los of that pernicious man. But Sir, though the King do blame you, yet all the people bles you, and the Court commends you: The Prince your brother is o joyed at it, that he cannot chue but hew his extream contentment: o as the wie Avitus was forced to beeech him he would at the leat hide it, let it hould too much exaperate the King: Alo I aure you, the joyes of the Princes Clotilda were no les, who extremely commended you, o as Sir, this action has gotten you that glory which you will never loe: Beides, all the Ladies think themelves highly obliged unso you, for attempting the defence of this innocent woman. The Town does univerally abominate the violence which the king offered unto her, to make her marry A • dilan by force: and therefore you may expect a great number of Dorindes friends to ait you, as oon they know where you are: for they are all more generous then to be lack in the acknowledgement of o great an obligation unto you. Then, aid the Prince I give thanks unto God for directing us o well, and bringing our intentions to o good an end: If the King do but conider who I am, he will love me better then he did Ardilan; if he do not, then I am reolved with uch good company as will follow me, to follow uch fortune as heaven will pleae to give me: I aure my elf it will be good, and give us all contentment, ince jutice and equity are the ends which all our deignes do aim at. Sir, aid Alcander further, the Prince your brother hath o loadned me and all my companions with o many jewels to bring unto you, as I think they out-weigh our arms: And I believe, if we had been able to have carried more, he would have ent them unto you, let you hould tand in any need of uch things in your voyage. Upon this, they laid them all down upon the table, to the admiration of all beholders, at the ight of o many and o large and precious jewels together. The Prince received them in tetimony of his brothers good will, and care that he had of him: Not, aid he, that I think I hall tand in any need of them, as long as I have a word by my ide, and accompanied with o many brave men as I ee about me; but only becaue I will not refue the kindnes of my brother. Upon this, imbracing them all once more, he commanded one of his ervants to have a care of thoe things which his brother had ent unto him; and then, he with all the company, went out of the chamber unto the place where the Nymphs were, who tayed for him in the great chamber, where the cloth being laid, Amais would have him to dine. But he being advertied of Damons quality, and that his wounds kept him in bed, beeeched the Nymph to let him go and ee him before dinner, and tetifie that eteem which he had of his valour. Madonthe hearing this reolution did preently advertie Damon, who received that honour which the Prince did him, with much acknowledgement; and eteemed this favour at uch a rate, that it ever after obliged him unto his ervice. Every one admired the noblenes and generoity which appeared in all his actions, and his curteie and
weet deportment, did generally get him love of all. After the firt alutions, they entred into ome dicoures of civility, which lated not long, becaue dinner was upon the table, and therefore the Prince as contrained to abridge it, with a promie to continue longer in his company after dinner.

Thus therefore they parted: and Clindor in the mean time had obtained leave of the Nymph to take his guets unto his houe to dinner, becaue that abundance of company was come in upon a udden: He therefore carried with him all the Shepherds and Shepherdees, except Dorinde, whom Amais would needs have dine with Gal • thea; but then in lieu of her, he carried with him the ix brothers of Florice, Cercinea, and Palanice, who were not orry for it, becaue of the Interet which each of them had in thoe diguied Shepherdees. The Prince in the mean time ate down to dinner; and becaue the Nymph would have him waited upon with uch obervance as was due unto o great a Prince, he beeeched her to ue him only as a Cavalier, and a tranger, that would not yeild unto any in devotion to do her ervice; but not as the on of King Gondebaut, ince hereafter he would decline both that name and that quality. Sir, aid the Nymph unto him, I know that I hall pay that debt which I owe unto you, better by my obedience, then by any other way; command therefore what you pleae, both I, and all that depend upon me, will exactly obey.

With uch dicoure as this, they all ate down; and all dinner time the dicoure was only upon Dorindes fortune, and the extream orrows of Prince Sigimond, that he could not follow her; Dorinde, who aw and heard all this, he was o ravihed and confued, as he knew not what to judge of her fortune. 'Tis true, that when he called to mind the coming of Prince Godomar, the dicoure of his brothers orrows, and how he had recommended her unto the Nymph Amais, he thought that he was to blame in having conceived o ill an opinion of Sigimond: yet not knowing the reaon why he failed to meet her at the place appointed, according to his promie, he had a great deire to peak with Periander and Merind • r, auring her elf that they would not conceal the truth. And becaue he ate very ad and penive all dinner time, and the Prince oberving it: Dorinde, aid he unto her, confes the truth; are you not now thinking upon thoe frights which you were in? Sir, anwered he, I am now in the protection of uch perons as have power to banih all fears; but I mut needs confes, that never woman o affrighted as I was, when a ouldier eized upon me in Florices Cabin: And had you een us, you would have aid there was a wolf was eizing upon a lambe; and how, aid the Prince, did you ecape out of his hands? Al • xis, anwered he, the daughter of wife Adamas, who was in that place, gave him uch a blow with her fit upon his temples, as o atonihed him, that he was forced to let me go; but I believe, if you had een me running in the fields, and a great number of men following after me, you would have aid, that fear had fix • d wings unto my feet: and yet for all that, but for Bellimartes, Merindor, and Periander, they had carried me away; for one of them had eized upon me, but thoe Cavalie • s taught them what it was to injure a woman. I wih that I had been there, replied the Prince, for if I had, I promie you, not one of them hould have ecaped with his life. Sir, aid he, had you een them run away, I believe you would have pittied them: for I, who had mot reaon to be offended with them, I protet I had compaion upon them, when I was told what hate they made to return unto the place from whence they came: why, aid Amais, did you not ee him when they fled? I Madam? anwered he. I was o affrighted, that I ran and hid my elf in the cloet corner of the Cabin, and crowded my elf into as lettle room as ever I could. But Sir, I beeech you conider the malice of my fortune, who in denying me the honour of your enterprie, would afflict me o for as to give me my deliverance from them, that next Ardilan, I hated the mot of any men in the world, and to oblige me the more unto them, the one of them was killed, another lot a brother, and the third a Coen germane. I wear I was o enible of this dipleaure, that I hardly reented any contentment in my deliverance. By this, replied the Prince, (and miled) heaven hews us that hatred ought not to be perpetual, nor obligation forgotten. O
Sir, replyed he, be pleaed to know, that I had good caue to hate thoe, unto whom I am now in pite of my teeth obliged. At this Alcidon began to peak: In this Madam (aid he) you hew the nature and humour of all Fair ones; for I never yet aw one of your beauty. that did not always prefer offences before ervices; and which is wort of all, thoe offences are commonly imaginary, yet have as much force in them, as if they were real. I cannot tell Sir, anwered he, of what nature and humour fair ones are, but only by hear-ay, but I have had ufficient experience of the nature and humour of men, out of whom hitherto I never yet found but one who did not deceive her unto whom they promied fidelity. I would gladly know (aid the Prince and miled) who that Phaenix of Lovers is? It is Hylas Sir, anwered he. Hylas! aid Madonthe, why he is the mot incontant Lover that ever was, So he is (aid Dorinde) and therefore I think him the leat Deceiver; for he will ay freely and ingeniouly, that he will change as oon as he finds another that will pleae him better; and in doing o, he deceives no body: whereas others will wear and promie the contrary, yet afterwards do as he doth. I beeech you (aid Godomar) in what rank do you hold the Prince Sigimond. I aure you Sir, anwered he, that upon a udden I am much put to it for an anwer; yet I will tell you, that till I had the honour to ee you, I placed him in the rank with other men. But Fair one (replyed Godomar) what do you now? Now Sir, aid he, I have heard you peak highly in his behalf: But Sir, I conider that you are his Brother, and perhaps are partial in your relations: You are very incredulous (anwered the Prince) if you believe neither words nor deeds. I will believe (aid he) whatoever you pleee, but I am afraid to be deceived again by any man. That hall never be by Godomar, replyed he, for if I hould, I hould too much injure the affection which my Brother bear unto you.

At the ame time Periander and all his company whom Clindor had carried with him, returned, and came into the great chamber, and becaue 'Dorinde was deirous to break off dicoure with the Prince; Sir, aid he unto him, if you do not know Hylas, cat your eye upon that plain Shepherd, whoe hair is a little inclinable to red, and you may ee the man that of all Lovers living is the leat diembler. Upon this Godomar, and all thoe that heard Dorinde ay o, did cat their eyes upon Hylas; who eeing o many look upon him, did think that omthing was amis about his clothes, and therefore began to look on himelf round about: But Daphnide who oberved him; No, no, Hylas (aid he unto him) they do not look at any thing in your habit, but at omthing in your oul. My oul, aid he, then they mut have more piercing eyes then ever Ly • x had, if they ee it. I believe it o (aid Dorinde) to ee the inide of any other but Hyla Hylas (replyed he) is the on of a woman. Then Shepherd, aid Godomar, if you delight in changing, you have ome to reemble. Sir, aid Hylas, I leave the Ladies to draw the concluion which you intimate. But Hylas, aid Dorinde, I hope you will confes with me, that there are more men peridious unto women, then there are women perfidious unto men: For there is not one woman which does not complain againt ome infidelity or other, but I never find any man that complains he hath been deceived. Your argument Madam is very naught (replyed Hylas) for if men do not complain againt your infidelities, it is becaue they are ahamed to complain againt a thing o common and ordinary. Godomar began to laugh, and o did Amais at this merry anwer of Hylas; and interrupting Dorinde who was about to anwer, me thinks (aid he unto her) this Shepherd has in a few words very well defended our caue.

She would have replyed. When Amais and the Prince did rie from the Table, o as this dicoure was referred until another time: But Godomar drawing to Dorinde, Believe it fair one (aid he unto her in a low voice) the Prince my Brother loves you above his life, and when I have leiure to talk with you, or you know what meage he hath ent you by me, you will confes that he deerves to be ranked in the number of thoe who do mot perfectly love; and becaue he turned uddenly towards Amais, he gave her not o much time as to anwer him; yet he bluhed, not being able to hear this news without much reentment: and turning towards Florice, Palanice, and Cercinea, my companion (aid he, to hide the alteration)
of her face) I hould be orry to diturb your company, but the Prince Godomar does oblige me o many everal wayes, that I am reolved not to forake you this night; for though the Nymph has lodged me in the Catle, yet I think it better to return unto our firt Hot, ince he deires it, and ince this houe is o full, that one can hardly turn themelves in it. I am afraid (anwered Florice) that the Prince is o fearful to loe you, that he will not permit it. Yet, aid Cercinea, it would be more convenient for us to lodge out of this houe, where we mut be in a continual contraint.

Godomar in the mean time who was very deirous to get the friendhip of Damon, of whoe valour he had received good information; he beeeched Amais to give him leave to pend part of the afternoon with him; and he anwering that he would accompany him, Madonthe ent preently to advertize him; and thoe who went to tell him, found already with him Thamires, Celidea, Palemon, Doris, and the poor Adrates, who never forook Doris, but followed her, as if he were enchanted, unles when he went to bed and bolted the door: for the poor Shepherd lept there, or at the leat lay there, and never tirred from thence until he went out again; and had not Palemon given him a Blanket, he had lain upon the hard boards, rather then have tirred from the door. When the Prince entred, Thamires was beeeching Damon to remember his promie concerning Celideas cure: And becaue Damon told him that he was ready o any would go with Halladine his ervant, Thamires offered to undertake the voyage himelf; Celidea being unwilling to let him go o far from her, had rather never recover that Beauty which he lot, then let him undertake a voyage o dangerous, for a thing of o worthles a value; he reolved that if he would needs go, he would accompany him. And becaue Thamiris would not upon any terms uffer that, the woman cryed o, that when the Prince entred he pitied her, to ee her eyes o well'd with tears; and enquiring of Thamires (whoe daughter he thought he was) what wrong had been done her; Sir (aid Damon, and anwered for him) you deire to know a thing which I believe is without example. Be pleaed to know, that this young Shepherdes was one of the fairet women in all the Country, you ee how her face is now; they offer to retore unto her that Beauty which he lot, and he cries at the motion. Certainly (aid Godomar) this humour is ingular. But Sir, aid Damon, tranger yet; he her elf did make her face o. How? aid the Prince, Did he difigure her elf? Yes Sir, aid Damon, and upon as trange a reaon; for it was to keep her elf from being loved. Heavens! aid the Prince, a woman not to be equall'd, who being fair, makes her elf foul, becaue he would not be loved; and afterwards angry when they offer to retore that Beauty! Sir, aid Celidea, and interrupted, Things that give us no contentment, and which bring us much inquietude, ought to be o rejected. I mut needs confes (aid the Prince) that I ee uch tetimonies of Vertue in this place, as cannot be enough admired. But Sir, replyed Madonthe, I beeech you cat your eye upon this poor Shepherd here, who is gazing upon this Tapetry; did you but know his fortune, you would admire it more, and if Dorinde would tell the truth, he would confes that all men are not deceivers when they profes to love: for he having long loved this Shepherdes, when he was out of all hopes of her being his, he lot his wits, and has ever ince o reented his los, that when he has any good intervalls, he employs them in nothing but in complaining againt her. I have heard ay (anwered the Prince, and looked upon him) that Love may make one mad, but not grief, nor dipleaure. But Sir, aid Amais, they tell us of a Receipt which may cure him, and which we intend to try. What is that? asked the Prince. It is Sir, replyed Adamas, to drive a nail unto the Temple of Jupiter, in the wall which is toward the Vetry of Minerva; and this nail mut touch the Temples of the ditracted party. Indeed anwered Godomar, beyond the Alpes I have een it ued, and many have been cured. I aure you Sir, replyed Amais, if you think it good, we will make tryal of it; for we have thoe two Temples of Jupiter and Minerva very near one another. I think it a work, replyed the Prince, very pleaing unto the Gods; for me-thinks there is no ight under heaven o ad, as to be deprived of his wits, as if Nature had failed in her work, and made a brute Beat in lieu of a rational man. Then (aid
the Nymph, I think it fit to advertie the high Priet of it, that he may come and let me undertand what is requiite to be done: and Adamas (aid he) I commit the charge of it unto you. And I (aid Damon) as oon as I ee what will be the effects of it, I will dipatch Halladin about the cure of this wie and vertuous woman, according to my promie; and I think it a work no les pleaing unto the Gods then the other: for they are much more pleaed with the Beauty of Women, then they are with the wits of men; and, as they ay; have often decended from heaven to behold thee mortal Beauties, but very eldom have let heaven to take the advice of any man upon earth.

Whilt the Prince was thus dicouring with Damon, Adamas took Amais a little apart, and repreented unto her, that it eemed Tautates took a more particular care of her buines then ever he could hope for, ince he had ent this young Prince o opportunely, and of uch near concernment to his brother Sigimond, as he might in all probability hope for all manner of help from him, as long as he had Dorinde with her: But it was mot requiite that he hould prudently take hold of that occaion which preented it elf: for nothing upon earth was better pleaing unto the Gods, then to ee a man prudently defend himelf againt the blows of Fortune: Now Madam, the greatet thing you have to fear, is the Intelligence which the Traytor Polemas holds with the Kings your Neighbours; the mot powerful of all which, and the mot dangerous, is Gondebaut: And ee how this great God hath enfeebled his arm, by giving you, as it were two of his children; and in as much as there are always more perons that do adore the riing Sun then the etting, aure your elf Madam, that thee two young Princes well united as they are, will have more partakers then their Father. That which depends upon your prudence is, to interet thee two Princes o in your preervation, that they may embrace it as a thing wherein in themelves are concerned. Sigimond is already obliged to ait you, by the protection which you give unto this woman, whom he loves o extreamly, that I hope to ee her Queen of the Burgundians, if I urvive King Gondebaut. All the work is to find out a way to interet his brother Go • omar, for my part, I conceive, that beides the dear affection which he bears unto his Brother, you ought to oblige him further by the ways of curteie, till time preent a better occaion; for a oul o generous as his, cannot be fater tyed then by honour, reverence, and kindnes. And becaue thee Letters which Gondebaut writ unto Polemas, and which are fallen into our hands, may be redoubled, and o Polemas come to be advertied ooner then we are aware, of your los, I conceive it good to prevent his deigns; which you may do this way that I hall propoe unto you. You intend that a nail hall be driven into the wall of Jupiters Temple for the recovery of this poor Shepherd: I conceive it Madam, to be a good work, and pleaing unto the great Tautates: and I conceive, that by this occaion you may preva •• with Prince Godomar to tay here. It is requiite that he which drives this nail, mut be the Prime Magitrate; and becaue you are not a man, it is neceary that you make a Dictator exprely for this ceremony; for that's the phrae and title which the Romans give unto uch a one: Now Madam, I believe that when you have well thought upon it, you will not make choie of any other peron but Prince Godomar, as well in conideration of his quality, as the welfare of your affairs: And I aure my elf, that upon this occaion he will take this honour upon him, which perhaps he would refue at another time: And if he do once take it upon him, then let him continue it until you be freed from the treaon of Polemas: By this coure you will make him as tender of your preervation, as of his own, and thereby alo engage the Prince his Brother, and all his Friends.

The Nymph did hearken very attentively unto the Druide; and when he had done, I do approve (aid he) of all you ay); But what mut I now do? You ought Madam (as I humbly conceive, aid the Druide) to acquaint the Prince, that for the cure of this poor Shepherd it is neceary he accept of this charge. And when all ceremonies are performed, aemble with him Alcidon and Damon, then declare unto him the death of Clidemant, the treaon of Polemas, the correpondencies which you fear he holds with the Princes your neighbours; and I am mot confident, that he being generous, will embrace your defence as willing as you
can deire him. And becaue you mut not dioblige Alcidon and Damon, I conceive it good, that before you acquaint the Prince Godomar, you talk with them, and ask their advice, and I believe they will o freely concur, as they will ait you in your deires unto that Prince.

Whilt they were thus dicouring, Godomar went towards Damon, where Alcidon, Daphnide, and Madonthe were talking of the accidents which befel Dorinde, and becaue that Prince did think that the habit wherein he was (though much different from what he was wont to wear) did well become her, and that he appeared very fair in it, he took a fancy to have her picture drawn in that dres; auring himelf, that his Brother would take great delight to ee her o diguied: And therefore Galathea (Who was talking with Lycidas, and highly pleaed to ee ome Ayr of Celadon in his face, whom he could not entirely forget) hearing her elf called by Madonthe, he went preently unto them; and hearing what Godomar deired, he told him, that he had a very excellent Artit, that could take a piece to the Life, and was very dextrous and quick at it. Such a man (aid the Prince) do we want; for I am deirous to end very peedily unto my Brother, and let him undertand our Fortune, of which I know he will be very glad, o as I would not delay this contentment any longer. The Nymph to atisfie his longing deire, ent preently for the Limner, who at her command, fell immediately to work though Dorinde was very unwilling, being ahamed to be een in that dres. Why Fair one, aid the Prince, can you be een in better company then is here? No Sir, anwered he but I am ahamed to be een thus any where but in this Country, where the Shepherdees are uch, as beget the admiration and eteem of all that ee them. Then for your atisfaction aid the Prince, we will write under your Feet,
div.q: This is DORINDE, one of the Fairet Shepherdeses of all Forrets.
div.p: Upon this condition he permitted them, provided they would leave out the Epithet Fairet. In the mean time, Amais having found an apportunity of peech with Damon and Alcidon, whilt the Prince went to ee the Artit take Dorindes picture in the next room, he acquainted them according to the advice of Adamas; and they did o approve of the propoition, that they themelves acquainted Godom • r with the dicoure, when he returned into D • mons chamber: and he was all curteie, accepted of whatoever the Nymph was pleaed to impoe upon him. Therefore he ending for Adams, he commanded him in the Princes preence, to prepare all things in readines for that action.

The day o paed away in variety of dicoure amongt thee Nymphs, Cavaliers, Shepherds, and fair Shepherdees, with o much delight and pleaure, that night urprized them before they were aware of it, and forced them to part till the next morning. Amais would have tayed Dorinde in the Catle, but he and her companions made o many entreaties, and were o unwilling to eparate, that the Nymph permitted her to return into the houe of
• li • dor, who bade them mot freely welcome, where they were much more free then they could be amongt o many contraints and obervances which they mut of neceity ue towards Amais and Galathea. Merindor and Periander waited upon Dorinde: Alcander and Clorian upon Cercinea, Lucindor and Cerintes upon Glorice, and Amilcar and Selienes upon Palanice. • hamires again kept cloe unto his ad C • lidea, who was quite dejected at the approaching departure of her dearet Shepherd, and Adrates never left following Doris, whom Palemon led by the arm: There was none of all the company who was without his charge but Hylas and Belliard, who yet paed away the time very pleaantly with all the Ladies, without being engaged unto any one: Alo there was none in all the company who had not buines of their own to follow, without minding Hylas; for Alcander and Clorian courted Cercinea, Lucindor and Cerintes loved Florice, and Amilcar and Seleines were ervants
unto 'Palanice, and the bet conceit was, every one knew of the affection of his Rival. On the other ide, Periander and Merindor adored Dorinde, who having been deceived by them, as he thought, did nothing but twit them with their infidelity, as often as they mentioned any affection to her; which he did with a more contented mind then before, when he thought that Prince Sigimond had alo deceived.

When they were come to the houe, thee Cavaliers, to regain the time which they had lot in being o long from them, reolved to tay as long as ever they could in thee Ladies chambers: But Dorinde would not upon any terms permit them, excuing themelves that they mut go to bed betimes, becaue they mut rie very early, to be at the Catle before Galathea was up. Then they were contrained to retire: and as fortune was, Hylas was lodged in the ame chamber where Alcander, Amilcar, and Beliaid did lie, and the other four Cavaliers in another chamber. And becaue thee two brothers had been long friends unto Hylas, as oon as they were in bed, and their beds tanding very near unto one another, they fell into dicoure of all paages that hapned ince lat they aw each other. For my part, aid Hylas, I hall quickly have told my tale; for ince Creeide, that fair tranger, ecaped the Guards of King Gondebaut, and went towards Gergovia, I followed her; but all in vain. for I could never find her. 'Tis true, I met with Madonthe and Laonice, with whom I came into this countrey, and found in it o many very handome Shepherdees, that I could not poibly leave them And to tell you truly, I have tated of all waters, and tried all kind of lives; but I find none comparable to the weet lives of Shepherds in this countrey: for though their garments be coure, and their converation mell a little of the Village, yet they are more dicreet, and more civil, then any I ever covered withall. Amongt the ret, there is one Sylvander, whoe acutenes of wit cannot be ufficiently admired nor commended. As for the Shepherdees, they are fair and handome, beyond all expreion or imagination: All the orts and ad • lterations of cities are o far excelled by the natural gaynes of thee Shepherdees, as it is impoible to look upon them and not love. You have een Florice, Palancie, and Cercinea, everal times, and have heard how their beauties have been cried up in Lions: Let them come amongt the Shepherdees of Licynon, and they are but as o many candles to the Sun. Fie, fie, aid Alcand • r until now I will pardon you, but to ay that any Shepherdes under the Sun is fairer then Circinea, I cannot endure. Had you poke only of Florice and Palanice, I hould have thought it omething probable; but as for Cercinea, no beauty upon earth ever equall'd hers. Brother, aid Amilcar, and interrupted him, Palancie mut challenge preheminence above all beauties that ever lived, and will ufficiently anwer for her elf: As for Florice and Cercinea, let Hylas ay what he pleaes, o he leaves Palanice out of his comparions, ince it is not reaonable, that he whom heaven never gave an equal, hould o unjutly be inferioured.

What my ons? (aid Hylas unto them and miled) have you any interet in thee women, that you take their parts o zealouly? Any interet, anwed Alcander; good Hylas, in what countreys have you been in, that you are o ignorant of it? what interet, and ince when? replies Hylas, for when I was with you, I never knew of any. Have you been at Lyons, aid Amilcar, ince the death of Thombres? No, aid he: Then, aid Amilcar; the affection which we have unto thoe fair Ladies began ince that time. Alo, if you remember, it is not long ince our father caued us to return home to his houe, True, anwered Hylas, but have you been ever ince in love? I think there requires more time in contracting love then fiendhip.

I believe, anwered Alcander, there is more time requiite to the choice of a friend then a mitres. Then, replied Hylas, (ince it is o, and ince we are entred into dicoure) it is not likely any of us can leep o oon, I beeech you let me know all the tory of your affections, that I may give my elf a check when I peak of the beauty of your Mitrees. I will, aid Alcander, upon condition you will not any more, for my ake, dipie the beauty of Cercinea, nor of Palanices for my brothers ake. No, nor you Stellas (anwered the incontant) for Hylas
his ake. We do promie it, aid Alcander, but one thing is very requiit before I begin. What's that? aid Hylas, you mut either come into our bed, aid Alcander, or ele we come in yours: for it hall be a great trouble unto me to peak o loud. It is but reaon, aid Hylas, that the choller hould go unto the mater: o leaping out of his bed, he went into theirs, where after a while Alcander began thus, whilet Belliaid lept.

div.head: The Hitory of ALCANDER, AMILCAR, CERCINEA, PALANICE, and FLORICE.
div.p: THere are ome who ay that love proceeds neither from impathy nor detiny but from deigne and will of the lover: and that the original of this affection has its rie from the violence of beauty, which does tiranize over the faculties of the oul: but uch, have not had that experience which Amilcar and I have had: for had they, they would preently be of another opinion, and confes with us, that every one is at his nativity detinied unto her whom he mut love and erve. This is a poition (aid Hylas and interrupted) which I cannot believe nor grant: for were it o, nuto which of the thirty or fourty whom I have erved will you decree me by impathy and detiny? To that, anwered Amilcar, we will peak another time; for a general rule mut till be oberved, though it may haue ome exceptions; and beides, Hylas is a monter in love, quite different from the nature of other lovers. This, anwered Hylas, and miled, mells of Silvander, but Alcander continued.

You mut know, aid he, that a little before the marriage of Florice, iter unto Amilcar and me, unto Theombres, our father ent for us to return home unto his houe, having no mind until then, that we hould be with him, until we had o qualified our elves utable to the degree of our Ancetours. In our more tender yeares he ent us to the mot famous Univerities, to be intructed in the liberal Sciences and Arts: when we were grown to be more men; he caued us to be taught in all the exercies and behaviours of the body, as riding, fencing, dancing, and the like: and afterwards ent us abroad to learn the languages, and know the manners and cutomes of our neighbours; then when we were arived at the age of two or three and twenty years, he ent for us home unto his houe, where we were uch trangers in our own countrey, and knew o very few, that had we not been told Florice was our iter, we could not have known her to be o.

Our return was (as you know) a little before Florices marriage, and when we began to love one another, Theombres carried her out of the Town: o as we lot her almot as oon as we found her: but heaven it eems had pity upon us, and retored her back in a hort time, by the death of Theombres, who lived not above three months after he was married. She took her los as he ought to do, and we helped her in this charitable office, but our tears were quickly dried up: for the dipoition of this man was not very pleaing, and he married him rather as a fortune then as a lover, without any fancy to him.

Our iters orrows unk not o deep into her oul, but he was quickly comforted by the affection which we expreed unto her; and he in requital to make our tay at home with our father, as little tedious unto us as poibly he could: and doubtles that droning kind of life, o different unto that which we had been accutomed unto, had been intollerable to us without her weet converation. Some dayes after Florice was returned home, and her mourning not of o deep a black, but would allow her colours, he took notice of the melancholy lives we led, and few recreations we frequented: Brothers, aid he unto us, I am orry to ee you droop thus; but I mut divert you ome wayes or other, o as you hall find this place not o drowie as you did at firt. Our father does tire you with thee viits
of kindred, who never talk of any thing but erious matters: but I will make you acquainted with ome of my aociates, and dare lay a wager, you will not think them o dull and tedious as his. We who had lived with our father in a kind of imprioned contraint, and could not indure it any longer, did intreat her to be as good as her word. She deferred the effecting of her promie, no longer then the next morning, when he carried us unto the houe of Cercinea, where we found Palanice, Dorinde, Cloris, Parthenopea, and ome others, all very fair and handome women. But Hylas, to prove the detiny which I poke of, I did no ooner cat my eye upon Cercinia, but I found in her o many allurements unto love, that I could not deny her my heart, and my soul: My brother alo at the ame time thought Palanice o lovely, that he could not chue but betow himelf wholly upon her.

Now let thoe who think that it is beauty which doth tiranize over our ouls, tell me the reaon why Cercineas beauty hould not tiranize as well over the oul of Amilcar as mine; or why Palanice hould not have as powerful an influence upon my heart, as upon my brothers? I am confident that mauger all their reaons, they will confes, that it was detiny and fate that did dipoe of us as they pleaed.

Detiny, I ay, decreed that we hould at one and the ame time receive two great loes: for the los of our liberty, was preently after econded with the los of a father, who being of a great age, was alo eized upon by a violent feaver, which in few dayes brought him to his grave. Perhaps if the new affection which we had conceived unto thee two Ladies, had not been written in the fatal book of detiny, this lat los might have tifled it in his grave: for the truth is, we took it more adly to heart then others ue; but Hylas, what can reit fatality? For our affections by this contrariety, increaed as a flame will by contrary wind.

There is nothing which hinders a growing love from taking deep root, more then to be out of ight of the party loved, becaue the eyes are they that give beginning unto love, and the ight does nourih it and make it grow: o as when this ight is denied, commonly love dies, or at leat languihes. But this, we found, might hold true unto others, who love by election, but not unto us who were decreed unto it by unreitable Fate: for being contrained to oberve the ceremonies of mourning, we were a long time deprived of the ight of thee beauties, but all would not do any good: only helped to make our miery more painful, and hard to be indured.

But the dayes of deepet mourning being pat; it is the cutome, upon uch accidents for friends and nighbours to come and viit the mourners, as well to condole with them and offer their aitance, as to renew that amity and friendhip which they formerly had with the predeceour. All our friends and neighbours, failed not to pay thoe duties of civillty: o as our houe was frequented as much as any famous Temple; Palanice and Cercinea, amongt the ret that were intimate friends unto my mother and iter, were not failing at this viit: and we who were almot alwayes with Florice, were, heaven knows, mot glad to ee them. The truth is the death of our father did greatly afflict us; and there was not the leat appearance of any mirth in our houe, until thee two fair Ladies were pleaed to come unto it. But then, I mut confes, the mourning of Amilcar and me, did vanih like a cloud before the Sun. When Cercinea had complemented my mother a long while, he came to render the ame civilities unto Florice: and becaue I could never atisfie my eyes with looking upon her, I drew near unto my iter; and after I had thanked Cercinea for the pains he was pleaed to take in coming to a houe o full of orrows, and that in requital of this honour, we offered unto her all our ervices, Florice was contrained to go and ay as much unto Palanice: o as Cercinea and I remained together at a ditance from the ret of the company: this invited me, in puruance of my former dicoure, to ay unto her; the truth is, fairet Cercinea, I have very little reaon to thank you for this favour, ince I foreee more harm then ever I can hope for good by this viit. She who did not yet perceive the affection which I had unto her, for all former demontrations
of kindnees were received only under the notion of civilities and courteies, I cannot tell Alcander, aid he unto me, what harm my viit may do unto you; but I am ure that I have no intentions of doing any: if you have no intention Madam (aid I unto her) then it is my detiny, for certainly Cercinea will be the caue of Alcanders death: Who I? aid he, the caue of your death? Doubtles you will, anwered I: but I will pardon you, not being my elf able to be dipleaed with it.

Upon this we were parted, by the coming in of a great number of Ladies, and after that, I could not renew this dicoure all that day. In the mean time Amilcar, who would not, no more then I, loe this opportunity, he accoted Palanice. I did not think Madam, aid he unto her, that the beauties of this countrey had been o cruel as I find them; what cruelties Sir, aid he, do you complain of? of yours Madam, replied he, who are not contended to ee this houe o full of adnes, but you will add more orrows unto it. Your orrows, replied he, and miled, are doubtles to be condoled; but I do not ee which way I am any addition unto them, or if I be, I am ure it is very innocently. That innocency, aid he, is not enough to repair my los which you have caued, without ome other cordial.

Doubtles their dicoure had continued longer, had they not been interrupted by the ame accident which evered Cercinea and me. And judge whether detiny did not drive us both unto this affection, ince the words by which we made the firt overtures of our loves unto thee Ladies, were almot the very ame, although we did not conult together about it.

Now though thee few words wrought no great effects, yet they erved, at the leat to open the eyes of Cercinea and Palanice, and let them know that we were in love with them: And upon the next opportunity of dicourse with them, we found not the difficulty o great to make them undertand us. It was not long before we had that opportunity, for when the firt dayes of mourning are pat, it is cutomary to return thoe viits which we received: and you may well imagine that my brother and I were not very backward in paying uch debts unto thoe fair ones, with whom we might have what opportunity of peech we pleaed. Florice who accompanied us thither, and oberved that I had talked very long unto Cercinea, when we were returned, he took me aide, and aid unto me: I forgot brother to advertie you, when I hewed you Cercinea, that you hould have a pecial care of being urpied by her beauty: for he is o engaged another way, as I fear you will take abundance of pains for very mall contentment: O my dear iter, anwered I, your councel comes too late, for I am already o deeply engaged, that there is no hopes of any retreat till death. O Heavens brother, cried he, I pity you extremely, and am very orry that I was the caue of your eeing her, for there is not a beauty in all the countrey more likely to make one in love then he. You mut know that Clorian brother unto Palanice does o poes her, as I believe none whomoever can divert her from him. Siter, aid I unto her, you atonih me extremely, in telling me he is o engaged unto a man: perhaps, anwered he, I do not mean as you do, when I ay that he is engaged unto Clorian, my meaning is, that he being brother unto Palanice, and Palanice the mot intimate friend of Cercinea; and beides, the husband which Palanice had (for you mut know he was married) being uncle unto Cercinea, and as long as he lived, he was alwayes with his wife: thee coniderations hath caued Cercinea to honour her, as much as if her husband was living: o as Palanice has a great command over her, and he loving her brother Clorian extremely well, he gives him uch acces unto Cercinea, and has uch a hand over her, that he dare hardly turn her eye without her leave. Not that I will ay he loves him, or that any thing has paed between them that is unhandome, for he is eteemed to be a very virtuous and dicreet Lady. But certain it is, that he being without father or mother, he uffers the iter of Clorian to have o much authority over her, as it is not credible any ele can be entertain'd. If it be o, aid I, that Clorian loves her, and that Palanice has all the power, why is not the marriage compleated? very many, anwered he, who are ignorant of the caue, and yet ee their affections,
have asked the ame quetion; but in anwer to it, you mut know that Cercinea has two brothers, the one of which is extremely in love with Palanice, and becaue he loves him not, and to colour it, pretends he will not marry again, he is reolved that Cercinea hall never marry Clorian, unles Palanice take him for her husband; and Palanice being obtinate, is the caue why Clorians contentment is retarded: This iter, replied I, is the bet news you could tel me, for certainly if I had no hopes of Cercinea, there was no hopes in my life: But Siter, if you love me, let me be acquainted with the Brother of Cercinea, that I may, if it be poible, gain him. Brother, anwered he, and miled, I would acquaint you with another ecret if I durt, and which perhaps may be more advantagious to you. Dear Siter, aid I unto her, I conjure you, as you love my life, conceal nothing that may advantage me in this buines; for heavens ake out with it, ince nothing ought to be hidden betwixt us. Florice miled, ince you deire it o eriouly (aid he) I will tell it unto you; but Brother, upon condition you receive this tetimony of my affection to you, as the greatet that I can do you.

Know then, that Cercinea has two brothers, the elder is called Selenes, and the younger Lucindor: The elder (as I told you) is deperately in love with Palanice; and Luci • dor; at this word he topped and miled, and Lucindor (aid I) is in love with Palanice too: Nay, nay, replyed he, and miled, it is not o; and then laying her hand upon her eyes, which made her more confident to peak, he aid, and Lucindor ays he loves me, though I do not believe him: but I dare boldly ay, that at my entreaty he will do you the bet ervice he can, for I am confident he will not deny me any thing I ask. Oh dearet Siter (aid I, and took her hand) my life and my death is in your hands, and if you do not help me in this condition which you your elf have caued, you are the mot merciles Siter that ever was. Oh Heavens! Alcander (aid he unto me) what a task do you put upon me? And what will Lucindor ay of me? Do you not conider how I hall engage my elf unto him? Siter, aid I very eriouly, I beeech you hear me, and mitake me not; but be aured that if my affection to Cercinea were not qualified with all the conditions of a vertuous Love, I would rather die, then employ you in it: I do love her with intention to marry her, not abue her. And as for Lucindor, he being the Brother of Cercinea, I will think him to be a man of merit; and if he be, why may he not marry you? Your young years will not let you continue long in a widowed habit; and for my part, I will never advie you hould Oh Brother, replyed he, talk no more of that I beeech you for Theombres is yet too freh in my memory to entertain any uch thoughts. Oh the groet piece of folly that ever was, replyed I; Do not I know that you married him only out of obedience to my Father and yours? And what great affection could you therefore have unto him? Ah Alcander, anwered he and miled, you are very pleaantly dipoed; why might not I conceive affection unto Theombres in three moneths pace, as well as you unto Cercinea in a moment? Oh Brother, did you know how the Bonds of marriage do oblige every good wife unto it, you would change your dicoure: For the knots of it are tyed to fat, and are o dear, that they can never be unlooed without reentments of orrow, o as a eparation is like unto that of the oul and the body. But though this conideration which is very great, had no force in me; yet there is another which is prevalent enough to keep me from any more marriages, which is Brother, The extream jealouie which he had conceived of me, o as I thought my life to be a torment unto me: As for Theombres, I hould have thought my elf the happiet of all my Family, had he not taken this toy in his head. Now after all thee great inconveniences, would you have me o mad as to plunge my elf into the like mieries again? Why Siter, aid I unto her, will Lucindor be jealous? Or why hould you think he will? Alcander, anwered he and miled, I ee you deire to know all, and I will tell you, ince I am reolved to hide no action of my life from you. You know Brother, that in this great City there is abundance of company, and one cannot chue but be een, and convere with everal perons: It happens that many perons eeing us, many come to love us, or at the leat eem o: for I believe that is the cutome of mot men: But however, many eyes being upon us, they
will ee thee addrees, be they true or fale; and thus this multitude of acquaintance produceth this enemy; or rather, this mortal dieae of Love, which is called Jealouie. Lucindor having oberved one of Palanices brothers did eem to love me, or perhaps loved me in earnet, he became o jealous upon it, that he will let me nor himelf take any ret. How? Siter (aid I and miled) I beeech you explain this a little better unto me; Does this Brother of Palanices love you, and did not you ay that he loved Cercinea? Is he in love both with you and her? No, anwered he, Palanice has two Brothers, The one is called Clorian, who is in love with Cercinea, and the other is called Cerintes, who makes a hew of ome good will unto me. This Siter (aid I unto her, and laughed heartily) is one of the finet encounters that ere could happen: Palanice has two Brothers, the one of which is called Cerates, who loves you; and the other is called Clorian, who is in love with Cercinea. Cercinea alo hath two brothers, Selcines loves Palanice, and Lucindor courts you; And you Florice, you may ay, that thee two fair Ladies cannot lend you any thing, but you are able to pay them back again in their own coyn: for as I do love the fair Cercinea, o Amilcar is deperately in love with Palanice. How? cryed out Florice) Amilcar in love with Palanice? Yes, yes, replyed I, mot deperately. This (replyed he) were an excellent ubject for a Comedy. I would it were, replyed I, for Comedies, they ay, conclude always with a marriage: but yet ince we are ix, and you but three, ome of us mut of neceity be dicontended; for I am ure I will uffer none to hare with me in her that I do love. Do you think (aid he) that any one of us would be divided into two? As for that, anwered I, I refer it unto your elf: But Siter, all that I require from you, is, to work o with Lucindor, that his Siter may love me; and with Cerintes, that he work o with Palanice, that he may take Clorion off from his Courthip of Cercinea.

It was by this dicoure, Hylas, that I came to the knowledge of all thee ecret paages; and becaue I could not ay any more, by reaon that many perons came in and interrupted us; The conclusion was, that he promied not only to ait me with all her power, but alo to deal o with Cerintes, that Amilcar hould find no ill entertainment from Palanice: for (aid he) I think my elf obliged to ait you both, ince I was the caue of your being in love.

Thus then we parted; and becaue I was advertied of Clorians affection unto Cercinea, and of the influence which Palanice had upon her, I thought to gain ome of Cercineas good will, before either the Brother or the Siter took notice of it; to the end, that when Clorian entreated his Siter to do me any ill offices, he might be armed a little before hand in my defence: and therefore the way that I took to oblige her, was principally dicretion; having heard that nothing does more engage a maid to love then it; and it is but mean prudence to employ any confidents in the buines: I have already told you how I made the firt declaration of my affection; and I aid no more unto her for ome days after: but being almot continually with her, all the demontrations that I gave her of it, was a mot obervant repect; and to the end he might know that it was a repect wh • ch proceeded from Love, and not from civility only, I behaved my elf towards Palanice after another manner, and did not render unto her any more then that honour which every Cavalier is obliged to pay unto Ladies of her qualities. My carriage to the one was a common road of complement, and to the other, a particular reverence, which glanced parks of Love:

One day, when Cercinea was at Palanices houe, he would wah her hands before a collation; I, as I always ued to be, was cloe by her to hold her Gloves; he was nothing nice in giving them unto me, becaue it was a trivial ervice which any would freely undertake: And pretending to have a little buines at my own houe, I went thither as fat as poibly I could, and with the ame hate, wrote this in one of her Gloves.
div.q: If I be not Yours, I am not mine Own, Nor Any's ele.
div.p: Cercinea took her Gloves again, but took no notice at that time what I had written in them: but at night when he was going to bed, her chamber-maid made the dicovery. Mitris (aid he unto her) who gave you thee Gloves? How? (aid he) who gave them? Are they not the ame I wore in the morning? I cannot tell, anwered he, but I did not ee what is written in one of them; and then he brought them unto her, for he was in bed. Cercinea reading it, and remembring that I had them once in my hands; but becaue he would not trut this maid who was wholly for Clorian and Palanice, he eemed as if he could not poibly devie who it hould be that writ it; and to hew how little he cared for it, he gave the Gloves unto Andronira (o was the wench called.) I wih Mitris (aid he unto her, and thanked her) that he who writ this in thee Gloves, may often do o; and I aure you, did I know him, I would give him hearty thanks. Thou wouldt do well (anwered he, and miled) for the gift deerves it. I believe (aid he) that the gift is very precious unto him, who is the caue of your giving them unto me; and if I hould preent them unto him from you, he would thank me with all his heart. Take heed of uch a trick, replyed Cercinea, for you may chance do me an extream dipleaure. Why hould I take any heed? replyed Andronira; I do not know who it is. And if thou didt (aid Cercinea) wouldt thou do it? Never doubt it Madam, anwered he, for I am extreamly pitiful unto thoe that are in love; and beides. I am ure Clorian would give me hearty thanks for informing him. As for Clorian (replyed Cercinea) if you would have me live in peace with Palanice and him, be ure you do not acquaint him with it. What need you care Madam, anwered he, as long as you know not who it was? No matter, replyed Cercinea, I would not have him ee them; and then feigning as if he had not read what was written, let me ee them again Andronira aid he) that I may read it; and he having given them unto her, Go, go to bed (aid Cercinea) thou art uch a fool, that thou halt not have them. Ah Mitris! cryed he, then retore me back the thanks which I gave unto you. If that will content thee (aid Cercinea) prithee take them with all my heart, and I will give thee another pair of Gloves beides; Then calling for a Cabinet where he kept uch things, he gave her another pair of Gloves. Mitris (aid Andronira and thanked her) you have taught me a way never to want Gloves. How? asked Cercinea. Why Madam (aid he) when thee are worn out, I will get ome body to write a little upon thoe you wear, and you will preently give me a new pair in exchange of them. Thou ayt right, aid Cercinea, but in the mean time, leave me to my ret.

Now Cercinea knew very well that it was I who writ upon them, and though he had no thoughts that were advantagious unto me, yet would he not upon any terms let Clorian ee them; and let this wench hould hew them unto him, he choe rather to keep them: yet it was impoible to avoid that which heaven had decreed, as you hall hereafter undertand.

In the mean time, this trivial paage was not altogether, unprofitable; for Cercinea remembring the words that I had poke unto her, and eeing with what obervance I behaved my elf, he was better aured by the reading of thee words, that I did really love her; and though he was far engaged with Clorian, yet could • he not reject this affection.

After he had a while conulted with her elf, whether he hould cherih this humour in me, or give me caue to quit it and her; at lat he reolved to let this have its free coure, thinking he could give it a top when he pleaed.

Some few days after he came to ee my Siter, and by fortune I was not at home, having then accompanied Amilcar unto Palanices houe; and taking my Siter aside, he hewed her thoe Gloves upon which I had written: Flories preently
knew the hand; but making a hew as if he thought it the act of Clorian, What? aid he will this love lat always? How? aid Cercinea, lat always! What love do you mean? It had been a much more pertinent quetion to have asked when it began? Why? anwered Florice, all the world knows that Clorian loves you: I do believe it, replyed Cercinea, and am orry for it: I believe every one ees the folly of Clorian: but uch paages as this are not uual with him: Pray look upon it a little better, and ee if you can know the hand? Then taking the Gloves, and looking upon the writing a little more preciely, he cryed out, Oh Cercinea, I know it very well, it is the hand of one that is very neerly allied unto me; I have often advis'd him to make no further attempts upon that deigne, and told him it was better to retreat betimes; then be foyld in a buines which he would never bring to pas. Ah Florice (anwered Cercinea) what trange offence have I committed againt you, that you hould wih me o much harm? Aure your elf, anwered Florice, that I never entertained the leat thought of any harm unto you; but I was loth that Alcander hould attempt a thing wherein he hould be baffled. And how do you know things future? replyed Cercinea. I do not know them ce • tainly, anwered Florice, but I can foreee by probable conjectures; and you your elf, if you will, can tell it as well as I. Then I will tell you eriouly, replyed Cercinea, 'tis true, Clorian has uch a Fancy in his head, which might well move you to peak thus; but it is more true, that if I continue in the ame mind wherein I am, he hall never bring what he intends to pas; not that I would by thee expreions engage Alcand • r any farther in his deigne which he eems to have: for beides my unwillingnes to put him unto o much pains, I have no deire to be loved: But take this for a mot certain truth, That I am very orry the indicretion of Clorian is uch, and o diadvantagious to me, as makes me weary of it and him. Since you are pleaed to peak o freely unto me, anwered my Siter, let me tell you again, that I think the courthip of Clorian is not diadvantag • ous unto you, unles it be in this, that he does eem in publique to have o much authority over you, as makes the world believe he has more in private; and whether this be prejudicial unto you, I leave it unto your own judgement. For my part, I think you would do much better if you by degrees get this abolute authority out of his hands; for o you will let the world ee, that the fault is not yours, and that thoe whoe profeion is to cenure the actions of others, are groly mitaken in the dicretion of the man. Oh Florice (aid Cercinea) this counel is eaie to give, but very difficult to execute; and did you know the humour of Palanice, you would confes as much; when we have more leiure, I hall more fully inform you: But in the mean time (continued he, and miled) do not think I deire Alcander hould trouble himelf o far as to love me; and to tell you truly, I think my elf obliged unto you for diwading him; alo you will add unto the obligation, if you continue it, though I know you will find no great difficulty in o doing; for I aure my elf he does but jet. At thee words my Siter oberved that he bluhed a little, which made her think, that what he aid was not the deires of her heart: yet eeming to believe her according to her words, he anwered her, I wih Cercinea, as well for your own interet as my Brothers, you would free your elf from this importunity; but I fear you will not.

Upon thee words they parted, becaue Amilcar and I entred into the room, and preently after us, entred Cerintes and Silcines: for my part, aoon as I had aluted all the company, I applyed my elf unto Cercinea; Cerintes, he began to court Florice, and Silcines and Amilcar ate down by Palanice, whom we brought along with us, I mut confes that I was not very attentive unto the dicoure of the company, being o joyed to have found her alone whom I deired, as I thought heaven was very favourable unto me: I ay alone, though all this good compan • was there, becaue I eteemed it o, ince Clorian was not preent; for if he had, I could hardly have had any opportunity of dicoure with her. Seeing her therefore to wear the ame Gloves in which I had writ, I wear, fairet Cercinea, aid I unto her, that all in thoe Gloves is full of Truth. I doubt it not (aid he unto me) for my hands are in them, and they are true. Your hands (replyed I) ought to have not only the Epithet of true, but alo of the fairet hands in the world:
but there is omething yet in your gloves which you have not poke of. She who eemed not to undertand my meaning; there is alo (added he) ome rings which I wear upon my fingers, which are likewie true rings. There is yet, replied I, omething ele. What can there be? aid he (and eemed to wonder) for my part, I neither ee nor feel any thing ele. O Cercinea, then anwered I and ighed, there is mall hopes of any happines unto me, when my heart is in your hands and you feel it not, nor will o much as look upon that writing which touches them. She then miling, how hould I feel your heart, aid he, if it be not there: then pulling her hand out of her glove, ee, aid he, if any heart be here. But ee, replied I, if it be poible, o fair a hand hould be there, and not have an infinit number of hearts. Then taking the glove, and hewing the writing unto her; See here, aid I, whether I ay truly or no, for I ee there what my heart did write. She eeming as if he never aw it before, truly Alcander, aid he, you are very bold with me, in writing thus in my gloves: do you think I take any delight in uch foolery? Then taking a pair of iers, he eemed as if he would crape it out, but interpoing my hand, I aid unto her, I mot humbly begg a pardon Madam, upon the gradure of my affection, and the boldnes whereof you accue me; and believe it fair Cercinea, it is in vain to crape out that writing, ince they are o engraved in that heart which I have devoted unto you, or rather you have ravihed from me, that neither time or death it elf can ever deface it. Alcander; aid he, I value neither your heart nor your tongue, knowing neither the one nor the other to be true, but though they were, I will not burthen my elf with any uch kind of merchandize. I mut needs confes, anwered I very faintly, that this merchandize not being worth much, and you eteeming it les, you have no reaon to be burthened with it, for if ever once you take it upon you, you can never hake it off: that is not my meaning, replied he and miled; but on the contrary, I know your merit, and eteem you as I ought to do; but this merchandize whereof you peak, is of uch a nature, that though I had it in my hands, it would not tay long there, it being like to thoe quinteences which vanih all into moke. But Alcander, to be plain with you, my meaning in effect is, that I have no inclination either to love, or to be loved. 'Tis trange, replied I, you hould be o ignorant in a thing wherein you have been o well taught. Alcander, Alcander (aid he with a miling eye, and giving me a gentle blow upon my hand) you are a very diembler, and au re your elf I take all you ay under that notion. Fairet Cercinea, anwered I, if I be not mot really devoted your ervant, then I am not Alcander, and I wih heaven may never let me live longer, then I love and adore you with all the faculties of my oul and body.

She would have anwered, and had half opened her mouth to peak when he topt upon a udden, and changing countenance and behaviour towards me he eeming to become quite another. This alteration did atonih me: but looking back towards the door, I aw Clorian with Lucindor enter. Imagine, Hylas, you aw a little child under the rod after he had committed ome fault: jut o looked Cercinea and Florice, when Lucindor and Clorian urprized the one with me, and the other with Cerintes: and though I had interet in them both, yet I could not chue but laught; But to hew my dicretion towards Cercinea, eeing in what trouble he was when Clorian aw me alone with her, I made a hew of going to receive him and Lucindor alo, and of doing them the honour of the houe: Florice did the like; and therefore every one for company roe up: but for all this, Clorian took notice that Cercinea did talk with me, and Lucindor oberved Florice talking with Cerintes: o as when they firt entred, their faces were full of evere and urly looks, and eemed to be much troubled, but Cercinea much more; yet they endeavoured as well as they could to put good faces upon the matter, and clear up all clouds of upition.

Clorian did not yet know of a certainty, that I loved Cercinea, but his doubts of uch a thing, and his humour of uffering none to peak unto that Lady, did make him knit the brows, and look o urly as he did. I mut confes this demeanure of Cercinea's did much dipleae me, and I was in a hundred minds to love her no longer; but then as oon as ever I looked upon her face, I yielded unto the power
of her beauty, and hrugging my houlders complained againt my unjut fate, that had made me a lave unto a lave.

At the lat, night drawing on, every one retired homewards, and Cercinea gave me uch a cold good night, as if I had committed ome grand offence againt her; yet thinking it was only becaue of Clorian, I would not, as I ued, wait upon her to her houe, but went home.

When I was at my own houe Florice related unto me all her dicoure with Cercinea, and afterwards added, Shall I tell you brother, what I think, certainly he will be more eaily taken off Clorian, then ever I thought he would: and the truth is he is o very imperious over her, as I wonder he hould o long indure it as he has. Siter, anwered I, and miled, that which you wonder at in another, you do allow of in your elf: believe it you are both alike, and if without offence I may peak it, you may well be ranked in a medium, betwixt creatures irrational and rational. Alcander, aid he unto me, you did oblige us both in aying o: Pray tell us what we hould do? Florice, aid I, does not Lucindor treat you as Clorian does Cercinea? if you do diapprove of her tolleration of it, why do you allow it it in your elf? And if Cercinea be weary of that tiranny, why does he till tie the knots of her bondage fater? Ah iter, believe it, both you and Cercinea, and all the women of the world are molded after one pattern, you will, and you will not: you will not, and you will. What do you mean brother, by thee intricate words? (aid Florice and miled) I mean, replied I, that you would fain be mitrees, and yet you are contented to be laves; and though you be weary of ervitude, yet you take delight in remaining under it: Have you not told me that Lucindor cannot indure Cerintes hould peak unto you? and yet the ame jealouie was your greatet torment with Theombres: if o, why do you ubmit your elf unto it? why do you not take upon you that authority which he uurps over you? you think it trange that Cercinea hould be o ubject unto the tiranny of Clorian, and I do think it more trange in you: for there is ome reaon to be alledged why he hould be o enlaved unto him; her education in his houe, the authority which Palanice ever had over her, her mall experience and many other coniderations, which you cannot alledge for your elf; but brother, aid Florice, who told you, that I do tand in fear of Lucindor? my eyes, replied I, a • d your actions: had you but een your elf in a glas when he entred with Clorian, you would have been ahamed to ee how every one took notice of you; and yet you can tell me that Cercinea is weary of that authority which Clorian aumes unto himelf over her; and that it is an eaie matter to take him off: Ah iter, how hollow is the hopes of it, ince they are grounded upon the faint reolution of a woman? were it a thing that is diadvantageous to you, or againt all reaon to make a man depair who is all yours, O how eaie and ready would you be to take up uch a reolution; but if it be a thing that is reaonable, or to your advantage, O how backward and difficult you find it to reolve with your elves.

Thus I continued twitting Florice with thee reproches, and he having given me hearing a while, he took me by the arm and interrupted me: Alcander, aid he, from whence did you come that you are in uch a crabbed humour? and I anwering that I came from walking in the garden, certainly replied he, you have tated of ome bitter fruit. I had ome thoughts, aid I unto her, which indeed were as bitter as any wormwood unto me: I thought o, replied he, for your words are full of wormwood. But ince you think us woman o inconiderate, I beeech you tell me, you that are o wie, would you have me break off with Lucindor? think well what councel you will give me; for I am reolved to follow it, auring my elf that you will give me none, of which you will not be called the Authour: believe it iter, anwered I, you are very kind; becaue Lucindor is brother unto Cercinea, you would at my charges, regain your liberty. You ee then, replied Florice, that as women want reolution, men are all for their own interets. Ah Alcander, how eaie it is to pie a mote in a neighbour eye? and how hard to ee a beam in our own? if I do uffer ome things in Lucindor, you have reaon to be glad of it: for he being brother unto Cercinea, we may keep
him within his devoires of erving you. Siter, aid I unto her, hall I peak freely unto you? I am not much againt Lucindor, for he is not out of all reaon; but I cannot endure the impertinencies of Clorian. Brother and friend, anwered he, I ee that now your tongue and your heart concurre, but et your mind at ret, and be aured, that if you will be ruled by me, we will take ome coure or other, that hall give you contentment. What couee, replied I, would you have me take? O heavens, anwered he and miled, how the cae is altered? mut it be I, that mut give the councel? well Brother, for this time, I will, and if you find it bad, never credit me again. However Cercinea behave her elf towards you, continue you erving her, but be ure you hide your affection from all the world but her, and leave the ret to your own merit, to the impertinency of Clorian; to the humour of Cercinea, and to my aitance for if you dicover it, Clorian and Palanice will lead her uch a life, as he will wih her elf out of the world: on the contrary, if you hide it handomly from them, you hall ee that this dicretion will o much pleae her, that Clorian will be doubly intollerable to her, and aure your elf that if he once begin to melt a little, I will not let any opportunity lip, which may advantage you. I mut confes, aid I unto her, that I find by your dicoure, every one is to be believed in their own mytery: to love and to diemble is the mytery in which mot women are vered; therefore iter, I will follow your advie, and not fail in the leat circumtance. Truly Alcander, aid he and clapped her hand upon my houlder, I imploy my time very well, in adviing you o affectionately, whilt you in the mean time requite me with retorting injuries.

This was our dicoure, in which I conceived no mall hopes, and thinking the advice of Florice was not to be rejected, I reolved to follow it as near as poibly I could: you know Hylas, that paion has a quality, to well that oul with violences which is poeed with it, and o it was with me; for notwithstanding all my deigns of contraint, and cloe deportment, my affection did hurry me ere I was aware into uch actions, as did but too much make known what I deired to hide: o as Palanice perceived it, making it appear, that art can hardly hide a thing from thoe that are of the ame mytery. And becaue he knew how impatiently Clorian would take this new affection, and he extremely loving her brother, one day he took Cercinea apart, and to begin; told her, how unadvied that woman was who would reject a firm and ettled affection, to enter any new one: how mot men do court rather out of humour then love, and oftentimes only to try whether women will be eaily won, that they may afterwards laugh at them, never caring for the reputation of thoe they eem to love, o they can but atisfie their vanity: how hard a thing it is to find a man of another humour, and what danger there was in truting any before long trial: Then afterwards he continued. Now weetheart, I mention all this unto you, to advertie you of a thing, which perhaps you take no notice of: I know, that Alcander ince his return, has a great aim upon you, and would make you believe that he loves you; he is a young man and has not yet old his merchandize, he has been abroad, and welled his mind full of wandring fancies: be ure Cercinea you do not believe what he ayes, and though you ay never o little unto him, he will be ure to take you at your word: we know yet of what humour he is, and I hould be very orry we hould learn it at your charges; what I ay is meerly for your own good, and as for the affection which my brother bears unto you, I am mot confident his worth will oblige you to wih him well, and did he know thus much, it would trouble him mot exceively: I ee that for your part you have not contributed any thing unto it, further then an affable complacency, which is ordinary amongt women of your age, becaue they think it a high honour to be courted by many: but weetheart I beeech you be not you of that opinion, for there is nothing more dicomendable in a young woman, then to be followed continually by all orts of men: for things that are common are not etimable, and perons of merit will not walk in a crowd: Dear Cercinea, take this advice which I give you, in good part, and make your advantage of it, like a wie and a prudent woman, as I know you are.
