Cercinea was very attentive to the dicoure of Palanice; and though he knew all her apient advice aimed only at her Brother, yet he took it handomly, without any dilike, or o much as the knitting of a Brow; o as after a complement of thanks for her good advice, he beeeched her to continue it, and her uual favours towards her; and as for her part, he knew not what I intended, but would with all dic • etion divert me, if he found any uch deigne in me; but above all, he beeeched her to hide it from Clorian, becaue he honoured and eteemed him, and would not upon any terms give him any caue of di-atisfaction,

This was the firt dicoure they had together upon that ubject, and ee I beeech you, how prudently he needed to carry her elf in uch accidents. 'Tis true this counel of Palanices caued her to carry her elf more coldly towards me then before: but withal, he treated with me as with her ervant: I mean, he was o perwaded that I loved her, as let all the world ay the contrary, he did not doubt it: o as the counel which Palanice gave her with intention to do me harm, did more advantage my deigne, then all my courthip would have done in a long time: My Siter who aw this alteration, and that Cercinea durt hardly name me without a bluh; that when I came into the room where he was, he preently cat down her eyes, or turned them another way; that when I came to her, he then changed place, and went into other company: that if I preented her with any flowers o • fruits as I ued to do, he refued them: and briefly, conidering how much dipleaed he eemed to be with me one day when we were both together at home, he could not chue but peak unto me about it, and repreented this corn to be o inupportable to a man of courage that if words had been able to have altered my opinion, doubtles thoe of Florice had been ufficient to have diverted me from that affection which I bore unto Cercinea. But the dieae had taken too deep a root, or to expres it a lit • le better, the Arrow was truck too far into my heart, to be pulled out by any thing but death: And he aw it very well by the anwer which I gave her; for when he had repreented unto me the wrong which that woman did me, and how every one admired to ee me o obtinate, or rather inenible; that upon all other occaions I hewed courage and judgement enough, but in this I eemed as if I had forgotten what I was; and briefly, after he had et before my eyes both who I was, and who he was, and that our alliance was all honourable and advantagious to her, as that of Clorians, or any others that could be propounded unto her. Dearet Siter (aid I unto her, and miled) you make of thoe Chirurgions who when they have looked upon a wound, do think they have done enough; thinking that when they have declared what Nerves, and whar Atteries are offended, to hew how mortal and dangerous the dieae is, and the great pain which the Patient endures, but never apply any remedies to cure them: Alas Siter, I do know too well all that you have told me; I ee Circinea does not love me, I know very well my ervices are not pleaing unto her, and I am not ignorant that Clorian is the happy man in her eye: But Siter, what am I the better for knowing all thee things, ince it is till but a bare knowledge, which ets before my eyes the grandeur of my wounds? If you have any pity upon my miery, make me know what remedies are neceary to cure it; for otherwie I aure you Siter, your pity in lieu of doing me good, will caue the end of my days, for to think that thee conideration can divert me from the love of that Fair one, is only to deceive your elf; ince I am o wholly hers, that he may ue what cruelties he pleae againt me, and my heart not murmure nor complain.

I ob • erved that when Florice heard thee expreions, he changed colour, and was even ravihed with wonder: After he had looked upon me a long while without a word at lat he aid thus, I mut needs confes Brother, that never any loved like unto you, if at leat it be love to give ones elf entirely away; but I mut tell you, that your affection deerves to meet with a reciprocal return, unles heaven have decreed you for the mot mierable man that ever loved. Truly Siter, anwered I, there is not a word which I poke, but I will igne it with my blood: But to what purpoe is all this? Will you let me try my lat remedy? aid he unto me. Alas Siter, replyed I, to what purpoe hould it be delayed, unles to make me loe my life? Then Brother (aid he) aure your elf that I will employ the
endeavours of Lucindor; and if he obtain no contentment unto you from his Siter, let him never look for any one good word from me again: In the mean time ue your utmot endeavours, for everal Batteries will ooner caue the Fort to yeild.

Upon this reolution we parted, he eeking for an opportunity of peech with Lucindor, and I beating my brains how to win upon the good will of this cruel Fair one. I have already told you that I had a Garden belonging to my houe, where I often ued to entertain my Fancies. At this time, as it was my cutome, I went thither, o taken up with my own thoughts, that I took no notice of Beliard, who was walking by himelf in a cloe Walk. This Beliard is the young man who is now aleep in the other bed, & who was appointed to have a care of us, when our Father ent us to the Roman Schools: The long time he hath been with us, and our contant familiarity has begot in him uch an affection unto me, that I dare ay he loved me with all his heart: The knowledge which I had of this, beides many other good qualities, which might well make him amiable, was the reaon why I had a very dear eteem of him, and concealed nothing from him: This time only I did not tell him of that affection which I had unto Cercinea, not knowing any reaon for it, unles becaue occaions did not handomly preent themelves: Now this young man was (as I told you) before me in the Garden, whilt I took no notice of him; and by fortune I went into a Walk which was parted from his, only by a Hedge of Lawrels, which was reaonable thick: He who pied me coming with my hat over my eyes, and looking down upon the ground, walking a great pace, he knew that I had ome deep thought in my mind which perplexed me, and becaue I did not ve to hide any thing from him, he knew not what to think of it; and therefore getting as cloe to the hedge as he could, to hear what words he thought he heard me utter, I began to raie my voice, thinking there was none to hear me; Then did he eaily hear that love was the caue of my perplexity. And as I was uttering thee words, Since all I can do will not avail to conquer the courage of this cruel Fair one, who is he that can help me? and from whom can I hope for any relief? I heard him anwer in a loud voice, Beliard. Judge Hylas, whether or no I was urprized at this voice. I topt, and looked about me, and eeing no body, I mut confes I began to think it was ome Spirit which made the anwer. But the young man went a little about, and came to me, aying everal times, Beliard, Beliard, from Beliard you may expect all faithful ervice: Oh Sir (aid he when he was a little nearer) is it you that is thus perplexed and does conceal your elf from me? Have you forgot my affection and fidelity? Oh friend, anwered I, you need not be offended with me for concealing that from you, which if I could, I would conceal from my elf, thinking, that as fire which is blown will belch out bigget flames, and when it wants ayr, will mother it elf away; o I by ilence hould become free as I was wont to be. Oh Sir, anwered he I perceive this is the firt time that you have been tainted with this dieae, ince you think that it will mother of its elf: You mut know Sir, that when a heart is once tricken, it can never be cured again, but either by uch extream corn as will blat all hopes, or by the enjoyment of the party who is the caue: and this is the reaon, There is nothing that can naturally live without ome nourihment: now favours are the food of Love; when a Lover is deprived of thee favours, then Love (like a candle that will extinguih for want of wax) will alo die for want of nutriment. Then again, as uperabundance of wax will extinguih that flame which would be nourihed by a mediocrity, o the fruition of the party loved, will tifle Love, by the uperabundance of favours which on like occaions are received, Oh Beliard, aid I unto him, if you know no better remedy againt my dieae. then you know how to dicoure of it, I am afraid I hould be long ick before you cured me; for I have found by experience, that one of thoe things which you ay will extinguih Love, will make it greater, and more full of pain: Nor can I imagine how the fruition of a good can make one hate it: o as reaon on one ide, and experience on the other, makes me conclude you no great Doctor in the dieae of Love. There is nothing Sir, aid he unto me, which o much hinders the cure of a dieae, then for the patient to have an ill opinion of his Doctor: Fancy
and Imagination will oftentimes work wonders, and produce effects incredible; and therefore you ought not to give o bad a judgement of my capacity, until you have conidered my reaons: I ay, that either extream corn, or uperabundance of favours, may either of them extinguih Love: for is not Love a deire? and one does never deire that which they poes: if then by poeion there be no deire, it follows by conequence then, that by poeion there is no Love. In Love (aid I) there is an inexhautible Abys of weets, of delights, and it is impoible ever to have them all, but there will till be ome greater and greater to deire then we enjoy: Beides, the appetite is not extinguihed nor atisfied, but on the contrary, the new thought of the happines enjoyed, does become bellows un • o deire, and makes it more violent; and o, according to your own argument, Love being a deire, and that deire being made more ardent and violent by the knowledge of the happines enjoyed, it conequently follows, that it which you a • does extinguih Love, does on the contrary make it more vigorous and violent. Such a Love as you mention Sir, replyed he, mut be a mot exceive Glutron, if nothing can atisfie it. But Sir, what do you ay to corn and didain? Can Love hold out againt a generous pirit? Cold will allay heat, and all contraries will detroy their contraries; nor can you deny but hatred being the contrary of love, will make Love die. All things in the Univere (replyed I) are preerved by their contraries; and if there were no contrarieties, all would be but one thing, and o the world would end, at the leat be no world. 'Tis true, replyed he, but then thee contrarieties are o equal in power, that the one cannot urmount the other: But what love is it which will not be extinguihed by extream corn? According to your argument, replyed I, Love may reit corn, when it is equally in the extream. But Beliard why pend we time in this uneaonable dipute? What will it avail me, whether what you ay be true or no? Since I do find by ad experience, that neither disfavours nor corn have wrought in me that effect which you peak of. Perhaps Sir, anwered he, there may be a failure in your experience: I beeech you tell me what arguments you have to think your elf corned? Oh Beliard, cryed I o many, and o great, as makes them mot apparent: And that you may the better judge, for I will not conceal any thing from you, Know that I am mot deperately in love with Cercinea. Who? She (aid he) who Clorian o long courted? The ame, replyed I, and I aure you, that ever ince this affection firt began, and ince I did dicover it unto her, her cruelties are daylie encreaed Sir, aid he then unto me, Will you not be offended if I be a little inqui ••• ve? Pray tell me whether he did treat you after the ame manner, before you made your love known unto her? No, anwered I, far otherwie; for then her language was weet, and her favours fluent. Then (aid he) when you did acquaint her with your love, did he take it in corn, or in anger? Neither the one nor the other, anwered I; but a while after he began to corn me. And what? continued he, Did he make her ill will known unto you? Alas, anwered I, he flies me like a contagious dieae: when I come into the room where he is, he bluhes, and turns another way: And ince he took this humour, would never o much as cat an eye upon me. But my dear Beliard, to what purpoe is the relation of all thee particulars? Know this for all, that all her actions are o many arguments that my ervice is not pleaing unto her. Beliard upon this miled: Mater (aid he) be of good courage, and take it upon my word, this woman loves you. How, anwered I, Cercinea love me! Believe it, he gives me but mall reaon to think o. Sir, aid he, mot auredly Cercinea does love you; all her actions of which you complain, are o many aured arguments of it. Thee lights, thee bluhes, thee hifting of places to avoid the ight of you, briefly, all that you have related unto me, are nothing but words of love, in which he ilently peaks unto you: She might as well ay, I love you Alcander: And to hew you Sir all this is true, what tetimony Sir will you pleae to have me bring you of it? Alas my dear Beliard (aid I unto him) it is the exces of thy love whi • h makes thee peak thus, to give me ome conolation. No, no Sir (aid he) I do not flatter you; I am mot confident I hall bring you ome tetimony of her love to you the firt time I hall peak with her; refer the whole care unto me, be
merry, only continue a dicreet behaviour towards her, and be not offended at the harhnes of her actions; for believe me, they are only contraints, and abolutely to your advantage.

I hould tyre you Hylas, if I hould repeat all the dicoure we had upon this ubject, for I hould never end; o pleaing were the flattering hopes of his promies unto me: In concluion, before we parted, he reolved to find out ome means of peech with her, which I told him might eaily be done if he feigned to viit her from Florice, as is uual in great Cities betwixt perons of quality: But I thought it neceary that Florice hould give him the Commiion. To feigne that I come from her, Sir (aid he) I think it good; but to take my commiion really from her, I do not like; or that he hould know any thing of your deigne: for Sir, learn this ecret from me, That there is nothing which a woman fears o much as to trut her elf in uch matter unto another woman, epecially if he be fair and young, there is nothing that will ooner caue a divorce between them; and then what danger are they in who truted them with any thing of importance? No no, uch as are well advied, will never run uch hazards: Should you acquaint Florice, and he thinking to do you a good office, peak unto her, you hould find nothing from her but coldnes, and hy looks. Alas (aid I unto him) I have concealed nothing from her, and he has poken unto Cercinea of it everal times. Well Sir, aid he, I will try if I can remedy it; but I beeech you deire Florice to peak unto her no more, and you hall find my advice to be good very hortly.

Night began to rob us of the day, and upper time drew near, when I went out of the Garden much better atisfied with the hopes which Beliard had infued into me, then I was when I entred; which Florice perceiving, Whats the matter Brother (aid he unto me) that your mind is better contented then it was when you went from hence? Siter (aid I, and poke very low) it eems my face is a Teltale, and will ave me a labour; but I beeech you take no notice of it, nor peak unto Cercinea any more concerning my affection, nor any thing ele concerning me, till I advertie you; he made a igne with her head, which intimated as much as he would oberve my deire, and o we ate down to Supper; when we had half upped, Amilcar came and told us of a great meeting at the houe of Dorinde, becaue the next morning he was to be married unto Bellimaries, a great Souldier, whom King Gondebaut made Governour of the City of Lions; and that Palanice and her Brothers would go thither as oon as they had upped: That Dorindes Father whom he met in the treet returning from our houe, deired him to invite Florice and me thither: That Cercinea was not there, though her two brothers were, becaue he found her elf not well dipoed.

This News made us hate with upper as oon as we could, that ince we were invited, we might go thither: And when I was ready to go Beliard came to me, and deired me not to be at that Aembly, ince Cercinea would not be there: for (aid he) I intend to go unto her; and if he be to be poke withal, I will break the matter unto her; and believe it Sir, I am the mot mitaken man in the world, if I bring not back welcome News unto you, before you go to bed: To which I anwered, that I would do as he deired, and o I did.

Beliard was as good as his word, and went to Cercineas houe, where by fortune he found none with her but Andronira, all the ret being gone to this houe of jollity: She was et upon her Beds ide half undret, with a Lute in her arms wherewith he was entertaining herelf; for amongt the ret of Cercineas excellent qualities, he plays upon that Intrument in the perfection; he was o attentive to her own harmony, that when Beliard came into the room, it was long before he perceived him; and had not Andronira pied him, and advertied her Mitris, he had longer pleaed his ear with the enchantment of her muique; But he tarring up, would have gone into her Cloet, becaue he would not be een o undret, had not he held her back by her garment; afterwards cating himelf upon his knees before; he did o beg and importune her to tay, that he returned to her place, yet commanding Andronira to take away the candle, that he might not be o well een in that dres.

Madam (aid Beliard unto her) if he do take away the candle, it is no matter,
for no Sun can illutrate a night better then your beauty: Beliaid, aid he unto him, thee flatteries might well be pared to your friends, epecially in their preence, let therefore the candle be removed that you may not ee me bluh at them, But tell me, I beeech you, what brought you hither? and why are not you at Dorindes houe, where o many beauties will be aembled? To anwer Madam unto your quetion, aid he, you mut know that either a good or a bad pirit directed me hither; and the reaon why I am not at Dorindes houe is double: For, continued he and poke aloud, Florice hearing you were not well, he commanded me to come and know how you did, and to tender her mot humble ervice unto you I am much obliged, aid he unto Florice for the favour, and her care of me: I beeech you tell her, that this icknes is not like to diable me from paying back unto her, the due debt of my mot humble ervice. O Cercinea, aid he and poke low, you are mitaken, if you think Florice knows any thing of my coming hither: why then, aid he, did you tell me a lie? becaue, replied he, too many people would know our buines, if we hould alwayes peak truth. Do you think I would have Andronica know the caue of my coming hither? No, no, I dare not trut her.

Cercinea d • d not wonder at the odnes of Beliaids expreions, becaue it was uual with him, both towards her, and her companions: yet he had a upition that I had a hare in the buines of Beliaid, becaue he knew that I had a great confidence in him; and therefore he would not ask him any more what buines brought him thither, but he beginning to peak: I did never in my life, aid he, ee a peron o little inquiitive as you are, ince you know that it was not upon Florices errand that I came, why do you not ask me, upon whoe the • ? Cercinea then miled and aid unto him: I did never in my life ee a man o prodigal of his ecrets as Beliaid, who will not only tell them unto thoe that ask him, but will force thoe who have no curioity, to know them. You may ee by that, replied he, how the blame which is laid upon woman, is due alo unto men. What blame do you peak of; aid Cercinea and miled; that they cannot keep their tongues in their heads, anwered Beliaid. 'Tis true indeed, replied Cercinea then, that men do apere us with that fault, which methinks, they are more guilty of themelves, at the leat, many that I know; if it be a vice natural in women, then nature failed in me: for I wear Beliaid, that when one deires me to conceal a thing, I do o abolutely forget it, that I remember it no more, then if they had never told me of it.

Are you of that humour, replied Beliaid, in every thing? In every thing, replied he, that is of any importance. I will try, aid Beliaid, whether you peak truth; for I will trut you with a ecret which I would not have known for half my life. Why then, aid Cercinea, will you tell it unto me? For two reaons, aid he, the one, to know whether a woman can be ilent; and the other to hew you how much Beliaid is your ervant, ince he will trut you with uch a ecret, by which you may ruine him when you will. Truly, anwered he, I would know what you intend to tell me, for the two coniderations which you mention; but be ure you mention it not unto any other, left if they hould blabb, I hould be accued of their fault: No, no, anwered Beliaid, I am confident, that when I have told it unto you, it will be the leat of your fears I hould tell any other. If o, replied Cercinea and miled, I hall be glad to hear it, as well to hew you what I am, as to know what you are. Be pleaed then, aid Beliaid) to hear what it is: you know very well, that there is not any upon the face of the earth, whom I love, and honour o much as Alcander; you know that I have been long converlant with him, and I think you know, that he is pleaed to et ome value upon me, and has truted himelf unto my fidelity. I will at this time acquaint you with a ecret which he hath truted unto me, and which he had rather die then it hould be divulged: Be pleaed to know, fair Circinea; that as he and I were dicouring together upon everal things of importance, he wore by his life, and proteted a hundred times by all that was mot acred and dear unto him, that he did love the f • ir Cercinea o, and was o wholy and devotedly her ervant, that never was any affection equal unto his: and that if this affection hould by his cured
fate be dipleaing unto you; then, he hould have recoure unto no other remedy but death.

And becaue Beliaid made here a top, Cercinea miled, and thus replied: Is this all the ecret, Beliaid, which you have to tell me? and do you think this to be a matter of uch huge importance? Do you think it is not? aid Beliaid, ince it concerns the contentment and the life of uch a Cavalier? for know Cercinea, that ince firt he aw you, he never thought of himelf, nor ever talks unto me of any thing but you; the whole tudy of his thoughts is to find out wayes how to erve you: all his dicoure is to extol and eteem you, and all his deires have no other ambition but the honour of your favour; But Madam, for Godake, I beeech you, keep all this ecret.

I promie you I will, anwered he, and ecret in uch a manner, that Cercinea her elf hall neither know nor believe a word of it. O Madam, aid he then, that's not it which I deire, but on the contrary, I would have Cercinea both know and believe it, as a mot infallible truth: but my meaning is, that you hould not impart it either unto Palanice or Clorian: No, no, anwered he, neither Palanice or Clorian, nor Cercinea hall ever know it. Do you not remember I told you at firt, that when any told me a thing with a charge of ilence, I hould quite forget it? trut me Beliaid, I will do the ame by this ecret which you have imparted unto me, for I will not o much as think of it any more. Pervere woman, replied Beliaid, do you think I would tell you any thing that you might forget it? Do you thus corn what I ay, and what concerns o deeply a Cavalier of uch merit, and a Lady that is the fairet in the world? what you have told me, replied Cercinea, has none of thoe qualifications, and therefore I ee you do but only mock me: for the Lady of whom you peak is good, but not fair, and the Cavalier whom you ay it o much concerns, does not think o; and this ecret which mut be o cloly kept is known already to any that will. I am very glad, anwered Beliaid, that, ince againt your concience you will deny what I ay, you confes, that every one knows it: As for that beauty which you deny to be in Cercinea, all that have eyes and look upon you will give you the lie; as for the affection of Alcander which you put in doubt, all his actions do give you a ufficient tetimony of it. And latly, for the ecret, which you ay is none: time which is the dicoverer of truth, will let you know, that none ever heard it but Cercinea, Alcander, and Beliaid: Ah lier, replied he preently, has not Florice poke of it everal times unto me? Florice, anwered he, might perhaps peak what he thought, but not that Alcander imparted any thing unto her: then Clorian and Palanice, aid he, they are acquainted with it; how, aid Beliaid, they acquainted with it? mot certainly, anwered he, for both of them have told me of it, and with many a bitter reproach: believe it Beliaid, ince they have known it, I have not been without exercie. Then Beliaid miling, fair Cercinea, aid he, would you have me confes the truth? All that I have told you concerning Alcander is as true as that there is a heaven, and a God: let me be caheered out of the number of the living, if he do not love you, nay rather adore you: but the reaon of my coming to you, and of all the dicoure which I have had with you, was only to know, what now you have told me concerning Palanice and Clorian: for Alcander and I could not imagine why you hould treat him o cruelly, conidering his extream affection unto you, and the dicretion wherewith he hath loved you; and thinking it not likely, that conidering his merit and his deire to erve you, he hould be courly ued: but now I plainly ee, that all this proceeds from no ill will in you, but only from the importunity of Clorian and his iter, who are the only caues of it; will you be pleaed to let us make this contruction of it? and for the atisfaction, or rather for aving the life of my dear mater, hall I let him undertand it o? and becaue he poke not; but in lieu of anwer roe up, and walked oftly up and down the chamber, he continued in this manner: I have many a time admired at the good fortune of ome perons, and at the bad fortune of others; I have een ome have great etates, who were unworthy of them, and others of great worth and merit to want. The ame conideration may be had upon this occaion; for with what jutice,
can the honour of your favour be denied Alcander? and what hadow of reaon can you have to let Clorian have uch a tirannical power over your will? If the merits of both be conidered, they are out of their wits that will not prefer Alcander before him. This very conideration is enough to win you from him: Clorian is imperious and domineers over you, Alcander does humbly reverence and adore you, as if you were a goddes, and yet you make him inferiour to Clorian. This is a thing o trange as is hardly credible, yet it is true: you are all ubmiion unto him that tramples you under his feet, and you are all cruelty and corn towards him that humbly adores you. O no, replied Cercinea, you are mitaken Beliaid; I do not corn him, but I do eteem Alcander as I ought, and as his merit does oblige all thoe that know him: a large gratification indeed, aid Beliaid, to eteem him as all that know him do; but are not you obliged unto him more, ince he would not live but only to do you ervice? What more (anwered he and miled) would you have me do? why hould I tell you, aid he, ince you will do nothing? Upon this they went to the table, and he taking up a pen without any deigne, why hould I tell you what you hould do more, aid he, ince I fear you will not do it? perhaps, replied he and miled, you have gueed right; and perhaps alo you are mitaken: Firt, aid he, anwer me to one quetion I will ask: do you love Alcander, or do you hate him? A very fine quetion indeed, anwered he and miled, and why hould I hate one of o much merit, and who never gave me any occaion for it? you ay very true, anwered he, why then do you treat him with o much rigour? I do not know, aid he, what you call rigour. When you ee him, replied Beliaid, you turn another away: if he come towards you, you flie him; if he peak unto you, you will not anwer him; or if you be forced unto it, it is but half words: breifly, all your other actions are corn and didain of him. Beliaid, aid he (and laid her hand upon his houlder) hall I peak freely to you? I never thought that thou or thy mater had o little wit as I ee you both have: Go, go, Beliaid and learn this leon, that women are oft contrained to eem as if they did not ee what they do ee; and on the contrary, to ee that which they do not ee. O Cercinea aid he, I give you mot hearty thanks for reforming my ignorance. This leon will be the greatet contentment in the world, unto one who is now the mot afflicted, but now I hall preently make him the mot contented and happy peron alive: whilt Cercinea was walking left Andronira hould upect any thing from their long dicoure, Beliaid took the pen, and began to write, for he had an excellent wit, and as good a faculty in writing as any in the Court: As he writ, Cercinea at every turn of her walk looked upon him, and aid aloud, be ure you write nothing but what is good, and do not poil my paper: if you pleae to ee what I have writ, aid he, you hall ee how I have obeyed you, and if you would approve of it, I would thank you; if it be a thing I ought to do, anwered he, I will: O Cercinea, replied he, I hould think this a happy night if you would: doubtles I will anwered he, if I can, but what have you writ? You hall ee it, anwered he, and never look upon me as your ervant, if I have inerted any thing, which in all reaon you may not avow, then taking the paper, he read thee words.

body.head: CERCINEAS Note unto ALCANDER,
body.p: THe asurance which your actions have given me of your amity, has obliged me in gratitude, to love you; and to et uch a value upon your merit as to eteem you as a peron whom I will honour as long as I live.

div.p:
When he had read it; now Madam, aid Beliaid, make good your word, and perform the promie • hich you made. What promie, aid he, did I make unto you? you aured me, anwered he, that if it were a thing which you ought to do, you would approve of what I had writ: have I writ any thing which is not true,
and which you ought not to avow? I do not know, replied he, to whom this is directed, nor from whom it mut go. You may eaily imagine Madam, replied he, that I will carry this tetimony unto the mot faithful ervant you ever had: what then aid he, would you have me do? I would have you, replied he, to approve of what I have writ: Well, anwered he, I do approve of it; Nay that's not enough, anwered he, you mut ubcribe your name unto it: what then, aid he, why then, anwered he, you have performed your promie, and I am atisfied; but that, anwered he, is no atisfactory anwer to my quetion: I would know what mut be down with the Paper when I have ubcribed it? Away, away, aid he, what needs all this curioity? Then taking the pen, and holding the paper unto me, come, come, aid he, make good your promie, and afterwards we will talk further: o even by force he made her write Cercinea; and becaue he preently took away the paper as oon as he had done: No, no, aid he, I do intend to keep it, for I did not promie to let you have it, but only to approve of it: 'Tis true anwered he, but I made no promie to give it unto you, but to keep it; o as I will keep mine as well as you have yours. Come, come, replied he, I will have it: Well Madam, ait he, if you will, you hall; but it hall be from the hands of Alcander.

After uch dicoure as this, becaue it grew very late, he bad her goodnight, and he eeing him ready to be gone and carry it away, he went unto him. I perceive, aid he and miled, one mut give that which one cannot ell, therefore I pray tell Alcander how you have deceived me; No, no, aid he, I will make him a more happy man then ever he hoped to be: So not taying for any anwer, he came as fat as he could to me, and found me compoing ome lines into meeter, upon this ubject, That though he corn'd me, yet would I love her. Jut as I had finihed them, Beliaid entred, and becaue I commonly communicated them unto him; before ere I asked whether he had een Cercinea, I made him read them, that he having a good wit, and was able to judge of uch things, might give his opinion of them: But at this time he laid them down upon the table; veres, aid he, are now no more in eaon, then Schollars are in time of war: What do you mean Belleaid, aid I unto him? I mean anwered he (and ets his arms a kimbow) that there is but one Beliaid in a world, that can cure a deperate dieae. Tell you me of Rigours, Cruelties, and Scorns? why? Nothing but love and favours can I find from her. Then throwing the pen out of my hand I embraced him, aying, Surely Beliaid you only mock me, is it poible that Cercinea hould give you any tetimonies of her good will to me? I am ure, aid he, that you were prepoeed with the opinion wherein you were, that you will hardly believe me: but firt hear what I will ay unto you, then ask what aurance, which in any reaon you can, and I will give it unto you. I will tell you, that Cercinea does not only accept of your ervice, but more, he loves you, and I am able to make good what I ay. Ah Beliaid, aid I unto him, (being tranported with too much content) may I believe this good news? I knew well enough, replied he, that you would be incredulous, and therefore I offered you at firt, uch aurance, as might make you believe what I ay: bethink your elf what will mot inpire you with belief; then wear, aid I unto him, by the love thou bearet me, that indeed, aid he, were well; but go on. Swear then, aid I, by the love I bear unto Cercinea. Oaths, aid he, are but words, and words are but wind; but I would give you ome aurance which you may ee and touch: I conjure thee, (aid I unto him being all impatiency) to tell me what it is. I pray you content your elf, replied he, and believe me another time, if I hew you in writing, that all I have aid is true. O I fear, aid I, that your promies are to bigg to be effected: I will make it evidently appear unto you, replied he, that the effects are greater then all my promies; for you hall ee it in writing, nay, in writing from her to you: Then giving me the paper; ee there, aid he, how that contract of love, to which I was Secretary, is approved of and igned by her own fair hand: there you may ee Cercinea ent unto you in writing, as an earnet that afterwards he will make you poeour of her elf in ubtance.

Oh Hylas, how can I expres my joys and my ravihments? I kied the name
of Cercinea a thouand times, and laying it to my heart, me-thought I received unimaginable comfort; and becaue I was atonihed, and admired how it was poible he hould obtain this declaration from her, he related the whole tory of his negotiation, not omitting one illable; and I heard with o much attention and delight, as I could have wihed he never would have ended: But in concluion, Mater (aid he unto me) this woman has not only all imaginable excellencies of body, but he is one of the raret wits in the world; her years, though few, are yet full of prudence and widom; and believe me, you are obliged to love her, not only for her high Beauty, but more for the good will he bears unto you: for beides her Letter unto you, her dicoure does better tetifie, that all thoe actions which have o much tormented you, were only contraints, and becaue he durt do no otherwie: But Sir, what may you now expect from her, ince I have this firt time obtained more then ever you could hope for?

Our dicoure together had not o oon ended, had not Florice and Amilcar o oon returned from the Nuptial houe, where neither of them had been very merry, and returned without much contentment; for Lucindor and Cerintes were there, who never left Florice, and Seleines kept Palanice company, o as Amilcar could not talk unto her without witnees. As oon as I aw them, Beliard and I having done dicoure, I took them both by their hands, and drawing them aide; now (aid I unto them) I will participate of your contentments, that this merry night pas not away without ome delight unto me. Both of them miled at this. For my part, aid Florice, I have een Lucindor and Cerintes. And I (aid Amilcar) to my happines have een Palanice, and to my orrow, Seleines with her. Then (replyed Florice) I cannot tell you any news, but that I have been the mot perecuted woman in the world with their importunities, or rather jealouies; for I could never peak to the one, but the eye of the other was upon me, and I could not do any manner of thing which did not dioblige them both: he to whom I talked, was orry I did not look upon her; and he upon whom I looked, was angry it was not him I talked unto: and I was afraid left they hould have faln foul upon one another. For my part Siter (aid I unto her) if you love either of them, I beeech you let it be Lucindor, for he is Circineas Brother; and the more to oblige him, let him know that I am his Solicitor unto you. Nay then Siter, (aid Amilcar, and miled) I conjure you to love Cerintes, becaue he is Palanices Brother and let him undertand that I did entreat for him. Brothers (aid Florice, and interrupted) firt for your ake Alcander, I will not love the Brother of Palanice, and then for your ake Amilcar, I care not for the Brother of Cercinea; and for my owne ake, I will not trouble my elf with either Lucindor or Cerintes.

We could not forbear laughing at this Declaration: Siter aid I unto her, either love them, or love them not, that's all I care, o you will but eem to do as I deired: But Amilcar (aid I unto him) what adventures have befallen you? Very well at firt, anwered he, but at lat not o: When we were altogether at the Aembly, Seleines was not there; o as finding the place free, and becaue I would not let uch an opportunity lip, I told her, that I hould have cured my Brother, if I had gone with him, as he deired: Perhaps (anwered he) you would have found more contentment there then here: Indeed (replyed I) there's none can tell better then Palanice, ince it is in her power to make me the mot contented, or the addet man in the world, and this he may do with one word: If o (aid he) you have confined your good or bad fortune unto a very narrow room. No, no, anwered I, for I et uch a value upon you, that the very leat things which come from you, eem great unto me. Take heed Amilcar (aid he) that what you think o, do not prove o really. Oh fairet Palanice, replyed I, I would to God you would be pleaed to make me judge of it by experience. What would you have me do (replyed he) to make you o knowing? I would have you peak but one word only (aid I) that is, I love Amilcar. That word (replyed he) ounds o ill in the mouth of a woman, that I cannot peak it. Say then replyed I, The love of Amilcar is pleaing unto me. How? replyed he, and miled, would you have me ay it when I do not think o, nor believe it? Oh heaven! cryed I,
do you not believe it? What hould I do to create a Belief in you? If that Belief (anwered he) would do you any good, you mut find our ways to infue it; but I will advie you no further. When I have brought it to that pas, that you cannot but believe I love you (aid I) will it be pleaing unto you then? The judgement upon things future (aid he) is very uncertain, and one can hardly be ure of any thing. Unto what then (replyed I) hall I have recoure? Upon this Sileines came in, who hindred us from any further talk, but that he aid unto me in a low voice, unto Tryal; And after this, we could not all that night peak a word, without that troubleome witnes.

Thus Hylas we dicoured together, and I thus undertood their adventures, and they not mine; Not but that I hould willingly have imparted it unto them, had I not feared the dipleaure of Cercinea, who I aw was extreamly contrained by that authority which Palanice had uurped over her; and becaue it was very late, we retired to our ret.

But I held Biliard o long in talk in my chamber, by making him repeat what he had told me before, that day did appear before I would permit him to retire. The Sun then hining upon us, we reolved to gain Cercineas chambermaid, it being almot impoible to find any defence from her eyes: And ince Beliard had been already o properous in his firt deign, I referred the managing of all matters wholly unto him.

The dicoure Hylas would be too long, if I hould relate unto you all paages concerning my Brother and me, and thee four Cavaliers. But o it was, that Beliard did negotiate the buines o well, that he did not only ininuate himelf into great credit with Cercinea, but alo made Andronira entirely his. Yet as ill fortune was, I was that time contrained to take a journey of neceary importance about our etate, into the Country of Veragrois, and my mother, do what I could, would by all means have me pot away with all peed; God knows whether this journey was not with an ill will, and whether I would not willingly have referred this charge unto Amilcar: But I being the elder, and conequently the heir to the etate, I mut reolve upon this unwilling departure.

But ee whether Fortune was not reolved to try my reolution and patience? When I had tayed to the lat minute, and my journey could not be deferred a jot longer, Cercinea fell ick; whether it was by too exceive heat (for then it was the Dog-days) or whether by eating too much fruit, as young perons are apt at that eaon; but o it was, that he was forced to her bed by a violent Fever: Oh Hylas! How heartily I wihed Amilcar were my elder brother; or at leat that thoe Rents which I was to receive and give dicharge for, had not been due: and the wort was, Clorian and Palanice never tirr'd from her Beds ide, o as it was a thing impoible for me to peak unto her before I went, unles before thoe two malignant witnees: Imagine what a leave I took, and what atisfaction I had in my adieu. It was my cutome always to carry Beliard with me, becaue I loved him as a econd elf; but at this time I left him behind exprely, to try if he could convey a Letter unto this Fair one, which might tetifie my orrows by my departure, and to end me word how he did. The Letter was this;

body.head: ALCANDERS Letter unto CERCINEA.
body.p: OH good Gods! What will be the end of my journey, when the beginning is o ad? To Depart! To Depart, and not be able to peak, and to leave you ick in Bed, are three uch fatal misfortunes as are intolerable. Yet be pleaed that I hall live; Pity my pain, and take ome hare in my inexpreible orrows.

div.p:
Upon the firt opportunity that preented it elf, Belliard acquitted himelf of that charge which I left with him; and o, that he did not only delude the eyes of
Palanice and Clorian, but alo of another maid which they had put to wait upon her, being entred into ome upition of Andronira. In the mean time, I continued on my journey with o much regret that I had not poke unto her, as but for the hopes which I had in the aitance of Beliard, I know not what would have been the iue of it.

Amilcar in my abence was o diligent in his courthip of Palanice, as he put Seleines, Cercineas elder brother, to abundance of pain. This Seleines as you know, was a very brave Cavelier, none excelled him, and few equall'd him in feats of Arms, or any thing belonging to a Cavalier: At Barriers, and Tiltings he always got the advantage: And as he had the eteem of every one, o had he no ill opinion of himelf; yet curteous and full of repect to his friends, but a little imperious in his affection, and thought that he obliged a Lady if he loved her. This Cavalier being brought up in the Court of King Gondebaut, and being very young, he cat his eyes upon Palanice: Their houes being near adjoyning, and he being oft in the Queens Court, he had frequent opportunities of eeing her. This affection grew o great by degrees, that Sileines and Palanice alo, became both perfect Lovers: yet becaue the Prince Sigimond who was about the ame age, fell in love at the ame time with that Lady, repect made them diemble their loves, and move Sileines to keep at a ditance: And though this at the firt was more in appearance then in effect, yet continuing in this diimulation, Sileines turned his eyes upon Doria; and though he deny it, yet it was generally thought that his jeting proved to be in earnet. Palanice, as young as he was, conented unto this Artifice, to remove from Prince Sigimond all caue of withdrawing that affection which he profeed unto her, and never reented the loes of Sileines, as long as Sigimond, continued loving her: But it hapned a while after, that this young Prince whoe humour was not unalterable, did for ome caue or other withdraw his affection. I believe (aid Hylas, and interrupted) that the occaion was not great; for being then at Lions, I heard as much. The relation of it, replyed Alcander, is various; but the mot common report is, that Palanice being with the Queen, Prince Sigimonds mother, as he was helping to dres her, this young Prince came to her, and took her fingers to play with them: Palanice fearing left the Queen hould ee, pull'd back her hand two or three times; and becaue he continued till, Sir (aid he) I beeech you let me alone: and becaue he pronounced thee words omthing harply, he aid unto her, Would you indeed have me let you alone? Then he anwering in the ame words and tone; I promie you (replyed he and bluhed) you hall never have occaion to bid me the third time; and upon that he left her, o as ever ince he looked upon her only as a peron indifferent: The caue indeed of this eparation was very trivial, but it erved to divorce this affection, o as it never ince knit again.

A while before Sileines making hew of love unto Doria, a very fair and handome Lady, he became fettered in good earnet, hewing by this experience, that fictions in love are very dangerous; for Love is but a play, and by playing, one may come to love in earnet. Palanices vexing at the los of Sigimond, and being dipleaed at the diverion of Seleines, made the way eaie for Roiliander, who no ooner began to wooe, then to win her; and the more eaily, becaue he being weary of the Court, and deirous to be far from the place where he found nothing but dipleaures, he entertained Roiliander, whoe habitation was the mot remote parts of the Sebuians: But ee whether Love be not a very child, Sileines no ooner aw Palanice gone, but he began to remember that heretofore he had loved her, and grieved more for her abence then he cared for her preence. Now began Letters and Meages to pas apace betwixt them, and Love found more heat at a ditance, then near hand: But it mut needs be confeed, that both of them did well deerve the pains they endured; Love hewed himelf jut in punihing Incontancy, or rather the imprudency of thee two Lovers, by a two-years abence, during which time there paed good correpondency betwixt them, and they heard from each other very oft.

At lat heaven (which does ordinarily favour thoe that love, and continue loving) did deliver Palanice from the obligations of marriage by the death of Roiliander.
She eeing her elf now free, and weary of the Sebuians, he returned into her native air, where he found Prince Sigimond married: and though he was preently after a widdower, yet no parks of that old affection which once he extinguihed were een to revive: But Seleines who expected her with extream impatience, receaved her with abundance of contentment.

I make a brief relation of thee things unto you Hylas, that you may the better undertand what a task Amilcar undertook when he addreed himelf to erve Palanice: ince he was already engaged another way long before, and that to a peron of very rare and high accomplihments; yet the obervances of my brothers were uch, and he addreed with o much prudence and dicretion, that Seleines could not defend himelf againt apprehenions of jealouie, a thing very common amongt lovers, and uch as have not a very full aurance of the good will of thoe they court. At firt, Palanice eemed as if he were afraid to cat any eye of love upon him; but afterwards, whether it was that ome friend had given her advice, or whether he diguted omething in Selienes, but o it was, that he received the ervices of Amilcar very favourably, making it appear that he gave uch counel unto Cercinea, as he would not follow her elf, for he advied her to make Clorian jealous. One day when Amilcar and Silienes both were with her at her houe, and neither of them, for fear of each other, durt talk a illable of their affections, they began to hint at it after uch a manner, as laves do, for fear of beating, and fell into a dicoure of laves. I wih, aid Sileines, that I might, as laves are for fear of loving, be marked under that notion, by your fair hand: Truly, aid he, if you will, I will atisfie your deire. Then taking his hand, hall I, aid he, with the point of a needle, et my mark upon your arm? If you hould, aid he, I hould not keep it long, for it would wear out: No, no, aid he, (after he had begun to cratch it a little) I will put a little ink upon it, and it will continue long: Sileines then conenting, he began with the point of a needle to rae the skin by little and little; but he impatient of o much pain, could not any longer indure it. Then Amilcar, holding out his arm, here Madam, aid he, honour this arm with what mark you pleae, and you hall ee, the pain hall not deprive me of that contentment. Palanice, who was not o familiar with my brother, no, no, Amilcar, aid he, I dare not do you o much harm: and yet, replied he, you dare do it for Sileines; 'Tis true, anwered he, but it is by way of revenge, for he did me an injury long ince, and I would punih him for it. Then Madam, aid Amilcar, do that unto this arm by way of recompence, which you would have done by way of revenge upon the arm of Sileines. Pray Sir, aid Seleines, what recompence can you demand of her? The gods, replied my brother, do accept of the good will for the deed it elf. This Lady therefore, whom I eteem and honour no les then any goddees, does own unto me a great recompence, if it be proportionable unto the good will I have to do her ervice. The Ladies of this country, anwered Sileines, are o far from o much liberality, that they do not pay thoe debts which they jutly ow, and therefore it is very unlikely they hould be o forward as to pay off thoe obligations which are yet to come. There are, replied my brother, both ervants and ervices of everal orts and prices: beides, I believe, prayers and upplications will never offend any; and I do beg this favour, but not as a due debt. Palanice, who as I believe was deirous to nourih the jealouie of Sileines; No, no, aid he, I would have Amilcar to know that you do make us far more niggardly and pairing of our favours then we are: then taking his hand, but now I do not know, aid he, whether my reolution will let me finih that payment which you ask: upon this word he made in his arm the firt letter of her name, whilt he did not eem o much as to feel what he did; and afterwards he took the blacket ink he could chue, and filled up the cratch which he had made, and which entred o into the skin, that the print of it would remain a long while, at which Sileines began to grumble, but he began to laugh, and aid, had I marked all thoe that were mine, thus, I hould have known them again when they trayed from me, or might in reaon have demanded them back from thoe that tole them from me. If you think to have retained them that way (aid Sileines, who was
extreamly stung, and knew he did it in reproach of him) I believe you are deceived. However, replyed he, I will try this means, ince I have found all others naught. Take heed (aid he, and went away in a dicontented manner) that the fault be not your own. Thus Sileines went away, and left the room free unto my Brother, who was not at all orry to ee this petty divorce, which yet lated not long; for within two days after Sileines returned, and with a thouand repentant ubmiions, obtained a pardon for his cholerick departure.

On the other ide, Lucindor, the younger Brother of Cercinea, and Cerintes, Brother unto Clorian and Palanice, who loved our Siter, they lot no opportunities of hewing their wills; and as Seleines was jealous, Lucindor and Cerintes were no les. I will not here enter into any elogies in commendations of Florices deportment, left, Hylas you hould upect me of flattery and partiality (he being my Siter) but the truth is, he carried her elf o prudently, as deerved abundance of eteem; you ee her modet behaviour, and equality towards all, and he is the very ame towards one that he is towards the other; o ballancing her favours, as one can very hardly brag of any favour above the other.

The firt that loved her was Lucindor, but he was preently contrained to a long journey, he found Cerintes, if not in his place, yet in one that was no les advantagious then his; and therefore he being in humour very like unto his Brother Selienes, he was out of all patience; yet Florices dicretion did o temper his pirit, that at lat he was brought to terms of reaon, though not without much heart-burning betwixt thee two Rivals; and had not Cerintes been a very rarely accomplihed Cavalier, and Lucindor the ame, certainly the jealouie that was betwixt them was uch, as perhaps might have produced ill effects.

When the affections of thee two Cavaliers were at the height, Florice was forced out of the Town to ee an Aunt that was very ick: This departure was very ad unto both thee Lovers; for nothing is more inupportable in love, then to loe the ight of the loved party.

Thus thee four Cavaliers purued their deigns, whilt I was at Agaune, where days eemed o long and tedious to me as years. And becaue I aw my buines would retain me yet longer there, my deires of knowing how Cercinea did, and how Beliard did thrive in my negotiation, I dipatched a meenger unto him, with a Letter for him to preent unto Cercinea.

This meenger made uch hate, that the third day he arrived at Lions, where Beliard began to be weary, and wonder that he heard no ofter from me, and to think that the buines which I left to his negotiation, ought to have made me write oftner unto him: He began therefore to complain againt my forgetfulnes, when he received my letter, which convinced him that he was too blame in having any uch thoughts of me: He received thee Letters with extream contentment, becaue Clorian about three days before was forced into the Country about ome buines which would retain him there; but yet Palanice was always at Cercineas beds ide, or ele the ervant which they had et to wait upon her: But Amilcar knowing what affection I bore unto Cercinea, he would go often unto Palanice, and entertain her with talk of buines, whilt in the interim Beliard effected his.

At this time, when my Letters came, Amilcar was very buie at Court with Prince Sigimond; and Beliard who ate upon thorns till he talked with Cercinea, he durt not go unto her alone; but as fortune was, he met Palanice as he was going from her houe to the Temple; and aoon as he was out of ight, he went immediately into the houe, where by fortune he met Andronira; Sweetheart (aid he) how does our Mitris? As for your Mitris (aid he, and miled) I cannot tell how he does; but as for mine, he begins to mend, thanks be to God, and I believe will not long keep her bed. If I have any Mitris, (replyed he) it mut be undertood Andronira, but when I ay our Mitris, you mut undertand I mean Cercinea; for he being Mitris unto my Mitris and my Mater, I may very well call her ours. Ah Diembler (replyed he. and miled) if he were no more the Mitris of your Mater, then Andronira is yours, you would not come to ee her o often. Then having ome buines to do in the houe, he told him, that he
might venture to go unto Cercinea for all the other woman was there, for he will not tell tales. How? aid Beliard, have you gained her already? Cercinea, anwered he, has charmed her, and won her love, o as I dare ay he will not do any thing that will dipleae her; but for all that, it is not good to trut unto her altogether, until a little further tryal; and ince he takes o much delight in eeing you dance, and hearing you ing, I am afraid Beliard, that if you be my ervant, I mut ere long go look out for another. No, no Andronira, (replyed he) but however, I will dance and ing; and he hall love me, and I will eem to love her: Upon this, becaue he would not loe the opportunity, he went up to Cercineas chamber, in uch a inging, dancing, and jolly manner, that as oon as the Wench heard him; Oh Madam (cryed he, and clapt her hands together for joy) yonder is Beliard; At the ame time he entred, and eigning not to ee Cercinea in bed, he ran to the wench with open Arms, as if he would have kied her; but when he came to the middle of the room, he topt upon a udden, eeming as if he had not pyed her Mitris till then: Madam (aid he unto her) had I thought you had been in bed, I hould not have preumed to enter. Beliard, aid he, I know your dicretion, and therefore you are welcome: this is not the firt time you have een me in this place. 'Tis true Madam, anwered he, but now you are ick, what pretence can I have for my coming hither? To comfort me in my icknes, replyed he. Madam (aid he then very gravely unto her) If you would take one medicine which I can tell you, I wear by Jupiter it would preently cure you. Are you in good earnet? aid the wench, and interrupted him. Yes (replyed Beliard) and I wih he would believe me. Did I think (anwered Cercinea) that your medicine were a good one, I would ue it. Beliard who deired to give her the Letter under this pretence, Madam (aid he) when did I ever tell you a lie? Or wherein did I ever deceive you? Never, aid he, but I am o weary of all Phyicians, who torment me with o many lothome drugs, as if I thought your medicine were a good one, I would take it with all my heart. Madam, aid Beliard, never let me live a moment longer in your favour, if it do not mot perfectly cure you. Cercinea knew wel enough that this medicine was omthing which was more proper for the mind then the body; and being very willing to be deceived, he hearkned unto him: What? aid he, mut I take any lothome potion? No, Madam, anwered he; This medicine does conit mot in the vertue of ome words. Perhaps then, replyed he, it is ome charm. No, replyed he, I am no Sorcerer; The words may be well undertood, they are no unknown Characters, nor has any thing like Sorcery in them. Then Beliard, aid he, I am willing to make ue of them, tell me therefore what I mut do? This remedy, replyed he, mut be kept very ecret; for if it be divulged, it will loe its vertue. Upon this he kneeled down by her beds ide, and taking the Letter which I had written unto her, Do you think (aid he aloud) that I mock you? He who give it unto me, did write in this paper the directions which are to be ued, and which I will let you ee: then feigning to look it out amongt many other papers that he had in his pocket, he gave her the Letter, which he firt unealed, to the end the wench hould not upect any thing: Then he read thee words.

body.head: ALCANDERS Letter unto CERCINEA.
body.p: OF all the torments that a mortal man can endure, none are more cruel then thoe of Love; and amongt all the torments of Love, abence is the mot intolerable: and of all abences, mine has the mot bitter Qualifications. To loe the ight of her for whom only I deire to have any eyes, to leave her ick in bed, and not to hear any news of her health, are the tortures which are reerved for me. If the mierable condition of a mot adly afflicted heart can move you unto it, let me hear how you do, but let paion, and not compaion obtain this favour from you.

div.p: Well Madam, aid Beliaid aloud, how like you the receipt? is it not a good one? I do not know, anwered he and miled, whether it be a good one, but it is very pleaant. But Madam, replied he, the man who gave it unto me, did give me this alo, which is a more particular direction how to ue it; I would have you to ee it alo, that you may be as skilful as my elf: Then he preented unto her the Letter which I wrote unto him; Cercinea not daring to refue it, let the wench hould enter into any upition, he took it. Beliaid, aid he, in a low voice, this is a fine invention to make me reade Letters: Madam, aid he, we mut delude the eyes of this troubleome wench: upon this, he began to read that Leter which I ent unto Beliaid.

body.head: ALCANDERS Letter unto BELISAID.
body.p: O My dear friend, how infinitely do I envie the happines which thou enjoyet? all the contentment which I enjoy here, is to think of thoe felicities which you enjoy there: and every thought ends with this wih, that I were as happy as Beliaid: But dear friend I mut accue you of neglect, that can let it be o long without letting me know the tate of my life: Of my life, I ay, ince it mut be the place where you are from whence that news mut come; be thou a little more careful of thy mater who loves thee: I would ay with all his heart, if I had it here, but thou knowet very well where I left it.

div.p:
Here is in this, aid Cercinea aloud, more buines then you told me of; and the wort is, I am afraid your receipt will not work thoe effects: for methinks it is very uncertain, believe it Madam, replied he, there is nothing but what is true, and I will die rather then tell you a lie. Well, aid he, what mut I do to make tryal of it? Madam (aid he and poke low) you mut love my mater, not only according to his merit, but according to his love of you; and for a tetimony of it, you mut honour him with a Letter. Ah Beliaid, replied he, that is too much; I had rather make ue of other more common medecines: The wench, who was buie about ome trivial work in the chamber, he came then unto her mitres: Madam, aid he, you have been o long in the hands of Phyicians, and cloyed with their potions, that it were not amis to make trial of Beliaids receipt. I beeech you tell me, is it a thing that is difficult to be taken? weetheart, anwered Beliaid, and interrupted (becaue he was afraid that Cercinea could not et o good a diguie upon it as he could) I will tell you what you mut do: Do you ee this Paper? (aid he taking the Letter which I writ unto Cercinea) all that he need to do, after he has read it over three times, is to ay, I do believe it with all my heart, and kis the Paper; then that he lap it up and hang it in a tring about her neck, o as it may touch the nearet place to her heart for nine dayes together, and never trut Beliaid again whilt you live if it do not cure her: O Madam, cried out the wench, this is a fine eaie medecine, and oon done: It is not uch an eaie matter, replied Cercinea, to keep it o long to the place next my heart, epecially when I am aleep; there is the greatet difficulty, aid Beliaid, and that none do read it but your elf: for if they do, after you have begun to apply it, they will infallibly have the ame dieae which you have, and will make you alo wore then you were before; and therefore, when the nine dayes are expired it mut be burned, and o (aid the wench) all the petilence of the dieae will conume away? No doubt of it, anwered Beliaid, and when it is burning, you hall ee everal colours in the fire: O Madam, aid the wench then, this remedy mut needs be good, and I will help you to hang it about your neck, o as it may hang jut to the place of your heart; but firt let her read it thrice over, aid he,
and get you out of ight, unles you will repent it: Cercinea upon this could not forbear laughing, to ee how quick the wench was to be gone, and then he took the paper and read it, but the wench was more careful of not eeing it, then Beliaid could deire her, and therefore he called her again, and aid, there was no danger to be feared if he did not read the words, o as he came in again, they lapped the paper about with ilk, and hung it about her neck in a ribband; and becaue Beliaid aid it mut be applied jut to the place where her heart did beat, the wench would needs feel with her hand where it was: but Cercinea, who laughed to ee how officious he was, would not permit her to feel her heart beat. Madam, aid the wench, you are not o wie as you hould be, pray let me place it right, for I know if every circumtance be not oberved, the medecine will do no good; at lat, this wench having put the paper where it hould be, nine dayes, Madam, aid he, will be quickly expired, take a little pains, for nothing o weet as health, ere long you will be able to walk in the Athenian Gardens, and enjoy all the pleaures about the Town: As Cercinea laughed at this piece of Sorcery, o did Beliaid in his thoughts. But at lat, becaue he feared left Palanice hould return from the Temple; This Madam, aid he is not all, I will now tell you the lat thing that you mut do: then approaching near unto Cercinea, Madam (aid he in a low voice) I beeech you, after all this port, that you will be pleaed to have pity upon my mater, and favour him with the honour of one word in a Letter. Beliaid (anwered he in a low voice) though I would, yet I cannot do it, becaue of thee two impediments: Firt, I have neither pen, ink, nor paper; and econdly, I am o watched, that the eyes of this wench are upon me both night and day, for Andronira and he lie together upon that Pallet in the night. For the firt difficulty, replied he, it is eaie to find a remedy, for I will bring you pen, ink, and paper: As for the other, does not a candle burn all night in your chamber? If it do, Andronira, when the other wench is aleep, may give you the candle, and you may write what you pleae. Beliaid, aid he, I would gladly be excued this: No, no, anwered he aloud, you mut oberve all circumtances very exactly; o thinking he had ordered every thing very well, he went his way, let Palanice hould return.

At his going out of the chamber he found Andronira, and (falling into a fit of laughing) aid that her mitres would acquaint her with the mot rare invention that ever was, in which he mut be aitant, but he durt tell her no more for fear of meeting Palanice. This wench who was very ubtile, went into the chamber, and asked Miina (for that was the other wenches name) what was the matter with Beliaid, that he went away o contentedly? We have all reaon to be o alo, anwered he, if his receipt be good: What receipt, asked Andronira? Ask my Lady, replied Miina; I wear he looks better on't already, and he aid truly, for Cercinea had laughed o heartily, that a very high colour was come into her face: Madam, aid Andronira, I beeech you what trange Phyick have you taken? Then Cercinea told all paages aloud, and afterwards told her every thing in private, at which he could not chue but laugh, though he eemed to believe it more then Miina.

Beliaid, who deired my contentment above his life, did not fail to come in the evening, with an inkhorn and paper in his pocket; but it perplexed him extremely to find Palanice at Cercineas bedide when he came into the chamber: Come (aid he in a confident way (how does your Phyick? Cercinea miled at Palanice, Do you know (aid he unto her) that Beliaid hath given me a receipt? I come to know (aid he and interrupted) whether our receipt have cured you. How Beliaid, aid Palanice, can you cure Ladies? Yes, fair ones, anwered he; and therefore when you are ick, pray come to none but me, I know you to be a man of much merit and knowledge, replied he, but I never knew that your knowledge reached o far, till now. But by the work, anwered he, it may be known what the workman is: I will give you my life, if within three dayes this fair ick Lady do not loe that name: What of fair? (aid Palanice) no of ick, replied he: However aid Cercinea, I hall not be o cloyed with this Phyick as I have been with others: Palanice would have inquired more particularly what the
Receipt was, and perhaps had made a better dicovery then Miina, but as fortune was, he heard a voice in the treet, which he knew preently to be Sileines, brother unto the fair Cercinea, and he ran to the window to look upon that Cavalier, who was her profeed ervant, and in the mean time Beliard conveyed Pen, Ink, and Paper, under the pillow of that fair Lady, beeeching her to have pity upon the mot faithful Lover that ever lived. Well, aid he, and miled, I will take the advice of my Councel, Clorian and Palanice. Beliard haked his head, and without any anwer, went unto the window to avoid upition, and to hear Sileines ing. Palanice who was skulking under the window let thoe in the treet hould ee her, caued Sileines to enquire whether he was in the houe; and hearing that he was, he entred, and was doubly glad to ee his Siter recovered, and to meet his dear Palanice with her: If Beliard would have talked with Cercinea, he had opportunity enough; for Palanice and Sileines had o much erious buines of their own, that they never minded others: But he not thinking it neceary to tay any longer there, to hew that he had no need of any opportunities, he went away, and aid nothing to any one, as if he were a dometique, and inited not upon any ceremonious complements.

The next morning he went to viit his patient, and ee what operation his Receipt had, taking his time for it, when Palanice, according to her cutome, had bid good morrow unto Circinea, and was gone to the Temple.

He entred into the houe, and undertood from Miina, whom he met upon the tairs, that Cercinea found her elf o well after her Receipt, that he had a good mind to rie, and walk a little up and down the room. And may I go in, aid he? Yes anwered Meina, I am confident he will be glad to ee you; and good reaon he has, for your Receipt is worth a thouand of all others, which did but make her wore. The bet news replyed he, that I could hear; but Sweet-heart has he not removed the Receipt this morning? No, not yet, anwered he. Oh aid Beliard, I was afraid he would, and therefore I came to ee, and put her in mind of it. Upon this he went up the tairs, and into the chamber, where he found Cercinea up, and Andronira combing her hair. I am very glad, Madam, (aid he unto her after he had bid her good morrow) to find you out of bed. I believe (anwered he and miled) that if Miina fall ick, he has uch a good opinion of you, and your Receipt, that you mut make the ame for her. My Receipt Madam, replyed he, is only for you; but I beeech you tell me, how did you pas away the night? Andronira can tell you, aid he, that I have oberved your directions: Upon this, eeing none in the chamber, he took the Letter from Andronira, and gave it unto him; Here (aid he) Seal it, and aure your Mater that I writ it for your ake. Oh Madam, replyed he, This favour will make him compleatly happy; and I dare ay, this paper mut never depart from that place where you wear that Receipt which I gave unto you, for he will hold it at a far dearer rate then all his etate. You have that opinion, anwered he, becaue you think he loves me. I do not think it, replyed he, for I know it of mot certain knowledge. As Andronira was combing her hair, Beliard was very buie in taking that hair which tuck upon the Combe, and which, by reaon of her icknes, did come off very much. Madam (aid he) if you will make him mot perfectly happy, give me leave to end him this which your Comb hath tolen from your fair hair. Oh God! aid he, I had rather die then any man living hould have any of my hair; and becaue he had it already in his hand, Andronira, aid he, let him not have it. Believe it, Madam, aid he, he has it already. Oh God! aid Cercinea, what a fool you were to let him take it. Then turning towards Beliard, Come, come aid he, give it me again, for I will have it, ele be extreamly angry with you. Pardon me Madam, I beeech you, anwered he; for treaon, and breach of trut, is the mot abominable vice that can be in man. True, aid he, but there is neither in this which I ask: If in retoring this which you ask, anwered he, I do not commit treaon, and break my trut, I am contented to retore what I tole; but ince I know you will count me the mot infamous man upon earth if I hould, I will keep it. Thee excues and pretences (anwered he) hall not erve your turn, for I will have it; and indeed Beliard, you will
do me a mot ignal dipleaure, if you do not retore it unto me. Firt Madam, aid Andronira, he pleaed to hear his reaons. My reaons, anwered he, are invincible; for when my Mater commanded me to tay in this Town, about the buines which I know of I vowed unto him, to do all I could that would conduce to his contentment; and were I not a Traytor, and a mot perjur'd peron, if I hould retore this back? and did I not falifie that trut which he repoeth in me? Certainly Madam (aid Andronira) he is obliged in Concience to keep his Vow. Certainly Andronira (aid Cercinea) you are out of your wits, to think that any man ought to have any of my hair. Madam, replyed Beliard, as unto you, Beliard is no man, he is only your ervant. She would have replyed, but Miina entred; he topt upon a udden: and Beliard fearing let this udden ilence hould raie any mitrut, Sweet-heart (aid he unto her) I am glad you are come to ait me, for this Lady will continue the Receipt no longer, and ays, that once is often enough to ue it: and I aure you, he had better never to have begun, then to leave it o imperfect. Oh Madam, anwered the Wench, What a trange humour is this? Will you be always ick? I pray what pain does the Receipt of Beliard put you unto? It vexes me, aid Cercinea, to continue the ame thing o long. But Madam, replyed Andronira, Is it not better to continue it o long then to continue ick in your bed? The truth is Madam, aid Miina, if you will not oberve the directions of the Receipt with a good will, you hall by force, for you mut read it: Then untying the tring which was about the paper, he preented it unto Cercinea to read. Prithee good Miina (aid Cercinea unto her, read it for me. Nay by my Faith Madam (anwered he, and turned away) I heartily thank you, would you have me to be ick? Andronira and her Mitris laughed heartily at the implicity of the wench; and after Cercinia had read it, what (aid he mut I do with it now? Kis it thrice (aid M • ina) and ay, I do believe all that is written in this Paper; and becaue Cercinea eemed unwilling, the poor wretch compelled her by force to kis it, and repeat word for word every illable of the directions, but not without much mirth to all the company: At lat all the ceremonies of this charm being ended, and Cercinea preently after dret, news was brought that Palanice was returning from the Temple, and Seleines in her company; upon this Beliard approaching unto her, aid, This Preent Madam, which you have ent unto the mot faithful Lover that ever was, or ever will be, will keep him alive: for otherwie, his orrows, to be o long abent from you, would mot infallibly have killed him. Beliard (anwered he) I do conent unto what you will; but remember, that if he do fail either in fidelity or dicretion, you hall anwer for it. Beliard would have replyed, but the coming in of Palanice and Sileines, and a little after, of Amilcar, prevented him: and when he aw them entred into dicoure, he retired according to his cutome unto his houe, where he did write every paage o punctually, as I believe he did not omit one circumtance. But in what a rapture of joy was I, when opening Cercineas Letter, I found her hair in it! I kied it a thouand times, and it was happy that none was preent when I opened them, for it had been a thing impoible for me to have concealed my extream contentment. At lat after I had kied, and over-kied this fair hair, I read the Letter, which was in thee terms.

body.head: CERCINEAS Letter unto ALCANDER.
body.p: Your paionate Deire and Wihes of my Health, do infinitely oblige and pleae me: May Heaven in requital, give you that happines and contentment which you merit and deire. This wih comes from her who loves you above all thoe that profes any affection unto Cercinea.

div.p: When I call to memory thoe contentments which I received at that time, I cannot chue but charge them with want of affection, who ay that there are more pains then pleaures in love.

For Hylas, no mortal man can be capable of greater felicity, and no les then two hearts and two ouls are requiite to gut it. Had any een my actions, certainly they would have aid, I had been out of my wits: but I will abridge the relation of them into as narrow a room as poibly I can, and tell you that the dayes which I was to tay amongt the Veragrois, eemed longer then they were wont to be, and therefore, I made uch hate, as within ix dayes after, I departed and came to Lions.

As oon as I aw my beloved Beliaid, I was o tranported with joy at thoe good offices which he had done me in my abence, that I could not Carres him enough. He on the other ide who loved me extremely well, had o great a deire to talk with me in private, that he would hardly give me leave to ee my mother and my brother. But after our firt alutations, (having given a general relation of my baenes) I pretended to be very weary, that I might retire with my dear Beliaid: and I believe my brother took notice of it; for I aw him mile two or three times at my impatience, and meauring me by himelf. Beliaid on the other ide, who was no les impatient then I, did follow me o cloe into my chamber, as I was no ooner entred, but he had hut the door. Then did I redouble my Carees, and asked particular quetions of all he had done during my abence. He anwered unto every thing, with more atisfaction to me, then ever I durt hope for or deire: Thus Hylas, we pent above two hours which eemed to me not a quarter, and I believe, had we not been interrupted by beeing called to upper, our eparation had not been oon, but it was not without a million of carees and thanks.

Becaue Beliaid told me that Cercinea would be glad to ee me the ame night, as oon as we aroe from the table, we eemed as if we would go to the Court, but went traight to the houe of that fair Lady; and to have better opportunities of talk, alo my brother being as deirous to ee Palanice as we Cercinea, he went along with us, and by this means we were welcome to the houe, for Palanice was very glad of my brothers company.

Lucindor, who was a ervant unto our iter, aluted us with all poible curraes, and Sileines as it fortuned was not there, not thinking that Palanice would go that night unto Cercineas houe; both he and Palanice were a little urprized, to ee me o unexpectedly: Cercinea bluht, and turning to Beliaid, after all complements and alutes were done; Ah Beliaid, aid he unto him, why did you conceal the coming of Alcander, from us? Madam, anwered he, it was concealed from me almot as much as from you, for he is but newly returned; but going a little nearer her whilt I was in ome complements with Palanice; yet aid he, if he had come in the morning, I would not have acquainted you: Why, aid he, for two reaons, replied he, the one, becaue I would not be the relatour of any thing before Alcander. And the other is, becaue I thought, you would not care for the news; and becaue he looked upon us and did not anwer him: what Madam, aid he, do you not conent unto what I ay? What would you have me anwer, replied he and miled, but that you are a lyer in both? Upon this, becaue I came towards her, he left him: I am glad of your return Sir, aid he, becaue now I hope to ee Florice hortly, who cannot be long abent from o dear a brother.
