I thought Madam, anwered I, you would have been glad of my return upon another conideration, more advantageous unto me; but I ee, that as you are as fair as you were wont to be, o you are no kinder then when I departed: what reaon have you Alcander, replied he, to accue me thus? becaue Madam, replied I, you do not ay you are glad of my return, for my own ake, who honours and adores you above all the world: I believe Alcander, aid he, that Beliaid and you have conferred notes together in your chamber, that you may agree both in one tale. Truth is Madam, aid I, Beliaid and I do often talk of you, and had I aid that we talk of nothing ele in private, I had aid truly, for I have as great a confidence in him as in my elf; but as for conferring of any notes together,
whereof you peak, we never o much as thought of any uch thing: for there being but one truth, we never agreed together upon any thing ele. Well, aid he, eeming deirous to change dicoure, I will believe what you and Beliaid pleae: But pray Alcander tell us how you have lived ince we lot you? Madam, anwered he, if you would know of Alcanders life, you mut ask the fair Cercinea, for it is only as he is pleaed to ordain it: Come, come, aid he, you are a diembler; tell me what adventures you have met with in your voyage, and what contentments you have received in it: Madam, aid I unto her, never was man more mierable then Alcander in his abence from you, nor ever any o happy as he, when he received the honour of hearing from you; and therefore I had reaon to ay that my life was jut as you were pleaed to have it, nor ever hall be any otherwie; but this is not it I would know of you, aid he, and interrupted him, tell me whether you have effected your buines well, and whether your voyage has been to good purpoe; Beliaid ent me word Madam, aid I unto her, that my buines was effected better then I could hope, o did the fair Cercinea alo; and that's the reaon of my return o oon, not only to kis your fair hand for o great a favour, but alo to pay that Homage which I ow unto you, as unto her who may dipoe of my life, and all I have, as he pleaeth.

She would have anwered, when Palanice not being o attentive to my brothers dicoure, as to forget Clorians buines, he oberving how affectionately I poke unto Cercinea, he came and interrupted us, eeming as if it was only out of civility, becaue I was yet a tranger: In the mean Beliaid was not idle, but talked with Andronira, and inquired of all dometick news a particularly as he could: he heard that my affairs could not be in a better condition then they were, unles Clorian did marry her, or divert her from me: That Cercinea had a great good will towards me, but the imperious authority of that man, by means of Palanice, did o retrain her, as it was impoible for o young a pirit to withdraw her elf from that ervitude, o oon as he and I deired: That if a means could be found to make Palanice in love with Amilcar, it would be a way to divert her from the protection of her brother: for believe it Beliaid, aid he, love has more prevalence then friendhip, and if ever he hould love in good earnet, Amilcar might make her do what he would: yet I believe he will have a hard task to overcome her: for Sileines who has loved her long, has gained much upon her. O fool, aid Beliaid unto her, new conquets are alwayes mot eteemed, and loved.

But being late we were contrained to part, and therefore bidding goodnight we retired to our chambers with much atisfaction to my elf, where as late as it was, Beliaid and I, had a long dicoure, from whom I heard all the dicoure betwixt Andronira and him.

As oon as Florice heard of my return, it eems he had a mind to make good the words of Cercinea; for he preently came to ee me, but becaue her Aunt was very ick he could not tay, only dined with us and then returned; yet not o oon, but Lucindor was firt advertied of it: for Beliaid, who thought this to be advantageous unto my affairs, was of opinion that it was requiite to oblige him, and to enter into ome conferrence with him, to the end that when he came to Cercineas houe he might bid him welcome: It was Beliaid therefore that gave him this intelligence, yet he no ooner came but Florice departed.

But Hylas, you may remember how I once did write omething in the glove of Cercinea; I know not how it came to pas, but o it was, that they came to Palanices hands: we had conceit that Miina finding them, did give them unto her; but however, Clorian was quickly acquainted, and leaving all his Court buines at randome, he returned home with more hat then I deired. The firt vexation I reented, was, that Cercinea entreated Beliaid to keep me from making o many viits; and when I did go to ee her, he durt hardly come near me, or cat an eye that way, much les to peak unto me; I did reent this change very adly, and much admired at it: for I thought thoe tetimonies of good will which he had given me, were too great to be forgotten, and to diemble, it was too gros; and becaue I could not indure this without making ome demontrations of my reentments, Beliaid thought it good for me to end for Florice; for Lucindor perhaps
might gain upon her; which if he did, he might caue Cercinea to hake off the tyranny of Palanice and Clorian.

As fortune was, when we were buied to find out ome handome excue for her return, the death of our Aunt did furnih us with a very good one, o as he returned of her elf, ooner then we looked for her. The ceremony of mourning for this good aged woman was oon over; for the infirmities of old age were uch a great burthen unto her, that her friends rejoyced, rather then mourned to ee her delivered from them. As oon as Florice came, I deired her to ue her utmot endeavours upon Lucindor, to favour me; he, who loved me very well, and wanted neither wit nor will to negotiate uch a matter, did o prevail with Lucindor, that he took my part both againt Clorian, and againt Palanice: indeed he poke o affectionately to his Siter, as he (to our thoughts) had ome inclination to me, and began to lean towards my ide; when Clorian and Palanice taking notice of it, reolved to negotiate with Sileines, after the very ame manner that Florice did with Lucindor; for Sileines was in love with Palanice, and was elder brother unto the fair Cercinea, o as by this means he took their part all that poibly he could. To what purpoe Hylas hould I ue any longer dicoure upon this matter; Sileines for the love he bore Palanice, took Clorians part, o as thee two Brothers were one againt the other, and the Family o divided, that all was like to be in a great confuion: But Hylas, it hapned alo at the ame time, that as Cercineas family was divided betwixt Clorian and me: o ours alo was divided betwixt Lucindor and Cerintes; for thoe two Cavaliers (as I told you) loved our Siter Florice; and I took part with Lucindor, becaue he was Cercineas brother, who did me all the good offices he could; and Amilcar favoured Cerintes, brother unto Palanice, upon the ame interet: And preently after, the ame diention hapned between Clorian and Cerintes, becaue Clorian was all for Sileines, who loved Palanice; and Cerintes olicited Palanice for Amilcar, becaue he was the ervant of Florice.

So ee, I beeech you, how Love had buied himelf amongt us; for Florice never met Cercinea, but he poke unto her in my behalf, and Cercinea olicited as much in behalf of Lucindor, Cercinea never aw Palanice, but he entreated her to favour Sileines, and Palanice at the ame time recommended Clorian unto her. When Palanice met Florice, he olicited her in behalf of her Brother Cerintes, and Florice olicited her in behalf of Amilcar. Judge (I beeech you) when we met all together, what fine dicoure there was amongt us: It was very happy we were all intimate friends before thee cros interets fell out; for otherwie, doubtles things would have fallen out very foul amongt us: But all of us foreeeing that things could not long continue thus, without ome more bitter exaperations, one day when we were all met together at Cercineas houe, we all agreed, both Ladies and Cavaliers, to ubmit our elves unto the Will of God, and o went all together to enquire of the Oracle, at the Temple of Venus, where we received this anwer.

div.head: The Oracle.
div.l: LEt Six within this Place remain,
Till Honour otherwie ordain:
No anwer to the Female three
Expect, unles alone they be.

div.p:
An old man who expounded thee words unto us, aid, that the Oracle commanded us to tay in this Town until uch time as ome action of honour contrained us to depart: and that if the Ladies came alone without us, the Oracle would tell them what they hould do. We undertood that three days after they went and conulted with the Oracle. As for us ix, we till waited until ome honourable occaion caued us to go out of Lions: And now it o fell out, that the Prince Godomar
being to attempt the preervation of Dorinde, the Prince Sigimond commanded us to follow him, and we thought our elves obliged in honour to obey him; o we came hither, where we found thee three Ladies; but we know not yet how Love will dipoe of our affairs.
Thus ended Alcander; and it being very late, Hylas (who began to be very leepy) bade them good night, went to his own Bed, and lept till the next morning.

Important affairs did o take up the mind of Adamas, and interrupted his leep that he oft left his bed before he had cloed an eye; and though his age required ret, yet his affection to the ervice of the Nymph, and the publique afety, did make him train his weak and wearied body beyond belief; uch power has deire of doing well upon a generous peron. The greater he aw the danger, and the more difficult he found the remedies, the more did he roue up his generous pirit and judgement to oppoe the deignes of Polemas.

And indeed, the difficulties he aw were not a few, nor mall; for he aw the Nymph detitute of men and money, and to have no place of ecurity but Marcelle, where he made no quetion but her enemies had many friends, and good intelligence: That he was to defend her elf againt a great Souldier, who had all the men, the Forts, the Intelligence, and all the money of her Dominions in his power: His greatet difficulty was, to make his preparations to oppoe this Treaon o ecretly, that the enemy hould not perceive it; a thing o difficult, that it eemed impoible: For Polemas had o corrupted all thoe which he had drawn to his faction, as Adamas hardly knew whom to trut.

The truth is, the unexpected coming of Prince Godomar in a time o opportune, and of all thoe Cavaliers who were with him, as alo of Damon and Alcidon, did much encourage him; thinking it a mot infallible igne, that the Gods intended to preerve the Nymph againt the tyranny of this wicked man. When he was deep in thee thoughts, thoe of the Guard ent to let him know, that there was a good Troop of trangers who deired entrance, who not being willing to tell their names, tayed there; yet their deigne eemed not to be bad, ince there was many Ladies in Coaches. This intelligence was no ooner given unto the Druide, but two Cavaliers were conducted unto him, to let him undertand what men they were.

Thee two Cavaliers were well in years, and eemed to be perons of great repect, which caued Adamas to do them much honour. And becaue they deired to talk in private with him, he carried them into his Cloet, where the elder of them began thus.

Prudent and age Sir, Argira, Queen of the Picts, hath ent us unto the great Nymph, to let her know, that he is entred into her Dominions, before he gave her any notice of it, becaue, not deiring to be known, for ome reaons which he will hew her, he thought it would not be dipleaing unto her: And becaue he is contrained to obey an Oracle, he has ent us, to beeech you from her, you would be pleaed to permit her entrance, and to let her pas unknown, auring her elf, that when the Nymph does know the reaon of her deire, he will think it mot jut. How? aid Adamas and interrupted, is the Queen of the Picts at the Gates? And being anwered he was; Oh God (aid he) how orry will the Nymph be, if he hould not know it, and will be extreamly dipleaed that o great a Princes hould be no better received in her Dominions! He would have gone on in his excue, if thee two Cavaliers had not interrupted him. Sir (aid they) the Queen deires not to be known upon any terms, and beeecheth the Nymph to conceal her: We are not hye in acquainting you with it, becaue we hear great reports of your widom; but we beeech you, from the Queen our Mitris, to take no notice of it, and to let her ee the Nymph, as a tranger unknown, that he may communicate the caue of her Voyage unto her. I know Sirs (aid Adamas unto them) that the Nymph would not upon any terms in the world dipleae the Queen, but will be extreamly joyed to ee her within her Dominions; and ince you deire to have it o, we will go all together unto the Nymph,
and acquaint her whoe pleaure I know is, that the Queen may command any thing here as freely as amongt the Picts.

Upo this, they went all three together, and Adamas acquainted her with the news, which being o unexpected, did not a little atonih her; and cauing the two Cavaliers to enter, he undertood from them what Adamas had briefly hinted unto her, and more, that the principal caue which moved Argira to come thus unknown, was that misfortune of Roilion whom he brought with her, and whoe mind was o ditracted, as moved much compaion from all thoe that formerly knew him.

For his reaon, he deired that he might be lodged by himelf, where none might ee him but his dometicks. The Nymph would have gone her elf to meet her, but the Cavaliers fell down upon their knees and beought her not to do o, becaue the Queen would be extremely offended at it; for Roilion would ometimes commit uch gros follies when he was in any company, that Argira was contrained to come almot alone, having brought with her but the Princes Roanira, the daughter of Poliander King of the Boyers and Ambaries, and a mall company of Cavaliers to guard them.

Since (aid the Nymph unto them) the Queen is not pleas'd to let me pay that honour which I ow unto her, my daughter Galathea hall go in my room to wait upon her unto her lodging in the Catle, where he may be een by none but whom he pleae: No, aid the Cavaliers, he will not be pleaed with that, he will accept of the lodging which you are pleaed to offer, becaue he would be near you; but we mot humbly beeech you not to let the Nymph, your daughter, meet her. Madam (aid Adamas unto her) ince it is her pleaure o to have it, be pleaed to content her in it, and tell her that all your Dominions is in her power, and that you will obey her in all things: If you pleae to command me I will wait upon her to her lodging, and eem as if I went only to command the gates to be opened for her entrance.

Thus was Argira brought to the Catle, and all thoe that came with her, which were about a hundred Cavaliers, were lodged in the Town with all fitting accomodation. Adamas did mot heartily rejoyce at the arival of the Princes, thinking it a great advantage to the Nymphs affairs: for he could not imagine he came to tay only a few dayes; and that if Polemas did attempt any thing, he would be engaged in the Town with them, which would invite the Picts to come and relieve her: Beides, having heard of Roilions great exploits in arms, and of the amity betwixt him and Policander the King of the Boyers and Amburies, and moreover, knowing that Roanira his daughter was with the Queen of the Picts, it was not likely that uch great Kings her neighbours, would uffer her to be beieged in a place without ending relief. And having thus communicated thee things unto the Nymph and Prince Godomar, they were both of opinion, that it was neceary to oblige this Queen, by all manner of kindnees, to interet her elf in their affairs.

And becaue Adamas had already obtained of the Queen, that Amais and Galathea might come and ee her, as oon as he had a little refrehed her elf, the Nymph went unto her, carrying with her only Galathea and Adamas. And that none might take any notice of it, he went through a gallery which paed between both their lodgings.

Argira, hearing of her coming, went into the gallery to meet her, having none with her, but three aged Ladies and old Cavalier. The firt alutations being done, Argira taking the Nymph by the hand, and itting down, Galathea deired leave to go and kis the hands of the Princes Roanira, which the Queen mot willingly conented unto: when he was gone with one of thoe old Ladies, and the doors being hut, the Queen commands the old Cavalier to relate, as briefly as he could, the caue of her voyage, and not to conceal or diguie from the Nymph, or any thing which concerned that buines; and o the Cavalier, in obedience to her commands, began thus.

div.head: The Hitory of ROSANIRA, CELIODANTE and ROSILION.
div.p: PAtience and impetuoity are two means by which men may bring great things to pas; for the one works by force and violence, throwing down every thing that oppoes his deign: and the other by temporizing and moothing the enemy, does get the victory, o as it eems one may arive at one and the ame end, by two contrary wayes. He that is mater of both thee qualities together, may be thought more then man; but becaue humane infirmity is very rarely capeable of both, I think, that all things rightly ballanced, Patience and Moderation is mot comendable and profitable, as being mot grounded upon reaon, And that he, who takes violent impetuoity for his guide, is ooner brought to ruine, and inevitable precipices.

Wie and great Nymph, the dicoure I am to make unto you, will tetifie, that if the Queen had alwayes et this maxime before her eyes, he would not have fallen into o many inconveniency and dipleaures as he hath; but when one goes into paion for advice, it is not to be wondred if the advice be often againt reaon, and draw after it a long train of misfortunes and ditaters; of which I will make you as brief a Relation as poibly I can.

Be pleaed to know Madam, that Policander King of the Boyers and Ambries, being a Prince very young, and eeing that his Provinces, under the age government of the King his father, did enjoy a ecure peace, he was deirous to travel, and by his courage to get glory and renown, o as he tole away ecretly, and with one ervant only, went into the next warre he heard of. This young Prince paed under the notion and title of the errant Cavalier, not only throughout all Gaul, but alo amongt the Grudiens, Menapiens, Battaves, Ubiens, Latobriges, Henides, Tullingeans, Marcomanes; and briefly through all high and low Germany: and afterward paing into great Brittain, he tayed long in the Court of that great King, where, and every where ele, under the name of the unknown Cavalier, he got o much glory, as hardly any in all Europe was better known then he that paed for unknown.

At lat, deiring to return into his own Kingdome, he imbarqued loadned with abundance of glory, and being upon the Armorick coat, his detiny carried him into the Court of the King of Picts, who hearing the fame of his valour, did receive him with o much curteie as invited him to tay longer there, then he deigned.

During the time of his ojourn there, he aw the Princes Argira; and as all things that are written down in the book of Fate are inevitable, o as he loved her, he could not chue but entertain his affection. This lat deigne made him forget his firt, of returning into his own kingdome, but tayed ome moneths in this Court where he changed the name of Cavalier errant unto that of Lover. The truth is, great Nymph, his valour, and the glory of o many combats, atchieved with o much courage and happy ucces, the dicretion honour and repect wherewith he courted this young Princes did oblige her to entertain that affection which he expreed unto her, but yet he would not let her good will unto him appear, until he knew that he was Prince of the Boyers and Ambaries; but he having ecretly made it known unto her, and he not being o young but he could ee that her father could not make choie of a husband for her more great, nor more worthy to command over the Picts, upon his promie never to marry any other but her, he took him for her husband, and uffered him to come unto her ecretly. I ee, great Nymph, that the Queen does bluh to hear me relate thee things: but the belief which he might jutly have, that a Prince o great and o full of honour and affection, would not betray thoe aurances which he had given unto her, does ufficiently jutifie her action and render her blameles.

They continued thus together ome moneths, unperceiued by any, unles her Nure, whom he acquainted with it, as her, that was to facilitate their meetings, and her on whoe name was Verances, whom Policander truted, and mot employed in this buines: At lat, Fortune would not let them any longer live in ret together, but gave Policander a caue of returning into his own Kingdom, by the death of the King his Father. This eparation was extreamly ad unto them both, epecially unto the Princes, who did not only reent his abence, but did almot foreee that he would forget her: yet conidering that beides the los of his father, there was a neceity of his return, he conented unto it, and the more willingly, becaue he promied to end his Ambaadours immediately, to demand her of the King, and o their deired contentment would this way be compleated. Thus he left her, after a thouand promies and oaths, which no ooner out of ight, but were all forgot; for never ince did he hear any thing of him more then what common reports did bring unto her. By this common Fame he undertood, that all his Kingdoms were in a flame, and divided into two factions, the one of the Queen his mother, who was all for him; and the other of a puiant Prince, in ome ort his Coen, called Bourbon Archimbout, who relying upon his friends and confederates, pretended unto the Soveraigne Authority, and to retore it unto his Family, which he aid the great Grandfather of Policander had taken from Bourbon his Ancetor, He made this attempt the more boldly, becaue a report was pread abroad that Policander was dead, who was the only Succeor betwixt him and the two Crowns. The King on the other ide who was old, and whoe vigour and trength began to fail, never offered to make any oppoition againt this deigne, although he aw it; but paed away his life moothly and calmly as he could: o as when he came to die, the faction of the Prince Archimbaut was o high, that if Policander had not peedily arrived, certainly the Queen, his Mother, would have been forced to yeild unto rebellion: For beides the trength of his Faction, he was alo aited by the power of the Limovices, the Queen of which people was his ole and only daughter, who had married their King, and was left a Widdow within a year, having only one daughter by him, named Cephie.

The Princes Argira came to the knowledge of all thee things, only by common Fame; and becaue he thought her elf nearly intereed in the buines, he deired the King, her Father, to end him relief; and the more eaily to invite him unto it, he did craftily make it known unto him, that the unknown Cavalier who had been o long in his Court, was the King Policander; but for all that, reaon of State moved him to take the other ide: For the partakers of Archimbaut made him believe, that Policander was already ruined, that all his hopes were gone, and that it was no prudence to make himelf o potent an enemy, as him, who had already the Kingdom of the Lemovices in right of his daughter, and who ere long would be King of thoe two Kingdoms: Briefly, thee coniderations were o cunningly ininuated into the Kings Belief, as they had uch an influence upon him, that in lieu of aiting Policander, as he deired, and as indeed he ought to have done (for all Kings ought to be enemies unto Rebels) he ent forces unto Archimbaut, and uch, as Policander was counelled not to put things to the hazard of Arms, but rather to top all factions by a more afe, and a more eaie way, which was, by a marriage betwixt him and the only daughter of Prince Archimbaut, whoe name was Cloriena, who though a widdow of the King of Lemovices, yet was very fair and young. Policander did the more willingly hearken to the motion, becaue he was extreamly incened againt the King of the Picts, for ending aid unto his enemy; and Archimbaut was the more willing to embrace it, becaue having but one daughter, and out of hopes to have any more children, he could deire no more then to ee his daughter Queen of the Boyens and Ambaries, and his grand-children King of thoe two Kingdoms. But that which mot of all moved Policander unto it was, a trong report that the Princes Argira was dead; and though the news was fale, yet was it not without ome colour of truth; for ome moneths after Policander was gone, he perceived her elf to be with childe, and being deirous to hide it from the King her father, whom he feared, and not without
reaon, he feigned her elf to be ick, which he might eaily do, by reaon of her extream dipleaure to ee her elf cat off by him in whom he mot truted, he o perwaded the King unto a belief of it, that he thought it good for her to leave the Court for change of ayr; and having made choie of a very retired place, which by the opinion of Phyicians was of a very wholome ayr, he was conducted thither with what company he bet pleaed; and taking very few with her but her Nure and her on, they only knew of her being brought to bed. Now as news is like unto a ball of now, which being tumbled from the top of a hill, does grow as big as another hill before it come to ret, o the reports of her icknes was made to be death unto Policander, without which he could not conent unto this marriage, at leat not without perjury.

This marriage was the firt news which he, to her great grief, heard of, when he returned again to the King her father: and doubtles he had more deeply reented it, if he had not alo heard, that Policander was forced unto this marriage, and that if he had not done o, certainly he had lot his Kingdoms: This gave ome atisfaction to her ad oul, when he conidered, that he committed this fault by contraint, and not by conent of will: and as if he had known what reports were amongt us, he ued the ame to clear himelf; and ince there was no other remedy, he believed them. But her greatet grief was, to hear that the King of the Santons had ent to treat upon a marriage with her, and that it was already reolved upon. This news was mot abominable unto her, becaue he was reolved againt all bands of matrimony, ince he was o unworthily deluded by the firt: But now he aw her elf contrained to change her reolution, ince he could not contrary it, unles he hould make known what he had o carefully concealed; which being once known, would extreamly vex the oul of her aged Father, and become a tain both unto his reputation and her own: Upon this prudent conideration, he married the King of the Santons, by whom within a year he had a on who was named Celiodantes.

But becaue he conented unto this marriage only upon reaon of State, he till retained her firt affection unto the Prince Policander; and it vexed her very oul to think the King of the Santons on hould inherit two great Kingdoms: whilt he, whom he had by Policander, hould live unknown, and without any Dominion. Then again, to have the Son of him whom he loved not, always under her eye, and to be always deprived of his whom he did love, eemed intolerable unto her. See Madam what affection will make her do, and into what extream it will drive one. A little while after he was well recovered from her lying in, he feigned to be very deirous (as it is the common curioity of mothers) to know what would be the fortune of her new born on: The King indeed did all he could to diwade her from it, as thinking it bet to be ignorant of things inevitable; but eeing her o extreamly deirous of it, he permitted her. There was then in thoe quarters a famous Sybil, who, if they may be o termed, rendred Oracles; and urely ome God did peak by her mouth, for otherwie it were impoible any humane hould foretel things o certainly as he did: She was an old woman of great anctity and olitude of life, her hair, which he wore looe about her houlders, was of the ame colour with her garment, both white as now, and her feet were always bare. This woman did profes to be intructed by thoe who ucceeded Vellede and Ganna, two famous Druids who rendred Oracles in Germany, and from whoe intitution came the Ile of Sayn, otherwie called Sena, in the Britanique Sea, oppoite unto thoe Banks which are termed Oiiniens, a place highly renowned for Oracles there rendred. The name of this woman was Meluine, and he was one of the nine which inhabited in the Ile of Sayne: But in as much as they divided themelves into nine Regions, and this Sybils lot was the Picts, the Santons, and mot of the Armorique Cities, he came to inhabite upon the top of a Rock, where he caued a Tower to be built, which he named Lux ignis, from that divine fire which hined in all her anwers, and which ince was called by the people Luignan; thither came all the country about to conult with her: At the firt it was a hard matter to peak with her, for he would never hew her face, to the end, as I believe, that more reverence might be had of her; and when any deired
to know any thing of her, the bet of the company mut always come and bring the demands, and carry back the anwers, and not daring to preume o high as to look her in the face; which to prevent, he wore a veil, that if any were o rah as to look up, he might not ee her. Now this Sybil was then at the Rock of Lu • gnan: And though he ued a fortnight before the Mileto was gathered, to come unto a tone near Poictier, and there remain nine days ready to anwer all quetions, yet the Princes would not tay till he came o near us: Having therefore the Kings leave, he went unto this Rock, with as few in her company as he could; and having accoted the Sybil, he asked her what would be her Sons fortune: But the Sybil anwered:

div.head: The Anwer of the Sybil Miluine, unto the Princes ARGIRA.

lg.l: HArk what the Fortune of them both hall be:
With Fratride the one of them you'll ee,
And by an Incetous marriage menac'd be.
In Forrests where hall be Prince Godomar,
The other hall his enes there recover:
Then Fate will kindly be both t'one, and other.

div.p:
This Oracle, not then undertood, did put her into a cruel perplexity, and he aw now that the King, her father, had good reaon to diwade her from that curioity; yet ilently keeping the anwer to her elf, at her return he fancied a different contruction, which was, that if the young Celiodantes were een, either by his father, or mother, or any ele, except his Nure, and thoe that were to nourih and bring him up, for a certain time, he would infallibly die. The Kings were exceedingly loth to be deprived of the ight of the little Cleodantes, yet fearing ome uch malignant influence, they conented to humour the Queen in her deires. Now the reaon why he deired this, was only to put the on of King Policander into the place of the King of the Santons, as well to enjoy the contentment of eeing him brought up with her, as to ee him hereafter King of the Santons and the Picts: And her deign was o handomly carried, that at the return of the wrong Celiodantes, none had any upition of him, though he was a little too big for his age: For the King of the Santons being of a big tall tature, did help to make every one believe that he would be like his father. Thus Madam, this Princes was both a bad and a good mother. In the mean time, he fearing let if the right Celiodantes hould remain in a place where he might be een by any of the Court, he might come to be known, either by his reemblance of his father, or by the indicretion of thoe who had the keeping of him, he pack'd him away, as far off as he could, and ent him to a Port of the Santons, to be brought up as the childe of Verances, unto whom he committed the care of him, with a good um of money for his education, and to intruct him in all uch exercies and qualities which a Cavalier ought to be: and let by any fortune he hould chance to be lot, either by the death of Verances, or any other accident, he thought it good to give him ome mark whereby he might be known: In order to this, he took a hot iron, with intention to burn him upon the left hand; but as he was looking about where it hould be done to do him the leat harm, & be leat een, he aw that Nature had aved her that labour, and had placed upon the ame hand a mot perfect Roe, o exactly, that no art could poibly do the like: She contented her elf with this mark, and commanded Verances, that at the firt Town he came unto, he hould take the picture of that little hand, and end it unto her, which he
intended to keep as a memorandum; and when he was ready to part, he took a Turkih tone from about her neck, which Policander gave her, and which he eteemed at a very dear rate, not for the value of it, for it was of no great price, but becaue he gave it unto her when he told her that he was King of the Boyers, which he was wont to wear in all his Travels: This tone had engraven upon it, a Lion, with certain German letters, which in that language ignified a King, the on of a King: Policander wore it for his motto; intimating, as the Lion is the King of all other animals, and was begotten by another Lion: o he, though he eemed to be only a Cavalier errant, yet was he a King, and the on of a King. The Queen Argira eeing what fortune this little Celiodantes was to run, he thought this motto uited with him very well: beides, a Turkih tone is very lucky when it is given with a good will; o he hung it about his neck, kied him, and recomended him to Verances, beeeching the gods to be propitious unto him: Natural affection began to work upon the heart of a mother, yet the Tirant love would needs hew himelf the tronger. Perhaps Madam, you may think it trange, that in a buines of this importance, the Queen hould imploy Verances, a young man, and one whoe undertanding perhaps was not o great as uch a ecret required. But be pleaed to know that Verances was on unto her nure, and they two only did know of Policanders love, and the birth of that child which was in the room of Celiodantes, o as he thought it not convenient to trut any more with thoe paages, but better to imploy thee then any other: beides, he was deirous, that if it were her fortune to die, the King Policander might be informed by ome, what love had made her do for his on, and he knew that he would give credit unto whatoever this man did ay.

In the mean time King Policander had by the Queen his wife a on and a daughter: The on was called Ariontes, and the daughter Roanira, and preently after Clorione died, and left many that adly lamented her los. Policander mourned beyond the imaginations of every one, for it was thought that he loved her only as the mother of his children; yet mot certain it was that he did love her, and as certain that Argira was quite out of his memory: O the odd humours of ome men, who can forget thoe they once loved as oon as ever they are out of ight.

p.U: eeing himelf a father of o fine an off-pring and a widdower, he bent all his tudies to rule his dominions well, and to ee his children educated in all noble and Princely exercies and qualities utable to their exes and degrees. And becaue the Princes Cephie, his wifes daughter, whom he had by the King of the Lemovices, and omthing elder then Roanira, was in his hands, after the death of her mother, he brought her up with his own children, making no difference between her and Roanira, who having attained to the age of even or eight years began to appear o fair that he carried away the glory from the greatet beauties in all Gaul, although Cephie in the eyes of many did not yield unto her. The young Prince Ariontes on the other ide, was o apprehenive and capable of every excellency (that he applied himelf unto) that no Prince of his age did equal him either in exercies of warre or peace, which joyed the heart of Policander beyond all expreions.

div.p:
At that time there was ome certain Merchants which ued to traffick upon the Armorick eas, and by reaon of the conveniency of the river Loire, did bring their wares into the Provinces of Gaul, amongt the Heduois, Burgundians, Allobroges, Galloligures, and others: Thee being contrained to pas through the Territories of the Boyers and Ambaries, in hopes of a free and afe conduct did preent unto the King Policander many rare and precious things, and amongt the ret, a young lave, o farre and o exceedingly handome, that as oon as the King aw him, he did dedicate him unto the ervice of the two Princees Cephie and Roanira, becaue he eemed to be no elder then the younget of them. Thee Princees lov'd him exceedingly well, being of a very pliant and weet dipoition, and trove who hould mot oblige him by carees: and becaue his name was Kynicon and that word hard to pronounce, they called him mot commonly by reaon of his beauty, the fair lave. But O the fate of inclination? Although
he was given at the firt unto both thoe Princees, yet he devoted himelf olely unto the ervice of Roanira; not but that he obeyed Cephie in all her commands, becaue he knew it was her deire and his duty o to do; but yet that ervice which proceeds from affection was wholly unto the other, at which Cephie would doubtles have been very angry, if he had been compoed of any Gaul, but he was of o wie and weet a temper, that though he had a mind to be ill pleaed with him, yet he could not be angry: o as all her anger did turn it elf into jealouie of her iter, and ometimes to twit him, who as young as he was, knowing that the dipleaure of that Princes might do him as much harm, did endeavour to pleae her, but it was o hard to hide his affection unto Roanira, that he was alwayes harping upon that tring.

One day, Cephie chid him for that he minded no ervice but her iters, and corned all others: Roanira, by fortune heard him anwer thus: Madam (aid he unto her) I think it a mot high honour to do you ervice, and if I fail, you will oblige me, if you punih me; but the very truth is, that though you hould not be willing I hould erve your iter, yet you mut take away my life if I do not; for if I live I cannot chue. But why (anwered Cephie very angrily) and did not ee Roanira) have you a more ready will to erve my iter, then me? are not you mine as well as hers? I did not ay (replied he very modetly) but that I am as ready to erve you as I ought to do: but, but me no buts, replied he, and looked red with anger, and going nearer him: but Madam, anwered he, then pying Roanira, and changing his dicoure upon a udden: but Madam, here is the Princes your iter: upon this word, going back a pace or two, he lipt out of the chamber door.

This Modety did extreamly pleae both the Princees; Cephie, becaue he would not acquaint Roanira with any paages betwixt them; and Roanira, at his dicretion, in hiding the anger of her Siter Cephie; o as that paage caued both of them to love him better then before. And a few days after, Roanira having an opportunity of talk with him, Prithee, aid he unto him, tell me one thing truly; Have you not much ado to content my Siter? Madam (anwered he) I hall be very glad to be told of my faults, if I neglect any thing in her ervice. I can tell you one (replyed he, and miled) and advie with your elf whether you will relape into it, or no. Surely Madam, anwered he, I hall not; at leat I will endeavour all I can. It is (continued Roanira) becaue you eem unto her to be o affectionate unto my ervice. Yours Madam? replyed he preently. Yes mine, replyed he, and conider with your elf whether or no you will continue it any longer, for this is it which does o much dipleae her. Oh Madam, cryed he, if her dipleaure proceed from thence, I hall continue it as long as I live. Why, aid he, had you rather dipleae her, then leave my ervice? Madam, anwered he, will you pleae I hould tell you the truth? Yes (anwered he) and tell me truly. If I do not (aid he) may the Sun never hine upon me, and may I be odious unto all the earth. Upon this aurance (replyed the Princes) I will believe you. I do wear and vow Madam (anwered he) that though all the Powers in the world hould command me to quit your ervice, I hould be diobedient: Nay more, I hould not think my elf too blame in uch diobedience: For ever ince that day the King, your Father, devoted me unto you, I have o ratified the donation, that I wear by all the Gods, I will never depart from your ervice. But (aid Roanira) were you not at the ame time given unto my Siter as well as me? No Madam (anwered he) for the King only gave me unto her, but both the King and my own conent did give me unto you. But yet (aid Roanira, and miled) he pretends to have as much right unto you as I; yet ince I ee your inclination, I will beeech the King to betow ome other upon my Siter, and let you be wholly mine. To make me become wholly yours Madam (replyed he) rets wholly in your own will, and though the favour you would do me in asking me of the King, be one of the greatet you can do me, yet I mot humbly beeech you not to peak unto him about it, for it may procure me o much ill will from my Lady, your Siter, as I am afraid the King hould remove me from her ervice, and yours alo. Say he hould, (replyed Roanira) would you continue erving me? Nay Madam (anwered he)
both alive and dead, that reolution hall never alter. But ay I would have it for (aid he) would you diobey me? If your Will Madam (replyed he) were tronger then Detiny, you might do what you pleaed; but ince it is not, mot certainly you would be diobeyed in that. Then (replyed the Princes) you hall never by my conent leave my ervice. Upon this, fearing let her Siter, or ome other hould come in upon them he retired, giving him a gentle blow with her hand upon his cheek, as a gage of that promie which he had made unto him; with which he was o well atisfied, that he was highly contented with his fortune: And as he increaed in age, he encreaed alo in affection; of which, the vertues of the Princes: and continual converation with her, was both Mother and Nure; Yet knowing himelf to be a lave, he durt not preume o high, as to dicover any uch thing. On the other ide, Roanira though he feigned otherwie, yet was he not quite exempted from paion, yet her haughty pirit would not allow her to love one that was unknown; and this conideration was a great top to the growth of her affection: All the leave that he gave unto her elf freely, was, to grieve and lament, as oft as he conidered the baenes of his fortune

A little while after, the King eeing him to be every way very handome, had a deire to have him wait upon the young Ariontes, and o have him more in his eye: but fate which had deigned him for other imployments, did afford him uch a glorious occaion to hew himelf, as the like is not upon the Theater of the whole univere.

The King Policander being one that did abominate all eae and idlenes, did much delight in hunting: one day as he was chaing a Hart through a thick wood, a lion ruhed out o near the King, that his hore extremely affrighted began to turn about, and o unhappily, that he fell backward with the pomel of the addle againt the Kings bret: o as the King being under his hore, he was not able to diengage himelf: The hore was run through the body by the Kings word; o as he died preently: the King alo received a little wound in his thigh; all thoe that followed the King, were o affrighted by this fierce beat, which they knew very well (being the greatet and mot furious of all thoe the King kept in iron cages, and was ecaped out) that they were all glad that their hores were affrighted, and in lieu of holding them in, they purred them away as fat as they could: The fair lave only, lighting from his hore, he ran towards the King, and in uch a happy nick of time, that he got between the Lion and him, when this fiery animal was with open mouth ready to devour him: but the courageous boy, without more ado, drew his word, and wielded it o happily, that he ran the Lion to the heart; but for all that, though the word was in the midt of his heart; yet this furious animal in dying, did give his valiant enemy uch a wound upon his houlder with one of his claws, as might very well have dipatched him. At the firt, the fair lave taggered, and afterwards fell, ome five or ix paces ditant from his dead enemy: but though his wound was great, and his fall violent; yet, half atonihed, he preently got up again and ran betwixt the King and the Lion, apprehending him till alive: He tayed o a while, and eeing the furious animal now tame enough, he run to help the King, who was triving to get himelf from under his hore, and with much ado, he helped him up; but when he pied the bloud to run from the Kings thigh: O Sir, aid he, you are wounded and with tears in his eyes would have held him up. Policander, who had more courage then to be daunted at any dangers, did admire the valour and affection of this young boy: fair lave (aid he, and embraced him) thou hat not this day imployed thy courage for an ungrateful mater: and till a better occaion offer it elf, ask what thou wilt, and I wear by my fathers oul it hall not be denied. The lave kneeled down, Sir, aid he unto him, it is your own goodnes to acccept of this ervice which I have done you: but alas Sir, both this, and all that I am able to do, are but tributes of that eruice which I ow, and I dare not pretend unto any recompence: An act o generous as this, replied the King, argues the height of merit, and cannot be equall'd by any recompence, and therefore I command thee to ak omething that may argue me not ungrateful. Sir, replied he, the gods do not meaure they benefits the betow upon us, according to our merits, but their own
good will and pleaure: and knowing that in this you are pleaed to imitate them, I dare preume, ince you command me to ask of you, that which is mot dear unto me, and that is, my liberty; not that I deire ever to be out of the honour of your commands; but to tetifie unto you for the future, that it is my own free will and deire to erve you as long as I live. The King, who thought he would have asked ome great umm of money, or other matter of profit, did till more and more admire the Generoity and Magnanimity of his courage, and embracing him again, yes (aid he) your requet is granted, you are from this hour free, and in tetimony of it, you hall receive the honour of knighthood as oon as we are returned unto Avarick: and though in any other, your age would not permit it (for he was then not above eighteen) yet in you, your courage and fortune requires it.

In the mean time, mot of thoe that ran away for fear returned, and finding the Lion dead, they were ahamed that o young a boy hould have more courage and reolution then themelves, and durt hardly look the King in his face: but when they aw what extraordinary favours the King did unto him, then every one welled with envy; for noble actions does caue envy in the ouls of bae people, and emulation in • enerous pirits.

The King, who deired only to invite others unto well doing, by the example of this valiant youth, as oon as he came into Averick, he made this lave a Knight: and although their wounds would not give them leave to ue much ceremony: yet would he needs have the Princees Cephie and Roanira, with all the Ladies, to be preent. He himelf put on his purrs, and girt him with a word, and kiing him, commanded the Princes Roanira to do the like, which he did with much willingnes and contentment; when all Ceremonies were performed, the King addreed himelf unto him and aid, Cavalier, I do pronounce you free, and would have all eteem you o: Alo, ince your merits do claim a better name then that of lave, I do ordain it hall be changed, and hereafter to preerve the memory of your brave Act in killing a Lion, be called Roilion, and Roanirus Cavalier: This title will oblige both my daughter and me to remember our engagements unto you.

The joyes and thanks of the new Roilion were great, but not greater then thoe of the Princes: after he had humbly kied the Kings hands, he did the ame unto that Princes, with a thouand protetations of eternal ervice; the expreions of which had not ended o oon, if his wounds in his houlder had not contrained him to bed, and to keep it for ome dayes. The Princee had much ado to hide her exceive contentment to ee him made free, for an act o noble: and to give him ome private knowledge of it, he wrote this Letter unto him.

body.head: The Princes ROSANIRAS Letter unto ROSILION.
body.p: YOur courage is victorius and can conquer Fortune, ince it has o generouly retored that unto you, which he mot unjutly detained from you, I would not have your virtue make a top here, but would have you lift up your eyes unto omthing that is above you: Hope well (for I would have you do o) and I will hope as well as you.

div.p:
When he had done, he knew not which way to convey it unto him; but at lat, hearing that his wound bled till, and they could not top it, he ent it unto him, under the notion of a medecine to tench blood, lapt up in a little tafaty; uppoing he would be o inquiitive as to ee what was in it, and it happened as he uppoed; for Roilion receiving it with all the honour and thanks that uch a favour could deerve, at firt he hung it about his neck thinking it to be a real receipt. But in the morning when he was awake, and thinking upon the favour
which the Princes had done him, he had a deire to ee what was in the Taffaty, in a conceit, that the Receipt was writ by the fair hand of his adored Roanira, which treaure he hould eteem as dear as his life; he took it then from his neck, and opening it, he found the Letter, which he read; then he kied it, with uch raptures of joy and admiration, that his wounds began to bleed a freh; and had not the man who waited upon him, heard him igh, this accident doubtles had done him much harm, before any notice could have been taken of it. But the man being very careful of his mater, ran preently to his Bed, and eeing his complexion changed, he asked him how he did? Friend (aid he unto him) help me a little to put this on, which I have in my hand; for it is the Receipt which the Princes ent me to top blood, and which I would needs ee: but I no ooner took it from about My Neck, then my wound began to bleed: Alas Sir (aid the man) I have oft heard ay, that uch things ought not to be een; for if they be, they preently loe their vertue; and if you have read it, expect no good from it. I did read it indeed (aid Roilion) little thinking that uch a thing could take away its trength: Upon this he kied it, and put it about his neck again; which done, he perceived the blood to run till: Friend (aid he) thou toldet me right; the Receipt has lot its vertue: run therefore, and call ome to apply another remedy.

Whilt the Phyicians and Chyrurgions were applying ome powder of his hair burned, and ome other retringent things; Roilion, whoe mind ran more upon the wound of his heart, then that of his houlder, did think this accident to be a very good occaion of thanking the Princes for the extraordinary favour which he had done him, thinking it to be infinitely beyond his merits: and retaining this thought in his memory, till every one was retired, he called for Ink and Paper, and writ what love did dictate unto him: afterwards lapping it up in the ame form that Roaniras Receipt was, and taking the other out of the Taffaty, he put this in the room of it. After he had lapped it up, he bade Meriin (o was the man called that waited upon him) to go unto the Princes, and thank her for the great care he was pleaed to have of him in ending that Receipt: but his curioity was uch, that thinking he had been cured, he read it, and then his wound began preently to bleed again: That he knew no better remedy for his dieae then that Receipt, and mot humbly beeech her to end him another, in lieu of that which he returned back: Meriin was diligent and faithful in delivery of his meage: and though the Princes did very well undertand the meaning of Roilion, yet the durt not to take any notice of it: But taking the Taffaty; Friend (aid he unto him) tell your mater he was too inquiitive; he hould have been contented with the good which the Receipt would have done him, without deires of knowing what it was: tell him I will make him the ame Receipt, but bid him take heed of uffering it to be een; for if he do, it may much prejudice him.

Then going into her Cloet, and hutting the door, he was long in debate with her elf, whether he hould read what he doubted he had written, thinking it omtimes a dihonour unto her elf to love: Roilion conidering the condition wherein he was when firt he came into her ervice; but preently beginning to flatter her paion; and who can blame me (aid he) for loving him that aved the life of the King my father? 'tis true, that fortune conducted him hither without Liberty; but being as it were in his cradle, the greatet King upon earth cannot defend himelf againt uch an accident. To be the firt whom Fortune was pleaed to pit her venome at? Surely pat ages can furnih out with examples of the like: and perhaps we may meet with a great abundance of that deplorable number, and never go out of Gaul; but very few, who by their valour, could recover their lot liberty, as Roilion hath done. Then looking upon the Taffaty, but who can tell (aid he) that I do love him, but himelf? If he is of o bae an extract as he is eteemed, he never dare be o bold as to think of any uch affection and much les to publih it: and if his birth be as high as his actions and courage, who can blame me if I uffer him to love me? But whooever he be, the very truth is, I do love him, and have already hinted as much unto him: Why then hould I not read his anwer? The wort is, if it do contain more then does become him, I will end him a blank paper by way of Reply, in lieu of that which he hath writ unto me.
Upon this he took a pair of Sciars, and with a trembling hand began to open the Taffaty, and found a paper which contained thee words.

body.head: The Anwer of ROSILION unto the Princcs ROSANIRA.
body.p: YES, My Fairet Princes, I will hope, ince you command me, But what is it you are pleaed I hould hope for? Oh that it were the honour of your Favour; which Favour would raie me above all the good fortunes of men, and would urpas all the merits of humanes: But it is abolutely impoible for me to give thanks equal unto uch uperlative benefits.

div.p: She bluhed extreamly when he read this Letter, and yet he could not chue but like it; thinking that if he were too bold, it was he that taught him to commit the fault, and therefore eaily excued him: and let Meriin, or thoe that waited in the anti-chamber, hould enter into any upition, he writ back this anwer.

body.head: The Princes ROSANIRAS Reply unto ROSILION.
body.p: PErevere till, and hope for that which will afford you mot contentment, for in doing o, you do but as you are allowed: But remember, that Fidelity, Dicretion, and Silence, are the Victimes which ought to be offered upon thoe Altars, on which you will acrifice.

div.p:
Thus lapping up thee hort lines with more care then did the firt, he called for one of her women, and commanded her to give that Receipt unto Meriin, to carry peedily unto his mater, and to tell him, that if he looked in it this time, let him never hope for any more. Roilion undertood very well what the Princes meant, when Meriin delivered his meage; yet he had uch a longing deire to ee what anwer he returned, that he was all impatience to be alone, that he might kis that happy Paper, when he received it, there was much company with him, for he was very well beloved, and a Favourite is always followed by many of thoe flies which ue to fly away as oon as any misfortune comes; o as to be handomly rid of them, he eemed deirous to take his ret, and commanded Meriin to leave him alone, and not to come into his chamber till he called for him: When he was alone, he took the Taffaty, and after a thouand kies, he read the Princes Letter, with uch an exces of joy and contentment, as he was hardly able to contain it within the narrow compas of his oul; but when he was a little cooler, and had long looked upon this paper, he remembred that many people were preent in the chamber when Meriin delivered his meage unto him, and epecially an old Cavalier, whom the King had ent unto him, and who without all doubt would make relation of it unto the King again, which might move ome, or perhaps the King himelf, out of curioity, to ee this Receipt: He took out that therefore which the Princes had written, and placed in lieu of it another paper, scribled over with a few odd Characters, uch as his pen did drop at random, and hung it about his neck, as he did the Letter: And happy it was he did o; for the King being deirous that every one hould know how much he eteemed Roilion,
to the end all the Court might imitate him, he himelf would needs go viit him, as oon as the wound in his thigh would permit him, and carried with him the two Princees, Cephie, and Roanira, telling them, that the great generoity of that Cavalier, and the good ervice which he had done him, did very well deerve their extraordinary care of him.

Though this unexpected viit of the King did urprize him, yet the ight of the Princes Roanira was the height of contentment unto him; and uch, as not knowing what thanks to return for uch an unaccutomed favour, he could not find words to expres his reentments of it. Policander came up to him, took his hand, asked him how he did, and whether the Receipt which his daughter had ent him, had done him any good? Very much Sir, anwered he, and o much, that I think I do owe my life unto it. 'Tis very well, anwered the King, for both he and I are obliged to have a care of your recovery. But Daughter (aid he, and turned towards the Princes) pray tell me who gave you this Receipt? Sir (anwered Roanira, and was a little urprized) it is o long ince I firt had it, that truly I have forgotten who gave it unto me; but I do very well remember, that whooever it was, he told me that it would not fail: yet having no experience of it, I laid it up, and made no reckoning of it. The King then turning towards Roilion, I believe (aid he) that this which you wear about your neck is the Receipt: It is Sir, (anwered he) and ince I found o much benefit by it, I would not leave it off. Policander very deirous to know what it was, did take it from his neck, and would have opened it. But the Princes who trembled for fear of dicovery, did preently lay her hand upon it, and would not let him. Sir (aid he) if you do ee what it is, it will be unprofitable to Roilion: And did not you ee it? (anwered he.) I did (replyed he) but it was, becaue otherwie I could not make it: yet if any other ee it, the vertue of it is lot. Thee upertitions (aid Policander) are to be oberved by little children, and their Nures: and to tell you truly, I have known o many of thee kind of Receipts, which never wrought any effect, that I will ee what this is: Then calling for a pair of ciars, he opened the Taffaty, and took out the paper. Judge Madam, in what a perplexity Roanira was; he was indeed more dead then alive, and could not devie what excue he could ue to cover the crime which he had committed; yet when he aw it was not the ame paper which he had written, he took a little heart: but he was preently urprized with a econd fear, not inferiour to the firt; for he thought it to be ome reply which Roilion intended to end: but cating her eye upon him, he aw him mile, which gave her ome courage; and more when he oberved that nothing but Cyphers and Figures were in the paper: Oh how glad he was, and how he applauded the prudence of him, whom a little before he condemned, for uffering it o eaily to be een, when it o nearly concerned his life. What Daughter (aid he, and was atonihed, after he had a while conidered it) does your Receipt conit of nothing but uch odd Characters and criblings as this? You ee Sir (aid he and miled) all there is. I hope then (aid the King and laughed) that it will cure me, if I be ill: Then lapping up the paper as it was, he put it himelf about Roilions neck, who kiing his hand, aured him, that he had received o much good from it, that he would keep it mot carefully as long as he lived. But (aid the Princes) it will not now do you any good, becaue it hath been een: I believe Madam (aid he) that if I do not ee it my elf, it will retain its vigour: for you ee, that though the King have looked upon it, yet I do not bleed again, as I did before. I am glad of it (anwered Roanira) becaue I cannot make it any more; for the condition of the Receipt is uch, that it cannot be made above twice for one peron. Roilion did very well undertand he meant, that he hould write no more this way: and yet he could not chue but anwer her; 'tis hard the favours which we receive from the Gods, hould be always o conditioned, that we can enjoy them but a while. The favours of the Gods (replyed he) ought to be deired no further then in caes of neceity; and we ought not to grumble, becaue we have them not in abundance. The King did hear thee words and Cephie alo, but undertood them not: o preently after he retired, and commanded all thoe that were about Roilion, to have as great a care of him, as if he were the
Prince Ariontes his Son; and by fortune, as the King went out, the Prince came in, who meeting his Siters going away, he carried them back for company, which pleaed Policander very well; for he was deirous all manner of favours hould be hewed unto this Cavalier, to invite others to follow his example in valour.

Roilion received the Prince with all due repects; and after he had kied his hand for o great a favour, Sir (aid he unto him) the honour you are pleaed this day to confer upon me, is o great, as makes me ahamed of my little merit: But ince he is not ungrateful, who though unable to atisfie as he ought, yet trives to do all he can, o I aure the Prince Ariontes, that for thee extraordinary favours, Roilian hall never be branded with that odious name, ince I do from this very day dedicate all the days of my life, not to exonerate my elf of this debt, becaue it is impoible, but in doing you all the ervices that a man can do unto his Mater and Lord. Roilion (anwered the Prince) your blood employed in the preervation of the King my father, can never be fully recompenced, as well for the generoity wherewith you pilt it, as for the great ervice you have done, and the whole State in it; aure your elf that it hall never be forgot. And becaue he would have replyed, and the Prince not pleaed to ue more words of ceremony, he interrupted him, and embracing him, aid; you may (Roilion) overcome me in good language, but never in tetimonies of affection: And going to a Chyrurgion who tood at the Beds feet, he expotulated with him concerning the tate of his health, and whether his wound was dangerous, whilt Cephie and Roanira taying with him, did hinder one another: for (if I be not much mitaken) Cephie loved him as well as Roanira; but becaue he always aw he had a greater inclination to her Siter, he durt not hew it; and Roanira (who aw it) did keep the matter as ecret from her, as from any other: As thee two Siters were itting ilently for fear of one another, Ariontes called Cephie, to hew unto her the terrible claws of the Lyon, which had wounded Roilion, which indeed were as harp as any needles; o Roanira remaining alone with him, and Roilion to acknowledge his extream obligations. Oh God, Madam (aid he unto her) when will Fortune give me leave to employ this life which you have preerved, in your ervice? If you think you are obliged to me (aid he) for the Receipt which I ent you, I do acquit you of it, and think my elf very well paid by what you have done in lieu of it; auring you, that I was never in my life o affrighted, as when the King was o impertinently deirous to ee it. You might very well think Madam (aid Roilion) that if your Receipt had been there, I would ooner have lot my life, then uffer a ight of it. But Madam (continued he) I mot humbly beeech you to ordain the way, in which it is your pleaure I hould behave my elf. You may find thoe directions (aid he) in the lat Receipt: he returned this anwer in hate, becaue he aw the Prince and Cephie returning: and the better to diemble it, as they came, he went to ee the Lyon, which (though dead) was a mot dreadful ight. Preently after, taking his leave, they both followed him, and the Princes had no conveniency of talk with Roilion.

But Madam, I am afraid I hall be too tedious in relation of all the ucces: but I thought it neceary to acquaint you with the beginning of Roaniras and Roilions love; for indeed they did already love each other, though they durt not tell it, but till were in hopes, that hereafter the fortune and valour of this Cavalier, might haply be uch, as they might marry. And in the mean time, the wound of Roilion cauing him to keep his Bed a long while, did give Roanira an opportunity of longer dicoure with him; For Cephie buying her elf with looking upon ome Pictures, he left her alone with him; and Roilion not to let uch an opportunity lip: Madam (aid he) if my tongue durt utter any complaint againt you, or my oul conent unto it, I think I hould be a little angry with my Fairet Princes. Take heed Roilion (anwered he) your anger be not without a caue; for if you do well conider my Receipt, certainly you will confes that it was beyond your deires, at leat your hopes: But I mut confes, that in this I was a little too free, and perhaps had I well conidered with my elf, I had not ent it, ince men are of uch a temper, that they mut not be too far acquainted with our good wills unto them: for they are all apt to be tranported with too much
vanity, or contentment, and to fancy many things that were never thought upon, drawing concluions from thence that are very diadvantageous to us.

Is it your pleaure Madam, replied Roilion, I hould think that the favours you have conferred upon me, were done without your conideration? No, aid Roanira, but on the contrary, I would have you know that if I had not done as I did, I hould have blamed my elf; but I ay, that it was done without any debate with my elf, for I was o tranported with joy, to hear that the King was delivered from o great a danger, and that it was by the valour of Roilion, as without any conult I uffered my hand to intimate my joyes unto you Then Madam, replied Roilion, hould thoe expreions which you are pleaed infinitly beyond my merit to make, work in me any of thoe effects you mention, I hould think my elf the mot unworthy man that ever lived upon the earth: but Madam, I did not draw any uch conequencies or hopes as you are pleaed to ay, from them; nay, on the contrary, your favour, o far from my expectation or hopes, was like the plendour of the Sun, which o dazled my eyes and my oul, that I knew not what to think, nor what to hope, nor what to ay, o infinitly they were above all my thoughts, my hopes, and my deerts. As for the anger which I mentioned againt you, it was only, becaue being o entirely yours, methought you did me wrong in not commanding me any thing in your ervice. Roilion, replied the Princes, the value which I find to be in you, and the affection which you eem to have unto me, together with your dicreet carriage of it, hath moved me to love you. Your unknown extraction does much trouble me; but I wih your valour may make you o known unto all, that it may be no reproach unto me when it is known that Roanira loves you. Draw from hence all the mot favourable conequences you can to content you, for I will not forbid you one, only remember the victimes which ought to be offered in this acrifice, as formerly I writ unto you.

Madam (aid Roilion tranported with joy) if I durt throw my elf at your feet by way of gratitude, I would, as the mot obliged man living: but I know uch expreions, before o many witnees, would dipleae you; only I ay, that words being too weak to do it, I hall with extream deire wait for the honour of your commands, to tetifie my obedience, that as there is none living more worthy to be loved, or rather adored, then the fair Roanira, nor any heart more devoted to adore her then Roilions, o there is nothing o difficult which I would not think eaie in your ervice. As for the unknown place of my birth which, and with reaon does o much dipleae you, I beeech you be pleaed, as oon as my wounds are healed, I may as a wandering Cavalier ee out the place, or ele die in the quet; or at leat, till the unknown place of my birth at my return, be no reproach unto you or him.
How? replied the Princes, do you ask if it will pleae me? Be aured Roilion, if you do otherwie, you will extreamly dioblige me.

This dicoure was a caue, that as oon as Roilion was recovered, which was not many dayes, he beeeched the King to give him leave, as a Cavalier errant, to go and eek adventures, according to the cutome which the famous King Arthur etablihed in great Brittain, that o he might better inable himelf to do him ervice: The King, though with much regret, conented, but upon condition he would return as oon as poible. I need not relate the dicoure betwixt the Princes and Roilion at his departure: for Madam, you may imagine it to be uch, as lovers before a long eparation and an uncertain return would ue. But Roinara, as oon almot as he was departed, received great conolation by the fame of many noble exploits, which he atchieved in all countreys he came into; for his Acts and his Glory, was all the dicoure at all aemblies of Ladies and Cavaliers.

Whilt Policander & the Princees lived thus, the King of Picts groaning under a great age, & after a long languihing in bed, did at lat pay that tribute which is due unto nature from mortal men: and as if Fortune would have us hed our tears for everal ubjects at the ame time, the grave was no ooner hut for him,
but it was opened for the King of the Santons, which indeed were greifs unto the Queen Argira, but with one conideration that was no mall conolation unto her, thinking that urely now Policander would make good his promie: for by Fortune, a little before his mother died, o as being now both at liberty, it was likely he would give all atisfaction deireable. But O, how much mitaken are the hopes of love, epecially when they are expected from uch men who look only after their preent interets: heretofore, I do believe, that if it had been in the power of Policander to have dipoed of himelf, he would have atisfied his promie; but ince the welfare of his affairs and dominions had contrained him to marry Cloriina, he did o forget all his relations to the kingdome of the Picts, that he did not o much as remember the very name of Argira. But now to leave him without excue, and that there might be no faillure on her ide, though ince the aitance ent againt him to the Prince Archimbant, there was no good correpondency betwixt us, yet when Cloriina died, Argira ent to condole with him, and to acquaint him with the King of the Santons death, intimating a kind of Summons to atisfie his former promie: His anwer was indeed full of civility and courteie, but o empty of all love, as the leat park of uch a flame did not appear in it,

The Queen did believe (for he was apt to flatter her elf in it) that perhaps he was unwilling to dicover himelf unto her Ambaadour which he had ent unto him, he being a peron with whom he never had any familiarity; and o he did attribute that unto prudence which indeed was defect and want of affection, as afterwards he found when he ent this Letter ecretly unto him.

body.head: The Queen ARGIRAS Letter unto King POLICANDER.
body.p: ALL promies are certainly due debts, and if o, remember what you ow unto her that now writes unto you: he is a very bad paymater that never payes what is due, epecially when nothing but will is wanting to cancel the obligation; and there can be nothing to hinder me from that atisfaction which is my due, but only want of will in you. The gods are witneses unto your promies, to them I appeal, and defore them I ummon you to give me atisfaction.

div.p: To which Letter, he returned this anwer.

body.head: King POLICANDERS Anwer unto the Queen ARGIRA.
body.p: PRomies that are made, and afterwards revoked by conent of parties, become null: And we ought not to eteem the ret of thoe who loved us, o little, as to diturb them in their graves, by the dipleaure of eeing us in the poesion of another. This conideration, together with the good and welfare of my Etates, makes me reolve to pas away the ret of my dayes in olitude, as mot pleaing unto the gods to which you appeal.

div.p:
Then giving this Letter unto him who brought the other; Friend (aid he unto him) aure the Queen, thy mitres, that I hall alwayes live her ervant, but I cannot poibly think upon any econd marriage. Grief for the loes which he and I have had hould take our thoughts off any uch things: The affection which
we do ow unto thoe children which the gods have given us, hould wain our wills: and it were a kind of cruelty to add more brothers unto them, who would hare with them in etate; beide, the age which he and I are of, is a ufficient priviledge unto us from any uch treaties: Aged matrimony is out of eaon, and fit only for uch as are green. and in the vigour of their age, not gray, and ready to drag into their graves. This anwer and meage, which was no better then a reproach, did make a deep wound in the oul of the Queen, who ever had entertained a mot zealous affection unto Policander: but this did blat all her hopes, and made good the old Proverb, that from great love proceeds great hatred. For he conceived o great a hatred of him, that he did abhorre the very name of Policander and all his: and as he did for his ake love the on which he had by him, better then the on of the King her husband, o now he changed her mind, and wihed he had never been born, for he never looked upon him, but he thought he aw the ingratitude of his father imprinted in his face. Now did he heartily repent he ever put him in the place of him of whom he bore the name, thinking it a mot jut judgement of the gods upon her for that impoture. This regret went o near her heart, that he ent unto the Port of the Santons to enquire of the right Celiodantes: but he heard that he was long ince carried away by certain Pirates, and his father alo (for o was Verances eteemed) and that his mother was lot, at leat never een ince in thoe parts. This news which took from her the foundation of her intended revenge, did more aggravate her displeaure, and blew it up to uch a height, that he reolved to make Policander and her elf a mot notable example unto future ages, for all uch as hould run the ame fortune.

The uppoed Celiodantes was then about the twentieth year of his age, and by the indulgent care of the King of Santons and Argira, accomplihed with all the excellent qualities of a great Prince. He was every way o compleated both in parts of body and mind, that though he had not been the on of a King; yet was he worthy of a Monarchy. But as formerly he looked upon him with the eyes of love, as Policanders on, o now he lookt upon him with thoe of hatred and revenge: he was long in debate with her elf, before he could reolve what way of revenge he hould take; at lat he made choie of the greatet that then preented it elf before her eyes.

The King of the Cenomanes had ome variance with the King of the Turonians: and commonly arms being alwayes judges between uch perons, and the word the bet Jutice, both of them begun to Levy men, and lit Souldiers and Commanders. The King of the Rhedonians and Condates, as allies unto the Cenomances came preently to their aide. The King of Venetes and Darioriques, having married the iter of the Turonian King, came almot uncalled with all his forces to the aitance of his brother in law: o as thee two Kingdomes were like to be the Theaters of many cruel and bloody Tragedies, when by the advice of thee four Kings, Celiodantes was choen to be the Arbitratour of their differences. Though his young experience in uch weighty matters, might make him eem unfit for uch an undertaking; yet the widome, Prudence and Jutice had already wrought uch incredible effects, in all his other actions, as got him o great a repute that by the a common conent, they referred themelves unto his arbitriment and doom, and upending arms and actions of hotility for a time, they waited for his Judgement. This happened to be at the ame time when the Queen Argiras anger was hottet againt Policander. As fortune was, the two Kings of the Armorique Cities were deadly enemies unto Policander, becaue when they were young, he aited Suenon the good Duke againt them, under the notion of a Knight errant, and had caued them to loe ome certain terrritories, of which they had been long Poeours. On the other ide, the King of the Cenomanes and the King of the Turonians, loved Policander no better then they, becaue his miniters had conficated ome boats upon the river Loyre, loadned with arms, becaue they had not a afe conduct.

This offence though but mall, yet was o freh, that it ought for revenge. Argira thought then, that if Celiodantes did compoe all matters between thee Kings, he
might eaily move them both againt Policander, as well to atisfie his requet us to be revenged for their particular injuries.

All the difficulty was to find a good colour of warre for Celiodantes, which he could hardly do, for Policander, though a neighbour, had carried himelf o free from any offence, as he took away all occaions of complaint: yet hoping that time might perhaps afford one, that which he recommended mot unto the Prince her on, and to thoe whom he had imployed to councel him, was to make a peace betwixt thee Kings, and to conider, that the bet warre, was not o good as the wort peace: and that the fire of diention being o near them, ome parks might fly into their own houes: briefly, he o intructed them, that a Peace was made, and o as gave full atisfaction to all parties, each in particular thinking the advantage to be on their ide. This did oblige them o deeply unto Celiodantes, and got him o high a repute, that all of them deiring before they parted to make a firm alliance, they choe him to be their general in cae they aembled any forces together: An honour indeed o high, and unhop'd for, he being o young, as in all likelyhood he would have been the lut that hould have been choen for uch a dignity.

But ee Madam, how fatally-unavoidable ome things are, the Queen was eeking out for a colour of complaint againt Policander, and could not find it, when by Fortune ome of the officers of Celiodantes puruing ome pilfering robbers that fled into Policanders dominions, the people of the town and ome ouldiers to maintain their Priviledges, did not only receive thee thieves, but killed a great number of his men, and took all prioners, but uch as aved themelves by flight.

This news being brought unto the Queen, he thought it a very good pretence, and uch an offence as he ought after.
