And becaue he was ure, that if he made complaint unto Policander, he would give her atisfaction, therefore he aid nothing, but ent ome ouldiers immediatly to ack the place, and ue all manner of hotility: but in lieu of revenging the firt injury, it did but beget a econd; for thoe that went found uch hot entertainment, that the Commanders hardly ecaped with their lives after the los of mot of their men: Argira was orry for their los, but he was well contented to have uch a colour to move thoe Kings to revenge the injury which he aid Celiodantes had received whilt he was out of his Dominions. And in order to this, he preently dipatched uch a meenger, as he thought mot fit to aggravate this offence, and move thoe Kings unto anger: and certainly he did negotiate according to her deires, for he ued all manner of arts and arguments to exaperate thoe Kings, and prompt them to revenge: all who remembring their particular injuries which they had received, and finding arms ready in their hands, they all agreed without more delay, to fall into the Dominions of King Policander, whom they found leeping in a dull ecurity all unarmed, and never dreaming of uch an unexpected invaion. A long and drowie peace had o lulled him aleep, that he had lot all his old ouldiers, and he knew not where to get new ones: beides, the people were all o drowned in an univeral tranquility, that they hardly knew what a word was. It was an eaie matter for Celiodantes, finding him in this condition, to foil him at every encounter.

Now the Queens deigne was (oberve what a trange animoity he had againt Policander) either to make the on kill the father in this warre, or ele the father to kill the on: and though they knew not themelves to be father and on, yet it was a great atisfaction unto her, to know that he was o revenged. Policander did what he could in this urgent extremity, and making a virtue of neceity, did muter together ome Cavaliers, as well of his own Vaals as of his Allies, and took the field with the Prince Arionthes his on. And though he knew it was full of danger to hazard a battel; yet not being able to endure to ee what plunder and ravage our Army made in his Dominions, although he was the weaker, yet he reolved to venture it. I will pae over all the circumtances of the battle, and only tell you that Celiodantes got the day, and Arionthes the only on of Policander was killed, and that the father had much ado to ave himelf by
getting into Avarick with ome reliques of his broken Army: but the inhabitants of that town and thoe that fled thither, were o affrighted that I believe, if our Army had purued cloe, the gates had been opened unto them: But it was thought better to forrage the countrey for victuals, and o beiege that great City, which they foreaw would continue long, becaue it was fortified with great ditches, Towers, and Ramparts; and becaue of the great abundance of men, as well burgers as trangers, which fled thither; but the main aim was the peron of Policander, who againt the opinion of his councel, would needs hut up himelf in the Town, with a reolution to be buried in the ruines of his Kingdome.

The Corps of Arionthes was found amongt the dead, and with all honour and civility ent unto his father, to hew that hatred did not go beyond life, nor that any revenge hould be taken of the dead. Policander received the body of his on with a dry eye, and hewed o much contancy and magnanimity in the ad conjuncture of woes, that the virtue of this King began to melt the enraged heart of the Queen, and in ome ort to pity his misfortune. Come, come, Argira (aid he unto her elf) cant thou find a heart to ee him who once loved thee, to be o mierable? is the ight of thee o fatal as to bring ruine upon all thoe that look upon thee: Conider that he whoe Kingdome thou wouldt now demolih, and whoe life thou wouldt have, is the ame peron whom once thou didt love above all the world, and one who is the father of thy on: Is his fault without any excue? and though it be, wilt thou remember one ingle dipleasure, more then all the ervices which thou hat received from him.

Thee coniderations and many more uch like, did o mollifie her heart, that he began to eek for a good pretence of letting him alone in Peace, and to withdraw our Army out of his Dominions; but not daring to declare her mind unto any, let he hould offend the united Kings, he laid iege before Avarick: her deign was when he conented to the iege, to make Policander her prioner, and then after he had made him acknowledge his offence, to retore him unto his Crown of Kingdomes. But things fell out farre otherwie; for a while after, Roilion, who was following his adventures in Germany and the Macromands, he was advertied by common fame how thee Kings had invaded the King of the Boyers, and how he was blockt up in the City of Avarick, which could not long hold out.

When he firt heard this news he could not believe it, becaue he knew Policander to be a King of great equity and Jutice, and would not give any of his neighbours the leat occaion of warre. Yet not to light it, he wended his coure towards the Boyers and Ambaries: And by fortune, as he was going out of the Countrey of the Lepontes, he met a meenger which the Princes Roanira had ent unto him, who had wandered everal dayes all over the Alps, after the fame of his exploits: he met with him then in this place; and becaue Roilion han not changed his arms, he knew him by the Lion that he wore upon his hield, with ome trange words which he had taken for his devie, which was a caue, that many called him the Knight of the Lion. Sir (aid he unto him, and preented the Letters from Roanira) I have been in quet of you above this moneth, to tell you that you are extremely deired by her that writ this Letter, and wih'd for by all the Boyers, as the only remedy and hopes they have in all their misfortunes, Roilion, gave no anwer, but opened the Letter, and found thee words.

body.head: The Princes ROSANIRAS Letter unto ROSILION.
body.p: YOur victories are great, but not o great as our misfortunes: our Army is defeated, all the countrey undone, Arionthes dead, and Policander and Roanira lockt up in their lost town: Iudge you whether this be not a large field in which Roilion may imploy his Arms and his Courage.

div.p: I hall not need (Madam) to relate the atonihment and orrows of Roilion, when he had read the Letter, and heard all the particulars from the mouth of the Meenger. But o it was, that taking the way towards the Boyens, and making all the hate his Hore would give him leave, he came into the Territories of King Policander, where he found many Cavaliers and Officers already aembled, and wanted nothing but a General whom they would obey; for the principal of the Boyens and Ambares, ome were lain with the Prince Arion • hes, and others were hut up with Policander in Avaricke; o as thee who wanted no good will but only a General to conduct them, received Roilion with a common conent, as well for the love they knew the King bore unto him, as for the brave exploits which Fame had reported of him. And though the number of thee Cavaliers and Souldiers were not above five hundred Hore, and three thouand Foot, and though our Army conited of above eight thouand Hore, and forty thouand Foot, yet Roilion truting in the jutice of Policanders caue, and in the good Fortune which alwaies accompanied him, he was not at all dimayed, but came up unto us with flying colours; which did o encourage his own men, and o affright ours, as if the very name of Roilion were enough to defeat us: His mal piece of an Army at every Quarter where he lodged, like a tumbling Snow-ball, grew bigger; for the whole Country flocked unto him; and as if they were already dividing our poils, they made themelves aured of Victory: And o it hapned, that by the jut judgement of the Gods, we were defeated: I may well ay, by the jut judgement of God; for otherwie, it was not likely o mall a handful of men could ever have got the victory of uch an Army as ours, which had o many Kings, and o many Grandees to command it, and o many old experienced Souldiers accutomed to Combats and Battles: But the truth was, our Army was routed, yet not totally, but o, as we were contrained to raie the Siege, and let Roilion enter into the Town with all his men. The carees of the King, the kind apect of Roanira, and the joys of all the people when he came into Avaricke, cannot be expreed. But Policander knowing that it was requiite to purue an Army that fled, he went out of Avaricke in all hate, with all thoe whom he thought fit to be added unto the Troops of Roilion, whom he kied, and made him Lieutenant General of all his Armies, and commanding all his Subjects by Edict, to obey him. This honour etting an edge upon the courage of the generous Roilion, and whetting his deires of doing omthing worthy of the Reputation he had got, he purued our hattered Army, and four days after overtook us at a little River, which is called Clein, where he forced our Army to face about, and give him Battel; in which we were almot totally defeated, with the death of the two Kings of the Turonians and Cenomanes, and to our greatet grief, with the taking of young Celiodantes prioner. But becaue Roilion was reolved to drive the Nail to the head, he purued on after our quandred Army, and ent Celiodantes with a good guard unto Policander and the Princes Roanira.

You may eaily imagine (Madam) that the Kings joy was not a little, when he aw not only his Kingdoms recovered, but alo o many Kings defeated, and the chief of all, his Prioner: It was uch, as not knowing which way to gratifie Roilion enough, he reolved to make him after his deceae, poeor of thoe Kingdoms which he had regained, by the marriage of Roanira; and therefore he pecified as much unto him by Letter to this effect.

body.head: King POLICANDERS Letter unto ROSILION.
body.p: WHat Gift can equal the merits of him that has et the Crown upon my Head, but the Crown it elf? Yes, I will give him more then that; For beides all my Dominions, I will give him that which is more dear unto me, my daughter Roanira: and therefore Roilion, she is at this hour yours, and after my deceae, o is the Kingdoms of the Boyens, of the Ambarres, and of the Bitturiges. Hate therefore to vanquih, for thee are the Tryumphs which I prepare for you, to congratulate your Victories.

div.p: Now ee Roilion and Roanira almot at the very top of their good Fortune: for this Cavalier did love this Princes with uch exces of paion, that he would not have lived but in hopes that Policander would betow her upon him: And he whoe affection was not inferiour unto his, though he did more diemble it, hoping that Roilion would become uch a one, as he might take for her husband without dihonour, he eeing him now o high in the Kings eteem, it could not chue but be a mot ingular contentment unto her. But now (Madam) you hall hear a very pleaant encounter: Whilt Roilion after the Receipt of this Letter, was continuing his Victories, chaing his enemies as far as the Armorique Cities, and crowning himelf with Palms and Lawrels, Celiodantes a Prioner in Avaricke, is treated by King Policander with o much civility, that going abroad where he pleaed upon his Parole, he was permitted to ee the Princes Roanira, whoe Beauty and Vertue did preently convert a Prioner of War into a Prioner of Love: For this Princes had o many inevitable attracts, as it was almot impoible for any eye to ee, and not adore her.

When Celiodantes was taken Prioner, many others were taken with him; and amongt the ret, an old Cavalier called Orontes, who had been his Governour ever ince he left his Nure. This man was very prudent and wie, and o affectionate unto the ervice of Celiodantes, that his interet took the deepet impreions in his heart: On the other ide, this young Prince knowing how affectionate he ever was unto him, did love and eteem him very much, as he was obliged.

Some days paed before Celiodantes would acquaint Orontes with his paion, thinking this Love to be in uch an uneaonable time, as it could not chue but have a bad detiny: This ilence caued the Prince to fret at heart, and his oul to well o with vexatious thoughts, that his body began to fall away every day more and more; which Orontes oberving, and thinking that this adnes proceeded from his detenion, he feared it would become prejudicial to his health: o as one day when he was alone in his chamber, he ued this dicoure unto him.

If thoe Sir who govern Kingdoms and Empires had any priviledge to be exempted from the blows of Fortune more then other men, I hould ay you had reaon to be troubled and grieved at the condition wherein you are: But we ee the highet hills mot ubject to the torms and winds, and not o erene as the valleys and plains; o as the highet Soveraignties are expoed to the tempets of Fortune, more then the humble condition of ubjects, what reaon then have you to think you hould be exempted? And why hould you complain of a general Law, that is commong to all great ones? Your high Birth and Quality which elevates you above the rank of other men, may well excue you from petty misfortunes, and trivial calamities, which they are ubject unto, as too inferiour and unworthy
for Grandees; but great afflictions, and uch as are inupportable to the common ort of men, are proper only for Princes, and uch great Kings as you are; and as you would blame thoe who faint in courage, and hrink under the burthen of little misfortunes, eteeming them as effeminate and puillaminous, o believe it Sir, Thoe that ee you with uch a ad dejected countenance, and bending at the firt blow that Fortune gives you, what will they think of you? The fidelity which I owe unto my King, and the affection which I have unto the peron of Celiodantes, does oblige me Sir, in duty and love, mot humbly to beeech you, and conjure you, even by the memory of the King your Father, to roue up your magnanimity and courage, and to look all dangers and misfortunes bravely in the face: If you tell me the blow is great, I will anwer, that you ought to arm your elf the better againt it: For the courage of a man cannot be vanquihed but by its own fault, nor can any accident of Fortune tagger him, if his own will do not betray him, and conent unto his defeat: Courage Sir, and roue up your Princely oul; you have before your eyes an example of unconquered vertue, as oft as you turn them upon King Policander; Did any of his defeats ever make him hrink? Did he droop and drown himelf in orrows, when he lot his only Son? And did his courage fail when his Kingdoms were taken from him? No, no Sir, but on the contrary, he armed himelf againt all the malice of Fortune, by uch a generous vertue, that at lat he overcame her, and (if it may be o aid) did force her to take his part.

Orontes would have proceeded on, if the young Prince had not interrupted him: Father (aid he, for o he called him) your pains was very ill betowed, and both my courage and memory were very bad, if the los of one Battel, part of my Dominions, friends, and my liberty, hould make me forget thoe apient documents, and wie intructions which I received from you; I would never have taken any Arms into my hands, if I had not known that all thee accidents might fall upon me: And ince mieries foreeen do les hurt, aure your elf that all thoe you peak of, do make no uch great impreions in me: I did, I mut confes, reent the change of my Fortune, as being enible, not faint-hearted, or puillanimous. The orrows you ee in my face and actions, more then ordinary, O my dear Orontes, are caued by no wounds that any do know of, but by others, which none ees but my elf: Upon this he groaned out a deep igh, and after a ilent paue, he began again.

Yes, yes Father, no eyes but my own ees the wounds whereof I complain; and though I ee them incurable, yet uch is my confidence in Orontes, that I will dicover them unto him, yet without any other hopes, but only, that he will help me to condole my misfortune.

Upon this he made a long relation of the extream affection which he bore unto the Princes Roanira, the little hopes he had in the good will of that Princes, or in the King her Father, ince he had been the caue of o much orrow unto them, epecially by the death of Ariontes: Now judge (continued he) whether I have not reaon to droop, and whether it were not better for me to end my mierable days preently, then to groan away a life which will be o wretched and diatrous? I know you will tell me, that Love is but folly and madnes and that a generous pirit may be ahamed to be urmounted by it; but Father, whether it be widom or folly, commendable or hameful, if it be folly, I mut confes my elf a fool; and if a generous pirit may be ahamed of it, I would not be thought generous; for the fatal truth is, that I do love Roanira, and o, that I mut not love my elf, unles I love her: Doubtles you wili advie me to reit this paion, but alas, all uch advice is given unto a deaf man, and to one that has not a will to be cured.

The age Orontes gave Celiodantes a long and patient hearing without any interruption, knowing very well that a ick oul finds eae in emptying it elf unto ome faithful friend; But when the Prince had done, he began thus.

I am very glad Sir, you have told me your orrows proceed from Love, epecially ince your paion is grounded upon uch a worthy ubject as the Princes Roanira; for till now, I thought you had drooped under the burthen of your
misfortunes, and that your injured patience had fainted at your diaters: But now I find your dieae to be o eaily cured, as I wih you may continue a little longer in it: for I hope this Love will be a means to re-invet you in your former etate and plendour. Do you think Sir, that the King Policander has forgot thoe extremities unto which your Arms reduc'd him? and out of which, heaven has mot miraculouly recued him? Believe it Sir, though he do ee himelf a Conquerour, yet he knows that all his Victories and Tryumphs may turn into the ame condition wherein he was, and that this is but an interval, and a gleam of Fortune: Do you think he knows not how momentary and uncertain they are? Yes, yes, and quetionles o prudent a Prince will be glad to make his peace with you now he may, and not defer it till perhaps he may be forced to take up uch terms as hall pleae you. Aure your elf Sir, he is more wie then to let uch an opportunity lip. I dare be hold to ay, this peace will be concluded, and nothing can hinder it but your own courage: This Love of yours to the Princes Roanira will remove all difficulties which can be propoed: Courage therefore Sir, and command me to negotiate the buines, for I dare aure you upon my life, to give you all deired contentment.

This was the anwer of Orontes, who infued uch courage into this young Prince, that though his pirits were a little dulled with his hopeles paion, yet upon better conideration, he aw ome probability in the deigne, the conduct whereof he referred wholly unto the prudent Orontes, giving him commiion to treat and conclude what peace he pleaed, o Roanira might be his.

Orontes, who knew he could not do more acceptable ervice to his Mater, nor greater advantage to the State, then to negotiate the matter, he employed the whole trength of his Wit and Prudence in it: And having oberved the everal Interets of all thoe about Policander, he perceived that two of the prime officers about the King, who had mot particular acces to his peron, and bore a great way in affairs, were very ill atisfied with the Kings deign, in giving his daughter unto Roilion, a man unknown, or at bet, but of an ignominious extraction; and, as they aid, they bluhed to think a man bought and old for money, hould ever be their Lord and King: That it was a vile blemih to the names of Boyens, Ambarres, and Bituriges, to make choie of a Slave for their Soveraign, and that he hould command over o many Provinces, and uch Provinces as abounded in great and noble Cavaliers, whoe valours and courages were not inferiour to this enfranchied lave; for he was no better, though his acts were very notable. But that which moved thee two Grandees mot to dilike this match, was a particular Interet which touched them more nearly; for each of them had a Son, and they had a quint eye at the ame happines after the death of Policander, which they aw Roilion was like to enjoy. And though both of them had the ame deigne, and were in the ame hopes, and certainly had been deadly enemies unto each other, if Roilion had not been, yet they united both againt him, and contracted friendhip o far, as to ruine their common enemy, and doubtles to ruine one another after if they could.

The wie Orontes heard of all thee paages, he thought either one or both of thee men might be made fit intruments for his deigne; He addreed himelf therefore unto them, he made the overture of Peace; and o advantagious were his propoitions to Policander, that they embraced them, conceiving there was no better way to put Roilion by his pretenions then this: And though the marriage of Celiodantes did blat all the hopes of their own children, yet they liked better to fall into the hands of the King of Picts, who would be obliged unto them, then into the hands of Roilion, whoe fortune hung all at the point of his Sword. Both of them therefore receiving this overture of peace very willingly, and deiring to promote it, they conulted together to peak unto the King, but everally, to the end he might not think it a compact againt Rosilion: And they carried it o prudently, and ued o much artifice, that Policander after ome kind of difficulty, by reaon of his promie unto Roilion, and after their propoition of giving Cephie in lieu of Roanira, he conented unto it, knowing very well, that the marriage betwixt Celiodantes and Roanira, was the only Cement of this peace, which
he apprehended to be o advantageous to him. Sir, aid they unto him, We beeech you conider, in what condition you were not long ince, and in what by the great mercy of God, you are in now: your prudence bids you not to loe that good fortune which preents it elf, for a few light coniderations. Never was any King of the Boyers o great and redoubtable as you may be, if you will conent unto this match, adding thereby unto your own crown, beides o many Alliances which the King Celiodantes will bring you, two great kingdomes which he enjoyes: All which advantages you can never pretend unto, if you give the Princes unto Roilion, who though a man indeed of great merit, yet has he no etate but his word; beides Sir, the Princes and Lords who are Subjects unto your Crown, will tomach more then they make appear, to be by your will ubjected unto one who they aw within thee few years a lave, & old by a Merchant. Aure your elf Sir, if you will pleae to honour them o far as to ask their opinions, they will with bonefires, and all expreions of joy, approve of this lat propoition. And as for the ervices which Roilion hath done unto your Crown, will he not be recompenced to the full if he be made King of the Lemovices? a tate o full of Cavaliers and great men, that there is not a Prince in all Gaul, but might <> be contented with it. But ay Sir this recompence hould not be made; ye •
<> he be o faithful and affectionate to your ervice as you believe him, he will not look upon his own interets, but will be the firt to advie you unto this peace upon thee propoitions: but if his ambition have o blinded his eyes as he will not ee the good of your tate, Prudence Sir, will bid you look to your elf: for his obligations unto you are uch, as though he gave you his life, yet were he till your debtour.

They added many other advantageous arguments to further their deignes, and ued uch Rhetorique as moved the King to follow their counels, and he gave them commiion to conclude this Peace and Alliance: And at the ame time, left Roilion eeing himelf diappointed of his hopes, and having the command of the Army, hould do him any ill ervice, he dipatched a meenger to give him many thanks and commendations & to command him at the ame time to come preently unto him, and to refer the charge of the Army unto the Marhal of the Boyers, a man whoe fidelity Policander could not upect.

Thee things could not be carried o cloe, but Roanira was ome way or other advertied of them, and he received the news very adly: For he loved Roilion, and harboured at her heart a ecret hatred againt Celiodantes, becaue of her brothers death, whereof he aid him to be the Authour; o as not knowing any better remedy, he reolved to acquaint Roilion with all poible peed, to the end he might break off this pernicious deigne, before it was fully concluded.

The meenger whom he ent unto him made uch extraordinary hate, that he delivered Roaniras Letter unto Roilion two dayes before Policanders came unto him: So as if he had been o minded as to do the King any ill ervice, he might eaily have done it; but any uch deigns were o farre from his thoughts, that on the contrary he imployed his time in making more hate to take a Town that was beieged, and to find out ome handome excue for quitting the Army, and taking that journey which the Princes commanded: And indeed he took uch pains, that the very ame day the Kings meenger came to the Army, he forced the Town by a general aault; where he hewed o much valour and Prudence, that if he had continued but a moneth longer in the Army, there had been no need of making any other peace, but that of conquet, for there was only a few mall Towns, and ome petty Ilands which remained in the power of the enemy.

As oon as ever he received the Kings command, he obeyed it, and leaving behind him very good orders for the Army, he came in all poible pot hate unto him, and gave him an accompt of his charge and tate of the Army, and how near he was to the obtaining of a perfect and entire victory: Policander thanked him, made him as welcome as poibly he could, and told him that when he had a little refrehed himelf after his journey, he would communicate unto him the caue of his ending for him. So without aying any more, he let him go to his
lodging: Roilion who was not ignorant of the Kings intention, had much ado to conceal his knowledge, yet fearing to offend the Princes, he contrained himelf, and o diguied his looks that the King was ignorant of his knowing any thing; but impatiently longing to ee Roanira, as well becaue he had been long deprived of that happines, as to undertand more at large what he had writ unto him in a few words; therefore he went unto her, whom he found in the ame mind he left her; but extremely afflicted at the reolution of the King her father, to betow her upon King Celiodantes, upon a Treaty of peace: but becaue many eyes were upon her, and let paion hould make appear the good correpondeney betwixt them, he told him in a low voice, that if he would meet her after upper in the place where they were wont to walk, they would talk together without o many witnees of their actions: upon this he retired, leaving Roilion extremely pleaed to ee that he had no hand in her fathers alteration.

This appointed hour, was long a coming, according to the impatiency of Roilion, which made him be upon the place before the Princes, who at lat came as privately as he could: As oon as they met, Roilion (aid he unto him) this tetimony of my good will, which I give unto you, and whatoever I hall now mot truly ay, mut not make you judge any thing in my diadvantage; but only let it thus farre poes you, that I will do for you all that my duty will permit me: I know that the affection which you bear unto me will never let you deire any more, and therefore I make no difficulty to tell you, that I am extremely grieved to ee the King o forgetful of his promie to you, and that he hould hope for good of an uncertain peace, before the certain ervices that he hath and daily doth receive from you: For the truth is, he has changed his minde: I mut be the victime, and be given unto Celiodantes, although he be all meared with my brothers blood: Judge Roilion what joyes I am like to have in living, lying, and eating my meat with him, that hath already wallowed in the blood of my brother, and but for you, had done the like to my father and us all: and yet this is he with whom this tyrannical reaon of tate does ordain me to pend my mierable dayes, and o I mut, unles your fortune, which hitherto never found any thing impoible, do not hew it elf more trong then the Kings reolution. O gods! O heavens! O earth! replied Roilion (and interrupted her) will then the King falifie his word? You may, anwered Roanira, be mot certainly aured of it. Has the King, replied he, o oon forgot my ervices? ince he can forget wrongs, o oon, anwered he, do you wonder he hould forget benefits? Will the King be revenged this way, aid he, for all the violencies, rapines, and plunders, that have been committed in his kingdome? is this Policander, that great Prince, whoe Fame and Glory reaches all over the earth, whoe goodnes is o much admired, whoe valour o much feared, and whoe jutice was never tainted with any reproach? The very ame, anwered the Princes, but it becomes not me to cenure his actions; only to be ilent, to uffer, and ay he is my father: Roilion, then pawed a while, and then replied thus. The repect Madam, which hinders you from peaking upon this ubject, does indeed argue your widome, but the faintnes wherewith you peak does argue but flender affection: O my Cavalier, aid the Princes, no more of this dicoure, unles you would have me think your affection unto me not uch as I would have it: for (and let this rule be an anwer unto all you can deire of me) I hall never believe you love me, if you requet any thing from me that contradicts my duty. You ee Roilion that I do love you: I have told you as much, and do tell you o again; nay, I will ever render you all poible demontrations of it, yet it cannot enter into my thoughts, but that you had rather die a hundred deaths, then wih me unto any thing that is againt my duty, or to entertain the leat thought of uch a thing, for I ought to obey my father, and o I will as long as life remains in me. Will you then marry Celiodantes? (aid Roilion with a deep igh) yes, anwered he, not only Celiodantes, but alo the veryet barbarian nay the wort of men, if my father command me. What good then, replied he, will all that affection do me which you are pleaed to expres? my affection unto you (replied he) proceeds from my own good will and inclination, but unto any other, from command only, and let I hould trangres
my duty. O gods! (cryed he out) mut I loe you upon this conideration? I hope, replied Roanira, my good intentions will not be recompened with o great a punihment: but if by the unearchable judgment of the gods, it happen that our Detiny be uch, you ought to hew as much courage upon this occaion, as you have in all dangers which hitherto preented themelves unto you. What? (aid Roilion) ee you anothers, and live? Ah Roanira, you meaure my affection by a wrong rule, if you think my courage able to permit this: Roilion can do any thing but that, when this comes in quetion, all repects are lot: courage and contancy faint, and all manner of coniderations are cat away, I cannot live without this hope; it pleaed the King your father to plant it in me, you your elf approved of it; and when my angry fate will diplant it, the ame blow diplants my life. But Madam, when you alledge it your duty to indute this dignity with patience, do you not give it a wrong name? May it not more jutly be called. Tyrannical then reaonable? How can you quit one you love, for one whom reaon and nature commands you to hate? Mut the Princes Roanira be the ranome of Celiodantes, who has done her o many mortal dipleaures? Does duty command this o extremely unreaonable? Is it not rather unnatural tyranny that triumphs over your pirit? Cat of this bondage Madam, break the cords which thus enlaves your reaon, and would o unjutly captivate it: All the world will diapprove of the Kings deigne, and commend your generoity: thee Arms which have upheld this tottering kingdome, and this word which hath conquered o many Kings, I do offer at your feet, to maintain the jutice of your caue, againt all men living; and to prove that the King, in thus ubmitting you to his enemy is mot unjut, and that it is a mot ignominious act, unworthy of the King of Boyers.

Roilion added unto their expreions many others, and would have continued longer, if the Princes had not interrupted him. Ceae, ceae, Roilion (aid he) and aure your elf that I am o reolved upon it, as I will be obervant unto my fathers commands as long as I live upon earth; the injutice of another, is no allowance unto me, to fail on my part: and I had rather have future ages ay that Roanirus fault was in too much obedience then in neglect of duty: And Roilion let me tell you, that you are obliged as a free Cavalier, to maintain me in this reollution, and wave your own interet in me; and therefore I advie you to addres your elf unto the King my father, put him in mind of all your ervices, of his promies, and of the injutice in his deigne: All that I can do for you is, that if he will refer me to my own will, I will give you all the atisfaction you can deire, if he will not, I will make as much reitance, as in duty I can; but if all will not do, then all I can promie you is, to condole your misfortune and my own, and to take my leave of you & all contentment in this life: After this, becaue it was late, and he fearing to tay any longer with him, he retired, leaving him o intangled with a multitude of confued and unatisfied thoughts, that the un did both et and rie before he had uffered any leep to eiz upon his eyes.

As oon as he had heard the King was up, and to be poken withall, he went unto him; but as formerly uch viits were wont to be with abundance of contentment, o now quite contrary; not knowing with that countenance to come before him, ince his preent fortune had put his eyes and all his actions into mourning.

At lat he thought it prudence, and for everal coniderations reolved, to treat with the King as formerly he was wont to do, becaue if happily he could diwade him from his pernitious deigne, he hould not then give him any upition of that intelligence between the Princes and him: he preented himelf therefore before the King, in a face quite different from his heart; and began to relate at large the tate of the Army; particularizing the places which he had forced thoe which rendred themelves; the battels he had won, the combats he had ought, and the encounters he had met withall: and briefly how little remained to do, before he made an absolute conquet of all his enemies; he alo et before him, yet without either reproach or vanity, all the good ervices which he had done him, and in uch a manner, as the King began to tagger in his reolution. But
Policander knowing his own good nature, and foreeeing that it would trouble him to dipleae a peron, from whom he had received o much good ervice, he commanded them two, who advied him unto this peace, to be preent when Roilion poke unto him, and to fortifie his reolution by their reaons: As oon therefore as this Cavalier came unto him he ent for them two, and dimied all the ret that were in the room.

As long as Roilions dicoure lated, the King did not interrupt him; but as oon as he had done, he began in the firt place to thank and applaud him for all his brave exploits, auring him that they hould never be forgotten, and in the end, concluded thus: But Roilion (aid he) becaue every jut war ought to have peace for its main end, we conceive it bet to make it now when we may do it upon our own terms, and not to tay till ome revolution force us to make it upon harder conditions. Truth is Sir, anwered Roilion, a great and a wie Prince as you are, ought to limit his ambition and his victories unto that end: but give me leave to tell you, that to conclude it now is omething dihonourable unto you, ince victory within thee few dayes will give you the ame peace upon farre more glorious terms; for there will not be any ere long that dare own the name of an enemy or abide the fury of your Arms. Then the elder of the two Councellours eeing the King to look upon him, as if he required his aitance; Sir (aid he) your courage and zeal to the Grandure of the King moves you to peak thus: but whilt you were in the Army, gaining Battels, forcing Towns, conquering Provinces, and adding victory unto victory, you are not enible of thoe ufferings which this poor etate indures, and which the King foreees, will increae the unupportable neceities of the people by ubidies and exactions, which they are forced to pay towards the continuation and maintainance of the warre, which will not only fleece but flea them, and drive them into depair. Pray tell me, what contentment and advantage will it be unto the King, to gain the kingdomes of others by the los and ruine of his own? Can he take any delight to ee the mieries, hunger and extream neceities of his people, whilt he is killing and maacring thoe of his Neighbour Kings? The hortet fits of fury, they ay are alwayes bet: and believe it Roilion, the ame may be aid of warre, the longet whereof are alwayes the wort and mot detructive. Thee wie and pious coniderations have moved the King by the advice of his Councel to give peace not only to his enemies, but alo to his people, who beg it upon their bare knees, and with tears in their eyes. And becaue he thinks you, as well he may, to be one of his bet ervants, he therefore ent for you to give your advice alo, auring himelf that you would approve of it, and rejoyce, as all thoe ought to do who love him, and have any care of his and his kingdomes welfare. The King hath conidered the tate wherein he was when the Kings, his neighbours, invaded him, and that he hall not perhaps have the word and fortune of Roilion alwayes by his ide to help him in the like accidents: o as now in the height of his good fortune, he is pleaed to hearken unto that counel with the bet of his friends do give him, which is, to conclude a peace in time, when he may do it to his bet advantage. In order thereunto he hath thought upon uch expedients as may make this peace mot honourable, mot profitable, and mot lating; and the only way is, by a marriage between the King Celiodantes and the Princes Roanira. For by this means, o many great kingdomes will become but one Monarchy, and will for ever perpetuate the Kings Name and Glory.

Hitherto Roilion was patient, but when he heard of giving Roanira unto Celiodantes, he roued up his courage and voice What Sir? (aid he) will you uffer thee Traytours to give you uch pernitious counel, and fortifie themelves with your name and authority? Traytours Sir, I dare ay they are, ince eeing your enemies at the lat gap, having no trength nor ability to oppoe your Arms, would not only ravih out of your hands this honourable victory, but would make you a lave unto thoe you have in your prions: Good Sir, will you uffer them to ell you, and your Crown alo? and will you approve and confirm the ale? Do you not plainly ee that thoe who give you this counel, do ell your honour, your liberty, and your kingdome? For what is it ele if you give the Princes Roanira
unto Celiodantes, but to make him King of the Boyers, Ambaries, and Lemovices? you pay very dear for the ranome of that captive Prince, if you buy it at the rate of Crown and Liberty. Was ever uch a fine device to get kingdomes as this? will loing of battels, and being taken prioner win Crowns? Tell me, Grand Sirs of the Councel; If the Kings fortune had been to have fallen into the hands of his enemies, and lot all his Towns and Dominions, what harder conditions would they have impoed upon him, then thee which your cantulous widomes do think o good and profitable for him? Doubtles he could have given no more unto his Conquerour, then his Dominions, Life, and Peron: yet you are o braen fac'd (my paionate zeal Sir to your Majeties honour forces me to this language) as to advie the King when he got the advantage over his enemies, and has them prioners, to pay their ranomes, and become a lave himelf? will you Sir uffer future ages to record it in perpetual memory, that Policander King of the Boyers did buy his peace with his Neighbor, by giving away his Daughter, his Scepter, and his Liberty? Nay rather then o, why did not thee wicked Counellours advie you at the beginning of the war, to go with a chain about your neck, and give it and your kingdome unto your enemies? you then would have done as much as all your victories have, and have pared the lives of many a Cavalier, and the ruine of many a Town.

He would have proceed further, when the King knowing him to be partly in the right, yet willing to deceive himelf, and not being able to endure thee remontrances; Roilion (aid he unto him) there is none about me who have uch intentions as you mention, and as for the Counel which they gave me concerning peace, if you call them Traytours for it, you mut put me into the ame number with them, and all the ret of my people. When I did communicate this affair unto you, it was not to require your advice, becaue it is a thing already reolved upon; but only becaue I took you for one of my bet friends and ervants, I thought you would hare with me in my contentment, and in the welfare of the people. And in this general joy, I have not forgotten the ervices which I have received from you, but have dipoed my daughter unto you: o of four kingdomes, which it hath pleaed upream Fate to ubmit unto my Crown, you hall have two of them, and the other two are deigned for the King of the Picts and Santons: Thus will I unite ix kingdomes together, which by the good correpondency betwixt Celiodantes and you will become but one. Roilion hearing the King peak of giving his daughter unto him, though he heard before that he would give Roanira unto Celiodantes, yet he perwaded himelf that he had miundertood him (Sir anwered he) the fovours which I have received from you are uch as trancend all capacities of requital; and yet Sir it eems you will add unto my infinite obligations, unles I do miapprehend you: for you ay you will honour me o far as to give your daughter unto me; and yet methought you aid before, that for a concluion of the peace you would give her unto Celiodantes. Mot true (replied Policander) for I will give the one unto you, and the other unto him: to you my daughter Cephie as I promied, and to him, my daughter Roanira: Sir (aid Roilion and interrupted) you did promie your daughter unto me, but Cephie is not o: he is not indeed, replied the King, but only in name, and yet I loue her no les then if he were: Sir replied Roilion, you named Roanira in your Letter unto me, I cannot tell (anwered the King, whether the Secretary mitook, but I am ure my intention was her I now mention unto you: Ah Sir, (aid Roilion, and looked the King in the face) will you do me o much wrong as to prefer Celiodantes before me? Celiodantes, who hath ruin'd your kingdomes, and reeks till with the blood of your on, and who will certainly make you King without a kingdome? before me I ay, who has et the Crown upon your head, revenged the death of your on by the death of o many Kings and have brought into your prion the plunderer of your kingdomes and murderer of Ariontes? O Sir, can your heart ever let your eye ee this Celiodantes it upon that throne where that Prince hould have raigned, had not the bloody Prince prevented him? Certainly the blood of that Prince will perpetually ring in your eares, and tell you that this marriage is unjut, and a horrour both to gods and men.

The King not being able to endure thee reproaches: Peace Roilion (aid he unto him) no more of this dicoure; for Celiodantes hall marry Roanira, and be you contented with this marriage which I have propoed unto you. Upon this Policander in a dicontented manner would have retired into another chamber. But Roilion extreamly offended at thee lat words, did run before him, as if he were almot out of himelf. Sir, (aid he) I have no deigns but what aims at your glory, and I would not have o great and o jut a King be blamed for favouring me above my merits; and therefore I do declare unto you, that I will not receive this honour which you offer unto me, as being concious of my own unworthines, but will think my elf ufficiently recompenced for all the ervices I have done you, by the gift of this word which I wear by my ide, at the point of which hangs your Kingdoms and Empires: But Celiodantes may aure himelf of this, that none hall ever marry the Princes Roanira, but he that gives her the head of Roilion. Thee words of rapture, uttered with o little dicretion, did o exaperate the already incened pirit of the King, that he looked upon him with an enraged eye; Ungrateful and impudent fellow (aid he unto him) Daret thou peak thus unto me? Hat thou already forgot the price I paid for thee, when I bought thee as a lave? Hence, out of my ight, and ee me no more, unles thou wilt feel the fury of my jutly incened dpleaure.

Thee words were pronounced in o loud a tone, that all thoe in the antichamber heard them, and ran in o fat, that Roilion had not time to anwer, but gnahing kis teeth, and tamping upon the ground, he was contrained to retire unto his lodging, where by the Kings command he was preently arreted by a number of Souldiers, who eized upon all the doors and advenues.

As you may ee Flies upon the firt froty day, vanih away from that place which warmed with them while it was hot; o upon the firt noie of Roilions digrace, all thoe importunate guets which warmed about him with o many offers of ervice, were all fled, and not one of them to be een in the place, where one would have thought they came for the love of him. Oh the mierable condition of thoe who go upon the legs of tottering Fortune: for in properity they are even mothered with the importunities of uch hore-flies, as in time of chill adverity, are all vanihed, and corn thoe that before obliged them.

Roilion begun preently to reent this change: but the falling off of thee hollow hearted friends, was not it which troubled him; it was the Kings reproach only which tung him at the heart; When he aw himelf alone in his chamber, and had shut the door, he began to walk up and down a great pace, not uttering a word, nor o much as knowing what he did, or where he was: At lat making a top in the midt of the room; Ungrateful and impudent fellow! aid he) hat thou already forgot the price I paid for thee, when I bought thee as a lave? Oh good Gods! continued he, Is it poible thee words hould come from the mouth of Policander, whoe life I have aved, and whoe Crown I have kept upon his head? Yet utter them he did, and mot certainly thee ears did hear them; it was to me, me my elf he poke them: Then being ilent for a while, he began again, Oh mot cruel Law, which will not let me pull out that Vipers tongue which pits thoe venomous words; words not worthy of a man that bears the Title of a King? Remember how I bought thee as a Slave! Remember (aid he unto me) the price I paid for thee, when I bought thee as a Slave. Well, when all reckonings are cat up, I have more reaon to upbraid thee: for though I were a lave, it was Fortunes fault, not mine, nor ought I to be accued for it: but who mut be blamed for that ervitude out of which I releaed thee, and into which thy drowie pirit and faint heart did bring thee? As thou dot bid me remember the price which thou didt pay for me, which was only a little money; o I bid thee alo remember the price which I paid for thee: Thou knowet it was my blood, of which I was too prodigal for the recovery of thy afety. Upon this calling to memory all the ignal actions which he had done for Policander: And for all thee (aid he) I mut be retorted with a remember what I paid for thee. Oh ye mot jut Gods, who do abominate all ungrateful men, how comes it to pas you do not punih this cured ingratitude? And thou Arm, who has o couragiouly defended the
honour of this unthankful man, why dot thou not revenge this intollerable affront? Why dot thou not as much for me, as thou hat for all thoe that ask'd jutice from thee in their oppreions? Oh thou unlucky Sword that has been o victoriouly keen in the caue of thy enemies, and o dull and blunt in his that wears thee? Did I win o many Battels, and conquer o many enemies, only to loe all my contentment and happines? Oh mot fatal Detiny! which would have made me Conquerour, if I had not conquered! Oh the injutice of heaven, why did I not die in the midt of my victories, that it might have aved me a dying by the hand of thoe I have conquered.

Thee thoughts, together with the advice which the Guards about his Lodging gave him, did put him into uch a fury, that he was almot quite out of his wits; and all that Meriin could do, was, to get him to Bed, without contradicting any thing he aid, let it hould augment his rage: There he remained two nights and two days without either leep or meat; at lat, a Fever eized upon him, and o high, that none did wonder he hould talk o rovingly, and far from any purpoe, becaue they thought his dieae to be the caue of it: But a few days after, when his Fever had left him, and yet he continued to talk in the ame frantique manner, it was plainly perceived that he had lot his undertanding, and was turned tark mad: which extreamly grieved all thoe that were admirers of his Vertue, epecially the King Policander, who when his anger was a little over, did know that his own los was the greatet: yet his earnet deire of peace, made him reent his los with les regret.

In the mean time, the Peace was concluded, as Policander wihed, and as Celiodantes deired; who thought all things advantagious, o Raanira might be his wie: And the Treaty of it was o cloely carried, that the firt news which the Queen Argira heard of it, was, when Orontes told us who Celiodantes had ent to that purpoe. Every one at firt did think by her countenance that he approved of it; for he eemed to be o joyful and contented, that one might read her approbation of what Orontes aid unto her, in her eyes. Madam (aid he unto her) As heretofore the los of the King did draw many a ad tear from your eyes, o now you may turn all your orrows into joys, at the great happines which he and your Dominions are like to receive: For that little rub of misfortune (little may it well be called in comparion of that great happines unto which it is converted) has made him a great King, and gotten Policander to be his friend: Nay more, it has gotten him two Crowns, that of the Ambarres, and that of the Boyens, by the marriage of the Princes Roanira, the Inheretrix of thoe two great Kingdoms: And this News (Madam) I am come to bring you from the King your Sno, whom now you may call the greatet Monarch of all Gaul. The Queen was o urprized at this News, that he tayed a long time before he anwered; whereat Orontes much wondred: and thinking perhaps that he did not rightly undertand him, he repeated it over again, relating the contentment of both the Kings, and the great joys of the people upon the publication of this Peace and Alliance: Unto which the Queen returned no anwer; but after a deep igh, this; Oh Sybil Meluine! How true are all thy Propheies? After this, he preently dimied Orontes, and a while after, went to Bed.

None heard what Orontes had aid unto her, but every one judged the News to be far different from what they thought at firt: yet none was o much atonihed as Orontes; for he thinking he had brought the mot welcome news the Queen could receive, he knew not what to think at her cold entertainment of it. But omtimes he feared that in the exces of his joys he had mitaken himelf, and told her one thing for another.

On the other ide, the Queen did nothing but cry, and igh in her Bed, not uttering a word that any could undertand, but only from time to time aying, Oh Sybil Meluine! and o lamented away all the night, until break of day, and then he fell aleep.

The reaon why this Treaty was carried on o cloely, was, becaue Policander knew what hatred Argira bore unto him: And though Celiodantes was ignorant of the caue, yet he knew it was o by her own animoity, in raiing wars againt
Policander, almot without any colour of reaon. So as when it was propoed not to acquaint the Queen his mother with it, till all was concluded, he was willing thereunto, left he hould give any top unto that marriage which he o paionately deired; thinking that when the peace and alliance was concluded betwixt them, then he knew not how to break it of; nor could he much as oppoe it, without hewing her malice too palpably: Yet they foreaw that he would extreamly wonder at the News, and would be very backward to this peace, and therefore it was, that Celiodantes gave commiion unto Orontes, not only to caue this to be publihed and oberved in all his Provinces, and amongt his Allies, but alo to receive thoe places which Policanders Forces held, and to retore them unto thoe Kings to whom they of right belonged: Alo to releae all prioners on both ides, according to the Letters which Policander writ unto the General and Officers of his Army. So as the next morning Orontes went again unto the Queen to communicate unto her all thoe Commiions which he had, and to beeech her he might put them in execution: But he lept on, o as it was very late before he could be admitted unto any peech with her: And when her Lady of Honour told her that he deired to peak with her, Sweetheart (aid he unto her) I am but in a very ill condition to hear of any buines; but ince his affairs are o preing, bid him do as the King his mater has commanded him, and o turned to the other ide.

As oon as Orontes had gotten this permiion, he aembled together all the Magitrates, and Principal Cavaliers, to whom he imparted the news of this peace, and commanded them to publih and oberve it in all the Provinces of the Kingdom: And after he had taken in all thoe places which Policanders men detained, he went unto the General of the Boyens and Ambarres Army, which was upon the Armorique Coat, where he was till continuing his lat victories; whom he acquainted with Policanders will, and who had already received the ame intelligence by one of his principal Officers. Peace was preently proclaimed, and places and prioners generally rendred and releaed; and o welcome was the news to all ides, that even thoe who had the advantage, were glad of it, o weary were all of war, and deirous of peace.

In the mean time Orontes advertied the King his mater, how Argira received the news of Peace, and of his marriage, at which he did not wonder, no more then Policander; both being of opinion, that it was an effect of the ill will which he bore unto the King of the Boyens; but they made no great reckoning of it, auring themelves, that time would alve the ore, and he be as well contented as either of them.

The conummation of the marriage was deferred only till the return of Orontes, and thoe whom Policander had ent to ee the Treaty performed on both ides. And one morning as Policander was going to the Temple, according to his cutom, a poor fellow eeing him pas by, and not uffered by the Guards to come near him, King Policander (cryed he out in a loud voice) Command that I may tell you my name, and o, as none may hear me. The King cating his eyes upon him, and eeing him to be an old ragged fellow, did think him to be one that would beg: and being ever of a charitable inclination, he commanded his Almoner to give him omthing: Upon this the poor man cryed louder, No, no King, I come not to beg, though perhaps I have need enough, but only to tell you my name. Thoe who heard him, thought him to be ome mad man, and therefore would have repuled him; but the King looking better upon him, did remember that he had formerly een him, and commanded to let him come nearer. The poor man kneeling down upon the ground, and in a better poture then his habit promied; Sir (aid he in o low a voice that none could hear but the King) I am Veronces. Policander hearing that name, preently remembred both by his voice and geture, that it was the ame Veronces who erved him when he courted Argira, and whom he left with her: o as being atonihed to ee him o unexpectedly, after a long opinion of his death, he could not chue but cat his arms about his neck, and embrace him, as affectionately as if he had been his on: Every one wondered at thee extraordinary carees; but the King called for one of
the Officers in his chamber, and commanded him to treat that man very kindly, to put good clothes upon his back, and money in his pure, and at night to conduct him to his chamber. Veronces was o over-joyed to ee the King acknowledge him, that he could not peak a word more, but cryed for joy.

At night the Officer conducted him into the Kings chamber; who after ome freh carees, asked him where he had been lot o long? Sir, anwered he, the quetion which you are pleaed to ask, is of too great importance to be anwered before o much company, and therefore I beeech you let it be in private.

Policander then taking him by the hand, and thinking it to be ome buines which concerned the Queen Argira, he carried him into his Cloet; where Veronces eeing himelf alone with the King, he began thus.

I have wondred (Sir, a thouand times, when I was in the Abys of my miery, why the Gods hould keep me o long alive; thinking that if the afflictions of men were equally divided, I have uffered above my hare, and more then any other: upon this conideration, I mut needs confes, I did omtimes begin to murmure againt the wie Government of the Gods, and accue them of injutice, for having o little care of humanes. But now when I ee their all-wie providence in preerving me, to do you a ervice of uch importance, I mut needs ay they are all-widom and goodnes, in keeping me alive, and conducting me opportunely unto this place, where I do not think any but my elf can hew you the greatet errour that ever could happen in your Family.

Be pleaed therefore to know Sir, that ince you commanded me to tay with the Princes Argira, who was preently after Queen of the Santons, and ince by the death of the King her Father, was Queen alo of the Picts, I may ay my life hath been nothing but a continual chain of mieries and diaters; one no ooner ended but another immediately began; and I think Fortune would never have been tyred with tormenting me, had it not been to do you ervice: But I think this favour o great, that I think all my pat torments and mierable time well employed, ince I have o much life left as to erve my mater. Imagine Sir, that in eeing Veronces, you ee a meenger of God ent unto you, or rather, a oul that has been retained at leat thee twenty years in hell, has at lat got leave to pas over the River Styx, purpoely to advie you of a fault which would have ecliped all your glory, made all your contentments bitter, and have unk you in orrows: For the truth is Sir, I have been prioner thee twenty years, without any hopes of liberty, until this general Peace, by which I receive the favour of heaven, and the light of the Sun, which has been o long a tranger to my eyes. Enjoying therefore this benefit, I came to undertand that you are giving the Princes Roanira unto the King Celiodantes in marriage: As oon as I heard this news, I made all the hate I could unto you, to peak with you before the marriage be conummated: and if I be come time enough I do thank the infinite goodnes of the Gods; and if too late, I protet that what I intended to tell you, hall die with me, and I hall think it the greatet misfortune that ever did befall me: I beeech the Gods after uch a diater, not to let me live a minute longer, ince life will be a mot intolerable torment unto me.

Upon this Veronces was ilent, and Policander laid his hand upon his houlder, Friend (aid he unto him) thy affection is o well known unto me, that thy expreions of it may be pared: Come tell me freely what this ecret is which you think o neceary to my contentment? For the truth is, I do intend to give my daughter unto Celiodantes, but it is yet proceeded no further then promies, and I tay only till the peace be publihed, and received by all thoe that have any Interet therein. Oh ye great and good Gods! be ye for ever bleed (cryed out Veronces) as well for your goodnes, as for your profound judgements. Then turning towards the King, Sir (aid he unto him) I hall acquaint you with a thing that will even ravih you with wonder, and will divert you from this marriage. What can divert me (replyed Policander) from a deigne o much conducing to the grandeur of my Crown, and the welfare of my people? Sir (replyed Veronces) This marriage is againt all Laws, both Divine and Humane: For, is not the Princes Roanira your Daughter? Yes certainly (anwered Policander.) And
the King Celiodantes (replied Verances) is your Son. My Son? (aid the King in a great amazemement, and tarted back) yes Sir, anwered Verances, Celiodantes is your Son; and be pleaed to hear the whole truth of the mattter, which none can tell you but the Queen Argira and my elf: Then being ilent a while he went on.

The Princes with whom you commanded me to tay, was preently after your delivered of a on, and o ecretly, that none but her nure and my elf, who he was pleaed to trut, did know of it: A few moneths after, he was married to the King of the Santons, by whom the ame year he had another on called Celiodantes; but becaue he married only by reaon of tate, and till preerved her affection entirely for you, he could not endure to ee Celiodantes continually under her eye, and be deprived of that better beloved on which he had by you; and much les that he whom he loved not hould be King of two great kingdomes, whilt the other had no etate: and a hundred times has he made her complaints of it unto me, and as oft did I indeavour to comfort her: at the lat he pitched upon a mot trange reolution: he pretended that a certain Sybil had foretold her, that if the little Celiodantes were een by any other but his Nure, and thoe that were to wait upon him, until a certain time, he would mot infallibly die immediately after. By this device he ent him away, and commanded me at the ame time to change him for the other which he had by you, o as ever ince he has been received by all for Celiodantes. Now he made choie of me for a witnes of this change, to the end, as he aid, that if he chanced to die, I might let you undertand how great her affection was unto you; and bleed be the gods, I have now, after o many years of miery made good my promie unto her.

King Policander hearing this dicoure, O Verances, aid he unto him, dot thou aure me that Celiodantes is my on? and that the Queen Argiras love unto me, moved her to put him in place of the true Inheritour? Aure your elf Sir, anwered Verances, upon that fidelity which I own unto you that I do not lie in one word.

Policander then made a ilent paue, and afterwards clapped his hands together, certainly (aid he) this is the caue of Argiras ad reentment of the news, when Orontes told her of the marriage between Celiodantes and Roanira, for ever ince he has kept her bed. Doubtles Sir, aid Verances, that if he know of uch a marriage betwixt them two, it will grieve her to the very oul; and I do judge of her by my elf, for I protet, I think that had I come too late to prevent it, it would have cot me my life. But Sir, there is no reaon you hould uffer one that has loved you o well, to continue in uch intollerable orrow; I beeech you therefore out of your own goodnes, and conjure you by the love you once bore unto her, to remedy it, and to quit your elf of thoe obligations wherein you tand bound unto her. Friend (aid the King then) now do I begin to believe that heaven does love me, and will let me live the ret of my dayes in contentment, ince It hath o unexpectedly given me a on in lieu of him I lot. I am reolved therefore not only preently to put the Queen Argira out of her pain, but alo give her uch tetimonies of my eteem, as he hall never again repent of her affection unto me.

After ome other dicoure upon this ubject, the King commanded him to retire, and above all to be ecret: then he went unto Celiodantes, whom he accoted with uch new and extraordinary Carrees as did amaze him, and afterwards told him, that he had a mot earnet deire that the Queen Argira his mother, hould be at the marriage, and therefore wihed him to continue the means of getting her to come, or if he would not, he was reolved to go unto her, although he was dipleaed with him, for he was fully reolved upon a reconciliation with her, and never to uffer the conummation of the marriage but in her preence. Celiodantes, who next his marriage, deired nothing more then to atisfie Policander, he told him after much other dicoure, that he would go himelf and invite her to come, auring himelf he would not deny him that favour: and Policander, approving his deign, he began to take order for his departure, and made uch
hate, as within three dayes after. he was ready to et forward, when Orontes returned and aured him, that the Queen Argira would be with them within two dayes, and that he came before her purpoely to acquaint them. Both the Kings were extreamly joyed at this news, and Celiodantes the ame hour et forward to meet her.

Policander the mean time enquiring of Orontes, how it came to pas, her humour was o much changed from what it whas when he writ, did undertand, that after he had kept her bed a long while, he ent one evening for him, and faintly asked him upon what buines the King her Son had ent him thither. Madam, anwered he, when I came firt I began to tell you my buines, but you were o indipoed then, that you could not hear me out; I undertand, replied he, that you come about the Publication of the peace, and to caue Publique joyes to be made for his marriage. But in that there was no need of any addrees unto me, for you had commiion ample enough for it without my approbation. Madam, anwered Orontes, 'tis mot true, I had uch commiion, but it was with a limitation, to act in it according unto your pleaure, and I am to beeech you from Policander and your Son, you would be pleaed to take o much pains as to be at the Celebration of the marriage. Did not you tell me (aid he and interrupted) that the marriage was already pat? Pardon me, Madam, I mot humbly beeech you, aid he, I might perhaps tell you that the marriage and the Articles of peace were concluded upon; but the conummation of the marriage was not to be, before your health would permit you to be there, or till you excued your elf.

O Orontes, (cryed he out with a joyful countenance) how I have been tormented, ince your firt coming, by not undertanding the buinee of your voyage: for you mut know that when I undertood the King my Son made o mall accompt of me, it did o grieve me to the oul, that my life has been odious unto me. O Madam, replied Orontes, entertain no uch opinion, I beeech you, but believe, though he ued all the expedition he could in concluding the peace without imparting it unto you, becaue he thought it o neceary and and advantageous to make himelf King of two great kingdomes, that he thought you would blame him if he ued any delay: yet for the marriage, aure your elf Madam, he was not o haty, ince the retardment of it could not be of uch importance; and the King Policander himelf deires you hould be preent at it. The Queen upon this, o changed her countenance, as if he had not been the ame; and took order for her departure the next morning.

p.U: uppoed that the Queen had prudently concealed the caue of her dipleaure from Orontes, and he longed extremely to hear the relation of Verances confirmed from her own mouth.

div.p: The Queen being arived, and received with all the honours that Policander could do unto her, and to the general joyes of all, except Roanira, who by reaon of her affection unto Roilion, could not in heart approve of this marriage with Celiodantes, The next morning, King Policander went to viit her, and after all Ceremonies of civility and complement, he deited to peak with him only in the preence of the Princes Roanira and the King her Son; o as every one quitting the room but they, the Queen began in this manner.

I am ure, Policander, when firt you reented the fury of my Sons Arms, and of thoe united with him, by my contrivance, to your ruine, you were then not a little atonihed. Do you remember what affection I hewed unto you, when (as a Knight errant) you came into the Court of the King my Father? if you do, you could not expect a lee revenge upon your ingratitude, from my wrong'd affection; and when you have heard me out, you will confee that love and hatred had never o trong an influence upon any, as it had upon the Soul of Argira. But you Madam (aid he unto the Princes) I beeech you wave your ill opinion of me, until you know by experience, what power thee two paions of love and hatred have over a Soul that loves well. And you Son (aid he unto Celiodantes) tay until the end of my dicoure, and then I aure my elf you will commend my fault, and think your elf beholding unto me.

Then beginning her dicoure at the arival of Policander in the Court of the King of Picts, he related all his Courthip of her, and the promies which he received from him, not concealing any particulars of their affection: how cloly he carried her being with child, and her delivery: The orrows he reented when he heard he had married Cloriena contrary to his promie; how he was forced by her fathers command to marry the King of the Santons, by whom he had a Son. She repreented her grief to ee this Son alwayes with her, and to be deprived of the other: her reolution was to change them, her contrivances about it, her curioity to know the Fortunes of thee children from the Sibil Meuline, whoe anwer he till kept in writing: how he put the true Celiodantes into the hands of Verances, and how extremely grieved he was, when he thought them both lot.

The King Policander, who knew all thee things from Verances, he was not o much atonihed as the ret: But Celiodantes, who aw himelf deprived of Roanira, and of two kingdomes, of which he thought to be Legitimate Lord, he was trangely confounded; yet it was no mall contentment unto him, to ee he had found uch a father as Policander, whoe virtue and valour was held in high eteem amongt all the Princes of his time. And to hide his dicontents, when the King his father opened his arms to embrace him, he kneeled down and aid, Sir, although I have this day lot that which I loved mot dear, yet the Princes Roanira will give me leave to rejoyce that I have found uch a Father as the great King Policander.

Son, aid he, wives, if one be lot another may be found, o cannot fathers, epecially uch as I hall be unto you: And for my part, I think this day the happyet I ever lived, ince in it I have found a Treaure which I eteem more then my Life; and ince now I find, that never was any Cavalier more obliged to a Lady, then Policander is unto the Queen Argira your mother: Then raiing him up, and kiing him, he uffered him to kie Roanira as his iter, who made it appear by her eyes, that he loved him much better as a Brother, then as a Husband.

In the mean while, King Policander addreing himelf unto the Queen Argira; I beeech you Madam (aid he unto her) Did you never ince hear of the true Celiodantes nor of Verances? Never, anwered he, though I have made all the enquiry that poibly I could; and yet I am in ome aured hopes he is not lot, by reaon of the Prediction which I received from the Sybil Meluine: For it is not probable he hould be a lyer only in this; before you ay any more Madam, aid the King, I would have you ee one, who perhaps may tell you ome news of him: then going himelf to the door, he brought in Verances, and taking him by the hand, preented him to the Queen: Madam, aid he unto her, do you know this man? As oon as he cat her eye upon him, although he was grown very old and lean, yet he cried out, Ah erances, where is the charge I committed into your hands? erances kneeling down upon the ground, with tears in his eyes, Madam, aid he unto her, force and violence hath diabled me from giving you a good accompt: O ye gods, cryed he, and joyned her hands together, is my Son lot? and is the Sybil a lyar? Tell me erances, aid he, and tell me truly, is he dead? didt thou ee him murdered before thy face? No Madam, anwered he; but if you pleae to hear the Fortune of the mot mierable man alive, I will briefly tell you mine, by which you may be better atisfied in your Quetions: Then Policander beeeching her to hear him, he began thus.

I was no ooner come to the place, where by your command I had changed this young Prince for his brother, but I changed alo his name, and charged his Nure to call him by no other then Kinicon, chuing that name rather then any other, becaue of the tone which you hung about his neck, whereon was ingraved the figure of a Lion, with thee words, Kinick, Knicon; conceiving that if ever he were lot, or came within compas of your hearing this name, you would know him by it. We went then, according to your command, unto the Port of the Santons, where taking a little retired houe, we paed away five years, every one thinking Kinicon to be my on, and his Nure my wife. When he was about that
age, one unlucky day, as he was playing amongt other children by the Sea ide, he was carried away by ome Pirats who roved about that coat: I was there alo, but aleep upon the ground, but did not awaken, till after thee Ravihers had got my mater into their hands, and me alo: yet amidt this great diater, it was ome comfort unto me to be with him, that I might in ome ort erve him; but alas, Fortune did preently after rob me of this conolation alo: for we were no ooner upon the open Sea, but another company of Pirats fell upon thoe that took us, and after a long dipute became maters of us; and it was my chance to be wounded. Thee lat Pirats, thinking that I had been one of the conquered Pirats, they put me into chains, and treated me with all the cruelties that uch perons ordinarily ue to be: Thee men carried us into one of the Armorique Iles, where they were wont to make their retreat, and where Merchant of the Continent ued to come and buy uch prizes of them, as they ued to take upon that coat.

A few dayes after, thee Merchants came thither, and the child was bought, as well for his handomnes, as upon the promies that I made unto them, to pay double what he cot, as oon as I could convey a Letter unto his friends; for I was extremely deirous to get him out of the clutches of thee wretched ort of men. When a thing, Madam, is decreed by heaven, it is impoible to be avoided. An honet Merchant bought him, and preently paid, what they asked, both for him and me. I told you that I received a wound in the Combate, and this wound for want of right dreing, did o gangrene, that the Merchant durt not take me with him, left I hould dy by the way; but gave me ome money to maintain me, with a promie to return unto me within fifteen dayes. And becaue the Pirats had taken the tone which you had put about the neck of little Kinicon, I beeeched the Merchant to buy it alo, and give it him: The honet Merchant did o, and before my face put it about the neck of the child; at which I was exceedingly contented, thinking that though I died, yet this mark might one day bring him to your knowledge.

Now Madam, the fifteen dayes were pat. and fifteen more, yet no Merchant came; and a while after, I heard he was dead: when I was recovered of my wound, I required a releae, becaue my ranome had been paid; but they who made profit their god, did but laugh at me, and the chief of them anwered, that the gods had made them Lords of all they could get, and owners of all that fell into their hands: o as clogging me with abundance of chains, I remained there in abundance of miery, until this lat war, when the Boyers and Ambaries, after they had forced many Towns towards the Armorique coat, did by fortune come into this Ille, which they plundered, and with many others, brought me into their camp; where though I was a prioner, yet it was ome atisfaction to be prioner unto reaonable men, and to ee thoe who ued me o cruelly, to be prioners as well as my elf. Heaven at lat, hewed ome pity upon me, and after a twenty years imprionment, did et me at liberty, by the benefit of the general peace, when all prioners were releaed.

The firt thing I did was to go unto the Temple, and render thanks unto the great Tautates, and next to beeech him, that if Kinicon were alive, to make him known unto you, that I might pas away the remainder of my old age in ome ret.

Having recorded in my memory, the name and place of the Merchant, I went thither as fat as I could; and all I could learn was, that the etate of the Merchant, after his death, was divided amongt his children, and thoe that had Kinicon, did end him up the river Loyre amongt other Merchandize, and old him either in Gaul about Lyons, or beyond: And being deirous to make a more exact earch, I undertood that all this Merchants children were lain in this lat war: So I went as fat as I could unto the Port of the Santons to enquire of the Nure whether he heard any news; but they told me, that as oon as he heard of the los of her on, and her husband, he died for grief: And indeed, Madam, I reolved upon the ame, not knowing what I had ele to do; but the news that I heard there preently after, prolonged my life: For I undertood that Policander,
having taken the King your on prioner, he reolved to conclude a peace, and for a confirmation of it, to marry the Princes Roanira unto him. Then did I think the Gods had preerved me alive purpoely to prevent that incetuous marriage; and though I knew, Madam, that you were alive, and that you knew the truth of things better then I, yet I thought ome conideration or other might keep you from declaring it. I made therefore all the hate that poibly I could, to acquaint Policander with it, let o great a diater hould happen in the Family of o good and o jut a King; and let that cure which would infallibly enue upon uch incetuous alliance, hould fall upon his head.

Upon this, he fell down upon his knees with tears in his eyes; It grieves me Madam to the very oul (aid he) that I am not able to retore unto you that charge which you committed unto me: But cured Fate! without any fault in me, did deprive me of that contentment.

q.l: In Forrets, where hall be Prince Godomar,
The other hall his enes there recover:
Then Fate hall kind be both to one and other.

div.p: Oh Madam (cryed he out) Do not condemn this great Sybil. Then taking Verances by the hand; Verances (aid he) in what place do they ay the childe was old? Alas Sir (anwered he) they know nothing, but that he was ent up the River Loyre with other Merchandie. Well (replyed the King) what age might the childe be then? About ix years old, anwered Verances. Was he black or fair, aid the King? Sir (aid Verances) he was the fairet childe that ever eye beheld: fair hair, and curled; full eyes, and lively; viage omthing oval, complexion freh and delicate, big for his age, and full made; in all proportions o handom, and in every action o becoming, as it was impoible to ee, and not to love him.

What was his name? aid the King. His right name (anwered Verances) was Celiodantes, but let he hould be known. I gave him the name of Kinicon, by reaon of a tone which had that name writ about it, and which the Queen did put about his neck. Oh ye infinite Gods! cryed out Policander, lifting up his hands and eyes to heaven, open our eyes, that we may find out the truth which hath been o obcurely hid from our eyes.
