Then turning towards the Queen, Madam (aid he unto her) as you have given me one on, o I will give you another, unles I be the mot mitaken man alive: For tell me Daughter (aid he unto the Princes Roanira) do you remember the name which Roilion had when the Merchants preented him unto me! Sir, (anwered he, almot out of her elf) his name was as you may ee writ upon this tone, which formerly he gave me, when he waited upon the Princes my Siter, and me; for (aid he) having nothing ele to give me for a New-years gift, when they gathered the Mileto of the New year, he gave me this; then pulling it out of her breat, I have ever ince kept it (aid he) becaue he told me it was very fortunate. The King no ooner aw it, but he knew it to be the very ame which he himelf had long worn, and afterwards gave it unto the Queen Argira; who alo as oon as he cat her eye upon it, he cryed out, and aid, Oh happy mark
of my pat contentments, I do demand of thee him unto whom I gave thee, whom if thou dot retore unto me, I will call the mot fortunate tone that ever was: then he kied it, and laid it unto her breat.

But all this was nothing to the joys of Verances when he aw it, for truly he eemed to be abolutely out of his wits. The Princes who durt not hew her joys, for fear of giving too much knowledge of her affection unto Roilion, he waited with extream impatience, until he was fully known, that he might be a harer in their demontrations of joy. In the mean time, the King taking the tone, and reading the incription about the Lyon, he found it to be Kinic, Kinicon, which ignifies, a King, the on of a King. Here is the name (aid he) which he had when the Merchants old him unto me as a lave, for I do very well remember it, and that afterwards when he killed the Lion which was ready to devour me, I changed it into Roilion; as well in memory of that generous act, as becaue he was my daughters Cavalier, and from Roanira and the Lion, I formed the name Roilion. When he was firt brought unto me, he was about the ame age which Verances mentions; his face was according to his decription; and all circumtances makes me believe Roilion to be the ame whom the Queen lot. And yet I conceive that a buines of this importance ought not to be divulged, until ome more certain tetimonies appear; for this tone might be taken from him, and put upon another and that name might be given unto him by chance, epecially eeing him o handome, as he might well be thought worthy of that name, which indeed does ignifie the Son of a King; and therefore before any notice be taken, I would have it made out by more infallible circumtances and proofs.

Sir (aid Verances preently,) he loved me o well, as I am confident that as oon as he hears my name, he will know me. If I do ee him (aid the Queen) I can know him by a mot undoubted mark; for I remember that when I put him into the hands of Verances, I was in ome fears of loing him, and therefore to know him, would have given him a mark with a hot Iron; and looking which was the mot convenient place, I found upon his hand a Roe o perfect, that I thought it mark ufficient. Oh Madam (aid the Princes preently) aure your elf then that Roilion is your on, for I have een a Roe upon his left hand o perfectly drawn by Nature, as is beyond all imitation of Art. Oh Sir, aid the Queen, and clapped her hands together, what can you deire more? Is it poible to give more certain aurances? The name, the age, the tone, the merchants, and the mark upon his hand, makes it mot apparent that he is the very ame; and above all, the prediction of the Sybil Meluine, puts in out of all doubt, conidering the condition wherein he is.

Madam (aid Verances) I mot humbly beeech you, give me leave to go unto him, and peak with him, before he hear any thing of this news, and I hall give you a mot perfect account. Upon this he went preently to the Lodging of Roilion, whoe malady was not at that time in its height of Fury, but only a ditraction of the undertanding, which made him conceit himelf omtimes to be in the Army, and commanding, as if he were the General; otherwhiles he fancied that he aw Roanira, and poke unto her; omtimes he would upbraid the King with breach of promie, and uch conceptions: And when he fell into thee humours, he would talk o temperately, and urge uch olid reaons and arguments, that if he did not omtimes rove preently from one thing unto another, one would not have judged him to be out of his enes.

When Verances came unto him, he was walking up and down the chamber, and aid not a word; but as oon as he was told that Roanira had ent to viit him, he left walking, and received him whom they preented unto him, o very kindly, and gave uch weet language, that none would have believed him ditempered: and this was no novelty; for when at any time they would have him to do any thing, if they told him that Roanira would have it o, he preently obeyed, with o much willingnes and alacrity, as if his mind had not been diordered.

p.U:
eeing him in this condition, could not refrain from tears: but before he made himelf known unto him, Sir (aid he) the Princes Roanira has ent me to know how you do, and to ee whether the Roe which you have upon your left
hand be worn out. Worn out (aid he preently) No, no, neither the Roe in my hand, nor the Roanira in my heart will ever wear out. She hopes the ame (replyed Verances) but becaue ome had told her the contrary, he ent me to ee, and report the truth unto her. Then he held out his hand unto him; ee Cavalier (aid he) how Nature knowing I was decreed by detiny unto Roanira, has given me a Roe, which I will keep as long as life. Poor Verances knowing him very well by that mark, Ah Kinicon (aid he unto him) is it poible you hould ee Verances and not know him? Upon this he tarted back two or three paces, and after he had looked a while upon him, Are you Verances (aid he all amazed) the husband of Lerina? (that was the name of his Nure, whom he thought to be his mother.) I am the very ame (anwered he) that was taken with you upon the Sea ide by Pyrats, and who never ince enjoyed one minute of contentment till I came hither. To ee the good nature of Roilion, he ran unto him with open arms, embraced and kied him, and for very joy, tears came into his eyes: afterwards, as if he were in his perfect enes, he enquired of his and Lerinas fortune, and why he had been o long abent from him. Verances then acquainted him with his long imprionment, and how he was et at liberty by the general Peace: At the word Peace he began to igh, and to be very extravagant in dicoure of the War which he had enterprized againt Celiodantes, with whom he would joyn Battel, and would have Verances there; and roved o far from any purpoe, that Verances not being able to conceal his orrow and tears; Sir, aid he unto him, what meage will you pleae to end unto the Princes Roanira? Tell her (aid he) that I will ere long end her Celiodantes a Prioner; but I do not intend the econd victory hall be o disadvantagious unto me as the firt. Then Verances would have gone away: But dear Verances (aid he unto him) take heed you be not again taken by Pyrats; if you go by Land, I will be your convoy with half my Army; but be ure you return preently unto me again, if you love me.

div.p: Verances with abundance of tears returned to the King and Queen, and reported what he had heard, and how Roilion remembred the name of Lerinda and Kenicon; of which the Queen was o glad, that he held up her hands, thanked heaven, and wept for joy: At lat (after much rejoycing) they all reolved not to publih their toys, until they aw the ret of the Sybils prediction verified; and in order thereunto, to carry Roilion into Forrets: And alo it was then concluded upon, that if he were cured, Roanira hould be his wife, and Cephie be given unto Celiodantes.

Verances then addreing himelf unto King Policander, Sir, aid he unto him, will you be pleaed to give you mot faithful ervant leave to put you in memory of that which my duty obligeth me unto? Mot freely (anwered the King.) Be pleaed to know then, O mot great King, that you can never hope for any bleing from heaven nor earth, as long as you continue in that injutice, wherein out of ome reaon of State you have lived everal years. Have I done any injutice? aid the King, and was a little moved. Yes Sir (replyed Verances) and the greatet that ever was done: for is it not the height of injutice to break all your promies made unto o good and o wie a Queen as this great Princes in? Do you not remember how I am a witnes of all thoe olemn Oaths, and Gods which you mocked, at the making of thoe promies? Aure your elf Sir, that all the misfortunes which hitherto you have received, are but fore-runners of greater, unles you do atisfie all thoe olemn promies which you made in the preence of the Gods. The King upon this was in a trange confuion. I do confes Verances, aid he unto him, thou ayet mot truly; and to make all due atisfaction, if the Queen will pleae to forgive, and forget the offence which I have committed againt her, which as thou ayet, was committed only out of reaon of State, I will this very hour take her for my legitimate Wife, and Queen of the Boyens and Ambarres; which he accepted of with much joy.

Thus the grave old man made an end of relating the caue of the Queen Argiras coming into that Country, and beeeched the Nymph to keep it, ecret, until it pleaed the Gods to retore Roilion unto his health. Unto which he anwered, that he thought it very expedient o to do, although he had very confident hopes
of his cure: for (aid he) beides the predictions of the Sybil, which hitherto have proved all true, the coming hither of him who mut cure him, which was but the day before Roilion came, eems as if the Gods had ent him purpoely for it: For the Prince Godomar, the econd on of the Burgundian King, came unto this Town but yeterday, and was conducted hither by a mot unexpected piece of Fortune, Madam (aid Argira) you do put me into great hopes and joys; but I beeech you, how do you conceive it hould be him whom the Sybil means? I do conceive (aid he) upon good reaon; for before your coming, we were reolved that he hould drive a acred Nail for the cure of a Shepherd that is troubled with the ame dieae; and this will be a means to keep it the more ecret: for under pretene of the Shepherd, both may be done as you deire. And I do think the Gods did end Prince Godomar hither, purpoely for it; becaue it being neceary that he who drives the Nail, hould be Soveraign Magitrate; I cannot think of any more fit for it then he, whoe quality is above the common rank. How Madam? aid the Queen Argira, Is then the young Prince of the Burgundians here? He is Madam (anwered the Nymph) and I cannot conceive any danger in acquainting him who you are; to the end, that if he hould come to know it afterwards, he hould not be offended at our diffendence in him. With all my heart (aid the queen) I will therefore end unto him, with a tender of my ervice, and acquaint him with it. Madam (aid Adamas unto the queen) I conceive it very neceary for many reaons, that all hate be made in the cure of the Prince Roilion, epecially becaue it is impoible but the buines will be divulged if it be retarded, ince there are many in your Train who know of it: And ince the acrifice is already reolved upon, and prepared for the Shepherd Adrates, the deferring of it would give occaion unto many to eek out for the caue of it, and perhaps find it out.

But beides all thee coniderations, the important affairs now in agitation, and which the Nymph will impart unto you, do require a peedy coure to be taken in it; o as Madam without more delay, let it be effected to morrow. Father (aid the queen) you motion a thing which uits much with my approbation, though I durt not trouble the Nymph o far as to move it; but ince her ervice requires it o, I beeech you let us joyn our petitions together, for a peedy concluion of it.

Adamas then turning towards the Nymph, Madam (aid he unto her) if you pleae, I hall ee the acrifice in readines, and hall acquaint the high Priet, and Prince Godomar, and therefore I beeech you give this atisfaction unto the queen.
The Nymph conented; and ending for Galathea, he retired, and left the queen Argira to as much ret as her troubled oul would give her leave to take.

The next morning the high Priet, accompanied with many Flamins, and the mot part of the Colledge of Augutalians, preented himelf before the Nymph, to let her undertand what was neceary to be done in the publique action which he intended; and amongt other things, that he hould chue a Soveraign Magitrate, unto whom he hould refer the Soveraign Power, as long as the buines was in hand: For (aid he) this Ceremony did come from Numa Pompilius; and at that time Rome was under the command of Kings, and it was they who were wont to drive the Nail: But after Kings, were abolihed, they ued always to elect a Dictator: For this olemn action mut not be performed by any, but uch a one as hath no uperiour unles the Gods. Now Madam, I preent thee things unto you, that you may put in effect thoe good and pious intentions which you have towards Adrates, and the other tranger; and in order thereunto, to make choie of him, who being made Soveraign Magitrate, may execute all conditions neceary: For though (Madam) you be the Soveraign Lady of the Country, yet according unto our Cutoms, you are not capable of medling herein, becaue in all acrifices unto Jupiter, men only mut be miniters.

The Nymph who was already advertized of the neceity in making this election, and who alo thought it advantagious to her affairs, yet eeming to have no
other deign, but the care of thee two Perons. Father, anwered he, I am o much deirous to obtain this favour from the gods, that I intend not only to make choie of uch a man o quallified as you mention, but alo to do any thing ele that you hall think either expedient or neceary; and ince we are not well experienced in uch olemn Actions, I pray give me a full relation of all that is to be be done. Madam, aid the high Priet, two things are neceary to be, done: The one a acrifice, the other an election of a overaign Magitrate; for after the acrifice offered unto Jupiter and Minerva, he whom you chue, mut drive a nail of bras, which we mut conecrate and make pure and clean with Lutralian water, into the wall of Jupiters Temple, which is towards the Sanctuary of Minerva, and this to be done after the nail hath three times touched the temples of the dieaed peron: Then for the acrifice we will take uch order as it hall be in readines, at what hour, to morrow, you hall pleae to appoint: But, Madam, as for the election of this Soveraign, it is requiite you make choie of him to day publickly, and that you give unto him a Scepter, & a Globe, as formerly they were wont at Rome: and becaue that was a Republique, and every one had a hare in it, that Dictatour was choen by the votes and uffrages of all the people; but in this place, where you have the ole interet, you alone mut make this election, o it be in publick, that every one may know your intention.

Adamas undertanding that the Ceremony was to be performed in this manner. Madam, aid he unto her, knowing it your pleaure to oberve all thee things, I have-taken order for all things requiite in this election, o as they have already begun to erect caffolds, and I aure my elf, that preently after dinner, all things will be in readines. After this, the Nymph appointing the high Priet to take order for the acrifice next morning, he referred the ordering of all the ret unto the Druide, intending preently after dinner to make this Election, unto which, the Prince Godomar, Alcedon, Damon, and Adamas, were of opinion, that it was requiite to ummon Polemas, to the end he might have no colour or excue for the Arms (which was in a low voice commonly poken) that he was preparing And though the Nymph knew very well he would not come, yet he approved of their opinions, and dipatched Clindor preently unto him.

On the other ide, Prince Godomar thinking it neceary to advertie the Prince Sigimond of all paages, and being unwilling to imploy any of his own men, left he hould receive ome coure treatment from King Gondebaut, he beeeched the Nymph to permit that Leontidas the on of Clindor might be the man; conceiving him to be man of courage and wit, and a peron whom he might trut in the buines, ince Dorinde lay at his houe, and ince he believed that he had acquainted him with the caue of her coming.

The Nymph liked very well of it, and ent Letters by him unto the King, unto Prince Sigimond, and unto the Princes Clotilda. Unto the King, by way of joy, for the honour he received from the preence of Prince Godomar his on; not taking notice that he knew any thing of the caue which moved him thither: Unto Prince Sigimond, by way of aurance, to give Dorinde for his ake all poible aitance; and unto Clotilda, to deire the continuation of her favours. And becaue Godomar thought that perhaps the King would not uffer Leontidas to ee his brother, he advied him to go unto him ecretly, if he could the night before, and to peak unto Gondebaut, according to the advice of Sigimond: having then given him full intructions, and Dorindes picture, he recommended him unto the Protection of Tharamis.

Dorinde on the other ide, who as he thought had o much caue to complain againt all men in general, and in particular againt Sigimond, he knew not what meage to end unto him: for when he remembred how he was left all night in the wood, in expectation of him, he could not afford him a good thought; when he conidered what Godomar told her, ometimes he thought him partial and poke in behalf of Sigimond, and ometimes again he excued him: At lat, at the intance of the young Prince, he ent him a Letter by Leontidas, and entreated him to aure Sigimond that he would be alwayes his ervant, in pite of Fortune.

Thus the Father and the Son, Clindor and Leontidas departed both in one day: 'Tis true the Fathers journey was not far, and therefore ooner dipatched when he came to Surida, which was about ome five hours after he went from Marcelles, he was amazed to ee uch a confluence of Souldiers, Officers, and Cavaliers: Clindor, who knew Polemas before he was raied to this Grandure, and whoe Predeceours were nothing inferiour unto the family of this man, he could not look upon this exceive arrogance without dipiing him: o as when he went unto him to deliver the Nymphs letter, and was firt carried through a long Guard of Souldiers in File, afterwards into his antichamber and withdrawing room, where he found a great number of Cavaliers ranked into two Files to make him paage; he could not chue but ay unto the man who conducted him, I wih ome tranger aw the Train of Polemas, that they might admire at the Grandure of the Nymph Amais, and publih to the world, that her ervants keeps as great a Court as the greatet Kings. Polemas was all this while at the higher end of his Chamber, and no ooner aw him, but with cap in hand he came and embraced him o kindly, that as Clindor was ill atisfied at his firt entrance, yet this reception obliged him o, that he thought Polemas worthy of all his Grandure, uch a trange influence has weetnes courteie upon the mot noble and generous hearts. And indeed it was true that Polemas, amongt the ret of his perfections, was his Arts Mater in Civility, Courtey, and Complement, a quality very requiite in uch as aim at Grandure above their native qualities: After the firt Complemental Carees, Clindor preented unto him a Letter from the Nymph, and withal acquainted him with her deire of his being preent at this Ceremony. Unto which returning no anwer, as if it were a thing he leaft intended, he fell into ome complaints, peaking as if he had great confidence in Clindor. Dear friend, aid he unto him, I beeech you conider how ill the Nymph has us'd me of late, and what reaon he has to think me worthy of coming into her preence: You know how dearly I loved Argenteus, as well for his merit as kindred; and yet he could look on and ee him treacherouly murdered befoee her face: Nay more, he forced me to cahier all thoe who oppoed that unworthy act, as if they had done omething that was ignominious, and againt her ervice.

Then again, in lieu of chatiing one Damon, that wanderer, or rather highway man, he has gotten him into Marcelles, and makes a great accompt of him, as if he were not guilty of the baet action that ever any Cavalier attempted. I et thee things before your eyes, to the end that you being a Cavalier, may pity my digrace, which forces me to keep a ditance from the Nymph, chuing rather the olitude of my houe, then to trouble her with the ight of him who is o dipleaing unto her. Should I relate ome other caues which I have, you would admire my patience, for to pas by the infinite number of affronts which I receive every day; you know, dear friend, that you and I are Cavaliers, whoe profeion is converant in Arms and affairs of State. How is it poible we hould endure to ee a Druide, whoe office is only about Altars, it at the helm of the State, and tear it as he pleaeth: To ee him et and appoint Guards in Towns, to lift Souldiers, appoint commiioned Officers, and uch like, as are quite contrary to contrary to men of his coat, whilt we it till in our own houes dipied, and not o much as looked upon; and yet we ee all thee things in the peron of Adamas, whom now has lot the name of Druide, and is become a great Governour of Provinces, nay of Amais her elf. Surely we cannot look upon thee things but with ad eyes, and I think none doubts but that it is a mot manifet injury unto me: for the Nymph has committed that charge unto me, and he cannot put me out, without mot apparent wrong: Have I any way misbehaved my elf? has not the tate enjoyed a erene tranquility under my regiment? Can the people complain of any ubidies or exactions? has any Souldier erved without his full pay? have I leened the revenues of the Exchequer • have any leagues or confederations been broken? Are any of our neighbour Princes dicontented? If any one in all the tate, great or little can complain of any wrong that I have done, then, I am guilty, and the Nymph has reaon to put another in my place that will erve her better. But when none of thee things can be charged upon me, tell me
dear Clindor, have I not jut reaon to complain? Yes certainly, if not againt the Nymph, yet at leat againt my bad Fortune. This grievance makes me to love my friends and my kindred, and to pend my time amongt them, ince my life has hitherto been pent in the ervice of one who does not o much as look upon my affection; or if he do ee it, does corn and reject it.

Clindor heard him out without any interruption, and let him ay what he would, but though his words were mooth, and language full of candour, yet he aw they were teept in viniger, and had a hidden bitternes in them and not being o ignorant in the affairs of the world, but that he had heard of his bad deigns, epecially when the Nymph at parting gave him a hint thereof, that he might more particularly oberve all his actions, he found that all his complaints had been long premeditated, and that to contradict him, would not convert him, nor do the Nymph any ervice; and therefore without entring into any excue he only told him, that perhaps his complaints had not o jut a ground as he imagined, nor as was reported unto him: That in love and court, abence was a mortal enemy unto any man: That the Nymph was o weet and every way o good, that he might expect all deired atisfaction from her: That he eteemed of him above all the ret of her Subjects, and therefore had elevated him above all the ret: That the demontration of her good will unto him was o great, that he could not any way upect the contrary: That her deires of eeing him was an argument that he et a higher eteem upon him, than he was made believe by ome owers of edition; and that to blat all the deigns of uch ill officers, he ought to come unto Marcelles, where he might receive from the Nymph all manner of atisfaction and contentment, and that he ought the rather to come, left the Prince Godamar being there, hould ait the Nymph in this publick Action which he intended.

Polemas had been already advertied of Prince Godomars' coming by his correpondent; but becaue the caue of his coming was kept cloe, he could not know it: yet imagining that o great a Prince would not come with o mall a train, unles upon ome great importance, he paionately deired to undertand what it was; but not daring to dicover his curioity too much unto Clindor, he conceived that their dicoure did give him a good occaion to talk a little more of it. But dear friend, (aid he and interrupted him upon that point) what great action is that which is intended? For though I know Prince Godomar did not come thither for nothing; yet I cannot imagine what it hould be. The Action (replied Clindor) will be very great, for the Queen deires that whatoever the high Priet and Colledge of the Augutalians, hall command, may be exactly oberved.

About three or four dayes ince, a Lady whoe name is Dorinde came unto Marcelles upon ome occaion, which truly I do not know; but o it was, that there came in her company ome hepherds and hepherdees, who brought one with them who ran mad for love. The Nymph was deired that a nail of bras might be driven into the wall of the Temple for him, a Ceremony which they ay is a common cure for madnes. Now the high Priet does tell her that for the driving of this nail he is to make choie of a Soveraigne Magitrate, for it can be done by no other hand but his. Who do you think (aid Polemas) he intends to chue for that Ceremony? I think, anwered Clindor, he is not yet reolved: but when you come unto her he will tell you, and I am confident he will do nothing without your advie. Clindor, replied Polemas, unles he intend utterly to digrace me, he will not think upon any but me: For it belonging to my office he cannot without extream offence prefer any other; but I perceive he thinks her contempt of me not enough, unles it be done to my face, and therefore he would have me preent at this publick Ceremony, that all the world may laugh at me. It is enough that I have pent my age and my etate in her ervice, and not loe that little reputation and credit that I have amongt men. Tell her therefore, that as long as I can, I will conceal from every one that mall value which he ets upon my ervices, and that I had rather hear ay he lights me, then be witnes of it. Clindor perwaded him all he could to divert him from this reolution, but he tood obtinately upon this and beckning unto Ligonias, Pelidontes, Argonides,
and Lyander to come unto him; he acquainted them with the caue of Clindors coming, and with the anwer he had ent unto the Nymph: And all four did o approve of what he had done, with o many complaints and imaginary injuries, that at lat he was contrained to come away with this anwer, to wit, that if the Nymph would chue him for this olemn Ceremony, and gave him the title of Soveraign Magitrate, he would come and erve her with a good troop of his friends: otherwie, he would keep at a ditance, and rather hear what was done, then ee it with o much dihonour to himelf.

But in the interim, the Nymph as oon as he had dined, carried Prince Godomar unto a great plain, where caffolds were erected, and there in the preence of all the Druids, Priets, Flamins, Augutalians and others, as alo of all Cavaliers, Sherifs, and Majors of the Town, he declared him Soveraign Dictator in all her provinces, and in order thereunto gave him a Scepter. He afterwards taking an oath to govern the State with Jutice and equity as long as his commiion lated, and not to pare any pains, life, or limb, in defence thereof! Then the Trumpets ounded, and the people with houts of joy accompanied him back to the catle, and as they paed through the treets, though it was night, yet it was as light as day, and not a door but had two Torches burning before it.

Clindor returned when all thee lights were et out, and uppoing it to be for joy of this election, he hoped that the Nymph did it upon good conideration, though he knew it would extremely incene the pirit of yonder ambitious man, When he came before Amais he would have given her an account of his journey but he would not hear him until the Prince Godomar, Damon, Alcedon, and Adamas were preent, who hearing the reolution of Polemas did not wonder at it, knowing very well that he would find ome excue or other for his not coming hither; but charged Clindor to be ecret in it, for ome reaons which afterwards he hould know.

But all thee Ceremonies were no ooner olemniz'd, then Meronthes the confident of Polemas, ent his on to acquaint him with it, and the arival of the Queen Argira, though he knew not her name; only let him know with what a Train he came, and how he was lodged in the Catle: All thee things did extremely trouble him; for being ignorant of the caue which brought Prince Godomar thither, with the Cavaliers, which, troop after troop, followed him, and then the great number which belonged unto the Queen Argira (for the hundred ouldiers which he brought were reported to be three) he was the mot confounded man in the world; and but for the hopes he had in the nimble wit of Climanthes, certainly he had hatned his deign, and attempted upon the Town: but the aurances he had from him, and the execution at hand, was the reaon of retarding the buines, and lacking his deign wherein he had uch great hopes. And the rather, becaue tomorrow was the day appointed by Leonide for Galatheas reolution: which the Nymph remembring very well, he appointed her and Silvia over night to go the next morning and know his reolution; which they failed not to do: and becaue they were very deirous to be at this olemn acrifice of driving the nail (a Ceremony never een before, and therefore invited with the more curioity) they got up o early in the morning, that they were almot the firt at the opening of the gates: and yet they found Climanthes already expecting them, at the door of his Temple, where eeming as if he aw them not; he began to adore the riing un, and the heavens, and endeavoured by uch counterfeit devotion to get an opinion of his anctity. But when he perceived that they aw his diimulation, he aroe up and came towards them. Nymphs (aid he unto them) the Divinity, who I adore, is pleaed with the prayers of Galathea and the acrifices which I offered for her; and therefore have permitted me to go unto her, and render the Oracle which he deires, and which is one of the greatet favours that ere was done unto any mortal. I aure you therefore that three dayes hence I will come about this time of the day unto the garden door which is under the Catle, not deiring to be een in the Town, or any places frequented, becaue they are not conformable unto my olitary coure of life; and I do give her three dayes warning to the end he may prepare her elf with a reolution to oberve the
commands of the Oracle: For otherwie, that great Deity whoe Meenger and Interpreter I am, will be more incened againt her, then I am able to expres; and therefore let her be ure he arm her elf with trong reolution to obey his commandments. Sage Nymphs, I know you love her, and therefore I conjure you to advertie her of it from me; and if by fortune you find her not inclineable thereunto, to give me notice of it, that I may not more aggravate her crime by my coming unto her. Nay, nay, anwered Leonide, never retard that favour which the Gods intend her for that; for I aure you he is fully reolved not to fail in any thing; and if any thing divert her from this her reolution, it will be only the delay of thee three days which you prefix, and which will eem very long unto her. That delay (anwered he) proceeds not from me, but from the Deity which I adore; and I take it for a very good Angury; for the number of three is pleaing unto the Gods: and to tell you truly, thee are the three days in which that God is mute; o as though I would my elf peak as I was accutomed unto her, yet I cannot. And for this caue I do not carry you at this time into his holy Temple; knowing that during thee three days, neither Sacrifices nor Prayers are pleaing unto him: and you hall ee that if I offer to enter, as I am accutomed, he will hut the door againt me: But fail not you to be both at the Garden door upon the day I have appointed, and you hall ee that contentment which heaven is preparing for her, as a reward of her obedience.

Upon this he hated up the tairs towards his Temple, for he thought that if he tayed any longer, the door would hut of it elf: and it hapned as he thought; for he was no ooner ready to et his foot in the door, but it hut violently upon him.

Leonide and Silvia did know very well that this man was an Impotor, yet for all that, they were afraid; having an opinion, that under a colour of anctity, he dealt with the Divel: And, as if heaven took delight in augmenting their fears, it hapned that when they were near the gardens of Marcelles, through which they could pas into the Bae Court of the Catle, without coming into the Town, preently they pied a man, who knowing them a far off, came running to them; and as oon as he overtook them, fell down upon his knees before Silvia, and endeavoured to kis her hand. The Nymph no ooner cat her eye upon him, but he cryed out, Oh good Gods, See where the oul of Ligdamon is! Ligdamon! replyed Leonide (and was wore affrighted then her Companion) oh Heavens! it is o, and began to run away as fat as ever her legs could carry her to the Garden door, which by chance he found open; and he had run her elf o out of breath, that as oon as he was two paces within the door, he fell down, as if he had been half dead: Silvia in the mean time eeing her elf alone, and held by this man, whom he thought to be a Ghot, was o extreamly affrighted, that he fell into a woond. The man eeing her in this pitiful condition, he was truck almot as dead as he eemed to be; he fell down upon his knees, called unto her, and pinched her to bring her again unto her elf. She upon this opening her eyes, and till feeling him, cryed out, and fell into her fit again; he till called upon her, and till pinched her, but all would not do any good; for her fears this econd time were uch, as indeed did put her in danger of death. At which the man was o affrighted, that he roe up, and ran to call for help, or at leat, to fetch ome water to throw upon her; and eeing a houe not far from thence, he ran thither: But as good luck was, he was no ooner out of ight, but Silvia came to her elf; and not eeing this Ghot which put her into this fright, he roe up and ran as fat as ever he could unto the Garden door, which he aw open, and as he was hutting the door, he pied the man running after her as fat as he could, yet o far off, that he had time enough to make fat the door, and get into the Catle, where he found Leonide in uch apprehenions of fear, as he was not able to utter a word.

But when he aw Silvia, Oh Siter, aid he, I am very glad you are ecaped out of the enchantments of this wicked man. Silvia half beides her wits, Ah Siter (aid he) would you run away, and leave me in o great a danger? All their companions eeing them thus affrighted, ask'd to know what the matter was?
But for all their diorder they would not tell, having this conideration with them, that perhaps it might he prejudicial to the ervice of the Nymph.

Galathea was preently acquainted with it, and thinking that Climanthes was wicked enough to do them ome harm, he went unto them in their chamber where they were: when they aw her, they cheered up themelves as well as they could, yet looked as if they were newly come out of their graves. Galathea not willing to ask them any quetions before o much company as was preent, he took them by their hands, and commanded the ret all to withdraw: And then, Come (aid he unto them) I ee you both extreamly affrighted, what is the caue of it? Madam (anwered Leonide) the stranget encounter that ever was: for the man unto whom you ent us, I think has a thouand Divels at his command: After we had poke with him, and he promied to be here the third day, and when we thought we had been quite out of his hands, he ent the Ghot of Ligdamon after us, who took my companion by the hand, and put us into uch a fright, that if we had not luckily found the garden door open, we had died. For my part, I ran away, and cannot tell how my companion ecaped out of his hands. Truly (aid Silvia) I followed your example, taking my elf to my legs; and 'twas well I did o; for I aw him running after us, and would certainly have followed us hither, if I had not been o couragious as to hut the door after me. All which the Nymph hearing, and knowing it to be nothing but fancy he began to laugh at the fears wherein they were; and leaving them to ret themelves, he went unto Amais, unto whom he related all he heard; whereat he was not a little atonihed: And whilt they were in talk of thee things, one came to tell the Nymph that the Sacrifice was ready, and that the Nails of Bras were wahed clean and pure with the Lutralian water: o as the Prince Godomar expected only the Queen Argira, who at lat came, holding the Princes Roanira by the hand; who was o fair that day, as he ravihed the eyes of all thoe that looked upon her; her Dres was modet, and by reaon of her affliction, rather too much, then too little; but o neat and handome, that envie it elf could not find the leat fault: he leaned upon the arm of Roilion, whoe countenance was very ad, and his looks omthing wilde, but by his walk and garb, and all the ret of his actions, appeared to be of no mean extraction. There was very few that knew him, for the Queen deired it o; o as for a long time together, nothing could be heard amongt all the aembly, but enquiry who they were; but none being able to atisfie their curioity, they all et themelves to behold the ceremony.

Firt came ten Trumpetters, who from time to time ounded all together. Next them, followed men who were crowned with flowers, and in habits trimm'd all over with Violets, dancing before the Victims, carrying in their hands little Daggers, which they knocked againt one another to a kind of Tune: After them came the carriers of Bains and Dihes to receive the blood of the Victims: after them followed many Victimaries with axes, hatches, and everal other Intruments to lay the Victims, all having caps of flowers upon their heads: Next followed the Victims, which were even Oxen to be offered unto Jupiter, and as many unto Minerva, with guilded horns, and dreed over with Garlands of Flowers: Thee Victims were followed by ome Sacrifices, one of them carrying the Veel that held the Lutralian water, who followed a Flamin, who with a branch of Mileto prinkled this holy water upon all the Aitants; Another carried a box of Aromatique Drugs, as Incene, Myrrh, and Aloes; Another carried upon his head a veel of Wine, which was to be ued in the Sacrifice: another carryed alt, and another honey, and another water: After all thee, followed twelve Players upon Flutes, and ome Choriters, who ung Hymns in praie of Jupiter and Minerva. Next followed the Epulian Triomvires, who are thoe that were wont to tell the people when they ought to make any Banquets unto the Gods: After thee followed the Flamins; the lat of which was Diale the Flamin of Jupiter, with his cap made of white wool, and in a Surplice of finet Linnen, o pure and white, that not the leat pot appeared in it. Afterwards came the Colledge of Augures, each having in their hands an Augurian taf. Lat of all came the high Priet, with mot comly gravity, clad in a garment of white linnen, this Surplice of puret white hung
down to the ground; he had upon his head a kind of cap, which might rather be called a Vail, hanging down on both ides; He held in one hand his Croier, and in the other his Patoral taff; on each ide of him was two Flamins, who carried in their hands a great Nail of Bras, which had been purified and conecrated.
After all this pomp, the Prince Godomar came all alone, with a Crown upon his head, and a Scepter in his hand, and following him a great croud of Cavaliers and Souldiers.

In this order they came unto the Temple, where the Queen Argira, the Nymph, Roanira, and the ret of the Ladies were with Roilion and Adrates: and every one having taken their places, Proclamation was made that all hould keep ilence upon pain of punihment:

Then the Flamin Diale, who was Sacrificer that day, called for the Lutralian water, and after he had wahed his hands, did prinkle it upon all that were to be aitants at the Sacrifice; then falling down upon his knees, he confeed himelf to be a man poluted with many ins, and begged a pardon of the Gods, not only for his own, but for the ins of all the Aitants; then taking a Torch which was made of Virgins wax, which was lighted at a clear burning fire, he kindled the wood that was upon the Altar; and commanding the Victims to be brought near, he turned towards the eat ide of the Altar: He firt invoked Janus and Veta, and afterwards Jupiter, calling him Father, Omnipotent, and Good; and after him he invoked all the ret of the Gods. Afterwards addreing his prayer particularly unto Jupiter and Minerva, he declared that it was unto them only this Sacrifice was offered: And thee were the words of his prayer, which a Flamin pronounced after him word for word.

OH mot great and good Father, Son of Saturn, Jupiter omnipotent, the beginning and ending of all; who art fulnes in the elf, who art every where, in all, and above all: The Creator, Preerver, and Director of the world; the Detiny upon whom the order of things depend; the Nature which produceth all things; thy Providence which foreees all things; the Eternity, that was before, and will be after all things. Oh thou Jove, who for the benefit of Mortals, conceived Minerva in thy Brain: Oh most mighty Minerva! who teaches mortals to be wie, to judge jutly, and to do rightly. Goddes of eternal Virginity, Phyician unto thoe who are deprived of their undertandings. Receive, oh Great and Omnipotent Deities! the Prayers and Sacrifice which Amais our great Nymph does offer unto you, for the afety and welfare of her elf and people: and becaue there is nothing in the whole Univere more pleaing unto you then man, and nothing in man more then the Undertanding: Grant, Oh Great and Good Jupiter, and oh Goddes of Prudence and Undertanding, Minerva the requet which this great Nymph makes unto you; That thoe acred Nails which the Prince Godomar, our Protector, and as Soveraign Magitrate is to drive, according unto your Ordinances, may obtain for Roilion and Adrates, the ame favour which Oretes formerly obtained near the City of Githea, when itting upon thy Stone, Oh Jupiter! he was cured of his ditraction.

After thee words were uttered in a loud and o ditinct a voice, that all, or mot of the people might hear as they were upon their knees; he caued the Victims to be brought near, he cut off the hair which grow between their horns, and cat it into the fire, which was the firt beginning of the Sacrifice: Afterwards he turned towards the Eat, and commanded the Victimaries to do their offices, which they did accordingly: Then he viewed the Intrals, and found the Hearts, the Livers,
and the Brains very ound, yet of a more dusky colour then uual, but not to affright the Aembly, they took no notice of them, becaue it portended dientions, wars, and tumults. After the Victims were viewed, the fat of them was burned and conumed upon the Altars; and they poured out wine and oyl, and prinkled Incene thereupon: The fire burned till all was conumed, but they oberved the flame to be blew like brimtone, and not burning upwards like a waving Piramide, but as if it were depreed with wind, which yet would ome times flah out into extraordinary flames: The moak was thick, dusky, and obcure, mothering downwards, and not acending as uual. At which being atonihed, they looked amongt the Wood, to ee whether there was any that was forbidden; as the Olive, the Lawrel, the Oak, and uch fat kinds of wood; but they found all to be dry, and very right; which put them into greater fears: but thoe fears vanihed, when at lat they aw the fire burn clear, the moak thin, and acending, and the Victims all conumed, with as good an odour as they could deire.

The acrifice was no ooner ended, and the Flamin had no ooner pronounced the lat word, but the high Priet taking the acred Nails, did wah them anew with the Lutralian water, and offered them unto Jupiter and Minerva: Then he preented them unto Prince Godomar, who taking them with all reverence and devotion, made ome private prayers; and afterwards touched the temples of Roilion and Adrates; which was a thing not eaie to be done without the Princes Roanira, and the Shepherdes Doris: But Roilion did o much repect the one, and Adrotes the other, that they durt not diobey whatoever they commanded. When the Prince Godomar was going to drive the Nails, Palemon went to the corner of the Altar: For my part (aid he in a loud voice) I do make a mot olemn vow, that if it will pleae the great Gods to grant our requet which now we ask, I will not deny the firt thing which hall be asked of me, be it what it will, if it be within the compas of my power. The Officer who recorded all olemn vows, did write down this of Palemon, and many oberved that Roanira looked upon the Queen Argira, as if he expected the like from her; which the Queen perceiving, he alo roe up, and went unto the Altar: And I (aid he, as loud as he could peak) who am a Queen, and the Wife and Mother of Kings, I do promie and vow, oh great Jupiter and Minerva, that if you grant the petition which I now make unto you, I will employ all the power and forces of thoe Kingdoms which are in ubjection to me, my husband, and my on, in maintenance of the Nymph Amais, and her Dominions, againt all thoe that hall offer any injury unto them or her. The people hearing this Vow, and wondering at it, would have broke out into acclamations of joy, but their repect unto the acrifice hindred them. In the mean while, the Prince Godomar holding the Nail in his left hand, and a hammer in his right, being directed by the high Priet, and the Flamin Diale, he went towards the wall which was towards the Sanctuary of Minerva; and there calling thrice upon the names of Jupiter and Minerva, he drove the Nails to the very head: But to ee the wonderous effects! upon the very firt blows that were truck, Roilion and Adrates fell to the ground as if they were dead, and o continued until the Prince Godomar came unto them, and till the Flamin prinkled ome Lutralian water upon them; then they came to themelves, as if they had waked out of a dead leep. Roilion opening his eyes, and eeing o many Flamins, and other people about him, did think himelf at firt in a dream, for he had quite lot the memory of all he had done, during the time of his ditraction. But Verances tanding by him, and taking him by the hand, Sir (aid he unto him) do you not ee the Princes Roanira coming towards you? If you do not make good hate, he will find you lying upon the Ground. How? aid he, will Roanira take o much pains as to come unto me? Upon this riing up, he aw her cloe by him, with the Queen Argira; and he not knowing the Queen, he went to alute Roanira, as if he had not een her even years before: But Roanira taking him by the hand, Roilion (aid he unto him) firt alute this great Queen, unto whom you are obliged as much as ever any Cavalier can be: Upon this he kneeled down, and would have kied her hand; but the Queen would not uffer him, but embracing him with tears in her eyes, Roilion (aid he unto him)
let us all render thanks unto the gods for freeing you from your enchantment: Enchantment! (replied he all amazed) what enchantment do you mean? you hall know hereafter anwered he; but in the mean time, let us expres our gratitude, as both you and I are obliged, and taking him by the hand he carried him to the altar: then preently after he took Roanira and him into a coach, and went unto the Catle, it being o reolved upon by the Nymph and the Prince Godomar, left if Roilion had tayed any longer amongt all the company, he might fall into ome fancy of his being ditracted, which perhaps might be prejudiciall unto him, having been o lately recovered. It was very dicreetly aid of the Queen Argira, when he phraed his dieae, inchantment: for had he aid he had been mad, it might perhaps have ditracted him again.

In the mean time Adrates was o atonihed, to ee uch abundance of people about him, and epecially o many Nymphs and Cavaliers looking upon him and aying nere a word, as he knew not how to behave himelf: Afterwards looking upon his clothes and eeing himelf o ragged, not remembring any thing that was pat; Friend (aid he unto Palemon, who held him by the hand) what is the matter, and where am I? Adrates (anwered he and till held him by the arm) give thanks unto the gods for making you a man again this econd time. The poor hepherd holding up his hands, and turning towards the altar, he fell down upon his knees and did as Palemon advied him: o all the aembly eeing the gods accepted of their acrifice and prayers, they houted for joy, and ang hymns in praie of Jupiter and Minerva: In the mean time Palemon taking him aide into a by room in the Temple, he deired him to put on thoe clothes which he had prepared for him.

On the other ide, the high Priet accompanied with thoe who had viewed the victimes, and conidered the burning of the fire, told the Nymph that as they found by the intrels and burning of the fire, the tate was menaced with many troubles and great rebellions, the iue whereof was indeed like to be happy, if by her prudence he gave a timely prevention. Upon which information he held up her hands, and beeeched the gods to impoe no greater a burthen on her then he was able to utain, that they would pardon all the ins of the Nation, and not punih according to merit: After this he went towards the Catle with the Prince Godomar, and all the trangers, who could not enough admire the prudence of the Nymph, and the widome that appeared in all her actions.

In the mean time Polemas, who had his pies in every corner, was advertied of all the paages concerning this Ceremony, as well of the election of Prince Godomar, as the recovery of the two ditracted perons; and alo of Queen Argiras expreions of intereting her elf in the Protection of the Nymph, when he declared her elf to be a Queen: He was advertied alo of one Dorinde, a Lady that fled into Marcelles; but though he heard of the combate about her, upon the banks of Lignon, yet he knew not the caue: and when he was thinking eriouly upon thee things, he was advertied of ome Cavaliers, trangers, who deired to peak with him, and who came as they aid, from King Gondebaut. Polemas commanded they hould enter, and after a very honourable reception of them, the chief of them poke thus.

The King my mater Sir, who loves you as well as any neighbour he hath, has ent me to acquaint you that he hath great occaion to complain againt the Nymph Amais, who values his friendhip at o low a rate, as that he harbours within her Dominions, thoe who have mot traiterouly aainated Clorantes, the Captain of his Guard, who would have took out of their hands a woman which run away from the Princes Clotilda, after he had committed mot foul crimes, which are unfit to be publihed in repect of the Princes honour: And though the Prince Godomar, whom he diclaims for his on, be the chief of thoe againt whom he complains, yet he conceives the Nymph ought not to receive uch runagate ubjects of his without his conent: he hath ent me to make thee complaints unto you, and commanded me to tell you that he would gladly live in peace with his friends, and that offences committed againt their wills, hall not make any eparation betwixt him and them; and therefore if you think it expedient,
I will go unto Marcelles; and declare unto the Nymph how much the King my mater is offended; I will demand from her a retitution of Prince Godomar and Dorinde, or ele declare open war: And in tetimony that all I ay is true, here Sir, is a Letter from the King my Mater unto you. Upon this Polemas took the Letter: Cavalier, anwered he, I am very orry the Nymph has given any caue of dicontent unto that great King: If he would be ruled by my advice, no uch complaints hould ever be; but truly thee new Councellours go upon Maximes which are much contrary unto mine, and uch truly as I do not undertand; I pray god he do not repent of them when it is too late. Then opening the Letter which he found to be a Letter of Credence. The King (aid he unto the Cavalier) tells me I may believe whatoever you hall ay unto me from him, and therefore peak freely your mind, for there is no Prince upon the earth whom I take to be my mater but yours. The tranger, upon this, thanked for his favourable declaration, and beeeched that he might peak unto him in a place where there was fewer witnees. Polemas then taking him by the hand he carried him into a private cloet, and hut the door.

The tranger then began to peak, and told him of the Kings affection unto Dorinde (yet in as favourable a ene for his Mater as poibly he could) of the love of the Prince Sigimond unto the ame woman: of the Kings jut anger, when he heard that the Prince intended to marry her; of the Kings deign in marrying her unto Periander or Merindor, to divert that Prince: of the detention of that Prince: of the Kings command unto Clorantes to follow her: of Prince Godomars going out of Lyons with many Cavaliers: of Ardilans death, whom the Prince Godomar killed at the gate of the Town; and briefly, how Clorantes was killed with almot all his company, as he was in quet of Dorinde, whom he found in the habit of a Shepherdes upon the banks of Lignon. Now Sir (continued he) the King is informed that this Dorinde, and the Prince Godomar, are fled into Marcelles, and that the Nymph hath promied to protect them: How? to protect them, aid Polemas, hath he inveted the Prince Godomar with abolute Authority in all her Dominions? Yes Sir, replied the tranger, and hath thereby o diobliged the King; that he is fully determined to come himelf and fetch him out of Marcelles.

But that you may know how much you are obliged unto the King, he lets you know that this is the nick of time to put your generous deign into execution: for Clidamant is dead: How (aid Polemas) is Clidamant dead? why Sir (aid the tranger) did you not know that before? It is long ince the King ent you word of it, but I verily believe the Letter which imported it, was intercepted by the death of Clorantes: but be pleaed to know that dead he is, and Lindamor o wounded, that there is no hopes of his life, alo all thoe that were under his conduct are quandered and gone.

O heavens! (aid Polemas) this is news beyond my hopes: now Sir, (aid the tranger) the King to tetifie his affection unto you, will under colour of Prince Godomar and Dorinde, raie a great Army againt the Nymph, and will himelf in peron come and beiege Marcelles: he will invet you with the Soveraign Authority, make you Count of the Seguians, and content himelf that you hould only hold it of him, as Duke and Earl of the Burgundians, thinking your merits and affection unto him alwayes expreed, does deerve no les then his aitance upon this occaion.

The joyes and thanks of Polemas were great, and his promies and protetations were greater: but indeed his joyes were extream, for Clidemant and Lindamor were two great rubs unto him, the one to his ambition, and the other to his affection: and they being thus removed, gave him aured hopes in his deigne. He deired the tranger therefore, that he might impart this news unto four of his friends, whoe advice he ued in all affairs: and calling for Ligonias, Peledontes, Argonides, and Litander, he related the whole matter unto them, whereat they eemed o extremely tranported with joy, that they were hardly themelves. At lat, it was reolved upon that this Cavalier hould go unto the Nymph, and demand the Prince Godomar and Dorinde; and in cae he would not retore them, as
they verily believed he would not, then to declare war from the King of the Burgundians; and let he hould receive any harm either in going or coming Polemas hould appoint him a Convoy of ix Troops of Hore; So in this reolution they parted.

The ame night Climanthes came to Polemas, to relate unto him all that he had aid unto Leonide and Silvia: But Polemas having not o much patience as to hear out all his dicoure, he embraced him: Oh my dear friend (aid he unto him) I have other kind of news to impart unto you: Clidemant and Lindamore are dead with all their men, and the King of the Burgundians will come himelf and make me Count of the Seguians, contenting himelf that I hould only acknowledge him to be Lord Paramont, as Duke and Earl of the Burgundians. The death of Clidemant and Lindamore (anwered Climanthes very faintly) falls out very happily for our deign; but let me tell me, that in my opinion, o is not the coming of the Burgundian King; for Ambition is a montrous glutton, and is never atisfied: Now objects will move new appetites: There is not in all Gaul a more pleaant Province then this; Galathea is very fair, Gondebaut is of an amorous complexion; moreover, he has two ons who are not married; Thee Interviews are dangerous: for my part, I like of his ending aid, but not of his coming: Do you think that when he is once in Marcelles, and tryumphant, that he will then care for you? The Prize is yours already, Sir, ince Clidemant and Lindamore are dead, why then hould you let another hare with you? The enterprize may be done without him, who can reit you? Therefore Sir, if you will be ruled by me, let him not come, unles you have a mind to make your elf greater enemies then thoe you have lot. This was the opinion of the crafty Climanthes, with whom the four Confidents concurred, when they were call to Councely and thought it expedient by all means to hide their mitrut, and to find out ome handome excue for it: As that it was not honourable for o great a King to venture his peron for uch a trifle, no nor afe for his crown, it being to be feared, that in his abene his ons might raie commotions in the State.

After this coure was reolved upon, and the Cavalier had declared war in the name of the King his mater, it was then time to cour up their Arms, and make all preparations without delay: Climanthes advied, that they hould give him leave to go and peak with the Nymph Galathea; for (aid he) if fair means will bring your deires to pas, why hould you ruine a Country by war, which is to be your own? I conceive it expedient indeed to have all things in readines, and if any way take not effect, then within two days after to force thoe feeble walls, which I think will be eaily done upon the firt aault; for I cannot believe they are able to man them: beides, the party in the Town that is for us, does promie to open us a Port when we will: Polemas was very much againt the going of Climanthes unto Galathea, thinking it to be too dangerous for him; for (aid he) aure your elf that Adamas hath een the Letter which King Gondebaut ent unto me, and which was lot when Clorantes was killed; and you ee that they are more trict in their guard of their Town then they are wont to be; therefore I am in fear they know omthing of our deigne; and if they do, you run extream danger of ill treatment, which would be a mot extream grief to my oul. But Climanthes who thought himelf o ubtle that none could over-reach him; No, no Sir (anwered he) never trouble your elf for me, but aure your elf I hall be cunning enough for them all. Thee Nymphs cannot catch me, I warrant you, and had you een and heard them, as I did, you would let that be the leat of your fears: As for the Letters, I believe they may be intercepted; but though they be, they will not hurt us: If they do not know of the death of Clidemant and Lindamore, I will acquaint them; for it will ooner bring them to our deigne, eeing themelves deprived of uch upport: And if they did know of it, why did they not do me ome michief all this while ince Clorantes was lain?

Upon thee reaons, and ome others, they reolved to let him go; and if he failed, to fall upon the Town two days after. In order thereunto, Polemas commanded his four confidents to have all things in readines, as well Foot Forces, as Hore, epecially the Artillery, which was mot neceary for an aault of a Town,
and with which they would begin: Alo intelligence was given unto Meronthes, who was within the Town, that when they began to compas the Town about with their Army, he hould open unto them the Port that was towards Mount Brion, which, with his friends he might eaily do, becaue all the Townmen would be o taken up in reiting the Aault, as they would be all upon the walls.

They were all ready to eparate, and take everal orders for all things neceary, when Climanthes tayed them; What will you ay (aid he unto them) if I make you all maters of what you deire, without a blow? I will ay (anwered Polemas) that you are Climanthes, that is, the wiet and bet contriver of things of any man alive. Then (aid the Impotor) aure your elves that within thee three days I will make you poeors of what you wih. To day (aid he, and counted the days upon his fingers) King Gondebauts Cavalier it talking unto Amais; to morrow I will go and act my part, and the day after Galathea is infallibly yours: And thus it will be brought to pas. I have already told you how extreamly he deires to peak with me, to the end (as he ays) he may the better conform her elf unto the Will of that God which hall peak by my mouth: I know that whatoever I hall ay, will be mot exactly oberved; for I will threaten her with o many horrible punihments in cae of diobedience, that I dare lay my life he dares do no other; and my intention is to tell her, that at uch a time he hall not fail to be at Termes, where the four ways meet, which is not above a mile from the Garden door, and that he whom the Gods have ordained he hould marry, hall be the firt that hall pas by her in the habit of a Hunter; doubtles he will come without any company but Leonide and Silvia; and then, if you eem as if you rode that way to hunt, what will hinder you from taking that Fair Prize? When Galathea is in your hands, may you not marry her the next day? Is not your deigne then accomplihed, and the war ended in three days? I mut confes (aid Polemas) that if you can do as you ay, the work is done; for he being my wife, as I am fully reolved to marry her that very hour, then who can dipute with me for the Seignory of this State? And I promie you, if ever that happines come to pas, I will quickly abolih that foolih Law, which excludes males from the Soveraign Power.

But on the other ide, Leonide and Silvia were o pitifully affrighted, that they thought the Ghot of Ligdamon hunted them continually: Adamas hearing of it, went unto them, to put them out of thoe imple fears; but for all that they were till o affrighted, that as oft as Ligdamon was named, they trembled. This were a trange encounter (aid the Druide) if Leonide and Silvia hould turn mad, the ame day that Roilion and Adrates are cured. In the mean time, as they were talking of nothing but this Viion in the Catle, and many laughing at the Nymphs being o affrighted, a great noie was heard below in the Court, and looking out, they aw ome run one way, and ome another, and aying nothing but Ligdamon, Ligdamon. The Nymphs that were with Leonide and Silvia, and laughing at them, hearing that Ligdamon was there, they all fled away as fat as they could, ome ran to ave themelves in Galatheas chamber, and ome into the chamber of Amais: As the women were affrighted, o were ome of the men: and the Guard at the Catle Gates knowing Ligdamon, and eeing him to come towards them, whom they thought to be dead; they all ran away, and left the Gates open. Adamas eeing every one to run in this manner, was afraid left this panique fear hould be the umbrage of ome Treaon; and therefore going as fat as he could to the Gates, he found them open, and all the Guard fled, which did much atonih him: But eeing ome of his own men coming from the Town, he beckned unto them to make hate, to hut the Gates, and to guard them till the Souldiers returned.

And becaue he till heard the cry in the Catle, he went to ee what was the true caue of it. In the mean time Ligdamon who had caued all this terror and confuion, finding the Gates open, he entred, much wondering to ee every one fly from him, and cry out o pitifully. He knowing all the rooms in the Catle, being brought up in it from his Infancy, he went traight unto the chamber of the Nymph Amais; and becaue the Uhers of the Chamber had command to keep
the door hut, they did not only lock it, but alo blocked it up with chairs and tables, o as when Ligdamon came he found all fat, and not daring to be o bold as to knock, he waited until ome came out. The Nymph Amais, Galathea and others, being advertied that he was at the door of the Antichamber, they trembled for fear, and one who was the toutet amongt them, peeping through the key hole, and eeing it was he, they all fled away, crying it was he, it was he.

The noie continued o long, before any had the courage to go out, that Egides who had erved him a long while, and whom Silvia ever ince did keep with her, paing from the chamber of his Mitres unto that of the Nymph, and looking as the ret did, through the keyhole, he looked upon him: O good god (aid he) it is my dear Mater; and running preently out at another door, for they would not let him go out at that, he went unto him: ome of the affrighted wowomen would have hindred him, telling him his mater was dead: I know he is, anwered he, but no matter, I love his oul as well as his body, and am ure that nothing which is his will hurt me. In this reolution this faithful ervant ran to him, and kied his hand, with uch a flood of tears in his eyes, that he could not utter a word, but ah my dear mater: Ligdamon on the other ide embraced him with extream contentment, and when he could peak, Egides (aid he unto him) what is the reaon that every one thus flies from me? O Sir, anwered he, who can chue but be affrighted to ee you o unexpectedly, your death being publihed by me who aw you dead. Why then, aid Ligdamon, didt not thou hun me as well as the ret? I Sir, anwered he, why hould I hun you, that would mot willingly follow you in death, and doubtles had done o, but for diobeying that command which you impoed upon me with your dying breath: well (aid he) didt thou then deliver my Letter unto the fair Silvia? I did, anwered he, and more then that, I told her all that you commanded me, and related unto her the whole tory of your death.

The Nymphs all this while, who looked upon them through the key hole and heard them talk, they began to take heart. Adamas at the ame time came alo to the door of the antichamber, where finding Ligdamon, he was a little uprized, yet till a peron of judgement and reolution: Ligdamon (aid he unto him) I charge thee in the name of Tautates, that if thou beet a Ghot, to return unto thy eternal ret, and leave this place in quietnes: Sir (anwered Ligdamon and miled) I hould be glad to be a Ghot, to meet with that ret which yet I could never find: But know, that I am the very ame Ligdamon whom formerly you have een, and whom the great God hath raied from death to life, to hew, that as men come into the world by his appointment, o they cannot go out of it, until it be his pleaure: upon this Adamas embraced him with open arms, and was extremely joyed, for Ligdamons virtue got himelf the love of all.

At this great noie, the Prince Godomar, Alcedon, and many other Cavaliers, came to the Nymphs chamber door to ee what the matter was: The Nymph hearing that the Prince Godomar, Adamas, and Alcedon, and many others had poken with him, he took courage, and commanded the doors to be et open, but neither he nor Galathea would have uffered him to come near, if the Prince Godomar by one hand, and Adamas by the other, had not preented him unto them Is it poible Madam (aid Ligdamon, and humbly kneeled down) that I hould be here in this place taken for another, and not be known to be my elf? We in this countrey (aid Amais and commanded him to rie up) are o eldome ued to ee any raied from the dead, that we could not but wonder to ee Ligdamon have that priviledge; but thanks be to god, the man who brought us the news of your death proves a lyer, and if ever any lye was welcome unto us, it is this I would to God Madam (anwered he) that this life of mine, which is preferred, might be lot in doing you any ervice: yet be pleaed to know that Egides was no lyer when he told the fair Silvia I was dead for I commanded him o to do and knew him o faithful that he would not fail me; and yet (aid the Nymyh) thanks be to god, you are alive, how then could you aure her that you were dead, unles he were a lyer? Madam (replied Ligdamon) did I not fear I hould
be over tedious, I could tell you how. Well; replied he, I will leave you with Galathea, Silvia, and the ret of the Ladies; they have not o much buines upon them as I; pray tell them, and let them relate unto me at night. Upon this, the Nymph, Prince Godomar, Alcedon, and Adamas, went unto the Queen Argira: and in the mean time Ligdamon, after a thouand Carees from the Nymphs, he was conducted by Galathea unto Damon, who was almot well recovered, and began to walk up and down his chamber, and alo did paionately deire to ee him.

After all civil complements and alutations, Galathea deired him to tell the reaon why Egides did fally report his death unto Silvia. Madam, anwered he, I deire nothing more then to obey you, but I cannot poibly tell you the tory, before I ee her that is the caue of it. Why? replied Galathea, have you not yet een Silvia? upon this he commanded Leonide to bring her thither: I believe, anwered Leonide, it will be as great a difficulty, as it was this morning to drive the acred nails: Alas (aid Ligdamon) is it impoible to mollifie her obdurate heart, both living and dead? Do not complain (aid Galathea and miled) until you have een her: I am afraid Madam, replied he, that ight will make it wore, and not only hinder me from complaining, but from living. Love, replied the Nymph, does allow that peron to love, who is loved: O Madam, cryed out Ligdamon, that general does hold in any but in Silvia, for never was any more loved then he. Then, aid the Nymph, let it o continue: My affection, replied he, is no les then an eternity, and I have loved her in the cradle, and in the grave: all this is not enough, replied the Nymph, unles he knew as much: Is it poible Madam, replied Ligdamon, he can be ignorant of it? both my life and my death hath told her of it. Aure your elf, replied Galathea, that if you do love her well, and that he does perfectly know it, he will pay unto you that tribute which love does exact from all true lovers, provided till you perevere, and be not weary. As Ligdamon was ready to reply, Silvia came into the chamber with Leonide, and with uch a lively apect, as made it apparent that the return of this Cavalier was not dipleaing unto her, yet with o much modety, that he was as much admired for it as for her beauty: for every one had heard that he did extremely grieve and lament his los, and at that very time did eem ilently to igh: but now, when againt all her hopes he aw him returned, he eemed unto her as a peron only indifferent. When he came firt into the room, Ligdamon looked upon Galathea, as if he had begged leave to alute her in her preence.

The Nymph who undertood his looks, did ignifie unto him by her looks again, that he would have it o; o as he went immediately unto her, and falling down upon his knees, kied her hand: but he pulled back, as thinking it an incivility before the Nymph. No, no Silvia (aid Galathea) his return is extraordinary, and o ought your reception of him to be. Sylvia then eeing it was the Nymphs pleaure to have it o, he permitted Ligdamon to kis her hand, but not without a bluh, and retiring preently amongt her companions, did hardly give him time to expres the continuation of his ervice, and becaue he followed her, eeming very deirous of ome conference, he aid unto him in a low voice; if you be the ame Ligdamon you were wont to be, take another opportunity of peech with me, and before all this company ue the ame dicretion you were wont to do. Upon this hint, Ligdamon making an obedient legg, turned towards Galathea, but o tranported with joy, at the ight of that beauty which was o dear unto him, that he could hardly retire from him: which Damon conidering, I believe Madam (aid he unto Galathea) that Ligdamon thinks it a hard penance to atisfie your commands, before he has a little longer entertained this fair Nymph, and I perceive by his eyes that he would be dipenced with all: if o (anwered the Nymph) my curioity is too great; Madam, replied Ligdamon) I have no greater deire then to obey you in all things, only I beeech you be pleaed that I make as hort a relation as poibly I can, of uch things as you eem deirous to know: Then after a hort paue, he began thus.

div.head: The Sequell of the Hitory of LIGDAMON.
div.p: HE, Madam, who peaks that which is not true, is not alwaies a Lyar, if he thinks it truth which he peaks; for it is not a perfect lye, unles the Lyar knows he lies: If this qualification be neceary to make a Lyar, Egides was none when he reported my death, becaue he thought me o as well as my elf: I ay my elf; for indeed it was my full intention to die, but heaven would not permit it, to hew, that the Gods will have our lives abolutely in their own dipoe.

Silvia who all this while took particular notice of every word which Ligdamon poke, and every one cating their eyes upon her, not being able to endure it, he lipt amongt her companions, and as well as he could, got to the door, uneen by Galathea or Ligdamon, till he was jut entring into her chamber, where hutting the door after her, he reolved to tay uneen, until this dicoure was ended. In the mean while Ligdamon continued thus.

Since Egides has been o obervant of all my commands, I aure my elf Madam, he has related unto you, how I being a Prioner amongt the Neutrians, I was taken for a Cavalier named Lidias, whom certainly I did much reemble, ince his own Mother, and all the ret of his Kinred would not be perwaded but that I was he. This Lidias had killed in a Duel his enemy called Orontes, and was condemned for it to loe his life; and I being taken for him, mut uffer for his Crime; but the Gods o guided my Sword, that being put into a Den of Lions, I killed two of them, rather by chance then trength. At the ame time, he for whom Lidias had fought with Orontes, taking me (as all the ret did) for him whom I o much reembled, he came and demanded me for her husband: for it was a cutomary Law amongt all the Gauls, that any woman might take any condemned peron for her husband, and o ave him.

By vertue of this Law I was reprieved, and a few days after carried into the Temple to marry her. I mut confes Madam, that my prion, my entence of death, my combate with Lions, and all my misfortunes, were nothing o intollerable as this; and therefore when I came into the Temple, and eeing no way to avoid this unfortunate marriage, I reolved to live no longer. Not but that Amerina (that was her name whom I was to marry) was very fair, very wie, and no way deficient, but I could not violate that fidelity which I had vowed unto the fair Silvia, without thinking my elf worthy of death. Some few days before, I had provided a certain kind of wine, o mixed, as might be a draught of immediate death; I drunk a full glas of this mortal potion, and before I was aware, o did Amerina alo: by force of which, with a firm opinion that it was poyon, I fell down as dead, and preently after Amerina alo.

I believe Madam, that Egides might relate my fortune thus far, but certainly all afterwards was unknown unto him; for he went away immediately, as well to perform all my commands, as to be out of that place where he had received o ad a los. Now you mut know that this Amerina, and this Lideas, were of them of the bet Families amongt all the Neutrians, and exceedingly beloved and allied; o as the noie of this accident was preently pread through all Rothomagues, and the Temple was o full of people, that one could hardly tir in it: for it was an accident of uch admiration, as moved every one to come and ee us. They had laid us upon the ground one by another, and cat a cloth over our faces, whilt all about us wept, ome for love, ome for pity, and many for company. They were ready to carry us into a Vault, where the Ancetors of Amerina and Lideas were entombed, when a Phyitian came thruting through the croud, and addreed himelf unto one that tood by us: Friend (aid he in a loud voice) is this Lidies who lies under that cloth? The ame, anwered the man. By what accident did
he die? asked the Phyitian: Alas (anwered he) both he, and this woman who lies by him, did voluntarily poyon themelves. No, no (aid the Phyitian) they are not dead; let ome water and vinegar be fetched, and by the help of Tautates I hall recover them.

Many were ready to run for thee remedies; and when they were brought, the Phyitian rubbed our Temples with Vinegar, and put ome into our Noes, and afterwards threw water into our faces: This did awake us preently, as out of a deep leep, but o atonihed, that we knew not where we were: the candles about us (for it was grown night) and the admiration of all the people who came to ee us, that for half an hour together we till eemed to be out of our wits: At lat we were carried to our Lodgings, where we undertood from the Phyitian, that it was he from whom I had the potion; and becaue he feared I intended ome hurt, in lieu of poyon, he gave this Dormative, for which he was much commended by all that heard him: But though this compoition was not mortal, yet it made us very ill many days, and Anderina wore then I, being of a weaker contitution.

This icknes was a great contentment unto me; for it gave me time to think what I hould do. Amerinas kinred were all extreamly offended that I hould rather chue death, then living with their Coin; conceiving that this didain could proceed from no other caue but from an ill opinion which I had of Amerina; o as addreing themelves unto her, they asked her what occaion he had given me to hate her o extreamly? And told her, that our Qualities were equal, that he had given me my life, and that formerly I loved her o very paionately, as they could not imagine that this alteration in me, proceeded from ome fault which I had dicovered in her, and that it could be no les then the los of her honour, if it were o; and that if they came to know of it, let her expect no les then evere punihment for being a tain unto a Family o noble: They added many other menaces, unto which Amerina anwered rather with tears then words, yet excued her elf from all thoe imputations as well as he could, and aured her elf that her innocence would defend her againt all calumny; o as the next morning he came unto me, and acquainted me with all thee reproaches of her kinred: By fortune, my thoughts were at that time upon Silvia, and grieving at her abene, I poke o loud, that when he came to the door, he heard me complain of my abene from her, and name Silvia everal times.
