Amerina had o much patience as to hearken, and durt hardly breath, for fear of being perceived, o deirous was he to know the caue of that alteration which he thought to be in me: And when he heard me lament the abene of a Lady, and name Silvia, he preently conceived that ome new affection had blated mine unto her; and being more offended at this, then at all the reproaches of her kinred, he violently puhed open the door, and entred into the chamber o troubled, that he could hardly bid me good morrow; and yet civility, rather then any good will, invited her unto it, and to reply thus, never taying for the return of her alute: Why (aid he) hould I alute a peron, who is the caue of o much adnes to my oul? Cruel Lidias, if there be any park of that name remaining in me, as when thou didt once love me; Is it poible thy incontant humour hould thus eparate thee from me, as to deprive thee both of judgement and reaon? Hat thou thus forgot all thy oaths and vows of fidelity: Dot thou not conider how thou art obliged unto me for thy life? Can thy new taken-up affection unto Silvia thus blind thy eyes? But tell me, mot inenible mad man, (for that's the name bet uits with thy nature) why houldt thou not marry me, ince thou cant not live without me? Mut I refer thee again to the claws of Lyons, from whence I have once recued thee? Dot think thy valour can keep thee always alive? Oh Lidias, didt thou know how many there are, and how fierce and cruel, the very thought would make thee tremble, they will pull thee in a thouand pieces, thy heart and thy intrals will be viewed by all the pectators: oh Lidias! What a mot horrid and gatly ight will this be? and how impoible is it to avoid it? Cant thou think fortune will alwaies fight for thee? Oh Lidias Do not deceive thy elf: Conider that he is a woman, and that thou wert always
wont to ay that incontancy is a quality ineparably incident unto our ex, and though he be a goddes, yet is he ubject unto that imperfection: Alas Lidias, dot thou not know that as a goddes, he is jut; and ince o, he will mot infallibly punih thy injutice: O heaven defend my dearet Lidias from uch misfortunes, at leat to favour me o far as to take me firt out of the world, that I may never ee it: upon thee words, he broke into a flood of tears, and with much ado uttered thee words: However, cruel man, though thou wilt not take me to be thy wife, yet eem as if thou didt to ave thy life, afterwards do with me what thou wilt: have ome pity upon thy own elf, and aure thy elf thy approaching torment does more trouble me then does thy corn, and I hall endure that better then thy death. She uttered thee words with o many ighs and tears, that I undertood her better by her meaning then by them. At lat, when he was ilent, I anwered her; Fair, and mitaken Amerina, aid I, all thoe horrid torments, of which you have poken, can never make me break that faith which I have promied: I will not now mention that gros errour wherein you are, for I ee it is to no purpoe; I have aid o much already, that if you will not give credit unto it, I cannot hope that any thing I hall ay will undeceive you; but that you may not entertain any opinion, that it is either any corn of you, or any change of will in me: Let me tell you, that all thee horrid torments you peak of are welcome unto me, o I may by them be rid out of that miery wherein I am, and o I may render unto Silvia my faith, pure and without a tain; it is not any fears that makes me peak thus, but only my deire to ee you unmitaken: I have already told you, that I am not Lidias: to my knowledge I never aw him; I aure you my name is Ligdamon, and am a Seguian: Therefore fair Amerina, if you do love me, go with me into that countrey, the journey will not be long, in fifteen dayes we hall eaily go it; and I protet unto you by all the gods of heaven and earth, that if when you are there you do not plainly find that I am not Lidias, as you think me, I will not only become your husband but your lave: for uch is the virtue and beauty of Amerina, that if I were not already engaged in affection unto Silvia, whom I will hew you, and whom I have loved from my very infancy, why hould not I eteem and embrace her alliance and good will?

Amerina hearing me ay o, cruel man, (aid he unto me, and fixed her eyes upon me) wilt thou inviolably oberve this protetation? or dot thou only make it to deceive me by fair promies? Fair Amerina, anwered I, had I any intention to deceive you by words, I hould never have been o free of them as I have been; but hould have let you go on in your errour, and afterwards have left you; but rather then I would be guilty of any uch unworthy bae action, you ee I will firt chue poion; and therefore you cannot think me any deceiver or abuer. I know, wie Amerina, that there is a great God in heaven, who ees all our mot ecret thoughts, before we can conceive them: I know alo, that this God is mot omnipotent and jut, and will punih every one according to their merits: I am ure of all thee as that I live; now Amerina, it is this great and jut God, whom I pray unto to cover me with eternal torments, if I do not marry you when we are in Forrets, in cae you do not mot plainly and apparently ee that I am not Lidias. Upon this olemn protetation, aid Amerina, I will follow you, not only into Forret, but whereoever you will, being mot confident to find you no other but my dearet Lidias, and that you will take me for your wife according to your promie.

Several other promies and vows did econd the firt, after which we conulted of the means how to take our journey ecretly. She thought it mot expedient, that I hould colourably take her for my wife, and to live a while with her as if I were really her husband, to the end her kindred might be atisfied, and not torment us o extremely. I conented thereunto, yet with this reervation, that I hould not be any way obliged unto marriage, but upon the former proteted conditions: for I knew there was no other way to be free from all troubles.

Thus we parted upon this reolution, and preently after, her kindred and
thoe of Lidias, being told by Amerina, that I was reolved to live with her according to her deires, they all came to viit me, and rejoice at the good reolution I had taken. I received their viits with as good a countenance as I could, and excued all former paages, upon pretence of a vow which I had made, which now being abolved from, I was ready to embrace that favour which Amarina and they hewed unto me: Thee excues were taken in a better ene then ere they were meant, and gave us thoe opportunities which we deired: So as a few dayes after, eeming as if we would walk unto a houe of Amerinas, not far from Rothomaques, we made all the hat we could into the countreys conquered by the Franks: and though I paionately deired to ee Prince Clidemant and Lindamor, yet I could not becaue Amerina would not give me leave, earnetly deiring to finih that voyage which we undertook, and reolving, as he aid, that if he found me any other then Lidias, to enter her elf amongt the Virgin Druides, not daring to return back unto her kindred.
We paed o near Paris as to hear of the Franks victory, epecially of the taking Callis, whereat he much grieved, as he was a Neutrian, uch a natural affection has every one unto their native countrey.

But Madam, be pleaed to hear of a new diater, which to my orrow befell us. About the hight of the day, when the un was extremely hot, Amerina not ued to travel grew very weary: o finding a handome hade by the way ide, he deired me to let her ret: I, who did very much honour and eteem this Lady, did lay ome of my clothes under her, left itting upon the ground might caue her to catch a cold, and haded her as well as I could with boughs, from the cortching heat of the un; and went a little ditance from her, to get ome more freh branches. I was no ooner gone ome twenty paces from her, but a young Cavalier lighted from his hore, near the place where Amarina was, with intention to ret there until the day was a little cooler: he tyed his hore unto a tree, and o as he might grae, but not without great need, for he looked to be o lank and faint, that one might eaily judge his mater had rid him a long journey. In the mean time I returned unto Amerina, and never minding this young man, brought thoe branches which I had gotten, and went to get ome more: he in the mean time, after he had tied his hore and looked about him, he pied Amerina, towards whom he went, and with a handome becoming civility, asked her if it would not be too great a trouble unto her, if he enjoyed part of that hade where he was. Amerina knew by his tone that he was a tranger, and finding much modety in his looks and garb, he offered him the conveniency of the place.

He was no ooner et upon the tump of an old tree, but I returned, and I perceived, that as oon as he cat his eye upon me, he changed colour, and was o amazed, that he knew not what to do, but lunk away: but hearing him peak unto Amerina, I knew by his tongue he was neither Frank nor Gaul, and thought that he had an opinion, I would dilike his intruion o near Amerina; o as minding him no more, I talked unto Amerina, and asked her how he did, and whither he deired to leep. Yes (aid he) I would willingly leep, did I not fear ome Serpents and Gnats would ting me: Never fear, aid I, for I will not tir from you, but keep a vigilant eye that no uch things hall hurt you. Then aid he, you hall be my Guardian o I made her a pillow of ome of my clothes, and covered her face with my handkerchief, then et my elf down by her. Mean time, the young man was got a good ditance off: I took notice that he pulled his hat over his eyes, tamped upon the ground with his foot, croed his arms, looked up towards heaven, and often cat his eye upon me; then would he bite his fingers, lay his hand upon his word, walk two or three paces towards us, and turn back upon a udden, uing uch raptive getures, as I thought him either mad, or ele had ome quetions of quarrelling importance to ask me: yet I eemed to take no notice, but kept my elf cloe and oberved what he did.

At lat, when he aw Amarina aleep, he came towards me, and when he perceived me to look upon him, he beckned unto me: I roe up as gently as I could,
and coming to him, asked him what he would have with me; but he without returning any anwer, looked earnetly upon me, and going back again, made a igne with his hand that I hould follow him; which I told him I would, but would not go far from that Lady: he looking upon me with eyes of fire, Does that Lady (aid he) hinder thee from retoring that which thou owet unto me, thou wicked and perfideous man? Am I (aid I in amazement) o wicked and perfideous unto you? Stranger, thou art either out of thy wits, or ele art weary of thy life. Life indeed (anwered he) is nothing pleaing unto me, but much more then thy ingratitude and unworthines: Upon this he recoyled two or three paces, and drew his word: Then coming towards me, This life (aid he) which Melander could not loe in twice aving thine, thy word, and thy ingratitude hall ravih from me. Upon that, without taying for any anwer, he fell inconiderately upon me, and I only tanding upon my Guard, he hit his right arm upon the point of my word, and received a wound o deep, that his word fell out of his hand; and preently after his heart failing him, he fell down, aying, Well Lidias, now I thank thee, ince not being ab • e to live without thee, thou art pleaed to give me my death.

Upon thee words Amerina waked, and eeing our words drawn, he ran unto us; but eeing him upon the ground, and in a woon, thinking him dead, friend (aid he unto me) let us make all the hate we can from hence, let if any hould come in, we hould fall into the hands of Jutice. Indeed (aid I unto her) I am unwilling to leave this young man thus; for I cannot think it poible he hould die upon o light a wound. If he be not dead (replyed he) o much the better, ome will come and do him that charitable office which he hould receive from us, but however, it is widom to ecure our elves: Upon this taking me by the hand, he carried me away, and paing by the place where he reted, he took my clothes, and gave them unto me with all poible hate.
Oberve Madam, how affection will omtimes foreee a danger unto the peron loved, as if we had a knowledge of future things.

I oberved that Amerina from time to time looked back unto the place from whence we came; and after a two hours walk, when we were almot cloe to the Town of Neomagues, one of the prime Cities of the Ambarres, ix Souldiers upon full gallop overtook us, and carried us away prioners: where Amerinas wit appeared to be mot admirable; for undreing her elf with all poible hate, he contrained me to change clothes with her: for (aid he) if the man be not dead, when he ees me, doubtles he will ay that it was not I who wounded him, and o we hall be releaed. Now o it chanced, that a while after we had left this tranger, the Governour of that Province paed by the Place where this Duel was fought, and asking ome Shepherds which aw the paage, who it was that committed this murder, he undertood that it was two perons who went towards Neomagues, and on foot: The Governour being deirous to do Jutice, dipatched ix of his Guard to eize upon us, as they did; and in the mean time, caued the Corps to be carried away, with intention to bury it: but being only in a woon, as oon as they began to undres him, he revived; o as they bound up his wound, and et him upon his own hore, with one to hold him, left he hould faint again, and fall.

He was no ooner upon Horeback, but eeing a young man riding fat upon the way, oh (aid the young tranger) yonder's the man who did me the wrong. Some that heard thee words, acquainted the Governour, yet not o oon, but the young man, who had a very good hore, and rid very fat, was got a good ditance off; o as do what they could, they could not eize upon him, till he was entred the Town: but enquiring at the Gates where he lodged, he was no ooner alighted, but they took him, and brought him to the prion where we were, yet into another chamber; and we were advertied of it by the Goaler, at night when he brought us our meat: But I mut needs confes, I was never in all my life more grieved, then when I aw them fetter with Irons the feet and hands of the fair Amerina, epecially when I conidered that it was for my ake he uffered: yet he took them with incomparable courage, and cat uch an eye upon me, as intimated
that all chains and fetters for my ake were welcome unto her: But indeed, when he aw that they intended to eparate us, he began to be omthing troubled, as well becaue it grieved her to be abent from me, as becaue he was to tay alone in that place; which made me ue all poible endeavours to prevent it: I ued all my Rhethorique and Prayers that we might keep together, for we aid that we were man and wife: but the man was no more moved with any prayers, or tears, then if he had been a Rock: I offered him to put as many fetters upon my hands and feet as he pleaed, I kneeled unto him, held up my hands, would have kied his feet, but all would not do any good: At lat, remembring that gifts will omtimes trike a thunderbolt out of the hand of Jupiter, I took a very fair Diamond from off my finger, and preented it unto him, beeeching him to take that in part of what we intended to do for him: He took this tetimony of our good will very willingly; and I preently perceived, that the luter of the tone did begin to mollifie his obdurate temper: And after he had looked well upon it, I perceive (aid he) that you deerve to have ome favour hewed unto you; I pity your condition, and am orry your affections to each other hould be eparated; but though I have command to ever you, yet I will not this night: yet do not think it is becaue of this ring which you have given me, but becaue I know by your faces that you are not guilty of this crime whereof you are accued; for we can tell at the very firt fight who are criminal, and can read their faults in their very eyes. After this he went away, and preently ent us a good Feather-bed, and good Bed-clothes, with o many kind expreions, as we could not chue but admire, that a heart which was as hard as any tone, hould be oftned o uddenly by gifts. After the door was hut, and I think a hundred locks upon it, Amerina after a deep igh, Friend (aid he unto me, for I lay upon a Matteras a little dis;tant from her,) are you yet aleep? No (anwered I) will you command me any ervice? The ervice I would command (aid he) is, that to morrow you petend to go and olicite for my enlargement, and when you are out, then to make an ecape, and tell me the place where I hall find you. But (replyed I) would you have me leave you alone in this condition? Friend (aid he) the condition wherein I am, would be pleaing unto me, were it not for my fears of you; and thee chains and fetters, ince for your ake, would be more weet and welcome to me, were I certain of your afety: in lieu of hating them, I would kis them a thouand them, ince by them I can tetifie the extream affection which I bear unto you. But tell me, dear friend, when you are gone from hence, will you ever think upon Amerina? Will it not come into your thoughts that Silvia cannot love you o well as I? Oh how great would be my felicity if it hould? But Friend, I will not oblige you unto o much; only promie me, that in the midt of all your contentments, you will give me leave to love you, and that you will not call my affection troubleome, nor be weary of it: Upon this condition go, and enjoy the felicities of that happy Silvia; and tell her amidt all the kind embraces which you receive from her, that it was poor Amerina which preerved Lidias for her.

She would have talked more, if tears and ighs would have uffered her; which moved me to o much compaion, that to comfort her, I went nearer unto her; as well to oblige her by it, as to avoid being heard by any, having heard, that omtimes walls have ears. Firt I fell upon my knees by her Bed-ide, and taking her hand, which I found fettered, I offered to kis it; but he pulling it back, caued me to it down by her, and then I aid unto her.

Thee tetimonies of that affection which you have unto Lidias, and for whoe ake I receive o many favours, do oblige me o far, fair Amerina, that I will wear I hall never enjoy any perfect contentment, until I ee you undeceived, and convinced of that errour wherein you are. Oh mot cruel man! aid he, yet harping upon that fale tring, which jars o extreamly in my ears? I mot then at one blow cut off all your impertinent excues: Upon this, raiing up her elf in her Bed; I conjure you (aid he) in the name of truth to tell me, who was it that recued you out of the claws of Lyons? Who av'd your life upon condition of Marriage? To whom did I give my peron and all my etate? For whom have I
left all my kindred and friends? Tell me who it is I have followed through all thee trange Countreys, not valuing my reputation nor any thing ele. Tell me (I ay) for whom do you think I uffer thee Irons upon my hands and feet, and am ready to endure all the torments that mortals can devie? I mut needs confes (aid I unto her) that it is I who am obliged unto you for all thee. Then (replied he preently) if it be you who is obliged unto me for your life, and all thee tetimonies of my affection, whoever you are, you are the mot ungrateful man that ever breathed, if you do not render me amity for amity, and love for love. I do not exact this from you as Lidias, nor bid Lidias love Amerina: But I ay, friend whomoever you are, love her who loves you, and her to whom you are more obliged, then ever any man was unto any woman.

Thee words did a little urprize me, and was the caue why I paued a while without returning any anwer, and gave her occaion to continue on: O mot ungrateful heart (aid he) O the mot inenible oul that ever was? what cant thou do more to make me die? why dot thou not open my bret, and pull out that heart which loves thee too well? perhaps you think it has not uffered enough yet, for the fault which it hath committed: I beleive he had not o oon ceaed her reproaches, though ighs and tears made her cut her words in the midt, if I had not beeeched her to hear me, and give a little truce to her paion.

What cant thou ay unto me inenible man? replied he, dot think I know not what anwers thou wilt make? Amerina (wilt thou ay) were I not already Silvias, and given my elf and my faith unto her, I hould endeavour to atisfie all my obligations unto you; but I am already tied up by the Laws of fidelity, and I were a mot unworthy man, if I hould offer to break them: This is the anwer I expect from you, but O thou unthankful peron, dot think to pay thy debts thu • ? Cant thou believe uch coyn as this will content Amerina? No, no, ungrateful wretch: I ummon thee before the throne of Jutice, and ask whether uch obligations as thee ought to be cancelled, upon uch hallow and unreaonable pretences. For pray thee tell me, has this Silvia, whom thou thus preferret before me, obliged thee with tronger chains then I have? Did he ever ave thy life? has he wholly given her elf unto thee? Did he ever follow thee through trange Countreys? Was he ever in prion for thy ake? Did he ever etter her hands and feet with Irons to et thee at liberty: if ever he hewed uch tetimonies of her affection, then I am ilent, and mut only complain againt my ill Fortune, which would not let me be the firt of thy obligers; but if he never did, then I mut ay, and ay again, with abundance of reaon and truth, that thou art the mot ungrateful, mot unjut, and mot inenible peron that ever lived.

At lat, I interrupted her in this manner: It is mot true, fair Amerina, that I could alledge all thoe arguments you have intanced, and were we before any unintereted, impartial Judge, perhaps thoe reaons would not be contemptible. But now I will not urge it o far, knowing as well as you can tell me, that never any was more obliged then I unto you: This I only mut ay, that if hitherto you do not know, how I reent the favours you have done me, it is becaue you never asked me, but only asked one Lidias, whom I protet before heaven and all the gods, I never aw to my knowledge: But now, ince you addres your elf unto me, and require of me peronally, a atisfaction, and acknowledgment, of all thoe obligations, wherein I tand bound unto you, I mut needs confes my elf infinitly to blame, if I did not give you all the atisfaction I am able. 'Tis certainly true, that he who is forward to borrow, unles he intend to convert his friend into an enemy, mut be as forward to pay: And it is as certainly true, fair Amerina, that I am as much obliged unto you, as any man can poibly be: and I do not now deny the debt, but only require a little time, to give ample atisfaction: in the mean time, as part of payment, I beeech you accept of my good will, with this aurance, that I can never pay all I ow you, but am as willing as you can deire: Ah Ligdamon (aid he) and now no more Lidias, ince you will have it o, what unpeakable contentment would thee words be unto me. if I could think them real? O fair Amerina, replied I preently, if you love me,
loe that of opinion of me, had I a mind to be a lyar, I could eaily have prevented all thoe reproaches, which you were pleaed to put upon me, for I could eaily haue promied all you demand, without any olicitation from you. But commonly thoe that are forward to promie are backward to perform: ince for the preent, I mut be contented with your good will (replied he with a more atisfied tone) and ince you promie to give full atisfaction, as oon as you can, tell me friend, what do you mean by thee words good will? To which I anwered, fair Amerina, that good will which I mean, and which I beeech you to accept, is a mot real deire to do you all manner of ervice, with an aurance that I do honour and eteem you. And why (aid he and interrupted) do you not ay, and love me; and love you alo (added I) ince you are pleas'd I hould ue the word; and love you with as incere and perfect affection, as your honour and my faith will at preent permit. To be brief, I am fully reolved to imploy that life which you have given me, in giving you all the contentment you deire, and never to think my elf atisfied and contended, until you be. Will you promie me (aid he) to oberve all thee conditions mot religiouly? I wear it (aid I unto her) by all that's acred: and may all the cures of heaven and earth fall upon me, if I be forworn. Then (aid he) give me your hand: I wear alo to receive your promies, and declare, that until uch time as you can give full atisfaction, I will be contented, and think my elf well paid for what I have done: Nay more, I will for ever love you, and upon all occaions whatoever, oblige you more for the future then I have for the time pat.

Thus was the mind of Amerina calmed, which was no mall advantage to me, for I believe if I had left her in that rage, he might perhaps, out of pite, have dicovered all that had paed, and o have ruin'd me and her elf too. But on the contrary, after all thee conditions, he was urgent with me to be gone the next morning, and that I hould tay for her in the firt Town of the Seguian Countrey. I urged my orrows to leave her in that condition, but he told me that as for her, he could not be in any great danger, for come the wort that could, he could ay that I was her husband, and to help me away, he lent me her clothes: That beides, there was another tranger already accued, and that when the firt tranger aw her, he would know he was not the ame that wounded him: That he was not the firt wife who helped her husband to ecape in her clothes.

To be brief, he perwaded o, that I reolved to be gone in the morning: So as in order thereunto, when the Goaler came to viit us, I told him that I had a great deire to provide ome good meat for my husband, alo deired him to dine with us, and therefore prayed him to let me go into the market to buy it. He who was already well prepared with the diamond that I gave him, and hoped for more, you may go, aid he, whether you pleae; for it is not you that is accued for wounding the man, but it is your husband, and I have no warrant to keep you prioner, but him only, o as the door hall be open unto you when you pleae: I thanked him for his courtey, and promied acknowledgment. I went then unto Amerina, and under a pretence of asking her what he would have to dinner, I told her that I would tay at a private place upon the high way, called Pacodiere, near a Seguian Town called Croet: that in the midt of that Town there is erected a pillar which divides four wayes: that upon this pillar he hould find the firt letter of my name, and the place where I lodged: And preently, without any ceremonious taking of leave, I went away; but I mut confes, not without tears in my eyes. The Goaler opened the doores, and told me where I might buy any thing I deired, o as I left him in expectation of a good dinner.

I was no ooner at liberty, but leaving the way of Gergovia, I went towards Deires, up the river Loyre; and though I was in womans habit, yet I was o deirous to ee my native Countrey, and o fearful to be taken in the Dominions of of the King of Ambaries and Boyers, that the fourth day I came to Pacodiere. There I tayed ten dayes, in which time I changed my habit, and hearing no news of Amerina all that while, I deired the good woman of the houe where I lodged,
who entertained me very kindly, to watch when Amerina paed by, and to give her thoe clothes which I wore; and alo to tell her, that uch urgent buines befel me, as I was forced to go unto the great City of Marcelles. And indeed Madam, the reaon why I tayed there no longer, was, a Report pread up and down all the Country of an enuing War, and I did ee that ome lited Souldiers ecretly about Surcea, o as I thought it my duty to preent my elf unto you Madam, upon this occaion, and employ my life in your ervice, as I was obliged.

Thus did Ligdamon relate his fortune, whilt the Nymph Amais Prince Godomar, Adamas, and Alcidon, went unto the Queen Argira, who deired to peak with the Nymph and the Prince, before he reolved upon her journey. She told them, that for the favour which he had received from the Gods in the retitution of her Son to his enes, he could never be thankful enough unto them, and all thoe that were intrumental in it: But he was afraid left Roilions malady being only a wounded imagination, he hould return into it again: And therefore (aid he) I thought good to tell him, that it was caued by Inchantment, and that Prince Godomar di-enchanted him; for he did no more remember any thing that was pat ince his ditraction, then a childe in the cradle: I thought it therefore expedient, as well upon this conideration, as for the preervation of his Reputation, not to let him be known here, but to carry him away ecretly, as he came.

Adamas then upon the Nymphs command, repreented unto her the contentment which Prince Godomar and he received at that atisfaction which he found in her journey: That it was very prudently conidered of her, to carry away the Prince Roilion: But before her departure, it was neceary for the obervation of that olemn Vow which he had publiquely made, that he knew the danger wherein that State was, which he had worn to preerve and defend. Upon this he acquainted her with the enterprie of Polemas, with his correpondencies with his Neighbour Princes, epecially with the Burgundian King; with the aitance that King had promied unto him; with his pretended offence againt Prince Godomar and Dorinde; with the death of Prince Clidemant, with the abence of Lindamore and his Forces: Briefly, the Druide omitted nothing that was neceary to be imparted unto her: o as Madam (concluded he) if you do not ait the Nymph, as you have voluntarily obliged your elf by olemn vow, I know not what will become of her.

The Queen then who gave a very attentive ear unto all this, turning towards the Nymph, I am very glad Madam (aid he unto her) to know all that this great Druide hath related unto me, that I may tetifie unto the Gods and you, how I can keep my promie: It eems to be the will of heaven my on hould receive this favour from this place purpoely to interet him and me alo in your affairs. I aure you, that if you will give me but a moneths time, I will bring o many fighting armed men into the field, as though the King of the Burgundians be a great Prince, yet he hall not be able to hurt you.

Whilt the Nymph was returning thanks, and the Queen confirming her promie of preent aid, one came and acquainted the Queen Argira, that a Boyen Cavalier was come unto her from King Policander. As oon as the Queen aw him; what News (aid he unto him) do you bring me from the King? Not good (anwered he) but Madam, he does paionately deire to ee you. Upon this he preented King Policanders Letter unto her. The Queen took it with a troubled hand, and with extream inquietude broke open the Seal; he read it, and then with tears in her eyes hewed it unto the Nymph, who read thee words.

body.head: King POLICANDERS Letter unto the Queen ARGIRA.
body.p: DEath is a thing o natural and common, that it never troubles me; but to die before I ee you, does extreamly perplex my oul: becaue I would gladly dicharge my elf of that Debt and Duty which I owe unto you. Come therefore, Madam, with as much hate as poibly you can, if you deire my Soul hould depart contentedly in giving you atisfaction. This Bearer will acquaint you with the condition wherein he left me.

div.p: Oh Heavens! cryed out the Queen, great joys are commonly followed with great orrows. Then addreing her elf to the Cavalier, he enquired of the Kings icknes, & what the Phyitians thought of him: She undertood that they thought him in great danger of his life, and that he mut make hate, if he came time enough to ee him alive.

The Princes (whoe courage was equal to her quality) mutering together all her vertues and generoity, after the effuion of ome tears, he reolved upon a coure worthy of her elf; and addreing her elf unto the Nymph, Madam (aid he unto her) you ee I am contrained to depart for the good of my children, and happines of all the remainder of my life: But I promie to arm in your defence, not only the Boyens, Ambarres, and Lemovices, but all the Picts, the Santons, and the Bituriges: Nay more, either my Allies and Confederates hall fail me, or the Armorique Cities, and other Kings, my Confederates, hall do the ame. If King Policander be not able to come in peron, my two children hall, who dare not refue, when they ee me come my elf. In aurance of what I ay, I will leave Roanira with you, who I beeech you may keep Galathea company till I return: This pawn hall remain with you, not only to put me in mind of my promie, but to invite Celiodantes as her Brother, and Roilion as her Lover, to come and relieve her.

Upon this, retiring her elf, he took order for her departure, acquainted Roilion with Policanders icknes, and how neceary it was to make all poible hate; that therefore he was contrained to leave Roanira in the hands of the Nymph, with almot all her women, and that they would very hortly return unto her again, but for the preent, there was a neceity of leaving her for a time, upon ome reaons which he would impart unto him by the way.
Roanira would gladly have followed the Queen Argira; but he was the better contented to tay with the Nymph, by reaon of the great League of Amity already contracted betwixt her and Galathea.

All things being ready, the Queen Argira departed with Roilion, and carried with her only five and twenty Souldiers, leaving the ret with the Princes Roanira, with a charge to obey the Nymph, and the Prince Godomar, in whatoever they hould command.

She was no ooner out of ight of Marcelles, but the Guards upon the top of the Tower, epied ome Horemen, whom they thought to be armed, becaue the Sun hining upon their Armes, did make a great glitering. The Prince Godomar was preently acquainted, and Adamas alo; who gave orders unto the Guards at the Port, to have their Hore in readines. A while after they dicovered them to be ix Troops of Hore, who accompanied ome perons that were unarmed. When they came near the Town, they tayed, and thoe who were unarmed, who were to the number of twenty, advanced, and told the Guard at the Gate, that there was Alerantes, an Envoy whom the Burgundian King had ent unto the
Nymph Amais. As oon as he was acquainted with it, by the counel of the Prince, Adamas, Alcidon, and Damon, he ent thoe Hore which the Queen Argira left, to receive him: and being brought into her preence, he would not hear him until Prince Godomar was preent alo: and becaue Alerantes was unwilling to peak before him: Then (aid he unto him) I dare not hear you without his permiion, becaue I have transferred all the Soveraign power into his hands. Since Madam you will have it o (aid he) I mut according to the commands of my Soveraign Lord tell you, that conidering the good correpondency which hath always been betwixt you, he complains exceedingly againt you; that you hould not only receive into your protection a woman called Dorinde, who mot ignominiouly ran away out of the houe of the Princes Clotilda, his Neece, but alo have protected all thoe that murdered Clorintes the Captain of his Guard, particularly the Prince Godomar, who he now diclaims for his on, and takes for his mot cruel enemy. And becaue Madam, perhaps you do not know how much he is dipleaed at your harbouring of uch as are his enemies, he lets you know by me, and ummons you to deliver into his hands Dorinde, as the hame of his houe, and Prince Godomar, as the Ring-leader of Rebels: In o doing, he offers you all amity and aitance; if otherwie, you mut expect the fury of his Arms.

The Nymph not at all daunted, he addreed her elf unto the Prince, Sir (aid he) It belongs unto you to give an anwer. Though Madam (anwered he) it was your pleaure to confer all authority upon me, and o conequently it belongs unto me to anwer, yet I beeech you to return uch a one, as you hall pleae; and believe, this word hall maintain whatever you hall ay.

Amais upon this turned towards Alerantes; Cavalier (aid he) I cannot believe that a King o wie as Gondebaut, would ever give you any commiion to peak o unworthily of o great a Prince as his own Son, nor of o wie and well born a woman as Dorinde; and therefore without expectance of any anwer from me, get out of my Dominions as oon as you can, or otherwie you hall find uch entertainment as your arrogance deerves.

Madam (anwered he) I came not without my Commiion, and here are Letters of Credence written unto you by the Kings own hand. The Nymph took them, and preented them unto the Prince: who reading them, aured her they were written by the Burgundian King. Then (aid the Nymph) I hall talk with you after another fahion: Tell therefore unto King Gondebaut, that as for Dorinde, my Dominions hall be always free unto any that are oppreed: And as for Prince Godomar, it is not he that is in my Dominions, but I that am in his, he being the abolute Lord of all the Seguians, and of all Forrets. As for the war which he threatens upon me, tell him, that it is men indeed who begins wars, but it is the Gods only who gives victories, and in that confidence I fear not the injutice of his Arms.

Thus poke the Nymph, and all that heard her applauded her courage: when Godomar aw he had no more to ay; for my part (aid he) tell the King, that though he di-own me for his Son, yet I will never do any act that hall be unworthy of the Name; and to tetifie the truth of what I ay, tell him, that as long as this word will lat, I will defend the honour of uch Ladies as are unjutly oppreed, and maliciouly apered.

As for Dorinde, whom I take into my protection, I will defend her with my word in my hand, againt any that will offer to wrong her: And if there be any that carries the Title of Cavalier, who will peak any ill of her, or maintain the words which you have poke againt her, or againt us, who have delivered her out of the hands of thoe who would injuriouly have carried her away, here is a pawn (aid he, and gave him his Glove) which imports a challenge; I except againt none but the King my Father; knowing very well, that Prince Sigimond my brother, will arm himelf with me in the ame quarrel, if Paternal authority do not oppres him.

As for war, which he threatens upon this great Nymph; tell him, I beeech one thing from him, which is, that he will not come himelf, unles he have a mind to ee his Army back'd in pieces before his face: but if he have a mind to
be rid of any bad ervants, he may end them hither, and we hall quickly dicharge him of them.

Alerantes turning towards the Nymph, Madam (aid he) Is this all the atifaction I mut carry unto the King my Mater? If King Gondebaut (anwered he) be not contented with thee anwers, tell him, he could expect no other from uch as he would oppres, and who yet fears not the violence of his unjut Arms wherewith he threatens a woman. I would not willingly (anwered Alerantes) make this declaration; but ince you do o little eteem the grandeur of the King, my Lord, and o much light the clemency which he offers, I mut let you know from him, that he is your mortal enemy; that he does defie you, and all that adhere unto you; that he declares the Seguians, and all Forrets, to be an enemies Country, and therefore liable to the plunder and inevitable fury of his Army. As he poke thee words, he broke a taff which he held in his hand in the midt, and threw the pieces at the feet of the Nymph: Thus (aid he) in the preence of Gods and men, be all amity broke of betwixt you for ever. The Nymph enraged with anger, and etting her foot upon the broken taff; and thus (aid he) do I trample upon this emblem of our broken alliance; I do not value any of his thundring threats, but hope that Tautates will blat them all.

Then Alerantes without doing any reverence, or any action of repect or honour, retired; when Godomar aid unto him, what anwer do you give unto the challenge which I offered? We hall come ere long (anwered he) with an Army of threecore thouand men. That (aid the Prince) is either too many, or too few: Too many for a particular combate; and too few to fight againt the Jutice of the Gods.

Alerantes returned him no anwer, but haking his head in a menacing manner, he went out of the Catle, and taking hore, when he was ome twenty paces out of the Town, he made a top, and turned about Oh ye titular Gods of the City of Marcelles (cryed he out in a loud voice) and all ye other Gods and Goddees who are here adored, I beeech you be aupicious unto the Arms of the King my Lord, and be pleaed to come into the Royal City of Lions where he vows to build you a Temple, to erect Altars, and adore you with all manner of Reverence and Honour. When he had repeated thee words thrice over, he took a Javelin, and ran with all his force againt the walls of the Town, then etting purs to his Hore, he rid as fat as he could unto the ix Troops which waited for him.

This action incened the people extreamly; and had not Adamas retrained them, doubtles they would have done him ome dipleaure; but he told them, that Ambaadors were no ways culpable of the meage they brought, nor deerved any punihment; and that by the Law of Nations, they were to pas freely. And eeing all the City much tartled at the noie of this war, he advied the chief Magitrates to appeae this Tumult wiely; and becaue it was now too late to aemble the whole Corporation of the Town together, the Nymph would to morrow acquaint them with the caues of all thee rumors. Thee prudent promies of the Druide, did a little calm their pirits; and doubling the Guards, he went unto the Catle, to advie with the Nymph and Prince Godomar.

He came thither jut as Adrates was upon his knees before that Prince to kis his hand, in gratitude for the favour he received from him. Godomar took him up, and carried him unto Damon and Alcidon. Cavalier (aid he unto Damon) Here is the Shepherd unto whom the Gods have been o favourable. It was a bleed act, anwered Damon, and a thouand pities o honet a Shepherd hould be reduced unto uch a condition upon o noble a caue; If all thoe that commit the ame fault he did, hould be as harhly treated as he was, I believe Sir, you would have work enough in driving of Nails. Every one did laugh at this: Afterwards he went on, and poke unto Celidea; Shepherdes (aid he) I wonder you hould not tax me with my promie, that the Gods may retore that which they once gave unto you. Sir, anwered he, I am o far from putting you in memory, that I mot earnetly beeech you to forget it. It does amaze me (aid Godomar) to hear you ay o; I cannot believe any woman in the world is of your
mind: for as trength and prudence have given men the priviledge to be Lords of the Univere, o the gods have given beauty unto women to be the Ladies and Mitrees of men.

Sir, anwered he, I hould prize this beauty whereof you peak, as much as any other, if I did not conider the recovery of it may cot me that which is dearer then my life; for it is a very death unto me to be abent from Thamires: No, no, (anwered Thamires) I beeech you et your heart at ret: for ince you deprived your elf of that which is mot dear unto your ex, only to become mine, I am reolved, rather then it hould not be retored unto you, to loe my life: and therefore Sir (aid he unto Damon) I beeech you perform your promie, and be not hindred by the tears of this Shepherdes, whoe paion does blind her reaon: appoint ome to be my guide, and tell me what I hall do before I go.

I hould be very orry to dipleaure this wife hepherdes (anwered Damon) but the obligation of my promie may excue me, and therefore Halladine my ervant hall be your guide; I will write a Letter unto the learned Operatour: and all that you have to do here, is to make the skars in her face bleed, and wet in the bloud as many little taves as there is wounds, in the blood; then when they are dry, lap them up in linnen clothes, and carry them away as oon as may be: in the mean time, care mut be had of keeping the wounds very clean, wahing them every day with warm wine, and covering them cloe, let any dut get in; then doubtles you will find her recovered at your return. O heavens (cryed out Celed • a) mut this tr • fle of Nature, which they call beauty, caue a eparation o long betwixt Thamires and me? Ah my dearet Thamires (aid he) are you not contented with me as I am? For my part I am, and if you be alo, why hould you eek it with o much danger to your elf, and orrow to me? Can you be better then contented? Take heed, let the gods, eeing you o inatiable, hould deprive you of thoe contentments which you now enjoy: upon this he hung about his neck, with uch a tream of tears, as moved every one to pity her, and admire her, except Thamires, who being peremptorily reolved upon the journey, was very earnet with Damon to perform his promie: Whereupon Damon, calling for Halladine, he commanded him to make himelf ready, and wait upon Thamires, unto the great mater of natures ecrets in Carthage, called Olicaris; and becaue Thamires intended to go home that night, and make all ready for his journey in the morning, Halladine went to prepare himelf according to his maters commands, though omething againt his mind to leave him before he was perfectly recovered. In the interim, Damon writ a Letter, and gave it unto Halladine.

Celidea (eeing there was no way to divert Thamires from this voyage, ince neither prayers nor tears would prevail) he called to mind Palemons vow of granting the firt requet that was made unto him. O Palemon (aid he unto him) I conjure you by your olemn vow which you made, to grant the firt thing which was asked you, after the obtaining your deires, to undertake this journey in lieu of Thamires. Palemon was a little urpized, but preently recollecting himelf: O Celidea (aid he) I will never break my vow, though the journey hould cot me my life, and therefore am ready to perform it: Ah me! cried out the Shepherdes Doris, what a fool I was, not to make the firt requet, that Palemon hould never leave me? Mut I now loe him to content another? O mot cruel Shepherdes, wore againt me then thy own face? What offence have I done thee that thou houldet thus grieve me to death? Companion (replied Celidea, with a more atisfied countenance). I mut confes I am very orry to do you this dipleaure; but you ee I ued all means poible to prevent it: and ince all will not prevail, I beeech you weet Shepherdee to pardon me, ince what I did was by force and contraint.

Doris having no hopes of altering Celidea, nor in making Palemon to break his vow, he broke out into a Torrent of tears, and went out of the chamber, complaining againt Celidea, and againt heaven for conenting unto her ad Fortune.

Halladine by this time being ready, Thamires, with a thouand thanks, took
his leave of Damon, and afterwards of the Nymph and the Prince: So likewie did Celidea, Licidas, Palemon, Adrates, and alo Hylas, who notwithtanding all the prayers of Dorinde, Cercinea, Palanice, and Florice, would tay no longer from Stella. What Hylas (aid Leonide unto him) has Stella more power to draw you from us, then all we together have to tay you? Madam, anwered he, every one mut follow their Detiny: Why, replied he, is not your Detiny the ame it was wont to be? for I have heard you ay, it was by Detiny you loved beauty whereoever you met with it; if o, you mut needs confee that all thee fair Ladies have more beauty then Stella alone.

Madam (anwered Hylas) I call nothing beauty but what pleaeth me, and if Stella alone do pleae me more then all thee you peak of, is not he her elf, more beauty unto me then all they? Upon this, ay what they could, he went away in the company of thoe Shepherds and Shepherdees, amongt which was Halladine, who never in his life undertook a journey more againt his mind then this, becaue he left Damon at a time when he might be mot erviceable about his peron. Almot at the end of the Town, they all parted, after abundance of thanks unto Clindor, who accompanied Licidas as far as poibly he could. As for Adrates, he acknowledged himelf o obliged unto Palemon for the care he had of his cure, that he offered himelf everal times to go with Halladine in his room, but he would not permit him, becaue he thought it no atisfaction of his vow, if he hould go only by proxy: But at lat, after many difficulties, his importunity o far prevailed as to accompany him: This action of Adrates gained more upon the good will of Doris, then all his former Courthip had done.

That night Hallad • ne tayed at the houe of Thamires, where he entertained all the company with all imaginable welcome; but when they were to draw blood from the face of Celidea, her pain was not a little: for blood was to be drawn from every Scar, and the Chirurgion hardly left any part of her face uncarified, becaue otherwie the Sympathetical alve would not work perfect effect. The little ticks then being all dipped in blood, and dry, they were all lapped up very carefully in linnen clothes, and put into a box: 'So betimes in the morning, Palemon, Adrates, and Halladine, all three et forwards towards Lions.

All this while neither Amais, nor Adamas forgot Climanthes, and it was the next morning he was to come unto Galathea: So as order was taken with Leonide and Silvia over night, to be up betimes the next morning, and to be at the place appointed to receive him, and bring him in: thoe alo who were to eiz upon him were provided. And the un no ooner begun to appear, but this impoture came to the garden door, where the two Nymphs received him: as he did very handomly counterfeit that anctity whereof he made profeion, o Leonide and S • lvia, did as well peronate a great veneration and repect of his peron, which puffed up his oul into uch a welling pride, that he went as if he admired himelf.

The Nymph Galathea took him into her cloet, as it was concluded upon, to the end the Nymph Amais, Prince Godomar, Alcidon, and Adamas, might hear what he aid, being placed in uch convenient corners, that they might hear and ee and not be een: The gravity of his pace, when he came into the preence of Galathea, was admirable; but much more the impudence, with which he began to peak unto her: Madam (aid he unto her, with a evere and Majetick look) you have before you an Ambaadour, not from a Prince, King or any Monarch upon earth, but from the great and omnipotent Prince of heaven: Conider well how great a favour this is, and how you ought to receive him: viits and embaies from mortal Princes, what faces oever they put on them, are all aimed at the profit of the ender; but mine cannot be upected to have any uch interreted aim, ince all things are the gifts of God, who needs not any thing the world can give: Hark therefore, O Nymph, unto what I hall ay; yet do not heari •• on your of curioity, but with a full reolution to obey, and correpond unto the good will of this great God unto you: Then he paued a while, and Galathea was o urprized at the admirable impudence of this Impoture, that he could not anwer a word: afterwards he begun thus:

This great God aid that unto me; arie Climanthis my ervant, go and talk with Galathea, chide her for a fault which he hath committed; and tell her that punihment is ready to fall upon her head: God hath already the whip in his hand, his arm is lifted up; and there wants nothing, but to let it fall again; He who mut be your husband, and you his wife will this very day be hunting, and pas by the four everal wayes at Termes: there you may ee him, that is the very nick of time; let it lip, and be eternally mierable: ee him, and be eternally happy.

He uttered thee words, in uch an imperious tone, as if a god himelf had pronounced them: Then changing his behaviour and auming his accutomed countenance and peech, he continued: Now, O great Nymph, you know the will of heaven, be more careful to oberve it then formerly you have been, for otherwie, the anger of this great God will overwhelme you. And becaue communication with this great God, forbids any convere with men, unles by his particular command: give me leave to prophane my elf no longer, ince I have done all that I had in commiion.

The Nymph, who admired the goodnes of God, in uch an Impoture to live, he much deired to be out of his company, and therefore left him without any anwer, but that he would be alwayes obedient unto whatoever the gods commanded her.

But (aid he before he went) mut I go alone, or in company unto Termes; only with one Nymph, anwered he; but replied he. what will thoe that ee me ay: have a thin Scarf over your face, anwered he, and you may o diguise your elf that none can know you: at what hour, asked he, hall I ee this Huntman? To morrow, aid he, betwixt ix and even of the clock in the morning, for o the god did tell me. Then, aid the Nymph, go and thank your God for me, and aure him that I will go and atisfie his commands. Upon this the Nymph left him, and referred him into the hands of Leonide and Silvia, who accompanied him as far as the Garden door, which they had no ooner hut, but thoe, who by the command of Adamas watched for his coming, eized upon him, and carried him away immediatly to a prion which was prepared for him: when they took him and put him into prion, he called them prophane and impious perons, and Atheits, for daring to lay any violent hands upon one that was a friend to the great God: But when they laid Irons upon his feet and hands, he changed colour, and began to tremble; and more, when he aw them begin to clog him with more chains.

The gravity wherewith he menaced them hitherto, began to be more mild and calm, and now he fell to prayers and upplications: Sirs (aid he unto them) what offences have I given unto you? why hould you be o evere againt me? what advantage will my ruine be unto you? If by any cunning I have endeavoured to get omething, and to arive at ome Grandure, unto whom have I done any wrong? where is he that can complain againt me? Is it not permitted the birds, who never ow nor reap, to fly into the fields and feed upon what they can find? If I by any harmles art would get a livelyhood, why will they unjutly punih me for it? Sir, be not you any intrument of uch injuries, unles you do not fear the punihment of the gods: I am not yet o mierable and detitute of friends, but if you will hew any pity upon my age, and et me at liberty, I can find out a way to recompence you very bountifully: Do not refue a Fortune when it is offered, he that will refue it when he may, may go without it when he would have it: No, no, aid they, we never make any profit unto our elves, but with honour, never with Treaon; all thy offers do but render thee more culpable, and never hope to corrupt us. Think upon thy faults, and aure thy elf thou mot very hortly render an accompt, and receive allary, according to thy deerts.

One of the company took notice, that when he thought he was not een, he trived everal times to put his hand into his boome, but his Irons would not permit
him: o as he uppoed, he had there, omething of importance. And as they were earching him, Adamas and Alcedon, who heard of his being taken, entred; but becaue they deired to talk with him alone, they commanded all the Guard to withdraw, then Adamas going unto him, and after he had well looked upon him; Fie, fie, thou wicked Impoture (aid he unto him) art thou not ahamed to prophane the habit which I ee thou wearet? Sir, anwered he with an impudent brow, I acknowledge you to be my Grand Druide, and I know you ought not to depie me as you do: for though unworthy, yet am I of the ame Order whereof you are chief: Heaven defend me (aid the Druide) from uch impiety, and rather take away my life, then uffer me to be the Patron of uch Impotures. Tell me? how are you qualified? where did you receive your Orders? Sir, anwered he, it is now almot an age, ince I received them at Dreux. Surely aid Adamas, he is mad, he thinks the ditance of the place will keep us from dicovering his knavery: why did you come into our juridiction without a Licence? I thought, replied he, that it was lawful to erve god every where: But do you not know (aid Adamas) that none are to officiate in the charge of a Druide in thee provinces, unles I licence them? It is o hort a time ince I came (anwered he) and I have convered with o few, that I never heard of this Ordinance. Did not that God (aid Adamas) whom you convere withall o familiarly, advertie you of it? The god of whom you peak (replied he) did never talk with me of any uch affairs, what then do you talk of (aid Adamas) when he commands me (anwered Climanches) then I hall tell you.

Alcedon and Adamas, who knew this man to be a mot notorious impoture, they could not chue but wonder at his impudence: when one of thoe who took him came and acquainted them, how he offered to corrupt them, to which he anwered with extream impudence, that thee were only meer imaginations, upon which he never entertained the leat thought: thus, aid he, are innocent men candalized by wicked men; which the ouldier hearing, and being extremely angry (Sir aid he unto Adamas) this is the mot brazen fac'd lier that ever lived: three of my companions tood by, when he gave us that language, and I am mot confident there is omething in his bret that would convince him: for we have een him everal times trive to take omthing out, when he thought we did not ee him.

Call then your companions (aid Adamas) and earch him very carefully. At this command, Climanthis was quite out of countenance, for though he was a very ubtil fellow, yet as Fortune was, when he was almot at the Garden door, very early, Polemas ent him a letter, which he put in his bret, becaue he knew not a more ecret place at that time to lay it up in: and therefore when they began to earch him, he made as much reitance as poibly he could, puhing all about him with his arms and head, and throwing them to the ground, as if he were poeed with ome devil. This great reitance made Adamas and Alcidon, more deirous to know what it was: o as calling for more help, they earched him, and found the Letter, and becaue it was very dark in the prion, they went out to read it, and found written thee words.

body.head: POLEMAS his Letter unto CLIMANTHES.
body.p:
DEar friend of my heart, impatience is alwayes a companion of love; do not therefore wonder I hould waken you thus early: at even of the clock I will be at Termes, and a mot happy hunter hall I be if by your contrivance I meet there with what you have promied unto me: Once more dear Climanthes, I wear that Galathea shall be no ooner mine, but I will make you a poeour of your dear Leonide,
with what hare thou wilt have in the State; of which, if ever I be Lord, I am beholding unto you for it. Force at the wort will not fail us but I had rather your Prudence hould bring it to pas by fair means: The firt is more afe and certain, but the other more honourable: yet if one do fail, the other hall erve the turn.

div.p: See (aid Adamas) what would we know more of this wicked man, here is the whole enterprize dicovered; Let us ee (aid Alcidon) if we can catch this Hunter at Termes. As for that (replyed Adamas) order is already taken; for Leonide and Silvia are gone thither already, the firt of them in Galatheas habit, yet with a Scarf about her head; alo we have placed Lerintes with thirty hore in a Grange cloe by; to the end if Polemas pas by, he may be caught in his own Net. Whilt they were talking thus, Climanthes eeing all his plot quite dicovered, and expecting nothing but an ignominious death, he fell into uch depair, that eeing himelf alone in the prion, he ran his head o violently againt the wall, that blood guhed out at his eyes and mouth; o as when Adamas came again into the prion, to ask him ome quetions, he found him gaping and grovelling upon the ground, as if he were choaked with a Catarh: they endeavoured to revive him; but all in vain: for he had made uch a hole in his head, that his brains came out. Thus died this mierable man; and thus (aid the grand Druide) is the great Tautates jut, who has brought upon the head of this wicked wretch, that vengeance and miery which he had prepared for others.

Upon thee coniderations Alcidon and Adamas went to render an account unto the Nymph and the Prince Godomar, and they had no ooner related all paages, and hewed the Letter, but they heard a great Tumult and noie which came from the Gate toward Termes. For Leonide and Silvia being gone thither, and Polemas paing by in the habit of a hunter, thinking Galathia was there, he carried them away on pillions, before thoe who were at the Grange could come time enough to relieve them: for the door being too little, and an iron bar which ued to hut the door falling unluckily a cros, they could not get out till Polemas had got a good distance off; and preently after appeared four great Bodies of Hore which came to meet him; o as thoe whom Amais ent, were forced to retreat a little hatily, which caued no mall noie in the Town.

Adamas then eeing that all was dicovered and that no longer delay was to be ued, Madam, (aid he unto the Nymph) thee tears which you hed for Leonide and Silvia, does indeed argue your natural weetnes, but at this time the neceity of your affairs requires you hould hew the courage of a man, and have recoure unto remedies of prudence, and not offices of pity: I conceive it expedient to aemble the Magitrates of the Town, and that you acquaint them not only with the los of Prince Clidemant, but alo with the Treaon of Polemas and Climanthes, alo at the ame time to hew them by what mean you intend to ubdue this Rebel. For the bet way to content the people, is to put them into great hopes, and to hide all dangers from them. Godomar concurring with his opinion, the mot notable of them were called and curioity brought thither abundance of the common ort: Then the Nymph commanded the grand Druide to let them undertand the occaion for which he convened them together; which he did in uch eloquent terms, that when he mentioned the death of Prince Clidemant, there was not one in all this great company that did not tetifie his orrows by his tears and ighs: But when he proceeded and mentioned the enterprie of Polemas and Climanthes, not only upon the tate, but upon the peron of Galathea, as he made it apparent by his Letter, and the taking of Leonide and Silvia, thinking the one of them to be Galathea: Then all the people began to cry out with one voice, Murder the Traytor, and long live our great Nymph Amais: But when to verifie the truth of all this, he caued the body of this Impotor to be brought out, and related his tricks, his deigns, and his death: Firt the children, next them, the common ort of people, and at lat almot all fell upon this Corps, and drawing it by the
legs almot quite out of the Catle, and threw it in a ditch: But as if this were not revenge enough, the people went again unto him, and hurried him by the heels out of the Town, doing all the ignominy imaginable unto it.

The chief of them in the mean time, and the mot notable, did not remove until they heard all that Adamas had to ay unto them from the Nymph: And when Adamas had done, Clindor who for his Age, Quality, and Prudence, all the Aembly made choice of to give the anwer, he poke in this manner.

THe los Madam, which you have had, does not concern only one Peron, or one Family, but it is general, and not only all this Country has a hare in it, but alo all the Gauls, nay all Europe may bewail the los of o great a Prince. You ee how our Tears and our Groans do accompany your grief, and how we give you this outward tetimony of the inward reentment of our Souls: I mut confes all this is but a feeble remedy againt o great a diater; yet it may be ome comfort unto you to ee how adly all your faithful Subjects do take unto themelves a hare in all your griefs and misfortunes. But Madam, we mut all needs confes, that this econd News which you have told us, does pierce us to the very heart, with more tinging reentments then the firt: For the death of a Prince whom none of us did ever think mortal, unles in his Reputation and Honour, is not o hard to be endured, as is the tain of Perfidie and Treaon upon this Country, which before was never een, nor o much as imagined. Oh Heavens! Madam, that uch Monters hould be found in Forrets amongt us, and in our days: I wonder our Earth (unaccutomed to uch an ignominious burthen) does not wallow them up alive. We know not what to ay, nor think, unles that Heaven being offended at us for our ins, will punih us more grievouly then all ages pat. This tain upon us does well us with o much grief, as we cannot lift up our eyes to weep, nor open our mouths to lament and igh for o great a hame. Yet ince the good ought not to be charged with the crimes of the wicked, we will lift up our eyes unto you, Madam, and peak in behalf of this Town, and we dare ay of all the Country, if we had time to confer with them. Madam, as becomes your faithful Subjects, we do offer unto you all that is within thee Walls, our Etates, our Children, our Blood, our Lives: Proteting before Heus, Belinus, Tharamis, our great Tautates, that as long as we live, and as long as you live, we will not have any Soveraign over us but Amais: And we will as oon fail in our Duties to the Gods, as in our Fealty to you, not paring either Etates, Children, or Lives: And in tetification of this, let every one lift up his hand and his heart, and cry, Long live the Nymph Amais.
Upon this, the hands of all the Aembly were een above their heads, and uch a hout that it was heard further then all over the Town.

As the Nymph was returning them hearty thanks for the demontrations of their good wills, Adamas was advertied that the ouldiers which had been levied in the province were very near the gates, which caued the Nymph to abreviate her peech, that he might view this welcome and neceary uccour. Be pleaed to know (aid the man that brought the news) That they are at leat fifteen hundred, the bet armed, and in the bet order that was een a long time; for they
imagined that they came upon the Ceremony of the Mileto, o as they had trimmed up themelves to the bet advantage. Thus all the Aembly parted with uch extream forwardnes to erve the Nymph, that he was exceedingly encouraged.

In the mean time, Adamas cauing the gates to be opened, thee ouldiers entred in uch an excellent poture, that all thoe who aw them, thought them to be men of very good ervice, all their caps were crowned with oak leaves, for o was the cutome of all thoe that were called to the Ceremony, as they were. They were no ooner drawn up into a body, but they were appointed Captains, Lieutenants, and other military officers, unto whom they were to be obedient, preently after, they were ditributed into quarters, as well for the defence of the walls, as to guard the treets and paes in the Town. Then taking a view of all the hore, counting thoe which the Queen Argira left, and thoe which Prince Godomar brought, the number was two hundred and fifty, which alo were divided into five troops, fifty in each; all the foot were put under charge of Damon, who not being perfectly recovered of his wounds, could hardly wear arms or get on horeback, yet he went into the Town, and viited the walls and works. On the other ide, Alcedon had the charge of all the hore, and put them into as good a poture as poibly could be. In the mean time Prince Godomar, who was general, did viit the Magazines both in the Catle and Town, and by the prudent advice of Adamas, provided all things which he could foreee neceary upon all occaions.

In the mean time Polemas was o proud of his price, that he thought upon nothing les already, then the ump • uoity of his marriage, and the magnificence of his train: for verily thinking that Galathea was in his power, he had no thoughts but upon his marriage, and that nothing could retard his happines, for he valued not the content of the Nymph, though he knew he would be extreamly againt it; but being fully reolved, according to the councel of Climanthes, to add force unto his prayers, he believed that after he was once his wife he would then be more tractable. But when he came to Surien, and with abund • n • e of honour and repect accoted Leonide, whom he took for Galathea, and at the very firt word he poke, he found his mitake. O how dead was he then truck? which Leonide perceiving, and deiring if it were poible to deceive the deceiver, he took him by one hand and Silvia by another, O Polemas (aid he) you had committed the greatet errour that ever you did in all your life, and if he who carried me away behind him, would have uffered me to have poke unto you, as I deired him a hundred times, I had prevented it. For this morning a Druide (if it be lawful to call o acred a peron by that name) came unto Galathea from his God, to command her to marry him, whom at even of the clock in the morning, he hould ee pas by the four wayes at Termes: and if he did not, to aure her elf that all the ret of her dayes hould be mot mierable, and he the mot unfortunate woman in the world: The Nymph he made a full account to go, and be obedient unto this command, rather then be mierable all her life; but when he was jut ready to go out, he fell ick and was forced to go to bed: But yet being extreamly deirous to know him that was detinied to be her husband, he commanded us to go thither, and tell her the name and quality of him that paed by the firt, thinking that him whom the gods did chue for her to be her husband, was a better choie then he her elf could make. I ay therefore, that if you had not been o rah in carrying, us away certainly upon our report, the Nymph would have ent unto you before night, and acquainted you with her mind.

Polemas hearing this, and knowing what Climanthes had told her, he repented himelf of his carrying them away o hatily; yet eeing Leonide in Galatheas clothes: but how comes it to pas, aid he, that you are in her clothes? As for that, anwered Leonide, when the Ceremony of driving the acred nails was, he gave unto me and everal others of my companions, this ute like unto her own: but, aid Polemas, why were you o hudded that none could know you? becaue (anwered Leonide) many ued to pas by that way, and were deirous to be unknown.
But, replied he, what was the meaning of thoe horemen that purued us? I believe, anwered he, that they were ome of the Queen Argiras men, who going to wait upon her part of the way, returned again to the Princes Reanira, who tayes at Marcelles, and they eeing us carryed away, and hearing us cry out, thought themelves obliged to relieve us without our knowledge, or deigne. What buines, aid Polemas, had the Queen Argira there? We do not know, anwered Leonide, he has been indeed ome dayes in the Catle, but o cloe and retired, that we did not o much as know her name till the day he departed.

Polemas calling for Peliodontes, Argonides, Litander, and Ligonias, acquainted them with what Leonide told him, and they were all of opinion that it was bet to end them back again unto Galathea, with an excue that ome hunters took them away unknown unto Polemas, and in the mean time to oblige Leonide and Silvia by all manner of courteies to ay o. Polemas then caued a coach to be made ready for them, and uing them with all poible reverence and kindnee, he profeed a thouand ervices; and waiting upon them to the coach, beeeched them both to be his friends upon this occaion, with all poible promies of remuneration. You may be ure, that they for their parts, did promie to do wonders for him, and taking his leave of them, he returned to his chamber, the fullet of hopes that ever was man: but he and his four privy councellers had no ooner hut the door; but the on of Merouthes, his correpondent in Marcelles, came to peak with him as oon as he came into the chamber, Sir, aid he, I am very orry to be the meenger of ill news, but ince I am commanded by a Father, and knowing how neceary it is you hould be acquainted with it, I thought it may as well come to your ear by me as by another; know then Sir, that all your enterprize is dicovered, and the Nymph hath publihed it unto the aembly: How came the Nymph to know it (aid Polemas) he hewed unto them a letter (anwered the young man) which you writ unto a certain Druide called Climanthes, who is dead. O (cryed out Polemas) is Climanth • s dead? Yes certainly (anwered he) for I aw him hang by the heels at the gate as I came hither. O gods, replied Climanthes, that o great a peron as the univere had not his fellow, hould come to uch a diaterous end? upon this he and his four confidents enquiring more particularly of all circumtances, they undertood that Adamas was acceory to his death, and that it was he who had contrived it, which made them believe, that Leonide knew all that this young man had related unto them. Doubtles he does (anwered he) for he and Silvia caued him to be taken, at leat, the common report is o. Oh God (aid Polemas in a mighty fury) let ome ride after, and bring them back, and if I can but get them again, they hall pay for this wicked act. Upon this Ligonias in all poible hate diparched away fifty Hore, with expres command to bring them back: In obedience to which, they mounted, and etting purs to hore, did gallop away with full peed: but the Nymphs being gone a full quarter of an hour before thee men took hore, and Leonide fearing left any hould follow them, he deired the coachman to drive as fat as he could, which he did, until one of the wheels broke quite in two: Judge you in what a condition thee two Ladies were in, who looked every minute for ome to fetch them back. The Coachman eeing no other remedy, told them that he would go into the next Town to try if he could borrow another Coach: They alo eeing no other remedy, deired him to make hate, and when he was gone, they began to conult with themelves what they hould do. For, aid Leonide, if Polemas do hear what has hapned unto Climanthes, mot certainly he will purue us, and it is not impoible but ome may give him intelligence of it. And if he hould have us again in his power, God knows how he would ue us: certainly Siter, aid Silvia, he would purue us; but what hall we do to prevent being taken; I am reolved, aid Leonide, to go away on foot; but Siter, aid Silvia, what hall we do when night comes upon us: I had rather, aid Leonide, be torn in pieces by wolves, then fall again into the hands of thee men: whilt they were thus talking and unreolved what to do, they epied the hore within a mile of them: Siter, aid Leonide, yonder they come, and for my part I
will leave you if you will not follow me: Silvia in a terrible fear began to follow, but being buied in tucking up her coats, and coming into a thick wood by the high way, he could not overtake her companion, by reaon of the Buhes and Bryers; o as preently after, the Horemen coming to the Coach, and finding it empty, they dipered themelves all about the Wood; and pying Silvia, they all ran unto her, thinking they were both there: but finding only one, they fell all in quet again after the other yet all in vain; for he was wandered into the wood upon the left hand, where there was o many Boggs and Buhes, that Hores could not pas: She being very crafty, in lieu of going towards Mount Brion or Marcelles, s;he took the quite contrary way, o as they never made that way; but after abundance of pains in eeking for her, night coming upon them they were contrained to return.

The Coach was by this time mended, and thoe who took Silvia, carried her unto it, taying there till the ret found Leonide; but thoe that were in quet of her, returning without any news of her, and Silvia aying that when he parted from her, he went another way, they reolved to look no more for her at that time, but to go unto Polemas, becaue it began to be night.

Leonide on the other ide, had o hid her elf, omtimes in the thick of the Wood, and omtimes amongt Bogges and Rocks, that it was almot impoible to find her; but the face of heaven beginning to mask it elf with darknes, he knew not what to do: She was a woman of a good pirit, and none of thoe that ue to be affrighted at trifles; but being in uch a alvage place, where he heard nothing but the murmuring of a Torrent, and the crieks of Owls, and eeing nothing but a hollow darknes, not knowing which way to go, nor having any thing to eat, a peron of a greater courage then hers, might very well apprehend ome melancholy fears; he ate long upon a great tone, as well becaue he was very weary, as to hearken whether any followed her; but hearing none, and the moon beginning to hine, he roe up, and looked every way about her; and neither eeing nor hearing any, he went up to the top of a little hill, from whence he thought he aw a light, and towards which he made her coure: But when he was come near it, he was afraid to find thoe from whom he fled; o as turning a little upon the left hand, he walked on, until it was break of day, where he found another wood. In this place he intended to tay until it was night: the length of the way had wearied her, her fears perplexed her, and hunger did much pres her; yet leep being above all, it eized upon her eyes, and he lept until the evening; when a very young Shepherdes eeking for an Ewe that was trayed. came by chance unto the place where Leonide was; and admiring to ee her in uch glitering clothes, he began to run away, thinking her ome Goddes; but the Nymph beckning unto her with her hand, he came unto her; Sweetheart (aid he) have you either a Mother or an Aunt? My mother (anwered the wench and trembled) is in our houe, but my Aunt and my Father are dead long ince. And what (aid the Nymph) are you looking for here? For an Ewe (anwered the wench) which is trayed, Well (aid Leonide) go unto thy mother, bid her come hither to me; but bid her be ure he bring none with her but thee nor tell any body; as for the Ewe which thou art looking for, I will give thee a core. The wench very glad of uch news to carry unto her mother, for they were very poor, he ran unto her, and told her, that yonder was a Goddes in the finet clothes that ever was een, who deired to peak with her, and had promied her a core of Ewes. The mother who had more wit then the daughter, enquired the place where he was, and leaving her at home, with expres charge to tell no body, he went unto Leonide, whom as oon as ever he aw in that place, o clad, he knew her to be a peron of ome great quality; therefore making her a low curteie, Madam (aid he) what ervice is it your pleaure to command me? Good woman (anwered Leonide) come hither into this thicket, that none may ee us, and tell me whether you aw any horemen eeking for one? Oh Madam, it is not above an hour ince there was above a dozen uch who aid they had been riding up and down all the night long. And what (aid the Nymph) is become of them? I know not Madam (anwered he) whether they be aleep in ome Country houe,
for they eemed to be very weary. Good woman (aid the Nymph) pray ee if there be any of them yet, for they are enemies to the Nymph Amais, and eek for me, deiring to do me ome michief, becaue I belong to her. Madam (aid the Country woman) if Agis our Lord were here, I dare ay he would guard you from any harm, but he has been long out of the Country in the ervice of Clidemant. Well good woman (aid the Nymph) Agis is my Kinman, and one of the bet friends I have, and therefore for his ake help me upon this occaion, and ee whether any of thee wicked men remain yet hereabouts.
