The good Country woman after a promie to erve her with all fidelity, went and pied about all the Town, whether any of them were there; and found not only them, but many others enquiring for the Nymph, and promiing large rewards to any that could inform them, with a menace of cruel punihment to any that hould conceal her: The woman who was ubtle enough for one of her condition, and knew the deigne of thee men to be naught, eemed as if he knew nothing of her, but went to her houe, got an old tatter'd Petticoat and Watcoat, and when he aw none within compas of eeing her, he went again to the Wood, related all that he had learned, and advied her to put off her own clothes, which would dicover her, and put on thoe. The Nymph was not all day undreing her elf, and putting on the clothes of this Country woman; but becaue it was late, and the Nymph had an opinion they would look for her all the night, he had no mind to go unto Marcelles, till it was time to carry omthing to the Market; and though he was much diguied, yet her Beauty was but too viible; o as getting ome mud, he did o fully her face and her hands, as would indeed have ooner moved laughter then love: As for her own clothes, he hid them in a Buh, and would not let the woman carry them, left they hould be found in her houe, and o caue a dicovery: The woman obeyed her, though with much regret, for he thought they would have enriched her for ever: which Leonide perceiving, good woman (aid he) never trouble your elf for things of o mall a value; if you can but get me into Marcelles, I will give you a hundred times more then they are worth. The Sun was already et, and the night began to be very dark, which might well invite the Nymph to go out of the Wood with confidence enough, which yet he did not without trembling; knowing that thoe from whom he fled, were in the Town: But the good woman, who undertook to be her guide, did hearten her as well as he could, and by the way, did bid her ay unto any that hould ask her who he was, that he was her daughter, and that he had lived three years amongt the mountains, in a place called Viverois.

This advice proved to be very good, for they were no ooner entred into her little houe, but four or five Souldiers entred alo, who earched every corner in the Cottage; o as if her clothes had been there, all had been dicovered: whilt ome of them were very buie in earchings, others were as buie in quetioning and enquiring after Leonide: The little Wench who had een her in the Wood, not thinking any harm, you eek (aid he) for a fair Goddes, all gold and ilver, and perhaps I can tell you where he is, for I aw her to day not far from hence. Oh heavens, how Leonide tarted when he heard this, and the good woman alo! yet to avoid upition, where (aid he unto the childe) did you ee her? Upon this all the Souldiers flocked about her, and preed her to tell. Sirs (aid the mother very craftily) if my daughter do tell you, I pray let her have the reward that is promied, it will be a good portion for her, and will advance her marriage; then taking her by the hand, he went out of the houe, eeming as if he would make her daughter conduct them unto the place where he aw her, though indeed it was only to get the Souldiers out of the houe: But he carried them to the very place, where they found Leonides clothes, and thought that the little wench aid true, but that they came too late: and as there are always ome more ubtle then others, o one of the Souldiers, whilt the ret were earching about, did take the wench aide, and with fair words got out of her, that her mother did know of her, for he acquainted her with it as oon as he aw her; o as it was preently concluded amongt them, that this old woman had hid her in ome place or other; therefore threatning to kill her, and to burn her houe if he did not tell them where he was,
the poor woman was forced to tell them, that it was he whom they aw in her houe, but beeeched them to do her no harm, for he was cozen unto Agis who was Lord of the place, and hould he come to know of it he would ruine her. The Souldiers, as glad of this as if they had won a battel, ran all to the houe: but Leonide doubting that this little wench might perhaps blab it out, that he had told her mother, no ooner aw them out of the houe, but taking a piece of bread which he found upon the table, he went out at the back door, and recomending her elf unto Tautates, he ran into the open fields, not knowing which way he went, yet topping ometimes to take breath, and to hearken whether any followed her.
The ouldiers in the mean time coming to the door, and finding it hut, did knock a while, thinking that Leonide had hut it for fear; but eeing he would not anwer, they offered to break it open.

The countrey woman, being very orry to ee her houe thus broken, O Madam (cryed he out) they have promied to do you no harm, therefore I beeech open the door, and do not caue my houe to be thus hurt. But he might have cryed loud and long enough before Leonide heard her. In the mean time all the Town flocked together at this noie, and after the ouldiers had broken open the doore, they entred, and earched it as if they had been looking for a needle: At lat, the Souldiers being out of hope, and vexed to the heart they could not find her, they et fire upon the houe, and burnt it to ahes, with all the houholdtuff and etate this poor woman had, who in her little Fortune may be example unto greater, ince there was but a moment betwixt her hopes of happines, and her certainty of utter ruine.

Leonide, who had taken upon the right hand towards the gardens of Mountbrion, though he was got a good ditance off, yet could he ee the fire of the little houe, and gueing at the caue, he pitied the poor woman in her oul, with intention to relieve her, if ever he found a fit opportunity, But this thought did not hinder her from making all the hat he could, for he was ure he hould be purued; and therefore the moon hining, he made uch hat, as at the break of day, he pied the Catle of Marcelles, which did o encourage her, and mend her pace, that at Sun riing he came to the garden door, out of which he came when he went unto Termes: her joy was great when he came there, but not compleat till he came as Galathea. She knocked at the door three or four times, and had hardly patience to tay till the Gardiner came to open it; but when Fleuriall aw her in uch an equipage, and knew her not, he would not let her enter: what Fluriall (aid he unto him) not know me? or art thou out of thy witts? I know your tongue (anwered he) but not your habit nor your face: Well, well, Fluriall (aid he) hut the door, and bring me ome water, and then thou wilt know my face as well as my tongue.

Then he went to the Gardiners lodge, where wahing her face and hands, well Fluriall (aid he) dot know me now? I think (aid he) that you are a Fairy, that can change themelves as they pleae: But Madam, I wonder you hould never peak unto me any more concerning Lindamor, but eem as if he were now quite out of memory. O friend (aid Leonide and ighed) didt thou know the condition wherein we are, and what hazards I run for him, thou wouldt ay I am the bet friend he has. But prethee tell me, dart thou venter a journey to him, if I hould have occaion to end thee? Courage Madam? anwered he, yes, I dare go to him, though it were to the furthet part of all the earth. Since o (aid he) prepare thy elf, for perhaps thou halt go ooner then thou art aware. Not o oon (aid he) as I deire: for Madam, I love Lindamor above my own oul; above me? aid Leonide, and miled, yes, aid he: and above Galathea! aid Leonide, and becaue he made no anwer, art thou mute (aid he) why dot thou not anwer? I do not anwer, replied he, becaue I am meauring the affection which I bear unto them, and I find the cale o even, that I know not on which ide it will lean.

She would have continued longer, if he had not heard the Catle door open, which let into the Garden, and eeing the draw-bridge let down, he went unto
Galatheas antichamber, meeting none that knew her; but the Groom of the Chamber eeing her o clad, he would not uffer her to enter, thinking her to be ome countrey impudent woman that knew not what he did: But Leonide aying unto him, what friend, know you none but by their habits? are you of the nature of Lions? then he knew her, and not being able to forbear laughing at her dres, he beeeched her to pardon his mitake, auring her it might well have been anothers fault as well as his: Then he went on into Galatheas Chamber, who was newly wakened: all thoe that aw her enter did not know her, and eeing her go to the Nymphs bed ide, ran unto her to hinder her, but he puhed them off, and took hold of Galatheas hand which he put forth to draw the curtain, and to ee what was the caue of the noie which he made: The Nymph eeing one kis her hand that was in uch ragged clothes, he knew not what to think, but asked what woman it was, and why they would uffer her to enter before they acquainted her, I beeech you Madam (aid Leonide) do not drive me out of your chamber, for I aure you, the pains I have taken in coming hither deerves better treatment.

O good gods (cryed out the Nymph) it is Leonide, then raiing up her elf in her bed, and looking her in the face, he embraced and kied her with abundance of affection: O weetheart (aid he) how I am over joyed to ee you, and how many tears for you have thee two dayes cot me? then looking her again in the face, he kied her, and hugg' her in her arms. The ret of the Nymphs, her companions, hearing of her return, ran half undret to ee her, and bid her welcome home: And as Galathea was asking her how he ecaped, and where he left Silvia, the Nymph Amais hearing he was there, ent for her, with abundance of impatiency, to ee her: for Adamas being then with her, and longing extreamly to ee his Neice, Amais was very deirous he hould enjoy that contentment in her preence; o as he was contrained to leave Galathea and go unto her in that ragged dres. Though the Nymph and the Druide had buines enough in their heads to keep them from laughing, yet now they could not chue when they aw her in that pickle. When he kied the Nymphs hand, and did reverence to her uncle, Madam (aid Leonide) not long ince I was infinitly deirous to ee you, but now truly I am extreamly ahamed to ee you being as I am. No, no, aid Amais, I am very glad to ee you in any habit; but pray tell us how you ecaped the hands of thoe wicked men, and where you left Silvia? Then he began to make relation, when Galathea entred into her mothers chamber half undret, but impatient to undertand the Fortunes of Leonide and Silvia: o then he related all her adventures, in uch emphatical terms and expreions, that the Nymphs did ometimes even tremble at the dangers wherein he was, and otherwhiles admiring her prudence and courage, but blaming the faint-heartednee of Silvia, which Adamas excued upon conideration of her youth. But certainly (aid he) he is not in o much danger as Leonide was, for he being my Neice, might for my ake expect the wort of that Rebels revenge; but as for Silvia, what caue can they have to treat her ill: No, no, Madam, I aure my elf they will end her back unto you, and had it not been for Leonide, they would never have ent after Silvia, for you ee when Silvia was in their hands, yet they purued the other almot to the very walls of the Town.

Upon this, Leonide making an humble reverence to the Nymph, he beeeched her to let her go and change her fine vetments, o as Galathea went out alo with her. The news was preently all over the Catle that Leonide had ecaped out of the hands of Polemas, and that Silvia till remained: as news does commonly get in the telling, o did this, and o much, that before it got into the Town, a thouand indignities were aid to be offered unto that wie Lady: which reaching the eares of Ligdamon, did o urprize him, that half out of himelf he ran to Leonide, beeeching and conjuring her, by all the mot preing expreions he could invent, to tell him the truth of things. She who knew what affection that Cavalier bore unto Silvia, he leened the danger as much as poibly he could, and told him that he choe rather to remain in the hands of Polemas, then run the danger of flying; but doubtles he was wie in it, for certainly Polemas would
ere long end her back, and the reaon of her tay o long, was only the breaking of a Coach wheel; and that when they poke unto Polemas, they received all manner of curteie and civility from him.

This did a little calm the mind of Ligdamon, who had already a thouand deignes upon the life of Polemas, and poke them aloud, which caued the correpondent of Polemas to end him word preently, that he hould take good heed of Ligdamon. Mean while the Souldiers who had taken Silvia, did put her into the Coach, and carried her to Polemas, who miing of Leonide, was vexed to the oul, for he was more animated againt her, by reaon of Adamas her Uncle: but paing uch ways where hores could not come, the Souldiers that were in quet of her, did mis her, and returned home at night o weary, that their hores could hardly et one foot before another: But when Polemas aw he had ecaped, his anger was extream; and hutting up Silvia cloe Prioner, did menace her, and terrifie her exceedingly: Poor Silvia not ued to uch treatments, was much atonihed; yet knowing her elf innocent from all harm, he committed her elf to the protection of God, from whom he hoped for undoubted aid: And yet the grief which Polemas reented at the death of Climanthes was o great, that he was apt enough for any barbarous deigne againt her; but Argonides one of his four great confidents retrained the execution of his fury, telling him, that it was poor revenge to take it upon a illy woman, and would render him odious unto all that hould hear of it. What then (replyed Polemas) mut we it till, and leave the death of our friends unrevenged? Stay but a while (anwered Argonides) and you may carve what revenge you pleae; for I hope you have men enow to take Marcelles this night, and then if you will, you may make yond wicked Adamas pay according to his merits. Oh (aid Polemas) I hould be fully contented if that Traytor were but in my hands, or any that belongs unto him. Oh Sir (aid Peledontes) if that will content you, I hall do it for you; you know that he has one on, and one daughter; the on has not been of late in the Country, but as I am told, will very hortly return from the Coat of the Allobroges; but till he do return, I will end to the Banks of Lignon, where his daughter, who is a Druide, has lived amongt a company of Shepherdees ever ince he came from Carnuthes: I have a Souldier who knows the place very well, and who no longer then yeterday had dicoure with me about it, when we talked of Leonides ecape The los of this daughter would more ting the heart of that old knave, then would the los of Leonide, who is only his Niece. Oh my dear friend (aid Polemas, and was even ready to kis him) I hould think my elf infinitely obliged unto you, if you could deliver that daughter of his into my hands, and till I could meet with a more olid revenge, he hould content me. Sir (aid Peliodontes) peak not a word more of it, rely upon me, and to morrow by this time he hall be in your power. He went preently to his houe, and ending for his Souldier, he gave him the command of fifty other Souldiers, and commanded him to eize upon Alexis, yet without doing her as little hurt as poibly he could, and to bring her unto him. The Souldier et out an hour before day, and went towards Atreas Town.

In the mean time Alerantes having told Polemas what anwer he had received from the Nymph, he had a deire to be gone, but Polemas deired him to tay two days longer, that he might carry unto the King the certain news of the taking Marcelles, for he made himelf ure of taking it upon the very firt Aault. Alerantes who aw uch a confluence of Souldiers from all ides, and all things neceary for uch an enterprize in readines, did think that two days would be quickly over, and in the mean time dipatched a Letter, importing the caue of his tay.

Over night, Polemas commanded his Army to draw all up into a Body, and in the morning, as oon as it was day, to march towards Marcelles, and would not loe o much time as to take a muter of them, but relyed upon the report of Argonides, that they were eighteen thouand Foot, and of Peliodontes, that they were eight thouand Hore; o as about two hours before day, the Moon hining very bright, they began to apply themelves unto thoe orders which he had given
them. Litander who had been long before preparing Engines of War, ent uch in carriages as were neceary for a udden torm, leaving uch behind him as were requiite for a long iege: In the firt place he ent Ladders, of which there were everal orts; one was Ladders of Ropes with hooks, which being flung up by trength of Arm, catched hold of the Battlements, and hung down with teps of cord, like Ladders. Another ort which they called Cranes, formerly called Tollones, which being planted to a wall, was reemblant unto a pair of weighing cales, with a beam, which as one end goes up, another goes down, and would convey up five or ix men at a time, in Baskets like Panniers, and Cords fixed at them, to pull them up and down at either end; o as when five men at one end, were at the top, other five were getting into the Panniers at the bottome, and o like two baskets, wh • lt one was going up, the other was coming down for more. This Engine was et upon wheels, with a kind of Rampart to defend thoe that were to plant it.

Beides thee kind of Scaling Ladders, there were abundance of the common ort, and abundance of Hurdles and Faggots to fill up Ditches, and make Galleries for Souldiers to pas under, and abundance of freh Hides to cover them, as a defence againt fire or arrow hot. They had alo certain Engines which they called Plutoes, and which indeed were little penthoues upon wheels, under which they approached the walls, and under them worked to undermine them. They had alo Cats, and Cat Catles, Rams, Rats and Foxes; all Engines with which they approached walls, and took their names from a reemblance unto thoe Animals. But above the ret, the Tortoie was the mot admirable; for it was forte foot in length, twenty in widenes, and twelve foot high; it was moved forward upon Rowlers, and under it were heltered many Pioneers, or others to work in Trenches, or to approach the walls.

Of all thee there was abundance of each ort; for being ubject to be burnt, it was requiite to have many of them; and indeed the carriages were o many, as they almot filled all the way betwixt Surien and the gardens of Mount Brion.

In the mean time Polemas ordered every thing for this aault, writing Tickets unto every Officer what they hould do; And as oon as day appeared, taking Hore with all his Officers and Souldiers, he rode into the head of the Army, to dipere everal orders unto them. And becaue it was impoible o many men hould rendezvouz from all Quarters, unknown unto Adamas, he preently acquainted the Nymph and Prince Godomar, who ent ome Troops of Hore to cour the ways all the night long, and appointed Damon to have a vigilant eye unto the Walls and Gates, and places mot neceary to be guarded. But by fortune, jut before the Gates were hut, Leontidas returned from Lions, to the great joy of Prince Godomar, for he did paionately deire to hear from Prince Sigimond his Brother; he went therefore preently to the Nymph, not doubting but Leontidas would be there, where he found Roanira and Dorinde in her Cloet, and the Nymph thought it fitter to hear his report in private, rather then in publique.

div.head: The Sequel of the Hitory of DORINDE and Prince SIGISMOND.
div.p:
AS oon as Leontidas was entered, and done all due reverence unto the Nymph, to Godomar, and to the Princes; Madam (aid he,) I come from a place where I have received all manner of honour, and all manner of dicurteie; honour from Prince Sigimond, and dicurteie from King Gondebaut: And that you may undertand all things in order, be pleaed to know Madam, that according to the command which I received from Prince Godomar, I came into Lions, not acquainting any from whom I came; As oon as it was night, I made the caue of my Voyage known unto Prince Sigimond, and beeeched him to admit <>
• nto the peech of him. That Prince was indeed kept
a prioner in his houe by command from Gondebaut, but not o cloe as ome report, nor o but any may peak with him when he pleae, and almot every night he goes out and viits the Princes Clotilda. As oon as ever, he heard of my arival, he ent one of his men unto me to bring me up a back pair of tairs into his cloet, where preently after he came and received me with o kind a countenance, as made it evident I was welcome unto him. The firt quetion he asked me was, how the Prince his brother did; but the econd was, not taying for an anwer to the firt, how the fair Dorinde did, and o empathically, as I aw his heart was in his tongue; and after he had asked me many particular quetions concerning her, Cavalier (aid he) I beeech you excue my paionate curioity, for the very truth is, I do love that fair one above my life.

Dorinde at this bluhed, and held her hands before her face: Nay, nay, fair one, replied Leontidas, never bluh at what I ay, for mot auredly he loves you beyond my capacity of language to expres, and then he continued: The Prince then thus excuing himelf, he asked me, Madam, how you did, and offered himelf to ait me in all things that conduced to your ervice: for, aid he, I am much obliged unto her for her merit, but much more for the kindnes he hews unto Dorinde, as I am informed by a Souldier belonging to Clorantes, who followed my brother under pretence of being one of his men, and o got into Marcelles, where he aw Dorinde, and the honour which the Nymph did unto her: then returned at fat as he could, and made report of it to the King, who upon this information dipatched away Alerantes to the Nymph, upon the mot impertinent Embaie that ever was ent unto uch a Princes.

After this dicoure I preented your Letters unto him Madam, and that from the Prince; and becaue he aw none from Dorinde, I perceived him to be a little atonihed and ad, which made me ay unto him, I keep this to preent unto you at more leaure, auring my elf that it does not import any buines of tate: but he taking it, and giving it many a kis, This, this, aid he, is it which mot imports my buines, and opening it he found thee words.

body.head: DORINDES Letter unto Prince SIGISMOND.
body.p: MAy I believe that this tetimony which Dorinde gives of her remembering Prince Sigimond, will be welcome unto him when I et before mine eyes my being abandoned to the mercy of the Wolves, and all manner of injurious Fortune, I believe not: If I give credit unto the Prince your brother, I believe yes; but when I conider how all men have hitherto failed me, O how oon am I of another faith? What then wilt thou do Dorinde? let he hould bely the opinion he has of this Prince, I will believe that he is no deceiver, and that he does love me; and therefore I will love, honour, and erve him, that if he do deceive me, he may have left no excue either before the gods or before men. As a conequent therefore of this reolution, I do aure you Sir, that I will be no more Dorinde when I am not yours.

div.p:
O Dorinde (aid he as oon as he had read this Letter) O my dearet Dorinde, how much caue hat thou to complain againt me? and how much caue have I to complain againt my Fortune? Cavalier (aid he unto me) were you ever in love? And eeing me mile without giving him any anwer, if ever you were in love, continued he, I would not excue the raptures of my affection; but if hitherto you have been exempted from that paion, I beeech you to wave your judgement of me, until you become a lover, and then I will give you leave to ay
what you will of me. I knew by this that no other buines was to be talked of, till all was dicoured of concerning Dorinde; and therefore I anwered him, I am not o ignorant of that paion Sir, but that I know it to be one of the greatet, and one of the mot jut: mot jut, becaue nothing can be more reaonable then to love that which is lovely; and mot great, becaue Nature and Will does mot violently prompt us unto it. And therefore, I was not only charged with a Letter from the fair Dorinde, but I have alo a preent which the Prince your brother hath ent unto you, and which I aure my elf will not be altogether unwelcome to you.
Then going to the door, I fetched Dorindes picture, which I commanded one of my men to bring. When I opened it, he fixed his eyes o upon it, and was o ravihed, that he eemed himelf a tatue.

At lat, returning to himelf, and conidering the pains I took in holding it o long, he made ome excues unto me for it, yet till could not chue but look upon it and admire: after a long contemplation he cat his eyes upon the Shepherdes habit wherein he was drawn, O (aid he) how this Shepherdes does well all thoe upon the banks of Lignon with envy? Mot true, anwered I, and therefore, Sir, he tayed o little amongt them, but came amongt the Nymphs of Amais, where though in the plain habit of a Shepherdes, yet he appears like unto a Diana amongt her Nymphs. Upon this he commanded me to relate unto him the whole Fortune of Dorinde, and by what good Genius he was advied to retire her elf unto Amais: which to atifie, I told him all that I had learned from her own mouth, from Merindor and Periander: I oberved, that when I related unto him the frights wherein he was when Duriana left her, he ighed everal times, as grieving that he was not with her; but when he heard what cruelty Clorantes would have hewed unto her, and in what a pitiful condition he was, when Merindor, Periander, and Bellimartes recued her. O mot cruel Father, aid he, couldt thou have eyes, and ee Dorinde thus wronged by the appointment? And when he heard of Bellimartes his death in that quarrel: Dear friend, aid he, thou art a greater gainer in thy death then in thy life, and aure thy elf we do all envy thee in the honour thou hat got in betowing thy life o nobly: To be brief Madam, this Prince did o reent every thing that concerned this fair Lady, that I verily believe never any was inpired with a more noble love then he. Having every way atisfied his curioity as well as I was able: he opened the ret of the Letters, and they being only Letters of credence, I acquainted him with every thing according to your commands, and particularly with your joyes to ee Dorinde in uch a place where you might erve her for his ake, which you aured him you would do, and hold her as dear in your eteem as Galathea her elf: afterwards I related unto him all that I had in commiion from the Prince his brother, and how deeply he reented every thing that concerned him: to be brief, I omitted nothing which I had in command; unto which he anwered with uch abundance of thanks, as I plainly aw how much he thought himelf obliged unto you in the behalf of Dorinde. But when I acquainted him with the deign of Polemas, and of King Gondebaut to make him Lord of that tate, and with the Letters which he had written and ent by Clorantes, which imported the death of Clidemant, and invited Polemas to take up arms, offering unto him all favour and aitance: I do olemnly protet and wear (aid he) that laying aide all repects of a on to a Father, I will never as long as I live, uffer uch an injury to be done unto the Princes: I have hitherto carried my elf with all humility and weetnes; but if he do arm, I will unvail my elf, and declare in behalf of the Nymph, with all my friends and confederates: for beides the particular interet which I have, the general title of a Cavaleir, does oblige me to this jut defence. Upon this he acquainted me with the correpondencies, which he held with the Dukes and Earls of high & low Burgundy, for o he called all thoe Provinces which are on both ides the Ararri he told me what great forces he could have from the Hudeois and Allobrogians, and aured me that he hould draw after him the better half of the Souldiery that were in his Fathers Kingdome, and that thoe who did not follow him, would not take arms againt him: Afterwards I acquainted him with the Letters which for
an umbrage of my voyage were ent from you unto the King; alo I acquainted him, how I had it in charge from you to expres your joys at the coming of Prince Godomar into your Court where you would endeavour to do him all manner of ervice, both for his own merit • , and in repect of the King, eeming not to know of any mi-undertandings that were betwixt them; which at the firt he laughed at, and told me the excue was good, but that Gondebaut would not take it o; and therefore I advie you to conceal the Letter (aid he) and only demand audience, which I am ure he will not permit; but on the contrary, will commit you to cutody, to the end you may not have a ight of me, and therefore have a little patience, and I will preently give you an anwer; which he preently did, and charged me to tell you, that his obligations unto you were o great, that he would never ret until he had acquitted himelf, and in the mean time commanded me to aure you, that as oon as Polemas took the field, he would do the ame with his friends, under a pretence of Aiting the Prince his brother: That if the King came himelf in peron to aid Polemas, he would then openly take Arms alo, and come in peron, being reolved either to die, or to defend you againt all the puiance of the earth.

As for Dorinde (aid he) pray tell her, that I am much more hers then my own, and that ere long he hall receive all deireable aurances of it. Then Madam, being parted from the Prince, I retired to my Lodging the next morning o fortunately, that none aw me either in going or returning from him.

But the next morning, as oon as I let Gondebaut know that I was come unto him from you, he fell into uch a paion, that he commanded me upon pain of death to get out of Lions within an hour, and preently et a Guard of Souldiers upon me, as Prince Sigimond foreaw; I anwered him, who brought this meage from him, that I claimed the priviledge of the Law of Nations, to be afe from all harm; and having done my chief buines with Prince Sigimond, I took hore, and made all the peed I could to this Town, the news being all over the Province, that Polemas was coming to beiege it with thirty thouand men.

Upon this Leontidas held his peace, and preented the Letters from Prince Sigimond unto the Nymph, unto Prince Godomar, and unto Dorinde: And becaue the lat of thee did not deire to have any witnees at the reading of her Letter, he retired into Daphnides chamber.

In the mean time, upon the intelligence of Leontidas, it was thought neceary to end unto Lindamore, to let him know, that he was to take heed of King Gondebau •
and aure himelf in Prince Sigimond; that in his return he hould come by the Picts and the Boyens, and bring with him all thoe Forces which the Queen Argira and the Prince Roilion would give him: Then conidering who was the fittet meenger for this voyage, Galathea remembring the dicoure which Leonide told her he had with Fleurial, he propoed him as the fittet to be truted, who could pas away without upition, and who knew the way. Every one approving of him, he was preently dipatched; and having received his Intructions, departed the ame night, being charged to have a mot pecial care to hide his Letters, o that if he were taken by Polemas, yet that they hould not be found.

In the mean time, Dorinde got into a corner of Daphnides chamber, with a Wax candle in her hand, and abundance of joy in heart at the News which Leontidas told her; there he broke open the Letter which Prince Sigimond had ent unto her, and found thee expreions.

body.head: Prince SIGISMONDS Letter unto DORINDE.
body.p: I Mut needs confes, my Fairet, that Dorinde has uffered abundance of orrows, but I do deny that they have been greater or more enible then mine own: I need no excue either towards Gods or men for failing in that affection, which I have promied unto you: For the Gods do know how pure it is, and without the leat tain: And men do ee that it is the tyrannie of a Father, which to my orrow hindered me from keeping you company. Perhaps your doubts of me might make you accue my Love as imperfect: But Heaven will not let me harbour any uch thought: For I am confident the grandeur of my affection will oblige you to love me for ever.

div.p: Dorinde read over this Letter everal times, and every time he oberved ome new expreion of Prince Sigimonds affection, which welled her with o much joy, that he thought he could never read it oft enough; and doubtles he would have been longer, if he had not been diverted by Galathea, who came to viit Daphnide, and tell her what news Leontidas had brought concerning the Rebellion of Polemas, which now was openly poken of.

But in the mean time, Adamas who had intelligence from all ides of the great Forces of Polemas, and what hate he made to fall upon the Nymph, he now undertood by his Spies, that the Artillery, and all Engines of War were gone out of the Arenal of Sarion, and that his Army began to march; whereof advertizing the Prince, Alcidon, and Damon, they all thought it expedient to end out a party of Hore to dicover, and to cour the ways, and in the mean time to appoint every one his tation where he was to fight: and becaue they imagined the enemy intended a torm, they prepared themelves with every thing neceary to utain it. But Adamas who could not imagine that Polemas would ever think of carrying the place before he had made a breach, unles it was upon hopes of ome intelligence, he therefore moved unto them to change the everal quarter •
• f the Souldiery in the Town o as being often hifted, thoe that end Polemas any Intelligence, cannot tell what Quarter will fall unto their lot; and perhaps, if we keep obervant eyes, we may dicover who they are and what Intelligence is given, as oon as he to whom it is ent.

This counel was approved of as good, and to prevent uch things not only at this time, but alo during all the Siege, it was appointed that every night the Quarters hould be changed: And becaue no quetion was made of any but the Townmen, they reolved that the walls and the Ports hould be guarded only by trangers, and that the Townmen hould be kept together in a gros Body, to relieve any place in caes of neceity: An Order which at this time aved the Town: For Merontes who had the Guard of one the Ports committed unto him, had promied to et it open when Polemas hould begin his general torm.

All the night then was pent in hifting the guards from one place to another; and about an hour before day, the party of Hore which Alcidon ent out to dicover the enemy, began to hear the noie of the Army, and to ee the lights which conducted the Artillery; for the night being extreamly dark, they were forced to light ome Links, that the carriages might be directed which way to chue. Alcander who commanded the Hore, though he was ure of the Armies coming, yet would he not return, till he could carry the news upon more certainty; yet thinking it neceary to make it known unto Prince Godomar, he ordered his brother to return with even or eight hore, and give an account of what they
had een and heard: and continuing on his way with about fifty Archers, he hid himelf and them amongt ome buhes which grew cloe by the high way, where he had no ooner placed himelf and his Sentinels, but day began to break, and he appointed even or eight of his men to tand in the high way, and when they dicovered the Army coming then to run away towards the Town, as if they were affrighted, purpoely to make them follow them in diorder: o it fortuned, that when it was light enough to ee, the Army appeared dicovering thoe whom Alcander had et in the high way did begin to follow them; and eeing none but thee even or eight men, they ee purs to hore, and rid after them in great diorder, out of an earnet deire which every one had to be the firt which hould do any ignal act. Above two hundred hore paed by the place where Alcander was, in this confuion; who coming out of his ambucado, did charge them o furiouly, that their hores being almot all out of breath, and the riders urprized, o that except three or four, who were very well mounted, and fled away, all of them were either killed or taken: But it concerned Alcander to make a peedy retreat, for immediately three great bodies of hore purued him to the very gates, where Damon received him with abundance of welcome; but they had not leiure to tand upon very many Complements: For the main Body of the Army appearing, every one betook himelf to his defence. Alcidon would have gone out with his hore, but the Prince at the upplication of Adamas, would not permit him; becaue not being well aured within, by reaon of much correpondency which they feared it was not afe to part from their hore, which was their greatet afety. Alcidon in obedience to orders, contented himelf to tay in the Town, and dipoed of his men unto thoe places that were aigned unto them to repule the Aault, which they foreaw would be very great. Peliodontes was already come up to the Town with his hore, and facing it till the Foot were alo come up, he et on foot certain Archers to begin the Approches: but thoe of the Town allying out by command from Damon, and under the conduct of Lucindor, did o repule them, that had it not been for their Hore, they had fated as ill as their Forlorn Hope: At lat the three Bodies of the Army being arrived, they of the Town prepared themelves for defence.

Marcelles is o eituated, that towards Mount Verdune and Iaures, there is both Plains and Mountains. The Catle (which tands at one end of the Town, is a mot afe Ram part unto it from the Mountains, tanding o high, that it is almot inacceible: for beides the Rock upon which it is eated, there is a torrent which paeth between the Mountain and the Catle, and erves for uch a Ditch as is impaible. The Avenues in all other places are very difficult; the Ditches deep, and the Wall • well •• anked with Towers very corredondent.

When Polemas came firt, not needing any view of the place, he knowing it very well, all his Infantry were drawn round the Town in form of a Half Moon, and being within Bowe hot of the Walls; the Cros bow men and Engineers began to play, and covered the Battlements of the Town with clouds of tones and arrows. In the mean time making paage for their Engines over the Ditch wherein was no water, they filled it up with abundance of Faggots and Hurdles in many places; then paing over thee Hurdles, and bringing abundance of Ladders, they ran to the Walls on all ides at one time: and which was mot admirable, all things were done upon uch a udden, that they who were upon the defenive part, were no ooner upon the Battlements, but they found them full of hooks, which had Ladders fixed to them, and men of all ides mounting them: the Cranes alo were lifting up men in Baskets, who were ready to tep upon the walls; which did o atonih thoe within, eeing themelves aaulted on all ides at once, that one could not run to help another, every one having enough to do in his own defence.

In the mean while Polemas went round about encouraging his men, and looking whether Merontes would open the Gate unto him, according to his promie. But they within taking heart, did mot couragiouly oppoe this furious aault, ome with halbards, and others with clubs, knocking down the enemy from the Walls. But uch was the reolution of the Aailants, that ome were no ooner knocked down, but others were in their places. At lat, thoe within be-thought
themelves of great Sythes ixed unto long Poles, with which they cut in pieces the cordage of their Ladders, Cranes, and other Engines: and thee Engines being that which mot troubled them, this invention was well thought upon.

But Polemas, who would needs hew unto Alerantes the valour of his Army, he caued his other great Engines to be brought called Tortoyes, and with them they mounted a great bridge of hurdles, as high as the walls, on which fourty men might go abret: Then he caued three thouand men with targets and words, the toutet in all the Army, to mount this bridge, which they did, and came to handy blows with them on the walls.

Now was the Town in great danger to be forced, and had not Damon come to that place, it had been impoible they hould have made any long reitance; but his coming was uch an encouragement to his men, and o great a terrour to his enemies, that it became a fierce dipute: beides, he caued a great quantity of boyling oyl and brimtone to be brought, and threw it upon the enemy with o many artificial fireworks, that they were not able to endure them: Many were wounded, and many faining to be o, began to retreat; which Prince Godomar perceiving, he opened a Sally Port, and ent out two hundred men under the conduct of Ligdamon, who etting artificial fires to their bridge of Hurdles which bore up the Tortoyes, and which kindled upon uch a udden, that mot of thoe that were upon them were detroyed: In this diorder the two hundred which allied out made a mot mierable laughter, for fear entring into the hearts of Pomas his men; they made no defence, but leaving all their Engines and their Arms, they fled away: In o much as thoe of the Town had time enough to burn all their Engines, Ladders, Hurdles and Faggots.

Polemas who aw his men thus killed and burned, and then not able to relieve them, for the bridge was all on fire, he began to cure both againt heaven and Fortune, for failing him in his firt attempt: and he was o extreamly vexed at this repule in the preence of Alerantes, that had it not been very late, doubtles he would have made a econd attempt; but his councel advied him to defer it until next morning, when the fire would be extinguihed; telling him that his Souldiers were weary, that it was late, and neceary to lodge them in uch a place of ecurity, that thoe within the Town could not hurt them in the night. The Army therefore making a retreat ome two or three miles ditant, they encamped themelves that night under a hill, whoe cituation was o advantageous, as they thought themelves in afety, and o contented themelves with that natural fortification for that night.

In the mean time thoe that were ent to the banks of Lignon to eiz upon Alexis were conducted by their guide into a little grove cloe by the houe of Atrea; where hiding themelves, they tayed till it was day. O what what a trange alteration did thoe trees now find? Formerly they were wont to be the harbour and hade of harmles of lovers, but now become a receptacle of ravenous Rebels and inhumane ravihers.

As Fortune was, Celadon waked that morning betimes, and as it was his cutome very often, he put on Astreas clothes: Then, after he had looked a while upon her as he lay in bed, with Diana and Phillis, and eeing her to leep very oundly, he had no mind to wake her, but went to walk in the hael wood, which was cloe by the houe, and there entertain himelf with his own thoughts. Thoe who lay hid in the next Grove, aw him come forth; but thinking him to be Astrea, by reaon of her garments, they tirred not, but kept as cloe as they could, auring themelves that Alexis would not be long after, in which they were not mitaken: for Atrea waking preently after, and finding the windows open, and Alexis neither in bed nor in the chamber; my companions (aid he and waked them) we are very luggards, Alexis is up and gone to walk without us; upon this, putting her arms out of bed, he took the Druides clothes, and her extream deire to be with her, made her ue all the hat that poibly he could and went out of the chamber ooner then her companions, and before they were half dret, auring her elf to find Alexis in the grove of Hazels; for there it
was he mot delighted to walk: She had no ooner et her foot out of the houe, but thoe that waited for her, dicovered her; and let they hould fright her back again to the houe; they lay till untill he was a good ditance thence, then compaed her about, eized upon her, and do what he could, et her before a horman, who held her before him in his arms whilt he wept, and cryed out for help.

Great was the wonder of this woman to ee her elf hurried away in this manner, but much greater grief and wonder was it to Celadon, who running to the place where the Shepherds ued to meet, in hopes of help to recue, could do nothing but cry out for help; but knew not what to do: he enquired which way thee Ravihers went, and ran after them, till not knowing what to do but to die near Atrea. He followed the track of their hores, more like a mad woman then a Shepherdes of Lignon; crying, or rather howling, after thee Ravihers: calling out for help from the gods, from men, from animals, from trees, from rocks, from the river Lignon, from all things he either aw or could think upon, but all in vain; for thee Souldiers having got what they came for, they rid away as fat as they could; and thinking to find Polemas at Surieu, they took that way, but when they came near, and heard he was gone to Marcelles, but they went thither, and by Fortune, came when Polemas having lodged his Army, was harking unto Ligonias and Peledontes, who were telling him what los they had received at this aault: the number of the dead amounting to above two thouand, and the wounded as many more at the leat: And when he was in the height of his anger, thee Souldiers preented Atrea unto him, under the notion and habit of Alexis: when he firt heard of it, he rejoyced exceedingly, and commanding her to be brought into his preence, his anger had o tranported him, that it was a hundred to one, but he would have done ome violence unto her; yet he keeping her elf at an humble ditance, and ad behaviour, he was ahamed to offer any violence to a woman, epecially in the preence of Alerantes, and ome other Cavaliers that were in his Tent. But having looked a while upon her: Come hither (aid he unto her) thou child of the mot wicked father that ever lived; what do you think I caued you to be brought hither for? I cannot tell Sir, (anwered he, and looked weetly upon him) But O the unreitable power of beauty? This Polemas, who flamed with fury, and breathed nothing but death and blood againt this woman: he was no ooner touched with the Luter of her eye, but as now melts before the Sun, o his fury and his rage did vanih at her beauty; yet making ome reitance againt the firt glance: O mot mierable daughter of a Father, far unworthy of uch a child. To morrow (aid he) thy body hall be a covering to my whole Army; for I will have thee fatned to the points of everal Pikes, and oppoed againt the blows of thoe wicked Rebels in the Town: and in this condition halt thou go with a torch in thy hand, and et fire to the gates of that Town. Sir (anwered Atrea) if ever I did you any wrong let the gods forake me: and if I be innocent, let them defend me: as he uttered thee words, tears flowed from her eyes, which moved compaion not only in Polemas, but all that aw her. Yet eigning the contrary, if thee tears (aid he) could mollifie the heart of Adamas, and make him open the gates of the Town, they might do you ome good; but otherwie aure your elf, they will do no good at all.

Atrea now aw, that they took her for Alexis; and though he looked for a mot certain death, yet would he die rather then dicover her elf; hoping by this means to ave the life of Alexis, who otherwie would doubtles be taken, and brought into her room. Her deire therefore to die for her, moved her to ay thus: I with Sir, my father had no occaion to wih you ill, but to think that the conideration of my life or death will move him to do any thing againt his duty, is infinitly to deceive your elf. for what will it advantage him whether I live or die; you know Sir, that we who are as it were cat out into the world, are commonly but hindrances to our parents. We hall ee (aid Polemas) how he will take it; for let him aure himelf henceforward, that he has nere a daughter: The los wherewith you menace him, replied Astrea, will not much trouble
him nor me. Upon this Polemas commanded he he hould be afely guarded until Silvia came, and afterwards to be bound together, becaue the next morning they hould run both the ame fortune. This command was no ooner given, but they brought a Shepherdes who deired to peak with her. As oon as Atrea aw her, he knew her to be Alexis in her clothes; Oh how it grieved her to the oul • for knowing that all the ill they intended unto her, was only becaue they thought her to be the daughter of Adamas, he feared that if Alexis was known, all the harm would fall upon her; and to give her a hint of it, Oh fair Shepherdes (aid he unto her) what fate brought you hither, where they eek only for me, as being the daughter of Adamas? It is fate indeed (anwered Alexis) that brought me hither, and the bet that ever was, Atrea, ince it brought me hither to undeceive thoe that took you for me. Ah Atrea (cryed out Astrea) Why hould you offer to Sacrifice your elf innocently for another.

Alexis giving her no anwer, but turning towards Polemas, who heard them, yet knew not their meanings, Sir (aid he unto him,) you ee how I am all wet and dirty, but it is by reaon of the hate I made, to prevent your errour? What errour (aid Polemas) do you mean? Your errour (replyed he) in taking this Shepherdes for me, who am the Daughter of Adamas. How? (aid Polemas) are you the daughter of that wicked man? Sir (anwered he) if you call Adamas wicked, I am the daughter of him you call o. Sir (anwered Atrea) believe her not, ome ditemper in her Brain makes her peaks thus, he is Atrea the daughter of Alces and Hyppolita, and I am the daughter of the great Druide Adamas, as indeed you may ee by my habit: And becaue thoe who were tying the hands of Atrea did tay upon this dipute, he held her hands unto them; Nay, nay, aid he, tye only mine, for I aure you I am the Druide Alexis. But Alexis on the contrary oppoed her, Sir (aid he, thruting away the hands of Astrea, and holding her own) let not her clothes deceive you, for we changed them this morning, as we many times were accutomed to do: Conider that he is too young to have been o long at Carnates, as I have been: If you pleae to ask her any particular quetions concerning the Druides daughters, and of their Statutes, I dare ay her anwers will let you ee he attributes to her elf more then is her due.

Polemas and all the company were even ravihed with admiration at this contet, which of them hould be the party expoed to death. After he had a while looked upon them both, and conidered how vehemently they maintained their caue; Alas poor illy wenches (aid he unto them) Why hould you thus dipute about the matter? Do you think any great recompence will be given unto her that is the daughter of Adamas? No, no, you are much mitaken, for all he mut expect, is a mot certain death: and to morrow he hall be tyed to the points of our Pikes, with a Link in her hand, and hall et fire upon the Gate of the Town, where he can look for no les then death, either from their hands, or from ours, unles paternal affection move the heart of her wicked father to open the Gates, and let us enter. Sir (aid Alexis) I knew as much before, and my compaion upon this innocent Shepherdes, moved me to make all the hate I could, left he hould uffer thoe pains that are due unto me. And why (aid Polemas) do you think them due unto you? Becaue they ay (anwered he) that the child is to bear the iniquity of the Father; and ince o, It is not reaonable that I who am Alexis hould not uffer for Adamas who is my Father, but Atrea who is only an innocent Shepherdes? Sir (aid Atrea and interrupted) thee arguments which Atrea urges, moves me to tell you again, that he is out of her wits, and that I am the ame whom my habit peaks me; and I would not have that harmles Shepherdes expoe her elf to death for me; It is I that ought to pay for my Father, and not you Atrea, whom it nothing concerns.

Alexis then interrupting; Ah fairet Shepherdes (aid he unto her) What a mot trange errour are you poeed withal? Why hould you without any reaon oon deire to end your days! Preerve your elf for the happines of him that mut enjoy you, he till the glory of Forrets, and an honour unto the Banks of Lignon. Let me pay what I owe unto Nature, as the daughter of Adamas, and do not deprive me of that honour I hall have by uch a death. Sir (continued he
and turned to Polemas, you may be ure that only one of us can be the daughter of Adamas; and I wear unto you, by all that is acred, that this Shepherdee whom you ee before you, is not Alexis the daughter of Adamas, but is Atrea: Send her back therefore without any harm, and expoe me to as many deaths as you hall pleae. Can you imagine that I who expect nothing but a death to morrow, hould perjure my elf to day? Atrea, who aw that Polemas was inclinable to the perwaions of Alexis; O Sir, aid he, I wonder you hould be led into uch an errour by the perwaions of this woman. You mut know, that ever ince he lot her father and her mother, and ince he her elf fell into the river Lignon, her judgement and intellectuals have been much ditempered: o, as ometimes he will fancy her elf to be a Druide, as now he does, ometimes a Shepherd, nay ometimes a Cavalier, and rage againt all uch as will not believe her: Pity her good Sir, I beeech you, and end her home to her uncle Phocion, who doubtlee is looking for her, and in fears, let he hould throw her elf into ome Pool, or the river Lignon, as before he did.
This dipute had lated longer, if Polemas, fearing let this difference hould turn to confuion, had not interrupted them.

Well, well (aid he unto them) it is enough: I will agree you; then addreing himelf unto Alexis. Are you Alexis (aid he unto her) the daughter of Adamas, the mot pernicious villain upon earth? Every one, anwered he, takes me to be the daughter of Adamas the Grand Druide; and under the notion of that Adamas, I do acknowledge my elf to be his daughter. Then turning to Atrea, and you, aid he, are you the daughter of this Adamas? Certainly I am, anwered he, look upon the clothes which I were. Since, aid he, you are both the daughters of that villain, you hall both be treated accordingly. Upon this he commanded them to be both tied together, and guarded afely till the morning, till keeping an eye upon Atrea as he went out of the room, and aying, It was a thouand pities o fair a woman hould have uch a devil to her father: but ambition, which is a monter that will admit of no companion, as oon as he was out of his ight, made him quite forget all her merits.

Polemas his intention was to expoe Silvia to the blows of the Town, and Alexis alo, as well to try whether the Nymph and Adamas would yield it to ave them alive, as to hew the world how deeply he reented the death of his friends, in the peron of Climanthes; of which Silvia and Leonide were principally accued. This was the reaon, that when he departed from Surieu to torm Marcelles, he left her under afe cutody in the Catle: Silvia being of a timorous nature, did nothing but dream all night of mortal accidents, and thought her elf to be in the midt of Pikes and Arrows. Which o affrighted her, that he tarted out of bed all tears and fears. As oon as it was day, and finding no ret in her bed, he got up ooner then her cutome: and ometimes walking up and down the chamber, and ometimes looking out of the window, he paed away ome hours with as much inquietude as he did in the night time.

div.head: The equel of the Hitory of LIDIAS.
div.p:
BEing thus leaning and looking out of the window towards the high way, he thought that he aw Ligdamon very carelely coming that way: When he was omething near, he coughed purpoely to make him look up; but he looking upon her, he turned another way very indifferently. She thought that he did o fear of being known, but eeing him come and go everal times, and at every time he making the ame igns unto him, he wondred extreamly he hould never take any notice of her; epecially, being in place where, if he would, he might have poke unto her, or at the leat have made ome igns. But that which almot made her mad, was, when he aw another tranger coming; and running unto him, embraced him with many expreions of joy: he thought that then Ligdamon looked up to the window to ee whether he was there: which he perceiving, he retired a little, and looked one
of a corner, to ee what they did: Then he aw the firt carraes were nothing to the econd; and this woman ued all poible getures to expree her joyes in meeting with him whom he took for Ligdamon.

This ight tung Silvia to the oul, and made her fling away from the window in pite, and go into the furthet part of the room: where tanding long till and peaking not a word, at lat he cryed out: O who would ever be o mad as to build upon the fidelity of men, or trut their diembling oathes? Is any man alive honet, ince Ligdamon is not? Ligdamon, who as Egides told me, would have poioned himelf rather then be any others but mine? Ligdamon, who lighted all the favours of Amerina? Ligdamon, who within thee three dayes was ready to die for the love of me, and who vowed himelf mine for ever! O what a mot ad fate it is to be a woman! If he love, he is ure to be deceived: if he love not, he is even tired with the importunities of men: he cannot exempt her elf, unlee he give her elf to be devoured by thoe fierce and fale Animals.

The very truth was, the affection of Ligdamon, had made a deep impreion upon the haughty oul of Silvia; and now eeing her elf mitaken in her opinion, her proud pirit could not endure it, without a bitter reentment: But yet he was much mitaken; for he whom he took to be Ligdamon was Lidias: who following Melander, and Melander the fale Lidius, were come into Forrets: and he who expreed o many joyes and carrees, was Amerina; who thinking him to be the ame he came withal from Rothomagues, was urprized with abundance of joy to meet him in that place. Had Silvia looked out at the window, perhaps he might have heard ome words which would have undeceived her: for preently after the firt alutations and expreions of joy, he began to upbraid him, Well, well (aid he unto him) is this your • ay for me as you promied? Ah Lidias, who will needs be Ligdamon, if my happy fortune had not brought me hither, where could I have hoped ever to have met with you? In aying o he renewed her carrees, which Lidias received as from a peron that he did but half love; being now o obliged unto Melander, that his affection was more unto her then the other: and if he did now return carrees, it was only out of memory of former paages, then any preent affection: But when he heard her call him Lidias, that would needs be Ligdamon, and tax him with promies of taying for her, he was the mot atonihed man in the world? and becaue he knew not what to anwer, I ee, friend (aid he unto him) that you thought to be thus rid of me, and that I hould never find you out in a trange Countrey: but love is a good guide, and will alwayes direct the heart of a lover towards the party loved.

I mut confee (anwered Lidias) that I am not only mute, but amazed, and know not a word of any thing you ay: for fair Amerina (aid he) what's this you tell me of Lidias, that would Ligdamon, and of a place where I promied to tay for you?

How? (replied he and look'd him in the face) have you o oon forgot our coming out of Rothomagues, our journey to Neomagues, the caue of your departur without me, your leaving me in prion, my clothes which you wore, and the place where you promied to tay for me? O heavens (cryed out Lidias) do I leep, or do I wake? What's all this that Amerina tells me? It is above thirty months ince I went from Rothomagues, by reaon of a duel which I fought for your ake againt Oronthes, and I aure you, that ince I never tirred out o • great Brittain, but when I came to ait Neutrians againt the Franks; and landing at Callice, Lipandas the kinman of Oronthes took me prioner, from whence I had never been releaed, but for the aitance of one whom I followed into this countrey: but as for you Amerina, believe, I never o much as heard of you, until I now unexpectedly met you.

How? aid Amerina, were not you taken prioner by the Neutrians in a battel againt the Franks? were not you condemned to be devoured of Lyons? Did not you kill two of them very courageouly? were not you him whom I recued from that danger, by asking you for my husband was it not you, who thinking
to drink poyon upon the marriage day, did only drink a dormitive? To be brief, was it not you whom I followed hither, and for whoe ake I have run o many hazards and dangers? Aure your elf, anwered Lidias, that I am not, nor do I know any more of any thing which you have named, then a child newly born. Amerina, folding arms, and going back a pace or two, did eriouly look upon him, are not you that Lidias, aid he, who would not own that name, but would needs be Ligdamon? I do not know who that Ligdamon is (anwered he) but I am ure that I am Lidias: O heavens! anwered he, am I Amerina? or am I out of my wits? Then being ilent a while, and thinking that Lidias pake very freely, he began to doubt of him whom he took for Lidias, and who had o much tormented her by his reemblance; then he asked him everal times, whether he was that Lidias who fought with Arontes, and he anwering that he was. O good gods (cryed he) is it poible that two men hould o extreamly reemble, as one could not know the one from the other; and that it is not two or three perons that are deceived, but all: I know not (aid Lidias) of whom you peak, but I am ure that I am Lidias, who has not een you this thirty months before: and to tetifie, that it was I who fought with Arontes (ee, aid he, and took off his hat) the mark of the wound which I received when I killed him. For you may remember, that flying unto your houe, you topped the blood with your handkerchief, I having not time to tay the dreing, for fear I hould be taken: O heavens (aid he) I do remember very well: where was my eyes and my memory, that I hould not take notice of this mark before? Now am I to my great contentment convinced of my errour; and then embracing Lidias again, he related unto him all that had paed betwixt her and Ligdamon: at which Lidias admired, and could not conceive it poible that two perons hould be o alike, as not to find ome difference either in face, voice, or geture.

No, No, Lidias (replied he) aure your elf your mother, your kindred, and all your friends were deceived in him, although he till affirmed that he was not Lidias, but one Ligdamon of that countrey; and when I chid him for his change towards me (for I thought that all he aid proceeded only from the alteration in his affection) he anwered that he was not Lidias, but one Ligdamon, who never loved any but one Silvia, nor hould he ever love any other: I was o deceived by his reemblance, that to be atified I reolved to come into this countrey, where he promied to verifie all he had aid: but when were near Neomages, a certain paenger and he fell out, and he whom I took for you, left him dead upon the place, for which we were both then prioners, and had not I helped him to ecape by lending him my clothes, I know not what might have happened unto him: for I taking his, I aid that I was his husband and he my wife: The next day I was carried before the Governour and other officers of jutice: I did not deny the fact whereof I was accued. They carried me to the Chamber where this wounded man lay in bed; when he aw me, thee clothes (aid he) are his who wounded me, but to him who wears them I have nothing to ay.

The Governer upon this looking better upon me, he knew by my hair & by my brets that I was a woman: whereat, wondring, what is the reaon (aid he) you are diguied in a habit not pooper to your ex? Sir (aid I) though I know my husband to be innocent, yet fearing the everity of jutice, I contrained him to change habits with me, and o he ecaped: I ay I contrained him, becaue he would rather have died then left me in that condition; but at lat my prayers, my ighs, and my tears, forced him away. As fortune was, this Governour had a wife who was both fair and young, and paionately loved her husband, as oon as he heard of my trick to ave my husband, he came where we were to ee me; and came time enough to plead and defend my caue: for the Governour ent for the Gaoler; asked him what was become of the man who was committed to his charge, and when he anwered that it was I, no, aid the Governour, this is his wife. Sir, aid he, if it be, then they were both women, for I aure you the other was as fair and as young as this; and this whom I here preent unto you, was delivered unto me in the ame habits you ee: Sir, anwered I, the man peaks truth; for before we were committed unto his cutody we had changed habits,
and therefore the fault is not in him. Well (aid the Governour) do you think you hall not be punihed in the habit which you wear? If my husband have done any injury, anwered I, I will willingly receive the punihment for him; but, replied he, do you not know what punihment they incur, who thus delude jutice. Be the punihment what it will, replied I, I am till the ame, and ready to receive it, o my husband may go free. The Governours wife coming in upon this, and hearing me peak thus: Sir, (aid he to her husband) the action of this woman is worthy of all honour and recompence; and all thoe that have husbands ought to take example by her, to honour her and ait her, and I our of my affection unto you, become a Petitioner in her behalf.

The Governour upon this miled; my dearet (aid he unto her) you need not petition where you may command, and you may command not only this, but my life: hereupon he commanded I hould be releaed into her hands, and he carried me to her houe, where he gave me this habit which now I wear, he carreed me beyond all expreions, and do what I could, would not uffer me to depart of four or five dayes; and I believe if I had not told her that my husband tayed for me at an appointed place, and perhaps would return to eek me, he would not have uffered me to departed o oon, o pleaing was my action unto her. But the bet was, that when I was out of the Town, and would go unto the place where this man aid he would tay for me, I had forgotten the name of the Town; yet knowing that it was in Forrets, I took towards that countrey, where ever ince I have wandred from one Town to another, not knowing whether to go, nor what place to enquire after. Lidias hearkened very attentively unto Amerina, and when he had done, fair, and dear Amerina (aid he unto her) I mut needs acknowledge my elf infinitely obliged unto you, for I ee that all you did unto Ligdamon was intended unto me, and it is my part to do you uch ervivices as uch favours merit; but as you have acquainted me with your adventures, o it is but reaonable I acquaint you with mine: wherein, if any thing dipleae you, or eem in ome ort to croe that affection which I promied unto you, yet I believe when you have eriouly conidered upon it, you will find, that to atisfie obligations received, I was contrained unto it.

Upon this, he related all that he had done in great Brittain: the courteies of Melanders kindred, the hew that he made of loving her, the manner of his leaving her without telling her, his imprionment at Callice, the reolution of Melander to fight for him againt Lipandas, how he was taken prioner by the troops of Prince Clidemont, the favour that Prince hewed in etting her at liberty: briefly, he acquainted her with his enterprize upon Callice, and the taking of that place.

But (continued he) we were no ooner maters of the place, but I ran to the Catle, and as he that was wonderous well acquainted with the prions, I went thither with an earnet deire of eeing Melander, and retoring her that liberty which he lot for my ake: but fortune which eemed to cros me in all my contentments, denied me this amongt the ret: for I found the prion doors broken open, and nothing within but fetters and hakkles: I ought every corner of the Catle in hopes of finding her, afterwards went into the Town, and enquired of her in every houe: at lat in the evening (for I pent all the night and all the next day till unet in eeking her) I undertood by ome who came from Rothomagues, that he was gone thitherward; and though I thought the friends of Arontes might procure me ome michief, if they knew me, yet o much did I think my elf obliged unto that woman, as I reolved to go thither; but when I was near Rothomagues, by chance, I met with a horman who diverted my deigne.

This man came from the Town, and rid upon a tired hore: it being my cutome to ask what news of all I met, o I did of him: Sir, aid I, can you tell me any tidings of a young man, tranger, habited after the mode of great Brittain, who went towards Rothomagues, and happily you might meet him? Sir, anwered he, if I be not mitaken, he whom you are in quet of, is called the ad Cavalier; the very ame (replied I very joyful): None Sir, anwered he, can give
you a better accompt of him then my elf, for I have accompanied him from the prion of Callice, as far as the next Town: we were both fellow prioners together, and when the Franks took the Town, and the prions all et open, this Cavalier, with whom I had intimate friendhip, deired me to how him the way unto Rothomagues; for, aid he, I have very earnet buinee there, and uch as does much import my contentment. I anwered, that I would not only hew him the way, but accompany him to the very gates, yet would not enter in, by reaon of ome great enemies I had there: o we mounted upon the firt hores we met, for all was lawful prize, and in the confuion, lipt out of the Town uneen. Then by the way I underttood, that the reaon why he made uch hate, was, to forbid the banes of a marriage betwixt one Lidias and a Lady, which was of great importance unto him; but he no ooner left me, then I aw him return out of the Town again in all hate, and asking the reaon of it; do not tay me (aid he) for I undertand that this Lidias whom I look for, is gone with her whom he intends to marry, and its thought unto a houe not far from hence, belonging to that woman: upon this, he et purs to his hore, not aying a word more unto me. Which way (aid I unto him) did he take? I cannot tell, anwered he, but I believe, towards Paris.

Thus we parted, and ever ince I have been following, hearing news of him almot every day, until I came to the Town which you named unto me, where a trange accident happened unto me: I came thither about the time that you were there, and as I alighted to ret my elf (for indeed I had rid a long journey that day) a company of ouldiers eized upon me, and carried me to prion, accuing me for wounding a certain paenger; and by what you have told me, I believe it was him whom that Ligdamon with whom you were, had wounded: heavens do know that I was altogether innocent of the fact, yet was I very harply ued; I lay that night with my hands and my feet fettered with iron, and the next day towards night, they carried me to the Governour of the place, who after examination, thinking me to be innocent, would have releaed me, when an officer of Jutice deired that before my enlargement, I might be brought before the wounded party who had accued me: thither was I immediately carried, and I took notice, that as oon as ever he aw me, he fetched a deep igh, and turned himelf the other way in his bed: Every one thought, (and I amongt the ret) that this igh proceeded from the pain of his wound; yet now I think that he took me for Ligdamon who wounded him, and that he would not accue me, but that perhaps being generous, he would, like a brave Cavalier, call me to anwer him in the way of arms and not of Law: but o it was, that when they asked him whether it was I who wounded him, he anwered no; and when they told him that yet it was I whom he had accued, he replied, I cry both you and him mercy, for it is not he. Upon this jutification the Governour releaed me; but my hore, and the bet things I had then about me, were then in the hands of the Gaoler and thoe that took me: I do believe, that if I had made complaint, perhaps I hould have got them again; but I thought it better to go away quietly, having heard that uch kind of uits do often cot more then they are worth: beides, deiring mot paionately to overtake her whom I followed, I directed my coure towards Forrets, becaue I undertood that he enquired the way into that Countrey.

Whilt Lidias and Amerina were talking thus together, Silvia was at every turn peeping out at the window, and as cloely as ever he could, pying and oberving their action: for not being able to hear what they aid, only ome words when they poke loud, he took notice only of their getures, and the carrees which they ued the one to the other, which tung her o to the heart, that he was divers times ready to cry out and exclaim againt thoe injuries. But as he was in thee thoughts, thoe whom Polemas ent, came unto her with intentions to carry her away as privately as they could, telling her that it was to carry her back unto Galathea, he was put then into a coach, and when he came to the place were Lidias was talking with Amerina, he did not o much as move when he looked upon her paing by; which troubled her o much, that he thought
upon nothing ele all the way, fretting againt the incontancy of all men for Ligdamons ake. She had not gone a mile further, but he aw a great number of Soulders galloping by her, and carrying Lidias bound, taking him, as he did, for Ligdamon: for Polemas was informed that Ligdamon made it his boat, that he would come and kill him in the midt of his Army, if he did not releae Silvia. Polemas, who knew what affection Ligdamon did bear unto that Nymph, he did eaily believe it, and gave a charge unto all thoe who knew Ligdamon, to eiz upon him as oon as they aw him and thee Souldiers being deceived by the reemblance which Lidias had vnto Ligdamon, finding him by chance coming towards Polemas, they eized upon him, thinking it a piece of good ervice to their mater. Amerina cryed out, that it was not Ligdamon, for he believed that they mitook him; but her cryes did no good: for thoe who took him, knew him to be Ligdamon, and went away very joyfully to preent him unto Polemas. Silvia, eeing him pae by, was nettled with two different paions at once: for he was glad to ee her elf revenged, and orry to ee him in any danger: o as when he cryed out aloud, Go diembler, and give an accompt of all thy falhoods, her heart within ilently aid, it was pity uch a Cavalier hould be o lot: as her anger made her look upon him with an eye of didain and revenge, yet, o as her affection tole from her heart ome ighs of compaion.

But on the other ide, thoe that were within the Town, though ome of them were wounded, yet did they extreamly rejoyce of the victory which they had gotten over their enemies: and all the Druides, Vaces, Eubages, and Sarronides in the Town, were commanded to render thanks unto the great Tautates: The hight Priet, the Flamins, and others, were enjoyned to go into their Temples, and thank their gods for this ignal victory.

In the mean time, the Prince, Alcidon, and Damon, went to viit the walls and the Ports, and to repair uch places as tood in any need: Adamas above all the ret took infinite pains; making it appear, that affection adds upernatural trength: for he never reted, until all the dead were interred, all the wounded put into the hands of Chirurgeons, and till he had viited every Quarter of the Town, and taken all neceary order for every thing.

Ligdamon in the mean time, who had not forgotten an unexpected relief which he had received from an unknown peron, had no ooner given the Prince an accompt of his Commiion, but retiring to his lodging, he made inquiry for him, unto whom he was o much obliged; and hearing that he was well, and that the wound he had received in his houlder was o light, that the skin was no more then cratch'd, he was extreamly glad to hear it; and the firt thing he did, would go and ee him: he found him in a chair with his arm in a carf, according to the directions of the Chirurgeons. As oon as this young man aw Ligdamon enter, he roe up to alute him, which he did with a countenance that expreed a long acquaintance: Ligdamon received his embraces with all the civility he could, as well becaue he thought himelf obliged thereunto by the rules of civility, as becaue of his particular obligation which he had received from him: Yet the tranger, who perceived he carried himelf as to a peron unknown, he had an opinion, that becaue it was omething dark he did not know him, or perhaps for ome conideration or other, would not eem to know him. After the firt alutes, and Ligdamon had enquired of his health, alo thanked him for the favour which he had done him, and the hazard wherein he put himelf: I beeech you Sir, (aid the tranger) dimie thoe who accompany you, and then I hall give an anwer unto all you ay: Ligdamon then turned to the company, deiring them to withdraw, and then the tranger began thus.

div.head: The equel of the Hitory of MELANDER.
div.p: YOu do a • k me, unthankful and peridious Lidias, how I do; and does give me thanks for that which I have this day done for you; as if you did not know, that I cannot be well unlee you be o; and that the hazard which I have this day run for you, is one of the leat whereunto I have expoed my life to preerve yours.

Forgetful and thankles man; Cant thou not remember the carrees and kindnees, which when you were in great Brittain you received in my houe, from all that had any relation unto Melander? Hat thou forgot all thoe oathes which thou o oft has worn, never to love any but this Melander? Dot think by aigning to forget thy flight from London, that all thoe who knew of thy peridy do not remember it? Is it poible thy infidelity hould o choke thy memory, as not to know that Melander, who putting on the habit of a man as thou eet her, did fight with Lipandas for thy liberty, or indeed thy life? Can it be imagined that ingratitude hould o dull thy oul, as to forget that this Meland • r, who hath now aved thy life, is the very ame, who in Callice came into the prions of Lipandas to deliver thee, and expoed her hands and feet unto etters, to releae thine?

She would have continued, but that Ligdamon interrupted her thus: Certainly I were the mot worthy not only of blame, but of extream punihment, if being o obliged as you eteem me. I hould ever loe the memory of them; but I protet before heaven, that this Lidias, whoe name you put upon me, is to me altogether unknown. How? replied Melander (and was extreamly angry) cant thou without a bluh ay, thou art not the ame, againt whom for thy ingratitude I drew my word, near Neomagues, and from whom I received a wound in my arm; I cannot ay (anwered he and was amazed) that I am the ame you mention; For I do remember, that being near the Town you named. I was aaulted by a tranger, without any caue; who was wounded; for which I was taken prioner, and got out by the help of a woman who being deceived as you are, and taking me for one Lidias, did give me her clothes, and he took hine. O my dear Lidias (aid he) if for any important reaon you deire to conceal your name, do not think me one that will reveal it; conider that o many tetimonies of my pure affection, as I have given, may well aure you that I will conceal whatoever you hall deire to hide.
