If you will, no other name but Ligdamon hall ever come in my mouth: Aure your elf my dearet friend, that my affection unto you is far above my own life, and no interet or advantage whatoever hall make we betray you: She who hath left her countrey, her kindred, her friends; She who hath hazarded her life a hundred times to ave you, can he have any interet further then to pleae you? Say unto me freely, Melander, my deigne is to be no longer Lidias, I deire the world hould think me to be Ligdamon, I would have it thought I never aw Melander, I would loe the memory of her, and thou halt o: O my dearet friend, that before I will dicover thee, I will loe the memory of thy name and my own, as long as you hall pleae: If I do betray thee, never eteem me for Melander, and drive me out of thy preence, as not worthy to bear the name of a woman who would only live to erve thee.

Wie and fair Melander, replied Ligdamon, I do not only admire at the grandure, and purity of your affection, but much more at the happines of that Lidias for whom you take me: Mot happy may he well eteem himelf, that is o perfectly loved, by o many dicreet and fair women: and certainly he is a man of mot high merit, that is thus incerely eteemed and loved: nor hould I yield unto him in happinee, by reaon of that reemblance which is betwixt us, were I in a condition to receive the good will of thoe who take me for him: But know, fair and dicreet Melander, that you are not the firt who have been deceived by my face and voice: Many have been alo mitaken, and hould I tell you that
thouands have been alo deceived as well you, I hould tell you nothing but truth: when I was brought a prioner of war unto Rhothomagues, the mother of Lidias took me for her on, and to my orrows, the whole corporation of justice condemned me to be devoured by Lions for ome homicide which that Lidias had committed; and there I had certainly perihed, if one Amerina, deceived by this reemblance, had not begged me for her husband. I relate unto you all thee things, that you may ee how much the world is mitaken in me, and that if I were the ame Lidias which you think I am, I hould think my elf obliged to you in all the ervices which you can deire; but mitake me not I beeech you, I know that I am Ligdamon, this countrey man born, where if you pleae, I am able to give you a thouand tetimonies of it: The Nymph Amais, her daughter Galathea, will tell you that I had my education under them; Adamas the grand Druide, the high Priet, the Flamines: to be breif, all the Town can tetifie that I am Ligdamon and not Lidias.

Melander was amazed at all this that Ligdamon had told her; and eeing how confidently he offered to prove all he aid, he began to doubt her mitake, though his face and peech were extreamly like to Lidias, and looking eriouly upon him, if it be o (aid he) it is a thing mot trange, that two hould be o extreamly alike, that no difference can be found, neither in face, peech, tature, behaviour, nor age: and let us ee (aid he) if there be the ame reemblance in uch things as come by accident: then going nearer him, and taking off his hat, he lifting up his hair, but not finding any mark of that wound which Lidias received in the combat with Aronthes, he was quite confounded; and going back a pace or two, I mut needs confes (aid he) that I think my elf mitaken, and that you are not the ame Lidias I look for: for he has a car in his head which you have not: and ure I am that his is uch a mark, as never will wear out.

Ligdamon, beyond expreion, glad to ee himelf delivered of this pain, but more, to know this difference, to the end he might undeceive Amerina by it, for he knew he would follow him. Would it had pleaed the gods (aid he) that I had known this difference when I was condemned for Lidias; for then it would have aved me many a dangerous adventure: The gods, anwered Melander, do every thing with uch wie providence, that none ought to complain: for as your reemblance unto Lidias had like to have cot you your life, o the ame reemblance hath aved it; for aure your elf, if I had not been deceived by your face, I had never ventured my elf o in the ditch to ave you. Alo had not I taken you for Lidias, I had never been convinced of my errour in thinking him perfideous, who perhaps is eeking me amongt the Gauls, as I did you as far as Callice: for Cavalier you mut know, that I being in prion under Lipandas, to get Lidias out, I undertood by the Gaoler, that he for whom I was a prioner, was taken by the Neutrians, condemned unto the Lions, and delivered upon condition of marrying Amerina; whether or no this was adnes unto me, let him judge that ever loved; but o it was, that after many a ad complaint, yet uch as never durt come out of my lips, for fear of being known, I languihed thus in this pain: for the life I led, could be phraed nothing but a languihment, never grieving for the condition wherein I was, but only becaue I could not ponyard my elf in the preence of ungrateful and perfidious Lidias; but when I was in greatet depair of ever getting out of that mierable place: The Franks one night, I know not how, became maters of the Town, the Gaoler h • melf et open the prion doors, and unetterd our feet, in hopes that ome Franks who were prioners amongt us would ave his life for it. But I, who extreamly deired to ee Lidias, that I might in his and Amerinas preence acrifice my life, I was no ooner at liberty, but finding ome hores which had no owners, I took one and got out of Callice, having in my company only one young man who conducted me, and being prioners together were become friends: with him I went unto Rothomagues, where I no ooner entred, but I was informed by a reverent Matron, of whom I enquired for Lidias, that he was at a houe of Amerinas his wife not far from thence, and beeeching her to tell me the way, he told me that it was in the way towards the great city of Paris. Judge you whether this news did
not ting me to the oul; but hating out of the Town, and overtaking the young man who conducted me, for he durt not enter in, by reaon of ome enemies; And I talked with him, but truly I know not what, nor which way I parted from him: But o it was, that preently after I came to this houe, where they told me that Lidias was gone three days before, with Amerina his wife, towards Forrets, upon ome buines: I preently followed after, and by the way heard oftten of them: At lat, one day, after a large journey, and when the heat of the day had almot weltred my hore, I aw a hade by the high way ide, which I thought would helter me from the extream heat of the day: The wearines of my elf and my hore made me alight, and I had no ooner tyed him to a Tree, but I pied a woman, who by what I have heard from you, I now think was Amerina: I went unto her, and asked her if it would be no offence to participate of her hade: To which he gave me a very civil anwer. At the ame time you came with ome boughs to make the place more hady: As oon as ever I cat my eye upon you, I took you, as I did now, for Lidias whom I looked for, and thought that woman to be Amerina: I mut needs confes that I was moved with everal paions; for once I was in a mind to fall upon Amerina whilt he lept, and firt to run a ponyard into her breat, and then into my own, before your face: Another time I deign'd to let the innocent woman alone and to open my own breat, and as I was dying, to take ome of my blood, and throw it in your face, upbraiding you with your infidelity: But ome good genius diverted me from thoe cruel reolutions, and contraining me to go a little further off, after a hundred different conceptions, I thought it bet to die by your own hand, and not by my own; to the end you might the more lament my death.

This being my deign, you know what igns I made unto you to eparate you from Amerina, and how violently I cat my elf upon your word, with which indeed I was wounded in my arm, but I know not how it mied my heart, for there was my intention to receive it; and I had uch an opinion of receiving it there, that when I felt the point of the word, I fancied that it had reached my heart; o as having heard that all wounds of the heart were mortal, I fancied my elf to be dead; and when I returned to my elf again, I found that I was in the hands of the Governour of Neomague. I undertood ince, that he finding me in a woon, he caued me to be taken up as dead, but the motion of thoe who carried me, did revive me; o etting me upon a hore, they carried me away; when, to my thinking, I aw you pas by my hore, very well mounted. Certainly (aid Ligdamon and interrupted) it was ome other, for I was on foot, and never left Amerina till we were both taken together. If o, replyed Melander, either it was Lidias, or ome other who reembles him, as you do: But o it was, that I told the Governour with a deep igh, it was he who had put me into that condition; and as oon as the Governour heard it, he caued him to be purued and brought to prion.

When night came, I began to think how I hould be a caue of punihing Lidias, and therefore was very orry for what I had aid: And as I was in bed the next morning, they brought me a woman in your clothes, to ee if it was he who hurt me, and I aid he was not: But I was extreamly atonished when they brought him whom I accued, for truly, I took him for you, I mean Lidias. And left he hould know me, I turned my face the other way, as I lay in my bed: and though I knew I had reaon enough to wih him ill, yet I could not find in my heart to do him any harm: o as altering my voice, I declared that it was not he, but ome other, who had taken the habit of that woman. Upon this dicharge he was releaed. I beeech you (aid Ligdamon) what became of the woman, for it was he who aved me? The Governours wife (aid he) took her off from all punihment, and is o far from all harm, that to morrow I believe he will return home. But to continue that dicoure of my mierable fortune; In the night time when I could not leep, by reaon of the wound, not in my arm, but in my heart, I made a hundred propoitions to my elf: one while I would write unto Lidias, and let him know what wrong he had done me; but I was preently off that, thinking he would but mock at my Letter, and with his Amerina, laugh at it:
Another while I would end for him, not telling who I was, and in the preence of the Governours wife, who was of a weet and pitiful dipoition, upbraid him with his peridie and ingratitude, as thinking, that hame perhap • might work more upon him then my love could. Upon this deign I lept, with a reolution to put it in execution the next morning; but I was diappointed, for that very night, as oon as ever he was et at liberty, he went privately out of the Town, none knowing which way he went,

When I heard of his departure, I was almot even mad againt my elf for letting uch an opportunity o imprudently lip; for (aid I) had I accued him, doubtles he had been tayed, and I might have executed my deign in peaking unto him before the Governours wife: And as for my fond fears of doing him any harm by way of Jutice, what greater punihment could he in Jutice receive, then a while of Imprionment, ince my wound was not neer mortal? But all this reaoning with my elf was in vain; and after a long debate, and vexing at my elf, Patience was my only remedy; and as oon as I could (which was within even or eight days) to et forward towards Forrets, where I heard you were; and as Fortune was, I came into this place where all thee Forces did rendezvouz to torm this Town: I earched every rank and file to ee if I could find you; and by chance being next him that leaped into the ditch with intention to kill you, as oon as ever I cat my eye upon you, and taking you for Lidias, I ran in to defend you, making it to appear, that nothing is tronger then Love, ince neither any corns, or offences, nor injuries, nor any thing, could keep me from expoing my life for Lidias, whom I thought that I had reaon to hate even to death.

Thus did Melander conclude the dicoure of her travels and pains; and Ligdamon preenting his hand unto her, Fair and Generous woman (aid he unto her) the life which you have this day preerved, hall be pent in your ervice; I hope you will not depart out of this Country, before you have found a full contentment. Your unparallell'd Fortunes, and dangers which beyond all hopes you have ecaped, is an argument that ome good Genius conducted you hither to preerve you. Hope therefore, and be confident that your hopes will not be frutrated: In the mean time, dipoe of me, and command me, as one that cannot be more devoted to erve you then I am. Thee offers (anwered he) are uch, as a poor woman, detitute of all help, but from the Gods, might hope for from uch a generous Cavalier as you are: I do not refue thee kind of offers, and at this time will only deire two things from you: The one, not to dicover that I am a woman; unto any: and the other, to let me live with you, to love and erve you, until uch time as it hall pleae the Gods I can hear ome news of him whom I look for: If you will pleae to grant me thee two requets, I hall live with ome contentment, having always in my eye the face of my o much loved Lidias. Ligdamon who did much eteem and admire the vertue of this woman, did grant her two requets, and with many aurances of his good will, did bid her good night, and went to et all things in good order within the Quarter that was aigned unto him: for though he had toyled all the day, yet would he not ret till he aw all right that was under his charge: and when he returned to his Lodging, he heard ome in the next houe that complained exceively. Ligdamon being very pitiful, and haring in the orrows of another, hearing this lam • ntable voice, and believing it to be ome that was wounded, he commanded one that followed him to go in, and bring him word whether the wounded man wanted any thing, in the mean time he tayed at the door: He who went in upon this errand, did ee a man tyed by the arms and legs unto a Bed pot, without any to look unto him: the light which the fire cat which was in the chimney, did make the meenger judge him to be ome tranger, and that perhaps ome had taken him prioner at the lat Sally, yet eeing no harm done unto him, and oberving that he trove all he could to draw the bed unto which he was tyed, towards the fire: What reaon (aid the man unto him) have you to complain? And why do you trive o to get near the fire? Perhaps it is to try if you can break your chains; but alas poor man, though they were looe, yet little hopes could you have to ecape a hundred Court of Guards, beides as many ports to hinder you. The tranger looking wildly upon
him, if I had no caue of complaint (anwered he) I hould be ahamed to open my mouth; but I mut die, and therefore when you thought my getting to the fire was to ecape, alas it was only that I might end this mierable life by fire; and I was o far from deiring any ecape, that the firt minute my hands were at liberty, I reolved hould be the lat of my life.

Ligdamon who was impatient, and thought it long before the man returned, he went himelf into the chamber, and eeing this man in that condition, who are thoe (aid he) who treats this prioner o cruelly? The Souldiers into whoe hands he fell, being in the next room, they came to give an accompt: Sir (aid a corporal) we did not put this man into this condition wherein you ee him, with any intentions of uing him ill; but on the contrary, we did it out of compaion; for he is o deperate, that if we had not taken a knife from him, it had been before now at his heart: o as we were contrained to tie him in this manner, let he hould kill himelf. Certainly (aid Ligdamon) he hath received ome trange misfortue, did he never tell the reaon of his depair? No, aid the corporal, nor could we ever get any thing from him, but ighs and tears. Ligdamon looking upon him, and thinking him to be a man of valour, it is pity (aid he) he hould be thus lot, perhaps he has lot ome whom he loved, for uch depairs eldome proceed from any thing but love. Then going nearer unto him, friend, aid he unto him, conider that you are a man, and by conequence, a ubject both of good and bad Fortune: after a gloomy cloud, will come a gleam of Sun-hine; after a torm of bad fortune, will come a calme of good: Cavalier (anwered the tranger) the compaion which you eem to have of my miery, makes me think you to be a man of merit: for I never knew a bae heart pity the afflicted.

This opinion which I have of you, makes me now repent my attempt of taking away your life in the lat cuffle, though I have caue enough to accue of all my wieries. Was it you (aid Ligdamon) who fell upon me in the ditch, when I caued all the enemies engines to be burned? It was I anwered he, that hould have been very orry if I have accomplihed my intent, but hould have been very glad if pour word had then taken away my life, ince it had ravihed that peron from me, for whoe ake I only deired life. I am orry, replied Ligdamon, that I was any caue of your dicontent; but you ought to think me very innocent, for in the heat of combate one can hardly tell whom they trike: yet, if my memory do not fail me, he whom I held under me, when you aaulted me, is not dead; for when he asked life of me I gave it unto him. O good gods, cryed out the tranger, is his life aved? Certainly (aid Ligdamon) I did him no hurt after he had rendred himelf, for it is not my cutome to hurt thoe who quit their arms; and beides, I could hardly do it, ince you aaulted me upon a udden: upon this, ome of thoe who were near Ligdamon at that time, did tetifie that the man ecaped, and though they aw him when he went away, yet they had o many other prioners in their hands, that they could not follow him.

O mot omnipotent Tautates (cried out the tranger, lifting up his eyes to heaven, and would have done o his hands, had they not been tyed) is it poible I hould be o happy? and that my depair hould help that peron to ecape? Certainly (aid all the company) we aw him out of the ditch: I am very glad on't, aid Ligdamon: But to ee the trange effects of inward joy; one might perceive the eyes and the countenance of this man, o to change, that he eemed not the ame he was a minute before; and addreing his peech unto Ligdamon, Cavalier (aid he unto him with a mild and temperate voice) in giving life unto one, you have given it unto two: for if he of whom I complained had died, nothing could have kept me alive; I ay he, for you mut know that though you aw her in the habit of a man, yet he is the mot generous and brave woman that ever was upon the earth: and that you may ee what caue I had to love and admire her, give me leave to relate the hitory of all my troubles. Ligdamon, who aw him much changed, and his peech more moderate and dicreet: he had an opinion, that this news had ettled his mind; and pittying to hear him talk o tyed; Stranger (aid he unto him) I hould be very glad to hear you, but am orry to
ee you in that condition; and yet I dare not uffer you to be untyed, let you hould do ome act of inhumanity againt your elf. No, no, Sir, anwered he, your courteie has more obliged me then o; and the aurance of o many perons, that he is alive whom I o much lamented, does command me to live, that I may erve both you and her. Upon this aurance (aid Ligdamon) I will command you hall be untyed: you hall go with me to my lodging, where you hall find better accomodation then in this place. This unask'd for favour (aid the tranger) obliges me to pas my word, never to forake you until you dimis me; and to tell you, that being neither any Officer nor Souldier unto your enemies, nor having paed any promie to erve them, I would never whilt I live bear arms againt you, nor ever go into your enemies army; but with a word in my hand to fight your quarrel, were it not that he, for whoe ake I am your prioner, is in their Camp, and I cannot dipoe of my elf until I have found her.

Upon this, the corporal untyed him, and he went with Ligdamon unto his lodging, where he was put into good clothes, for his own were plundered from him by thoe who took him, and thoe which remained upon him, he had torn to pieces in his rage: afterwards Ligdamon, cauing him to it down, and they two being alone in the chamber, he began thus.

div.head: The equel of the Hitory of LIPANDAS.
div.p: THoe who never knew the Grandure and Puiance of that god which is called Love, ought to learn by my example, how to honour and reverence him, unles they will incur the ame punihments which I have, for abuing thoe who did adore him, and for not doing o great reverence unto that great Deity as is due: for know Sir, that as oon as I left my Nure, I began o much to depie love, and all that followed him, that to tell me one was a lover, was enough to make me corn him, when at any time I chanced to hear of any extraordinary effect of that paion, I ued by way of mockery to ay, that they changed the name of things, and that this which they called love, was indeed madnes, and o ought to be called. When I was at any meetings, where I aw many idolizing a fair face, and were o tyed by the eyes that they could not move out of the preence of thoe fair ones, I was wont to ay, that the men did but mock the women, and the women the men; when ome would needs prove, that he was forced to a beauty, and that her charms were inevitable, I preently concluded him to be only a Sophiter, that to hew his wit would argue for, or againt any argument that was propounded. Nay more then al this, from my very infancy, to the Autumn of my age, I could never find in any of thoe who were cryed up for uch high beauties, any thing more amiable then in other women: So as I may ay, that as there are ome who are born blind, others deaf, others without a tate, or at leat a tate different from others: o was I born without any entiment of love or beauty, and all my delectation at that time was in hunting, or in wars, which I followed whereoever I could ee the eat was. Now Sir, I lived in this contempt of love and beauty until of very late, when that God, who would not uffer any mortal to trample his honour and his laws o under foot, did make me know his power, by a way as extraordinary as my crime.

Thoe who knew me, called me by the name of Lipandas, born in a city of the Neutrians called Rothomagues, and of Parents, who there held the prime rank. And whereas, my countrey maintained great wars againt the Romans, and they againt the Franks, I had occaions enough of hewing my valour without tirring out of the Neutrian limits, or at leat out of our Army: and therefore a place of great concernment being in the power of our Lords, which was called Callice, the government of it was committed unto me, and I kept it everal years. About a month ince, one whoe name was Lidias, coming from great Brittain, unto which he was fled for Sanctuary, landed in this place.

Ligdamon upon this laying his hand upon the trangers, tay a while Cavalier I beeech you (aid he unto him) are you the ame Lipandas, who being Governour of Calais, did imprion Lidias for the death of Arontes? I am the very ame (anwered he) but what knowledge could you have of me in a place o ditant from the Neutrians? Content your elf (replyed Ligdamon, that I know what you tell me, and more, that a young woman of great Britain, called Melander, armed like a Cavalier, did fight with you about the liberty of that Lidias; afterwards to deliver him, did put her elf into prion, and when the Franks urprized Calais, was delivered out of your hands.

I perceive (replyed the tranger) that you do know almot all I have to tell you, and therefore my dicoure will be horter then I intended: Then looking upon him a little better, Oh heavens! cryed he out; why do I make any relations of it unto you? for if I be not much mitaken, it is Lidias unto whom I peak: To Lidias! anwered Ligdamon, No; but to one that has paid very dear for his reemblance unto that Lidias, as you hall undertand when you have done your dicoure. The credit which I give to your words (replyed the tranger) makes me give my eyes the lye, for I durt have worn you had been Lidias; but ince you do deny it, I will return from whence I digreed; and then he replyed thus. Oh Sir, ince you are acquainted with thee accidents, perhaps you know alo, that this Melander was no ooner out of my prion, but he went after that ungrateful Lidias, who having forgotten all thoe extraordinary favours which he had received from that generous woman, went unto Rothomagues to marry Amerina, her for whom he had killed Arontes, my neer Kinman: As for me, I remained a Prioner in the hands of one Lindamore, a Cavalier of Gaul the mot accomplihed that ever came into Neutria; and the caue of it, as afterwards I undertood, was this fair Melander, whom I retained Prioner: for Lindamore hearing, I know not how, what tetimonies of generoity and affection this woman had expreed unto Lidias, and being informed that he was a prioner in the Catle, as oon as the Catle was taken, he ran to deliver her: But not finding her (for the doors were et open, and he, with many others, ecaped) I think there was not any corner or hole which he did not eek, continually asking me where he was: I who could not tell him, nor knew Melander but under the notion of the ad Cavalier, I knew not what to anwer him: At lat, making me undertand that he ought for a woman in the habit of a Cavalier, who fought with me for Lidias, and was afterwards imprioned: As for the ad Cavalier, anwered I, he indeed was my prioner, but as for any woman, there was none in my hands. Well, replyed Lindamore, that ad Cavalier is the woman I mean: How? replyed I, the ad Cavalier a woman! Why? aid Lindamore, was he o long in your hands, and you not know it? Why it was he who loved Lidias, and in defence of him, armed her elf, and vanquihed you, and afterwards with a mot heroique courage, bought the liberty of Lidias by the los of her own.

Now Sir, you hall hear how that puiant God of Love was revenged upon me; I who always mocked at his power, and depied his Laws, no ooner heard that this ad Cavalier was a woman, but I fell into mot extream admiration: this admiration bringing into my memory the generoity of that woman, I began to eteem her; and at lat, contemplating upon the weetnes of her face and apect, her modet behaviour, her admirable patience, and her unparallell'd affection, I fell from eteem, to love her; a thing which I ever thought impoible: But learn O all ye mortals! to reverence the upreme Deities: for I not reting in an ordinary affection, Love had tuck his arrows o deep in my heart, that I became all paionate flame, o as I may erve for an example unto all uch Atheits as do not acknowled the puiance of this great God, who above all the ret, ought to be called Heus, that is, trong and puiant. In the mean time, Lindamore undertood that Melander was no ooner at liberty, but he hated after Lidias, who was gone to Rothomagues: and the very truth is, had I been free, as Melander went after Lidias, I had gone after Melander; but having paed my word unto that Cavalier, not to tir out of his houe, I was able to do nothing but languih, and think my elf worthy of that punihment which I endured, for having o fair,
and o weet a woman o long in my hands, and never knowing it. I found then that this paion made me have a different opinion of things, and was forced to ay, that none was able to reit the god of Love: I that was wont to laugh at thoe that begged any trivial favour from her they loved, could now be contented to kis and adore the very chains which touched the fair hand of my Saint Melander. And therefore I deired one of Lindamors men to go with me into the prion where he was wont to be: The man like the mater, being all Courteie, went with me, and not being well able to dicern which chains had fettered her, I deired him to put them all upon me: as oon as I had them upon me; O chains, aid I, which once fettered the hands of her who now has fettered my heart, yet les cruel then I, ince you were broken to let her go at liberty, whom I o unworthily kept in my prion; you may with abundance of reaon upbraid me with the crime which I have committed; for I was the caue and the Authour, but you more inenible then I was, had ome pity upon her, and knew that he to whom the liberty of all hearts is due, did not deerve to be o imprioned. O you mot happy bonds (aid I and kied them) happy in the touch of her fair hands, hew me in what place you received that honour, that by kiiing it, I may expres the devotion which I bear unto them: upon this I kied them again, and beeeched thoe that were about me to fetter my arms and my hands with all the hakkles in the prion, and becaue out of pity, they refued to do me that office, O good gods (cryed I out) is it poible that he who had no compaion upon the fairet, and mot generous woman upon earth, hould find any o compaionate unto me? Upon this their denial, I poke and did many things that were ridiculous, ome could not chue but laugh, and others eeing a man o lot in love, did reent my condition.

All thee paages were reported unto Lindamor, and Lindamor related them unto Clidemant, and both out of curioity would needs come and ee me. The condition wherein they found me, was uch, that any that aw me would ay I was out of my wits: I had fettered both my feet with as many chains as covered them, and one hand was tying the other as well as it could: as many chains were about my neck as could hang; and thus hardly able to tir, I kied thoe that my mouth could reach, reverencing the ret, becaue they had touched that fair one. Although I aw them enter, yet I continued my devotion of kies, as if I aw them not, which held them a while admiration: at lat Clidemant came nearer unto me: Cavalier (aid he) what are you doing with all thee chains? and why are you thus fettered with them? Sir, anwered I, I do not only deire them to be continually upon me, but I wih I could hang them about my heart. About your heart? (aid Clidemant) you know that then they would kill you: for any thing that touches the heart is mortal. O Sir, replied he, that rule is fale. For Melander doth not only touch my heart, but has pierced it with a hundred arrows; yes, has pull'd it out of my bret, and yet I do hot die. That touch of your heart, replied Clidemant, is only in imagination; but if thee chains hould touch it doubtles you would die: No Sir, (aid I unto him) for do you not know that Iron touched with a Loadtone, does participate of the quality of the ame Loadtone, and will draw Iron alo? I know it, anwered Clidemant, and have een it; but what's that to the purpoe? Why this (anwered I) thee chains though of Iron, yet having touched the fair hands of Melander, have received a certain virtue and quality, as they can touch hearts and not make them die, as the fair Melander can do her elf. Upon this Clidemant hrugg'd his houlders, and went away; but Lindamor very orry to ee me o ditracted, he came unto me, and did all he could to divert me from uch thoughts; and by little and little, his kind words, and the pains I aw him take to reduce me to my undertanding, did o operate with me, that I was perwaded by him: for though thee actions did make me eem as if I were mad, yet I was not o; but the Grandure of this new paion, as the plendour of the Sun does dim the Stars, o this at the firt did dim me from the ight of all other things, or at leat made me depie them.

Eight dayes did I continue in this ort; at lat the kindes of Lindamor was
uch, that eeing me o unmeaurably ad and melancholy, and that I grew wore and wore every day, he took pity upon my affliction, and drawing me aide, did ue all poible arguments and coniderations that could comfort an afflicted peron, and afterwards offered me o many favours as have created me his ervant as long as I live. Unto all which, I returned no other anwer at the firt but ighs; yet at lat, being preed unto it, I let him undertand in the bet language I had, how deeply I reented his extraordinary kindnees, and told him, that my griefs did not proceed from my imprionment, or my loes, but only becaue I undertood that Melander was gone after Lidias, and I not able to follow her; and that love had o wholly devoted me unto her, that if in this quet he received any harm, it would mot infallibly cot me my life; becaue I thought my elf the caue of all the harm he received.

Lindamor, who I believe was not ignorant of loves power, went the ame hour to procure my enlargement, and did o olicite Clidemant, that he obtained it of the Childerick, who was newly arived at that place. Upon this Lindamor returned unto me with a miling apect, Cavalier (aid he) leave off all your orrows and any afflicting your elf, for the Prince Clidemant, at my requet, hath obtained your liberty, and I come to bring you the news, to the end that before you go away you may promie me one thing, which is not at all prejudicial unto your affection, but on the contrary it will oblige you to oberve it. Upon that condition (aid I unto him) I hall thankfully receive the favour you have done me. Then promie me (aid he) that you will never bear Arms againt the King of the Franks nor againt Clidemant: and you are obliged unto it by the courteie which you now receive, but much more by the affection which you bear unto Melander, who is o affectionately devoted unto Clidemant, for the favours which in good time you may know he hath received from him, that certainly if he have any power over you, it will be one of the firt commands he will enjoyn you.

Sir, anwered I, I am extreamly glad the obervance of your deires will ute o well with Melanders, for I hall with more courage make a promie of it unto you. But aure your elf, Sir, that though he hould tand but as indifferent, and not poitively enjoy the contrary, I hould think my elf the mot ungrateful man that ever wore a word, did I not mot religiouly oberve it. Upon this promie (replied Lindamor) I give you your enlargement. I did admire at this kindnes and magnanimity, for avarice does often choke thoe virtues in many men. I took his hand, and by force would have kied it by way of thanks; and becaue he would not uffer it, you know Sir, aid I, that this is the leat tetimony of my gratitude I can pay, and it hould be greater if I were able, but at this time I beeech you receive it with aurance, that as long as I live I hall never forget my great obligations unto you: and going along with him, I made the ame protetations unto Clidemant and Childerick; and after I had taken my humble leave of them all, I went in quet of that fair one.

Firt I went towards Rhothomagues, but not being willing to enter in, becaue I knew not how the Lords would take the los of Callice; and therefore went unto a kinmans houe, not far from the Town, where enquiring how all quares went, I undertood that every one was well atisfied concerning me, though the los of that place was of great conequence: for they all knew I was betrayed, and that there is no guarding of ones elf againt a Traytour. But that not being the buines which brought me thither, I fell into dicoure concerning Lidias; and then he told me, how he would have poyoned himelf to prevent his marriage with Amerina; then did I conclude with my elf, that his love unto Melander was the caue: in this opinion, I asked him what was become of Lidias, and he anwered that both he and Amerina were lot, and that it was reported they were gone into Forrets, none knowing the caue.

I thought that I knew enough for that time: o as the next morning pretending that I deired to know more particularly what the Lords did think of me, I would go as ecretly as I could unto one of them that was my profeed friend, but I went quite another way, auring my elf that Melander was infallibly followed
after Lidias. And yeterday by fortune I came into this Army, where curioity invited me to tay, and ee the dicipline of that Country; and finding that the General of the Army did think to carry that Town at the very firt onet. I had a deire to be there, and at the lat Salley, I tood upon the ide of a ditch, looking upon the valour of your men, and the flight of the Aailants, having no dipoition to draw my word on either ide: But I know not how, cating my eye upon you, I thought I aw the generous Melander, whom you held by the Neck, and ready to run your word into her Breat. Oh heavens! Cavalier, how infinitely was I urpried at the ight? I lept into the Ditch, with full intention to be killed in killing you; and I know not what had hapned, if the voice of ome who ran after me, had not warned you of my intention; for upon it you guarded your elf. But now I thank the Gods that my intention took no effect, as well becaue of that vertue and merit which I find in you, as becaue I am yet preerved, to erve that generous woman.

Thus ended Lipandas; and Ligdamon with a mile and anwered, I mut needs confes Cavalier, that Love, above all the ret of the Gods, takes mot delight in entangling the pirits of men, and in producing wonderful effects: And that you your elf may confes as much, know that this Lidias, who was reported would have poyoned himelf, becaue he would not marry Amerina, and who ince came into this Country, was my elf, who am Ligdamon, and who having a great reemblance of that Lidias, was like to be devoured by Lyons, and ince being contrained to eem as if I would marry Amerina, who could not be perwaded but I was him whom I reembled and therefore to undeceive her, I brought her hither, where by a trange misfortune we parted. But that you may the better ee how that God delights in thee confuions, I beeech you follow me, and you hall ee how far your eyes deceived you, when you thought you aw Melander in the ditch. Then taking him by the hand, he carried him into Melanders chamber. Cavalier (aid he unto her) I come to let you ee one of our prioners, who will not tell us his name, and to ee whether haply you know him. At the firt, her thoughts were o far from Lipandas, that he knew him not. But the poor Cavalier being extreamly urprized at this encounter, as oon as ever he cat his eyes upon her, Oh heavens! cryed he out: Upon this word he fell at her feet, and would have uttered ome words, which he was not able to pronounce.

It was happy that Ligdamon brought him alone, for otherwie certainly Melander had been known to be a woman; for he not being able to endure a man hould lie o protrate before her, did (out of her natural curteie) offer to raie him up; and he at the lat cryed out. O Melander! Is it poible your fair hand hould daign to touch uch a worthles peron, and one whom you have o much caue to hate? Though the voice was not altogether unknown unto her, yet he knew him not; but till offering to raie him up, Oh mot fair and generous woman (aid he unto her) I will never rie from your feet, until you have either pardoned or punihed the errour which I have ignorantly and innocently committed againt you. Melander who did not yet know him, as well becaue he had eldom een him when he was in prion, as becaue it was now dark, the candle being at the other end of the chamber, he knew not what to anwer, unles in words of civility, and actions which expreed her good will; yet till he continued to raie him up. Ligdamon who perceived he did not know him. It is trange Cavalier (aid he unto her) that this humble ubmiion of Lipandas hould not obtain that favour which he begs. Lipandas! (aid he, and was extreamly urprized) is this Lipandas? Yes Madam (anwered that Cavalier) I am the ame unworthy Lipandas, who when he did not know you, did o unworthily treat you, and who now knowing you, does admire your vertue, and beg a pardon for his innocent ignorance. She looked a while upon him, and gave no anwer; at lat, taking him by the hand, yes, yes Lipandas (aid he) I do with all my heart pardon all the injuries I received from you; and the more willingly, becaue by this means you have given me an occaion of making my love to Lidias appear. After this, raiing him up with more carees then ever he expected, he asked him what fortune brought him to that place? But when he undertood that he was
the caue of his being taken, and that it was he who would have killed Ligdamon, out of an opinion that he aw her in danger, he could not chue but wonder at this happy encounter: And to let you ee Lipandas (aid he unto him) that I do not only pardon, but alo forget all the ill uage I received from you, I beeech you Cavalier (aid he unto Ligdamon) to betow this prioner upon me. I will not only betow him (anwered Ligdamon) but all that I have upon you, but one thing I hall humbly beg of you in exchange, which is, to make him as much my friend, as I am a ervant unto Lindamore and Clidemant, unto whom he is o much obliged. I do not know (replyed Melander) what acquaintance he has with thoe two Cavaliers, but if he have any mind to oblige me, he hall make it appear, in loving and erving all thoe that love them, or have any dependency upon them: For I am as much obliged unto them for their curteies, as unto him that aved my life, ince being by fortune of War their prioner, they did not only give me my liberty, but hewed me o many favours, that I was in a capacity to ave the life of Lidias, by taking his imprionment upon me. Fair and generous Melander (aid Lipandas) thee words, which are to me inviolable commands, hall be for ever engraved in my memory: and I do profes and vow my elf as long as I live, a ervant unto Ligdamon, and all thoe who are lovers of Clidemant and Lindamore. Upon this Ligdamon aid unto him, I do receive this aurance of your amity, and do acquaint you, that you are obliged by your vow to erve the Nymph Amais; as the mother of Clidemant, and Galathea as his Siter. The Mother and the Siter of Clidemant! replyed Lipandas, I were unworthy to bear the name of a Cavalier, if I did not freely offer my life for them both, and I wear by Tantates, o I will.

Ligdamon upon this embraced him; and after Melander had deired him not to tell any that he was a woman, he gave him his liberty. Then cauing him to be better clothed, he carried him to the Nymph Amais, and the Prince Godomar, telling them, that the curteie of Clidemant and Lindamore, had purchaed unto them that Cavalier, whom they received according to his merits.

In the mean while, Meronthes who was grieved to the very oul that he had failed in his promie of opening a Port, he ent out his on, when Ligdamon allied forth to <> the Engines which were in the ditch: This young man being well intructed <…> Father, he mingled himelf amongt thoe that followed Ligdamon; an •
<…> aw every one buie about other things, he lipt away unto Polemas,
<…> an excue from his father, that he could not open the Port as he promied, becaue Adamas had changed their Quarters in the night time, and if he continued the ame order, he could not promie him for the future, ince he could not know what Quarter would fall to his lot: But that if he reolved to continue a formal Seige, he had thought of an infallible way to let him into the Town in a hort pace, which was this: The houe of Meronthes tood cloe by the wall, in a place which the on hewed unto him; in it there was a deep cave, which was made for keeping of wine in the Summer, and the ditch about the Town was much higher then it; he promied to make a pas under the ditch from it, unto what place Polemas would appoint, if one thing did not hinder him, which was, that he knew not what to do with the earth which he digged out in making this pas. Polemas did exceedingly approve of this way, and asked him if there were any Wells about the houe: and being anwered that there was; Then aid Polemas, throw the earth into thoe Wells. But (aid the young man) they will be preently filled, beides another Cave which is ued for keeping of wood; for all are nothing to contain the earth which will be digged out. Then (aid Polemas) I will pring another Mine as neer yours as I can, that both may meet; in this I ee no difficulty but one, which is, that our Works may be o treight, that they may meet each other: Sir (aid the young man, to morrow about three of the clock in the morning, et a light upon the place where you intend to begin your work, and we will et another upon our houe, towards which you may work and o we hall ee which way to direct our coures. I hall (aid Polemas) and moreover I have two Levels, the one I will give unto you, and keep the other; when you ee the light upon the place where I intend to begin the work, then plant your
Level directly towards it, as I will mine towards yours, and o we cannot mis of each other: For the Miners having the direction of thee Levels to work by, they will directly make their Mine that way: Upon this he himelf took the two Levels, and hewing the ue of them, the young man having a quick apprehenion, quickly undertood them.

Yet Sir, (aid the young man) I am to advertie you of two things; the one concerns your life, and the other the welfare of your affairs: As for the firt of thee, Ligdamon hath vowed your death, unles you peedily releae Silvia: This advice Sir, is not to be lighted; for you know he is deperately in love with her: and he that contemns his own life, is mater of his enemies.

The other is Sir, That there are many who yet tand neutral, and are neither for, nor againt you, who are ready to fall unto your enemies ide, becaue they think the war you undertake againt your Soveraign, is unlawful, and without good ground: Now Meronthes your faithful ervant thinks it expedient to retain many who yet waver, that you eek out for a pecious pretence, and a handome colour for your War; which though it be not altogether true, yet it may have a face and probability of truth: And therefore he thinks it not amis for you to give it ont. that Adamas apires at the Soveraign Authority and detains the two Nymphs Prioners; in order to which, he has procured the Prince Godomar, unto whom he has made mountainous promies of reward if he compas his deign: That likewie he hath held ecret correpondencies with Neighbour Princes; witnes an unknown Queen that came into Marcelles, and left in it many ouldiers. Briefly, by this coure many things will be imputed unto him, which though afterwards they appear fale, yet no matter, ince they will erve to blind the people, who take only the firt impreion of things, and will o declare themelves thereupon, that they cannot afterwards change, though they would.

Polemas gave Meronthes many thanks for the care he had of his peron, and for his good advice. Above all Sir, (aid the young man, and interrupted him) he beeecheth you to make it appear how you reent the death of your great friend Climanthes, that all the world may ee your love of thoe that erve you; and that it is a great hame to ee him till hang before the Gate of the Town, from whence doubtles he would be taken, were it not for fear of being • i • overed to ide with you, and o men ruine themelves without doing any con •••••• ble ervice to you.

As to this point (anwered Polemas) you may tell him <> know this wicked Adamas to be the intrument of our los in Climanthes; but to morrow he hall ee what revenge I will take upon Alexis, the daughter of that damned Villain, whom I have in my hands; Alo upon Silvia, whom I have ent for, to make Amais, and that Tray or, reent the injuries which they have done me. As for Ligdamon. I do believe the notice which Meronthes gives me is true, for I have heard as much other ways, but I hall look well enough to him: So after many thanks and promies, the young man took his leave.

When night came, and was dark, the man being well intructed by his father, crept over the ditch, and coming to the place where Ligdamon had made a great laughter of his enemies, he began to groan, and complain in a pitiful tone, o as the Sentinel hearing him, and asking who he was? Alas (aid he, faigning to f • ar being heard) I am the on of Meronthes, who coming out with Ligdamon, have been here ever ince amongt the dead. The Sentinel calling the Corporal, acquainted him, and the Corporal the Commander of the Guard; Order was given to throw down Cords to pull him up: So after he had bloodied his face, and durtied himelf, complaining as if he were all wounds, he was pulled up the Wall, and carried to the houe of his father, who was the Inventor of all this, and who eemed to be tranported with joy at his ons Reurrection from the dead: For (aid he) I gave him for dead, ince he came not back into the Town with the ret. Oh father (aid the ubtle on) you may well ay that the Gods have twice given me unto you; for I have been ever ince I went out, amongt the dead.

The father held up his hands, praied the gods, and thanking thoe that pulled him up, did reward them liberally for their care and pains. Then getting him preently to bed, and eeming to end for a Chirurgion, he went with the company to the door of his houe, and gave them a thouand thanks. As oon as ever they were gone, he came into his ons chamber, and the door being hut, he gave an accompt of his voyage; advertied him of the light which would be placed where the Mine was to be begun, hewed him the level, and the ue of it: and to be breif, made a mot circumtantial relation of every particular paage; all which gave Meronthes abundance of contentment. And let friends hould come in the morning to ee his on, and eeing him well, hould upect any thing, he lapped his head about with two or three napkins: patched his face all over, and intructed him o well with what to ay, that he was prepared for all comers.

In the mean time, Polemas acquainted Peledontes, Argonides, Litander, and Ligonias, with all thee advertiements that had been given unto him by Meronthes, and the reaon why he could not open a gate unto them; and entreated them they would dipere it about every where, that the caue of this taking up arms was only to et the Nymphs at liberty, and get her out of the hands of Adamas, who under a pretence of piety and fidelty, had eized upon their perons, and intended to ell them and the whole tate unto that unknown Queen; whereupon Litander thought it expedient to print a Manifeto, and divulge it, not only throughout the Army, but alo to end unto all the neighbouring Princes, in jutification of their taking arms.

The drawing up of this Manifeto was referred unto Ligonias, who had wit and words at will to guild over a rotten caue: and as Polemas was acquainting them with the reolution of Ligdamon to kill him, by reaon of Silvia, one came to tell them that Ligdamon was brought a prioner: O good gods (cryed he out) how favourable is heaven unto me? and cauing thoe to enter who brought the uppoed Ligdamon unto him, they preented Lidias, whom every one took for Ligdamon: come Ligdamon (aid Polemas unto him) does it become the profeion of a Cavalier, thus to revenge his quarrels? I have no quarrels to revenge, anwered Lidias, epecially in this countrey where I never was before. Were you (aid Pol •• as and miled) never in this countrey before? Never (anwered Lidias) to my knowledge. I do not wonder (aid Polemas) that one who can ly o familiarly, hould have o poor a courage; and therefore (aid he to the Officers) take this impudent fellow out of my preence and guard him afe, that to morrow he may accompany Silvia whither I hall end them: o without any further hearing, he caued him to be taken out of the chamber. A while after came Silvia, whom he would not ee. but commanded he hould be afely guarded till the morning; and to affright them the more, he ent them both word that they mut prepare themelves for death; and becaue many in the Army might think this cruelty barbarous, he ordered his confidents to give it out, that he put Aexis to death in revenge upon Adamas, who was the caue of all the warre, and detained the Nymphs whom he would et at liberty: that Silvia hould uffer in revenge of Climanthes, who he, with Leonide, had betrayed into the hands of Adamas. And as for Ligdamon, he would punih him for attempting againt his life.

This was preently divulged all over the army, o as the Spies of Adamas gave him intimation of it the ame night, whereat he was grieved extreamly: for though Alexis was not his daughter, yet remembring the Oracle, in obedience unto which he had been o indulgent unto the Shepherd; beides, the merits of Celadon and Atrea, he could no chue but adly reent their loe, epecially conidering what the Oracle peaking of Celadon aid, that he obtaining his Mitres, his own age hould find abundance of happines.

But the orrows of Adamas were not comparable to thoe of Leonide, who hearing that Alexis and Atrea were in the hands of Polemas, and that he would expoe them to the hot of the Town in the morning; he reented it o bitterly, that he could not chue but give great tetimonies of it: for he knowing that
Alexis was Celadon, who he loved but too well, it grieved her very oul to think he hould be o mierably murdered; and it was well, for he he might pretend kindred unto Alexis, for otherwie her orrows would have been known to proceed from affection; but this excue did not atisfie Adamas, who knew what relations were betwixt them, and therefore he was driven to another, before he could give him atisfaction: o as when Adamas wondered at her exceive mourning: father, anwered he, if I do not hew exceive orrow for Alexis, I hall be eteemed of a very ill nature, and it is to be feared our enterprie will be dicovered, o as Adamas was in ome ort atisfied with this reaon. But Leonide not being able to uffer the loe of that o dearly beloved Shepherd, he went unto Galathea, and with a torrent of tears, acquainted her with the taking of Alexis and Atrea, and with the cruel entence of Polemas, againt them and Silvia: Great was the grief which this news brought unto all the Town; but it had a more bitter influence upon the pirit of Ligdamon then any other: for the orrows of Adamas was to ee himelf frutrated of the future happines which he expected from the Oracle. Leonide reented the loe of Celadon, out of a love without hope of reciprocal correpondency: Galatheas grief for Silvia, was, becaue he had been ever familiar with her: To be brief, the general complaints of all the Court, proceeded only from pity; but the torments of Ligdamon proceeded from love: o, as like a madman, he went up and down from one to another enquiring news, and hearing it with trange impatiency, he fell upon the mot extream reolutions that are imaginable: he would go out in the night unto Polemas his Tent, and drink his blood; and becaue they would not open the gates unto him, he would needs leap over the walls: he begg'd of Amais, and importun'd Prince Godomar to let him out, for he would deliver them from that rebellious enemy; he told them, that if they retained him by force, he would kill himelf; and ince he was reolved upon death, it was better for him to receive it from the hands of his enemies then his own: That happily the gods would proper his deigne; and o direct his hand, as he hould deliver them all from the Tyrant. But Godomar, by the advice of Adamas, would not permit him; yet promied, that if the Rebel continued his reolution till the morning, they would not only open the gates to him, but rather then Alexis and Silvia hould uffer, they would all go out and die with him.

This promie of the Prince, being ratified by Damon and Alcidon, did a little appeae him; yet not o as to uffer his eye to cloe all the night: and hereupon Alcidon told him, that happily reports might prove fale; for ome part of it they knew to be o, as that Ligdamon hould be in the hands of Polemas. O Sir, anwered Ligdamon, bad news proves commonly too true; and aure your elf, they have mitaken me, and took Lidias whom I reemble, for I was told that he followed her who came with me into this countrey. The repors of this mitake came quickly to the eare of Melander, who being very impatient to know the truth, came preently to Ligdamon, of whom he enquired all circumtances and what he would do. What hould I ay, or what hould I do (anwered Ligdamon) but that I will die for Silvia: and I (replied he preently) for Lidias. Upon this, parting from him, he wept away all the night.
As thee things did extreamly trouble thoe that were within the Town, o there were ome in the Army of Polemas, who took as little ret, and amongt the ret Alexis and Atrea.

This Shepherd hearing what a hard entence Polemas had paed, it pierced him to the very oul, that his Shepherdee was to be thus ued for his ake: and when he was rudely treated by the Officers of Jutice; is it poible (aid Alexis) that in Forrets uch avage pirits, and inhumane courages hould be found, as are not moved at the beauty of Astrea? Does this countrey, where weetnee and civility o long raigned, now produce and nourih Monters, more wild and keen then Africa?

Certainly you have no eyes nor heart; for if you were not blind, you could not chue but honour and reverence the mot excellent work of the great gods, but all his words were uelee: and he was no ooner in prion with her, but he
fell down upon his knees. Oh Atrea (aid he) I conjure you by the love you have unto me, to have pity upon your elf; and ince 'tis only I whom they aim at, be not guilty of your own death: Could you exempt me by it, haply I hould excue the exces of your affection in bearing me company; but ince your death will do me no good, alas, why will you add unto my grief, by eeing you die? You know that I do love you with all my oul, and what wrong did I ever do you, that you hould make me the Author of your death? You know that homicide is abominable unto the Gods, and why will you incene them by committing it upon your elf? Be not more guilty of your death then thoe who bring you unto it. Celadon would have continued longer, but Atrea interrupted him. All thee arguments and perwaions might avail, if you were not to die (aid he) but the Gods in depriving me of my mot dear Alexis do know, that they deprive me of my life alo, for I neither will nor can live without her; and in putting you to death, they do the ame to me: Tell not me that I am guilty of my own death if I die with you, for the threds of our lives are o interwoven and knit together, that the Sciars which cut the one, does alo cut the other: And as for being an addition of orrow unto you by this action; Oh Mitris, Is it poible you hould think I can live without you? Will you wrong me o much, as think I love you o little? A common Souldier will run through that fire which burns him unto whom he hath promied fidelity, nay he will be corned if he do not; and may not as much be allowed Atrea when Alexis dies? Let not (I beeech you) any uch thought harbour in your oul; but if you will have me die contentedly, ay unto me, Astrea, I would have both our hearts pierced with the ame pear, that our ouls as they pas out of our bodies, may unite for ever, as our affections already have conjoyned our wills with a love ineparable. I ue Mitris thee expreions of affection and love, which perhaps becomes not the inequality of our conditions and ranks, but you have allowed this familiarity formerly, and well may now, ince death is to remove all terms of inequality, and level us all alike.

Celadon did liten long without interruption; for firt he thought it indicretion to do otherwie; and econdly, he was o pleaed to hear and receive uch expreions of affection from her he loved, as he was even enchanted with her words. At lat, my dear ervant (aid he unto her) thoe who love well, as I know you do Alexis, will always value the contentment of the party loved, above their own; I doubt not but it is ome comfort unto you to end your days with Alexis, but do not you conider what a grief of oul it will be unto me, to ee you die? Ah dearet Mitris (aid Atrea) if thoe who love well ought to have this conideration, why not you the ame of me? And why do not you conider what a mot intollerable depair it would be unto me, to urvive you? No, no Mitris, let us not reit the will of the Gods; if it be their will that one of us hould live, mot certainly they will preerve the life of the other; and if I die, I believe you will not live. 'Tis true (anwered Celadon.) And it is more true (replyed Atrea) that I cannot urvive Alexis one minute.

Thus Alexis and Atrea ighed away all the night, in giving new aurances of the affection which they bore unto each other; and though it was upon a ad occaion, yet Love did draw, even out of their mot bitter tears, mot incomparable conolations. Alexis at lat, eeing his Shepherdes would not be diverted from the reolution which he had taken, did often think it now time to declare who he was, and to undeceive her in the opinion which he had of his being the daughter of Adamas; but yet ome conideration retrained him: Somtimes he would ay unto himelf, why hould I any longer conceal my elf, ince now we are both at the very brink of death? But then again (aid he, and reprehended himelf) why hould I make any dicovery of it, ince that will alo be a very death? For the knowledge of it will either pleae or dipleae her: If it pleae her, will not her death be more dipleaing unto her? And if it dipleae her, why hould I add more grief unto her, when we are both going to die? Thus was he long diputing with himelf; at lat he thought it the fittet time to declare himelf as he was falling at her feet, thinking that if the trangreing her commands did offend her, he would wah away the crime with his blood.

In the mean time day began to dawn, and the whole Army began to move and march towards the Town, circling it about as the day before; and cauing abundance of hurdles, and faggots, and engines to march before them, it eemed they intended to fill up the ditch, as they did before; but becaue they of the Town began to alute them with many clouds of Arrows, and throw uch heaps of tones upon them, they kept at a ditance further off: Then a body of hore and another of foot did open, and make a lane for Atrea, Alexis, Silvia, and Lidias, whom they took for Ligdamon, to pae through, accompanied with a hundred Pikes, and as many Halberdeirs, conducted by a Captain that was no Seguian, and o choen by Polemas, becaue he feared thoe of that countrey would be too favourable unto thoe innocent perons, which had relations to the principal of the countrey.

They had tied them all four together by the arms; and let they hould make any reitance or difficulty at their going before, they had each of them a Pike fated hehind them, to the end that he who held it might thrut it into their bodies if they would not go: They had each of them tyed to their hands of a flaming link, and o were driven forward towards the gate of the Town: O mot barbarous and prophane wretches (aid Alexis unto them that tyed them together) is there no park of humanity in your hearts? Dare you lay your deiled hands upon the mot perfect workmanhip of the gods, and not hut your eyes? but eeing Polemas himelf coming to look how they were tyed: O thou mot cruel Tyger (cryed Alexis unto him) hat thou a heart of ee die the fairet and mot innocent woman that ever was? If Adamas have offended thee, dicharge thy chollour upon me that an his daughter; but what injury has Atrea done thee, or Alces her father? yet all this was to no purpoe: and eeing a Souldier take the arms of Atrea to ty them he grew wild and furious, and was o tranported with rage, that pulling out the Souldiers word (for his hands were not yet tyed) he gave him uch a blow as laid him dead upon the ground, and ran to another; and doubtlee had done ome brave exploit upon Polemas, or the Captain, if many Souldiers had not upon a udden fallen upon him, and certainly had killed him, if the Captain had not retrained them, aying, that it was not for the ervice of Polemas; but that he was to be preerved alive, to make the gates of the Town be opened unto them.

The Captain thus got him out of their hands, and afterwards coming nearer unto him, brave woman (aid he unto him) it is better for thee to hew thy courage in taking thy death patiently then in fury; for thou eet that force cannot ave thee: Cavalier (aid Alexis) I value not my life at a traw, for I have kept it but too long, and I care not how oon it be taken away; but I cannot endure to ee this poor harmlee innocent woman, o unworthily ued: I had rather you would run your word through my heart, for I cannot endure fo ee it and live. What is it (aid the Captain) that you call unworthy uage? you know we have command to ty her unto the end of a Pike, and to drive you before us to the gate of the Town, with burning links in your hands, to fire them if they be not opened. I know it anwered Alexis, but generous Cavalier, ince without offence to the gods you may do it, command that he be not treaed as a peron culpable, for I do protet before the gods he is innocent; and if he mut be tyed, let her arm be tyed unto mine, let the knots be as fat as you will; but if you will oblige me in the highet degree of courteie, let both the Pikes be tyed unto me, and that he who is without crime, may be only ubject to the hot of the Town, which he may receive at randome, and not unto the thruts of the rude Souldiers, who perhaps fancying he has a mind to run away, though he have no uch intention, may be o barbarous as to pierce her ides.

This tranger, a little moved at the earnet entreaties of Alexis, it hall never be aid (anwered he) that I will refue o mall a favour, unto one that is going to die; and taking a cord, he tyed their arms together; and putting Atrea between him and Silvia, he tyed the other arm unto the Nymph, and the other arm of that Nymph unto Lidias, and Silvia all the while turning her head the other way thinking Lidias to be Ligdamon. Afterwards he tyed two Pikes unto
Alexis, and one a piece unto Silvia and Lidias; o as Atrea only was without the point of a Pike to her ides: When they began to march, the whole Army was moved to pity them; and if any one would have begun, certainly these would haue been a tumultuous mutiny. But Polemas accompanying him, he retrained the compaion of many; and though he aw Atrea had no Pike tyed unto her as the ret had, yet he eemed to take no notice of it, becaue her beauty had infued ome reentment of pity unto him.

In the mean time, Alexis had everal motions to tell Atrea now at the end of his dayes, that he was tyed unto Celadon: but defferring it till he aw himelf wounded, he till preed to be before her, and to put her behind him, purpoely to guard her from the hot that came from the Town; but he perceiving his deigne, preed alo forward to get before him, o as in lieu of being backward, they went forward, fater then thoe that followed after them deired.

The walls of the Town were all lined with ouldiers, who ent whole howe • s arrows and tones upon the enemy: But when they aw thoe four perons appear tyed unto Pikes, and followed by thoe •• to whom they erved for Bucklers, they were all amazed at this novelty, and as i • their arms were fallen out of their hands, they ceaed hooting without any command given o to do, only to behold what would be the iue of this pectacle. But Ligdamon, who with Lipandas and Melander, were upon the battlements of the gate, no ooner cat his eye upon them, but preently he knew Silvia. Whether it was that he knew her by her habit, or whether the eyes of a lover can ee their Son as oon as ever it begins to hine, I know not; but he knew her: and the hore no ooner opened to make a lane for them, but he cryed out like one that was deperate, and deired he might go out and deliver her out, of the hands of thoe Barbarians. And becaue the Prince Godomar was unwilling to uffer him, he beeeched Alcidon by Daphnide, and Damon by Madonthe to intercede for him, that the gates might be opened. He begged it upon his knees, and conjured the Prince as he was a Cavalier, and obliged to relieved ditreed Ladies, that he would let him go to the place where Silvia was o unworthily treated. And becaue Godomar told him, that he would only ruine himelf by it, and that when it was fit time, he might and hould do what he pleaed for her: O Sir, anwered he, my life is pent unprofitable, if I now do not imploy it for Silvia, and if you will not let me go, I vow by all the gods, thee hands of mine hall deprive me of life.

But the Prince being unwilling that upon any terms the gates hould be opened, and thoe without the Town coming nearer, Melander (as he thought) aw Lidias tyed unto Silvia: O God, cryed he out (and pointed with her hand) yonder is Lidias. And Lipandas, peaking becaue Ligdamon, as one out of his enes, anwered not, certainly (aid he) it is he, who doubtlee will pay very deer for his reemblance unto Ligdamon, Ah Ligdamon, aid he, and clapped her hands together, will you uffer Silvia to die? and hall I ee Lidias perih, and we not perih with them? Ligdamon, then eeing that the Prince would not yield, and that every one gazed to ee what the enemy did, he embraced Lipandas, and recommended Melander unto him, deiring him not to forake her: and after he had bid adieu unto them both, he et his foot upon the battlements, and leaped down into the ditch in the ight of the whole Army. and all thoe that were upon the walls.

Melander, though a woman yet tranported with incredible affection, he would needs follow, but Lipandas hindred her, and put her into the hands of a Century, deiring him to have a care of her; and kiing her hand, Melander (aid he) for your ake I will go and loe my life to ave Lidias, and preently, before any took notice of him, leaped after Ligdamon.

The place where they fell, was by fortune very oft, o as when they came to the ground, they were up to the middle in durt, without any hurt but bemiring themelves; and as good luck was, Lipandas light o near Ligdamon, that they could help each other out of the bog.

Thoe who did drive the four prioners before them, eeing two men leap
over the Walls, and not knowing whether or no they were on their ide, and came to give them ome Intelligence, they topped. At the ame time, thoe upon the Gates oberved that two men, who eemed to have the command of thoe who puhed thee Prioners forward, did come to ee whether they were fat tyed; and they were not mitaken in their obervation: for the Captain when he was within fifteen or twenty paces of the ditch, told Polemas, that now the Prioners had been driven a great way, and perhaps the Pikes which were tyed unto them, might be by that time looe again, and therefore before they went any further to the Gate, he deired leave to go and ee them tyed fater, becaue the charge was committed unto him, and it concerned his honour to ee it well performed. Polemas commended his dicretion and affection to the ervice, and bade him go, and thoe of the Town forbearing to hoot, he was in good hope that his deigne would take good effect.

The Captain then taking his brother with him, went unto them; they had both, beides their other Arms, each of them a Buckler, and in either hand a drawn word, beides hort ones that hung by their ides. The Captain went unto Atrea and Alexis, and his brothe •
• nto Silvia and Lidias, and eeming to ee whether their arms were fat tyed, they cut the cords in pieces which tyed them, and likewie the cords which fatned the Pikes unto them. Know (aid he unto Atrea in a low voice) that I am Semires, whom the Gods have preerved alive, to die this day in doing you ome ervice, and in expiation of that crime which I formerly committed againt you. You fair Atrea (aid he unto her) get you into the ditch with that Nymph, and the Gods ait you; and you Celadon (aid he unto Alexis, and gave him his Sword and Buckler) now hew your elf this day to be the on of the valiant Alcippes. His brother at the ame time giving a Sword and Buckler unto Lidias; Celadon and he joyned with Semires and his brother, and made head againt the whole body of the enemy, who tood till a while, and offered no harm, becaue Semires was the Captain of the Troop, o as the Souldiers durt not advance againt • im. But Polimas perceiving it, and alo eeing Ligdamon and Lipandas who met with Atrea and Silvia, and conducted them to the walls, from whence they had already let down Paniers to pull them up, he cryed out, Kill the Traytors; upon which command all the Souldiers fell furiouly upon Semires, his brother, Celadon, and Lidias.

Thoe that aw how Celadan behaved himelf in the habit of a woman, and profeion of a Shepherd, might well ay he did not degenerate from the courage of valiant Alcippes; all the arms he had was the Sword and Buckler which Semires gave him: but not valuing his life, he fell upon the enemy with uch furious agility, that he made them all keep a ditance from him; Truth is, at every blow he truck, he looked back to ee what was become of Astrea; and when he aw her and Silvia upon the top of the Wall, he was joyed beyond all expreion, but yet they were o preed upon, that they were not able to utain the force of a multitudinous enemy: Semires had already received a wound with an arrow in his thigh, and his brother another in his houlder; Lidias was almot run through with a Pike, and but for Celadon, could not have defended himelf, when Ligdamon and Lipandas arrived. Thee ix joyning together, and being fully reolved to ell their lives as dear as they could, they made a mot incredible defence, when Polemas even tark mad at the los of his Prioners, did caue a whole Legion to advance. Thee fell furiouly upon them, and they had inevitably been all lot, if the Prince Godomar at the ame time had not commanded Damon to relieve them, allying out with three hundred Archers, and as many Pikes, over a Drawbridge, by which they might pas uneen as far as the Countercarp. And certainly they came but in time; for all ix were o wounded, that they had nothing but courage to utain them: yet eeing this relief coming, their trengths renewed, and they did not feel their wounds: Every one admired their valour, and were ravihed to ee what Celadon did; for the habit of a Shepherdes made all his actions more admirable: His Buckler was tuck o full of arrows, that there was not room for one more; his Sword anguin'd from point to pomel, and himelf wounded in two or three places, epecially in his right houlder with a pear, and
which had made a very deep wound: yet for all that, his extream deire of being revenged for the wrong that was done to Atrea, did o tranport him, that he hardly ever felt it: But all this reitance had been in vain, but for relief which Damon brought; which being conducted by Cerates and Merindor, did give them time to take a little breath, but not long; for Polemas ent a party of a thouand men more, they were forced to retreat to the ditch in a little diorder; and Semires being wounded in two places with a Pike, he was like to have caued the los of many, for he could not go, and Celadon loth to leave him, the fight renewed in that place more hotly, and more dangerous then all the time before; o as the multitude of enemies were very near giving a total defeat unto all this relief. But Damon keeping the enemy off with a tand of Pikes, and they upon the Walls hooting abundance of arrows, and throwing of tones, did keep the enemy o in play; that Celadon took Semires by one arm, and his brother took him the other, and got him over the ditch, whilt Ligdamon and Lipandas did the ame to Lidias, who could not utain himelf; and they were preently after both carried unto the place where Ligdamon was accutomed to lodge.

In the mean time, Silvia and Atrea, who were pulled up the Walls, and in the Town, they were no ooner come to the next Court of Guard, but Leonide who had beeen a pectator of all the paage, came running unto them, as well to embrace her companion, as to know whether that Druide was Atrea or Alexis. As he went, by chance he met Adamas, who for all the great affairs that he had in hand, came to take uch order that Celadon hould not be known, thinking that if Galathea came to ee him, he would enter into ome ill opinion of him: The hate wherein he was, would not permit him any long dicoure; but only told her, he would have the Druide carried preently unto his Lodging, and let none peak with her, and afterwards all fitting orders hould be taken.

As oon as ever Silvia aw Leonide, he embraced her with abundance of joy, and Leonide was glad to ee her out of the hands of Polemas: But Leonide having an earnet deire to talk with the Druide; my dear companion (aid he unto Silvia) Galathea has a mot longing deire to peak with you; go therefore unto her, whilt I wait upon this woman unto my Uncles lodging; for I perceive he is o affrighted, that I would not have Galathea ee her in this condition: Upon this taking Atrea by the hand, he carried her almot by force unto the Lodging of Adamas; for he had no mind to be from the Wall, until he knew what was become of Alexis: But Leonide made her believe, that he was already in the Town, being come in at the Sally port, out of which the Relief went. In the mean time, Adamas being told that all thoe who went out, wete returned in, he ran unto the Port to receive Celadon; and he came jut in the nick of time; for that Shepherd was no ooner entred into the Town, but his los of blood made him fall into a woon, with Semires, who was in a wore condition then he Adamas commanded he hould be preently carried unto his Lodging: and taking no notice of carrying Semires with Celadon, becaue he knew him not; Sir (aid Semires unto him with much pain) it was I that aved Atrea and Celadon, I beeech you let me be carried where he is, that I may die neer them. Adamas hearing him name Celadon, and fearing left he hould dicover who Alexis was, he preently commanded they hould be both carried together unto his Lodgings. It was well that at the ame time a hot Alarm was given on all ides; for upon it, Damon, and all the ret, ran as fat as they could to make defence, never minding what Semires aid.

The Alarm was no fale one, for Polemas being almot out of his wits at the los of his prioners, he gave the igne to make a general Aault, as he did the day precedent, and which was o hotly purued, that nothing would make them retreat but night, which then he did, with the lot of many men for which much he cared not, o he could but at lat find revenge: But the darknes of the night cauing him to ound a retreat, every one retired to his Quarter, finding now that the Town was not o eaily entred as Polemas rahly imagined, never conidering that the weaknes of the Walls were trongly fortified by the valour and courage of o many brave men as were within. So as Alerantes the next morning departed,
to give King Gondebaut an account of all that was done, and of the condition wherein Polemas was; who remembring the wie advice which Climanthes gave him, he beought Alerantes to inform the King, that this Town was not worthy the preence of o great a Prince, but to beeech him he would only end him ome Forces which he promied, and to ecure the peron of Prince Sigimond, conidering that though he was his on, yet he was deeply in love: And for his part, he would beiege the Town round about, of which he doubted not but to give him a good accompt within a few days. And latly, to aure him of his affection and fidelity, as one whom he would always acknowledge as his Lord and Mater. Oh this tyrannical and horrid ambition! With what violence does it hurry mortal pirits to acrifice their thoughts, their ret, and their lives, to atisfie its unjut and inatiable paion.

Celadon in the mean time, and Semires, were carried unto the houe of Ad •
