mas; Semires o wounded, that every one thought he would die before they got him thither: And the faint Shepherd with los of blood, though he was returned to himelf out of his woon, yet they had no more hopes of his life, then of the other: Yet both of them did mot paionately deire to be carried unto the place where Atrea was: but the Chyrurgions would not upon any terms allow of it: for, aid they, the ight of them will make their wounds much wore; and beides, they tand in need of ret, which they cannot take if any company be with them: So they were carried into everal chambers; and becaue they were till concontinually asking where Atrea was, ome made anwer, that he was with the Nymphs Amais and Galathea, and that he would come preently. Alas, anwered Semires, I fear it will be too late, for I feel the pains of death coming upon me, and if there be any one amongt you that has any park of pitty in them, let them go and hate her away, that my oul, before it depart out of my body, may unload it elf of an intollerable burthen. And he aid truly, for he was in that weak condition, as he was hardly able to utter thoe words.

His Brother who held him by the hand, and knew why he was o deirous to ee her, he turned towards the Chyrurgion who had earched his wounds; Learned Sir (aid he unto him) why hould you deny my brother this atisfaction, ince you ee his death is inevitable? Semires hearing his brother ay o, Oh Gods cryed he, unles you will make me die deperate, let me receive this favour from you; and becaue he was o extreamly importunate, alo ince there was no hopes of his life, it was reolved to end for her; and Leonide, who had not left her, came with her, and truly it was full time to come; for when they entred into the chamber, he was hardly able to move; yet triving with himelf, and making a igne unto his brother to draw all the company from the bed, let they hould hear what he had to ay: Fair Atrea (aid he unto her) You ee here before you that Semires, who in loving you too much, hath given you o much reaon to hate him, but to wah away my crime, I have given you my blood and my life, and beg a pardon: Had I any thing more dear unto me, or precious, I would alo give it to repair that fault which Love hath made me commit. I know the Gods have pardoned me, ince they have favoured me o far, as to die for you. I thank them with all my heart for it, and only beg of them o much time before I die, as to hear you anwer; which if be uch as I deire, it will accompany me unto my eternal ret; and if it be otherwie, it will damn me to a hell of torment and depair.

Semires uttered thee words with uch a faint and languihing voice, as wrought o upon the heart of Atrea, that he could not chue but pity the man whom of all the world he had mot reaon to hate; and thoe tears which compaion brought into her eyes, did tetifie that no offence can be o great, but a generous pirit can pardon it; yet not knowing how to anwer him, he wiped her eyes, and tood mute; o as Semires finding himelf at the lat gap; fair Atrea (aid he) Thee do tetifie ome pity, but no pardon: Say preently, Semires depart in peace, if you will have me hear that o much deired peech. Then Atrea anwered,
be at peace Semires, and know that as heretofore thou caued me to loe him would I loved, o now thou hat preerved her whom only I can love. Upon thee words one might ee Semires o change his countenance, as if he had ailed nothing, o much contentment did they give him. Afterwards, ighing upon a udden. May heaven be ever favourable unto you (aid he unto her) and preerve Atrea for her happy Celadon: Thee were the lat words he poke and o expired: happy in his misfortune, that he gave his life for her he loved, and in eeing the fair eyes of Astrea hed tears to wah away his crime: tears of compaion, though not tears of love,

The out-cry which certain Shepherds made when Astrea was carried away, came preently to the ears of Diana and Phillis, who having newly dreed themelves, ran preently out of the houe to know the caue of the Tumult: As oon as ever they were out of the doors, one of the company met them: O fair Shepherdees (cryed he out in a mot ad tone) Atrea is violently carried away by thirty or fourty Theives, and we being without any arms, alo few in number, it was impoible for to defend her from the violence of thoe wicked men. At the firt, Diana and Phillis upected ome knavery in the report, but afterwards thinking it not poible to counterfeit o well, and being econded by the ret of the company that came after him, they began to believe it, and were o urprized at the news, that they could do nothing but gaze one upon another with atonihment.

At lat, when the firt apprehenion was a little abated of its violence, and left them liberty to cry and complain, they guhed out into uch a torrent of tears, as would have moved the mot barbarous man in the world to compaion. They were both wimming in the flood of tears when Silvander came, who knowing nothing at all of the caue, began firt to enquire what the matter was; and not believing that any could better inform him then themelvess, he acccoted Phillis, and in a ad low voice aid unto her. May not I know what it is which thus afflicts my fairet Mitree? Alas, anwered Diana, with welled eyes, doubtlee you do know it, and are very inenible, if you do not hare with us in our orrows. I wih (replied he) I could as well bear it all to eae you, as I can hare with you in part, and I give you a ufficient tetimony of it, ince not knowing the caue of your dicontent, I am grieved to the very oul.

Shepherd (aid Diana then) I doubt not but you will hare with us in our orrows, when you know that Phillis and I do lament the loe of Atrea, whom thee Shepherds, aw carryed away by Thieves within this quarter of an hour: How? (aid Silvander then) Atrea carried away by Theives? Yes, yes, replied Diana, and as her misfortune is without remedy, o are our orrows without an end.

Upon this Diana broke out again into ighs and tears, which moved Silvander o much, that he reolved immediately either to die or recover Atrea: and in order thereunto, he went unto the Shepherds, who were preent at the misfortune: Fle, fle, ye cowards (aid he unto them) could you uffer this injury in your ight? would you not defend Atrea as long as there was one drop of blood in your bodies: Shepherd (aid one of the company unto him) it was done upon uch a udden, as it was impoible for us to help it. The number of thoe that carried her away, was treble ours; and they were upon hores and armed, but we on foot without any arms but our heep-hooks, Was not that enough? (aid Silvander) Philander, in defence of Diana, killed a Barbarian compleatly armed, and had no other arms but his heephook: 'Tis true, anwered the Shepherd, and happily we might have done as much for Astrea; but they had no ooner et her upon horeback, but they galloped preently away out of our fight? O heavens (aid Silvander) what became of poor Alexis when he heard of this unfortunate news? Alexis (anwered the Shepherd) was the firt that was advertied of it, and like one tranported, not knowing what he did, we aw her run after the Theives, calling them all the opprobrious names that could be devied, but I cannot think it poible for her to overtake them, for they will go further in an hour, then he can in a day.

Diana and Phillis hearing that Alexis did run her elf into o much danger to relieve this Shepherdee, their orrows redoubled, out of their apprehenions of ome harm that might happen unto her: Mean time, Silvander in an audible voice that all the Shepherds might hear him: Come, aid he, mut we it till samely, and put up this affront without reentment? For my part, I am fully reolved, either to die or be revenged upon thee Rogues. Such a tain hall not lie upon me, and my reputation: He had no ooner uttered thee words. but all the Shepherds, who being decended from generous Ancetours, had courages much above their quality, they all cried out in a loud voice, that they would loe their lives in the quarrel. Silvander was extreamly glad to hear their reolutions, and more when one of them deired him in the name of all the company, that he would be their Captain, telling him that they had great confidence in his courage and conduct, and that they tood in need of uch a one to teach them what to do in uch an imployment. Silvander at firt refued, but being earnetly olicited, he took upon him the honour and charge of being their commander.

When he was ready to depart and follow after thoe who had carried away Astrea, auring himelf he hould by ome means or other hear of their retreat; and addreing himelf unto Diana and Phillis: Fair Shepherdees (aid he unto them and hewed them thoe Shepherds) here are brave pirits that are reolved to repair that hame that might be imputed to us, for uffering your companion to be thus carried away: we will follow our detinies; and if heaven favour our deign, you will hortly turn your tears into joyes, at Atreas liberty. Phillis hearing this, he could not enough admire o trange a Metamorphois, which in a moment turned a company of Shepherds into a company of Souldiers, but expecting the judgement of her companion upon it, he perceived her to look pale, and doubted that it did trouble her o as giving her the opportunity of telling him her mind concerning his o haty departure, he withdrew two or three paces: And then Diana thinking that none could hear her, Silvander (aid he unto him) what do you intend to do? But fairet Mitree (aid he and interrupted her) why do you not call me your ervant? Then ervant (aid Diana) pray tell me what your deign is? You that have o often condemned rahnee in another, can you be o guilty of it your elf? Conider Silvander the danger whereunto you expoe your elf, ince you neither know what enemies to have for to fight againt, nor their number; for though they appeared not above thirty or fourty; yet perhaps there are thrice that number engaged in the ame deigne, and for ought you know, may be the principal of all the neighbouring Provinces. Methinks ervant, you hould more eriouly weigh thee things, and omething atisfie the deire that I have, you hould not attempt things impertinently.

Silvander hearkened unto Diana with abundance of contentment, yet being a little too impatient, fairet Mitree, aid he, though my ruine were inevitable, and though I were ure my deigne would find no favourable uccee; yet would it be much glory to pend my blood and my life in endeavouring to retore that contentment unto you, which is o unfortunately ravihed away. And therefore without thinking whether it be pertinent or no, I ought to fall upon it: for I know, that though the execution prove not properous, yet the deigne at leat is honourable, ince it aims at retoring unto you your companion without whom I know you cannot enjoy any contentment in the world. Shepherd (aid Diana then) you force me to make a trange confeion: I mut needs ay I do love Atrea, and were I out of hopes ever to ee her again, I hould grieve extreamly; but withall, conider Silvander, that I do not hate you, and perhaps if you and he were weighed together, in the cales of my affection, you would out ballance her. In aying o Diana bluh'd: and the Shepherd, even ravihed to hear this declaration from the mouth of his Mitree, he was ready to cat himelf at her feet; yet being retrained by thoe who oberved their actions, he only aid thus unto her: My fairet Mitree, you have made me the mot happy man upon earth, and I would protrate my elf in all humility at your feet, if there were not o many witnees; but I protet and vow fair Diana, that I will behave my elf with the ame reverence and repect towards you, as is due anto a Deity: my
dicretion and obedience hall make good my words, and hall be utable unto that harmonious language which you have poke in my advantage. If o (replyed Diana) I would have you now give a tetimony of it, and obey me, when I command you not to depart o rahly, but firt to conider and conult with thoe that are mot intereed in the quarrel; if Phocion hould raie forces in behalf of Atrea, I hould allow his jut reentment; But that Sylvander, whom it nothing concerns, hould be the firt that will deliver her, I cannot eaily conent.

The Shepherd thought Dianas judgement to be good, and that there was no reaon for him to follow Atrea, before he had communicated it unto Phocion, who was her Uncle, It was then reolved upon to go unto his houe, and by the way, they met with all thoe Shepherds and Shepherdees who accompanied Dorinde to Marcelles, and returned not in three or four days; After the firt alutations, they were told of the accident that had hapned unto Atrea, and how Alexis followed her; at which they were all extreamly grieved: For uch was the beauty and goodnes of Atrea, that never any aw her, but loved her beyond meaure. But Licidas who was one amongt them, addreed himelf unto Phillis: I verily believe (aid he unto her in a low voice) that the Gods have punihed Atrea, for the wrong which he did unto Celadon: For I beeech you conider it well, Was ever uch an accident as this heard of in this Country before now? It is to be preumed, that it is a revenge abolutely determined by Fate; for Diana or you might as well have been carried away as Atrea; and yet the judgement has only fallen upon her, as mot culpable. Certainly (anwered Phillis) the Gods did pardon my companion for the death of Celadon, when (for the Ret of his oul) he erected an empty Tomb for him; and mot auredly there is ome other hidden myterie in the action of thee Thieves. With uch dicoure as this, they came unto the houe of Phocion, whom they found in a melancholy tudy, walking before his houe; and his wonder was not a little, when he aw o great a company coming towards him: At firt he received them as kindly as poibly he could, compoing his countenance o, as he did not hew the adnes of his oul: But when he had aluted Diana and Phillis, and did not ee Atrea, the firt thing he asked, was, where he was? None durt give him any anwer; But Sylvander conidering that he mut know of the accident, and that it was as good to acquaint him betimes with it, as to defer it any longer; he took him aide, and deiring Thamires to ait him in the office, he related unto him in few words, the diater that had hapned unto Atrea. Phocion who loved her as his own oul, received this news like an arret of death; but Thamires and Sylvander gave him uch cordials, that at length he recollected himelf, and like a man of a ound and perfect judgment, did think it better to employ the time in remedy, then in complaints. And all etting themelves to conult what coure was bet, a way was no ooner propounded, but they aw a Shepherd running towards them as fat as he could; and when he was come within ken, his countenance eemed as if he had ome meage of great concernment; which caued them all to keep ilence, and look upon him: At lat Licidas went to meet him, and returning, told Phocion, that this Shepherd was come to peak with him. The aged Pator took him aide, and asked the man his buines, and what it was which brought him thither in that hate. Unto which the Shepherd anwered in thee terms: Father (for o every one called him by reaon of his age) I have been at the houe of Adamas, our grand Druide, but not finding him at home, I thought you the fittet peron in all our parts, to be acquainted with what I have een, and the rather, becaue it being neceary to look unto the preervation of our Towns, Houes, and Families, there is none better able to do it then you. I mut acquaint you therefore, that as I was looking to my Flock near Mount Verdune, I aw all the Plain of Marcelles covered with armed men, who hot whole clouds of arrows into the Town, and have compaed it about on all ides: I aw alo that thoe within the Town did come forth, and meeting with the enemy, made a long fight: I not having o much patience as to tay to ee the difference ended, I thought it better for us to look to our elves, and therefore came as fat as ever
I could to acquaint you, in hopes that your prudence would direct us in the bet coure to prevent uch misfortunes as may fall upon us and our flocks.

Phocion was a little urprized at the report of this Shepherd, yet having heard ome few dayes before that Polemas did ecretly levy all the men he could, he preently concluded that his rebellion was broken forth, and that he had made an attempt upon Marcelles; but being unwilling to declare his thoughts before the Shepherd, he dimied him with many thanks for his care, and a promie to be very vigilant in the prevention of any diorders which eemed to menace them. The Shepherd being gone, Phocion turned towards Thamires and Silvander, and taking them by each hand, he began to walk in the middle, and to ay thus unto them. I need not now ask who were the ravihers of Atrea, nor where he is detained: for this Shepherd hath aured me, that Marcelles is beieged, and none being able to offer this violence but Polemas, I believe none but he would haue been the Authour of this wicked action committed againt this young Shepherdee; but this that hath hapned unto her is a warning to us all, and bids us look unto our elves: and in lieu of delivering Atrea, to recommend her unto the tuition of Tautates, and to eek out for ome place of afety for our elves againt this rebellious Cavalier.

This was the firt dicoure of Phocion, unto which Thamires anwered, that the report of this Shepherd was very probable, and uited with the upitions they had of Polemas; that he had heard ome whipers of it in Marcelles, and therefore he thought it bet to recommend all unto Heus the Puiant God, and get into ome trong houe or Catle, to defend themelves againt uch violences as might be offered unto their perons.

Silvander began then to peak: if we retire our elves into any place (aid he) it ought not to be unto any other place but Marcelles, where we may be erviceable unto Amais, and imploy our courages in defending her againt the injuries of her enemies: For my part (aid Phocion) I think it to be the mot honourable coure we can take, and then if Atrea be in the hands of Polemas, I will ummon him, either to retore her unto me, or to fight with me: though I have long dicontinued the exercie of arms, I have not yet quite forgot the ue of them; and though age have a little abated me of my younger trength, yet will my courage upply that fault.

Thamires and Silvander admired the generoity of Phocion; and Thamires, after he had a while conidered upon the propoition of getting into Marcelles, I beeech you (aid he) if Polemas have compaed the Town round about, which way can we poibly enter? To that, Silvander anwered, that it mut be with arms in their hands, and by forcing their paage where it was conceived the enemy was weaket; but Phocion, haking his head at it: This way (aid he) is very dangerous for uch as carry any women with them and certainly Diana, Phillis, Celidea, Stella, and the ret, will never leave us; I think I have a better expedient then that, and if I be not much mitaken we may proceed this way: Firt, it is impoible that Polemas hould hut up Marcelles toward • the Mountain; for that way unto the Town is inacceible, by reaon of the teep and harp rocks upon which it is built, for he had need of wings to mount up by that way: Now I do know a little private back path, which is known unto very few, and which will lead us through the wood jut under the Catle: from whence, after we have paed over Herdrick, which is a little river that runs between the Mountain and the Town, we will hoot in a letter, which being carried to the Grand Druide, will let him know the place where we are: and for the fear of failing, we will write everal coppies, and hoot them all into the Town at the ends of arrows, o as o many, it is impoible but ome one mut come to his hand. Adamas will undoubtedly do all he can to avour our deigne, and it is to be hoped he may open unto us the next gate, which is not above a hundred paces from the place where we hall be when we hoot in the arrows. At the wort, if we hould chance to meet with any hinderance from the enemy, we may hold them in play whilt the women enter, and Adamas will certainly end out a party to relieve us.

Silvander and Thamires thought this the bet way that could be devied; and Silvander taking upon him the writing of the Letters, they all reolved upon the execution of this coure the next day towards night, and in the interim to amble as many men as they could, and the Shepherds to provide themelves of arms: after this they returned to the ret of the company; and Silvander having acquainted the Shepherds, who had choen him for their Captain, that the Rendezvous was to be the next day, they vowed not mie a minute of the time and place appointed, but would be ure to come and bring with them all their friends, and o they retired.

Phocion did keep with him Silvander, Thamires, Hylas, Stella, Celidea, Licidas, Phillis, Diana, Cor • las, and ome others, unto whom, by the advice of Silvander and Thamires, he ecretly communicated the principal heads upon which they had concluded: all the day was very adly pent, for Phocions grief at the loe of Atrea, made all the ret very melancholly, and their dicoure was nothing, but upon a thouand vexatious dreams which Phocion had the night before: The next morning they all roe as oon as Aurora began to dawn, and every one began to put themelves in order. Amidt all their orrows, it was ome port to ee Phocion cour up his old ruty arms, that had not een day of at leat an age before. Diana and Phillis were afflicted with a certain fear of ome misfortunes that might befall Silvander and Licidas; but when they conidered, that there was no other means to prevent their carrying away as Atrea was, they patienty ubmitted themelves unto uch neceity as could not be avoided. When the Sun was at the hight of the day, the Shepherds who were appointed to Rendezvous at the houe of Phocion, began to flock from all ides: before night they were all aembled, and the number of them appeared to be a hundred and fifty: This rejoyced Silvander, and particularly Phocion, who now thought himelf able, if need were, to make a very coniderable defence. And to defer the execution of their enterprie no longer, as oon as the Sun was et, they et forward; but not before they were ranked and filed into as good order, as if they were to fight a battel.

Silvander, who yielded unto Phocion both in age and experience, and ubmitted all unto his conduct and command, did admire the order which this generous old man did bring this troop into: Firt he divided them into three Companies; and himelf marching in the head of fifty, he commanded the Shepherdees to follow immediately after them: the other fifty he recommended unto Hylas and Licidas, and the lat fifty he referred unto the charge of Silvander: and thus after they had recommended their flocks unto the tuition of Tautates, they et forward: had they been a little ooner, they had een ome marks of the lat aault which was given againt Marcelles; for Polemas, whom night focced to ound a retreat, aw his men and Engines burned, and received a hameful repule in the preence of Alerantes, not being able o much as to keep Alexis, Silvia, and Atrea, who were his prioners.

In a little pace, Phocion perceived the Catle of Marcelles, and though the place which they were to decend, was very rough and difficult; yet they got over the little river without any harm, for the night was not o dark but they could find the paths, and ee where to tread and hold themelves upon the rocks, over which they were to pae. As oon as they came to the place from whence Phocion aid they hould hoot in the Letters; Silvander, Hylas, Thamires, and Licidas, did take the bows which they had given unto Diana, Phillis, Stella, and Celidea, they tyet the Letters unto the piles of the arrows, and hot them into the Town everal wayes. Each of them hot ix times, for Silvander had prepared everal coppies; o waiting for what heaven would do with them, they tood ilently upon their guard, in a reolution to defend themelves, if any aaulted them. It was not long before they heard from Adamas, for one of the arrows lighting happily near the place where he was, a Souldier did carry it preently to his corporal, who carried it preently unto the Druide; and he had no ooner opened the Letter, but two more were brought unto him, which were found in other places of the Town. He received them very gladly, as thinking it ome advice
for the ecurity of the place: but when he aw it was Sylvander, who writ in the name of all the Shepherds of Lignon, his joys were extream, and as oon as he had opened the ret of the papers which were tyed to the ends of arrows, he found thee words in them all.

body.head: SYLVANDERS Letter unto ADAMAS.
body.p: MOt Reverend Father, If you have any Indulgency towards the Shepherds of Lignon, and if their lives, which they come to acrifice for the Liberty of Amais, be a victime worthy of acceptance, we are here an hundred and fifty, who dedicate our lives unto her ervice. Our Woods are now a Receptacle only for Owls, and we have left them, to eek for Sanctuary in this Town, if your favour will give us admittance, Phocion, (whoe blood boyls in his veins, as if he were but twenty years of age) has the Conduct of us, who do all vow our fidelity in particular, and will be ready to be employed upon all occaions whatoever. We beeech you to advertie us of your reolution, who tay here in the ame place from whence we ent this Lettes, which is under the Catle in a Meadow that parts Herdicke from the Rocks of Marcelles,

div.p:
The Druide preently found out the ingenuity of Sylvander, and knew that o many Letters to one purpoe, was only for fear left any hould micarry: o as deiring to end them all peedy relief, he went unto the Nymph as fat as poibly he could, to communicate the Letter unto the Nymph, and found her preparing her elf to go and viit Alexis, but he diverted her, o as he deferred her viit until the next morning. Amais thought it very fit to receive Phocion, and told Adamas, that if he wanted any Forces, he hould acquaint Prince Godomar with his deires, which he did; and the Prince hearing that Phocion was there, and enquiring who he, and all that came with him were, he was very glad of his coming, and would go himelf to bring them into the Town. Mot of the Souldiers were either wounded, or weary with fighting; but as oon as ever they heard of Phocions deigne, they offered to obey the Prince in whatoever he would pleae to command them. Godomar mounted Alcander with thoe that followed the Queen Argira, and were left with the Princes Roanira, only to dicover whether there was any Treaon in the deigne: But it being told him that Polemas was quite retired, and that there appeared no enemy near the Town, he commanded Alcander to go unto the place where Phocion was, and Guad him and his company into the Town: Alcander obeyed the Princes order, and turning a little upon the left hand, he went down as far as the little River; he had not gone forty paces, but he epied the Troop which he was to Guard; and left he hould give them too terrible an Alarm, he ent two Horemen to advertie Phocion of his coming: The good old man no ooner heard that Alcander was come to guard them, but he acquainted Hylas, Licidas, and Sylvander, and afterwards all together went to meet him. Alcander alighted to alute Phocion, and preently taking hore again, he commanded half of his Troop to march towards the Town; then deiring Phocion to follow, he would bring up the Arrear himelf with the other half. Thus they came to the Town; Adamas tayed at the Gate in expectation of them; and the one half of Alcanders Troop being entred, Phocion appeared, whom the Druide received with cordial carees. But ince al this could not be done o ecretly, and with o little noie, but Polemas mut needs be advertied of it: Phocion was no ooner entred with the hepherdees & that fifty which he conducted, but they heard Alcander engaged with the enemy. Sylvander faced about with his company, and went immediately to relieve the Cavalier: Alcidon at the ame time allyed out with two hundred Archers; Phocion, do what Adamas could, would
needs do the like: but all this needed not, for the noie immediately ceaed, becaue Alcander had taken Peledontes prioner, and thoe that followed him, who were not above thirty Hore, fled all away, when they aw the inequality of the number. Thus Alcander, Sylvander, Phocion, Alcidon, and the ret, all entred into the Town, very proud of their new conquet, in taking Peledontes prioner: for he being one of Polemas his principal privie Counellors, they hoped to crue much of the enemies deigns out of him: Adamas obtained of Phocion, that Diana and Phillis might lodge at his houe with Leonide, but he would not tell him that Alexis and Atrea were there already: Licidas, who knew what credit he had with Clindor, he carried thither Phocion, Sylvander, Thamires, Hylas, Corilus, Stella, Celidea, and ome others; the ret of the Shepherds were put under everal Captains and Officers, and had their Quarters aigned them.

After the Druide had een the Gates of the Town hut, he carried away his new guets; and Alcander committed Pelidontes to a place of ecurity, intending to preent him unto the Nymph in the morning. Diana and Phillis having now nothing in their minds but the los of their companion, they asked Adamas by the way. whether he heard any thing of Alexis and Astrea: To which he anwered in o faint a manner, as made them think he knew nothing that was good concerning them: He told them, that the lat news he heard of them was, that they were prioners unto Polimas, and that they received very harh entertainment from him. At this dicoure Phillis and Diana could not refrain from Tears, and coming to his houe, he carried them into a very fair chamber, neither Leonide nor Atrea knowing of their arrival: After this, calling for his Neece to keep them company, he met her, and charged her not to tell thoe Shepherdees that Atrea and Alexis were there: Leonide who knew her Uncles deign, only winked at him; for at the ame intant the Shepherdes came upon her with a thouand expreions of great affection. Whilt they were in the midt of their mutual carees, the Druide left them, with a promie of returning preently again, and he went unto the chamber of Alexis, where Atrea was; for ay what the Chyrurgions would, Celadon would not uffer Atrea to part from him: And after he had been a while with them, he told them of the arrival of Phocion, Sylvander, Hylas, Licidas, Thamires, and at lat, of Diana, Phillis, and other Shepherdees of Forret: at which Alexis eemed to be very glad, but epecially Atrea, who hearing that Diana and Phillis were in the houe of Adamas, beeeched her Mitris to let her go and bid them welcome. Alexis conented, upon condition he would bring them into her chamber; and though Adamas was at firt againt it, by reaon of his wounds, yet at lat he conented upon condition alo they hould tay but a while, and that they hould be in another chamber, ince it was not handome they hould ee the dreing of his wounds which he received in the fight. Celadan obeyed whatoever Adamas deired, and then the Druide taking Atrea by the hand, he carried her to the chamber door where her companions were; and deiring her not to enter until a while after him, as oon as he was come to Diana, You hall ee here one (aid he unto her) whom you little expected to meet, and one who perhaps you will love when you know her: Upon this Atrea entred, and uch a udden urprial did o amuze them, that they could hardly alute each other. At lat, being a little recollected, they began to embrace each other o affectionately, and o long that they were ready to tifle themelves.

Their carees had continued longer, if Adamas had not interrupted them, who taking them by their hands, Nay (aid he unto them) this is not all; I will alo conduct you unto the chamber of Alexis, upon condition you will not tay with her too long, becaue of ome wounds which he hath received, which caueth her to keep in bed; and that Atrea may have more time to tell you all their adventures, I will let her lie in your chamber.

Then he carried Diana and Phillis unto the chamber where Alexis was; and though he was full of pain, epecially by reaon of a wound which he received in her houlder, yet he received them with uch an apect, as tetified abundance of joy to ee them. Their dicoure was not long, for it was late, and their tay
might have been prejudicial to the health of Celadon; therefore Leonide conducting them into their chamber, they all ate down upon the bed, where Atrea made a punctual relation of every paage that had hapned unto her ince the time of her taking away.

On the other ide, Phocion, Licidas, and the ret, whom Clindor entertained, all heard what brave exploits Alexis had done in the habit of Atrea: and Phocion was o joyed to hear of his Neeces deliverance, that had it not been very late, and uneaonable to trouble Adamas at that time of the night, he would have gone to ee her that very hour.

Amais had already viited almot all thoe who were wounded in the lat aault; and amongt all the dicontents which he received at the inolency of Polemas, it was no mall conolation unto her, to conider how many brave men were armed in her defence. But Polemas was almot tark mad, as well at the los which he had received in the two aaults, as at the taking of Pelidontes; being come into his chamber, and unwilling that any hould be witnees of his depair; as oon as he aw himelf alone, he threw his hat upon the Table, cratched his head with one hand, and thumped his breat with the other, then walked up and down the room a great pace; at lat he topped upon a udden, and tamped upon the floor with his foot. Will ye alwaies be my enemies, Oh ye Gods! who dipoe of Scepters and Crowns (aid he) Is my ambition to have ome Empiredome over the pirit of that Beauty o great a crime, that Love, and the perfections of Galathea will never pardon it? Though there be a Law which forbids what I have done, and renders my Arms unjut; yet, Am I the firt that has violated that Law, Or, whom you have let go unpunihed? Then beginning to walk again: But (aid he) this Nymph does not love me, Lindamore is Lord of her thoughts, as he is Lady of his liberty: Mot of my men are murdred, burned, and defeated, Gondebaut perhaps will not ait me, Alexis is ecaped, Pelidontes is prioner, Oh mot cruel Gods! Oh mierable Polemas! The mot mierable of all men living! What cant thou do to unravel thy elf out of this labyrinth of confuion? How wilt thou compoe into order this Chaos of thy affairs? Upon this, cating himelf upon his bed, he called for him that waited in his chamber, and commanded him to go for Ligonias; who as oon as he entred, was atonihed to ee Polemas in that poture wherein he found him; one leg lay a cros over one knee, one hand upon his bret, and the other with a handkerchief wiping his eyes, which the ire of his love and anger together had made extreamly red; and becaue he poke not a word unto Ligonias, but lay adly in this manner a long while; Sir (aid Ligonias unto him) perhaps you have a dipoition to take ome ret. So I have (aid he, and turned towards him) I do eek for ret, and would buy it at the price of my blood: but I fear it is impoible for me to find it, unles in my grave. Upon this Polemas fetched a profound igh, and Ligonias with a cold countenance aid thus unto him.

The truth is Sir, you have to do with tronger enemies then ever you imagined to meet with: Is it not a miracle that a Princes whom we thought detitute of all humane aitance, hould in o hort a time have her Town o full of valiant men, as it is impoible to take it without the favour of ome Forrain help? Ah Ligonias (aid Polemas) 'Tis true indeed, I have very potent enemies; but thoe whom I mot fear, are the Gods, and Galathea. I am not o well read in the book of Fate (anwered Ligonias) as to know what detiny the Gods have ordained you, but the very truth is, Galathea has no great caue to love you; for can you think to oblige her, by doing the very ame things that are proper to make a mortal enemy? Does laves ue to hold their Lords in captivity? Why, you do kill her people, trike at her, and are as careles in oberving her Laws as any Satyre: I mut confes (and I beeech you pardon the freedom of my language) that this deigne has too geat a tincture of tyrannie; and your caue having no pillars of Jutice to underprop it, you had need be very careful that it fall not upon your head, and ruine you. Upon this Ligonias held his peace, and Polemas poke. I hould think (aid he) that I have greatly offended the Gods, if the greatet of them all had not connfeed me to ue thee violences againt Amais: Love is the only Author of
all thee diorders and ince a god cannot in, the actions which he hath done in me, cannot without blaphemy be called crimes: and therefore I hope they will regard my paion, and pity my ufferings for Galathea, ince certainly they would never adorn her with o many perfections, unlee they had deired he hould be adored.

As concerning the trength of Amais, I have reolved upon your departure tomorrow with Alerantes, to conjure and olicite Gondebaut about hating away thoe Auxiliaries which he hath promied: for if they come in time, it is impoible he hould reit us; perhaps we hall do omething in the mean time, for if my deigne with Meronthes hit handomly, doubtles before your return I hall be mater of the place, and of Galathea alo: Nothing goes o near my heart as the taking of Peledontes, and certainly it had been better if he had been les valiant and more prudent; for he was much to blame in fighting with the enemy, when I ent him only to dicover, epecially having not above thirty or fourty hore, and the enemy doubtles ix times the number. Perhaps (aid Ligonias) he was contrained to fight; and being dark, may be he went nearer then he determined, and was firt aaulted, o as he cou'd do no lee then defend himelf. Well (replied Polemas) I will think upon his deliverance; in the interim make your elf ready, for I go preently about your dipatch: upon this Polemas went into his cloet and began to write.

In the mean time Amais was in her chamber with Godomar, Damon, Alcidon, and almot all the Nymphs and Ladies that were then in Marcelles: and becaue it was yet too oon to go to bed, the Nymph commanded Silvia to relate the particulars of her imprionment, and how he liked the entertainment of Polemas. The young Nymphs interceded to excue her, becaue they thought he could not make a right relation, without interweaving the caues of her complaint againt Ligdamon. But being obliged to obey the command of Amais, and olicited by Godomar he made a relation of it unto them, yet with o much dicretion as he did not at all touch upon her relation to Ligdamon: but that Cavalier by chance coming in to do his reverence unto her, for he had not yet een her ince the recovery of her liberty, he changed colour two or three times, and afterwards retired her elf into another room, none taking any notice of her but Leonide: for the eyes of all the company were wholly upon Ligdamon, whoe handome grace, and becoming carriage, did whereoever he came beget eteem and admiration. At lat Amais intending to preent him her elf unto Silvia, he roe up and took the Cavalier by the hand; but when he turned about to look for Silvia, and aw her not, he was extreamly atonihed: the turning to Leonide, what have you done with your companion (aid he and miled) have you imprioned her again? I do not think Madam (anwered Leonide) that he is far from hence: go then (replied Amais) and command her from me to return. Leonide went into the next chamber, where finding Silvia itting in a ad and erious tudy: how now? (aid he unto her) does your heart fail you? Truly (anwered he, and bluhed for anger) my heart is vexed to ee Ligdamon live, after o many tetimonies of his infidelity. There is omething (aid Leonide) which I do not undertand: but ince my Lady asks for you, let us go in, and in the mean time conider, that you ought not to condemn before you hear: I hear (replied Silvia) ah iter I will never neither ee nor hear him again by my good will; and I beeech Amais to pardon me, if I do not obey her command as long as he is in the room, for I cannot endure the very ight of the Traytor: Leonide knowing that he had a pirit that was not eaily bended, did not importune her any longer, but returned into the chamber, and told Amais in a low voice, that Ligdamon could not hear, how angry her companion was: at which, Amais knowing how much Silvia was obliged unto that Cavalier, he could not chue but wonder; yet not being willing to enquire any further then; well (aid he) I will for this time content her melancholy humour. Madam (aid Ligdamon) perhaps Leonide has failed in her commiion, or ele may be he is troubled at omething in which I may atisfie her; I beeech you give me leave to go and ee what it is: It may be, aid Amais, he may receive a remedy from him that hurt her, hurt
her (replied Ligdamon) what hurt have I done unto Silvia, unlee you give that phrae unto the love I bear unto her: I know not (anwered Leonide) but I am mot certain, that your preence at this time cannot cure her. Ligdamon being atonihed at this alteration in Silvia, and a little offended at her action, if this be an effect of my abence, I will uffer it as long as her cruelty is pleaed to appoint, and to begin my ubmiion to her will, he hall not now be offended at the ight of him whom he cannot endure: upon this he retired, but being impatient to know the caue of Silvias dicontent, he turned back again, and finding the door of the cloet which belonged to the chamber open, he got as near as he could behind the hangings, uppoing they would be talking of his affairs. And indeed Amais ending again for Silvia, he entred, and being importuned by Godomar to tell the caue of that hatred which he eemed to bear unto Ligdamon, he told them, yet not without a hundred bluhes, all that Lidias whom he mitook for Ligdamon, had done in favour of Amerina; he poke of her jealouie in uch pritty pleaant manner as made them all to laugh, he related unto them the combate which was in her oul, when he aw him carried away prioner: he told them how glad he was to ee her elf in ome ort revenged, by the danger unto which he was expoed: and afterwards her extream compaion when he conidered him to be the ame that choe death rather then be fale in his love; but (aid he and continued) he would never take any notice of me, till now he ees me out of all danger; and now he would come and fawn upon me, but I am reolved not to ee him, o ave him the labour of peaking, and me of hearing.

Amais, Godomar, and Galathea, would all have poken, when Ligdamon lifting up the hanging, and throwing himelf at the feet of Silvia before any body perceived him: Madam (aid he) if this entence of death which you have pronounced againt my happines, be only to make me feel your rigour, and o make me the mot wretched man alive, I will not enquire whether it be jut or no, for it is enough if you bid me die, to make me do it; but if it be to punih me for a crime whereof you conceive me guilty, I am confident my innocence will move you to revoke your entence: hould I eek for any arguments to jutifie my elf, perhaps you would upect the real truth of them, ince you are o prepoeed with an opinion that I have inned againt you. But if it would pleae this fair Nymph to peak in my favour, aid he, and pointed at Galathea, you will find that if I be guilty, it is only in your imagination. Though he do not (aid Amais) yet I can tell you Silvia, that if you did ee Ligdamon when you were with Polemas, there is two Ligdamons. That is it, replied Silvia, whereof I accue him. I can aure you (aid Galathea) he never left me all the while you were in the prion of Polemas, but perhaps your mind was then much troubled, and you fancied only that you aw him: My mind indeed was much troubled (anwered Silvia) yet my eyes were not o bad but I could ee uch objects as preented themelves before me; you will find Silvia (aid Galathea) that he whom you aw was Lidias, and that the woman whom he talked with, was Amerina or Melander. Doubtles it was (aid Godomar) and now I do not wonder that Amerina hould heretofore take Ligdamon for Lidias, ince this Nymph who brags that he can ee o well, has taken Lidias for Ligdamon. Then Amais told her how much he was obliged unto the love and courage of that Cavalier, and how he leaped down the walls to relieve her. And Silvia who indeed did ee two Cavaliers in the ditch, he no ooner knew that Ligdamon was one of them, but he lov'd him more, and began to have a better opinion of his fidelity then ever.

On the other ide. Polemas finihed his Letter; and becaue the confidence he had in Ligonias would not let him hide any ecret from him, he ent for him into his cloet; and being both there alone togetherr, he made him uch extraordinary Carrees, as Ligonias tood as if he were charmed: at lat Polemas hewed him the Letter which he had written, which Ligonias opening, he found thus indited.

body.head: POLEMAS his Letter unto GONDEBAUT King of the Burgundians.
body.p: THis Cavalier whom I have dipatched unto you, and who is mot entirely faithful, will acquaint you with the mierable tate of my affairs, and what neceity I have of thoe Auxiliaries which you hav promied unto me: I have already made two attempts upon the Town with bad ucces: for having the valour of Prince Godomar to grapple with, it is impoible but I mut be ruin'd, unles your Authority do take from me the obtacle of o o puiant an enemy. Were not your Majety concerned in my ruine, I hould not be o zealous to avoid it as I am: But ince you do loe a Crown by my defeat, me-thinks you hould defend me for your own Interet as well as mine. Ambition, that glorious Paion, which reigns in the hearts of the highet, hould not (me-thinks) be aleep in you, ince the authority of your Arms and Actions will make that eem jut in you, which would be condemned as Tyrannical in another. Furthermore Amais has openly declared her elf againt you, and mocks at your power, as if you had not any power to do her any harm. Her offence, which is no les a in then blaphemy, (for Kings are Gods upon earth) does deerve no les a punihment then the anger of your Majety, which he will feel by the effects of that Army which I ask, and by which I hall hold a Scepter of you, which being taken out of the hands of a woman, will be better accompanied with a Lance then a Ditaff.

div.p: Ligonias having read this Letter, he lapped it up, and ealed it with the Arms of Polemas; and promiing to make all the hate that poibly he could, he retired, and prepared himelf, to depart with Alerantes betimes in the morning.

On the other ide, Amais deiring to betow ome time upon her particular affairs, though the night was well pent, he retired into her cloet with Godomar, Adamas, Damon, and Alcidon; and having propounded her reolution of ending unto Lindamore left ome misfortune hould have befallen Fleurial; the Prince, and all the ret approved of her deigne, and told her, that the ooner it was put in execution, the better it was for her: But one thing did put them unto a little tand, which was, whom to employ in the buines: for whomoever it was, he was to run the danger of paing through the Army of Polemas: but Godomar deired her not to trouble her elf about that, but to dipatch her Letter as oon as he could, for he would help her to a Cavalier which doubtles would undertake it. As oon as Amais had finihed her Letter, the Prince ent for Philiander, who was a very ubtle Cavalier, one of an excellent wit and pirit, and one that knew Lindamore in the Army of Clidemans, from whom he was returned only ince the death of that young Prince: Unto him Godomar communicated the intention of the Nymph, and Philiander deiring nothing more then to do her ome coniderable ervice, prepared himelf for the execution of her commands; the firt thing he did, was, was, to change his clothes, and to put on the habit of a Country fellow; and having the Letter of Amais, he hid it under a piece of leather, which he fixed under the oals of his hooe with a hundred hobnails; and being to be let down the wall into the ditch by ropes, he o daubed his face and hands with dirt, and afterwards rubbed them with an herb which gave a yellow colour, he o changed his complexion and countenance, that none living could know him in that diguie. As oon as ever he was over the ditch, he began to walk as if both his legs
were broken, and the night being already far pent, and the affairs of Polemas were in great diorder, as well by reaon of his repule, as the taking of Pelidontes, it was long before any of the Army took any notice of him: At lat, he was met by ten or twelve Souldiers very well mounted, whom Polemas had ent out to cout, let he hould be urpried by a Salley: As oon as ever they aw him, they et him behind one on horeback, and intended to carry him unto Polemas. As oon as the crafty Philiander aw himelf in this condition, By th' Faith of my body (aid he) I thank you with all my heart; for, but for your kindnes to me, I could not have gotten thither in two days: as he aid o, he leaned firt on one ide, and then on another, as if he had never been on horeback before: he was o very troubleome unto him that carried him, that after he had bid him hold fat a hundred times, and eeing that he could not, he let him lide off the hore, to the ground, on which he fell all along, as if he had been dead. What hould we do with this illy fellow (aid he that let him fall) who takes that for a curteie which were enough to affright any other to death, that is not as innocent as himelf? No matter (anwered one of his companions) ince we have taken him, we mut carry him; and though he be never o innocent, we hould be to blame, and perhaps upected of treaon, if we do not carry him to Polemas Upon this, three of the company alighted, and lifted up Phliiander behind a fourth; then taking two gyrths, they tied the legs under the belly of the Hore with one, and tied his arms about him behind whom he rid, with the other.

He was no onner brought before Polemas, but eeing many velvet chairs in the chamber, he claps him down upon one, and counterfeiting himelf full of pain and wearines, This great ill favoured beat (aid he in a doleful tone) has jogged all my bones in pieces, but they have made me amends in bringing me amongt o many fine oft chairs; by my ay, would all our oxen could go as fat (aid he, and dried his eyes upon his leeve, and looked upon Polemas with an innocent imple look) for if they could, our lond would be ooner tilled, and ave us mickle labour. Polemas, as little caue as he had to laugh, yet could not forbear, when he aw how innocently the man did it him down in the chair, and being moved to pity him, commanded that none hould do him any harm; but deiring to make himelf a little merry with him, he called for a candle, and went neerer unto him, then looking a while upon him, he asked from whence he came? From whence do I come? aid Philiander, why, I came from Marcelles, where I have been put to more pain in two days, then ever I was in all my life; for they tied a word to my ide, and made me hold a long piece of iron in my hand, that was fuller of nails then my hooes. Well, well (aid Polemas) what news in Marcelles: I know not (anwered he) but as long as I was there, it tood in the ame place it was wont to do. I mean (aid Polemas) what are they doing there, and how quares go? For ought I aw (aid Philiander) they do there as they do here; every one goes upon their legs. But (aid Polemas, and laughed heartily) how did you get out? I'll tell you all I know (anwered the Peant) they put me into a little round houe, that tands amongt many tones that are on the walls, and are made like windows; and he that put me there, bade me look about me on every ide, and if I aw any coming, that I hould make a igne to him; when he was gone, and left me there with that great piece of iron in my hand, I fell fat aleep: Now I know not what they did after, nor how I got out of the place where they put me; but as oon as ever I waked, I found my elf under the walls, with my legs, and my arms, and all my body bruied to pieces, pox on't, I feel it yet: Philiander did act all thee things o to the life, omtimes rowling up the brims of an old hat that he wore, omtimes putting his fingers into a hole that was in it, and till keeping his chair, as if he had taken eternal poeion of it, that Polemas eeing and oberving all this, he broke out into uch extremity of laughter, that he made all about him do the like. And knowing what belonged unto war, he very well undertood all that Philiander aid, he eaily knew that the round houe whereof he poke was a Tower, and that the windows were Battlements, and that he being placed there as a Sentinel, they threw him over the walls when they found him aleep.

That which mot helped Polemas to deceive himelf was his knowledge that there was abundance of Peants went at firt into Marcelles, many of which being very illy and ignorant in uch matters, might be well capable of uch mitakes. This made him more apt to pity the illinee of this imple fellow; o as cauing a piece of money to be given unto him, he fell upon erious thoughts, and commanded they hould let him go. Philiander was very glad to ee his counterfeiting thrive o well, made two or three leggs according to the countrey mode, and went unto the next Town, where he furnihed himelf with all things requiite for his journey. All this while Fleurial was making all the hat he could, for he travelled both night and day without any leep: by fortune, when he was beyond Moulins, he met many Souldiers upon the way, and enquiring of one whether they went, he undertood they came from the Army of Childerick, where they had born Arms under the commands of Lindamor, and that now they were returning into the countrey of the Sebutans, the place of their birth. As oon as ever Fleurial heard the name of Lindamor, he was joyed at heart, and hoped for good uccee in his journey; and enquiring further where that Cavalier was; he was anwered that he would be at Moulins within two dayes: This anwer was good news to Fleurial, and made him turn back to Moulins where Lindamor came according to appointment. As oon as ever he aw Fleurial he asked him the caue of his voyage: and Fleurial preenting unto him the Letters from Amais and Galathea; Sir, aid he, I believe thee papers will give you a better accompt then I can: Lindamor took them, and retiring apart, he opened that from Amais, and found it thus written.

body.head: The Letter of AMASIS unto LINDAMOR.
body.p: YOu have not received any Letters from me ince the death of Clidemant, and yet this hall contain no expresions of my orrows for it, but only tell you that Polemas has beieged me in Marcelles, where I am like to ee the los of my on, econded with the los of my tate: Lindamor is now all the hopes I have in my affections, he need not now any longer hew his valour in a trange countrey, ince he has a more glorious occaion for it in his own: I conjure you therefore by the tears and ighs I pend in the memory of Clidemant to come hither, and give liberty to a Princes, who is deprived of it by a rebellious Subject.

div.p: O thou mot impious wretch (aid Lindamor) if heaven do not punih thee, it declares it elf a ider with the unjut. Upon this opening Galatheas Letter he found thee words.

body.head: GALATHEAS Letter unto LINDAMOR.
body.p:
THough the Letter of Amais hould not have any power over you, and though I were deprived fo the command which once I had upon your will, yet I am confident that the delight you take in glorious actions will invite you to relieve us. Polemas will needs triumph over Galathea, without any other pretence or title, but the injutice of his Arms: and whilt Lindamor is triving to crown himelf with Laurels, he is triving to ravih from him thoe Mirtles, wherewith love would recompence his fidelity: Iudge then, my Cavalier, whether any punihment can equal his crime, or any interet more coniderable unto you,
then that of your own good. Come therefore and viit Polemas and Galathea both, to keep him from living, and me from dying: both will be equally advantageous unto you, ince in ruining an enemy you will ave a lover, who will no ooner be out of hopes of your relief, but will have recoure unto word or poion, as thinking them not o bad as the preence of Polemas, in the diobedience of Lindamor. Think therefore upon what I ay: Come, and all the gods be with you.

div.p: Lindamor read this Letter twice over, and thinking a while upon it; Yes, yes, fairet Galathea (aid he and pulling his hat over his eyes) I will come through fire and blood to pull down the arrogance of that rah man: Upon this he preently ent for two or three of thoe in whom he had greatet confidence, and communicating the Letter of Amais unto them, it was concluded that Lindamor, who had appointed all his troops to meet a Rendezvous, to pay and dimie them off, hould now keep them on foot for the ervice of the Nymph.

The Cavalier thought this to be the bet expedient he could chue: o as having paid all his Souldiers, and asked them whether they would continue till under his command, there was not one who thought it not an honour to erve him: And therefore he reolved to go and relieve Amais with all poible hate, and vowed not to take any ret until he had done that Princes ome ervice worthy of his valour; but his had been very mall if it did not urpae that of Polemas all that while, and particularly that night wherein Peledontes was taken: for though he lay upon the bed with endeavour to leey, yet could he not reconcile his eyes, and before he could compoe the ingratitude of his mind, the night was gone.

The Moon hined very clear, and Atrea waking in the middle of the night, and having no mind to leep again, he roe out of her bed and went to the window: as oon as he was there he began to tudy a little, at lat upon a udden he aid, as this night will not be long, o mine methinks ought not to be eternal, and then I hould receive ome conolation. But, what a deperate condition is mine? for my un once et will never rie again: afterwards fetching a mot profound igh. Ah Celadon (aid he) is it a igne of love or hatred, that I hould uffer my elf to live o long after I have been the caue of thy death? Alas I am afraid it is a tetimony of hatred in thee, ince thou dot now want the company of her in the Elizian fields, whom thou didt court in this world with o much paion; but alo it is an argument of thy love, ince thou dot till uffer her to love thee, and in her tears to wah away that crime which he committed againt thy fidelity: upon this, tears flowing in great abundance down her cheeks, and dropping upon the window where he leaned: Alas poor tears (aid he) why do you not the ame unto me that Lignon did unto my dear Shepherd, and drown'd me; but I know the caue, you are dryed up too oon by the fire of my love.

With uch thoughts as thee he entertained the memory of her Shepherd, and the window where he was, being towards the place where Polemas gave the lat aault upon the Town, the good office which Semires had done her came alo into her mind: Poor Semires (aid he) thy death has well repaired the wrong which formerly thou didt againt me; and preently remembring the lat words he uttered: but why (aid he) didt thou pray heaven to keep Atrea for her happy Celadon? Didt thou imagine that Shepherd to be till alive, ince I am o? thou hadt indeed ome reaon for thy thought, ince the oul of Celadon does till live in me, or wat thou deceived by the reemblance of Alexis, and took her for him? If thou wert, I would to heaven I could be o mitaken alo, and that I were not o ure Alexis as the daughter of Adamas, as I have ome kind of upition that Alexis may be Celadon? But alas, alas, I know too well that Celadon is dead; and I have not o much forgotten his favour unto me, but I well remember how I aw his Ghot. Why then Simires, who in this I mut call cruel, houldt thou offer to torment me thus? May heaven (didt thou ay) preerve Atrea for
her happy Celadon. If none be happy till after death, and if Celadon be happy, then it follows he is dead, and how can I be happy then unles I be dead as well as he? Perhaps, and I believe this is thy meaning, the heart of Celadoa and mine being but one and the ame, thou prayet heaven I may preerve it intirely for him, and not uffer my oul to take the impreion of any other object but his: If this be thy requet Semires, aure thy elf it is granted, and heaven it elf cannot warm me with any other flame. But pardon me, valiant Alexis, for pleaing my elf in thee vain fancies, and for remembring the name of this Shepherd o much as in ome ort to forget my duty to you: I have but only two contentments in thr whole world, and they are to think upon him and ee you. Atrea entertained her elf long with thee thoughts, after which, eeing the night was far pent, and knowing by her eyes that he wanted leep, he went back unto her companions, where inenibly he fell aleep, and waked not until the rayes of the Sun (jealous of thoe delights which the God of Love did take, in being hut up with the fairet eyes in the world) die enter into the chamber to let him out.

Hylas, on the other ide, whom it eems love would begin to punih for his former levity, he wondered that a Summers day hould be econded with o long a night, and as if his bed were tuck with thorns he could not find any ret in it: He turned himelf from ide to ide a hundred times, and till found himelf o out of order, that he that none o much tormented as he, being out of all hopes of any leep; how comes it to pae (aid he to himelf) that I hould now igh all night long at uch objects as I was wont to laugh at all the day? What Demen is it that preents Stella unto my fancy more amiable then ever he was? mut her charms be o powerful as to break my leep? Well, well, Stella (aid he and turned himelf with a mile full of didain and anger) though you never committed any other crime but this, in hindering me from my ret, it is enough to make me love you no longer: afterwards imagining that he talked unto her, from henceforward Stella (aid he and flung his arms out of bed) provide your elf of another ervant: for my part, it hall go hard but I will find out of Mitree that will let me leep: had I waked o long for every one of thoe whom I have loved as I have for you, I had long ince lot my wits, and have put Prince Godomar to the pains of driving a nail for me, as he has for Adrates and Roilion; but thanks be to the gods I have hitherto kept my wits in my head, and till now all the women I ever loved never broke me of a quarter of and hours leep. And Stella, can you pretend to have more authority over me, then all thoe beauties had? but believe it, as I left all them for you, o I will leave you for the next I meet, whoe humour and face pleaeth me better then yours.

Thus did Hylas reolve to take his leave of that Shepherdee, and to chue a new one; but preently reprehending himelf, what now Hylas? aid he, cant thou uffer another to be mater of her whom thou now poeet, and to enjoy all thoe favours which that fair one reerves for thee? In aying o, his oul reented uch parks of jealouie as argu •• him to be very deeply wounded: No, no, aid he, never think Hylas, that after Stella any in the world is worthy of thee; and it is for her only whom the gods have permitted thee to cat off Carlie, Stilliana, Cloris, Florice, Chriide, Phillis, Laonice, and o many others, who had not charms powerful enough to retain me any longer in their ervice; but let me tell you (aid he preently after) if all my nights hould be like to this, Stella would be quickly without a ervant and I without a Mitree; and therefore I think it is bet for both to part fair, and hift for our elves betimes whilt we are both well.

This was his lat reolution, upon which he fell aleep, and dream'd that Stella was very glad of his intention to quit her, and eemed to accept of any ones ervice before his: when he waked he aw it was broad day, therefore he dret himelf, and not thinking Stella yet ready to be een, he went to divert himelf in the garden of Clindor.

On the other ide, Phocion, who was extreamly deirons to ee Atrea, acquainted Stella and Celidea that he would go unto the houe of Adamas: whereupon
they reolved to go with him: o unknown unto Hylas, they, with Thamires, Licidas, and others accompanied him unto the houe of the Druide.

Alcander in the interim intended to preent his prioner unto the Nymph, and deired Adamas to acquaint her, which the Druide did, and afterwards told him the dicoure which paed between the Nymph and him: he told him how extreamly the Nymph thought her elf obliged unto his valour, and how deirous he was to give him thanks; alo her great deires to acknowledge o many ervices, and particularly this of referring Peledontes to her dicretion: He told him what reaons Amais had to punih him, that being her ubject hould offer to ait Polemas in his rebellion. And in concluion, deired Alcander from Amais, that he would be contented Jutice hould be done upon uch an offendour, to teach others to keep within compas of their duty.

Alcander, who was wholly devoted unto the interet of Amais, and aimed at nothing more then her preervation, he conented unto whatoever he pleaed, and transferred, though with a little regret, Peledontes into the hands of Adamas, and he was preently put into the ame prion where Clemanthes a little before rendred up his lat breath: there the Druide caued him to be clogged with Irons, and put him into uch a certain expectation of great, punihment, that he looked for no les then death: Now he began to think upon the crime whereof he was guilty, and lamented the mierable condition whereunto he had brought himelf. Death preented it elf unto him in a thouand forms, and o dumped him, that he was deperate: he did nothing but cure Polemas, who had drawn him into that unjut quarrel: In the midt of all his horrour, he began to think which way it was poible for him to ave his life: At lat, the hatred which he had conceived againt Polemas, or perhaps the gods, who were not willing he hould end his dayes o ignominiouly, did help him with an invention, which he had uch hopes would teke, that he extreamly deired to peak with Adamas; and the Druide was no ooner come unto him, but Peledontes aid thus unto him. I mut needs confes, reverend Father, that the crime which I have committed againt Amais cannot be too everely punihed; but if you will pleae to conider how great an influence large promies and protetations of advancement have upon humane imbecillities, you will alo confes it extream hard to avoid the wallowing poion of uch gilded pills as Polemas laid before me: I do not peak this to dicharge my elf, or to ecape the punihment which I jutly deerve, but to let you know that I did not in out of my own inclination, but was violently tempted unto it by the trong intigations of that wicked man. Now Father I know it to be the quality of the gods, ometimes to pardon the greatet crimes, epecially when the inner does trive to make a repentant reparation; and I am in ome hopes, that if you do not deny me your interceion, I may obtain a pardon for my crime, as great as it is, ince I am able to repair it with advantage, and can dicover a deign, upon which the welfare or the ruine of the Nymph does mot infallibly depend.

Adamas litned very attentively unto the dicoure of Peledontes, without any interruption, and conidering in what reputation this Cavalier was with Polemas, he thought that he might perhaps dicover ome ecret which might be the preervation of the place. Yet doubting let it hould be only ome ubtilty to defer his punihment, he tayed a while without any anwer. Aure your elf Father (aid Pelecontes) that if my life may be aved, I will make good what I ay; but if not, I protet no Torture or Rack hall ever get this ecret out of my mouth, Peledontes poke this o earnetly, and Adamas who knew the courage of that Cavalier, and began to compaionate his misfortune, anwered, that the heart of Amais was not made of marble, nor her oul o inenible of any benefit, but he knew how to meaure her recompences accordingly; and therefore (aid he) ince you may very well rely upon her mercy, tell freely all that you know which may be advantageous to her, for that is the way doubtlee to obtain any pity or pardon from her.

Father (replied Peledontes) I am able to do her the greatet piece of ervice that ever was done: for if I hould not prevent it, the Town of Marcelles will
mot certainly be in the power of Polemas within thee ten days. If what you ay be o (aid the Druide) the Nymph is obliged to preerve his life, that will preerve hers; and if you have any confidence in me, I dare promie you upon the faith of a Druide, that he will grant your pardon, o you will make all this apparent unto her. Your word Father (anwered Peledontes) is as acred unto me as the Nymphs; and upon this aurance of it, I will dicover a treaon unto you, which if it be not prevented very uddenly, will certainly be the ruine of Amais and your elf. Upon this Peledontes knowing that Adamas was the Ruler of all in Marcelles, he acquai •••• him, with the treachery of Meronthes, and his plea of bringing Polemas with all his Army under ground into the Town. He told him, that this very night the work was to be begun, and that he might know the place by a light which would be et up upon a Tent where it was intended. When Adamas heard this, he tood amazed, not being able to think Meronies culpable of uch a trechery, ince Amais had been o good unto him, as to trut him with one of the Ports in the Town; yet ince the time of tryal whether it was o, was at hand, he upended his thoughts till then, and bade Peledontes adieu, wearing unto him, that if this were found true, he would obtain from the Nymph, not only a pardon for his life, but a recompence worthy for uch a notable piece of ervice.

In the mean time Phocion came to the houe of Adamas, and not finding him, he went unto the chamber of Atrea, where Celidea, Stella, and the ret were no ooner entred, but that Shepherdes began to cares them, as if he had not een them in ten years before: Preently after, Alexis ent for them; and though Adamas had no deire he hould be een, as well in repect of her wounds, as out of fear he hould be known; yet he had taken uch good ret, and her wounds were o little troubleome to her, that he could not endure to be any longer out of the preence of Atrea.

Thee Shepherds then, and thee Shepherdees, went unto the chamber of Alexis, where they had not been half an hour talking, how much Atrea was obliged unto the courage of that uppoed Druide, but Hylas entred: This Shepherd wondred not to find Stella in the houe of Clindor, but hearing that he followed Phocion, he enquired which way they were gone, and hearing it was unto the houe of Adamas he went thither: As oon as he was well entred into the chamber of Alexis, he topped upon a udden, and looking upon all the company, he asked if they knew him: And the Shepherdees anwering yes: Truly (aid he) I wonder at it; for I am extreamly changed of late: Do you not ee how I have all the ignes of death in my face? Stella who laughed at him, and eeing his eye fixed upon her, he thought it her part to anwer and therefore aid unto him: It is very trange ervant, that you hould wonder at any change in your elf, ince it is but cutomary in you; but I have much ado to find any igns of death in your face, for they ue to be extreamly pale, and I never aw you more red then now you are. It is then (anwered Hylas) becaue I bluh at my implicity, in wihing you o well as I have done. That caue (replyed Stella, and was a little netled) hall never put me to the bluh; for the truth is, I never wihed you well. Your angry mood (replyed Hylas) is not an argument of your indifferency. Then it is of my didain (anwered he) for uch a pitiful thing as Hylas cannot make me angry. All the company were much urprized at the rarenes of thee two new Lovers; and the more, becaue they could not imagine what hould be the caue of their quarrel; o as for better atisfaction, Atrea addreed her elf unto Stella, and aid unto her, The ill humour wherein I ee Hylas, makes me afraid to peak unto him, let he hould be angry at me alo; but ince I believe you are not compoed of o much Touchwood as he is, good Stella, tell as what caue of dicontent have you given unto him? Really (anwered Stella) I am as ignorant as you; but I believe, that he not having any colourable pretence of quitting me, he will needs quarrel with my innocency. Astrea and the ret did know very well that Stella poke as he thought, yet not being able to believe the levity of Hylas o great, as to break off with a woman without ome appearance of reaon, Phillis ventured to talk unto him: Hylas (aid he) we
cannot imagine the reaon of your ange • , unles it be that you are reolved to dioblige all manner of women. Fair Phillis (anwered the incontan • man) my anger reaches not o far as you, nor any further then Stella; and could I not remember her, which will be ere long. I hould forget that ever I was angry. You hall make good hate (aid Stella, and interrupted him) if you forget ooner then I; for I protet, I begin already to think that I never aw you. No matter (replyed Hylas) whether I go pot or no, o I arrive at my intended port, all is well enough. All this (aid Phillis) does not give us any atisfaction. Fair Shepherdes (aid Hylas) I can tell you what the matter is in f •
• ords; it is becaue this woman which you ee there, will not let me ret in the night. Oh heaven! aid Stella, is he o impudent as to ay that I ever went unto him when he was in bed? Yes, yes, anwered he, I did ay, and will ay again, that you were with me when I was in bed; not in your proper peron, but your Image did take up a lodging o long in my mind, and kept poeion of it o trongly, that do what I could, I could not for my heart get you out of it. Stella who expected to hear omthing that would offend her, now hearing that he complained only againt her Image, and that he accued her of a thing, unto which her very thought was not o much as acceory, he broke out into uch a fit of laughter, as made all the ret laugh for company: at which the Shepherd being netled, well, well (aid he) laugh on Stella, as this firt harm you have done me; but I wear by my elf (for that is now the only peron whom I love) that I will never give you any caue to laugh at any harm you hall ever do to me again.

p.U: poke this in a very erious manner, and Stella till laughed more and more, tetifying by her actions that he repented of nothing of what he had either aid or done. I promie you Shepherd (aid he) that I hall neither laugh nor cry at either your good or bad fortune, and it hall be the leat of my cares, whether you be dead or alive. Hylas did not hear thee lat words, becaue he was walked to the other end of the room in a melancholy tudy; and itting down near the bed of Alexis, he heard Alexis ay unto him. Hylas, what do you think upon? I am thinking (anwered he) upon whom I hould betow that heart which I have taken from Stella; and that which mot troubles me, is, that truly I do not know a woman that better deerves it then he. Then (aid Celidea) You cannot do better then to betow it upon her again; and I aure my elf, he is not of uch a marble compoition, but he will melt, and receive it. Your advice (replyed the Shepherd) is good, and the better, becaue it uits with my inclination: as oon as he had aid o, he went and cat himelf at the feet of Stella, and taking her hand by force, he kied it, and aid: If our Laws and conditions fair Shepherdes, were tyrannical, it were injutice to oberve them, and I believe I hould in againt you the firt minute I began to put them into ue; but ince they aim at nothing but liberty, and ince they are of your own etablihment, I hope I hall not be condemned if I put them into practie: Now Mitris, the ame Law that allows me to take away my heart when I will, does allow you to receive it again when you pleae. I do now preent it unto you again, and wear by the Moon, by the winds, and by all the waves of the Sea, that I will never again revoke it: Upon this, Hylas kied her hand again; and Stella, after a eeming denial, was at lat contrained to remit him into grace, being condemned unto it by all the company.

div.p: All this while Celadon durt not peak, left if hould be inconvenient unto him, but he took much delight in this paage between Hylas and Stella. Diana only and Sylvander eemed ad; and indeed both their ouls were o full, that they had much ado to hide it: It was happy for them that all the windows of Celadons chamber were hut; o as it being very dark, and being near each other, Silvander, not to let uch an opportunity of dicoure with his Mitris to lip, he began thus.

How does the fairet Diana? You look (me-thinks) as if your mind were afflicted with ome new orrows. My orrows (anwered he) are not more grievous then ordinary, nor worth the talking of; but I hall be glad to know from whence proceeds thoe orrows which I ee in your countenance more then were accutomed. My countenance then (replyed Sylvander) is more eloquent then I
am, ince it can better peak my orrows then my elf; and ince you command me tell you the caue, he pleaed Mitree to know that my orrows are the legitimate children of your dicontentments. I hall much complain againt the badnes of my humour (aid the Shepherdes) ince it is the caue of yours: and I (aid the Shepherd) hall much commend my humour for being conformable unto yours: And from hence, fairet Mitres, you may draw an argument which tetifies my affection, and the power which you have upon me, ince it is impoible I hould be any otherwie then as you would have me. Did your Fortune depend upon me (aid Diana) and were I the dipoer of Scepters and Crowns, I do eteem your merit at that night, that I would make you the Monarch of all the world. The glory of being your Slave (anwered Silvander) is deares unto me then an Empire; but my dearet Shepherdes, hall I not know the caue of your orrows? You will know it but too oon (anwered he) both for your contentment and my own.

Let not the harm which can happen unto me (aid Silvander) hinder you from telling me what it is, for conidering my condition I am to fear the wort, an unknown vagabond, without upport of Parents, or any hopes to accomplih my deires, unle • in death which is the end of all things I am a man the leat of all men in Fortunes favour, and I can jutly ay, that the gods can take nothing from me but the favour of Diana.
