Though they do not take my favour from you, replied the Shepherdee, yet they will rob you of all hopes in receiving any fruits of that favour: for, at which word he tope, and fetched a deep igh, at which Silvander was much troubled: I Mitree (aid he) I beeech you go on the end of your dicoure cannot be more ad unto me, then the beginning which of it elf is enough to make me die: For Paris (replied he) will no ooner be returned but he mut marry Diana: in aying o, he took a handkerchief out of her pocket, and turning aide left the Shepherd hould ee her, he began to drive up thoe tears which he could not retrain: Silvander, who had no les caue for tears then he, yet he contrained himelf; for eeing uch a fit opportunity of talk, he thought the time better imployed that way then in tears: he told then that the misfortune which the Oracle did threaten unto him, was not abolutely without a remedy, if love, or the conideration of his ervices did oblige her to have pity upon him.

Diana then peaking lower, let they hould be heard, Shepherd (aid he unto him) I mut needs confee that I ow all manner of affection unto that good will which you have expreed unto me; and let me tell you freely, that my affection unto you hall go as far as ever honour will permit me; but conider how far that is, and you will find, that if my mother be reolved to give me unto Paris, it is impoible for me to diobey her. Certainly (aid Silvander) he will never force you unto it; the virtue of Belinde is repugnant unto uch Tyranny. But (aid Diana) if he do expres her deires only of having it o, is not her will a perfect command unto me? What deires oever he expreeth, replied the Shepherd, your conent is alwayes neceary, without which he will proceed no further.

Did you live only for the contentment of another, and not your elf, I hould not condemn this thought in you; but ince you are the peron mot concerned in it, and the weal or the wo of all your life depends upon it, mot undoubtedly you were much to blame if you do not rather follow your own humour, then theirs, who not knowing your inclination, aim more at their own conveniences then yours. What then would you have me do (replied the Shepherdee) would it become me to proclaim at the Market that I will have Silvander, and not Paris? Believe it Shepherd, my honour is dearer unto me then my life, and I had rather endure all manner of torments then fail in my duty, and will ooner refue all happinee then do any thing that becomes not a woman of virtue. To take one and refue another (anwered Silvander) does not at all tain the reputation of a woman, and though you hould ay you love Silvander better than you do Paris, cannot your affection plead a full excue for it? if thoe upon whom you have dependency will allow you ome particular means which hat
pleae your tate, ought they not as well to allow you the choice of that man with whom you are to live and die? No, no, fairet Diana, you are not in the condition of laves, whoe tongues are not their own; you may peak and peak boldly in a buines which concerns your elf the mot, and in which none but your elf mut anwer for the uccee. Silvander expreed himelf o very affectionately, that the heart of Diana began to melt, and o far as to tetifie it by her tears, and the Shepherd eeing that he did not peak, but wavered in her reolution, he would try if he could make a compleat conquet, and therefore he aid thus unto her. When the gods told me I hould die, they knew (my fairet Mitree) that your rigour would be the caue of it; and I hall oon verifie their words, ince you are not pleaed to afford me the conolation of a word: I beeech you conider into what raptures I am ready to fall, and how excueable my fury will be, ince it eems you have flattered me only to betray me; and has raied my ambition high, only that it might have the greater fall. I hall not greive to ee my elf an object of corn by every Shepherd, ince I am the object of your cruelty; but it will be ten thouand deaths unto me to ee my enemies triumph over me, without any other arms but your want of affection. Shepherd (aid he) you may loe me, and ee me in the poeion of another, but you hall never loe my affection; The knowledge that I have of your merits, and of my obligation unto your dicretion, are chains trong enough to retain it eternally. The gods are my witnees, how I deire your contentment above my own life: Hope therefore Silvander in the goodnes of the gods, and in their jutice; as he poke thee words, her eyes did o overflow with tears, that they took away her ight; o as he took no notice when Silvander leaning his cheek againt hers, did kis her: Dearet Shepherdes (aid he) let this kis inpire that life into me which you would have me preerve. Shepherd (aid Diana) your boldnes does extreamly dipleae me; Dicretion and Fidelity are the arms wherewith you have overcome me, and without which your victory will not continue long; and this is the way to make me dry up all my tears, and never grieve for the loe of you.

The Shepherd began to ask her pardon for his offence when Adamas entred, o as he made all the hate he could to tell him, that if he did acknowledge his crime, and promie to offend no more, he would pardon him; and Silvander (aid he) commit not uch a fault again upon pain of my extream dipleaure: upon this he roe up to do reverence unto the Druide. Adamas did not expect to find o much company with Alexis, and was at firt urprized at it; yet conidering they were all his friends, he was better atisfied, and was not orry for their viit of Celadon: After the firt complements he went to the bed of the uppoed Druide, and told her that it was convenient to dimie all the good company that her wounds might be dreed: Celadon obeyed him, and after thanks unto Atrea, Diana, and Phillis, thoe Shepherdees took their leaves and went out of the chamber with the ret of the company, but parted not from Celidea, Stella, Phocion, Silvander, Hylas, Licidas, and the ret, until it was dark night.

Polemas amidt all his dicontents did not forget the reolution he had taken with Meronthes, by the negotiation of his oon: o that as on as day appeareed, he pitched a Tent as near the ditch as he could get, where having erected a light, he gave his level unto thoe that were to work in the Mine, and commandad them, that as oon as ever they aw another light in the Town, they hould fix their level to point at, and be their guide in the work. But Adamas who extreamly deired to urprize Meronthes, and to know whether Peledontes told him truly, he no ooner perceived the Tent which Polemas had erected near the ditch, but he upected their dangerous deign: He took therefore a good party of Souldi • rs, and entreating Damon and Dalcidon to go with him unto the houe of Meronthes, they were no ooner come, but they broke open the door, and went preently into the cave, where the Traytour had prepared all things neceary for his intended work. The noie which they made in breaking open the door did o urprize Meronthes, that when Adamas came to him he looked as pale as death.
And the Druide eizing immediately upon his peron, Traytor (aid he unto him) is this the way to pay that fidelity which thou o wet unto thy Princes Father (anwered Meronthes) I am a mot faithful ubject, and never failed in the ervice which I owe unto my Soveraign. Thy works are tetimonies of what you are (aid Adamas) and in aying o, he put him into the hands of the Souldiers: afterwards asked him, to what purpoe he placed a light upon the top of his houe? To this he anwered with a confident Brow, that in doing o, he did the part of a good ubject; for his houe being neer the Walls, he always et a man in that Tower with a light, to dicover whether the enemy made any approaches. Then Adamas asking him what was the meaning of all thoe pades, hatchets, and mattocks? He anwered, that they were uch as he was wont to ue in the Country about the husbandry of ground, and when he doubted the rebellion of Polemas, he brought all his houhold-tuff, and other moveables out of his Country houe, into the Town, for afety. The Druide admired his impudence in lying, and commanded he hould be earched, to ee whether he had the Level about him; and a ouldier no ooner put his hand into the pocket of Meronthes, but he found it.

Alcidon and Damon in the mean time eized upon his on; and putting the ame quetions unto him which Adamas did unto the father, their anwers were o different, that they alone were enough to convince them of their villany: yet Adamas deiring their own confeions might be witnees againt them, he followed them into the prion; where telling them of the detention of Polemas, and charging them home with their enterprie, he made them at lat confes their intended treachery againt Amais.

Meronthes fell preently into tears and upplications and falling down upon his knees, implored the Druide to intercede for a pardon: But all his hews of repentance would not move that Princes to grant it; for as oon as ever he heard of their confeions by the the report of Adamas, he did o abhor their treaon, that without any motions of mercy, he commanded they hould be preently trangled, and hanged upon the walls, oppoite to the Tent which Polemas had erected, for an example unto all Traytors. The Nymphs command was executed the ame night, and their punihment was thought by every one o jut, that none did pity them.
Their deaths was the life of Peledontes, for Adamas was as good as his word, yet upon condition he hould till remain a prioner, till it was een how the deigns of Polemas againt the Nymph would end.
All things thus paed, whilt Laonice lived in the ame olitude which the Oracle commanded hould be her retreat.

This Shepherdes was no ooner parted from Thiris, but he reolved to wander o long, as till he had forgotten the didain of that ungrateful Shepherd, and till he had found out a handome way of revenge upon thoe whom he thought to be the Authors of her miery: But not being able to live o far from the place where her beloved Shepherd, or rather her own oul reided, he changed her purpoe, and went unto Mount Verdune, where he offered her acrifice of prayer, and beeeched the Deity of that place, he would be pleaed to afford her ome comfortable hopes by the mouth of his Oracle. Her requet was not in vain, for the ame day he conulted with the Oracle, he received this anwer.

div.head: The Oracle.
div.l: WIthin this Wood, a ecret Cell
Will all thy orrows cover well:
If Laonice contant be,
Heaven does her promie remedy.

div.p: This Oracle being pronounced, and Laonice having written it in her Table-book, let he hould forget it, he rendred thanks unto the Gods for putting her into ome hopes of remedy againt her miery; and though the way was very obcure unto her undertanding, yet he thought not any impoibility in it.

The firt thing he did, was to pay obedience unto the firt vere of the Oracle; and auring her elf that the Wood mentioned therein, was the Wood of Mount Verdune, he went unto it, and ought out for a ecret Cell which was in it: By Fortune he found one more pleaant then ere he expected, for it was a thick kind of an Arbour, and no way to get into it, but a little path which conducted into it, and through into a Grotto, which both Nature and Art had caved out of a Rock: As oon as he was in it, he began to look about her, and conider ome particulars which he found in everal places; but becaue he could not comprehend the mytery of them within the compas of her undertanding, he thought the place had been formerly the retreat of ome Druide: o not thinking to find a fitter place, he reolved to tay there, until the Gods did direct her unto ome other coure; and o utaining her elf with ome Country fruits which the Woods afforded, he pent her time, omtimes conulting with the Eccho, and calling upon Thiris, was anwered with Thiris again; and omtimes talking to the Rocks and Trees: but till that Shepherd was all the only ubject of her dicoure.

Thus this Shepherdes led her life, which eemed les tedious unto her, becaue it was in expectation of that remedy which the Gods had promied unto her, and in the hopes whereof he only lived; for he had no other ret nor delight, but only in thinking continually upon Thiris, whoe oul in the mean time was wholly devoted unto the memory of his dear Cleon.

Polemas, who had all the night thought upon his intended work, and flattered himelf with a thouand hopes, that by this means his Love, and his Ambition, would obtain a happy concluion; he no ooner aw day appear, but he aroe, and went to ee how things went forward; and finding that he had already got within ix paces of the ditch, he was infinitely pleaed; o as commanding thoe who had wrought, to ret themelves until the next night, he appointed others to upply their places. This command was no ooner obeyed, but it was broad day; and the Sun guilding the top of the mountain Ioures, Polemas by chance cat his eye upon the houe of Meronthes, always imagining that if he made as good hate with his works, it was impoible but Galathea, and the Town too, would be preently his: But the bodies of that Traytor, and his on, being hung upon the Walls, and expoed to the view of all Polemas his Army, that Cavalier did quickly know them: At the firt he would fain have given his eyes the lie, and did what he could to make ome doubt of that which was too apparent; but after he had rubbed his eyes a hundred times, that he might ee the better, he found that it did but make him more clearly ee the marks of his misfortune: Then did he begin to vomit out all the cures and blaphemies againt the Gods and Amais, that fury could inpire into a deperate oul: Afterwards recollecting himelf a little, Is there no way of revenge (aid he) left me? Has my cured fate deprived me of Alexis, and Atrea, and Sylvia too, Is Semires turned Traytor, and I not know whether he be dead or alive? Ah Vilain! continued he, thou art the cauer of all my mieries, and if ever I get thee again into my hands, the mot cruel torments that ever Tyrants invented, hall bring him to a cured dea • h: But certainly this Traytor could not know of my correpondency with Meronthes; and if Pelidontes have not betrayed us, certainly they have ued Witchcraft to dicover it: But alas (aid he, and looked upon the corps which he aw hang upon the Walls) yonder is Meronthes that uffers for my rebellion: Poor Meronthes! thy fidelity unto me did not deerve o ad a recompence: But dear Meronthes, in what place oever thy oul is now, I would have it know, that my end hall not be more happy then thine, unles I have taken a full revenge upon thy enemies and mine.

In aying o, his orrows o encreaed, that he was contrained to retire; and commanding that the work hould ceae, becaue he knew that his deigne was
dicovered, he was once in a mind to attempt another deperate aault upon the Town, and either to die in the head of his Army, or ele force it to ubmit. But Argonides and Listander, who were then with him, knowing very well that he was not in a condition for uch an enterprize, advied him to return unto Suriea, where the ret of his Artillery and Engines were; and that he hould fortifie that place, and tay there with all his Army, until the King of the Burgandians did end him his promied relief: They propounded alo, that if he aw that relief from Gondebaut low in coming; he hould under ome honourable pretence offer a Truce unto the Nymph, for as long or hort a time as he hould think expedient. Polemas, whoe oul was all in confuion, by reaon o many misfortunes upon the neck of one another, he gave ear unto the councel of Litander and Argonides, never conidering whether it was good or bad; o as giving orders for the retreat of his Army, he ent a Herald unto Amais. This Officer was no ooner at the gate of the Town, but Adamas was advertied of it, and cauing a draw bridge to be let down, they gave him entrance, and conducted him into the Catle. All the Cavaliers were then with Amais, o as the Herald being amazed to ee o many men of merit, he conceived it would be a long time before the Town could be forced; yet it not being his office to judge of their trength, but to acquit himelf of his Commiion, as oon as he aw Amais, he kneeled down upon the ground, and being commanded by the Nymph to rie, he poke in this manner.

Polemas my Mater, being unwilling to neglect any way of weetnes, whereby he way obtain from you that contentment which he deerves, does yet offer to lay down his Arms, if you will put into his hands the Nymph Galathea, whom he deires to marry; and becaue he knows very well, that though you hould have a dipoition to conent unto it, yet you have many about you to conult withall: He offers unto the term of fifteen dayes conideration, during which time, if you pleae, there hall be a ceation of Arms. Upon this, the Herald having made an humble reverence, Amais told him that he hould have an anwer within an hour: during which time, he would advie with Godomar, Adamas, Damon, and Alcidon; which he accordingly, and all were of opinion that he hould accept of this Truce, ince in that interim, Sigimond, Roilion, or Lindamor, might come unto her relief: upon this reolution he returned to the Herald, and gave him this anwer.

Herald, tell thy mater Polemas, that as yet I do not think his arms are able to maks me conent unto that which his arrogance does pretend unto; but ince he will give me that time of conideration: Tell him I would have him in that interim bethink him of uch a coure as may move me to forget his crime, and to pardon it: That otherwie, I do not think this ceation of Arms will do any good, but make me hate him the more, and think him lee worthy of pity. Upon this Amais aroe, and the Herald went away, whom Adamas conducted to the gate of the Town.

Polemas, who expected his return with much impatiency, was very glad the Nymph had accepted of the Truce; but when he heard that he advied him to think upon ome way which might render him worthy of her favour, this tung him to the oul, imagining that this Princes was not yet in any inclination of any will unto him: yet not being able to avoid his misfortunes, he rejected all uch good motions of mind; and till flattered his preumption with huge hopes of that relief which he expected from Gondebaut. In this obtinacy he commanded his Army to make a retreat, and return unto Suriea, fully reolved to begin the iege again, the next day after the expiration of the Truce: auring himelf, that within fifteen dayes he hould receive that relief which was promied unto him by the Burgundian King.

On the otheride, Adamas was not imployed in the preervation of Amais and the State, but he thought upon the recovery of Celadon, o as by the help of ome Medicaments, he was in a hort time able to rie out of his bed; at which Astrea was o overjoyed, that it was apparent he valued his recovery above her own life. The Druides greatet care was to keep Amais from any viits, let Galathea
hould come with her; yet he found out uch handome excues as prevented that danger.

About the ame time the Queen Argira ended her journey, and came unto Policander, who till lived as if he had made a league with death, to let him live until he rendred up his lat breath in her preence: As oon as ever he aw her he rouzed ny himelf, for his intellectuals were as perfect as ever; and not being able to retrain ome tears which pity brought into his eyes, he turned himelf, though with much ado, towards that Princee; and eeing her already upon her knees at his bed ide, and her eyes flowing in tears: Madam (aid he in a faint voice) the gods have favoured me o far, as to upend my death, that I might oberve that promie which I made unto you; and that you being a witnee of my death, I hould receive the greatet comfort that I ere can hope for. But ince my icknee will not uffer me to be o ceremonious as I deired, be pleaed, Madam, to accept of my good will, and to know that I am no les yours then if our marriage had been olemnized with the mot umptuous Ceremonies: upon this he topped, as if it were to recollect a little trength, and whilt the Queen was drown'd in orrows, he began to peak again. I do declare before the gods and all the world (aid he, and turned himelf towards all the Grandees of his Kingdome) that Argira is the wife of Policander, and that I am her legitimate husband; and if any one do deire to know the caues of this marriage, let him know this, that it is the will of heaven and my own duty that cummands it. Then holding out his hand to the Queen, who taking it and bedewing it with tears, Sir (aid he unto him) I do with all my oul receive this favour which you do unto me, and protet that I take this honour for the greatet advantage that heaven could advance me unto: But alas mut I now loe you? heaven has favoured me in the recovery of Roilion, and I hope they will not deny me when I begg for yours. At the name of Roilion the King began to change colour, and looking upon him, he could not chue, notwithtanding the violence of his icknes, but give ome expreions of joy.

Roilion, who was even dead with orrow, and whoe face had as few igns of life in it, as in that of Policander, he advanced towards him, and falling upon his knees cloe by the Queen, he heard the King ay thus; The Law of death is o common unto all men, as you ought not to think it trange I hould pay that debt which I ow unto Nature. Did not Kings ue to die as well as other men, you had ome reaon to wonder I hould be excluded from that priviledge, and that my Scepter and my Crown hould not defend me againt the blows of death; but a Monarch has no more right to live then the pooret Shepherd: we do dayly ee their ahes and their Monuments; as this methinks hould be a great conolation unto you all; to know that I die becaue the gods will have it o, and that they never made any man who was not ubject unto death: therefore my dearet Argira, if you have any conideration of my ret, and have any deire to pleae me. I beeech you top the current of your tears which do but grieve me. I do not require any greater tetimonies of your love, then thoe you have already given me, and wih for no more but leave to die.

Policander uttered thee words with uch a dying voice, as if his oul had gone out of his mouth at the lat word: the Queen was deeply overwhelmed in orrows, as Roilion, whoe groans did tetifie the adnes of his oul. The wrong Celidontes, unto whom Policander had already given the Crown of the Ambarres, of the Boyers, and of the Lemovices, upon condition he would marry Cephie, was o extreamly afflicted, that he could not rejoyce at the return of Argira, nor reent that contentment, which at another time, the recovery would have been unto him.

At lat the King perceiving himelf every minute to grow weaker, and weaker, and finding himelf not able to hold out any longer; he began to trive with himelf: Argira (aid he with a deep igh) I conjure you by that which you love bet, and I think that is my memory, to have a care of thoe whom I leave under your tuition: Make them, by your example of virtue, to abhor vice; and conidering that riches are as fading as our elves, remember that all the good or bad
which we are to have in the other world, depends only upon the merit of our actions in this life. And you Roilion (aid he, holding out his feeble hand) or rather the true Celiodantes, forgive that crime which in my ignorance I committed againt you: Do not accue me of ingratitude; and may Roanira, whom I give unto you, long enjoy thoe Grandeurs wherein you hall hare, as King of the Santons and Picts: Love him for my ake, who hath o long uurped your name.

In aying o, he turned towards the wrong Celiodantes; and you my on, aid he unto him, pay back with interet the good will he hall bear unto you: Love Peace: Never take up Arms but in a jut caue: Have God till on your ide: and above all, carry your elf well towards Argira: This is all I deire from you, Farewel my Sons, farewel dear Argira, farewel Ro — At this word he expired, and his eye remaining till fixed upon Roilion, they knew his intention was to have named him, but could not pronounce the lat part of his name; which the Queen perceiving, and finding Policander to be as cold as marble, it was an hundred to one but he had followed him that very hour. All former coniderations of her voyage, which hould have been conolations unto her, were quite forgotten, and not one thought could keep her from a preent depair; one would have thought that he had drowned her reaon in her tears, and that he had ought for the oul of Policander, in the roots of that hair which he pulled from her head. The wrong Celiodantes was almot out of himelf; and though the death of the King did leave him an Empire, yet he tetified, that he thought the los of his peron made him no gainer. Cephie and Roilion were no les afflicted; and all the Cavaliers preent, expreed abundance of grief for the los of their Prince: They came all unto the Queen, and wore fidelity unto her and Celiodantes; but he was not in a condition to hear what they aid unto her; and if the Ladies had not got her into bed, perhaps he had died.

Thus they all retired, almot as ad for the icknes of the Queen, as for the los of the King. But as in the viciitude of things, nothing is durable; o the orrows of Argira, of Celiodantes, and of Roilion, at the lat leened, and their reaon having ecaped the hipwrack of the firt reentment, the Queen began to remember that aid which he had promied unto the Nymph, and he thought upon nothing more then her preervation.

At the end of a few days, the people over whom Policander reigned, did put the Scepter and Crown upon the head of Celiodantes, with the ame ceremonies as they were accutomed to crown their Kings; and Roilion making all hate to the Picts, did levie by the Queens permiion, twelve thouand men; and afterwards taking leave of Celiodantes his brother, did take the field with his Ar •• , being reolved to relieve Roanira, and oppoe all violence that hould be offered unto Amais.

div.head: The Sequel of the Hitory of LIPANDAS, AMERINA, MELANDRE, and LIDIAS.
div.p:
DUring this while, Lipandas recovered of his wounds, but not of his paion: and though this Cavalier had not much acquaintance with Melandre, yet did he know her pirit, and that he was the mot generous woman in the world. This was a caue, that as oon as the Truce was concluded, and Polemas raied the iege, he was grieved to the very oul: He was not orry that Amais had great hopes in that relief which was promied unto her; but when he conidered that this took from him the means of hewing his courage, and of overcoming the oul of Melandre by thoe tetimonies of his valour which he intended, he grew almot deperate: yet knowing no remedy, he reolved to wait with all poible patience, until the end of this ceation of Arms, and afterwards to perform uch glorious exploits, as he hould in ome
ort of think it an honour to be erved by a Cavalier o full of courage and affection.

In the mean time, it was permitted him to ee her; and becaue in this liberty he lot not a minute of time, which afforded him the opportunity of entertaining her, he endeavoured a thouand times to make her enible of his paion. But he would never be moved unto any further then pity; for he appeared always o prepoeed with the thought of Lidias, as he could hardly ever hope for any alteration in her inclination. As oft as he conidered by how many Laws he was obliged rather to die then leave loving her, he was confounded • he mentioned the combate wherein he was overcome, when he expoed her elf unto the fury of his Arms for the liberty of Lidias; and telling her it was a kind of miracle he hould go off the field with that advantage which he had; he endeavoured to perwade her, that it was the Will of the Gods o to uffer it, only to let him have the glory of being furmounted by the charms of her eyes, as he was by her word. He told her how much he was obliged unto her curteie in procuring his enlargement of Ligdamon, and wore unto her, that when he thought to et him at liberty, he o made him her lave, that he could not think any thing could be more pleaing then his captivity: In concluion, he expreed unto her all that his paion could ugget unto him: But all would not melt the heart of Melandre: for when he talked of his love, he talked of that affection which he preerved for Lidias; and if Lipandas begged any comfort from her, he told him that he tood in as much need of it her elf.

Thus ome days paed over, during which, all that the Cavalier could obtain from her, was, that in the end he conented he hould call himelf her prioner: and whilt he lived in ome ort comforted by the delight he took in that T •
tle which he thought o glorious unto him, Melandre was more and more afflicted; for hearing no more news of Lidias ince he aw him tyed with Alexis and Astrea, in the head of Polemas his Army, he was full of jealouie and depair: omtimes he imagined that he was ecaped with Amerina, and that in prejudice of the fidelity which he had vowed unto her, he would marry that woman in the firt Town they came at: Afterwards conidering it was impoible but he hould be extreamly wounded in the combate, he perwaded her elf that he was dead. Amidt the confuion of thee vexing thoughts, he was likely to die her elf, and certainly had done o, if heaven had not hewed ome compaion upon her, and ent her ome news of him in this manner.

Amerina whom Lidias talked withal under the window of that chamber where Polemas kept Silvia prioner, he no ooner aw her Lover carried away, but he beg •• to follow him; and though he proteted a thouand times that he was not Ligdamon, he could not keep him from being as the ret were, he begged of them upon her knees to put the ame cords upon her hands; but eeing he could not obtain that favour, which they ued upon Lidias as a punihment, he reolved however not to forake him, but to die with him. In this reolution he followed the Army of Polemas; and as oon as he aw Lidias by the favour of Semires, looe from his cords, and in a condition to defend himelf, he went traight unto him; and having no other Arms to fight with but her tongue, he made ue of it to animate him; and did infue o much courage and trength into him, that he began to think himelf invincible: but at lat, not being able to reit o great a number, he retreated, as the ret did, into the ditch, where he fought until he was o weak, by reaon of everal wounds, and los of blood, that he was contrained to fall down upon the ground. Then did Amerina fall down upon her knees, and without loing any time in vain complaints, began to help him; o as pulling out her handkerchief, he topped the blood which ran from a wound in his arm.

A while after Polemas was entirely repuled: o as when every one went back into the Town, Lidias had recovered a little trength; o as by the aitance of Amerina, he roe up; for he taking him by the arm, and holding him up, he got him within the walls: as oon as they were within, Lidias finding himelf to faint, did turn his languihing eyes upon that woman, and would have bid his lat adieu: But he whom Love had inpired with trength, did o utain him, that
he got him ome thirty p • ces further into the Town: Now did Amerina believe he hould loe him: for he falling into a wo • n and he having an trength to utain him any longer, he was forced to et him down under the near houe upon a tone eat, which he found by chance; and there finding no motion in Lidias, he could not chue but cry out, and o violently, that the noie came unto the Mater of the houe; and though all the Town was in arms, you o it hapned, that he not being in a condition to bear Arms he never tirred out of his houe, but tayed within at his prayers, and • o expection of what ucces the Gods would give unto the Arms of Amais.

This man was a Chirurgion by profeions, rich in the ecrets of Nature, but o very old that he could hardly tir out of his chamber; and being very charitable, he no ooner heard the cries of Amerina, but he doubted the caue, and commanded ome of his dometiques to take a light and ee who it was: They were no ooner in the treet, but they brought back word, that he who made the Lamentations was a very fair woman, and bewailed the loe of Ligdamon, whom he held all bloody in her arms. At the name of Ligdamon the good old man changed colour, for he loved Ligdamon extreamly; yet recollecting himelf, perhaps (aid he) that Cavalier is not quite dead: let him be brought hither unto me, for if there be any life, I hope by my remedies to prolong it. Upon this command, almot all that were in the houe went out; aand whilt they were preparing a bed to lay him upon, Lidias giving ome ignes of life, the Dometicks laid him thereon, who heard Amerina igh extreamly, and he hearing them igh and ay ah Ligdamon, alas poor Ligdamon, he hoped that as his name was the caue of Li • ias his wounds, it might, perhaps, be the caue of his cure. She reolved therefore not to name him, but let them go on in their mitake, and not to divert them from their charitable intentions of helping him; o as entring with him, and eeing what cure the old man had in getting him to bed, and to look upon his wounds, he began to have ome hopes in his aitance. Lidias was found not to be mortally wounded, though he had received four very great ones, two in his left arm very near his houlder; one in his thigh, and one on his right hand, which could not be cured without the los of a finger.

As oon as the Chirurgeon had earched all thee wounds, he came unto Amerina; and telling her how the wounds of Lidias were, he gave her aurance, that within a while he would be perfectly recovered: at which he changed colour, and though he was much diordered in her dres, and bloody in everal places, yet he appeared o fair in the eyes of this charitable old man, that he could not chue but think the paage extreamly trange, for he knew that Ligdamon was never married: And therefore upon the firt opportunity he beeeched her to tell him, from what relation did that love proceed which he expreed unto Ligdamon Amerina anwered him, that in the condition wherein he was, he could not poibly atisfie his curioity: beides, the tory was uch, as he could not tell it without bluhing; but as oon as Ligdamon was a little better recovered, he would entreat him to make a relation of it. This anwer confirmed the man in his firt opinion, and whetted his deire of further atisfaction; yet being unwilling to be importunate, be eemed contented to tay until the Cavalier was better recovered; and indeed he began to mend in a few dayes, for a feaver not eizing upon him, and his greatet harm proceeding from his exceive los of blood, it was no great difficulty to cure him; which Amerina perceiving, he told him all that had hapned, and conjured him to continue the mitake until he was perfectly recovered. Lidias therefore did peronate Ligdamon as well as he could, and when the good old man deired to know who Amerina was, he ingeciouly told her name, and related all that he her elf had related concerning the adventures of that Cavalier: the old man had heard omething of it; o as after he undertood the whole truth, he was o well atisfied, as he thought himelf ufficiently recompenced for the cure which he had of his cure.

One day Amaiel (for that was the name of the good old man) would needs go out to be preent at a particular acrifice which Amais intended to offer, for the afe and oon return of Lindamor; and he took that liberty, the rather, becaue
Lidias began to walk up and down the chamber o as uppoing him to be pat all danger, and tood in no need of his preender he was carried • n a chair unto the Temple. Preently after he was entred, Amais came alo, waited upon by all the Nymphs and Ladies that were in Marc • lles; and with them came Godomar and all the gallantry of the Court. It was not long before good Amaiel pied Ligdamon amongt them, and this ight did o much urprize him, conidering the condition wherein he thought he left him, that he went as well unto him as he could, and eemed to be more then half angry. Ligdamon (aid he unto him) you are very undicreet in venturing your elf o oon abroad, and had I thought you would have come out of the houe, I would not have tirred out: Ligdamon, who eteemed this man very much, and had his age in great reverence, did anwer him a in mild manner, and proteted that he did not know what he aid: I ay, replied the good Man, that your triving to walk o much, may caue the wound which you have in your thigh to open again: upon this the Cavalier bethinking himelf of all the wounds that ever he received, and not knowing any uch as he mentioned: I never had any wound in my thigh, replied he, and unles you better explain your elf, I hall not undertand you.

p.U: poke thee few words in uch a trange manner, that the Chirurgeon thought he would not acknowledge his wound, becaue he would not acknowledge his obligation unto him for his cure, and wondering to find o much ingratitude in the oul of that Cavalier, whoe generoity was eteemed by all the world: Sir (aid he unto him) the care which I have had of you deerves a b • tter acknowledgement, but though you do not think me worthy o much as of thanks, yet I hall not loe my reward; for the gods will accept of my good intentions. Upon this Amaiel was ilent, yet tetified by his actions that he was a little diconted, and Ligdamon not being able to imagine the caue: Amaiel (aid he unto him) if I do not with all my hart deire to erve you, may the gods punih me; but I do not know what you mean by thee words, of wounds, of obligation, and of reward. I think (aid the old Man and interrupted him) that you either imagine me in a dream, or ele would make me believe that I am mad. Can you deny that you have been eleven dayes in my houe, and that I have dreed your four wounds, one in your thigh, another in your hand, and two in your arm? Now Ligdamon begun clearly to ee the mans mitake, and knew that it was Lidias whereof he poke: therefore pulling off his gloves, and hewing his bare hands unto him: Father (aid he) do you ee any uch wound in my hand? The old man cating his eye upon the place where Lidias received his wound, and finding not o much as the leat cratch, he tood in a trange confuion; and Ligdamon beginning to peak; bat Father (aid he) do not think your charity any wore betowed: for you have helped a Cavalier who reembles me; one who my name had like to have been his death, as his formerly had like to have been mine, being for him expoed unto the fury of Lions: The good office which you have done unto him, hall be acknowledged by me as thankfully as if it were done unto my elf; after the Sacrifice is done, give me leave to go unto your houe and viit him, for I have longed to know what was become of him. Amaiel heard all that Ligdamon aid, but he was not able to anwer him a word, for his wonder had taken away the ue of his tongue: one while he would cat his eyes upon the face of Ligdamon, and fix them a long while together; and then upon a udden, he would take his hand, and wonder he could not find the wound which Ligdamon received. But the Sacrifice beginning, they were both forced to give over dicoure and fall to their prayers.

div.p: The Sacrifice was no ooner ended but Ligdamon carried Amaiel to his Coach, and went to his houe; and Amerina no ooner aw Ligdamon coming; but he went to tell Lidias, who had uch an earnet deire to ee him, and o glad to hear the news of his coming, that a freh colour came into his cheek; o as Ligdamon no ooner cat his eye upon him, but he thought that he aw himelf in a glas.

They were a long time in aluting and carrying each other, for Lidias knowing how much he was obliged unto that Cavalier for Amerinas ake, thought he could
not embrace and look upon him enough: yet at the lat, falling into dicoure which touched them more nearly, Ligdamon related what Lipandas had done, when to atisfie the deires of Melandre, he leaped over the walls, only to relieve Lidias. At the name of Melandre, Lidias and Amerina were both equally urprized; the one, for the ecret obligations which he had unto that Fair one; and the other, by reaon of uch parks of jealouie which entred into her oul; which Ligdamon perceiving, I aure you (aid he) you mut prepare your elf for a harp combate; for the love of Melandre unto Lidias is as violent as ever; and though Lipandas do all he can to divert her, yet he cannot do any good. Then Lidias, I aure my (elf anwered he) that when Melandre knows what I have, promied unto the fair Amerina, he will not wonder, that (as a Cavalier) I have oberved what I was o olemnly and trictly obliged unto. I believe (aid Amerina) that it is the bet for us both not to let her know any thing, but to teal away out of her preence, and accord all hazards that he may attempt againt us.

Unto this Lidias anwered nothing and Ligdamon was almot of the ame opinion: But for all the •• deires to put this in execution, it was not in their power, for the dometiques of Amaiel, who talk ••
• f this unto everal perons, that the very ame day almot all the Town knew of it: Melandre no ooner heard this news, but he made great complaints againt Ligdamon, and as oon as ever he could teal from Lipandas, who left her as little as poible he could, he went unto the houe of Amaiel. In the way thither, her mind was full of various thoughts, omtimes he fancied the contentment which he hould have in eeing him, for whom he ran o many dangerous fortunes: and otherwhiles thinking Amerina to be with him, he had changed his mind, and was vexed at her apprehenions of his infidelity. At lat, after a long dipute with her elf, he came unto the chamber of Lidias; and not having quitted the habit of a Cavalier, he was hardly known unto him. She found him upon his knees before Amerina, who itting upon her bed, held the head of her Lover in her lap; at which Melandre was o much offended, that being all anger and jealouie, well, well, perfideous man (aid he, pulling Lidias by the leeve of his doublet) are thee any igns of that acknowledgement which you ought to give me? Upon this Lidias knew her, and roe up to alute her: But he puhing him away, No, no (aid he) continue on your ubmiions unto that fair on; but he hall not long enjoy the acrifices of ervice which you offer unto her, for I have a way to be revenged of thy perfidy, and if heaven do deny me jutice, I have courage enough to carve it out of my own depair. Upon this looking upon Amerina, and then upon Lidias, with an eye of extream dicontent, he went away, and would not give that Cavalier o much time, as to peak one word. As oon as ever he was out of the houe, he went traight to the Catle, and never conulting any further what to do, he cat her elf at the feet of Amais, and poke thus unto her: Madam, That Jutice which you have o happily executed, and never denied unto any, I do now emplore upon my bended knees, againt the perfidie of a Cavalier, whom I conjure you to command that he may do me right and reaon in your preence; Our combate hall ue no other Arms but the Laws; and if the ight of his crime will bring him unto any repentance, I do protet I will preently forgive him; however Madam, be you the Arbytrator of our differen •• and when you have heard what we can ay for our elves, I hall mot willingly ubmit unto your doom.

Then Melandre was ilent: And the Nymph who took her for a Cavalier, and thought it better to take up the matter, then to let it proceed unto a quarrel, he conented unto her motion: So Lidias was ent for by a Herauld, and commanded to appear that very hour before Amais. Amerina began preently to upect the deigne of Melandre, and told Lidias how much he feared the los of his affection; but he aured her, that he would rather die a hundred deaths, then break thoe firt oaths which he had worn unto her.

All this was not o ecret, but almot all the Court knew of it; o as when Lidias was brought before the Nymph, the chamber was full of Ladies and Cavaliers: Lipandas and Ligdamon were not then there; But Amerina who would not leave Lidias, entred almot as oon as he, and placed her elf amongt the women.
The Herald had no ooner commanded ilence, but Amais told the ad Cavalier, that he was ready to hear him; whereupon Melandre after an humble reverence, began thus.

I know Madam, that it would become me better to bluh and be ilent, then to peak, ince the habit wherein I am, which is as contrary unto my ex as my humour, doth accue me of impudence, before the mot vertuous Princes of all the Univere: But ince nothing can better condemn Lidias, nor convince him of ingratitude, then the ame Arms and habit wherewith I made him owe his life unto me; I do mot humbly beeech you Madam, to pardon me, for not leaving them off, and for making ue of them, to reproach him with the greatet infidelity that ever any Cavalier ued. Perhaps Madam, the various adventures of my life, are as well known unto your Highnes, as unto my elf, for Clidemant had the relation of them from me; but if neither he nor Lindamore ever writ any the particulars unto you, I have great caue to lament the death of the one, and the abence of the other, ince by them you might have known how much Lidias is obliged unto me, and what right and reaon I have to pretend unto • is affection. Upon this he made a top, to wipe away th •• e tears which the memory of Clidemants death did bring into her eyes, and gave the Nymph time to do the ame; afterwards he went on thus.

They could have told you, Madam, when Lidias was forced to fly for his life, and when the kinred of Aronthes, whom he had killed, would not let him live in any place of the world, my houe was his afe anctuary: I had at that time a greater regard of his honour then of my own; for not being able to avoid thoe wounds which he gave me, I was at lat forced to imitate the goodnes of my father, and give him the ame entertainment in my heart, which my father gave him in his houe: It was not long before this wavering minded man became mater both of the one and the other: but almot the very ame day that he let me know he loved, the very ame day alo he aured me of his treaon: The truth is, he quickly cat me off, and to make his crime the more enormous, he left me, without o much as bidding me a civil adieu. I will not peak of my reentments, becaue I hall make us both bluh; him at his crime, and me at my follies: let me only tell you, that at that intant, I forgot what I was, and changing my habit and my name, I reolved to overcome all thoe horrors which fear commonly imprints in the oul of a woman: I left then all my Parents, and G • d knows how much againt my mind I committed this aburdity: But at lat overcoming all the difficulties of a journey, and all the injuries of weather, after a thouand rubs of fortune, I undertook to fight with Lipandas, thinking it no matter by what hand I died, o it might be in the preence of this perfideous man.

If thou hat any park of memory, Lidias, of thoe dangers whereunto I expoed my elf, and of the favours which I hewed unto thee, thou wouldet confes that this young Beauty which is now an occaion of my jealouie, and an argument of thy incontancy, never had the courage to defend thee as I have done. But that is not the greatet obligation wherewith I will charge thee; and if thou beet unwilling I hould name it unto thee left thy crime hould have too many witnees, ask ecretly thoe chains which fettered my arms and feet, which I aumed upon my elf to releae thee: Ask the Vermin of that place where I was imprioned, whether my orrows for thy departure were not blacker unto me then the darknes which environ'd me: Conult with the walls, and if thou beet not deaf to their anwers, as thou art now unto my love, thou mayet undertand the quality of my ufferings, and how more ad I was at thy in then at my own miery: But Madam (aid he, and turned towards Amais) to expres how my Lidias is obliged unto me, is to expres the whole coure of my life, for I have worn a thouand times that I would never live a minute longer then I loved him: Nay, let him peak himelf, for if he have any memory of my favours, it is impoible but he mut needs confes himelf wholly mine: You may perceive Madam by his ilence, how faint he is to excue himelf and his incontancy; and I mot humbly beeech you, to declare that he in right belongs unto me, and that if there be any glory to be gotten by poeing him, that it cannot be denied unto me, ince he is obliged unto me for his life and liberty.

This was the dicoure of Melandre, which was hearkened unto with a univeral murmure, ome admired her courage; others the Grandure of her love; but all did abhor the humour of Lidias, and thought it impoible for him ever to wah off that tain of ingratitude, yet when the noie of the murmure was ceaed, Lidias in all humility bowed unto the Nymph, and offered to peak; but Amerina, into whom the dicoure of Melandre had infued ome new fears of loing Lidias, he advanced, and begging leave to peak uttered thee words.

It is very jut, Madam, that I do prevent Lidias, and before the entence, on which my life or death doth depend be pronounced, I do hew legitimately the poeion of this Cavalier, be granted unto me before Melandre. I cannot deny but that he hath done even miracles for him, but I mut tell you that all her actions are nothing in comparion of mine; and that if I could urmount her in merit as much as I do in love, the dipute about him would be quickly determined: the only advantage which he can boat of above me is, that he was not o mitaken as I was; and that the tetimonies of her love were given unto Lidias, where mine was given unto Ligdamon; but why hould that fallacy prejudice my caue, ince the grandure of my affection is till apparent, and has given all the tetimonies of a mot inviolable faith? You know very well courageous Melandre, that I was the firt unto whom that Cavalier did acrifice his liberty; o as when he eemed to put his heart into your hands, he did but deceive your innocency, ince he never did take it back out of mine: you may happily tell me that his oathes are too many, and too great to be broken; but why hould they not be broken, rather then thoe he has worn unto me ten thouand times? I confee that he ows his life unto you; but if he take what I did unto Ligdamon as done unto him, he mut needs ay, that when I delivered him from a den of ravenous Lions, he is alo a debtour unto me for his life: and I mut tell you, that I have done more for him then you have; for when you ventured your life in a hopes of overcoming, I looked upon death as inevitable, when I pledged Ligdamon in the cup wherewith he intended to poyon himelf; o as I have the glory to ay, that I dared to do more then you, who never ventured further then the hazard of a private duel: But great Nymph (continued he and turned towards Amais) ince as they ay, the firt inclinations are mot trong, what right hath this fair one to pretend unto Lidias, ince he had o long ince devoted himelf unto me, and ince at this very day, his paion does conent unto his firt ervitude? If Lidias had two hearts, I would conent he hould have the one, and that he hould dictate uch laws unto him as he would have him oberve; but ince he has but one, and ince his firt promies has given me the abolute Empire over him, is it not mot fit he hould deit from her enterprie, and leave puruing a thing which my love cannot yield unto her?

Amerina ued other arguments to et forth the jutice of her caue, but Amais eeing Melandre about to reply, did ordain that the diviion of the controverie, hould meerly depend upon the will of Lidias, and to that end gave him all that night to weigh the reaon on both ides, and that neither of them hould ee him, until he had declared his ultimate judgement: o every one retired; and Melandre being extreamly ahamed to be een in the habit of a Man, after he had declared her ex, he took the offer of Galathea, and being dreed in ome of her clothes, he fully reolved never to tir out of the Catle, but either to marry Lidias, or ele to go out of the world.

Lidias in the mean time returned to the houe of good Amaiel, and Adamas took the care of Amerina upon him; but do what he could, he was not able to diolve that adnes which appeared in all her actions and countenance: he offered himelf a thouand times to erve her upon all occaions, but he till told him, that the only office which could oblige her, was to make Lidias hers: The Druide offered his aitance in that, and this made the young fair one o confident as to ay unto him thus: I do conjure you father, by that which is mot acred and dear unto you to contrive it o, that I may dicoure with Melandre in private: this is all the conolation that I ask, and if I obtain it, I hall more eaily upport
any misfortune Adamas conceiving that this might eaily be done, and that there was no inj • tice in the deire, he went the ame hour unto Melandre, and made the propoition unto her: That generous woman conented unto his deire, and offered to go unto her; but the Druide not knowing whether Amerina would be pleaed with that, he thought it better that he tayed in her chamber, and undertook to bring Amerina unto her: which he did; o as making them both to promie that nothing hould pae in their dicoure which might make his mediatourhip to be imputed unto him as a crime, he went out and left them alone: he was no ooner gone out but Amerina hut the door, and poke thus unto Melandre.

Do not wonder generous Melandre, that I hould tand in fear of the judgement of Lidias; for your own merit is the caue of it; and I know that unles he be blind he cannot prefer my beauty before yours: you are owner of o many eminent qualities above me, that I am forced to beg that from your pity, which my own merit can never obtain: I know very well that my demand is high, when I ask this Cavalier; but then conider, that if you grant him unto me, you do render your glory and my obligation to be extream: I am ure, fair Melandre, that you know very well how due this recompence is unto pains, and that my many years ufferings deerves no les reward: If you tell me, that you may pretend unto him by the ame title, and that you have endured as much as I, conider I beeech you, that your courage, which is naturally prompt unto great things, was never put unto o much difficulty as mine, whoe inclination never reached above that of a illy woman, and who never durt attempt any thing, if love had not ued a particular violence upon me. Again, dicreet Melandre, you have many perons here about you, the poeion of whom will be no les glorious unto you, then if you enjoyed Lidias, and will be a Fortune as advantageous unto you: Wheas if I do loe what I do expect from the inclination of that Cavalier, I am utterly undone; left deolately alone, far from my native countrey, detitute of all humane help, and, perhaps, abandoned to the mercy of ome raviher who will triumph over me, and has none to defend me from any violence: I do conjure you therefore, even by Lidias himelf, not to deny me this comfort which I begg; and conider, that if you have o much pity as to yield unto me this, upon which all my joy and felicity does depend, I hall not be o ungrateful, as for your ervice, to loe that life which you hall preerve.

Amerina expreed her elf in uch a weet obliging manner, that Melandre was exceedingly moved: and had not love been abundantly predominate above her compaion, he had at that very intant granted unto this fair one that contentment which he asked, and eemed to merit. Yet her own interet being above that of Amerinas, he paued a while, and tudied what to anwer: at lat he broke out thus.

The gods be witnees, fair Amerina, I am extreamly grieved that I cannot render you this contentment which you ask: for pities ake put your elf into my room, and tell me what you would do if I hould make the ame upplication unto you? If you do love Lidias above your own life, would you not rather die then uffer another to enjoy him? but alas, I am extreamly afraid left that misfortune befal me, and that his judgement will be advantageous unto you: for I mut yield unto you in all thoe qualities, wherein you think I have the advantage above you. But however this is my deigne, age Amerina, to wait upon that judgement which he hall pronounce: do not think it is any want of affection unto you, which moves me not to yield that happines which you deire: for command me to attempt things even impoible, nay even to die for your contentment, and I protet I will do it, o my love unto Lidias may be excued.

This was all the anwer that Melandre gave, at which Amerina was o tung, that he was not able to tay any longer with her; after, therefore, a civil adiew, he went away in uch a dejected manner, as it was apparent he was not all atisfied: by Fortune, as he went out he met Adamas, and went with him unto his houe, beeeching him to let her go to bed without any upper, or being een
by any. The Druido would hardly conent unto it; yet to atisfie her importunity, he permitted her to do as he would. All the night long he never cloed an eye, and though the lat tetimonies which he received of the love of Lidias was a great ubject of conolation unto her, yet he could not chue but fear, and extreamly afflict her elf, as oft as he thought upon the promies which he had made unto Melandre: The remembrance of this, forced ome tears to trickle down from her eyes, and afterwards to fall into a thouand dangerous reolutions. The lat of which, and upon which her mind fixed was, not to uffer that her Rival hould ever tryumph over Lidias; o as to prevent that, he intended to arm her elf with a poniard, which he would wear under her Gown; and in cae the entence was pronounced in the favour to Melandre, he vowed to kill her, afterwards Lidias, and latly her elf.

Lidias for his part was as much diquieted as they; all his obligations unto Melandre came into his memory, and welled his oul with uch lively apprehenion of them, as he thought he could not chue but atisfie her deires, unles he uffered himelf to be branded with extream ingratitude. On the other ide, his vows unto the fair Amerina had uch an influence upon him, and the merits of both held him in uch an inequality, as he knew not which of them to chue or reject: Lipandas alo received uch a hot alarm when he heard of the paages at the houe of Amais, that he would never let Ligdamon be at ret, but forced him to accompany him unto the Catle, where he o expreed his paion unto Melandre, that if he did not move her unto any love, yet he moved her at the leat unto pity.

The hour when they were all to appear before Amais was no ooner come, but all the Court aembled there, epecially the Lovers, but with very different thoughts and reolutions: Lidias endeavoured to oblige Amerina without offending Melandre; Amerina was afraid that Lidias would not be favourable unto her, and therefore prepared to execute her dimal deigne: But Melandre being more confident then any of the ret, before Lidias was commanded to peak, did cat her elf at the feet of Amais, with thee expreions. It is to believed Madam, that every one will wonder that after o violent a puruit of a happines, I hould now deprive my elf of all hopes therein; but if they will be pleaed to take o much pains as to conider the reaons which induce me thereunto, doubtles they will rather commend then condemn me.

At the firt Madam, I was in hopes to enjoy Lidias without any prejudice unto Amerina, whoe affection does merit to be preerved; but now if I do voluntarily yield unto her an advantage which perhaps he may obtain in pite of me, I hall o oblige her, as I believe that her affection unto me will be for ever immutable: And ince Madam, though Lidias hould give his judgement in favour of me, he would till be guilty of breaking thoe oaths which he hath worn unto this fair one; and though he hould be favourable unto her, he could never clear himelf of infidelity unto me; o as Madam, either Amerina or Melandre mut of their own motion quit the interet which they have in this affection: Therefore ince the Gods have inpired me with the deire of it, and have now given me the courage, I do intend never to give Lidias any caue to hate me, but will for ever love him only in the degree of a Brother. I beeech you therefore Madam, to let them enjoy that contentments which fortune hath many years denied them, and which now I do mot earnetly wih unto them: Thrice happy hall I think my elf in contributing any thing to their contentment. Upon this Melandre was ilent, and made an humble reverence unto the Nymph.

All the company admired to hear this language proceed from her; but above all, Lidias and Amerina; who eeing themelves at a higher pitch of felicity then ere they expected, made an humble reverence unto Amais; and after they had asked leave to thank Melandre, they expreed themelves unto her with all tetimonies of acknowledgement and affection.

This being done, Amais offered to rie, but was hindred by Ligdamon, who holding Lipandas by the hand, and preenting him unto the Nymph, beeeched her to determine omthing for the atisfaction of that Cavalier: Lipandas cat
himelf down upon his knees, and after a relation of his love and adventures, beeeched her to dipoe the will of Melandre to receive him into the room of Lidias. Amais found o much Jutice in the deire, that he made the propoition unto Melandre, who after ome modet refual, remembring what he had done for her upon everal occaions, epecially when to relieve Lidias, he leaped down the walls of Marcelles, he obeyed the commands of the Nymph, and granted the deires of Ligdamon.

Thus thee four Lovers did in one hour reap the fruit of all the pains which Love and Fortune had made them endure: Thee two marriages were conummated before the Truce was ended; and in the mean time, Lindamore lot no opportunities of advancing his Troops and having met with Phil • nder, who acquainted him with the affairs of Amais, and the intentions of Gondebaut againt her, he determined not to go into Lions, but to cros over the Rhoue about half a league from them, and the next morning to go unto Vienna.

On the other ide, Gondebaut who thirted to be revenged upon Amais for the affronts which he had, as he conceived, received from her, and being preed by Ligonias, who every minute preented unto him the inconve • iences which would happen in cae Polemas was not relieved according to promie, he iued out his Commiions, and raied thirty and two thouand men, which he committed unto the conduct of Ligonias, with command unto all the Officers to obey Polemas, unto whom he writ this Letter.

body.head: GONDEBAUTS Letter unto POLEMAS.
body.p: I Have ent thirty and two thouand men unto Polemas, not out of any ambition to enlarge the limits of my Empire, but only out of a deire to raie his glory unto the highet pitch of glory that he can wih. I have made choice of uch Souldiers for him, as bet know how to obey, from whom I do expect even wonders to be done, being under the conduct of a man who knows mot perfectly how to command them. But how great o ever the victories be which they hall get, they are till les then the hopes I have in your courage, the Grandeur whereof may aure any one of the conquet of the world, if he will be pleaed to employ it. Fight therefore preently, brave Polemas, or rather vanquih preently; for I know, that with you, to fight, and to overcome, is one and the ame thing.

div.p: Whilt affairs went thus, Sigimond had but a very dull time of it; Gondebaut had locked him up in a trong Tower, the better to ecure his peron, it being doubted, that if he were at liberty, he would not have uffered any deigns to be againt Amais, Godomar, or Dorinde, without oppoing it with all his Interet. Thus this Prince thought his detention inupportable; for hearing of this Armies departure, he was enible of the danger wherein his Brother was; he was o extreamly dipleaed that he was not able to help himelf, that all thoe who aw him, might read in his countenance the marks of a mot violent orrow: At lat, heaven who reerved him for a more glorious end then to languih in prion, did permit him to make an ecape in this manner.

Amongt thoe whom Gondebaut had et over him to prevent his ecape, there was two kinmen of Ardilan, who alo carried the ame name; the one of which finding more favour with the King then the o • her, he had obtained the ole donation of his deceaed Cofin; which the other extreamly tomaking, yet not daring to murmure at the injutice which was done him, he reolved to be revenged by favouring Sigimond, and freeing him from the Tyrannie of his father. He made the overture of it unto him, the ame morning that the Army was drawn into the field; and Sigimond being confident of his fidelity, ince (aid he unto him) you do offer me your aitance, and your own good will hath prevented my requets,
I do wear by all that's acred, that if you do help me to ecape, to raie thy fortune above any Subject in all the Kingdome, but be ure you fail me not, for if thou dot deceive me, I will mot infallibly be thy utter ruine. Upon this the Prince began to walk up and down the chamber, and the young Ardilan fearing let ome hould hearken at the door, he came nearer and aid unto him in a low voice: You never need Sir to doubt either of my affection or my fidelity, and I will contrive the matter with o much prudence, as if it hall not micarry. As oon as he had aid o, the hour which Ardilan was to tay with him was expired, and he quitted his place unto another who came for the ame purpoe: he was no ooner gone, but to loe no time, he provided one of thoe mall boats, which they ued upon the River Arar, and alo providing two Fihermens habits, ome nets, and a rope long enough to reach from the Tower where Sigimond was detained; and at the entrance of the night, he carried them himelf unto the Princes chamber, where he was to watch that night with one of his Comrades: Sigimond was no ooner in bed, but he eemed as if he were aleep, and Ardilan who alo brought a great bottle of wine with him, did o entertain his companion, that he was contrained to trut the keeping of the Prince unto him: o oon as Ardilan perceived his Comrade to be o fat aleep that he could not be awaked, he pulled the Fihers habits out of a ack, and putting one of them on, beeeched the Prince to put on the other; then fatning the rope to the window, they both wen • down by the rope without any noie. As oon as they were down, Ardilan carried him to the boat, and throwing their nets into the water with more fear of being taken then deire to take, they came unto the chains which croed over the water jut as day began to dawn, and they tayed not long before they were opened unto them; o as rowing as fat as ever they could they entred preently into the Rhone, whoe impetuous current was uch, that it carried them to Vienna in lee then three hours.

When Ardilans companion awaked, and did not ee his Comrade, he ran preently to the Princes bed, and not finding him neither, he went to the window, where finding the rope, he concluded that they were ecape, and diputed with himelf whether it was not his bet coure to ecape alo: at lat conidering, that if he hould be taken, he hould be punihed as a complice, he choe rather to rely upon his innocency, then run the hazard of being thought culpable: he began therefore to cry out as loud as he could, and hewed unto the firt that came unto him the marks of Sigimonds flight. Gondebaut was quickly advertied of it, and coming himelf unto the place, he aw the Princes and Ardilans clothes lying together upon the bed; but this made no excue for him whoe office it was to watch them, and he wore that he hould preently be hanged; but when he aw the rope, and conidered that if the man had been culpable, he might eaily have ecaped alo, he turned all his anger againt the young Ardilan, and preently proclaimed throughout the Town, that if any one could bring him either alive or dead, he would give unto him a large pention for his life; but all inquiition was to no purpoe, for they were already got into Vienna, and it fell out very happily for them, that Lindamare came thither that morning.

Their entrance into the Town was after a pleaant manner, for having left their boat at the port, they came into the firt houe they found open, and asked for omething to eat; and being thought to be Fiher-men, very homely victuals was et before them, uch as were enough to turn the tomach of the Prince: but Ardilan, who had rowed very hard, and never lept all the night, did fall abord with uch a harp appetite, that Sigimond after his example did tate uch coure food as he found. During their repat the Prince was very inquiitive after the news of the Town, and left their hot hould think it trange, that any in uch habits as they hould enquire after news, the Prince told him that they came from Lions to ell their fih in Vienna: for Gondebauts Souldiers took up all proviions in their countrey, and never payed the owners for them; and therefore they came away with their boat, to ee what money they could get for their fih in that place: The Hot told him that they were come in a very good time: for there was newly come to Town one Lindamor, whoe valour was very famous, and
brought with him four or five hundred Noble men, beides four thouand Souldiers. I have (aid Sigimond) three or four fihes of a trange bignes, and I believe they would very willingly buy them, if I knew how to let them know as much. Alas poor fellow (anwered the Hot) dot thou think uch men as they ue to go unto the Market as we do? No, no, they have ervants and officers that take care for uch things, and thy fih, perhaps, hall be bought and old before thou ever ee any of them, or they know any thing of them. So I have money for my fih (replied Sigimond and miled) I do not care, and ilver is as good from the hand of a ervant as from the Mater: Well (aid the Hot) I will carry thee to their houe where thou mait peak with ome of their ervants, and to tell thee truly, I have a great deire to ee this man they call Lindamor, for I have heard tell uch wonders of him, that I can hardly believe he is like unto other men.

Sigimond could not chue but laugh at the conceit of this man, and calling to memory all that he had heard of Lindamor, I had a conceit that his return from Childerick, was purpoely to ait Amais againt the attempts of Polemas. Thinking therefore that his bet coure was to joyn with him, he and Ardilan deired the Hot to conduct them unto his lodging. As oon as they came there, the Prince deired to peak with Lindamor, and becaue he aw they made ome difficulty of it, he told them that he had ome buinee of importance to impart, which Lindamor would be very glad to know. This man unto whom he addreed himelf, finding more in the apect of Sigimond then uually is in the common ort of people, and thinking him better then his clothes promied, alo remembring how Philiander got out of Marcelles, he did imagine that happily he might be one that came from the Nymph; o as without any more ceremony he carried him up a back tairs towards the chamber of Lindamor; and leaving him there at the tair head with Ardilan, who knew not what would be the iue of this viit, he went and told Lindamor that there was two men in the habit of Fihermen, the one of which aid that he had ome buinee of conequence to impart. Lindamor pretending ome dipatches in his cloet, he left the company and came to the place where Sigimond tayed. As oon as ever the Prince aw him he liked his countenance and behaviour, as indeed, Lindamor had a very charming way & mind to win love; and aluting the Prince very affably, he returned the alute in a way more utable to his quality then habit, Sir (aid he unto Lindamor) I come to acquaint you with an accident which happened in Lions of which we have been witnees, and in ome ort Complices: which is, that the Prince Sigimond hath ecaped out of that prion where his father detained him, and we have brought him away in our little boat, without any other company but one man who ecaped with him.

Lindamor had hardly patience to let him peak out thee lat words, for clapping his hands together, and lifting up his eyes to heaven, bleed be the great gods of heaven (aid he) for delivering him from uch great injutice: In aying o ome tears of joy ecaped from his eyes, which pleaed the Prince o well, that he was ready to dicover himelf immediatly: yet deferring it a little longer, Sir (continued he) we heard him often by the way name you, yet not knowing (as I think) that you were o near him: o as at our arival here, hearing of your return and where you lodged, we thought it would be welcome news unto you, to the end, that whether he be your friend or your enemy, you might make what ue you pleadd of it.

Dear friend (aid Lindamor unto him) I give thee hearty thanks, and I will and I will recompence thee very well before we part, for this good news; but I pray thee tell me where he is, that I may go unto him and kie his hands. Sir (replied the Prince and hrugged his houlders) he landed on the other ide of the Rhone, and I am afraid he is taken hore to go unto his brother in Marcellos, for we heard him ay he intended it. O heavens (aid Lindamor and tamped upon the ground) how unhappy hall I eteem my elf if I do not erve upon this occaion he commanded to make ready hores with all poible hate, and intended to follow him immediately; yet being deirous to reward thoe that gave him this intelligence;
he commanded to give them a good um of money, and after many hearty thanks would have dimied them; but Sigimond, who was much delighted at hit trouble and impatiency, Sir (aid he unto him) we mot humbly beeech you to let us wait upon you in your journey, perhaps we may be a means of your ooner finding him: Lindamor, whoe mind was more upon omething ele then heeding what he aid, was a long while before he anwered; at lat, alas (aid he) it will be a long while before we provide boats for you both; beides you do not know what a deal of difference there is between riding a hore and rowing a boat: upon this he would have gone out, and Sigimond, not being able to hold any longer, Sir, aid he, there needs neither boats or boat, nor any hores to meet with him whom you deire to ee, ince Sigimond is already very near you: As he aid this, he embraced him, at which Lindamor was o urprized, that he knew not what to ay: and upon a better urvey he found o much Majety under the cloud of that poor habit, as he found his errour; yet not to perit any longer in it he kneeled down, and all the Princes entreaties could not make him rie until he had obtained that pardon, which the Prince aid he was rather to ask for deceiving him o long. Their firt complements being ended, the Prince went to bed, during which time order was taken for ome clothes utable to his quality, and Lindamor yielded his chamber unto him, giving it out that he was troubled with the head-ake, purpoely to prevent viits, and to have the better opportunity of dicouring upon the affairs of the Nymph: o the Prince wa • no ooner got into bed, but he deired Lindamor to it down by him, and then began to peak thus unto him.

This picture (aid he, and opened a cae et with very rich tone, which he wore about his Neck) will tell you that Dorinde is partly the caue of all Gondebauts disorders: That fair one whoe Image you ee, and whoe perfections are o great, as no Painter in the Univere is able to imitate, hath o captivated the mind of my father, that he is fallen into uch extravagancies, as indeed are unworthy a man of his quality: When his affection was firt known unto me, I was in uch fears that he would marry her, that I reolved to be as great an obtacle unto it as I could. The firt coure that came into my fancy was, to eem as if I were in Love with her; but oh how dangerous a thing it is to jet with matters of Love! for a little after I became o deperately lot in a real Love of her, that I cannot believe ever any paion was o violent as mine; but however, my firt deigne of ruining the pretenions of my father, did prevail; for whether that fair one did think my age more utable unto hers, and found more ympathy in our humours, or whether he thought the Kings intention was not o honet as he pretended; but o it was, that I gained her affection, and after the death of her father, I perwaded her to go into Forrets, where I intended to follow: but I was o much interrupted, that all I could do, was, to end my brother thither; who after everal encounters, carried her into Marcelles, where now they are. Now the perwaions of Polemas, who promied to hold that etate meerly of my father, and my fathers deire to be revenged upon Amais, who took them into her protection, has caued him to declare war againt that Princes, and no longer ince then yeterday, ent above thirty thouand men unto Polemas: But let I hould engage my elf in this quarrel, which was partly begun upon my core, the King hut me up in a Tower, out of which I ecaped by the aitance of this man, whom you ee diguied as I am, and now am come unto you, to act omthing that is glorious unto Amais and Dorinde.

Lindamore was joyed beyond all expreion at the dicoure of Sigimond, and proteting that he could not better employ his arms; then in defence of that Princes, he beeeched him to make all the hate he could to do her that favour: Firt (aid the Prince) I conceive one thing is expedient to be done, which is, that we employ four of your men who are leat known, two of them to go and divulge it in Lions, that I am in Viena, and the other two to get into that Army which Gondebaut ends unto Polemas: and this will be the conequence of it; I have many friends in Lions, who will not value the Kings dipleaure, o they can but erve me, and follow my fortune; and I dare confidently ever, that almot all the Nobility
are for me: Mot certain it is, that as oon as ever they know where I am, they will make preparations to erve me, and will follow me: As for thoe who are in the Army which my father hath ent unto Polemas, certainly ome are for me, and thoe that are, will draw others, o as I expect a good party will revolt, and come unto me.

Lindamore approved of this deigne, and that very hour dipatched away four uch as he mot truted, and giving them all requiite intructions, he returned unto Sigimond, and aid thus unto him, I do verily believe Sir, that the Gods do intend to be very favourable unto Amais, and are reolved to free her very uddenly from all manner of oppreions, ince they proceed by ways that are even miraculous: For in your dicoure, I oberve ome extraordinary paages: As the flight of Dorinde, the voyage of Prince Godomar, and the interet which you have both in him and her, makes much for the advantage of that afflicted Princes. Philander poke of a certain Queen called Argira, who came not long ince about the cure of a Cavalier called Roilion; he told me alo, that he left behind her a daughter very fair, with a promie to end for her by an Army trong enough to reit all the power of any enemies. For my part, I thought that I could not die more gloriouly, then in the ervice of her, unto whom I owe my life, and all I have, and therefore reolved to force my way into the Town, with thoe ouldiers that I brought with me, and afterwards defend it to the lat.
