Your reolution is mot commendable (aid Sigimond) and I aure my elf, you might effect it, for there is no greater danger in it, then formerly your valour hath encountred withal, and gloriouly executed; but you mut know, that as the tate of the Town is at the preent, it is not in any neceity of either your or my being there: My brother writ me word at the beginning of the iege, that there are o many brave Cavaliers in it, and I believe Philander told me as much, that without any aitance, they could defend it for two moneths; and ince o, it is much better for us to make up a Body wherewith we may keep the field, and as we ee occaions, either give battel, or enter into the Town.

Lindamore thought this advice o good, that he reolved to follow it; the only difficulty that he found in it, was, left Gondebauts Army joyning with Polemas, before they had formed a coniderable body, hould violently fall upon them; and therefore he propounded it unto the Prince, whether it was not bet to advance a little forward with thoe men he had, to amue the enemy, whilt he tayed in Vienna, to receive thoe men who came to take his part. The Prince anwered, that it was very neceary o to do: And upon this reolution, Lindamore pent the ret of the day in giving orders for their departure, as in the morning he did, with all his forces.

The ame day, thoe that Lindamore ent unto Lions, arrived there; who having told unto five or ix perons that Sigimond was in Vienna all the Town knew of it before it was night. Gondebaut was vexed at it to the very oul; and doubtles if he had not ent away all his Forces, he would have beieged him there: for his humour was barbarous enough to prompt unto any violent reolution. But on the other ide, mot of the Nobility and Cavalry of the Town were o joyed at the news, that they pent all the night in nothing but preparing themelves to go unto the Prince in the morning. The King, whoe paion had blinded his judgement, and who never feared any harm could happen unto him, did permit the Gates of the Town to be opened, for they had been hut ever ince he heard of Sigimonds flight; o as there went out everal ways no les, then five thouand men, who the ame day came unto the Prince. The next day after he went to joyn with Lindamore, who had appointed Boen for his Rendezvouz.

In the mean time Gondebauts Army was advanced within a little of eeing the walls of Marcelles: Polemas who was welled with joy, and proud with the title of General over uch a puiant Army, did promie unto himelf no les then the conquet of Galathea, and went half a days journey to meet thee Auxiliaries: There he received Gondebauts letter, which he kied two or three times; and having received the oath of Fidelity from all the Captains, he wore that the greatet interet that he had in this war, was only for the glory of Gondebaut. After this
he made a peech unto the Souldiers, in which he omitted nothing that might move them to fight valiantly; and got o much credit and authority amongt them, that there was not one amongt them all which was not very glad to be under his command. And latly, being deirous to know certainly of what number this new come Army conited, he wondered to find of thirty two thouand not above four or five and twenty thouand; for the ret had disbanded themelves as oon as ever they heard of Sigimonds intention.

As this was prejudicial unto Polemas, o it was erviceable unto Sigimond, who in les then three days, found himelf ixteen or eventeen thouand trong compriing thoe which Lindamore brought from Childerick.

Roilion on his ide, he made all the hate that poibly he could; for his love unto Roanira, was uch a pur unto him, that he could not ret until he had given ome ignal tetimony of his valour; o as he was within a days march as near Marcelles as the Burgundian Troops.

The Truce was to end the next morning; o as the retardment of Roilion, the arrival of thee forces unto Polemas; and no intelligence of Lindamores return, did put Amais into a mot extream perplexity: he knew nothing of Fleurial and Philianders ucces, o as he grew even deperate of all relief, and was exceively afflicted: Adamas urpried her as he was almot drowned in orrows; and though he knew them to be but jut, eeing o little hopes of any remedy, yet having a firm belief that the Gods would never abandon o jut a caue, he candemned her exceive orrows, as out of eaon: Which the Princes not being able to relih; Alas Adamas (aid he) how can I chue but be enible of all thee ad accidents which are even ready to ruine me: every thing contributes unto it; Strangers deceive me; my Neighbours aault me, and my own Subjects betray me. Upon this he pulled out he handkerchief and wiped her eyes, which notwithtanding the Grandure of her courage, did end forth a flood of tears: which the Druide perceiving, and deiring to comfort her: Madam (aid he unto her) I mut needs confee that you have ome caues to fear, but pardon me if I tell you, that you have no caue to dipair: A high born oul as yours is, cannot be culpable of uch a crime, which is a mark of a bae pirit that is d • ffident in the goodnee and omnipotence of the gods: by the grace of Tautates our affairs are no • in uch an extremity as to expect nothing but certain ruine; and though we were all to perih infallibly, methinks it hould be a great comfort unto you, to know that though the gods have permitted it to be o, yet it is not for any crime which you have committed: I do know, Madam, that Etates have ometimes their revolutions and changes; but I know alo, that it eldome happens without ome legetimate caue have drawn the anger of the gods upon them. Now Madam, no uch caue can ever be found in you, whoe piety has ever been o obervable, that the leat hadow of any crime could never be found in all your actions. The mot religious of all my actions (anwered the Princes) is as bad as a crime, ince I do uffer the punihment of them: This is no good concluion (anwered the Druide) no more then if you hould ay you never did any good act ince the gods do not recompence you. But, Madam, you mut know, that the eye of man is too weak to ee the ecrets of the gods, nor can our hallow thoughts reach the ublimity of theirs; and it is a thing mot difficult to find out the caues of the good or the bad which they do end unto us: ometimes they are pleaed to uffer the good to be overwhelmed with mieries and calamities, whilt the bad do wim in good Fortune and properity; but alas, Madam, it is becaue they think that the properity of this world is not recompence good enough for the good, and therefore their reward is referred unto the next world. But Adamas (replied the Nymph) admit all this true, yet in the mean time this Traytour Polemas will triumph over my daughter and my dominions: If the gods have o ordained it (anwered Adamas) all humane power is not able to hinder it; but the bet way is to uffer patiently without murmure. I know (replied the Nymph) that if Galatheas courage be like unto mine, we hall not want remedies to keep our elves from falling into his hands. The bet remedy of all (replied the Druide) is to have recoure unto the gods, who will never deny you
what is neceary: The Gods are o jut (replied Amais) that they have given me power to die when I pleae. Upon this, he was o welled with grief, that he left the Druide in the chamber, and hut her elf in her cloet: Adamas fearing let the Nymph hould fall upon ome dangerous reolution, he went in all hate unto Godomar, who had with him Damon, Alcidon, Lipandas, Ligdamon, Lidias, and ome other Cavaliers, and telling them in what condition Amais was, and all the dicoure they had together, he beeeched them to go unto her: afterwards giving them ome particular intructions, he accompanied them unto the cloet door, and afterwards went into the Town to give neceary orders for the preervation of it.

Amais was already laid down upon her bed, in hopes to find ome ret, but found none: for joyning to her orrows, at the bad etate of her affairs, the los of Clidemant her on, in whom he had placed her greatet hopes, he was o drowned in orrows, that he was even ready to acrifice her elf unto the violence of her depair. She had a thouand deignes in her mind, and the mot advantageous was to die: And though he knew well enough that complaints and tears would do no good, yet he till complained and cryed, becaue he could not chue: Alas, my dear Clidemant (aid he) mut thy death be the caue of mine? and mut thy los be ucceeded by the los of my etate? did the afety of all this Province depend upon thy life? and was the good of my people wholly built upon thine? Alas, alas (added he with a deep igh) what reaon had I to think o, ince before ever thou camet into the world they flourih'd with o much glory, that there was no fear of any change, but that it was their fate to perih with thee; Ah Clidemant, Clidemant, my dearet Clidemant; and would have continued in her Lamentations, but hearing ome knock at the door he topped, and as oon as he was told that it was Godomar, he covered her tears with her handkerchief.

The young Prince, in whoe valour was all her hopes, ued uch excellent expreions, and the Cavaliers who accompanied him, did make uch promies of ervice and affection, that he received ome comfort: o as deiring them to it down, he told them that the courage of a woman was not trong enough to reit the blows of Fortune; epecially when they threatned the los of reputation with the los of life: Hitherto I have with ome patience reited the aaults of my misfortunes; but now ince the forces which Polemas has received, it has put me out of all hopes to punih his rebellion; and ince I ee my daughter and my elf ready to be acrificed unto his arrogance, I mut confes my reaon bids me depair when I ee armed againt me no fewer then fourty thouand men. All that number (anwered Godomar) may be haked into dut, by one ingle blow of heavens anger. It is not the number that gets victories; courage and a good caue are the ure foundations of getting combats and battels, which makes me believe, that you, Madam, having o much right on your ide, and your enemies o much injutice, and the carriage of thoe which erve you being incomparably above theirs, it is impoible but all this great puiance which you ee, mut vanih before your arms, as the light of many little Stars will at the arrival of the Sun. All the ret of the Cavaliers added ome uch dicoures, and gave her uch hopes, that her countenance began to reaume freh colours again: After this, they retired, and went unto the walls to look upon their enemies.

Celadon in two dayes was o well recovered of his wounds, that he began to tir out of his chamber; and that day in particular, he went to viit Clindor and his Guets, and return them thanks for their viits; and therefore Adamas went thither alo, who finding them in the Garden, did firt alute Clindor; afterwards taking Alexis by the hand, who was talking with Atrea, he aid unto that fair Shepherdes, will you fair one give me leave to take her out of your company a little, whom you eem to love o well though he deerve it not? The Authority (anwered Atrea) which, Sir, you have both upon her and me, may do what you pleae without asking my conent; but ince you are pleaed to ask it, I mut tell you, reverend Sir. that I will give it upon condition you retore her quickly again for the truth is I cannot enjoy any contentment in any other company but
hers. The Druide miling at her innocency, and admiring to ee how perfectly he was deceived, I will keep her o little from you (aid he unto her) that you hall have no caue to chide me for croing your contentment: In aying o he carried Alexis into another walk where none could here; and Atrea retiring into an harbour with other Shepherds and Shepherdees, he began to ay thus unto her, are you reolved Celadon to languih thus eternally in this habit which you wear? Do you not conider that you have been now above two moneths with Atrea, and abuing her credulity under a fiction which cannot long continue. Conider I ay, that you are Man, and it is impoible you hould continue long in the diguie of a woman; in time will your beard grow in pite of your Petticote, and if you hould be dicovered, what a oul blur would it be unto my reputation, and what advantage would you give unto my enemies; They would talk of this action as a Scandal, and o tain my repute in the opinion of men, that they would look upon me as an Impotour, who to make Celadon triumph over the chatity of Atrea, made ue of this Artifice. Father (anwered Celadon) all the actions of your life are unblameable, o as you cannot offend either againt heaven or men; and the honour of Atrea is o plendent that it cannot be clouded by any upition: o as you need not fear to let me continue till in this condition wherein I am: you may afely uffer me to tay till with Atrea under the umbrage of Alexis, ince I am ure I cannot live under the notion of Celadon.

Adamas then hrugged his houlders, and recoyled two or three paces; then taking the Shepherd by the hand, he began to walk, but I mut tell you (aid he) that this deire of yours was reaonable the firt time that you aumed this habit; but now, when by a thouand expreions in the advantage of Celadon, you may conclude he loves you, methinks you hould not be o much an enemy unto your elf, as to loe the contentment of appearing Celadon. My deign was to have you marry Atrea, and not this habit, and ince you tay only for a command from her to retore her that, whoe los hath cot her o many tears; you may plainly ee that he has a deire of that retitution, and that deire may erve you for a command.

Ah Father (anwered Celadon) he did banih me in expree termes; had he aid go Shepherd, and let me not ee thee again until I make it appear that I do deire it, I confee, that now I ee her deire, I were infinitly to blame if I did not appear; but ince her fatal words were, Go, go, perfideous man, and come not in my preence untill I command thee, I hould diobey her if I hould appear Celadon, having not yet received that bleed command from her. But yet (aid the Druide) this way of living with her mut one day have an end; and ince it is inevitable, why hould you defer it o long? That does depend upon her, replied Celadon, and not me; and until he be pleaed to give the command, I am not to blame if I hide my elf from her: for all the mieries and dicontent that I can fall into by concealment of my elf, are les then the crime of diobeying her. But (aid Adamas) whom would you have her give this command unto, ince he believes him unto whom it is to be given, not in the world? This (anwered the Shepherd) is a ecret which the Gods have reerved unto themelves: but I who am reolved to die a thouand deaths rather then fail in the leat circumtance of a perfect lover, I will wait with patience, and not dive too deep into the Mytery.

Son (aid the Druide) do no • wonder I hould till perit in my deires of your enjoying Atrea, ince my contentment is ineparably linked with yours, and ince the Gods have promied a contented old age unto me, in cae you receive that happines. Now you know the tate of our affairs, and ince you have a clear judgement to ponder all thee things, I would gladly have you conider that I can never meet with that felicity which the Gods have promied unto me, nor give you unto your Shepherdes at any other time but this: if things were in a better condition, and the Treaon of Polemas had not brought this Province to the very brink of ruine, I hould tay with as much patience as you; but ince all is in a deperate condition, and ready to be irrecoverably lot, I earnetly beeech
you my on, even for Atreas ake, who hath the greatet power over your pirit, not to oppoe any longer the deire that I have of eeing you two united together.

Celadon hearkned unto the Druide very attentively; but when he heard him mention the pitiful condition unto which the affairs of Amais was reduced. Make what hate and diligence you can (replied he) to render me this happines, it cannot be compleated o oon as the mieries which threaten this City; o as, Father, it is better never to begin to be happy, then not to enjoy it after the obtaining. My own particular interet is not o eparated from the Publick, but that it is my duty as well as other mens to endeavour the delivery of Amais from her oppreions, and I believe o you will permit it, I hall not altogether be unprofitable, and few there are that will endeavour more boldly then my elf, the glory of dying honourably: And therefore, Father, I do mot earnetly and heartily beeech you, and conjure you by all thoe cares which formerly you have had to hinder me from dying, to find out ome invention or other, by which I may fight as Celadon, and yet Astrea not perceive it.

Adamas did in his oul commend the courage of this Shepherd, and was extreamly glad to find in him uch marks of the generoity of his Ancetours; yet finding much difficulty in the deign, and yet deiring to trye his courage, he told him that the thing was impoible, and bad him never think more upon it: at which Celadon was o troubled, that not being able to hide his dicontent at this anwer, he changed colour; therefore to atisfie him, Adamas aid unto him, your deire Celadon is not o unjut but I would willingly grant it, if I did but know how to mannage the matter: for to tell you truly, I am afraid that the love which Atrea bears unto you will open her eyes, and make her oberve our actions more narrowly then yet he hath: upon this he paued a little, and afterwards continued.

I begin (aid he) to think of a way which may happily take effect; you mut know, Celadon, that as men commonly have recoure unto the god, more zealouly in adverity then in properity: o in mot deperate affairs they ue to imploy the prayers of uch as they think have mot prevalency with the gods. Now doubtles, uch as live out of the affairs of the world have more free accee unto the gods, then uch whoe minds are wholly upon the earth, and who hardly ever look up to heaven, unlee to ee what weather it will be: I do therefore conceive it expedient to pretend that Amais hath commanded me that you hall imploy your elf in offering up ome prayers according to the cutome of Druides daughters; and becaue during that time their eyes are not to be profaned by any terretrial object, well will pretend that you have cloytered up your elf in my houe; and afterwards covering your face and the ret of your body with uch Armour as Godomar, Damon, and other Cavaliers were, you may do as your courage inpires you, yet till without hazarding your elf too rahly.

Celadon, more glad of this expedient then he was able to expree, did kie the hand of Adamas: and after he had thanked him for the care he had of him, the Druide carried him back to Atrea: after this he returned to the Nymph, but not before all the Shepherds did wear unto him a thouand times, that they would pend every drop of blood they had in the ervice of that Nymph.

Clindor and the ret waited upon him out of the Garden: Atrea only tayed with Alexis; for her extream deire to know what dicoure Adamas had with him, made her defer it no longer, but to ask what it was: eeing her elf therefore without any other witnees, but the flowers and the fountains wherewith the Garden was adorned, dearet Mitree (aid he unto her) give me leave to be o inquiitive as to ask, what dicoure was it which Adamas and you had together? With all my heart, ervant (anwered Alexis) for your deire to know my buines, makes me believe that you think your elf intereted in it, and it is a great argument of the affection which you bear unto me, to hew your elf enible of what concerns me: I hould (replied Atrea) be the mot ingrateful peron in the world if I were not, ince your merit obtains as much, even from the mot barbarous dipoitions; but, dearet Mitree, I beeech you hold me
no longer in upence, but tell me what was the ubject of your dicoure? I hall tell you in few words, replied the uppoed Druide, all our dicoure was of nothing ele but the calamities of the State, and of thoe troubles which afflict the mind of Amais: after this he thought upon the bet remedies to prevent them, and found none more expedient then thoe which come from the gods, and told me that it was very neceary I hould make ome prayers unto them for that purpoe, and beeech them to deliver us from thoe calamities which threaten us: I make no quetion (aid Atrea) but you promied that you would: I did indeed (anwered Alexis) but ervant you know that there is a great deal of buinee to the accomplihment of this promie: What can there be extraordinary, aid the Shepherdee? for you can very eaily end up your thoughts unto heaven as you are accutomed, and becaue they hould not go unaccompanied, I will joyn my prayers with yours, and preent them with you. I am afraid (anwered Alexis) that you are ignorant in our manner of praying, and think this action as eaie, as to obtain of me a kie, or ome other trivial favour; but Servant, know that the gods will not be erved by any in a light manner. We mut make great preparation for it, and beget in our elves a fitting dipoition to receive their favours, otherwie in lieu of hearing our prayers, or decending into our hearts, they will be far abent from us, and leave us in the dark in lieu of clearing our undertandings. What mut we do (aid Atrea) to get this dipoition in us which you ay is o neceary? Should I tell you every particular (anwered Alexis) our dicoure would be too long; but in hort it is abolutely neceary to eparate my elf, for eight or ten dayes, from all manner of company, nay almot even from my very elf, and that I do not uffer my eyes to look upon any object that is prophane. How? (aid the Shepherdes and was a little urprized) how then can Atrea ubit when he is o long from Alexis? I cannot tell (aid the uppoed Druide) but I am ure that Alexis cannot live without the preence of Atrea.

The Shepherdes, who did not comprehend what Celadon meant, alas (aid he) Alexis indeed will not be upon the earth, for her thoughts will be all in heaven in weet raptures, whilt I being abent from her, and far from all conolation, hall droop and die a hundred times in a day with grief and inquietude: But Mitree (aid he and reprehended her elf) is it not poible, I that may be left out and not comprehended in the number of thoe objects, which you call prophane? and being but a woman, hall not diturb your olitude. Upon this Astrea began to hed ome tears, which the Shepherd topped with his lips, let they hould drop into her bret; but after he had pent a little time in this pleaing office, I wear Servant (aid he unto her) the time of this abence cannot be o ad unto you as to me; and yet when I conider, that I do not eparate my elf from you, but only to render unto the Nymph a ervice of coniderable importance, it is a kind of comfort unto me, and moves me to conjure you by all the tetimonies of love that formerly Celadon hath given unto you, that you do not any more oppoe my deire of imploying my elf for the afety of that Princes, and preervation of all Forret. But if (aid Atrea) Polemas hould become Mater of the Town whilt I am out of your ight, and will expoe us unto the barbarime of his Souldiers, will you not give me leave, Mitree, to die rather then uffer uch villains to triumph over me? Celadon was nettled at thee lat words, and fearing that uch a misfortune might happen, Servant (aid he) I do not only conent unto it, but command it, as a Victime which you oghut to acrifice for the preervation of your honour, and let nothing in the world hinder you: for aure your elf that I would do the ame; and as oon as ever they attempt any thing upon you, if I be not there to defend you, I am not in the world: however (aid Atrea) in the other world there will be no obtacle that can hinder our contentment; and I aure you, fairet Mitree, the preence of Celadon will not be one of the leat joyes which you will find there. I hope, aid the Shepherd, that he will be an eternal witnes of your Carrees; in the mean time, Servant, receive this adieu which I bid unto you, and promie to love me for ever with the ame paion which you have hitherto expreed. I do mot
faithfully promie it (aid Atrea and kied him) and if ever I fail in the performance of that duty, may heaven punih me: upon this they came near unto Clindor, Silvander, Diana, and others, who were newly entred into the Garden; and all of them went together into the next arbour, where the good old man caued abundance of excellent fruit to be brought, whereof every one did eat according to their appetites.

Whilt thee Shepherds and Shepherdees pent their time thus in the houe of Clindor, and had no other perplexities, but uch as were common to all the State, Roanira and Galathea eldome ever let each other, and had united themelves in uch terms of amity, as it was very hard to meet with two whoe affections were more inviolable. That day they went to pae away the afternoon in Roaniras chamber, becaue Amais deired to be left alone, and becaue the orrows of that Nymph did extreamly trouble thoe two Princees, as oon as they came into the chamber they ate down upon a bed; and Roanira embracing Galathea, I would to God (aid he unto her with tears in her eyes) that it were in my power to retore that contentment unto you which you have lot: if it were, I wear, fair Nymph, I would not pare my life it elf to procure it. Madam, anwered Galathea, that is a great deal too much: it is enough that you are o good as to honour me with your good wihes of it; I peak it, aid Roanira, from my very heart, and I beeech you believe it, that I cannot render you any ervice o great, but whatoever it be, it will be les then your merits. After Galathea had given many thanks for her good will, if heaven and Polemas (aid he) did not hate me wore then you do, Amais would never have been reduced unto thee extremities which afflict her and make me depair, becaue I look upon my elf as the only caue of all thee diorders: if heaven (anwered Roanira) would hearken unto my prayers, or if Polemas would hearken unto reaon or equity, all your mieries hould end this hour, but to my grief, both are deaf: Ah, Madam, replied Galathea, it was a fatal minute when firt Polemas looked upon me with the eyes of liking: for had he never loved me, or had I at the firt given, a check unto his vanity in pretending love to me, doubtles I had topped all thee misfortunes in their very beginning, and all our orrows had died with thoe hopes which have ince nourihed his preumption.

It was not in your power, replied Roanira, to keep your elf from appearing fair in his eyes, becaue you are really o in the eyes of all the world; but indeed, you might have kept him at uch an humble ditance, that the effects of his preumption hould never have dared to appear: And indeed, I cannot comprehend within the compas of my knowledge, what interet he has to pretend unto you; for if he do love you, how dare he be o bold as to dipleae you? and if he do not love you, what makes him o eager to overcome you? Madam (aid the Nymph) believe it, he is the mot peridious and dangerous pirit that breathes upon earth: He loves me only for ome ends; and if the State were to decend unto any other but me, I believe he would not o much as look upon me: You mut know, that his ambition oars higher then the thoughts of any mortal man could ever reach: Beides, he is of uch a jealous and envious nature, that the happines of another puts him into a burning Feaver, What has he not attempted againt Damon? he has everal times indeavoured to murder him, and takes thoe honours which my mother renders unto his merit o impatiently, as I believe it is one of the main caues of his dicontent; he has alo had ome bickerings with Lindamor, who was a very brave Cavalier; and when he aw himelf forced to yield unto the valour of his enemy, there was no treaon nor trick which he did not invent to ruine him: At lat, eeing all his pernicious ubtilties turned to his own hame and confuion; he openly took up arms, and takes the advantage of my brothers death, and of the abence of all our bet Cavalry to ruine us, under pretence of a deire to marry me.

Thus did Galathea condemn Polemas, whoe undertakings were indeed mot unjut; and Roanira, for a better information of her life, deired her to tell her more concerning thoe two Rivals, which the Nymph was very willing to do: o as he related all the Treaons of Polemas, the Juglings of Climanthes, the candalous
reports he had raied againt Lindamor: The combate wherein that Cavalier overcame him; and indeed all the remarkable accidents, which happened an conequents of that affection. Which Roanira hearkning unto with admiration, certainly, aid he, before he compas his ends, it will cot him much blood and pains. Truly, anwered the Nymph, if he hould prevail, and I not die with grief, I think I hall become my own executioner. We hall within a few dayes (anwered the Princes) ee what will be our Fates, and then we may guide our thoughts and our hands accordingly: For my part, if Roilion fail to relieve you, I hall have no joy in life, but would mot willingly die to punih him for his negligence, with thoe torments which my death would caue unto him: As he aid o, he embraced her again; and Galathea, till kiing the cheek of Roanira, why hould I, aid he, be the caue of o much misfortune unto you? It is not you, replied the young Princes, that would be the caue of it, but his negligence, or, perhaps, his infidelity: with uch dicoure as this, they entertained each other upon a ubject of orrow which was common unto them both.

Silvander in the mean time kept cloe by Diana, and by good fortune he found a fit opportunity of talking unto her, not out of the preence of other Shepherds and Shepherdees, but o as they could not hear him; and becaue he would not it idle whilt othert were labouring for the defence of Marcelles, he beeeched Diana to let him get ome honour as others did in dangers: Not Mitres (aid he) that I tand in any need of your permiion to whet my courage, but becaue I am certain that all I attempt will proper if it be done by the conent of fairet Diana.

The Shepherdes who did infinitly love him, and who could not any longer conceal her paion, was a little urprived at this requet, and her fears of loing him made her begin to look pale; but fearing withal that notice hould be taken of it, he recollected her elf as well as he could, and anwered him in thee terms: Servant (aid he) what need you ask me any leave to do that which your humour is o prompt unto that nothing in the world is able to divert you from it? If you hope that it would give good fortune unto your arms, you may conider it is impoible I hould give that which I have not my elf, and that being the mot mierable woman that lives, I can impart nothing unto you but my mifortunes.

It is no matter (replied the Shepherd) what uccee my Arms have, I hall think my elf abundantly happy, if imploying them in the defence of Amais, I can but pleae Diana; and therefore I mot humbly beeech you to expres your approbation of my deigne, to the end that if I die, it may be with this atisfaction that I did not dipleae you. I wih withal my heart, replied Diana, that you would not follow this coure; for your afety is dearer unto me, then perhaps, you imagine: But ince it is inevitable, I will not be oppoite unto the entence of our Detinies: The truth is, if that power which you have given me over you, had o much prevalency as not to be denied what I hall requet of you, I would have you make a mot inviolable promie unto me, not to venture your elf too deperately into any perils, and in your greatet dangers to remember, that the leat misfortune which can happen unto Silvander, is a very great one unto Diana.

Actions (anwered the Shepherd) which may be condemned of rahnes, are not uch as I think worthy of a man of courage; and therefore you may believe, that I will be as wary as becomes my honour, and will not o carelely expoe my life, but that if I do perih, it hall be honourable unto me, and profitable to the Nymph: But Mitres (continued he) ince Paris mut enjoy you, and ince you have not reolution enough to defend your elf againt him, can I deire to die more gloriouly then in thee wars, or in a eaon more advantageous unto me then this? ince you eem to pity my misfortune? Shepherd (anwered Diana) you have good reaon to ay that I have not reolution enough to defend my elf from marrying Paris, ince it is Bellindes will, and ince the gods have commanded me to be obedient unto her: But for all that believe me, what caue oever you have to eek for death, I am ure it can never happen unto you, but it will be mot
ad unto me, and perhaps intollerable: And therefore I tell you once again, that if you do value my contentment and atisfaction, you mut preerve your elf. As he aid o, Silvander would have kied her hand; but he oberving that ome eyes were upon him, he withdrew it, and preed his very hand, which was the greatet favour that ever he received: And becaue he was afraid, that if he purued this dicoure it would move too much paion, therefore he litned unto what others aid, and then he heard Hylas ay thus unto Tyrcis.

I cannot imagine Tyrcis, what object thou hat for thy courage, nor for whom thou houldt fight, becaue ince the death of thy dear Cleon, who lives till in thy excellent memory, all things are meerly indifferent unto thee, methinks anwered Tyrcis, that your imagination is very hallow, and that thou hat a wrong opinion of me, when thou thinket, that to fight I tand in need to propoe unto my elf any private interet: as if all actions which have uch objects, as to be eteemed valiant, to become rich, or uch like, were not fale Images of true valour: It is enough for me if I can erve Amais as I ought, without the thought of any other recompence, but the atisfaction of doing o; for virtue is a ufficient reward unto it elf: Lord how wie you are (anwered Hylas) but for all that I have reaon to upect thy courage, ince Laonice could make thee afraid: If I did fear the ubtilties of that woman (anwered Tyrcis) it was not for want of any courage, but rather a horrour that I had againt her wickednes; and if I be not much mitaken (continued he looking upon Hylas and afterwards upon Silvander) thou oughtet to put a great difference between that kind of fear which is directly oppoite unto courage, and thoe apprehenions which makes us fear a peron only out of a knowledge we have of ome ill qualities in her. I perceive (anwered Hylas) that thy eyes require ome help from Silvander, but we will at this time defer our dicoure unto another; only conider, I deire thee, that if I had leaure, I would make thee know that this Shepherdes is not o much to blame as you imagine her: Upon this he roe up, becaue Clindor began already to walk out of the Arbour, and Tyrcis had not time to make any other anwer, but that he believed all the eloquence in the world was not able to perwade him, but that he was unworthy, not only of his amity, but of the meanet Shepherds upon earth.

This was the opinion which Tyrcis had of the love and beauty of Laonice, who being not o far ditant as he imagined, did pae away her dayes and nights in her olitude, without any our thoughts, but upon the ingratitude of this Shepherd. Upon that day he was walked up to the top of a rock, which being very high, urveyed all the plain of Forrets; and becaue he could perceive every thing, even to the leat hrub, he quickly pied the Army from which Polemas expected the etablihment of his Fortune. At the firt it put her into a fright; but afterwards thinking it a thing impoible they could do her any hurt in that cloe olitude, unto which the gods and Tyrcis had confined her, her fears reflected only upon her Shepherd; and though he was well aured that he loved not her; yet he could not chue but wih his afety, and fear let ome harm hould happen unto him: Thee coniderations made her wet the very rock with her tears, and afterwards to dry up thoe tears again with the wind of her ighs; and thus he continued until night, which invited her to retire, and left her only as much light as to find out the way unto her cell: into which entring, he fell into her contant exercie, which was to pray unto the gods, and to think upon the ingratitude of Tyrcis.

At the arival of this relief from Gondebaut, Polemas caued all his own Forces, and all his Artillery to march out of Surlea: o as his joyes welled to an unmeaurable hight, when he imagined that the power which he had now under his command, was enough to bring Marcelles unto his will in a hort time: when he thought upon what he had gotten by the flight of Sigimond, he could not imagine that the Arms of the Son were able to give any check unto the Arms of the Father: He knew nothing of Lindamors return, who yet was not o far ditant from him as he uppoed; for that Cavalier, having marched with extraordinary hate, was already come to the rendezvous which he had appointed unto Sigimond.
That Prince on the other ide, made as much hate as poibly he could, and was o far advanced with his Troops, that he joyned with Lindamor about the middle of the night. They were no ooner met, but one of thoe Scouts which Lindamor had ent abroad, brought them word that Roilion was alo advanced with ten or twelve thouand men, and that he was already on this ide Moutbrion, at which they were o joyed, that they reolved to joyn with him, and accordingly they ent that Scout unto him with twelve of their Cavaliers, to prepare him to receive them; and afterwards, by the favour of the night, they took the field: Roili ••
who wih'd for no better, and was extreamly deirous to ee armed in the de •• g • of Amais, not only Sigimond and Lindamor, but all the world together, he advanced to meet them as fat as he could, and when they did meet with each other, their Carrees were o great, that the Sun eemed to rejoice at them, and began to gild the mountains with the luter of its beams.

Polemas had lept but a very little, by reaon of his longing deire to ee the Truce ended: o as being awake very early in the morning, day did no ooner dawn, but the received intelligence of this Armies arrival: his wonder was o much the greater, by how much it was beyond his expectation; yet finding it to be upon equal terms, he believed the los or the winning of a battel would decide the difference. He commanded therefore all the Officers of his Army to be in readinee, and did not draw any line about Marcelles, nor erected any of his Engines, let the eparation of his forces hould weaken him too much for a field fight.

On the other ide, Lindamor, who knew to a very man the trength of Polemas, did conceive it a very hard task for this Rebel to reit the valour and prudence of Sigimond and Roilion; and though he made no quetion of giving him a defeat, yet it grieved him extreamly to think that o many men hould be involved in the interet of one ingle man, and thought it a thouand pities, that for the crime of this one ingle man, fifteen or twenty thouand hould be punihed with death. This conideration made him think upon a remedy againt uch a mifortune; and finding none better then to move Polemas unto a deciion of the controverie by ingle combate, he reolved to ue all poible incitations that might pur him up unto it. Yet being unwilling to attempt any thing without the conent of Sigimond and Roilion, he did communicate his intention unto them in this manner.

Sirs, (aid he unto them) I make no doubt but you do know as well as my elf, that all thee violencies of Polemas againt Amais, do aim at no other end but the uurpation of her Etate. Now ince the crime of this Rebel is committed immediately againt a Princee, unto whom I am both by birth and inclination a Subject, none can more jutly then my elf revenge the wrongs which he hath received from the arrogance of this perfideous man; not, but that I know you have power to ruine the Rebel when you pleae, and his rahnee mut needs ubmit unto your valour. But I beeech you conider who are the enemies that you are to fight withal, and finding them to be almot all Subjects unto either Gondebaut or Amais, does it not grieve you to ruine them? I do therefore mot humbly beeech you, not to uffer o many people to perih for the fault of him that hath educed them, but to conent, that in the ight of your Army and his, I may punih his pride by a ingle Combate, o hall the guilty be punihed according to his merit, and the blood of my Princees Subjects aved. After this Lindamor was ilent; and Sigimond, without any long tudy what to anwer: let me perih (aid he) if I had not the ame thought before, and if I was not ready to make the ame propoition unto you. I do not know what Polemas is; I never aw his face, nor know of what temper he is; but I have o great an inclination to hate him, that difference of qualities hall not hinder me from meauring my word with his, if I knew by any means how to oblige him unto it. His courage, replied Lindamor, is not o mean, but he deerves to be held in ome conideration; yet it is accompanied with o many wicked qualities, that it mut be acknowledged his bad ones do extreamly urpae his good ones: He is extreamly vainglorious
and ambitious; the mot jealous man alive, and of uch a pernicious nature, that he cannot endure any other hould be owner of thoe virtues which he is not: there needs no decription of his humours (replied Sigimond) It is enough that I know what he attempts againt Amais and Galathea, to make me think him a mot wicked man: let me only tell you, that if I could bring to pas what I have already propounded, I hould receive a mot extraordinary atisfaction. I do conceive (aid Roilion) that we cannot in jutice deny Lindamor the requet which he hath made unto us. It is very true that you and I being both come to tetifie unto the Nymph our willingnee to erve her. I •• ceive Lindamor ought to imploy us both, which he cannot do this way, unle ••• e he admit us both to the ame ervice. Sir, aid Lindamor, what you have already done for the relief of Amais is not o mall, but by what arm oever he obtains her deliverance, he will acknowledge her elf infinitely obliged unto you. Brave Lindamor (aid Sigimond and interrupted him) you cannot be againt this, I ee what it is the courage of Soilion aims at, and if you will needs fight with Polemas, it mut be upon uch conditions as this Prince hath propoed. That (aid Lindamor) cannot well be, for there is none in that Army worthy of this honour, nor who dare accept of it. To remedy which, aid Roilion, you may end a challenge unto him to fight three to three, and happily he will accept of it without asking who the two are who take your part: Lindamor thought that it became him to ubmit to their wills, and therefore without any further oppoition, he ent Philiander, with a Herald, to carry this Challenge unto Polemas.

body.head: LINDAMORS Challenge unto POLEMAS.
body.p: DId I not perfectly know that Polemas is a man of courage, I hould fear he would not accept of that Combate which I offer unto him, and of which he himelf hall make the conditions: but having upon former occaions een ome experience of him, I am confident he will be glad to end that now, which then we did but begin: I would have for witnees of our actions, both our Armies: And I would have for companions of my Lot, two Cavaliers to fight on my ide, if you can find two that will o venture their lives for you. Let me peedily know your determination, and ince your ruine is inevitable conider that you cannot die more gloriouly then by the hand of Lindamor.

div.p: As oon as Palemas had read this defiance: Truly, aid he, if his valour be equal to his preumption, I hall find no feeble enemy to encounter withal; but I believe he has not o much advantage of me as his hopes do flatter him he has: Upon this, promiing Philiander that he hould receive anwer within an hour, he went to conult with Litander and Argonides upon the matter. Afterwards, being reolved upon it, he returned to Philiander and gave him this anwer: I do accept of the combate which Lindamor offers me, upon uch conditions as are expreed in this paper which you hall give unto him: And that he may know by the hate which I hall make, how much I deire to ee the end of all his hopes, with the end of his life, tell him; that within this two hours Argonides, Litander, and my elf, will be on horeback: upon this Philiander threw down a Gantlet which Polemas took up, and returning unto Lindamor, he gave him an accompt of his uccee, and preented unto him the paper of Polemas: which Lindamor opening, he hewed it unto the two Princes, who found in it thee words.

body.head: The Anwer of POLEMAS unto the Challenge of LINDAMOR.
body.p: YOu are come very opportunely to preerve unto my reputation, that Luster which in ome ort it would have lost, in vanquihing only women, my glory wanted nothing but your return, and ince heaven has harkened unto my deires; I am glad that I need do no more but overcome you before I enjoy thoe favours which are more due unto my merit then unto your vanity. You hall ee me therefore this day in the condition of a man, who is triumph both over his Rival and his Mitres: and ince I can engage thirty thouand men to fight for me, you need not doubt but I hall find two that will think themelves highly honoured in following my fortune; and therefore ince you have left the conditions of our Combate unto my choie: Thee following are they which I propound, unles you find any thing repugnant to your mind.

p.hi: The death of Lindamor or Polemas hall be the ole diciion of the Combate.
It hall be lawful for the firt vanquiher to help his two Friends.
The Armies hall follow that ide which proves victorious.
And it hall not be permitted the Conquerours to exercie upon the bodies of their conquered enemies, any act that may render their memories les glorious.

div.p: Thee were the conditions upon which Polemas accepted of Lindamors Challenge, in which Sigimond found nothing but what was jut: Roilion only proteted, that this article which obliged the Armies to follow the Conquerours, ought to be undertood only of that Army which Lindamor brought from Childerick: for, aid he, I am mot certain that there is not one of my men who will not die to revenge me, or to get Roanira out of the power of Polemas. Sir, aid Lindamor, the gods do fight for us, ince jutice is on our ide: Let us give this Traytour that contentment which he askes, and conider that it will be the lat he mut ever make. Roilion who would not be any obtacle unto this deign, did conent unto it, and propoed it as a good expedient to advertie Ama • is of all paages; but Lindamor and Sigimond were of a contrary opinion, and aid, that if the Combate did end well, the joyes of the Nymph would be the greater, becaue he would be the more pleaingly urpried: and if it fell unto the glory of their enemies, it was till bet for the Nymph to be kept from depair, and not be at once from a hope of happines into a mot certain miery. Upon this reolution Lindamor ent word unto Polemas: upon the ame conditions which he had propoed; alo caued the Articles to be publihed; Polemas on his ide did the ame, and afterwards went to make choie of the bet arms and hores he could find.

Things tanding upon thee terms, Amais who knew of no paages without the Town, was o much overcome with grief, as he could hardly tell what he did: he took but very mall ret all the night; but when day appeared, o as the Army of Sigimond, Roilion, and Lindamor, might be een (which this afflicted Princee took to be a freh upply coming unto Polemas) he was ready to end her elf into another world; She wihed for death a hundred times; and was angry with the Sun, becaue it would not let her hide her elf in eternal darknes. Ah me (aid he) how dimal is this day unto me, wherein being deprived of my Etate and Galathea, I have left me nothing in the world that I care for: O how
ad a thing it is, that the words of men hould be nothing but o many lies, and how fale are all uch hopes as are built upon uch failing foundations: Upon this he was ilent a while, to wipe away thoe tears which had bedewed her cheeks, then he began again to expotulate the adnee of her condition: O heaven (aid he) how cant thou uffer o much injutice; why dot thou not punih Lindamor for his negligence, and Roilion for keeping the promies of Argira? Surely thou art a favourer of ins, ince thou dot uffer the perfidie of Polemas to pas unpunihed. With uch diparing expreions as thee, this Nymph did lament her condition, when Godomar, Damon, Alcidon, Adamas, and ome other Cavaliers, who were no lee troubled at the coming of this new Army, did come unto her, after they had viited the ports and the walls. She was then upon the top of one of the Towers in the Catle, from whence he might look upon thoe Forces which he thought to be enemies, and eeing all the plain which was wont to be o fertile in grae, now filled with armed men, and o many Pikes as reembled a thick wood: O ye pittiful gods (aid he) what a deplorable change is here ince yeterday, and how illy are all uch as eek for any tability in the poeion of humane things? In aying o, he fixed her eyes o attentively upon the two Armies, which were not ditant from each other above five or ix hundred paces, that he did not ee Godomar when he came unto her; but he urprized her o unk in orrows, that he was even ready to die: She thought the Town already expoed to the fury of the ravenous Souldier; and fear had o eized upon her oul (an evident tetimony of the weaknes in her ex) as he thought the rattling of the Princes armour to be Polemas who was come to eiz upon her: o as he gave a loud criek, and uch a cold chilnee eized upon her, that her leggs failed, and he fell as dead into the arms of Godomar. Adamas atonihed at this accident, did run as fat as he could for uch remedies as might recover; and therefore Roanira, Galathea, and Dorinde, who that night lay all in one chamber, were quickly advertied of it; o as they run to help the Nymph; but when they came unto her he was returned out of her wound. Galathea was the firt upon whom Amais cat her eye; and becaue that young Princee was all in teares: Ah daughter (aid he unto her) our tears are now uneaonable, and are only tetimonies of our puilanimity: For in uch depair as ours, we had better die then cry. Madam (anwered Godomar) what reaon oever he has to deire living no longer, a precipitated death is odious unto the gods, and rather argues puillanimity then magnanimity: uch as for fear of any future pain do rahly horten their dayes, are uch as want courage, and who falling from one extremity into another, do fall from temeroity into depair: It is much better patiently to obey whatoever the heavens ordain, and he will receive more contentment by it: The contentment which he can expect, replied Amais, is o inconiderable, that if he have no other then it to deire living, it is better to prepare our elves betimes to die; but if we have o much courage as to try how far our misfortunes can go, we till live on: Therefore, Galathea, let us not die until Polemas perih with us. Upon this he was ilent, and her countenance hewing more confidence then before, he eemed at that time to aume ome trange reolution. Galathea, whoe orrows for Amais pierced her very oul, did anwer in no language but that of tears, who eeing her elf econded by Roanira and Dorinde, he, ad oul, welled the more with orrows, and eemed to be proud of uch good companions in grief.

Damon, on the other ide, who was all pity, did trive as much as he could to turn his eyes from off thee fair ones; and by good fortune, looking towards the plain, where the two Armies appeared in very good order; he aw three Cavaliers come out from one of them, without any other company but three Trumpets, and three Pages, who carried their Lances: their comly manage of their hores did extreamly delight him, for all his hatred unto thoe of Polemas his party: o as calling to Godomar, and hewing him the countenances of thee three Cavaliers, Alcidon came alo to ee them, af • erwards Adamas, and after him Amais and the Ladies who were with her; all who, not knowing what the deigne of thee Cavaliers was, they reolved not to tir from thence until they aw the concluion of this paage.

Celadon in the mean time had deired Adamas to execute the intention which he reolved upon the day before; but the Druide having deferred it until the next morning, by reaon of ome affair he had concerning the arival of thee new forces, he was contrained to return to Atrea: and that fair Shepherdee perceiving by Celadons dicoure, that he was to enjoy the company of her dear Alexis longer, he was o extreamly joyed at it, that he was not enible of thoe afflictions which tormented the minds of all the world. Clindor, Diana, Silvander, Phillis, Licidas, Hylas, Stella, Alexis, and Atrea, were all come together unto the walls of the Town, to look upon the new Troops that were arived; and they had not been there above a quarter of an before they pied thoe three Cavaliers which Damon aw: and conceiving by the Trumpets and Pages, that they came not thither without ome deign, they tayed to ee the uccee, and it hapned thus.

Sigimond, Roilion, and Lindamor, who were the three Cavaliers before mentioned, no ooner appeared, but Polemas, Argonides, and Litander, appeared alo; o bravely armed, and every way accomplihed, as was impoible of better: they alo had their Trumpets and Pages, o as after they had faced each other a while, the Trumpets began to ound; and the Pages giving them their Lances, upon the firt ign which was given, they et forward o furiouly, and encountred with uch force, that the rocks ecchoed back the noie of their blows. Amais did wonder at the novelty of this pectacle; and asking Godomar the caue of this Combate: Madam, anwered he, we cannot know it but from themelves; but it is credible that ome difference is amongt them concerning the command in the Army, and ambition and jealouie are the caues of their coming hither, and they are reolved to decide their differences by Arms, which they cannot any otherwayes compoe: the Nymph found ome probability in this, and oberved that their firt coure was not ended upon equal advantage: Roilion broke his Lance upon Litander, and hitting him upon the right houlder, did break a piece of his Curae without doing him any other harm: Listander alo broke his very well. Sigimond, whoe activity and valour was not inferiour unto any, and being to encounter with an enemy, that was accomplihed with all the ornaments of a brave Cavalier, did give and receive his blow almot in the ame place; for the blow did light upon the mouth of his helmet, and the point of his Lance piercing through did a little hurt the lip of Argonides; and he himelf received a hurt under the left eye, but o happily, that the point did but glide by it. Lindamor, unto whom the life of Polemas was abominable, he ran with uch fury upon him, that he thrut his enemy out of the addle to the ground: o as becaue he corned to take advantages, he preently alighted, and accoted him as oon as ever he was got up from the ground.

In the mean time Roilion and Litander had taken new Lances, and at the econd coure the Prince diarmed the arm of his Antagonit, and made uch a wound in it, that the Cavalier not being able to weild either Lance or word, but loing a great abundance of blood and his peech, he fell dead ome thirty or fourty paces ditant. Sigimond broke three Lances againt Argonides, and finding that he had got but a very little advantage of him, he advanced unto him, and aid, our Lances Cavalier, have done their office, let us therefore ee whether our words can determine our Combate. Argonides, who found himelf a little wounded, and who knew very well what an unjut quarrel he had epoued, he wihed that he had never undertaken the Combate: yet eeing that without the los of his honour, which he valued above a hundred lives, he could not refue the offer of his enemy: Brave Cavalier (anwered he) I am ready to do as thou deiret; and if my courage do not deceive me, thy word can do me no more harm then thy Lance: In aying o, they both drew their words, and began to lay on uch load, that fire parkled out of their arms, like unto a hot piece of Iron which the Smith is triking upon his Anvil.

Polemas in the interim was diputing for his life with Lindamor, whoe agility at every blow made a freh wound: At lat, the Rebel finding himelf wounded in everal places, he reolved to eek for that in his depair which he could not find
in his valour, and to imploy his whole trength at once; o as cloing with Lindamor, he endeavoured to throw him to the ground; Lindamor, who was not at all weary with fighting, did eaily perceive his deign, o as preparing both his word and his foot for it, he ran the one up to the hilt into his thigh, and tript up his heels with the other o nimbly, that he laid him all along in the dut. Polemas yet made ome reitance, but Lindamor finding out the defective part of his Curae, did run his word o far into his body, that his oul came out before it.

Roilion, who did not think his enemy would die upon that wound which he had received, he no ooner aw him fall from his hore but he alighted, and when he came unto him, eeing him give up his lat breath, he preently mounted again: This chanced to be at the very ame time when Lindamor had dipatched Polemas o as now there remained none but Argonides: who remembring the conditions of the Combate, and eeing Roilion and Lindamor approach, he recoyled two or three paces, and aid thus unto Sigimond; By that experience, Cavalier, which I have of thy valour, I know thou hat no need of any aitance to vanquih me: I ee here thy friends are come to help thee; if therefore thou wilt have the glory of vanquihing me alone, let them not do me any harm. Sigimond admiring the courage of his enemy, and thinking it pity to ruine him; do not think (anwered he) that I will uffer any other arm but my own to get that victory of thee which is infallible; but if the deire which I have to let thee live do concur with any deire in thee not to die in o dihonourable a caue, render up thy word unto me, and I will promie thee upon mine honour that none hall do thee any injury. Argonides eeing there was no diputing againt three, here generous Cavalier (aid he and urrendred his word) the honour to be overcome by thy courteie, is as dear unto me, as the glory to overcome half the world. Then Sigimond took his word, and Roilion and Lindamor being come near unto them, they heard Sigimond return this anwer; how great oever the advantage I had over thee might be, yet I do acknowledge my elf more beholding unto the good fortune of my arms, then unto my own valour: yet ince thou do freely yield unto me a victory which thou mightet till dipute, here (aid he) I do give thee thy arms again, upon a promie thou will never imploy them again againt the ervice of Amais: Argonides having olemnly worn that he would not, Lindamor ent unto Ligonias, who was the ole commander of Polemas his Army, to know whether he would oberve the conditions of the Combate: unto which Ligonias himelf coming to give an anwer, and ubmitting himelf unto all that Lindamor commanded; he ordained the head of Polemas to be brought unto him, and his body to be very ecretly buried with Litanders; and afterwards they all turned their coure together towards the Town.

Amais, who all this while never took her eye off the Combatants, had a hundred everal conceits in her mind; and as no miery is o great, but there is till ome park of hope in it; o the Nymph ometimes conceited that happily this diorder might produce omething to her benefit; yet he was not long flattered with this imagination: for beginning to conider that they were all her enemies, and that this Combate was only to deide the controverie which of them hould have the glory of doing her the mot harm, he fell again into her uual apprehenions, and lot all thoe hopes which her firt thoughts had infued into her.

It was not long before he oberved that the Conquerours, in lieu of returning unto their Army. did come traight unto Marcelles, and therefore he advertied Godomar of it, who, no more then he, could imagine the end of this adventure; and therefore he thought good to end Adamas unto the gate, to hear what propoitions they would make. The Druide was no ooner come to the gates, but the Conquerours met him, who crying in a loud voice, Liberty, Liberty, did put the pirit of Adamas into uch an amazement, that he knew not whether it was real or a Dream. The people, who longed for nothing o much as this contentment, they were o enible of this word, that they run immediatly through all the treets crying, Liberty, Liberty; o as their voices reached unto
the walls of the Catle, and came unto the eares of the Nymph: This made her colour to come and go two or three times, and make her think the voice of the people to be the voice of God; yet he had o many caues of fear that he hardly durt allow any room for hope: At the lat Adamas came to aure her that the Gods were pitiful unto her; that Polemas was dead: That he who had overcome him deired permiion to kie her hand, and lay at her feet the Trophies of his victory: At this news Amais was o urpried with joy, as not being able to anwer, he entreated Godomar to upply her defect; and the Prince finding no danger in opening the gates, ince they were o mall a number, Adamas went out in order thereunto; and Godomar himelf, with all the Cavalry in the Town, went to meet them.

The novelty of this accident, and the noie which the Trumpets made in the treets, did aemble together all the people of the Town, o as Lindamor found it to be better manned then he imagined: Adamas went before to advertie Amais of their arival: Godomar accompanied Sigimond, who eeing that his brother knew him not, did laugh under his arms to ee him o deceived: Damon was upon the left hand of Roilion, and Alcidon went in the middle between Lindamor and Argonides. In this order they came to the Catle, and Adamas receiving them at the gates, did carry them into a great Chamber where Amais was already, accompanied with all her Nymphs, and all the Ladies that were in Marcelles.

As oon as they entred, Amais aroe from her chair, and Lindamor advancing (as it was agreed amongt them) Madam (aid he in a loud voice, and kneeling upon the ground) your complaints have at the lat reached heaven; and the jutice of your caue hath moved us to leave a countrey where Mars has imployed our courages and our arms, to retore unto your people that Liberty which they deire, and unto you that tranquility which you deerve. Polemas is punihed for his perfidie, and his head which I do bring unto you, will witnee his defeat and my fidelity: Upon this he took it from his Page, and threw it at the feet of Amais; but the Nymph looking another way, and raiing up the Cavalier, Sir, aid he, what thanks oever I do give you for this benefit which I receive from your valour, they will till come hort of that good will which I have to acknowledge it. And if you will compleat my joyes; take away the head of that Rebel, and let me ee the face of my deliverer. Lindamor, who could not diobey this command, did pul off his helmet, and tooping down to kie the skirt of her garment, he was prevented by her, who knowing him, and taking him in her arms, he could ay nothing unto him but, ah Lindamor, Lindamor. Whether Galathea was glad of Lindamors return, I leave any to judge that ever was in love; but o it was, that he tood like a tatue immoveable, and wavering between love and repect, he was o tranported, that he eemed defective in both. At the lat, Amais giving ome repite to her Carrees, Lindamor preented Sigimond and Roilion unto her aying, here, Madam, are the Cavaliers unto whom all the favours you are pleaed to confer upon me, are more jutly due, and, who do better deerve the title of your deliverers: Their courages have overcome all difficulties, and there is no obtacle which they have not generouly urmounted to relieve you: Then the two Princes advancing, and the Nymph received them with a countenance full of joy; but brave Lindamor (aid he) ince I am o infinitly obliged unto them, why will you not let me have the happinee of knowing them? Madam (anwered Lindamor) do not wonder at their ilence: They are Cavaliers, and have vowed not to dicover themelves until you have obtained from ome Ladies that are about you, thoe favours which they have a deire to ask. The Nymph who was extreamly deirous to ee thee perons whom already he eteemed o dearly: I do believe (replied he) that if it be a thing which they can lawfully grant, they will conent unto it for my ake: which mot of the Ladies proteting they would do, Sigimond took off his headpiece, and aluting Dorinde, Madam, aid he unto her, the favour that I ask from you, is only a pardon for being the caue of o much miery unto you, ince your coming from Lions: And I (aid Roilion having uncovered his face) fairet Roanira, do claim
from you the performance of that promie which you made unto my love, and that obeying the will of Policander, you receive me for your husband. Amais could not have the patience to permit thee Ladies to anwer: for hearing Godomar name the one Sigimond, and knowing Roilion, he ran to embrace them with more joy then is poible for any tongue to expree.

Adamas had no ooner done what was due at the arrival of thee two Princes, and return of Lindamor, but he went to advertie Clindor of the joyes which Amais had received: He found with him all the Shepherds and telling them the name and quality of the Conquerours: Children (aid he unto them) I am mot heartily glad that all our enemies are dead in the peron of Polemas, and that by the blood which Lindamor hath drawn from the veins of this Rebel, the gods have preerved yours. I protet Father (aid Hylas and interrupted him) I am as glad of it as you: for I was ever more apprehenive of an arrow from our enemies, though it did but hit my little toe, then I am of a hundred arrows which they ay love hoots at our hearts. Yet let me tell you, anwered Adamas, the wounds of the oul are much more dangerous then thoe of the body: Yes, yes, replied the incontant man) unto melancholly people; but I who can in a moment find a hundred remedies to cure my elf of uch wounds, I had rather have twenty wounds in my oul, then a little cratch upon my body: Heaven (aid the Druide) has out of its abundant goodnee freed you from all fears of any harm: and as well a wiher as I am unto the afety of Amais, I am as glad of your preervation as of hers: Heaven (aid Atrea) has hewed unto us the effects of her piety; but is it not as much to be acribed unto the upplications and prayers of Alexis, ince by her pious intention only of praying, he hath obtained our deliverance? The gods (anwered Alexis) have hated their helping hands to hew that the jut caue of Amais has more prevalency with them then all my prayers, the power whereof is o little, as it is almot impoible they hould ever obtain any thing they ask.

Ah Mitree (aid Atrea) pardon me if I ay, that then they mut be made into marble: for if they be directed unto any that have reaon, it is abolutely impoible you hould be denied any thing you ask; and for my part, I mut tell you without flattery, that there is nothing in the world which you can require from me, but I hall mot freely and willingly grant it. Take heed Servant, anwered Alexis, that you do not engage your elf further by promies then you are willing to perform. No, no, aid Atrea, I will not except any thing; and I ay it again, nay wear it by all that is acred, that you have the abolute command of my life and all I have, and there is nothing which I would not mot willingly do to pleae and obey you. We hall ee that one day (aid Alexis) and in the mean time do not forget what you ay, and remember that you have promied it before all this good company, o as you cannot go back without being blamed for too much Levity.

After ome other dicoure, the Druide returned unto the Catle, to put Amais in mind of the Liberty which he had promied unto Peledontes; and as oon as ever he made mention of him, the Nymph ent to releae him out of prion, and o graciouly pardoned his crime, that this Cavalier for ever after was faithfull unto her. Adamas alo preented unto the Nymph the uffering of ubjects ever ince the rebellion of Polemas began, and the extremity under which they were till preed, having at the leat ixty thouand Men quartering upon them: of whom the Nymph had o much compaion, that he reolved to take ome coure for their conolation: he communicated the matter unto Sigimond, Roilion, and Godomar, who the very ame hour took uch good order in the buinee, that the next morning mot of the troops were dimied and ready to depart the countrey: Sigimond dipoed Ligonias to take upon him the conduct of thoe forces which he brought from Polemas, and gave him a Letter unto Gondebaut: Roilion alo writ unto the Queen Argira, intimating the uccee which they had: After this, the Nymph carried them unto the Temple, to be witnees of thoe thanks which he would render unto the gods for their goodnee in delivering her from the fears of captivity, to the enjoyment of perfect Liberty, in o hort a time.
The ret of the day was pent i • feating and joyes: o as in the excee of this publick jollity, Amais did quite forget all her pat mieries; the death of Clidemant only remained in her memory, and therefore he took Lindamor aide to acquaint her withal that he had done ince the death of her on: This Cavalier deiring nothing with more paion then to tetifie his obedience, did prepare himelf to atisfie his curioity; and whilt the Cavaliers were dicouring with the Ladies and Nymphs in the Chamber, he held this dicoure.

div.head: The Sequel of the Hitory of CHILDERICK, of SILVIANA and of ANDRIMARTES.
div.p: I Do not know, Madam, whether that Cavalier whom I ent unto you after the death of Clidemant, did well acquit himelf of that commiion which I gave unto him; and whether he made a faithful relation unto you of all thoe circumtances which happened concerning the digrace of Childerick: He did relate unto us (anwered Amais) the paion of that young King unto Silviana: his deignes of breaking the marriage between Andrimartes and her; The violences he committed in the houe of a new married woman in the abence of her husband: The flight of Silviana in the habit of a boy; and latly, the revolt of the people, and the los of my on, which was almot econded by the loe of your elf; for he told me that you were extreamly wounded in the ame encounter. Then Madam, replied Lindamor, he hath neglected nothing which he was to relate unto you; but becaue you do not know after what manner Silviana and Andrimartes met, nor what befel them ince they came into Gaul Armorique, whereof Semnon hath made them uperiours, I hall relate the particulars unto you, having received them from themelves: For Andrimartes, who honoured me with his love, paing by the city of Rhemois to complain unto Queen Methina of the extravagancies of her on, was pleaed to viit me as I lay in bed, by reaon of my wounds, and related unto me thee accidents which you hall hear: after this Lindamor was ilent a while, afterwards he began his relation in this manner.

The good advice which Guyemant gave Childerick did work o well upon the pirit of this young King, that he was fully reolved in his very oul, and proteted a thouand times never to relaps into the ame or the like in again; but the commotion of a people being much reemblant unto Torrents, which in their firt fury carry all before them that makes any reitance, Childerick was forced to yield unto that enraged multitude that were rien up againt him, and to acknowledge, that to the reparation of a crime repentance is not alwayes ufficient: he fled away therefore in a diguie, as oon as he had divided the piece of gold with Guyemant: and becaue he could not better commit his afety unto any, then thoe whoe fidelity and courage he had tryed, he deired, although I was extreamly wounded, that I would bear him company until he came unto Bain, Duke of Turin, into whoe protection he reolved to fly: I who after the death of Clidemant, did not at all value my life, did conent unto his deire; and though I knew unto what danger I expoed my elf, yet I would go with him. And o we departed after he had bid adieu unto Guyemant, who hed tears at this ad eparation. Childerick in this departure did hew the generoity of his courage, which was the only good quality he had; for without o much as any changing colour, dear friend (aid he unto Guyemant) I do depart in puruance of that councel which you have given me; and I would have you believe that my departure is a very great argument of that power which you have over me; but for you I had wahed away the crime which I committed, with my own blood, and had not lived a minute after the los of my Crown: But ince you promie me to labour for my reetablihment, I am reolved to live, that you may know I do not depair of that
help which I may receive from your prudence. After this intreating him afreh to imploy his widome in order thereunto, and embracing very affectionately, we took hore, being accompanied with ome Seguian Cavaliers which then I had with me, and within a few dayes after we came to the city of Rhemois, by which Childerick would pae to acquaint the Queen his mother with his exile. It is the mot lamentable pectacle that is imaginable to this ad encounter: for as oon as Childerick entred into the Queens chamber, he did cat himelf at her feet; and that Princee who knew not the caue of his coming, looking upon him with a more joyful apect then his misfortune required, he advanced to embrace him; but he gently, thruting her back, Madam (aid he unto her) do not prophane your pious hands by touching the inful corps of him whom the gods do hate, and who hath mot hamefully dihonoured you: How? aid the Queen, and was extreamly atonihed, are not you Childerick my on, the King of the Franks? I am indeed Childerick (anwered he) whoe crimes have made him unworthy the glory of being called your on, as the Franks have already taken from him the quality of King. Upon this the Queen upecting the misfortune which had hapned unto him: O Childerick, cryed he out, what is this you ay? In aying o, he aroe up with a tream of tears in her eyes, and the Prince being retreated back two or three paces, he went unto him, and taking his hand, he carried him into her cloet.

She then ent preently for me, and as oon as I entred I offered to kie her feet; but he embracing me, ah Lindamor (aid he unto me) how truly did Merovens Prophecy, and how unfortunate am I to ee the effects of that which that poor King o much feared? Madam (aid I unto her) it is a misfortune which is now come to pae, and which none but the gods can now revoke: It is true, Lindamor (anwered he) but if Childerick had been virtuous, it was in his power to prevent it. I who knew what jut caue he had to accue him, but deired to infue ome conolation unto thoe orrows which I aw her uffer: Madam (aid I unto her) we are ometimes hurried unto things by uch a ecret and vehement violence, as it is almot impoible we hould reit it, and it eems there is a kind of fatality in it, which is unavoidable. But (aid he and interrupted) a man of any ound judgement, and that has any repect unto the gods, will never obey the unruly fury of a brutih appetite; and how vehement and violent oever their inclinations be that puh him forward, he will till find uch arms in his virtue, as will be to urmount them: but (added he and ighed) Childerick had ever uch an inclination unto vice, as he alwayes held thoe for his mortal enemies who endeavoured to divert him. His paion at thee, unto Silviana, replied I, could not abolutely be termed vitious, ince notwithtanding the inequallity of their conditions, it had virtue for its object; but indeed, after he was out of any hopes to enjoy her, he ought to have extinguihed the deires of it, and not to have endeavoured to dihonour her: Did he offer any violence (aid the Queen unto me) unto Silviana? I did not well know what anwer to return, when cating his eyes upon me, Nay, nay, (aid he) go on boldly, and atisfie the Queens curioity: make me as enormous as you can, you cannot decribe me o wicked as my own concience tells me I am. Sir, anwered I, and turned towards him, ince you are pleaed to command me, and ince the Queen deires to be informed of all paages, I will not conceal any thing from her: Then I related all unto her, yet adding ome arguments that might in ome ort extenuate his crime, and render it pardonable.

I had no ooner ended my dicoure, but this afflicted Princee addreing her elf unto her on: Now Childerick (aid he unto him) you find a recompence for all your actions: now you are without a Crown, without a Scepter, and in a condition to eek the protection of another; now you are depoed from the title of a King, to aume that of a Tyrant, and I without any other conolation amidt o many calamities, but what I receive in admiring the jut judgement of the gods in your punihment. O ye mot jut Deities (aid he, lifting up her eyes and hands to heaven) I do call you all as witnees of my innocency, and do earnetly beeech you to turn away your anger from our family; you only do know the
thoughts of my oul, and punih m • if ever I have neglected any care in the good education of my on, either by dicoure or example: In aying o he begun to hed uch abundance of tears, that I had much ado to retrain mine. Childerick after he had tudied a little upon it; Madam (aid he unto her) though I had a oul that was altogether inenible of any orrow for my ins, yet your tears are able to inpire me with repentance: And believe it, my oul is o exceedingly orry for what I have done, that I would mot willingly do any pennance in the world to repair it; but not knowing any atisfaction that equal the grandure of my in, I do mot humbly beg of you, Madam, a pardon for this offence, to the end the gods, after your example, may ceae to purue me, ince they have already made me very enible of the effects of their vengeance.

The Queen was o full of orrow, that he uffered Childerick to continue upon his knees, and knew not what to do; but at the lat raiing him up, Childerick aid he unto him) I beeech the gods as freely to forgive you as I do, and may your repentance move them as much as it hath overcome me. But conider how much I uffer for the haynounee of your crime; and if my commands have not prevalence enough in them to keep you from relaps, let the conideration of your own Interet be o preualent with you.

It is not pertinent to relate unto you, Madam, all the promies which Childerick made unto her, nor the ret of the dicoure which the Queen and he had together: It is ufficient you know that he accompanied us with a Letter unto the Duke of Thurin, and uffered us to depart the next morning, which we did; and I aure you, though I had a very excellent Chirurgeon with me, who dreed my wounds every day, yet the length of the way was very troubleome unto me.
