But within a few dayes, we came to Thurin, where we were kindly received; for Bain, being both the couin and allie of Childerick, was very orry to ee him in uch affliction, which made us confident of obtaining that reception which we hoped for: As oon as I preented the Queens Letter unto him, he opened it, and having read it, hewed it unto me; afterwards he addreed himelf unto Childerick, and proteted that he would protect him againt any that had any deigns to hurt him: perhaps then (aid Amais and interrupted him) you have the Letter which the Queen did write unto him, for it was left in your hands: I believe I have, Madam, anwered Lindamor, and if you have a deire to ee it, I am confident I can find it: The Queen expreing much deire to have a ight of it, he put his band into his pocket, and amongt many other papers he found it; which opening he read thee words.

body.head: The Letter of Queen METHINA unto BASSIN Duke of Thurin.
body.p:
CHilderick does come to cat himelf into your arms, in hopes to find a fafe anctuary against all the misfortunes that perecute him: but if there be as great an inequalitie in your inclinations as there is diproportion between his vice and your virtue, I expect but a very bad uccee of his voyage: Yet if the kindnese which you have ever expresed unto the mother, can be any way communicated to the on, I hall not altogether depair of his afety, but will at the leat believe that you will favour him o far as to let him live. His ins have offended heaven, and I fear that in revenge it will not let him find a afe retreat upon earth: But be the anger of the gods never o much exaperated againt us, yet I know that they are not always inexorable, nor o deaf, but his repentance and my tears may open their eares, if you once begin to be enible of thoe tears which I mingle with the ink that writes thee lines. Take therefore ome pity, I beeech you, upon the affliction of
Methina, and upon the mieries of Childerick, and ince both the one and the other have the honour of ome alliance unto you, let their interet be in ome ort yours, and let that little hope which I have remaining, be kept alive under your protection.

div.p: This, Madam (aid Londamor) was the Queens Letter unto him, which had uch influence upon his oul, that he proteted, as I told you before, to erve and protect him againt all whomoever. For my part, I made as little tay at Thurin as I could, becaue Guyemant o advied me; but though my deires of returning oon unto you were never o great, yet I could not: for being engaged to return unto the City of Rhemois, to acquaint the Queen with the good reception of Childerick, my travel did caue two of my wounds to open, and a Feaver eizing upon me, I was forced to yield unto the violence of my dieae, I was brought into uch a condition, that I almot depaired of my recovery.

In the mean time, Silviana was gone from Paris in the habit of one of Andrenecks children, and had with her only the wife of that good man, and one that was ervant unto Andrimartes: It hapned, that being gone from under the hedge where they lay all the night, and being in the high way towards Gandelu, he had not gone above half a mile, but he heard a great noie of men and hores coming towards her: Her fears, by reaon of the danger which he hunned the day before, did make her preently look about: and becaue he aw they gallopped very fat, and heard them cry, tay, tay: O God (aid he unto the wife of Andreneck) yonders the Tyrant till puruing me; but (aid he) if you ecape with your life, I command you to tell my Andrimartes, that I will die before they hall do any injury unto my honour or his: in aying o he drew her word, and looking for no afety by flying, he tood till, and expected the uccee of her Fortune.

Mean time, thoe that purued her came o near as to oberve her poture, and taking her for a Cavalier, they wondered what hould move him to tand o in a poture of defence: thinking it fit to ask the reaon of it, they made a tand ome fourty or fifty paces ditant, and ent one of their company to ask why he tood o with his word drawn. Silviana, till eeming a Cavalier, he anwered boldly, that about two dayes ince, a Traytour had made ome attempts againt his honour, and thinking that he was now come to execute his murderous deign, was the caue of his tanding in the poture of a man that would ell his life at a dear rate: Then the man aured him, that thoe whom he upected, would alwayes be more ready to erve, then to hurt him, and the reaon why they rid after him, was, becaue they took him for one of their friends, who went from their houe not above an hour ince, and hearing that a Hart was to be coured, they called him to be a partaker of their port. Silviana, very glad of her mitake did put her word, and began to prepare her elf for the continuance of her voyage; but the man deiring to know her name: My name (anwered he) is Cephindres, who hall think himelf very happy in any occaion to erve you. Upon this, he rid away, and going towards Gandelu, he oberved that thoe who had followed her, did go into a thick wood which was upon the right hand. In the mean time, Andrenecks wife eeing her elf out of that danger which o affrighted her, he began to be a little angry, but o handomly, that the brave Cephindres could not forbear laughing: Madam (aid the good woman unto her) if you be o forward to draw your word, and defie all you meet, I beeech you make it your profeion to be a Knight errant, and maintain my beauty againt all the world; but to tell you truly, I think your courage was not very eaonable: Good mother (anwered Silviana) what I did was not o much out of eaon as you imagine; for conider what abundance of reaon I have to fear: Childerick, eeks my ruine, and perhaps at this very hour is lying in ambuh for me, or ele ending after me. Childerick (replied the good old woman) hath now other matters in his head; and let him ue what endeavours to get you he can, I believe
it is out of his power; this habit does o diguie you, that you can never be known, and therefore, I ay, you were too much tartled at the arrival of thee Cavaliers, and hould have truted more to your diguie then your valour. Alas, replied Silviana, you do not know what an exaperated pirit may do; and I am in uch a great ditrut, that I think fidelity it elf may deceive me: there is nothing o cruel, but I have reaon to expect it from the malice of Childerick, I believe that Tyrant will put Andreneck to uch torments, as will force him to confee the truth, and know from him, what the boy which was our guide did communicate unto him of our deigne. For heavens ake, Madam (aid the woman) do not entertain any uch thoughts, but believe that he will ooner perih then do any thing which hall be prejudicial unto you or Andrimartes: Good woman (aid Silviana) when we feel no pain, we are perwaded the mot cruel torments are not able to force any ecret from us, but in the extremity of pain, it is a mot hard matter to continue contant; and therefore imagining that Childerick will put him to the rack, I am afraid he will confee that which I would not have him dicover unto any.

With uch or uch like dicoure as this, they beguiled the length of the way, and Silviana, who longed with abundance of impatiency, for a ight of her dear Andrimartes, he imagined every man that appeared to be him: yet for all her eager deire of it, he found her elf mitaken, and all that journey could not hear any news of him. The wife of Andreneck did comfort her as well as he could, and till the young man that guided them, affirmed that Andrimartes could not come any other way but this which they went: after this ort he came to Gandelu, where indeed he lay, but did not ret; for her eager deire of departing, did invite to rie before Aurora; and as oon as he was on horeback he took the way of Coucye.

I, hould tyer you, Madam, if I hould relate unto you all the thoughts which afflicted her during her voyage: for he was in a perpetual retlenee; and from the time he firt fancied that Andrimartes had taken ome other way, he was almot quite deperate; but all thee fears were nothing in comparion of that which he apprehended, that Childerick had procured ome to be his aainates: when this came into her fancy he changed colour, afterwards would igh, and latly, her eyes guh out with tears: ah mother (would he ay unto the wife of Andreneck) I am afraid all our labour in this journey is but lot. The good woman who wondered at this change, why (aid he) have you that opinion? becaue I fear (anwered Silviana) that yonder Barbarian hath murdered Andrimartes. Good God, aid the woman, why ay you o? the very upition of uch a thing makes me to tremble: for God ake do not imagine any uch thing can be, for uch misfortunes eldome happen, but I ue to have ome preages of it beforehand: The likelyhood of it, replied Silviana, makes me fear it; for reckon from the time of his departure, and judge whether he hould not be returned before this. Andrenecks wife began to think with her elf, and to count the dayes upon her fingers; truly, aid he, according to my weak judgement, let him make what hat he could, he could not be returned thus far before this time: the boy who guided them, cating up his account alo; aure your elf, Madam (aid he upon a udden) the woman is in the right; for her account and mine do perfectly agree.

Upon this they came to the top of a little hill, which urveying all the plain beyond it, permitted Silviana to pie ome horemen afar off, who came in great hat towards them; at the firt he could not ditinguih neither the perons nor the number; but hewing them unto Andrenecks wife, Mother (aid he) do you not perceive ome men coming towards us? I have a conceit that it is Andrimartes: The good old woman whoe ight was omthing dim, I do not ee any uch, anwered he; but if it prove Andrimartes, as I pray heaven it may, what then will you do? I hall even die, anwered Silviana, with excee of joy: No, no, replied he, you had better fight with him, or at the leat defie him, as you did yeterday the Cavaliers. Alas, anwered he, it is long ince he overcame me; in aying o, he fixed her eyes till upon the men which he aw, and as oon as ever
he perceived one with a plume of white feathers in his hat, he clapped her hands together: O mother aid he, yonder is Andrimartes, I know him both by his feather and his habit. Madam (anwered the woman) if it be he, I would advie you keep your elf till to your diguie, and try if he will know us: Doubtlee, replied Silviana, he will know us; for his ervant is not diguied as we are: As for that, replied the woman, there is a remedy, for he may hide himelf until we call him. Upon this, Silviana commanded the young man to tand behind a tree, which he did accordingly; but Silviana, who in the excee of her joyes minded not what he did, he never heeded her bridle, and her hore being almot tired, did tumble o downright, that Cephindres, who was none of the bet horemen, did fall three or four lengths before the hore: This fall did much harm in the preence of her husband; but he got up preently, and told the good woman, that all the harm he had was a little hurt upon her noe; which, indeed, did fall o againt the ground, that blood guhed out.

Andrimartes was already o near, that he aw Cephindres fall, and therefore to help him he galopped as fat as he could, and came unto him jut as he was got up upon his feet; and becaue Silviana did preently take out her handkerchief, and held it unto her noe to receive the blood, Andrimartes could not poibly know her; yet thinking himelf obliged by the laws of civility to ay omething to him, Sir, aid he, I made all the hate that poibly I could to help you, but now I ee you do not tand in any need of my ervice: Silviana bluhed when he heard him peak, and could hardly forbear revealing her elf; yet deiring to make ome port in this diguie, Sir, anwered he, and altered her voice, your intention was the ame, and does infinitly oblige me in aying o, he looked upon him with the ame eyes which had long ince inflamed him, and Andrimartes oberving ome glances, which formerly made him enible of loves power, he had a confued fancy, that he had formerly een that Cavalier in ome other place; and as he was ready to peak unto her, he oberved that her hore was broke looe, and ran up and down the fields; and therefore he commanded thoe that waited upon him to run after the hore, and bring him back: In the interim he alighted from his hore, and entreated this unknown Cavalier to it down upon the point of a rock which was in the high way; which Silviana did not refue, for indeed he was neceitated unto it; and Andrimartes knowing the name of Cephindres, he beeeched her to tell him what news was tirring in the world.

Silviana being reolved to perplex him as much as he could, to make him think the meeting with her more weet: The news (anwered he) which I do know, will fill you fuller of horrour then delight when you hear it; for being (as I uppoe you are) a Frank by Nation, as I my elf am, it is impoible but you mut needs abhor to hear of o many, and o great crimes in a Monarch, who may boat that he has the mot glorious Empire in the Univere under his government: yet ince your civility would tax me with a crime if I did diobey you, I will tell you, that Childerick has tained his honour, by committing the mot foulet and wicked act, that ever any Tyrant was guilty of. Andrimartes trembled at this dicoure which Silviana perceived, and continued thus: His impiety is o high, that it has emboldned him to dihonour a woman, whoe merit and virtue was as high as her beauty; and it is probable that you having been at Court have een her with eyes of admiration; for Silviana (that's her name) was never looked upon by any eye, but he won the heart of him that owned it. At the name of Silviana, Andrimartes was dah'd quite out of countenance, and riing up as if he were tranported: O Heavens (aid he in a loud voice) has that barbarous Tyrant atisfied his brutih fury? has he triumphed over the virtue of Silviana, and the honour of Andrimartes? Indeed, replied Silviana, he did attempt it, but the reitance of that young woman, did frutrate the deign of that Luxurious Tyrant; and her virtue made her have recoure unto a remedy, which was no lee neceary then violent.

The lat words did a little calme the pirit of the Cavalier, and therefore addreing himelf unto Cephindres, who kept her handkerchief till before her face:
Cavalier (aid he unto her) I beeech you relate unto me the particulars of this paage, and uffer not my oul any longer to languih in this inquietude wherein it is: why? aid the pretended Cephindres, have you any concernment in the accident? So great (anwered the Cavalier) that Andrimartes himelf has not a greater interet in it then I have. Then (aid Silviana) I will certainly make the relation of it unto you; and though I do not think you can apply any remedy unto it, yet I will give you the relation, that you may afterwards behave your elf according to your bet dicretion: upon this Andrimartes took his handkerchief out of his pocket, and laying it upon his hand, he leaned his head thereon, and Silviana eeing him look down with a drooping countenance, he grew the more bold, and taking away hers which he held before her noe, he purued on her dicoure thus.

Were I but acquainted with the uccee which accompanied the love of Andrimartes and Silviana, I hould take more delight in making a relation thereof unto you; and you alo would be glad, I believe, to hear it; but ince I am ignorant in the tory of their lives, and know nothing but what has hapned ince their marriage, I mut only tell you, that as oon as ever they came to reap the fruit of all their labours and pains, Childerick under a faigned and imaginary pretence, began to diturb that tranquility which they were to enjoy: and becaue the love of that Prince unto Silviana, had no legal foundation, he did not keep within compae of dicretion, but on the contrary, it made him attempt to corrupt or to force her. He ent therefore Andrimartes unto the Queen Methina, to the end, that in his abence he might have the better opportunity to execrate his pernicious intention; and as oon as ever that Cavalier was gone, he took his time o, as he came unto Silvianas houe when none was with her but an old woman, who was he from whom the whole truth was known.

You may eaily imagine how much Silviana was atonihed when he aw Childerick enter; yet he did et as good a countenance upon her fears and dipleaure as he could, and coming unto him with a look far different from the thoughts of her heart, he would have aid omething unto him; but Childerick preventing her, fell down upon his knees, and taking her hand offered to kie it: at which Silviana was o urprized, that he pulled it away from him: upon this the Prince roe up, and itting down upon a eat, he forced this young woman to it down by him; and there, after ome amorous looks, accompanied with a hundred ighs; Come, come, fair Silviana (aid he unto her in a udden rapture) why hould you deny me that favour which Andrimantes hath already obtained obtained? Since time and opportunity allows it, why hould we not enjoy that pleaure which I eteem the weetet of all my life: Mitrut not my dicretion, night it elf hall not be o ilent and ecret as I hall be. At thee words Silvania bluh'd, and being in uch a tate, as without a in againt her duty, he could not hear uch dicoure from any mouth, but that of her dear Andrimartes: Sir (aid he unto him very boldly) I do very well know the duty that I do ow unto my husband, and though I do not doubt of your dicretion, yet let me tell you, that you do but in vain attempt to make me guilty of an act, which the eye of heaven will mot everely punih. Silviana aid omething ele which the Prince did hearken unto with a very impatient eare; but Silviana (aid he unto her) why do you perit o obtinately in a refual? to preerve that (anwered he) which I will never loe but with my life: perhaps you may be deceived, replied he, for you are not trong enough to reit my will; and believe it, if you continue in your denial, you will force me to ue that violence which will overcome your cruelty.

In aying o, he took hold upon one of her arms, and would have eized upon the other, but Silviana pulled it away, and catching hold of the Princes hair: hold off Sir, cryed he out, or ele you will force me to go beyond the limits of that repect which I ow unto your birth. Childerick, who would not any longer defer the execution of his wicked intention, he called out for ome men who came with him for that end, who opening the door, and eizing upon Silviana, would have thrown her upon the bed. She who aw that all reitance was in vain, did
at that intant fix upon a mot trange reolution, and promied Childerick the atisfaction of his deires, o he would dimie thoe men: Childerick flattering himelf with this weet promie, did command them to withdraw, and they obeying, Silv • ana went nearer the Prince, and deired him to let her put off ome of her clothes in her cloet; to which the Prince conenting, Silviana put off her gown, and all her rich ornaments: afterwards coming out again, all undret, and her brets and arms almot all naked, and Childerick eeing her in this amorous equipage, he was infinitely ravihed; and being tranported with joyes, in hope to enjoy uch a beauty, he roe up and offered to embrace her; but he pulling out a Poniard which he had prepared: Stay (aid he) upon pain of your life, and hearken unto me: upon this command, the Prince topt upon a udden, not knowing for what deigne he brought thoe arms; and then he aid unto him, ee here, thou cruel Tyrant, this is the remedy againt thy luxurious fury: This, this, hall put an end unto my dayes and thy impudent lut; this hall help me to quench thy fire with my blood, ince all my tears were not able to do it. Turn now thy lutful love into an honet compaion, and let not this corps of mine, when it is dead, be poluted with one of thy looks: Andrimartes will revenge himelf upon thee; and if the gods will uffer the truth of this action to appear unto the eyes of the world, they will know that I had rather die then in againt heaven or him; and thou halt ee that it is an eaier matter to triumph over my life, then my honour. Hereupon, this fair one did give her elf two uch great blows upon a vein, that all he could do before he died, was to utter thee two words, adieu Andrimartes.

Silviana could not chue but to laugh to her elf, as he related this lat accident; but it was not long before he repented of her mirth, for Andrimartes lifting up his eyes, and looking upon Cephindres: Do you then aure me (aid he adly unto her) that Silviana is not alive? She is not alive (anwered Silviana) unlee he live in you: in aying o he put her handkercheif before her face; and the Cavalier, who heard that Silviana did not live unlee in him, alas (aid he) then the life that he has will be my death: Upon this he topt, and put his handkerchief to his eyes; afterwards upon a udden he aid, yet my misfortune is not without a remedy: for as my dearet Silviana could dy becaue he would not offend me, I can do the ame to follow her; and you Cavalier (aid he and looked upon Cephindres with an eye of rapture) as you have been an eye witnee of Silviana's courage, o hall you be of my depair: In aying o he laid his hand upon his word, and drawing it out of the cabbard, Silviana cloed with him, and eizing upon his arm, did all he could to keep him from running it into his body; yet all her trength had not erved, if the wife of Andreneck had not alo fallen upon him, and he triving with them both, they all three fell to the ground together,

•• oe that were in puruit of Silvianas hore returned back; and eeing their <>
• own with a naked word in his hand, triving againt two men, they <…> that their intention was to murder him: They galloped up therefore as <…>
• hey could, and the foremot of them alighting from his hore; ah ye villa •• cryed he out, ye hall never execute your wicked intention: As he aid o, he r • n with his word drawn againt Silviana, and had run her through, if the ervant of Andrimartes, who was hid behind a tree, had not at the ame time come in, and cryed out that it was Silviana: Silviana, hearing her elf named, did preently turn her head about, and eeing what danger he was in, did think ome michief might enue, if he continued her diguie any longer. Deiring therefore to give her dear Andrimartes that contentment which he had concealed from him Andrimartes, aid he, is it poible you hould not know the face of your Silviana? Do you recompence the pains I have taken in eeking after you, with oblivion in lieu of love? Upon this An • rimartes looked eriouly upon her, and eeing nothing before her face which might hinder him from knowing her, he came out of that errour into which Silviana had put him; and knowing both his ervant and the wife of Andreneck: Fie, fie, aid he, and took Silviana in his arms, what crime have I committed, that you hould punih me with the invention
of uch ad news? Silviana not able to anwer him any other way but with kies, it was long before he poke one word: at lat, making her ex known better by her tears then her habit, he gave him a particular accompt of all that paed ince his departure.

Andrimartes then knowing in earnet how far the inolency of Childerick was grown, he intended to retire peedily into Gaul Armorique, and to pare no pains in the drawing a memorable revenge from this libidinous Tyrant; yet conceiving it a kind of ingratitude to depart, before he had returned thanks unto the Queen Methina, for the favours he had hewed unto Silviana and him, he reolved to pae by her: o as taking hore, they took that way from whence Andrimartes already came.

But, Madam, humane intentions do often meet with many rubbs before they arrive at their accomplihment; and the equel of this dicoure will let you know, that Fortune does often caue us to find a hipwrack, where we thought to find a afe harbour.

Andrimartes was not gone above half the way to Rhemoi, when, let the chorching heat of the Sun hould be offenive unto Silviana, he deired her to alight and ret her elf under a hade of willows, untill the heat was over: She, who had no will but to pleae him did preently alight, and the Cavalier doing the ame, they left their hores and went into a large meadow which was near the high way: there they found two rows of little trees, which art had planted in a traight line; between which was a pleaant walk, and becaue the place eemed very delightful unto them, they reolved not to tir from thence, until the Sun, and the flames of their love, were a little cooled and abated of their violence; yet as he began to uck the weet of thoe which were upon Silvianas lips, he was, notwithtanding the ravihment of his oul, contrained to retire, by reaon ome words which he heard clahing very near them: he had no ooner turned his head, but he epied in the next meadow two men with words drawn, and triving withal their trength to take away the lives of each other: and becaue he thought he could not do a better office then to part them, he paed through the willows, and run with his word drawn towards them, intending to prevent their Combate from becomming a Tragedy; but he, of the Combatants, who thought himelf mot injured, thirting for revenge, he no ooner aw Andrimartes coming, but he reolved preently either to dy or to vanquih; and therefore he fell mot deperately upon his enemy, and made uch a lucky pas, as he ran his word through his bod, which wound proved mortal: after this, he preently ecaped; and all that Andrimartes could do, was to come time enough to hold up the corps of the wounded Combatant, who beginning to tagger, and not able to utain himelf, he fell into the arms of this Cavalier, and in a dying tone, aid unto him: Know Cavalier, whooever you are, that I am mot jutly punihed; my vanquiher hath earned a jut revenge for an injury, which he could not put up without the los of his reputation: whilt he was aying o, Silviana, who followed Andrimantes, came unto him, and tore her handkerchief to top the wounds of the man; but he finding himelf out of all hopes to live, lifting up his eyes to heaven, and afterwards fixing them upon Andrimartes: Alas, alas, aid he (with a feeble and ighing voice) your courteie in helping me is in vain, I know my death to be inevitable; yet that this benefit may not altogether be uelee, let it erve for a dicharge of him that has lain me, whom I do pardon as freely, as I wih he would forget the offence formerly he received from me: upon this he topt, and loing both his peech and his life, he remained cold in the arms of Andrimartes, who was exceedingly troubled at the accident; but ince there was no remedy, he took up his word which he cat upon the ground, to be the more fit for helping the wounded man: afterwards preenting his hand unto his dear Silviana, they returned to their hores, and went on their journey.

They were not gone above three or fovr hundred paces, but they met a great number of hormen, who eeing Andrimartes and Silviana tained with blood in everal places they began to murmure amongt themelves: afterwards dividing themelves, ome followed within ight of Andrimartes, and others went on to
ee whether they could hear any news of that misfortune which they upected omething: As oon as they found the body of Cl • ioderus (for that was the name of him that was lain) ome galloped as fat as they could to acquaint thoe that followed Andrimartes: and afterwards all together, eized upon him, Silviana, and all their company, before they could o much as defend themelves: Judge, Madam, how much they were amazed, when they aw themelves thus treated; epecially when an old man, who was hardly able to peak for anger, addreing himelf unto Andrimartes: Perhap, murderer (aid he unto him) thou thinket the day to be as black as thy crime, and that thou cant hide the infamy wherewith thou art branded for murdering my on; but the gods have uffered it to be dicovered, and before two dayes be expired thou halt uffer what the Laws have ordained againt thee and thy Complices.

p.U: eeing himelf upected for a murder of which he was a witnes, and not an actour; and thinking he was more obliged to anwer unto the injury of the old man, then to plead in behalf of his innocency, alo relating the the action which he had een, he looked upon him with an eye nothing like a guilty peron, and aid unto him, I am neither guilty of any black actions, nor any murder of thy on; but my actions are irreproachable, and will help me to give the ly unto any that dare upect me of any perfidie: The old man was o enraged at this anwer, that he with the ame word which he took from Andrimartes, had run him through, if one of his ervants had not fortunately tayed his arm, and told him that it was too much for a prioner to die by his hand, but fitter to perih by that of a hangman: this conideration tayed the hand of the hand of the old man. But Silviana eeing him o near death, was o frighted, that he knew not what he did; and her eyes twinkling, he began to tagger, and doubtlee had fallen, if ome that tood by her had not taken her by the arm, and held her up as long as her wound continued: yet they not knowing the true caue of her orrows, they thought it had been only remore of concience for the crime which they thought he had committed. The wife of Andreneck alo looked as pale as death, and amidt her ighs and tears, letting the word Madam ometimes ecape her tongue, he caued thoe that looked upon her to think that fear of punihment had already ditracted.

div.p: In this manner they carried them into the Town of Fime, which is not far from the City of Rhemois, and there they hut up in a mot naty prion, where the Sun was ahamed ever to hine. I cannot expree, Madam, the orrows of Silviana and Andrimartes for their captivity: I will therefore only tell you how they got out.

He who killed Cloiodorus, had no ooner given him his deaths wound, but he fled away as I told you before; and getting into the next Town, he changed his habit with the firt Shepherd that he met, hoping to get unto his own houe by the help of this diguie; yet hearing in the beginning of the night, that the Cavalier who came into the meadow to part them, was eized upon as guilty of the fact, he altered his mind, and reolved to die, rather then let the innocence of Andrimartes uffer for the murder which he only had committed. In order to the effecting of this reolution, he wended his way towards that City, and there reting himelf as long as the night lated, he came unto the Pallace of the Queen Methina, as he was going unto the Temple to offer a Sacrifice in the behalf of Childerick. As oon as be perceived her he tepped forward, and hit upon his opportunity o handomly, that he had cat himelf at her feet, before any came to give him the top: The Queen, who is the weetet Princee that evere bore a Scepter, did preently tand till, and cating her eye upon this Shepherd, did ask him what he would have? Madam (anwered the tranger) I do upon my humble knees, mot earnetly beeech your Majety to grant unto me my life, and to hear thoe reaons which perhaps will move your clemency not to deny it: what have you committed (aid the Queen) that does deerve death? my crime is (replied the tranger) that becaue I could not live after the loe of my honour, I have taken away the life of a man, that would have taken it from me. How? replied the Queen and miled, are the Laws of honour as inviolable amongt Shepherds
as amongt Courtiers? This habit, Madam, which you ee me wear (aid he) is not utable unto my quality; but I did aume it only as a means to bring me in afety unto your preence. The Queen apprehending ome mytery in the matter, which deerved better examination: Well (aid he) at my return from the Temple, I will hear your reaons and do you Jutice. In aying o he went on, and the tranger was no ooner rien up, but he was compaed about with a great number of Cavaliers, who would not leave him until they knew his adventure. The Sacrifice being ended, the tranger was conducted into the Pallace, and from thence into the Queens chamber, who no ooner commanded him to peak, but he faithfully related the offence which he had received from Cleiodorus: He told her how in Lions they had both been rivals in the ervice of a great beauty, and how Cleiodorus, prompted unto it by the motions of his jealouie, was reolved to ruine his reputation In order unto this, Cleiodorus had aembled many of his friends together, and meeting him as he was ingle by himelf, he truck him three times with a batinado, before he could have time to defend himelf: afterwards all his friends fell upon him at once, and ued him o ill, that they left him for dead in the treet: after this he related how he recovered, and how the flight of Cleiodorus made him to eek him out in another Countrey, where having found him, he challenged him the field, where he did let out o much of his blood, as to wah off the dihonour that had tained his reputation. But Madam (continued he) ince this, has hapned an accident, which doth extreamly perplex me: Two Cavaliers who came to part Cleiodorus and me, are, as I am informed, seized upon as culpable of this homicide: and becaue they are put into a prion in Fimes, I am afraid their innocence will not ufficiently appear, unlee my confeion do clear it: and therefore though I could have paed away without being either taken or known, yet I reolved to ubmit my elf unto the mercy of your Majety, and do mot humbly beeech you to tay all violent proceedings againt thoe innocent prioners.

Thus ended the tranger; and the Queen being inclinable to hew him favour, did for everal coniderations promie him a pardon, upon condition he could verifle all that he had aid to be true, and at that very intant commanded to end unto Fime, and to bring before her thoe perons whom the father of Cleiodorus had taken prioners. This command was executed with o much diligence that Andrimartes and Silviana were the very ame day conducted unto the Pallace; and as oon as ever the Queen aw Andrimartes, he entertained him with uch extraordinary Carrees, that the father of Cleiodorus was atonihed; yet being extreamly enible of the loe of his on, he cat himelf at the feet of Methina, and demanded jutice againt the Cavalier whom he upected to be the Aainate of his on. But the Queen cauing them to enter into her cloet, did ue uch arguments unto the old man, in jutification of Andrimartes, that he was quite convinced of the bad opinion which he entertained of him. The Father of Cleiodorus was no ooner atisfied, but Andrimartes undertanding from the Queen what the tranger had done, he began to relate the uccee of the Combate between him and Cleiodorus, and did o faithfully report the lat words of that dying man, that after the example of the on, the father was forced to pardon the Conquerour.

This accident was the buinee of the Court, until it began to be late, and the Queen dimiing the father of Cleiodorus, he was no ooner alone with Andrimantes, but the memory of the misfortune, or rather the debauchery of Childerick did caue her to fall into a tream of tears. Andrimartes did exceedingly pity her; and notwithtanding the great caue he had to be revenged of Childerick, he was even forced to grant unto the tears and the prayers of the Queen, that pardon which he begged for her on. After this he enquired where Silviana was; unto which Andrimartes anwered, that he heard he was returned into Gaul Armorique, and that he had ent her brother to give him an accompt of what had paed. The Queen commanded preently that he hould enter, and as oon as ever Silviana did obeyance unto her, truly (aid he unto Andrimartes) he is the handomet young man that ever I aw, and has many of thoe features
which makes his iter o much admired: when Silviana heard the Queen ay o, he bluh'd, which the Princee perceiving; he has not yet (aid he unto Adrimartes in a low voice) well tated the aire of the Court: for I ee he is a little bahful, and bluhes when one looks upon him. But Cavaller (continued he and addreed her elf unto Silviana) what good news can you tell us of your Siter?

At this Silviana cat her eye upon Andrimartes, as if he had aid anwer for me; which the Cavalier undertanding and not being willing to delude the Queen any longer: the mot certain news (aid he) that he can give you, Madam, is, that he does preent her elf unto you in that habit wherein now you ee her, and which he is forced to wear for a afety of her elf, from the puruance and Tyranny of Childerick: In aying o, he took Silviana by the hand, who cating her elf at the Queens feet, did receive from that Princee all the Carrees and favours which he could expect amidt that diorder and affliction, which the inolence of her on had brought upon her. After this, he told her what tetimonies he had received of Childericks repentance, and what had paed within a few dayes: at which Silviana was exceedingly joyed. Yet not conceiving that the life of Andrimartes could be afe any where, but in thoe Territories where Sem • on had made him Lord, he beeeched the Queen to let them depart the next morning, which being condecended unto, Silviana and Andrimartes received the Queens commands; and being retired, Methina ent them a great abundance of clothes and jewels for Silviana; and for Andrimartes a coach with ix hores, the finet that ever eye beheld, Thus they departed, and Fortune being now weary with diturbing their contentments, he permitted them to arrive at the place where they deired, without any diaterous encounter. Some few hours before their departure, Andrimartes hearing that I was in the Pallace, retained there by my wounds, he was pleaed to honour me with a viit, and there, after he undertood from me all the particulars of the Combate wherein I had been wounded, he related unto me all that you have heard.

Within a few dayes after I found my elf in ome ort recovered; o as my Chirurgeon telling me that I might venture to travel without any danger; I went to kie the Queens hand, and becaue he was infinitly deirous that Childerick hould be reetablihed, he olicited me not to tir from Guyemants until it was effected: I told her plainly, that it was a buinee which required a long time, ince a multitude of people are like unto pirits, eaily raied, but very hard to be laid again: and yet he had reaon to hope well, ince Guyemant had promied the utmot of his ervice, and that I thought time would bring it to pae: Then he asked me, if I knew upon what grounds Guyemant intended to tranact; and I who was deirous to give her all the conolation I could, I told her in hort what Guyemant had communicated unto me, which was, that he hoped to make Gilon, who was of a mot covetous dipoition, to loaden the people with uch abundance of Subidies, Taxes, and Impots, under a pretence of keeping them under, and within their duty, that thereby he would render all the nobility his enemies; and o by this action render him odious to all the world: That afterwards he would take his time o well amidt thee diorders, as he would remontrate unto the people how Tyrannical the government of Gilon was above that of Childerick, and perhaps hould have uch an influence upon them, as to make them revolt againt Gilon, and call back their former King. The Princee eemed to hope well in this deign, and permitting me to depart, I returned unto Guyemant in Paris, who finding my tay there to no great purpoe, he conented that I hould depart with thoe forces which Clidemant and I had: o as I did depart in a reolution to dimie them at Moulins; but meeting with Flurial, and receiving your Letter, I retained them on to imploy them in your ervice.

Thus Lindamor ended the dicoure which Amais deired to hear, and it being omething late, every one prepared themelves for leep: Amais accompanied them to their everal chambers; and having left it unto Galathea, to wait upon Roanira and the ret of the Ladies into their lodgings, he beeeched them all to command freely any thing that was within the compae of her power, and
confeed that he owed all he had in the world unto their courages and affections.

As oon as day dawned, Ligonias departed, and Atrea waked: That fair one lay that night in the houe of Adamas, becaue he was not able, without extream orrow to her elf, to be one minute out of the preene of her dear Alexis; and though there was a partition between her chamber and Celadons, yet it was abundance of conolation unto her to think that he was not far off him & that nothing but the god of leep was able to part them; She no ooner opened her eyes, but being in abundance of impatience to ee her Mitree, he dreed her elf withall the hat he could, and went into the chamber of Celadon, and made as little noie as poible.

The Shepherd, who was not aleep, oberved the warinee of Atrea, and counterf • ited himelf till aleep, that he might the better ee the motions of her oul: He aw then the Shepherdee kneel down by his bed ide, and afterwards did kie him two or three times, and igh very loud: at lat he aid, alas, alas, why is it not permitted me to give thee kies unto him, whoe Image you do repreent unto me? Although thee be more hot and more moit, yet are they not lee innocent and harmlee: upon this he was ilent, and then began again with a deep igh, aying, but ince I cannot kie Celadon, yet I will adore this face in memory of him: in aying o, he kit him again, and dwelt o long upon the lips of the Shepherd, that he being ravihed with delight, he could not chue but igh and open his eyes: which Atrea perceiving, O fairet Mitree (aid he) I mot humbly beeech you pardon my rude indicretion in waking you. Then Celadon, to make it the better, believed that he was aleep, I give you mot hearty thanks, dear ervant (aid he unto her) that you would take o much pains as to viit me: I beeech you tell me (continued he) how long it is ince you firt came? but a little while (anwered Atrea) and had only o much time as to kie you twice: It was very well (anwered Celadon) love was my frien • in it, and knew that your favours are o pleaing unto me, that I am contented with them either in reality or in a dream; but dear ervant (continued Alexis) and caued Atrea to it down upon her bed ide) what is the reaon of your being o early, for I know by my eyes that it is not very late? O my fairet, Mitree, replied Astrea, I need no other alarm to waken me, but my own thoughts, which fill me o full of inquietudes, as I do very believe, that unlee you do give a remedy unto them, they will ditract my wits: O heavens (aid Alexis and ighed) why do you expect any remedy from me, who expects the ame from you? from me? (aid the Shepherdee and was a little atonihed) what can you expect from me? To contrive it o (anwered Celadon) that we may be eternally ineparable: May heaven for ever hate me (aid Atrea) if that that be not my chiefet deire; but, Mitree, that does depend more upon you then me: No, no, (aid Celadon) it is your conent only that is requiite and neceary for the accomplihment of this deire. I do mot freely conent unto it (aid Atrea) and do mot earnetly beeech heaven there may be no other obtacle but my conent: It is very well, replied the Shepherd, there wants nothing but one thing, without which this happinee will not be obtained. O heavens! aid Atrea, I beeech you tell me quickly what it is, for I wear it mut be an abolute impoibility, if to obtain this happinee, I do not do it. It is nothing, all that you need do (replied the uppoed Druide) is to command me that — upon this word a colour came into her countenance, and her peech falling her, the Shepherdee might well imagine that ome trange accident or other had befallen her: at which being exceedingly troubled; Mitree (aid he unto her) I perceive you are not well, will you be pleaed to take any thing? I need not take any thing (anwered Alexis) but only a little courage: In aying o, Adamas entred into the room, which pleaed Celadon very well, who plainly aw, that had he not come, he could never have come off in this dicoure, without declaring part of his crime: his joy at it appeared preently in his face, which Atrea perceiving, father (aid he unto Adamas) you are the bet Phyician in the world, for your very preence can cure dieaes Thee words did a little trouble the Druide, and
going a little nearer Celadon to enquire the truth, the Shepherd told him in a low voice, the danger from which his arrival had recued him. But Adamas conceiving tha the conveniency of the place, and the dipoition of the perons, did afford an opportunity of undeceiving Atrea, he reolved to do that which Celadon durt not, and to do it before the Shepherd could hinder him; therefore he did not peak unto him, but cauing Atrea to it down in the place where he was, and itting down by her, he held this dicoure.

I do believe Astrea, that you know I love you, and has oberved in all my actions, a more particular good will unto you then unto many other perons whom I am obliged to eteem; and therefore I am very confident, that you will take the councel that I hall give you in good part, and not doubting but I hall have as great a care of your welfare as my own, you will apply what I hall ay unto you to your bet advantage: Now, Atrea, you mut know that this Druide, whom you ee before you, and paes under the notion of your Mitree, yet her greatet glory is to obey you, and what features oever you find in her face, he is the ame— then he was going to pronounce Celadon when he aw Diana and Phillis enter, who coming from the houe of Clindor, upon a viit unto Atrea, did imagine he would be in the chamber of Alexis, ince they did not find her in the place where he was was wont to lie. As oon as Adamas pied them, he took Astrea by the hand, and preing it a little, Sweet heart (aid he unto her in a low voice) that which I did intend to communicate unto you, mut not have o many witnees, and therefore I will defer it until another time: In the mean time, entertain your companions, whilt I advertie Alexis in all things which he mut do to carry you with her unto Carnutes, whither you have o great a deire to follow her.

Atrea upon this went to meet the two fair Shepherdee, who were come already very near her, and as oon as they had aluted Adamas, and the uppoed Druide, they went and ate down in one of the corners of the Chamber, where Atrea, with a face of extraordinary contentment, poke to them in thee terms.

The common Proverb (my companions) is very true, which ayes that a good Fortune as well as a bad one, never comes alone by it elf. Within thee two dayes I was overwhelmed with a multitude of mieries, and now ince the deliverance of Amais and our elves, every minute affosds me a freh ubject of delight.

You need not tell us any more of your contentment (anwered Diana) for we find it in your face; and I wear unto you (aid Atrea) it is lee in my face then my heart: but Siter (aid Phillis) I beeech you tell us from whence proceeds this great joy? From ome hopes (anwered he) that Alexis will carry me away with her; O Siter (aid Diana) you are extreamly cruel, in threatning us with a eparation; and I cannot chue but wonder you hould take delight in a thing which perhaps will kill us with grief: I do indeed believe, aid Astrea, that you a little lament my departure, but I hope your orrows will not be o great, but that Silvander and Licidas will chear you up again in a few dayes.

To tell you ingeniouly my mind (aid Phillis) were I to chue whether I might live alwayes with Licidas or with you, I hould certainly prefer the company of my Shepherd before yours; and let it be poken only amongt our elves, I believe Diana has more wit, then not to be of my opinion; but if it were poible for me to enjoy both your companies, I could deire no greater happinee. You mean (anwered Atrea) that your contentment would be compleat, as mine would be, if heaven would be o kind as to let me alo enjoy the company of Celadon and you: But ince the gods, by the death of that Shepherd, has denied me this felicity, it is but requiite you hare with me in my misfortune, and uffer in the loe of a Siter, as I do in the loe of a Lover. I hall be more enible of the loe of you, aid Diana, then the loe of all men living; and though I do highly honour Silvander, yet I will not except him: O tay (aid Atrea, and laid her hand upon her mouth) you ought to love that Shepherd above all, and though you hould render your affection equal unto his, yet you would not do more then is due unto his merit. Let us talk no more on't (aid Phillis) for Siter
I hope you will not leave us, and there needs no more to end me out of the world, then to deprive us of your company.

With uch weet dicoure as this, Atrea prepared the pirits of all thee fair ones, not to take her eparation from them over adly. Adamas alo in the mean while prepared Celadon, not any longer to oppoe his deire of making himelf known unto his Shepherdee; and becaue this poor Lover oberved how they had been interrupted; certainly Father (aid he unto him) there is a kind of fatality oppoite unto your deign; far had not Diana and Phillis entred, I know not what would have become of this diguie which we have ued. Certainly (aid the Druide) the gods do ometimes teach us what their will is by trivial things, as well as by great ones; and I will with you believe, that it is not their pleaure, Atrea hould here have the honour of knowing her Shepherd: And therefore, I will hortly take my leave of Amais, ince now he has no need of my ervice; and I will carry all the Shepherds and Shepherdees to my houe, where we will with more leaure advie upon the bet expedients, how to make you happy in the enjoyment of Atrea. Celadon tood a while without any reply; and Adamas asking the reaon of his ilence: Father (anwered he with a great igh) if we have any ecret foreight of things that are to happen unto us, I do preage very ad accidents that are to befall me by the knowledge which this Shepherdee hall have of me: you have entertained that fear o long (replied the Druide) that now it is become a belief, and your wit is too ingenious in afflicting your elf. You do now take it as a thing infallible; but know that my opinion is quite contrary unto yours, and I dare promie you all imaginable contentment in that coure: whether the event prove good or bad (aid Celadon) I am however infinitely obliged unto your indulgent care of me, and I wih my own welfare as much for your contentment as for my own: Dipoe therefore of me as you pleae Sir; and if ever I diobey the leat of your commands, let me be branded with the ignominy of the mot ungrateful Shepherd that ever lived. Adamas infinitly atisfied with Celadons anwer: Son, aid he unto him, ince you are reolved to trut your elf unto my care and ubmit unto my will, if you do not enjoy your Mitree, the fault hall be only mine: In aying o, he kied his cheek, and riing up, he bad adieu unto all the fair ones, and afterwards went unto Amais.

He was no ooner out of the chamber, but Atrea being extreamly impatient to know, what it was the Druide intended to ay unto her, he went unto the bed ide of Alexis, and beeeched her to give her that atisfaction: but Celadon in lieu of telling her truly, did put her off with o many other things, that he could not undertand any thing of it. Diana and Phillis came alo to her beds ide, and almot at the very ame time when Leonide entred, who doubting that Celadon durt not rie before them, he carried them into another chamber till he had dreed himelf.

Adamas in the interim was come unto the Nymph, and intending to ask leave to return, as oon as he could peak unto her, he knew o well how to et forth an urgent neceity of returning unto his houe, that he conented thereunto, upon condition he would return again with in a few dayes: which the Druide promiing, he humbly thanked her, and went away without taking his leave of Galathea, let he hould be deirous of eeing Alexis, or enquire of Celadon: o he came unto the houe of Clindor, where Atrea, Alexis, Phillis, and Diana, already were, and with them all the ret of the Shepherds and Shepherdees: having therefore propounded his intention of carrying them back, he found them o impatiently deirous of eeing their flocks again, that they were all very willing to depart at that very intant: Clindor only was very orry to part o oon with o much good company; yet eeing no remedy, be took Licidas aide, and after he had deired him to love Leontidas his on, with the ame affection which wont to be betwixt Al • yppes and him, he made him promie him above a hundred times to return again, and bring with him the ame perons that were now to depart. After this, he embraced Phocion, and though he could hardly walk by reaon of his great age, yet he would not bid adieu unto any of the Shepherds or Shepherdees in his
own houe, but would needs wait upon them out of the Town, where he received all their thanks, and after a ad departure, and looking after them as far as he could ee, he retired by the help of Leonti • as, who led him by the arm unto his own houe again.

All this great troop, to whom was added the brothers of Circinea, Palanice, and Florice, were not long before they arrived at the houe of Adamas, who intending to receive them very well, did carry them into a very noble room, where they found a collation ready: After which, carrying them into his gallery, unto ome he expounded the Pictures; he made others admire the excellency of the work; all being very pleaingly diverted, they were in the concluion dipoed to it down. On the other ide, Amais did all that he poibly could to treat the Princes with all magnificence, and her endeavours were not lot: for though the iege might excue many defects, yet he was o very careful in entertaining them well, as they confeed that the umptuoity of her banquets was not inferiour to the expences of the greatet Monarchs.

That day after the repat was done, he acquainted them with her fears, that Gondebaut would Arm anew againt her. But Sigimond, Roilion, and Godomar, did promie o often never to forake her until he was in a condition free from all manner of fears, her mind was atisfied. Giving them therefore mot hearty thanks, for the tetimonies of good will which they had expreed unto her, he beeeched them not to live in any way of contraint, but to command freely any manner of thing that was in her power. After this, he went unto her cloet, and took order for her Dometick affairs; and the Princes going into a chamber where mot of the Nymphs, Ladies, and Cavaliers were, Sigimond drew Dorinde a little aide, and held this dicoure with her.

What caue oever you have, my fairet Dorinde, to think all men incontant, I am confident that what I have done is enough to make you change that opinion, or at the leat make you confes, that my fidelity deerves an exception from the common ort of men, as well as doth my birth. Sir, anwered Dorinde, that you have done much more, then I know how to merit, is without all manner of doubt: but that your fidelity is above the train of other men, pardon me, I beeech you, if I do not abolutely confes it, ince it is alwayes the end that crowns any work, and ince I cannot tell whether you will be as contant for the future, as you have been hitherto. This diffidence, aid the Prince, is no mall argument of your mall affection: It is an argument, replied Dorinde, of the enibility which I have of my own imperfections, which are more like to quench affection then to inflame it. The only imperfection whereof I aure you, (aid Sigimond) is that you do not love me enough; and yet you are in ome ort excuable, ince it is a very hard matter to finde one man amongt mortalls, that is worthy of o great an honour and happinee as to enjoy you. Thee flattering expreions (anwered Dorinde) do mell too much of artifice and diimulation, and are unworthy of a man that makes profeion of loving rightly: If you intend to ue no other language but this, I will not ay that you may become unfaithful, but will think you are o already. What thoughts oever you have of me (aid Sigimond) I mut till eteem you above all the women in the world; and if you do not think that thoe tetimonies which I have given of my elf, do not proceed from a clear heart and oul, I beeech you appoint me Laws, and tell me how you would have me behave my elf, for I protet I will mot inviolably oberve them: It becomes not me, Sir, replied Dorinde, to give Laws unto you; and ince your rank and quality is not to receive them from any but the Gods, if you do love me, let the God of love precribe them unto you. It is love, my fairet, anwered the Prince, which commands me to think that all the beauties in the world are inferiour unto yours; and that all merits are too little, if compared unto your high perfections.

Love then, replied Dorinde, is like unto thoe pectacles which deceive the eyes, and makes all objects eem greater then they are: No, no, my bright Star, aid the Prince, I do look upon you as you are, and let me perih if I do not think, that envy it elf is not able to find the leat hadow of any defect in you:
I perceive, anwered Dorinde, that complacency and flattery is a vice o common, as it is inevitable; bu • good Sir, continued he, let us talk no more of my beauty; for if you do, you will but anger me, ince I am in the leat degree owner of what you precribe unto me; but I wih I were, that I might be more pleaing unto you: All I can ay is, that uch as I am, have a perfect inclination to honour you: Then all I can ay (aid Sigimond and interrupted her) is, that I am the mot happy man alive, and that the love which I bear unto you, joyned with the aurance which you give me of your affection, is a thouand times more dear unto me then my Fathers Scepter: O heavens (aid Dorinde) the Scepter of Gondebaut, and the affection you bear unto me, are two things which will ute very ill together: For the one will no ooner come into your hands, but the other will go out of your heart.

All my oaths, vows, and protetations (anwered the Prince) hould methinks remove all uch upitions out of your mind, and believe it, my fairet Dorinde, the effects of my fidelity may well make you ceae doubting of my faith, if you would but pleae to call them into your memory; but to my great happinee, you do not judge rightly upon my humour, and are perwaded that the name of King can exclude that of Lover: but, No, no, my dearet Dorinde, the dicretion which you have een in all my actions, is a mot evident demontration that I do not pretend unto any thing which can offend you, and that entertaining no paion but what is legitimate, I hall till preerve it as pure and acred when I have an Empire, as now when I am only in hopes of it: I wih I were more free then I am, that I might be able to give you a better aurance of it; but ince I do abolutely depend upon the power of a father, and a Father incened, I cannot at this time do any more then make a mot faithful promie to marry you, as oon as ever I am at liberty.

Dorinde, flattering her elf with the title of Burgundean Queen, and imagining that this Prince might raie her fortune as high as her ambition, he did fully build upon thee lat promies, and uffering a pritty, kind of hame, mixed with incomparable joy, to appear in her cheeks, he returned this anwer. The good will, Sir, which I bear unto you, does not proceed from thee great hopes which you are pleaed to give me; for I dare ay, and that mot truly, that I do love your peron above your Crowns and Scepters, and your merits above your quality; yet ince you are pleaed to aure me, that your love is o great unto me as to make me a harer in the glory which your birth doth cat upon you, I do mot willingly accept of the offer which you make unto me, and promie never to dipoe of my elf, but according to thoe commands which I hall receive from you; and in tetimony of what I ay (continued he, pulling out a ring which Sigimond gave unto her, and breaking it in two) let this be the Symbole of our union: The time whilt the pieces of this ring do remain eparate, hall emblem our abene, and when you are in a condition to accomplih what you have promied, their conjunction hall be ours alo. Then Sigimond taking the one half of the ring, and kiiing it everal times, I do wear (aid he) that I will never believe my fairet Dorinde defective in her fidelity, until he end me back the other half of this ring which remains with her; and I would have her think the ame of me: in aying o, the Prince took her hand, and laid it to his heart: be aured, my dearet Dorinde (aid he) that this heart over which you lay your hand, is much more yours then my own, and will ooner die, then fail in the leat tittle of what I have promied: Dorinde looking ilently upon him, and the eyes of the Prince meeting with hers, they both wore an unalterable fidelity unto each other, by the language of their eyes: which though mute, yet did more eloquently expree their paions then any tongue could tell: At lat, Dorinde fearing to loe her elf in this rauishment, he firt withdrew her eyes, and bluhing a little, he beeeched him to go unto the ret of the company.

Lindamor in this interim, had not ill imployed his time: for as oon as he aw Roilion apply himelf to Roanira, and Sigimond to Dorinde, he went unto Galathea, and knew o well how to et forth what he owed unto all his labours, that he obtained leave to court her openly: and though he had a great confidence in
the good will of Amais, yet he thought it not expedient to conult with her, without communicating his deign unto the Druide, who, beide the power which his virtue had gotten him with the Nymph, had a very particular inclination unto him. He propounded then unto Galathea that deire which he intended to acquaint Adamas withal, and that Nymph thinking it to be very jut, Lindamor ent to eek him; but word being brought that he was gone out of Marcelles: I perceive (aid Galathea) that he was very deirous to carry home unto their habitations thoe Shepherds which Clindor entertained; and truly I am very orry that he did not acquaint me before he went: but I will entreat Ligdamon to go unto him, and olicite him to return as oon as poibly he can: Upon this, Galathea beckning unto Ligdamon, who was then entertaing Silvia, that Cavalier came unto her, and had no ooner received her commands to go, but he went immediatly and took hore.

Amais came out of her cloet at the ame time; and becaue he had been a long while cloitered up in Marcelles, he was very deirous to ride out into the fields to take the air: he caued therefore her coaches to be made ready; and going into one, with the three Princes, Lindamor, Roanira, Galathea, and Dorinde, the firt place he viited was the place where Polemas had pitched his Tent and his Camp: from thence he went unto the plain, where the blood of that Rebel was till to be een; and remembring the fears he was in, he related unto them the extream perplexity and anguih of pirit, in which he was when they fought. At lat, after they had ufficiently aired themelves, they returned to the Catle, where Amais did all he poibly could to Carree them, o much did he acknowledge her elf obliged unto them, for the great care they had in delivering her from the inolence of her enemy.

Ligdamon in the mean time, came unto the houe of Adamas, whom he found walking in his gallery with the Shepherds and fair Shepherdees of Lignon; when the Druide firt aw him, he was a little urprized, and was afraid that ome new diorder had hapned in Marcelles: yet, when he aked the caue of his coming, he was very glad that it was only to deire him from Galathea, to come unto her as oon as he could. He intended therefore to go very early in the morning, that he might be there as oon as the Nymph was ready; and beeeching Ligdamon to be his guet till then, he took him by the hand and carried him to the ret of the company: They were no ooner there, but they perceived Cercinea, Palanice, and Florice, were tanding all about Phillis, unto whom Cercinea poke thus: But fair Shepherdee, or rather the Interpretour of the gods, ince it hath pleaed heaven to make choie of you, to give us that atisfaction and tranquility which we have long prayed for, when will it pleae you to afford it unto us? Why are you o lack in doing the will of heaven? are you not afraid that the ame Diety which hath inpired you with the knowledge of his Oracle, will charge you with neglect, and punih you for the mieries which we uffer? To which Phillis miled, and returned this anwer. Fair Shepherdee, hould I refue to give you that atisfaction which you expect from me, I hould confee my elf mot worthy of punihment, as being guilty of an unpardonable in; But I mot humbly beeech you to conider, that your atisfaction do not wholly depend upon me, but that there are two perons more who are alo necearily required, and whom I believe we cannot eaily meet withal; yet I do mot faithfully promie to endeavour, with all my power, the atisfaction of your deires. Upon this he embraced them all three; and Adamas not being able to imagine the meaning of all this, he entreated Phillis to tell him why thee fair ones made this requet unto him? Father (anwered he) ince you do know, that the Decrees of the gods are unalterable, you will not wonder at the relation which I hall make unto you: Thee three fair ones not long ince received an Oracle, which commanded them to come into Forrets, and there to eek for a remedy againt thoe mieries which love had bred amongt them: and that you may know from whom it is, they ought to expect it, I hall repeat unto you the ame Oracle which they received.

div.head: The Oracle.
div.l: AGaint the pains which all you three endure,
In Forrets you hall find a certain cure:
On that was dead, and afterwards hall live
Unto you all a medicine hall give:
Another medicine you hall have from one,
To whom againt her will a good is done,
Which he rejected with her will: 'Tis he
Not you, by whom the overture mut be:
What he ordains, as if ordain'd by me,
Believ'd as Oracle by you mut be.

div.p: Now Father, continued Phillis, I cannot tell whether by inpiration or how it was; but o it certainly was, that having met them about a month ince, I repeated their Oracle unto them, and at the ame time beeeched them to tell me the tories of their lives; but ome particular conideration did hinder me from giving them that full audience which was expedient for them, I beeeched them to defer it until another time, which at my requet they did; and finding now a favourable opportunity for it, they deired me to give them the hearing now: Adamas was extreamly atonihed at the dicoure of Phillis, and not knowing how he hould come to the undertanding of the Oracle, he attributed it unto a kind of Miracle, and addreing himelf unto Cercinea, aid thus unto her: I do ee, fair one, that this is the time wherein you are to receive that contentment, which you with o much impatience longed for; for having found out them who is to be the Judges of your differences, I cannot ee any difficulty in the ret. Firt you may, and go no further, meet with thoe two perons who are to be the Arbitratours of your Fate: and certainly, by the peron dead and yet alive, the gods do mean—upon this he was ready to name Alexis, as the peron that lived after the death of Celadon: but eeing he could not name her without dicovering the deignes and ecrets of that Shepherd, he topped, and having a quick and preent wit, he named Ligdamon: for, aid he, and continued, every one does know that he was believed, and condoled, as dead, and when he took the Dormative in lieu of poyon. The other, unto whom that benefit which he lot with her will, hall be retored againt her will, is Celidea, unto whom Damon, maugre her reitance, will retore that beauty which he deprived her elf of, by cutting her face with the point of a Diamond. Upon this, Palanice, tranported with abundance of joy: Father (aid he, and took the Druide by the hand) we have reaon to denote this day, as the happiet of all our lives, and to acknowledge our obligations unto you to be infinite, ince by your means our eyes are opened, and we do now plainly ee thoe things, which before were as obcure unto us, as darknee it elf: There now wants nothing but to let us ee the perons that are to be our Judges, to the end we may relate our caue unto them, for we do not doubt, but this is the very place, where we mut receive our tranquility: Adamas who was very deirous to divert Ligdamon whilt he tayed there: Then (aid he) put all your three names into a hat, and that peron whom Phillis hall draw, is the name of that peron whom the gods have decreed to be the peaker for you all. Cercinea, Palanice, and Florice, conented thereunto: The Druide writ their three names in three pieces of paper; and folding them up, then putting them into a hat, Phillis, unto whom the hat was preented, did draw the name of Florice, who eemed very glad of the Commiion, and was obedient thereunto: o as after Adamas had entreated all the company to it down, he looked upon Phillis, and began her dicoure thus.

div.head: The Sequel of the Hitory of CERCINEA, PALANICE, and FLORICE.
div.p: I Wih, fair and dicreet Phillis, I could compoe the dicoure which I am to make, into uch an order as might clear me from all diobedience to the gods, and dicourteie towards you: but having not wit enough to avoid diorder in the relation of it, I beeech you let your ingenious judgment upply my defects, and pardon me, if I preent a relation unto you, which is not much unlike a skene of ruffled ilk, very difficult to be unwound: for we our elves, whom the buinee mot concerns, have much ado from loing our elves in the diorder of it: The accidents that have hapned amongt us, are o many, and o trange, that hould I enter into the whole Series of them, they would require a large volume; but knowing that Hylas hath been long in this Countrey, and he being an enemy unto all ilence and ecrecy, quetionlee he hath imparted many of our affairs unto you; and therefore I hall omit all impertinencies and uperfluities, hinting only upon the principal effects, to the end you may the better Judge upon the motions of our ouls, and ordain which of thee Cavaliers ought to poee our affections. Be pleaed to know therefore, O our jut Judge, that Cercinea, Palanice and I, have each of us two brothers, and (ince it mut out) two ervants, if at the leat any faith or credit be to be given unto the tongues and oaths of men; but to the end this may appear more plainly unto you, I beeech you give me leave to draw a little figure of them unto you: upon this he took pen, ink, and paper, and drew this figure.

Afterwards, he proceeded thus; Now in this ruffle of diorder, our interets are o mingled and intangled, that Cercinea cannot do good offices unto Lucindor towards me, without diobliging Cerintes, who is brother unto Palanice, and without fearing, that by way of revenge he hould ruine her towards Clorian: Palanice cannot peak unto Cercinea in behalf of Clorian, without angrying me in the peron of Alcander, and unlee he oblige me to ravih Amilcar from her; and I cannot countenance the two paions of Alcander and Amilcar, unlee I do vex Cercinea and Palanice, who had ome right to take from me, the one Lucindor, and the other Cerintes: This made us for a while look a quint upone another, and live in mot intollerable contraint and Tyranny; and becaue we imagined that this confuion would caue a breach in our amities, we went all together unto an Oracle, who gave us this anwer.

div.head: The Oracle.
div.l: LEt ix within this place remain
Till honour otherwie ordain:
No anwer to the Female three
Expect, unles alone they be.

div.p: This anwer made us think that the Oracle had omething ele to ay unto us; and therefore conulting with it alone, we received that anwer which the gods have communicated unto you as well as us: This now is the principal caue of our voyage, and coming into this countrey; but ince it is mot requiite I hould inform you what inclinations we have unto thee Cavaliers whom now you ee with us; I hall begin with Cercinea, and tell you, that, before Alcander, my brother, ever cat any eye upon her, Clorian had o far ingratiated himelf into her favour, by the interceion of Palanice, as it was believed this amity could not be broken: Alcander mut pardon me, if the affection which I bear unto him be not trong enough to make me tell a lie; and if being forced by a greater power to peak truth, and confee that this fair one is every way obliged unto Clorian. It was he that firt began to erve her, and found in her thoe flames which burned him; his affection was not born with him for any private interet, but only becaue he had dicovered in her tender years, ome parks of thoe charms, which now have inflamed him, and made him admire her: he was o obequious unto her in his youth, that for all her ingratitude towards him, he mut needs confee her elf much beholding unto his converation, for much of that gentilnee which he is Mitree off: And truly I cannot chue but laugh, when I remember ome of thoe replies which he retorted upon him when he began firt to love her: Be pleaed to know, he had not then attained to above the age of even years, when he began to be prinkled with paion, and talk unto her of love with as much ardure, as if he were at full age; One time tanding by the fire, he fell down upon his knees before her, I wonder how it's poible (aid he unto her) that my fairet little Mitree hould ever have any deire of warming her elf, ince he is able to inflame and warm a whole world? Servant (anwered he very weetly) it is not to be thought I can warm any thing; for were it in my power, I would warm the weather, o as it hould never be cold. The fire I feel (replied Clorian) and which your eyes have kindled in my oul, will not uffer me to doubt but that you can; but I profee unto you, it is o great, that I had rather dy then extinguih it. Do you then burn? aid Cercinia (and interrupted him) yes, replied Clorian; but it is in the weetet flame that ever heart was chorched in: I wonder then (aid Cercinea) that I do not mell it; for if one cat a bone, or a feather, or a little c • oth into the fire, it will mell all the houe over: Whether it do mell or no (anwered Clorian) who had much ado to forbear laughing, I am certain my fire will encreae from day to day, and perhaps will become o great, that before you be able to remedy it, it will reduce me unto ahes: It is good then (aid he) to apply ome remedy betimes; in aying o, he would have gone away, but Clorian, holding her by the arm, what remedy (aid he) would you fetch't me? I believe, anwered he, that if two or three dihes of cold water be cat upon you, it will do you much good: for I oberve they ue to do the ame unto wood when it burns too fat: Ah my fairet (aid Clorian) the fire you peak of, is much different from that I feel; for if water were able to extinguih the fire of a Lover, tears would do it, but they do rather nourih then extinguih uch flames.

Another time, when he was going into the countrey about ome buinee concerning his etate, I went to viit Cercinea, and to play with her, though my age then was above the play with little children: I found her at the firt a little troubled at the abence of her lover; for though he was incapable of knowing what love was, yet he had ome entiments of an amity above the common train; and asking her how long it was ince he went from her: believe me, anwered he, I have not counted the dayes: How? (aid I) they ay when one loves a peron very well, they will not only count the dayes of his abence, but the howers, and the very minutes. That (anwered he very coldly) is a tetimony of more affection then he mut expect from me: for do you think I can keep an accompt of uch things, that can hardly tell how many the clock trikes?

Such dicoure and entertainments as thee (fair and wie Shepherdee) they ued, during the innocency of that age, and I was a very frequent witnee of them: for being near neighbours, I aw Cercinea almot every day; and Clorian
himelf, who knew me more capable of reaon, did take much pleaure in relating unto me her pritty anwers; yet this Cavalier eeing he was to erve a long prentihip unto a child, and that it would be at leat ix years before he could pay what was due unto his love; he reolved to imploy his time in the wars, and did as he reolved.

In his abence he got great reputation; and Cercinea became uch a perfect beauty, that at his return, he found himelf a mot perfect lave unto her: She was now pat a child; and though he did remember the name of Clorian, yet he eemed not at all to remember that liberty which he formerly had given him: he received him indeed very civilly, and well, and being of a weet and affable dipoition and deportment, all her actions and expreions, confirmed this Cavalier in a belief, that he was till loved: Now conider him a mot perfect lover, and if Hylas would but take the pains to relate the paages of this affection, at the return of Clorian, he might intance more particulars of it then I can: for I know, that this Cavalier made ue of him in the buinee, and that Hylas af • er he had taken upon him to be his mediatour unto Cercinea, he began to peak for himelf, and to forget all his promies, as well as the interet of his friend: It is o long, aid Hylas, ince I have related all thoe follies unto a hundred of thee Shepherds, as I think it needlee to peek any more of them, ince their memories is good enough to remember them all: I do not peak it (replied Florice) to trouble them with any long and tedious relation; but I only ay, that you were a long time his rival, and that you left him peaceably to the courthip of this beauty: But O our equitable Judge, do but oberve how heaven is pleaed to dipoe of us. Clorian was no ooner out of thoe apprehenions, which the courthip of Hylas had caued unto him, but as they ay, he fell into a feaver of a cold train: for Alcander, my brather, being returned out of that countrey into which my Father had ent him, to better himelf in all noble qualities, he no ooner cat his eye upon Cercinea, but he loved her; and his paion made him o aiduous unto this fair one, that Cloan in a few dayes became jealous upon good terms. At the firt, the reentments of it were not of a deep train: for he imagined that the authority of Palanice would give a top to the matter. But at lat, eeing, that neither the perwaions of his Siter, nor his own vigilant aiduity (for he was hardly ever out of her ight) could not divert her from Alcander, but on the contrary, every thing made wore for him, he was o extreamly tranported with jealouie, that he could not enjoy any manner of ret. To relate all the paages that were fuel unto his fits of jealouie, and to tell you how Alcander courted the affection of Cercinea, will not be very pertinent: It will be enough to know, that he had in a hort time o ingratiated himelf, that he might boat himelf to be as high in her favour as Clorian; yet Cercinea being extreamly oth to dioblige Palanice, unto whom he was o much beholding and engaged for marrying her uncle; and not being able to downright hate Clorian, though his jealous humour did as much dipleae her, as the dicreet behaviour of Alcander, take her; therefore he carryed her elf wimmingly betwixt them both, and is without regret ready to receive him whom the gods, by you and your doom hall ordain and command.
