As for the affairs of Palanice, I can very eaily & exactly give you an accompt of the greatet part of them: for he and I have been long very good friends, and being both of us a little elder then Cercinea, we had contracted a more intimate league of amity, then we had with that fair one: And this was the reaon, that as oon as ever Sileines fell in love, I knew of it, almot as oon as the iter of that Cavaliers: for Palanice had no ooner a glimps of it, but he did communicate it unto me, and deired me to give her my opinion of it. To be ingenious and plain, I did not diwade her from him; but on the contrary, Sileines eeming very amiable in my eye, and eeing what eteem every one had of him, I thought it • glory unto her to be courted by a man whom every one eteemed: I found the humour of Palanice did rellih my opinion; whether becaue he had already ome inclination to love him, or whether he was wayed by the good opinion I had of him, I do not know; but o it was, that as oon as I advied
her to entertain the affection of Sileines, he expreed her elf unto me, in thee terms.

I have good reaon (dear confident, for o we ued to call each other) to ask your advice in the carriage of my elf towards him: for you mut know, that the day after he danced in a Maque, wherein he repreented Narcius, who was in love with himelf, he met me at the Queens lodgings, who is the mother of Sigimond, and dicoured with me upon matters of meer indifferency; but as oon as I talked of the Maque, and told him how admirably well he danced. O heaven I my fairet Palanice (aid he unto me) do not put me in memory of a groe fault which I then committed, and which were I out of hopes to obtain a pardon for, I hould not live. I who did not undertand what he meant, did anwer him, that I knew of no fault he had comitted, but on the contrary took notice how every one admired and commended his behaviour. If every one did o (aid he) then am not I like unto them; for I know that I did commit a very great fault in peronating to be in love with my elf, whereas it ought to have been, in really peronating my elf in love with you.

God knows how trangely I was urprized, when I heard this dicoure come from him: I wear (dear confident) it was dicoure which I little expected; and becaue I could do no other, I bluht, and in a little anger anwered: Though you hould Sir, change the object of your love, yet you cannot change your detiny, ince you cannot hope ever to obtain any thing from me, more then from that Image which you peronated to adore in your glae: In aying o, I removed a little from him, imagining he would not purue any further, becaue my companions advanced; but he putting his hand into his pocket, he pulled out ome weet-meats, and preented them: Every one took ome, and I, to tetifie that I had no caue to complain againt him, I took an orange comfit which he preented unto me; but as oon as I bad it in my hand, I began to play with it, and toe it up and down like a little ball: He, who feared that it would fall, came to me, and aid aloud, do you, fair Palanice, make o little account of my preent? I who did a little better undertand his mind then before, and that he tacitly alluded unto the affection which he had already expreed unto me; I do not at all light it (anwered I) but the reaon why I thus play with it is, becaue it is o light. Take heed (aid he) that it fall not into the power of ome of your companions; for perhaps they will make better ue of it then you do. There is none of my companions (anwered I) that will offer any uch thing: then cating down his eye, and peaking in a low voice, though it be only to hew (aid he) that I am not your deadly enemy, I beeech you eat it, believe me it is not poyon unlee love, by my carriage of it, has given it a tincture of that which hath infected my heart. Upon this, he retired, and I mut needs confee I upected his craft; but ince there was no remedy, I reolved to keep this Orange comfit from being toln from me, let if any one hould have dicovered the cunning of Sileines, they might think I conented to the invention: The Queen at the ame time retired, and as oon as I aw my elf alone in the chamber, I began to dipute with my elf, whether I would open it or throw it into the fire; but my curioities being above all other coniderations; I broke it in two, and aw a little paper incloed within it: I took the paper, and opening it, I found thee words written in it.

body.head: The Letter of SILEINES unto PALANICE.
body.p: Pardon me, my fairet Palanice, if I made ue of this device to deceive your cruelty, and put not an unhappy contruction upon my love, though the firt tetimony of it be a piece of juggling: If your pity do afford me any favour, I hall blee the invention which my pasion prompted me to ue, with a vow never to ue it again, in the expresion of my devoted ervice, which you cannot refue without making me the most mierable men in the world.

div.p: I had no ooner read this paper, but I reolved to hew it unto you, and not to let Sileines know I had een it, until I had conulted with you what to do, and therefore I told you the whole truth, to the end you may advie me unto the ame coure you would take your elf, if the like accident hould befal you.

This was the firt dicoure that Palanice and I had of it together, by which I was fully informed of the paion of Sileines, and of her inclination to entertain his courthip: o as having in ome ort found out her humour, I olicited in his behalf, that after removal of ome mall difficulties, he permitted him to erve her; upon condition he would behave himelf o dicreetly, that his very thoughts could not be condemned: which Sileines promied with o many protetations, that I believe the earth would have opned and wallowed him up, if he had been perjured.

Ever ince that time, he continued his courthip, with o much love and aiduity, that the heart of Palanice had been a hundred times harder then Marble, if he had not been enible of his expreions: I remember one day he deired her to give him a favour; he, deiring time to conider of it, came unto me the very ame day, and entreated me to tell her, whether it were jut, he would give him ome tetimonies of her affection: to which I anwered, that ince he did really love him, and knew his dicretion o great as might aure her of his love, he might well let him know, that he eteemed him above any other; but yet I advied her to make triall upon ome occaion, whether his love was anwerable to his expreions.

Palanice hearkned unto my advice, and firt he gave him a favour, which was a bracelet of her hair, woven with gold thred into letters, which made thee words; Better the Heart then the Arm: The firt time Sileines aw her, he begg'd again for a favour; I will (aid he) give you a tetimony of my amity, but withal, I would have you give me in exchange a tetimony of your obedience. Sileines, who to obtain this honour, would have promied impoibilities, did wear whaoever he deired. Then (aid Palanice) all that I require of you, conits in two things; that you will not laugh at this favour which I give you, though it be unworthy of your merit: Secondly, that after I have tied it about your arm, you will not look upon it in three dayes. As to the firt of your commands, (anwered Sileines) there is no great difficulty, Madam, in obtaining it; for nothing can come from you. but is more worthy of admiration then laughter: But, Madam, as for the econd, pardon me I beeech you, if I do not promie more then I am able to perform: for I am o infinitly deirous to ee that which is a tetimony of your affection, as I dare not wear I will abtain a day from the ight of o dear a favour: Well, replied Palanice, then promie me you will not look upon it, until you be come unto your own chamber: I will Madam (replied Sileines) ince you deire it.

Upon this, Palanice cauing him to hold his hat before his eyes, and charged him not to take it away; he unbuttoned one of his leeves, and after he had put on the bracelet, he buttoned it up again: As oon as Sileines had leave to take away his hat, he fell down upon his knees, and taking the hand of Palanice, fairet hand (aid he and kied it) which this day daigns to admit into the number of Palanices leeves, I do wear by thy fair elf, that I will never break the marks of my captivity; and that there is no conideration whatoever, that can indure me to cat of my bonds. Upon that, not taying o long as till Palanice could peak one word, he ran out of the chamber, and as fat as he could unto his own. As oon as he was there, he went into his cloet, and locked the door: Then opening his leeve, his eye and his mouth went both at once to that part of his arm which he perceived to pree him a little: But O, in what a wonder was he, when he found it to be Palanices hair, compos'd into a bracelet of fine curioity: he has told me ince, that his atonihment was the greater, becaue he expected it to be only ome of her knots which he ued to wear; he tood a long while, and looked upon it, not daring to utter one word, for interrupting his ravihment: afterward, upon a udden, kiing every letter in it one after another: Yes, yes, fairet Palanice (aid he) it is mot true, that this favour is better upon the heart then the arm: After this he was ilent again; and kiing it a thouand times, pardon
me (O ye great gods, aid he) if I do commit this Idolatry, and adore the giver of this, as the mot perfect work of a great divinity.

Fair Phillis, it would be uperfluous to relate all his expreions, upon this pleaing ubject: it is ufficient I tell you, that he tayed in his cloet above two howers, and would have tayed there much longer, if Lucindor had not called him, who came to invite him from Sigimond, to a coure at the ring, which was to be held within two or three dayes by the Queens command. It was not long before I knew from Palanice her elf, that Sileines had this bracelet; and therefore I told her that he had already done much at the requet of this young Cavalier; and that I thought it expedient for her to try by ome artifice or other, whether he did really love her. Palanice told me that he would, and that before eight dayes were over, he would tell me what he had done: but it it fit I hould tell you how he went to work, that you may ee the quicknee of her wit.

I told you before, that within two or three dayes after Sileines had the bracelet, the Queen was to betow a ring, at which he would have Sigimond to run, and with him all the Cavalry of the Court; and Sileines being one of the greatet Gallants in it, he was invited unto it by this young Prince. The next morning, then he went to acquaint Palanice; and he, who was very glad of that occaion to execute her deign; as oon as Sileines began to peak of it, and ay that he thought none was able to dipute with him for this ring, ince he ran at it for the love of her: You (anwered Palanice) hall not dipute for it with any, for you hall not run at all. Pardon me, Madam, I beeech you, aid the Cavalier: for Sigimond commanded me unto it by Lucindor. And I, replied Palanice, do forbid you. I hope, replied Sileines, you are more jut, and a greater friend unto my reputation, then to forbid me the performance of what I have promied: Ah Sileines (aid Palanice) this is but a lender argument of any power that I have over you. Why, Madam, (replied the Cavalier) were it that your ervice called me another way, I protet I would excue my elf, and had rather dipleae Sigimond then you; or if you do poitively command it o, I will obey; Then (aid Palanice) diengage your elf from your promie; for if you do love, or will obey me, do not run, but tay with me all that day whilt the ret are at the port. Sileines was a little importunate to know the reaons which moved her unto this; but Palanice her elf knowing none, it was impoible he hould give him any. The very ame night, he went unto the chamber of Sigimond, and being not able to think upon any thing but the commands of his Mitree, he took his opportunity o fitly, that as he was coming to this young Prince, his foot lipt, and he fell down to the ground: At the firt, none thought he had received any hurt, but Sigimond himelf began to laugh; but when they aw him get up, with much pain, and that he complained, every one came to him to know how he did; he told them that his ancle was out of joint, and the young Prince believing it, caued a coach to be immediatly made ready to carry him unto his chamber: afterwards ent everal Chirurgeons with pecial charge to have care of his cure; but Sileines who would not be viited, let a report hould be made of his heart, contrary to his intention, he told them he had ent for a Chirurgeon of his own, in whoe experience he had a great confidence.

The noie of this mihap which was believed to befall Sileines, was quickly pred all over the Town, and Palanice was not the lat that heard of it: yet eeming to be ignorant of the caue, he entreated Cerintes to go and ee him; but Sileines hearing that Palanice was pleaed to have any care of him, I beeech you Sir, aid he unto Cerintes, aure Palanice, that ince he is pleaed to pity my mihap, I feel no pain: and were I freed from my dipleaure, that I cannot wait upon Sigimond at the Coure, there is nothing now that would trouble me: which Cerintes having told unto his iter, he preently undertood his meaning, o apt are Lovers to expound the words and actions which do any thing concern them.

The day aigned for the Coure at the ring came, and Sileines with a taff in his hand, as if he could not go without it, coming to the lodging of Palanice,
he waited upon her unto a friends houe, whoe windows looked towards the place where the Coure was to be: It was not long after before Sigimond came, and with him a great number of Cavaliers, all whom, after a long dipute, yielded the praie unto the agility of that young Prince, who carried it away, to the great contentment of all the Court. Whilt they were running at the ring, Palanice and Sileines did nothing but talk; and if it were true which he ince told me, their dicoure was to this purpoe: They leaned both together upon the ame window, and Sileines looking upon his Mitree, as if he were ravihed at o fair a ight; how infinitly have you obliged me Madam (aid he unto her) in forbiding me to appear amongt thee Cavaliers, that I might enjoy the happinee of being o near you? Some (anwered he) are often near in body, who are far off in heart. That misfortune (aid Sileines) is inevitable unto all uch as are owners of o little merit as I am. Truly (replied Palanice) I mut confee you have qualities enough to win eteem; but I cannot perwade my elf you have uch, as will make all the women that look upon you, run out of their wits for the love of you: I wear (replied Sileines and miled a little) that as I have not the power to do it, o I have not o much arrogance as to think it; and hould I deire to be perfectly loved by any one (I mean not o far as run mad for me) I protet I hould wih it were your elf, whom I adore, and for whom my life is only pleaing unto me: you will quickly leave off that wih (anwered Palanice) ince you can never gain any thing upon me, who am inviolably reolved to hold all men alike indifferent.

O heavens, Madam! (aid Sileines and interrupted her) do you not remember thoe oathes and protetations you have made in my favour? I do remember, replied Palanice, all the promies that I made unto you: and if your memory be as good as mine, you will find, that though I did wear to love you yet I did not thereby wear to hate all other men, but will on the contrary, carree them equally, without giving one more credit or authority over me then another. May then every one, replied Sileines, pretend unto the ame favours which I have obtained from you; how can I put any high value upon them, if your melting kindnee make them common unto all the world? Then he held his peace to hear what Palanice would anwer; but eeing her to look another way; O mot cruel fair one (continued he) is it poible you hould in o hort a time change your inclination? and do you intend to recompence my obedience no better. I perceive (aid Palanice) you think that you have done a great matter at this time, and think me much beholding vnto you, for depriving your elf of the pleaure of one poor day; but Sileines, ince you have o good an opinion of your elf, and apires unto o great a recompence for o mall a matter, I pray look betimes for ome that will give them unto you: as for my part, I will not, and wear unto you, that I hall be very glad if you will trouble me no more. Sileines, atonihed to ee her o angry, and not knowing what in the world hould be the caue: Fair Palanice, anwered he, if it be my love that troubles you, pardon me if I tell you, my fidelity will not uffer me to give you lee; but if it be my preence which vexes you, you hall not long languih in that dipleaure: for I do protet not to preent my elf before you, until I be well aured that you deire my company: In aying o, he went from her, and would have gone out of the chamber; but Palanice who followed him with her eye, called him back as he was opening the door.

As oon as Sileines heard himelf named he turned back; and coming to her, he aid unto him, with a cornful look, ince you intend to retire your elf, Sileines, it is not reaonable you hould keep a companion with you that may trouble you in your olitude, therefore (aid he) pray r • tore me back my bracelet; for I will have it again. I wih with all my heart (anwered Sileines) that I were able to give you that contentment; but having worn never to part with it as long as I have life, you mut, if you would have it back command me to die: Die or live, aid Palanice, I am indifferent, o I can but obtain what I ask, and have my own hair again: Fair peice of cruelty (replied the young Cavalier) can your rigour find a heart to kill me, before I know the caue of it? Will you ue me with more
Tyranny, then thoe whom they ue to doom unto death before they be convinced of any crime? Do not accue any for the treatment which you receive, anwered Palanice, but the hallownee of your own merit; and unlee you will mot mortally dipleae me, retore unto me immediatly the bracelet which you had of me. But Madam, replied Sileines, you gave it unto me freely without any condition; therefore, replied Palanice, I would have it freely again without any condition. As long as I have done nothing (aid Sileines) which renders me unworthy to enjoy it, is it not extream injutice to ravih it from me: tell me no more of injutice (replied Palanice) all the reaon in the world allows me to take my own where ere I find it: I am afraid, replied Sileines, that you will have much ado to unty it; for there are a thouand knots upon it: No matter, no matter (anwered Palanice) I have a pair of Sciers which will do that office excellently well, if you will but hold out your arm. Well, well, peridious woman (aid Sileines in a rage and holding out his arm) atisfie your fury, and take your fill in ruining me, I will not give you o much advantage, as to ay hereafter, that ever I oppoed your will in any thing: Upon this Palanice did cut the ribband which tyed it together, and having put it into her pocket: Go now (aid he unto him) even whether you pleae, and ay that you are beholding unto me for cutting your chains and etting you at liberty: in aying o, he went to the window, not o much as cating a look upon him; and poor Sileines, unk in orrow, went away; but quite cured of his lamenee, for his rage had made him forget his taffe, and to counterfeit a cripple, as he did when he came.

His humour (aid Hylas, who at and aid not a word till now) point blank contrary unto mine: could I with any patience ever endure he hould call me troubleome, and accue me of too little merit for her? Let me dy if I would not have given her, not only the bracelet, but dublet, hirt, and all, to be delivered from the Tyranny of uch a peevih piece. Sileines did not o, replied Florice, but being enraged at uch treatment from that fair one, he reolved to come no more where he was; and began to prepare himelf for travel, o find ome remedy againt his orrows.

As oon as the running at the ring was ended, Palanice came to give me an accompt of all he had done; and becaue I knew by her looks and peech, that he repented of it, I advied her to think upon a remedy. We went therefore to ee Cercinea; and though that fair one was his iter, yet he knew nothing of his ecrets, for Palanice durt never trut her, becaue he was very young. Though we had known nothing of what had hapned unto her brother, yet we might well have imagined it by the diorder in the houe: for the inquietude wherein Cercinea was, and thoe tears which omtimes fell from her eyes did give us ufficient knowledg of it: yet eeming to be ignorant of all, we beeeched her not to conceal from us the caue of her orrow. She was not at all hie in telling us all very freely; how about two hours ago he had een her brother o extreamly troubled and offended, that it greived her very heart; for, aid he, he asked ome money of me, which he gave me to keep, he caued all his clothes to be packed up, he commanded his hores to be made ready, and I aw him in uch trange diorder, as it troubled my very oul: I wih (aid Palanice) that he were here, for he would not hide from me the caue of his dicontent: Alas, aid Cercinea innocently, never believe that; I think he loves me very well, and that I have as much power with him as any in the world, but all my prayers and deires could not get one word from him. In aying o, they aw Sileines enter, and paed by, not eeing who was in the chamber: Palanice, thinking all that Cercinea aid of her brothers depair was true, he eemed to have omething to do out of the chamber, and went unto the Hall dor, out of which Sileines mut of neceity pae, before he could go out of the houe: Sileines, o troubled in mind, that he never took any notice of me, he took his cloak and word; but when thinking to go out, he aw Palanice at the door, he was extreamly atonihed. She, who tood in the midt of the door-tead, and held out both her arms to top the pae, with her face from the houe; as oon as he heard him coming, who is there? (aid he, and turned a little about) Sileines then, not o much as
lifting up an eye, it is I, anwered he, that would go out. Out? aid Palanice, what? out of my heart, or out of the houe? out of the world, replied Sileines, ince your cruelty will not uffer me to live: after this, triving a little wi • h her, as being deirous to pae whether he would or no, Palanice catched hold of his arm; I wonder (aid he) you hould o much forget the Laws of civility, as to force thoe that have taken the pains to come and viit you: No, no, replied Sileines, you love your own contentment better, then to take any pains to come and viit a man that is o troubleome, and of o hallow merits as I am. Palanice, who knew well enough what he meant; whether you be troubleome or welcome unto me (aid he unto him) I will not now dipute; but be it which it will, I would have you tay in the houe, and if I have any power of you, I command it.

But fair Phillis, to horten my dicoure, Palanice carried the matter o, that he tayed him, and gave him uch full atisfaction, that in the preence of his Siter, who ever ince had a hare in his ecrets, he wore, that as long as he carried himelf with the ame fidelity and dicretion as formerly, he would never change. Now, O our fair and jut Judge, I cannot tell whether it be that men grow weary in properity, or are glutted with too many favours; but mot certainly, they are all incontant, and more by being too much loved, then too little. Sileines is an argument of it in his change: for without any good excue and colourable pretence, he cat off my companion, and devoting himelf unto Doria, did o extreamly offend Palanice, that in revenge he permitted Roiliander to make addrees unto her; but though a marriage betwixt them was almot fully concluded, yet he reolved, that if her peridious Sileines would return again unto his duty, he would find out ome invention or other to break off with Roililiander: he ventured therefore a Letter unto him; but he, in lieu of giving her any hopes, returned this anwer.

body.head: The Letter of SILEINES unto PALANICE.
body.p: You think that the Letter which you writ unto me is a testimony of your love; but I take it to be a full aurance of your infidelity. You are like unto uch as are ready to die, and would never have any recoure unto any remedies, till their dieae be pat all hopes of cure. Marry freely Palanice, ince heaven and you have conpired my ruine, and do not think I will ever forbid the banes, ince it is not fit men hould contradict the ordinances of the gods. I must needs confee, that he whom you hall love, hall enjoy the richet treaure that is this day upon the earth: But ince I hall never be jealous, nor have any deire to buy it at o dear a rate as the loe of my liberty, I hall not envy him: your incontancy has begot in me uch an odium unto all women, as if they do but hate all men, as much as I do hate all them, the age wherein we live will be the lat of Nature, and o adieu.

div.p:
This Letter did put Palanice into uch a rage againt him, that to put him out of all hopes of ever pretending again unto her, he gave her elf unto Roiliander, who after he had married her, did carry her into the mot fruitful place of the Sebuians. Sileines repented himelf of his fault; but it was now too late; and all that he could ever obtain from Palanice, was ome Letters, by which he aured him, that he did eteem him as much as the condition wherein he was would permit her. In fine, Roiliander died; Palanice returned to Lions, and the lover of Sileines and he began to kindle into as hot a flame as ever; yet with lee tranquilility unto him: for Amilcar his brother, who returned at the ame time, became his Rival, and fell o deperately in love with Palanice, that after a million of expreions of it, he could nor chue but wih him well. I mut confee, that at
the firt I would have diverted him; but at lat, when I aw his wound was incurable, I left Sileines, and took Amilcars part; and do what Cercinea his Siter could, I did o harp upon this tring unto Palanice, that the firt falling away of Sileines had made him o unworthy of ever being loved again, that if I did not abolutely overcome her, yet at leat I made her confee, that both of them had an equal weight in the ballance of her eteem, and that he would give her elf unto him whom the gods appointed her by their Oracle.

Now fair and wie Shepherdee, there remains no more, but to acquaint you with the follies of my youth, which I could wih any other were to relate; but ince the lot is fallen upon me, I will relate them without any artifice, and beeech you to excue me, if my imperfections make you think the relation tedious.

Be pleaed to know, fair and jut Judge, that of thee two Cavaliers, to wit, Lucindor the brother of Cercinea, and Cerintes the brother of Palanice, Lucindor was the firt that profeed love unto me. I will leave it unto Silvander, to find out the caue of this affection: for my part, I do ingeniouly confee my elf not to be o good a choller as to know it. But however, thus it began: Lucindor hapned one day to come into a great deal of good company, where they fell into talk of me, and to lament the death of a young Cavalier, who they ay erved me, and who ome five or ix months before was lain by a man whom he loved. This Cavalier was called Melieor; a man of an excellent wit, and one who though very young, yet eteemed one of the bet Schollers of all Gaul-Lyonee. Now after many a igh at the remembrance of this loe, they aured Lucindor, that there was an extream reemblance betwixt him and Melieor, and that they found the very ame features in both their faces: which Lucindor being very glad of, and proud of that reemblance, he reolved to ee me, and to try whether he hould have the ame inclination unto me which the aid Melieor had; but ee the power of Sympathy, or rather Detiny: Lucindor being brought by Cercinea, unto a place where I was in company, he no ooner cat his eye upon me but he was raviht; and uffering himelf to be captivated by that appearance of beauty which he aw in my face, he made a ecret Sacrifice of his liberty unto me. For my part, I mut needs confee, his handome mind o charmed me, that I preently began to have a deign upon him, and to pruce up my elf to catch him; but it was not long before I aw, that the place which I intended to beiege was already rendred unto me: for Lucindor, after ome amorous quints had paed between us' coming nearer me: Did you know, fair Florice (aid he unto me, an encounter that is befallen me, it would make you laugh: and you may make it ad or pleaant unto me, as you pleae. I anwered only with a mile which told him, that his firt accot was not dipleaing unto me, and this made him the more confident and bold to go on, and relate unto me what they had told him of the reemblance he had with Melieor; and truly (aid he) I do verily believe it, ince they told me at the ame time that he loved you, and ince the firt time my eyes had the honour to ee you, I was never able to defend my elf againt thoe overcoming charms wherewith you have captivated me. You ought not (anwered I) give any more credit unto them that Melieor loved me, then I do unto you when you would perwade me that you alo do love me: 'Tis true, I knew that Cavalier, and I did no lee eteem his merit, then I do lament his ad and fatal end; but I am of an humour o far from uffering any courthips of men, as I know, that though I had a deire unto it, yet he durt never be o arrogant as to preume any mention of it: In aying o, I cat my eye upon Lucindor, and perceived that he changed colour; for the coldnee of my anwer went to his heart and truct him dumb; but afterwards taking a little better courage: If ever he did love you (aid he unto me) I cannot believe but he did expree it unto you; and truly though you are pleaed to accue him of a fault if he had, yet what punihment oever I mut expect, I cannot chue but commit the ame crime.

I hall trouble you, my Judge, with a relation of his anwer, and what arguments he ued to win my conent unto a reception of his ervice: But o it was
that I yielded unto his importunity, and permiting him to expree his paion in writing, I received almot every day a Letter from him for a long while together, all which he gave unto me himelf; for want of a peron whom I durt trut with the interet which I had in him. Within a hort while after, Cerintes, he declared himelf; and becaue he feared I was too far engaged in my affection unto Lucindor, he did not dicouer himelf at the firt unto me; but he knew o well how to comply with the humour of my Father, that the good old man thinking him a convenient match for me, he did command me to love him. This did not put me to a little pains; and the more, becaue Lucindor, having ome touch of a jealous nature, did evidently make it appear unto me, that he could not brook his Rival without abundance of impatiencience; yet I carried my elf o wimmingly, both to the one and the other, that they both went away without any reaon to boat of any particular atisfaction. Yet I had a tronger inclination unto Lucindor then Cerintes; and the greatet light that ever he had of it was one night when we were at the table, and jeting with one another, my Father gave a book unto us, out of which we might draw our fortunes; either for war, or for riches, or for love, or marriage, or many other everal things: Cerintes was the firt who cat the dice, to know whether or no, he hould obtain his Mitree, and met with a very favourable lot which gave him great contentment. Lucindor on the contrary, he was o unfortunate, as he met with the mot unkind anwer in all the book; at which eeing him a little troubled, cat the dice again (aid I unto him) for to be more aured of the truth, one mut try more then once: to which Lucindor conenting, he threw the dice the econd time; but meeting with the very ame fortune, he fell into a mot furious chae, and wore he would eat the dice if he met with the ame lot again; but he might well be angry with his Fortune, for it changed not; for throwing the dice again he was as unhappy as before. Let me die, if it did not extreamly atonih me, for though I gave no credit unto uch fooleries, yet I could not chue but upect that our affection would meet with ome initer event. Being no lee damped at this chance then he, I took up the dice; but Lucindor laid his hand upon mine to take them from me, and eat them according to his oath; and eeing I reited him, he prayed me to give them unto him: but I aid unto him in a low voice, I fear Lucindor, that you will ue them ill, if I ubmit them to your mercy: I will ue them (aid he) as an enemy, that has robb'd me of all my hopes, unlee you will be pleaed to make my Detiny more kind unto me then they have: your welfare Lucindor (aid I unto him) depends upon your merit, and not upon chance; and therefore, if you have any good opinion of your elf, let me advie you to hope well. You mut peremptorily command me o to do (replied he) if it be your pleaure I hould live. Well (aid I unto him in a low voice) I do then command you, and be confident you hall be as happy as I can make you. Upon this, I threw the dice upon the Table, and we continued in our rallary, until it was my Fathers pleaure to retire.

It was not the latter end of Winter, and as ill luck was, an Aunt of mine who lived in the countrey, fell ick, and ent to entreat my Father that I might come and tay with her. Upon this I went, and being well aured, that both Lucindor and Cerintes would come and viit me, I was afraid, let ome fits of jealouie hould make them fall foul upon each other, as they met upon the way; and therefore I charged them both, upon pain of my dipleaure, not to tir out of Lions: Cerintes was obedient, and I mut confee his obedience did much pleae me, But Lucindor, after he had endured this abence, with as much grief as a man that loves well could do, and imagining, that what crime oever he committed, I loved him o well as to pardon it, he reolved to ee me, and began to conider upon the way how.

Fortune preently after favoured his deires: for my Aunt ending a young man to acquaint my Father with her recovery, Lucindor chanced to meet with him, and knew o well how to tickle the fellow with fair words, that he made him promie to bring him unto my chamber, when I was ready to go into bed. So as when the young man was returned, and told us how glad my Father was to hear
of his Siters recovery, he began to think upon the promie which he made unto Lucindor, who according to appointment, was to come that night: The Cavalier in the interim forgot not his time; but before I tell you how I received him, I will tell you what befel him by the way.

Firt, he et out of Lions in the evening, none taking any notice of him; and becaue the gates of the Town did ue alwayes to be hut very timely, he went out alo betimes, and tayed in the uburbs until it was a fit time for him to et forward. The air was very muddy, and much dipoed unto rain: o as he was no ooner et forward, but the clouds began to open, and hower down in uch abundance, that though he had a very thick cloak, yet was he as wet, as if he had been thrown into a river: The Moon lent no light at all; and thus accompanied with rain and obcurity, he went on his journey; yet chearing up himelf in hopes of enjoying two or three weet hours with me. He had not gone above the third part of a mile, but miing his way, and galloping through woods and buhes, he hit his head againt omething which truct off his hat: at the ame intant he pied a man, who, as he thought, had an intention to pull him off from his hore: At the firt, he apprehended him to be ome thief who waited in the way for a prize; therefore purring on his hore, he galloped ome fourty or fifty paces, afterwards he topped, and drew his word, ready to defend himelf againt any that followed him: He tood a while in this poture, till enduring all the rain, which powred down fater and fater. Seeing none came after him, he litned with his ear, to try whether he could hear any noie; and then he thought he heard ome laugh near the place where he aw the man; but not thinking it poible to find his hat again, he put his cloak over his head, and in this equipage he came to my Aunts houe, and at the gate, he found the fellow that had promied to let him enter.

Lucindor was o pitifully wet, that his clothes made a tream of water whereoever he came, yet being hewed which was my chamber, <> entred jut as I was beginning to undree my elf. He preently cat himelf at my feet, and taking my hand kied it, I making no reitance, for I was o urprized at his arrival, that I was even ready to fall into a woon. Yet imagining, that perhaps ome grand reaon had induced him unto this diobedience, I asked him with a trembling voice, if my Father was well, and he anwered, yes. What is it then (aid I unto him) which makes you o bold as to come out of Lions and depie my commands? My love, replied he, which would not let me live and not ee you. How? (aid I) will o mall a matter move you to dipleae me? Madam, anwered he, do you think the life of a man that loves you above all the world, o mall a matter? very well, Lucindor, replied I, and eemed to be extreamly angry, ince you do love your life o well, and ince it concerns me to have a care of my reputation, tay not a jot longer in this place, where neither of us both can be in afety. He offered to reply omething, but I interrupted him, go, go, aid I, hate away as fat as ever you can, upon pain of eternal dipleaure. Upon this I ran into my Wardrobe and hut the door, reolved not to come out till he was gone out of the chamber: But Lucindor, at the firt tood till, as if he were immovable; but at lat, enraged at my cold entertainment of him, he went out in a mot deperate mood, and took hore without a hat, though the fellow which gave him entrance did offer to lend him one.

As oon as he was gone, I would needs know by what trick he had thus urprized me; and the young fellow confeing that it was by his means, alo that Lucindor told him, he came upon buinee that was very erviceable to me; though I firt threat ••• to make him be turned away, yet afterwards, upon his asking pardon, and his repentant tears, I could not find in my heart to punih him.

Lucindor in the mean time returned homewards, the mot afflicted man that ever received any ill treatment from his Mitree; but as if the weather were more kind unto him then I: the clouds cleared up, and the Moon hined upon him as if it were a new day; and therefore riding on, he epied upon his left hand, a gibbet, raied up above the ground, about eight or nine foot, and ome three or
four paces further, a corps lying upon the ground, he began to think it the body of ome Fellon, but he could not imagine why the corps that hould have been upon the gibbet, hould be under it. At lat, conidering upon it, he remembred what adventure he met withal about that ame place and imagining, that perhaps riding under this gibbet, he light upon the corps and threw it down, and then believed that this was the theif whom he upected; and to confirm him in this belief, as he rode a little further he found his hat, which he took up, and continued in his way: the only thing wherein he was not atified, was, that he thought he heard ome laugh; but hearing upon a udden, the cry of ome Owl or night Raven, which ued to feed upon that corps, he found his mitake, and that his fears at that time had in ome ort diordered his judgement: Lucindor hath ince confeed unto me, that he could laugh heartily at this adventure, if the condition wherein he was would permit him to entertain any other thoughts, but uch as bore the image of depair: and if it was true which he told me, his oul was o unk in orrows, that nothing in the world was able to raie it unto any pitch of mirth. Thinking therefore upon the cold entertainment which I gave him, he began to igh out o many ad complaints againt me, that his journey ended ooner then his orrows. Yet night not being done, he called at the houe from whence he departed, and taying there till the gates of the Town were opened, he went unto his own houe; in which he was no ooner entred but a feaver eized upon him, and in a hort time grew o violent, that every one depaired of his recovery.

My Aunt was now perfectly recovered; and my Father ending for me home. I was no ooner returned, but I heard Lucindor was ready to die. I mut confee, that I was very angry with him: but hearing this ad news, I did o quite forget his fault, and was o exceedingly troubled at it, that my Father himelf, by the alteration of my face, perceived my orrows, and certainly I had ome reaon to be orry for him for when I began to conider, that if he had not loved me, he would never have •• ollen out in the night time, to come and ee me, and conequently, would not have endured uch rain, wind, and weather, as he did: all this made me pity him o much, as if it had been poible, I would have endured the one half of his pain, as a punihment upon my elf, for being the principal caue. All the Phyicians of Gondebaut were imployed about him; but as he told me, I had better Phyick for his dieae then all they: for indeed, as oon as ever he heard that I had pardoned his diobedience, he began to mend, and within twelve dayes after left his bed.

Cerintes in the mean time had entirely gotten the good will of my Father, and yet being unwilling to marry an enemy, he did all that poibly he could to make me a friend; but till finding that Lucindor was highly in my favour, and that I looked upon him with a more favourable eye then upon himelf, he began to be almot furious. He intended therefore to tetifie his reentments to the height; and thus he went to work. One evening, when Lucindor and he did come to keep my Father company, after ome ordinary dicoure, I entreated Cerintes to ing: he taking my Lute, muick Madam (aid he unto me) does not ympathize with my adnee; yet ince you command me, I hall ing you a very new air, which one of my bet friends compoed, and none but my elf ever heard as yet: upon this he ate down, tuned the Lute, looked upon me, and ung certain veres which extreamly reflected upon his Rival.

Afterwards, he laid the Lute down upon the Table, and at ilent: I bluh'd; but on the contrary, Lucindor grew pale; and I oberved, that he had an itching deire to call him to an accompt for the words of his ong. Yet being in a place where repect tyed him to the good behaviour, he contented himelf to ay this unto him: Your ong, Cerintes, is very fine, and I believe, that if he who compoed it hould ing it before any that was concerned in it, it would beget a quarrel: Perhaps (anwered Cerintes) it was o intended: Then they looked upon each other in uch a manner, as made my Father plainly perceive the caue of their quarrel: and therefore intending to top the coure, he carryed them both into his cloet, and ued uch perwaive arguments as made them friends; and conceiving
the only way, to take away th •
• ffects of their ill will, was to take away the caue, he wore unto them both, that he would betow me upon Theombres, and that he was well pleaed with it: Lucindor was ready to bite off his fingers for anger, and paing through the chamber where I was, he went away without o much as bidding me good night; but as oon as he came to his chamber, he wrote me uch a Letter, as did preently let me ee his fury; but this did not afford me any means to remedy it: for indeed my Father did give me unto Theombres, and this Cavalier having married me, did carry me with him unto his houe within eight dayes after. Yet during this abence, the affections of Lucindor and Cerintes did not die; but were, as it were nourihed by my abence: and I knew it to be o, becaue Theombres dying, they began their addrees afreh; and as if heaven would remove all obtacles out of their way, I lot a Father, oon after, a husband: yet not being able to reolve how I hould demean my elf unto either, or both of them, I willingly conented to take that coure which we reolved upon all together, which was to conult with the Oracle in the Temple of Venus: whoe anwers, mot equitable Judge, you have heard, together with the tories of our lives, the tranquility of which depends upon your doom.

After this, Florice was ilent; and Phillis taking Ligdamon and Celidea, and asking Florice, whether there was any danger in calling Adamas and Alexis to councel, he anwered, that there was no particular prohibition to the contrary: o as the Druide and Celadon, being added unto Phillis, Celidea, and Ligdamon, they all evered themelves a while from the ret of the company, they all gave their everal votes unto Phillis; and then they returned again, and itting down, he uttered thee words in an audible voice.

Since it hath pleaed the gods that your differences hould be referred unto me, and ince they have ordained that my Doom hall be an inviolable Law unto you, upon the grave deliberation and advice of thoe whom I took to be my Aitants, I do judge, that all you three being almot equally obliged unto thoe who have the honour to erve you, therefore it is of neceity, that the gods do further make it known, which of thee Cavaliers are detinied to be your everal and repective husbands. I do therefore ordain, that the diciion of it hall be by lot, and that each of you, with each of your two Lovers, hall be blinded with an Napkin; and each of you hall marry him who firt falls into her hands, without any permiion unto thoe to whom detiny is avere, to murmure either againt me, or againt heaven, whoe will is as I have pronounced.

After this Phillis roe up, and taking napkins, he firt blinded the eyes of Cercinea, and afterwards Clorian and Alcander; and carrying them into one of the corners in the gallery, he gave two little keys unto Clorian, and two unto Alcander, to the end, that they making a noie with them, Cercinea might hear and know where to find them: After this, turning <> about everal times, and giving them a watch-word when they hould begin their walk: Cercinea at the other end of the gallery, et forward at the noie of the keys, and went blindfold whether her Genius did lead her: the firt that he met with was Alcander, who eeing himelf more happy then his Rival, did embrace Cercinea o cloe, that he could not poibly ecape out of his arms.

This controverie thus decided, Phillis took the napkins, and putting them over the eyes of Palanice, Sileines, and Amilcar; he oberved the ame ceremonies as before, until at lat he fell unto the lot of Sileines.

Florices turn was nex, and he having a more particular inclination unto Lucindor, the gods favoured her deires, and cat him into her arms before Cerintes, at which he was extreamly well atisfied. In the mean time Cerintes till looked on, and Hylas having gotten Lucindors keyes out of his hands, he made a noie with them, as if Florice had not yet made her blind choie: at lat, not to let him any longer run on in that vain and unprofitable quet, he put himelf into his arms and embraced him: Cerintes, who thought at the firt, that he had Florice in his arms: O my fairet Florice (aid he) now at the lat you are mine for ever: Yes
(aid Hylas) if it pleae Lucindor to p •• with her: Cerintes, then finding his mitake, wretched fellow (aid he unto Hylas) is it not enough to ee me deprived of Florice, but I mut be mocked at? why mocked? replied Hylas, I would have you know Cerintes, that you are extreamly obliged unto me, and that in taking me, you are more rich then you imagine.

Away, away, replied Cerintes, do not o extreamly dioblige me with thy foolery: I protet (anwered Hylas) I am in good erious earnet: for if a Lover be tranmigrated into the peron loved; as Silvander affirms, then conider who am I, that in putting my elf into thy arms, I have in lieu of one beauty, preented thee with a hundred that have loved me: every one laughed at the rallery of Hylas, Cerintes only, Clorian, and Amilcar, eemed dicontented, and reolved to go the next morning after Sigimond, and o they did; Adamas with Ligdamon, bearing them company, as far as Marcelles.

Adamas had o hort a mornings walk, that he came to Marcelles long before either Amais or Galathea were awake; and therefore he went traight unto the chamber of Lindamor, whom he found almot ready: for his love would not let him lie in bed o long as others: and there inquiring the caue of Galatheas o udden ending for him, Lindamor anwered him in thee terms. The reaon, reverend Father, why that Nymph did put you unto the trouble of coming, does equally concern both her and me, and for your full atisfaction, I will make a relation of it unto you: Know therefore Father, that as the tate tands with me, my life does abolutely depend upon three perons, and they are, Amais, Galathea, and your elf. Perhaps Amais may conider my ervices; and as oon as my intention it known unto her, he will not deny me a happinee which hath already cot me many a igh: Galathea is almot overcome, and if it may be poken without vanity, he has deires which are entirely to my advantage: I want only your aitance in the buinee, and that you will be pleaed to mediate for me unto the Nymph, for none has a greater influence upon her then your elf, whoe prudence is o well known unto her and all the world, that the charm only of your approbation, is enough to move her unto any thing: but Father, to the end you may know in what a deparate condition I hall be, if my deigne be not econded with a happy uccee, anwerable unto my deires and hopes, I will make you a particular relation of my love, and other accidents of my life: provided you will be pleaed to pardon a groe crime which I have committed, in o long concealing from you, an interet which cannot but prove very fatal unto me, with that aitance which you may afford unto me.

Upon this, the Cavalier deired the Druide to it down, and began to prepare himelf to make a long Narrative of all that had paed betwixt Galathea and him; but Adamas, who knew it perfectly already, by the relation of Leonide, prevented him and aid: Brave Lindamor, you do think me more ignorant of your affairs then I am; but to ave you the labour of any relations, let me tell you, that I do know o many pa ••
• oncerning your love, as perhaps will make you wonder, when you hear me, <> them to the very leat particular: and in tetimony of what I ay, was it not Lindamor who fought with Polemas, and having vanquihed him, did retire himelf, and would not be known by any? Do you not remember the time, when in the habit of a Gardiner you preented a hart unto Galathea, which he found to be a living hart, in lieu of a dead one that he expected? Did you not that very ame night make many promies unto her? and did not he vow, that he would never deny her conent unto any thing that you deired? You ee Lindamor, I know all that concerns you, and be not orry for it, for I do honour you o much, as I will make ue of my knowledge, rather to erve, then to hurt you: I mut tell you, therefore, that if ever you had any reaon to hope for good fortune, it is now, jut now, when all things contribute unto it; only let me advie you to carry your elf very dicreetly, let if your paion hould make too great a noie, it might in ome ort offend Amais and Galathea.

Lindamor did hearken very attentively unto all the Druide had aid; and he preently apprehended, that it could be none but Leonide that could be his informer;
yet not willing to loe any time in condemning her for it, he eemed to be very glad that he knew the truth of all, and afterwards returned him this anwer: ince Father you are not ignorant in any one accident of my life, and does know that if Galathea be denied me, I can never live contented, I do mot heartily and humbly beeech you to tell me, what coure I hould take to obtain her. I know one ingle word of perwaion from you, has more prevalency with Amais, then all that I can do; which to ay truly, is not o coniderable as to hope for o fair a recompence as that Nymph: therefore, dear Sir, I conjure you by all the effects that pity can produce in a oul capable of reentment, to make the propoition unto Amais, and repreent unto her, that Galathea can never meet with one who will love her, honour her, and erve her, better then my elf.

Lindamor uttered thee few words with o much paionate affection, that Adamas was much moved by them; and to give him a tetimony of it: Generous Lindamor (aid he unto him) you hall ere long ee how much I deire you hould enjoy that contentment which you merit; and for the better effecting of it, I would advie you to acquaint Sigimond, Roilion, and Godomar, with your deign, and oblige them to break the motion unto the Nymph: probably he will deny them nothing, and though he had a mind to deny them, yet he would not, until he had communicated the matter unto me, which if he hould, then hall I be ready to erve you, and not be wanting in my perwaions of her. Upon this, Lindamor took the Druides hand and kied it, and promiing to follow his advice very punctually, he roe up to end and know whether Galathea was yet up; but Adamas, who had no mind to ee her, left he hould chide him for departing the day before without taking his leave: Sir (aid he unto Lindamor) if the Nymph Galathea have no other buinee with me, you may give her an accompt of my voyage, and of the buinee whereof we have dicoured: for my part, I do intend to return, for the Ghets which I have at my houe, do long for my return. As for your Ghets (aid Lindamor and interrupted him) I believe he is very deirous to enquire of them, for he was very orry that he did not ee them before they went. They, anwered Adamas, do o little know how to behave themelves, as they are excuable, if they did not do thoe complements as are belonging unto the Grandure of Amais and Galathea, but I hope you will make their excues, nor hould I put you upon it, did I not think that it does much concern you to have a pecial care that Amais does not know how I came upon your buinee, let he hould upect me, and think that I aim more at your particular contentment then her ervice. Lindamor thought this conideration o good, that he conented unto all that Adamas deired. Thus the Druide departed: and the firt thing that came into his thoughts by the way, was the obtinancy of Celadon, in hunning all occaions which might make him known unto his Shepherdee: yet not being able to imagine the caue, he reolved, whatoever came on't, not to uffer this deluion to continue any longer.

In the mean time, the Shepherd was awake, and lying in the ame chamber, with Atrea, Diana, and Phillis, he no ooner opened his eyes, but he drew the curtain, and looked towards the bed where his Shepherdee reted; but Atrea who waked almot at the ame time: I beeech the gods (aid he unto him) make this day as happy unto my fair Mitree, as he can deire, or I wih it- You need not wih it (aid Celadon) for it is in your power to make it as you pleae. O heavens! (aid the Shepherdee) I wear, that if it be in my power, you hall never have an ill one: for I do o unexpreably well, that I will do any thing in the world to content you. I do protet, replied the uppoed Druide, my affection unto you is uch, that I do devote my elf olely unto your contentment: the weetet day of all my life hall be bitter unto me, if it be not pleaing unto you; and my bitteret day hall be weet unto me, if it delight you. Mitree, replied Atrea, you do expree your elf o affectionate unto me, that you will either well me with joy, or make me upect that you do mock me: The Shepherd would have anwered, but that Diana and Phillis waked upon their talking; and therefore he was ilent to hearken unto Diana, who rubbing her eyes, and
turning towards him, Madam (aid he) I think Atrea and you, have done nothing but talk all the night; for when I fell aleep the lat night, I left you talking; and till find you talking when I wake: I mut confee (anwered Alexis) if that fair one could as well forbear leep, as I deire to do, perhaps we had pent the whole night in dicoure. Truly (aid Atrea) I had no great dipoition unto leep; but fearing let I hould diturb your ret, I was the firt that gave over talking. That conideration, replied Alexis, ought not to have topped your mouth: for I expect more ret from your words, then from any leep: Well, well, replied the Shepherdee, I hope one day we hall enjoy this weet ret you talk off, if you will but haten the accomplihment of that promie which you have made unto me: Celadon was ready to reply when Phillis interrupted: O God (aid he unto Atrea) why are you o haty to be with that fair Druide and live in ome place with her, where our preence cannot divert you? As I live, were I in Dianas room, I would throw you out of bed, that you might go and take poeion of that place which you o much deire. In aying o, he began to thrut Diana, and Diana Atrea, and o hard, that Atrea was thrut more then half out of bed: Diana (cryed he out) before you thrut me out, you hould firt have known whether my Mitree will receive me into her bed: The Law (anwered Alexis) which forbids us to lie with any, is not o trickt, but in caes of neceity I may receive you: In aying o, he opened her arms, and made a ign as if he hould come thither; but as ill luck was, the mock of Alexis being open before her bret, did let appear the Ribband, in which was Atreas picture, and the ring which he tied unto it, when his depair made him cat himelf into the river Lignon: which Astrea perceiving, and remembring that the colour of the Ribband was very like unto that knot which Celadon took from her, he began to change colour, and not being able to remove her eye from off that object. he tood till a long while and aid not a word. The Shepherd, who all the while expected her coming, did wonder at uch a udden alteration, and could not chue but ask the caue: to whom Astrea anwered, I protet Mitree, I am o much ravihed at that which you wear about your neck, that I cannot take my thought off an accident which had like to have cot me my life. Celadon upon this looking down, and eeing thoe dear pledges of his love and Atreas jealouie to hang out of his hirt, which he had o carefully till then concealed; he was ready to fall into a wound: yet conceiving, that the bet way to deceive her, was to et a good face upon the matter, he began to recollect himelf and mile: Servant (aid he unto her) never let this which you have een trouble you, for I will hew them unto you when you pleae, and freely tell you from whom I had them, upon condition you will aure me not to be jealous. In aying o, he put the Ribband, as it ought to be, out of ight, and Atrea in extream impatience, I were exceedingly to blame (aid he) if I did not receive your offer, and atisfie my mind concerning what I have een: upon this he offered to go into Celadons bed, and when he was in the midt of the room going to him, he heard ome coming up the tairs and name her; and becaue he feared it might be ome that came to viit them, as Adamas, or or Leonide, he returned as fat as he could, and went into her own bed, though Diana and Phillis would hardly receive her: immediatly after this, Leonide entred; and God knows, to the great contentment of Celadon, when he aw himelf delivered from the perplexity, into which the curioity of Atrea had put him.

But as great as his joy was, it was not comparable to the atonihment of Diana, when he aw Leonide to be the uher of Bellinde: yet that fair Shepherdee diembling her dipleaure, which the coming of her mother caued, he received their embraces with many tetimonies of gladnee: Phillis and Atrea did the ame; and whilt Leonide went unto Celadons bed, and asked him how he had reted. the Shepherd anwered: The night (age Nymph) has been as kind unto me, as the cruelty of my detiny will permit, which is till finding out new wayes to afflict me: Leonide, a little urprized at this, why (aid he) what new accident has hapned ince yeterday? one o ad, replied Celadon, that if you had not come in the very nick of time, I had been plunged into the mot trange perplexity
that ever Lover was: then he related unto her, how the Knot, the Ring, and the Picture of Atrea appeared upon his bret, and how Atrea pying them, did change colour: he told her alo the intention which that Shepherdee had of coming into his bed to be atified in that doubt, which that object had put in her; and in fine, the perplexity he was in, to find out ome invention that might deceive her. Leonide, after he had heard all this; truly (aid he) I am afraid the gods will punih you for the injury you do unto your Shepherdee, in deferring the giving her the contentment of knowing you but if you will follow my advice I hall councel you to defer it no longer, but this very day find out an opportunity of telling her that with your tongue, which your eyes have told her a thouand times. had he undertood that language: May my mieries be eternal (aid Celadon) if I do not mot paionately deire to know what happinee or what mieries I am to expect: for you may well imagine, that in uch uncertainties as we are in, I am not him that uffers leat: Well (anwered Leonide) I will talk with my uncle, and tell him how willing you are to ubmit unto whatoever he will direct: In the mean time I conceive it your bet expedient, to put the Knot, the Picture, and the Ring, into my hands, to the end, that if Atrea do come and enquire after them, I hall be your lawful excue in denying her that contentment. Officious Leonide, anwered Celadon, without any giving them unto you, I can tell her that you have them, and hall not lye, if I wear that you did deire them of me, but pardon me that I dare nor part from them, no not for a minute: for uch would be my grief at uch a eparation, as it would be the hazard of my very life. Leonide, who knew he hould never obtain them, did not importune him any longer; but having told him in what manner he ought to receive Bellinde, that Shepherd behaved himelf o well, and did his complements o handomly, that he would have deceived not only Bellinde, but all the world.

Adamas at the very ame time returned from Marcelles, and met with Paris cloe by his houe, who came to meet him, and acquaint him with the coming of Bellinde: Paris giving him a particular accompt of his voyage, Adamas did bid him as heartily welcome home, as a on could expect from an indulgent Father. Belinde was immediatly acquainted with the return of the Druide, and therefore he left all the fair ones to dree themelves, and went to acquit her elf of that repect which he owed unto the affection and qualitie of Adamas. But the Shepherdee Diana (for all her contraint) could not hide the dipleaure which the coming of her mother caued, knowing that her intention was to make up her marriage with Paris; o as at every pin which he ued in dreing her elf, a igh did econd it, at which Atrea wondering, and asking the reaon, Diana anwered, that the coming of her mother had welled her with uch an excee of joyes, that he was tranported with it, and her mind in uch a confuion that he eemed to be in that diorder of pirit, more ad then glad. Phillis, who heard her ay o: I am afraid (aid he) that the joyes of Silvander are not like unto yours; and that the return of Paris has given his oul uch a breakfat of joy, as will never be een in his face: I believe (anwered Liana) that it will be very indifferent unto him, or if he have any reentment of it, it will be rather of joyes to ee my mother, then orrows to ee Paris. I know not what it will be, replied Phillis, but I would not have that contentment which I expect from the enjoyment of Licidas, hould be like unto that which Silvander will receive, when he hears the news of her coming: for Diana, I do know his humour and temper o well, as I dare wear, that he will not only be ad, but even deperate when he hears it; and as good a face as you do et upon the matter, you know him to have more judgement then to be ignorant, that her coming is to make up your marriage with Paris.

O heavens iter (aid Diana with tears in her eyes) why do you ay o? As he aid o he bluh'd, afterwards added; and you know Silvander to be a man of o much judgement, you will alo know, that he will not think it trange I hould obey Belinde, and oberve her will as a Law inviolable. I do not ay (anwered Phillis) that he will condemn your obedience; but I do ay, that he will be extreamly afflicted at it, and that the orrows which he hall reent, will be o violent, as perhaps will force him unto ome deperate coure. Diana the hruging
her houlders, and lifting her eyes up to heaven, I wih the gods (aid he) would give him what he deerves, and which to make him happy I would give him, if it depended only upon me. This (aid Phillis) is a fine reward indeed: whilt you betow all your great and particular favours upon another, poor Silvander mut be put off only with a bare wih, as a recompence for all his ervices: alas (aid Diana) what would you have me do for him, in this condition wherein I am, and wherein I cannot do anything for my elf. I dare not tell you, replied Phillis, what I would have you do; but I know what a woman of courage ought to do, and what I my elf would do were I in uch an extreamity. My weet companion, replied Diana, I know you to be o wie, that you would not trangree againt my duty, but would rather uffer, and never complain of any injutice done unto you. This is the reolution which I have taken and will follow, what mieries oever my Detinies prepare for me. Diana uttered thee words after uch a manner, as Phillis and Atrea knew, they came from her heart: Beginning therefore to lament the lot of Silvander, they continued dreing themelves, and when they were ready, they went down into the room where Adamas and Belinde were.

On the other ide, Ligonias, who knew he could not do Sigimond a greater pleaure, nor Amais better ervice, then to carry out of Forrets all the forces under his conduct, as oon as he could, he took long marches, and quartered them within the territories of the Burgundian King; the next day he got up betimes, and marched in uch peed with them, that they all arrived in Lions at night. Ligonias went preently, and cat himelf at the feet of Gondebaut; and gave him a very particular accompt of all paages relating to the defeat of Polemas. This King, extreamly offended at all thee unhappy events, did turn all his anger againt Sigimond, as the principal authour of Polemas his ruine: unto this mut his jealouie be added; for beginning to remember that that flight of Sigimond was not o much to relieve Godomar, as to give ome tetimonies of his love unto Dorinde, his anger turned almot into tark madnee: he tood a long while, and poke not one word: At lat, after five or ix turns in the chamber, this diobedience of Sigimonds, doth mot infinitly dipleae me (aid he) but let me loe the quality of a King, if I do not ere long let him know, that he is no lee unworthy to live, then to bear the name of my on. Upon this he was ilent again; and Ligonias thinking it not fit to ay any thing in Sigimonds defence, till the torm of his anger was over, he looked till upon the ground, until he heard the King begin to peak again. Pray Ligonias tell me (aid he) when Sigimond gave you commiion to bring back my troops, was that ungrateful peron ad or joyful at their departure? I believe Sir, anwered Ligonias, that he was both: for Sir, your anger is a mot ad affliction to him, and I believe he is glad that Amais is delivered from thoe mortal fears which your forces had infued into her: and as an argument of it, when I took my leave of him: farewel Ligonias (aid he unto me) carry back unto the King my Lord and father, thoe men who deerve to be imployed upon better occaions; and becaue I ee him angry with my brother and me, beeech him to pardon us, and tell him it would be much more jut to receive his two ons, as upporters of his Crown, then as the objects of his hatred and arms.

Ligonias delivered this meage in uch a mild and handome manner, as did mot enibly melt the King into compaion; and as violent as his paion was, he could not forget, that thoe whom he accued were uch as he gave being land education unto; yet having a kind of fear that Ligonias had invented what he had told him; I cannot believe (aid he) that any repentance can come from one in whom ingratitude is o predominate: If your Majety do doubt of what I tell you (replied Ligonias) I have that in my hands which will plead my jutification: and conceiving that I could not meet with a better opportunity of preenting a Letter which Sigimond had writ unto him, he took it out of his pocket and kneeling down, preented it unto the King: Gondebaut changed colour two or three times, and was in a great dipute between affection and anger; yet in fine, paternal love prevailing, he received the Letter, in which he found thee words.

body.head: SIGISMONDS Letter unto GONDEBAUT.
body.p: IF the heal of your anger againt me, have not excluded out of your oul all manner of pity, I mot humbly beeech you to look upon thee few lines, and to believe that they are not like me, altogether unworthy of your view. You will find in them abu • dance of grief that afflicts my ad oul for dipleaing you; and if there be any hopes of a pardon, they will not want words expresing my repentance: The truth is, my orrows are much above my crime, but I hope and deire, that both may be below, and lee then your compasion. I will not, my Lord, make any mention of my past actions: It is enough, and too much tha • they have dipleaed you, and it were a kind of a econd crime to offer a jutification: I mot humbly beeech you only to conider, that they are not of o black and horrid a die, as in jutice to merit your hatred and my banihment; yet if if it be your dire doom, I will not murmure againt any of your ordinances: but I dare be o bold as to requet, that the interet of Amais may not be mingled with my digrace. That great Nymph doth deire from you a peace, which her innocence mot jutly merits: and if you hould refue this favour, it is to be feared you would have all the world to fight with, and become your own enemy: It is in your power to remedy all thee diorders in a moment; and by re • eiving the amity of this Princee, you may boat that you have overcome her by the arms of your goodnee. This, Sir, is the lat favour that I will ask of you, but will wait for the return of this Cavalier, who will tell me whether Godomar is to be as mierable as my elf, if no pardon be to be hoped for from you, dipair mut then be the portion of them whom heaven had done a favour unto, if it had never given them life, ince it is the wort of fate to be thrown out of your ervice and affection.

div.p: Whilt Gondebaut read this Letter, Ligonias oberved all his motions, as o well, that he conceived very good hopes in the uccee of his voyage. He aw the King pull out his handkerchief, and wipe his eyes two or three times, afterwards he heard him igh everal times; and at lat, His demands (aid he) are of uch conequence, as I mut think better upon them: to • morrow you hall know my anwer. In aying o, he began to walk up and down the chamber again, and Ligonias would have left him, if Clotilda had not at the ame time entred, unto whom Gondebaut, hewing the Letter of Sigimond, and Ligonias giving her a hort relation of his ervice, he econded the requet of that Cavalier, and had uch a perwaive influence upon the King, as he obtained from him at that very intant, all manner of advantageous promies towards Sigimond and Godomar.

The affairs of Amais and thee Princes were in this condition, whilt Adamas (as I told you before) was with Belinde, and entertaing her with all imaginable Carrees and welcome. He was then walking with her in the great chamber, where Alexis, Diana, Atrea, and Phillis, already were, and almot at the ame time, Ceroinea, Doris, Florice, Palanice, Delphire, Doriea, and others came alo, all whom aluting Belinde, he was even atonihed at their beauties, and handome behaviour. Preently after entred Paris, but with as much joy as Diaana was of repentance, for ever giving him leave to propound a marriage unto her mother.

Whilt they were in the height of their complements, they aw come into the
chamber a Shepherd, who at the firt they knew not: his complexion was as pale as death it elf, his eyes hrunk into his head, upon which hardly a hair was to be een; his cheeks lean, his looks languihing, and his feeble legs, which tetified the weaknee of him that owned them: As oon as he entred, he did his humble reverence unto the Druide, and unto Belinde, who at the firt gave him but a cold reception; but preently after, Adamas looking more attentively upon him: O God (aid he and embraced him) I beeech you are not you Adrates? how comes it to pae you are o oon returned, and o extreamly changed? At the name of Adrastes, all the Shepherdees came about him; and Doris not imagining he would ever return without Palemon, he began at the firt to be much troubled, and to fear he hould never ee him again: following therefore the uggetion of her fears, he approached unto him, and as oon as he had returned an anwer unto the Druide, good Adrastes (aid he unto him) what news of Palemon? The Shepherd then looking upon her with a kind of mile which was mixed with indifferency, better news of him, fair Doris (aid he) then you expect, if at the leat I may judge of your thoughts by the palenee in your cheeks. You may indeed (anwered he) tell me better then I do expect; but if he be not returned with you, I am ure it is impoible it hould be o good as I deire. I wih you could enjoy that contentment, anwered the Shepherd; but ince heaven is yet pleaed to deprive you of that happinee, all I can do for your atisfaction, is to give you an accompt of his actions and mine, ince our departure from you, until the time of my departure from him. Upon this he retired a little, as having a deire to talk with her in private: but Adamas, who perhaps was as full of curioity as he, he tayed him, and aid, that if the news which he was to relate unto Doris, was not of o great a ecrecy, he would be glad to hear it; and the Shepherd, being well dipoed unto it, they all at down, and fixing his languihing looks upon Doris, he began his relation in this manner.

div.head: The Sequel of the Hitory of ADRASTES.
div.p: IF, fair Shepherdee, the ad accidents of my life were not already known unto all about the river Lignon, I hould think my elf obliged to keep my orrows ecret: and as bitter as they have been, and great, yet are they lee then my ilence; but ince it hath pleaed the gods to make my afflictions both in their beginnings and progree, known and bewailed almot by all, I beeech you take it not, if their end have the ame fate that their beginning and continuation had, I do know, that rigour will condemn, as ceremonial, all the paions which I reent; but when you hall know that in their very extremity they cannot dipleae Palemon, it is credible you will be moved unto as much comgaion, as your virtue will permit. May I die, if my ambition ever reached any higher, and if I did not think my elf worthy of the wort of torments, if I hould not meaure my love according to your Devoire and my dicretion. I tell you this, fair Doris, to the end you may know the tate of my oul, and may judge of your beauties power by the quality of my wound, of which I would never be cured, ince the caue of it, which is the life of Palemon, is a thouand times more dear unto me, then all the remedies that can be given me. But to the end you hould not think the affection I bear unto him has any artifice in it, which I would make any ue of to engratiate my elf into your favour, I hall relate unto you ome of my obligations unto him, that you may know how infinitly I am beholding unto his amity, for the favours which I have received from him.

Be pleaed then to know Father (continued he and turned toward Adamas) that the day on which we departed, was the day in which all my contentments died: for I was o extreamly orry to be at uch a ditance from Doris, that I did ever inc, not only loe all my hopes, but alo all delight or deires in my life. I paed over the firt dayes journey in uch a profound melancholly, that Palemon, who thought ome other trange misfortune had befallen me, did ue all his bet
inventions to divert me: but when night came, and he aw that I would not eat any meat, this did exceedingly trouble him, and caued him to get me into a bed, that I might at the leat get ome ret: For his part he eat but a very lender upper; but Halladine, who minded nothing but his own preervation, he did eat like a man that intended to live: and therefore he ate longer at the table then Palemon, who came preently into my chamber, where I was already in bed, he asked me how I did? I that was afraid to trouble him, and aw how adly he reented my condition, I told him, that I was much better then I was the day before, and that fating, with a nights ret, would make me perfectly well again.

I wear unto you dear, Adrates, (aid he unto me) you cannot tell me better news: for I do verily believe, this journey will cot me my life, if your dieae hould encreae: I thanked him for being o enible of my ufferings, and beeeched him not to encreae my trouble by his own, beeeching him to go to bed betimes, becaue we were to go away early the next morning: upon this, Halladine entred, who coming to my bed, and looking a little upon me, he gave us good night, and went to his own bed, where he lept till we waked in the morning. Palemon no ooner aw him laid down, but he whipered me in the eare and aid; This is the happiet man alive, all his care is to pleae a mater that loves him: there is nothing that troubles his mind; and I do not think any thing in the world can diturb him of one minutes ret: Then (aid I unto my elf) alas, alas, Palemon, he is not o happy as thou art, who triumps over my Mitree who loves thee: afterwards I anwered him aloud; 'tis true indeed, Halladine is happy as he deerves, as a jut recompence for his fidelity. Sometimes (aid Palemon the mot faithful are not the mot happy: No, no, aid I unto my elf, for if they were, Adrates hould be as happy as Palemon, for he is as faithful, and yet Doris is none of mine: afterwards I replied aloud, the fault may be in the ingratitude of the maters, which is a thing whereof Halladine cannot accue Damon; for he has more judgement then not to acknowledge his ervices according to their merits.

In uch dicoure as this, we pent near half an hour, after which he asked me, if he was not troubleome unto me, to which I anwered no, but was very glad of his company, and deired that one bed might erve us both during all our journey: o undreing himelf, he was no ooner laid down, but he oberved that I burned as hot as fire, for indeed I had already ome ymptomes of a feaver; and therefore laying one hand upon my bret; O God Adrates (aid he unto me) how you burn? yes, anwered I, my body is in a mot extream heat, but aid I to my elf, this heat is nothing in comparion of that heat which conumes my oul; but (aid he) I am afraid, I hall be too troubleome unto you, and perhaps if I did not lie with you, you would not be o hot but would ret better.
