You cannot, replied I, make my dieae wore then it is, ince (aid I in my elf) to do that, Palemon mut either leave the world, or Doris mut drive me out of it: he talked till on, and I believe, would have talked on till it was day, if to be a little more free in my thoughts, I had not eemed as if I were aleep, and did not for a while anwer him: o as he thinking that I was dipoed to ret, he left talking and fell aleep. For my part, I ended the night as I begun it which was without ever cloing an eye, or finding any eae amongt thoe fretting thoughts, which the happinee of Palemon, and misfortune of Adrates, infued into me: Then did I experimentally find, that of all dieaes there is none that hath o few remedies as love; but this experience did nothing ele but feter my wound, and the more, becaue being out of all hopes ever to be cured, I never durt o much as pretend unto, or look for any comfort. Whilt I was even loing my elf in my own fancies, Palemon waked very often, and becaue he laid his hand every time upon my bret near my heart, cruel friend (aid I in my elf) doft thou doubt whether or no I am till alive, after thou hat taken Doris from me, who is the very oul and life of my heart? afterwards continuing, and faigning till to be aleep: illy man (aid I) to eek for my heart in this bed, as if that beauty who had charms able to ravih it from me, had not charms alo to preerve and keep it.

I was till broad awake, and turmoiled with thee fretting thoughts when the night began to vanih, and Palemon wakening took notice that day began to dawn: At the firt he durt not peak for fear of diturbing me: which I perceiving, I eemed to awake alo; and therefore be cating his eyes upon me, though he could not perfectly ee me, he told me, that I was very retlee all the night long; to which I anwered, that indeed the night was not very delightfull unto me, but that it had enabled me to continue on our intended deign; In aying o, I got up, and Palemon doing the like, we wakned Halladine, and departed before the un was up: This fit of a feavour which I had, beides my natural complexion, which was never good, did make me look o pale and meager, that Palemon could not chue but tell me, that it was my bet coure to return, and that our journey being long, I was never able to go through with it, ince I found my elf o ill the firt day; but I, who deired no better Fate then to die by the way, did o contend with him, that he was forced to yield unto my deires of going forward, and o we came to Lions: unto which we were no ooner come, but Palemon knowing that it could not be a ingle fit of a feavour that could caue in me uch a profound melancholly, he took me aide in a chamber, and itting both down upon a bed, he ued this dicoure which I hall relate unto you, that I may not omit the leat circumtance relating unto the interet of Doris and me: and o he began it thus.

Dear Adrastes (aid he unto me) I beeech you pardon me, if I be o inquiitive as to ask you what the caue is, which makes you o extreamly melancholly and ad? I know very well that you are omething indipoed, and that travel may omething trouble you; but I cannot believe it poible all this can caue you to be of o ullen a temper. If any memory of the lat ad accident which hapned unto you be the caue of it, and if that thought do nourih a orrow in it, for not being alwayes in your perfect enes, I beeech you conider, that uch a orrow ought not to trouble your mind, by reaon of your joyes at your perfect recovery: beides, that were to grumble at the will of heaven, which was pleaed to deprive you of your reaon only for a time, to render you afterwards a more eminent meaure of it: I heartily beeech you my dearet Adrates, to tell me what it is which troubles you: I do conjure you unto it, by the torments which I uffer to ee you o adly afflicted; by the affection which I bear unto you, and which I deire you hould bear unto me, I beeech you do not hide the caue of it from me, and to believe, that if it do lie within the compae of my power to apply any remedy unto it, I will not pare my own contentment, or my life, to procure it. This was the firt dicoure that Palemon and I had of it, unto which I anwered in thee terms.

It does grieve me extreamly, my dear Palemon, to ee that my malady is o contageous, and that my orrows hould be any caue of yours: I wih for your own contentment, that you had lee compaion of me, and wih for my own ake, that I were lee enible then I am; but ince you your elf do confee it extream imprudence to grumble at the will and pleaure of heaven, I think that you are no lee to blame in taking o much pains to know my dieae, then I hould be, did I hope ever to be cured of it: Therefore, dear Palemon, I do mot heartily beeech and conjure you, even by that which you love bet, to ceae all this improfitable care which you take for my preervation, and not to mingle my bitter orrows with thoe contentments which heaven does give you. I poke this with uch an accent, that Palemon was moved to drop ome tears: in fine, embracing me, my dear Adrates (aid he unto me) why will you till offer to conceal that, which pale looks do force you to tell me: if it be becaue you know me unable to remedy your miery, do not dicover it unto me, as unto a Phyician, from whom you expect ome remedies; but tell them unto me, as unto a friend, who will be ready to leen your pain by partaking of it with you: I anwered, that the argument which he ued to induce me unto it, was the only thing which retrained me, ince I loved his contentment o much, as I would never conent that the relation of my mieries hould ever make him a harer in them. But in concluion, Palemon was fully reolved to know the caue of my affliction, or
ele never to let me ret in quietnee: Adrates (aid he unto me) or rather my brother, for I will never uffer you to call me otherwie, I do once more conjure you, even by my affection, and by the love that you hear unto Doris, to eae my mind of that impatiency which is caued by your ilent reervednee; and to believe, that if any man living can give you any comfort in your miery, I will rather die then uffer any other but my elf to do you that good office. I mut needs confee, Father, that at the name of Doris all my blood did rie, and now thinking it a crime againt her not to atisfie the deires of Palemon, being conjured unto it by her name: Dear Palemon (replied I) you have uch a commanding influence over me, that you may obtain any thing in my power; and you not ue any other aeverations by your command, and therefore I will no longer defer the atisfaction of your deires; for I know that it were a crime punihable to oppoe whatoever you deire. Let me tell you therefore in the firt place, that I do mot gladly accept of that alliance which you offer unto me; and next, I do mot ingeniouly confee, that the very ame thing by which you have conjured me to dicover my grief unto you, is the only thing which is the caue of my griefs: Do not wonder, dear brother, to hear me ay, that though I do love Doris, yet I love Palemon too; and that though my affection unto her be never o great, yet it is not able to make me forget thoe repects which I do ow unto you.

I would it had pleaed God (continued I) that the firt day my eye ever aw her, had been the lat of my life, as it was of all my happinee and tranquillity: then hould I have avoided a thouand deaths by uffering one, and hould not, as now I do, be forced to nourih a flame, which burns, but does not conume me: Believe it Palemon, the arrow that firt wounded me, was hot from the fair eyes of Doris; but it was hot by the hand of a God, which did communicate part of his own Nature into it, and made my wound immortal: and therefore it is, that though I do depair of any cure, yet mut I needs love the hand that gave me the blow, and do know, that it is much eaier to ceae living, then not to love that dear caue.

Fair Doris (continued Adrates and turned towards her) your dear Palemon heard all this without any interruption, and without taking his eyes off mine; and when I aw him till look and not ay a word, I perceive (aid I upon a udden) that my love, as much tempered as it is with dicretion, does make an impreion in you, and that you cannot endure the continuation of it without very great impatience; and therefore, to top your jealouie and my own torments both at once, it is mot jut I do ruine my elf, and betimes rid you of a man, whoe preence will be alwayes a heart-burning unto you. Upon this, I leaped off the bed where I at, and ran to take my word which lay upon the table, my intention being to go out of the houe, and afterwards to end my ad dayes in ome olitary place, where the Sun hould never daign to look upon me: But Palemon, who aw me in uch a fury, and feared let I hould do my elf ome harm, he fell upon me, and took my word out of my hands, I making no great reitance, for I was o very weak, as I was hardly able to utain my elf. He began preently to chide me for my rahnee, and ued uch handome arguments, as he qualified my mind unto his own will; and as I was till hinting unto him, how impoible it was my affection unto Doris hould not dipleae him: that, brother (aid he unto me) were indeed very true, if I did not very well know her virtue and dicretion. But on the contrary, I do deire that you hould love her, and to aure your elf that your affection hall never trouble me. Upon this, he took me about the neck: Come, come (aid he) love her till, perhaps heaven will have pity upon you, and will one day permit you to poee that place, which I confee I have in a manner tyrannically uurped from you: I wih to heaven it were now in my power to transfer her unto you; if it were, I wear the condition wherein you are, and have been for her ake, does move me unto o much pity, that he hould be the wife of Adrates, and the iter of Palemon. As he aid o he embraced me mot kindly, and bedewing my cheeks with his tears: Not but dearet brother (continued he) my love unto her is infinitly
beyond all my expreions; but I mut confee, that my compaion of you is not of a lee degree.

I tood a while without returning any anwer but in ighs; at the lat eeing that he aid nothing unto me, I were extreamly ungrateful, replied I, if I did not the ame thing for you which you would do for me. Therefore, Palemon, live for ever, unto Doris may you be happy, in the enjoyment of her many years, and as long as I hall my misfortunes; and be aured of this, that he hall be the iter of Adrates, as long as he hall be the wife of Palemon. Upon this, I graped him in my arms a long while; at lat we parted, for uch a coldnee eized upon me at the ame time, that without his aitance, I could not get my elf to bed. At the firt, Palemon did not know my dieae; but when he aw me vomit up abundance of green and yellow water, he conceived that a fit of my feaver had eized upon me: He ent preently for a Phyician, who was no ooner entred into the chamber; but he ate down in a chair by my bed ide, where after two or three coughs, and a uperilious pit, he took my arm and felt my pule; then began to conider upon the quality of my dieae. Preently after, he asked me whether or no, I had been exceive in any thing; to which I innocently anwered, that I had never been exceive in any thing but love; but he who put a wrong contruction upon my meaning: that (aid he unto me) is very dangerous, epecially at this time, now the canicular dayes approach: Afterwards, coughing two or three times again, I oberved that Palemon took him aide, and as I undertood afterwards, did infue a better opinion of me into him then he bad conceived, and gave him a particular exact accompt of all the accidents that had hapned unto me; after the Phyician was better intructed, he came unto me: Well, well Sir, aid he, take courage, we will not precribe you any thing until to morrow. when we have een the tate of your dieae: mean time, eat but little, nay nothing till your fit be pat, or at leat pat the violence of it: Palemon promied to be very careful in eeing his directions oberved, and waited upon him down the tairs. Halladine in the interime, came to my beds ide, and began to ue ome arguments of diwading me from continuing the journey, when Palemon preently returned, who joyning his arguments and entreaties unto Halladines, did conjure me not to think any more of keeping them company; not (aid he) that I do intend to leave you, for if your dieae continue, I will not go away until you be perfectly recovered; but the reaon why I diwade you, is becaue I ee you altogether unable to perform o long a journey without extream prejudice to your elf. Halladine, who heard Palemon ay that he would not depart untill I was perfectly recovered; but Palemon (aid he unto him) do you not conider, that whilt we tay for the recovery of Adrates, we hall loe the opportunity of our imbarkment, we mut of neceeity take the time when it is, and not carry till a tempetuous reaon hinder us from executing our intended deigne. I knew he aid truly, and therefore told Palemon, that the next morning we might go in a boat unto the Town of the Mailians, and when we were there, I might take ea or return, as I found my elf in a condition; they approved of my propoition; but to be hort, I was not able to go any further: for my feaver continued, and the Phyician, who viited me the next morning, aured me, that without extream danger of my life, I mut not take the water; but that it was far better for me to tay there, where I might be accomodated with all things requiite and pertinent to my dieae: it was therefore determined amongt us, that I hould tay at Lions; and becaue Palemon and Halladine could not any longer defer their departure, and my feaver grew wore and wore, Palemon came unto my bed ide, and with tears in his eyes, ued this language. Now my dear Adrates I am ready to depart, or rather ready to die; for I cannot call our eparation a life, epecially, ince I mut leave you in o ad a condition; but I beeech you conider, that were I not by oath obliged unto this voyage, nothing in the world could make me undertake it: I call the gods to witnee how orry I am to leave you, and may they punih me to eternity, if it be not be oret dipleaure I ever received: could I devie any pretence to excue my elf from my oath concerning Celidea, I would make ue of it; but certainly there is no evaion,
and doubtlee, heaven would punih either you, or me, or both, hould I perjure my elf: you ee then, dear brother, how impoible it is to avoid this departure, and how I am obliged to the performance of my promie, and I hope you will not condemn me for it, though I leave you in a condition that requires the aitance of all your friends.

Palemon ued thee expreions, with uch a deep reentment of my condition, as I knew he loved me; and therefore turning my languihing eyes towards him, and putting one of my hands out of bed, I took his, and graping it as hard as I could, go dear Palemon (aid I unto him) and endeavour the cure of Celidea: continue on your journey without being troubled at me: for I know I cannot urvive our eparation one day; and therefore I conjure you to bid me your lat adieu, and receive this kie, as the lat tetimony of my affection. O Heavens, dear Adrates (aid he unto me) why will you blat me to death with uch ad news; have you not courage enough to overcome the violence of a feaver, which will lat no longer then you harbour ome ill humour in your body to nourih it? Though I had the means to cure it, anwered I, yet I have no will unto it, for I am o extreamly weary of living, that a doom of death is the mot welcome news unto me.

But, Father, why hould I trouble you any longer with a tedious relation, it is ufficient Doris knows, how Palemon perwaded me o far, as to promie him two things: The firt, that I would do all I could for the recovery of my health; and the other, that as oon as I was recovered, I would return unto our flocks, and give Doris a Letter which he left with me. Thus Halladine and he, after a thouand embraces, ighs, tears, and adieus, did take ea; and left me in the hands of a Phyician, who ince their departure, never left me, unlee when upon extream neceity, he went to ee ome other ick peron. My feavor continued above a fortnight, after which, it was not o violent; and though I tood not in need of any more Phyick, yet my Phyician aw me every day, until I was perfectly recovered, and in a condition to return back: every time he came to viit me, he brought me ome news; it was he that firt told me of the iege of Marcelles, and of the flight of Sigimond; by him I undertood that Gondebaut had ent an army unto Polemas, which troubled me o much, that had I been able to travel, I had gone then unto Sigimond, who was then in Vienna, and as they aid, raiing an Army to relieve Godomar his brother. The lat time he took the pains to ee me, he told me that the iege was raied, and that Lindamor had killed Polemas; at which I was o exceedingly rejoyced, as I believe it did perfectly recover me. And indeed, after I had taken my leave of my Phyician, and thanked him for his particular care of me, I went from Lions, and by the way found all his relations true, for I met a party of thoe Souldiers which Gondebaut had ent againt Amais.
After this, Adrates held his peace, and preented unto Doris that Letter which Palemon ent unto her, which he opening, found inerted thee words.

body.head: PALEMONS Letter unto DORIS.
body.p: THe concernment which I have in the preervation of Adrates, moves me to ue all manner of remedies, that are conducible to this cure. And becaue I know that your affection is the bet I can imploy; you must, dear Doris, love him, ince he does deerve it, and ince I would have it o: your virtue keeps me from precribing any limits unto this love: yet, let under pretence of honour, you hould treat him lee kindly then I deire, I would have your amity to him, no les then unto a brother: Prepare your elf therefore to give me this contentment: and conider that in o doing, you will preerve two who ought to be mot dear unto you: I mean, the life of Adrates, and the contentment of Palemon.

div.p: She had no ooner read this Letter, but he changed colour, which the Druide perceiving: fair Doris (aid he) why do you bluh, certainly there is omething in that Letter which nearly concerns you: Nothing of uch near concernment, anwered he, which I hall not mot willingly hew unto you: if I did bluh, it was at the deire of Palemon, who commands me to love Adrates, as if I could without a crime have any favourable inclination unto any whooever: Adamas then taking the Letter and reading it: I protet, replied he, the thing he deires is o jut, that you are much to blame if you deny it unto him: and for my part, I do advie you to give him that contentment which he deires, ince he eems to be o much concerned in the life of Adrates, that perhaps he would love you lee, if you hould uffer him to die.

Thee words, together with that eteem which Doris had of Adrates, had uch an influence upon her humour, that he permitted him to love her as his iter, promiing him to value him in the degree of a brother. Upon this, Adrates roe up to kie her hand, by way of thanks, for that favour; but he was prevented by the coming in of a very fair Shepherdee, who at the ame time came into the room, took him about the neck and kied him. This alute did a little urprize him; and the more, becaue he knew not who it was that eemed o kind unto him: uppoing then that he had mitaken him for another, he recoiled two or three paces, whilt his amazment would not permit him to peak a word; but the Shepherdee following him: Is it poible Adrates (aid he unto him) that you hould have done me o great favour and yet not know me. Adamas did think he knew the voice; yet thinking it o improbable it hould be her whom he thought upon, he looked upon her very attentively: Adrates then, he hrugged his houlders; fair Shepherdee (aid he unto her) I beeech you do not wonder, that I hould not know you: for I have been o long ignorant of my elf, as I am partly pardonable, if I do not remember that ever I had the honour to ee you. Yes, replied he, you have een me in Marcelles, and upon the banks of Lignon; but though you have forgotten me, yet perhaps Atrea, and Diana, will remember me: In aying o, he went unto them, who received her very civilly, but with as much amazment as Adrates: at which this unknown Shepherdee, miling, O heavens (cryed he out) was ever the like known? Is it poible you hould all, ince this very morning, forget Celidea? Upon that name, all the Shepherdees began to look earnetly upon her, and upon one another: At lat, remembring that Palemon and Halladine were gone about her cure; and calling to mind the features of her face before he poiled it; they knew her, and rejoyced with her, for the recovery of her former beauty: It was long before they did any thing ele but embrace each other; whilt Adamas made an exact relation unto Belinde of the lat accident which befel this fair Shepherdee; and at lat, going to her, fair Celidea (aid he unto her) hall we not know in what manner you have been cured: for the remedy had uch a udden operation, as I cannot chue but wonder at it, epecially when I conider, that though you were yeterday as much disfigured as ever, yet this day you are as fair and handome as ever you were before: Father, anwered the Shepherdee, with a countenance that poke her contentment: I cannot poibly tell you how it was done, for truly I my elf do not know further then this, that this morning, after Thamires was gone out of the chamber to walk with Silvander and the ret of the Shepherds, I aroe out of my bed, and itting before my glae dreing my elf, I oberved within a quarter of an hour, that I did not look o ugly as ordinarily I did: and eeing that every minute my complexion came more and more into my cheeks, and that my cratches healed very fat; I did imagine, that this might happily be an effect of thoe good hopes which Damon made me conceive. I ate thus the pace of an hour, and every time I cat my eye upon my glae I found ome change in my elf. In fine, eeing my elf in a better condition then ever I was before, and thinking it a mot arrogant preumption if I hould expect to be better, ince I had already obtained more then ever I hoped for, I finihed the dreing of my elf, and going down the tairs, I no ooner heard that Adrates was returned, but being even ravihed with joy to ee my elf o handome, I could not chue but come
and Carree him by way of gratitude, for the benefit which I had received, whereof he was partly the caue.

Thus Celidea related all that he knew concerning her cure, whilt Adrates was talking with Doris: Dearet iter (aid he unto her) you need not now enquire any further concerning Palemons journey: the face of Celidea tells you, that hitherto it hath been properous, and that all we have to do, is to wih him a afe return. Truly (aid he) there is a great probability in what you ay: yet for all that I cannot chue but be full of faint fears, becaue he is to return by ea, which as they ay, is a mot cruel and mercilee element. Doubtlee, replied Adrates, Fortune will look upon with a miling eye, and will never uffer him to feel the effects of her incontancy, the glory that he has to enjoy you, is a mot evident argument of it. In aying o, he ighed very loud: which Doris oberving, and doubting that his ighs were parks of the fire which he entertained in his oul, he was in ome ort moved not unto love but pity. Wondering therefore to ee his paion hould urvive his hopes, he was once in a mind to advie him to place his affection upon ome, from whom he might expect more recompence; but conceiving, that this perhaps might more open his wound and feter it, he choe rather not to mention it, but leave it unto the dipoition of time, which often proves the bet remedy againt uch dieaes: o he left off that dicoure, and making a ign unto the Shepherd, that he deired to hear what Adamas aid concerning Celidea, he leaned his eare that way, and heard the Druide peak in this manner.

It is to be thought that Thamires will not be a little joyed to ee you in this condition, ince he was uch a paionate deirer of it. I believe Father (anwered Celidea) that his joy will not be a little at it; but I believe alo, that it will not lat long, ince that which is the caue of it, is but a glance, a flah, called beauty, and cannot continue in me long, becaue it is a tribute which we do ow, and mut pay, unto a few years, which will be ure to imprint wrinkles upon the fairet cheek. However it be, replied Adamas I hall ere long ee him enjoy that contentment; and ince he knows nothing yet of your cure, I would advie to deceive him a little.

Th • s was no ooner conented unto, but Thamires entred with Alcander, Sileines, Lucindor, Calidon, Licidas, Thomantes, Hylas, and ome others. As oon as they came into the room, they aluted Belinde; but Adamas took Thamires by the hand, carried him to Celidea, and made him believe, that it was her iter whom Belinde brought with her. Thamires was the more apt to believe it, becaue indeed Celidea had a iter, and becaue he found in her face the very ame features which formerly he adored in his Mitree. He went therefore unto her, and after a hundred thouand welcomes, he asked her whether he had yet een Celidea. This fair Shepherdee could not chue but mile at this, and was upon the point to peak; but the Druide, fearing left he hould know her voice, he interpoed, and told him, that truly he had een her, but tayed not long with her, becaue he was not well, and therefore left her to her ret. This did much trouble Thamires, in o much, as leaving the company, he went into the chamber where he thought Celidea was, The firt thing he did when he came at the door, was to hearken whether he could hear her complain; but hearing nothing, he went to the bed whoe curtains were all cloe; and hardly daring to breath, let he hould make too much noie; he endeavoured to make it little lighter, that he might ee her face.

Adamas, in the mean time, who followed him held Celidea by the hand, and eeing Thamires o buie, he could not chue but laugh: which the Shepherd perceiving; you laugh, perhaps (aid he) to ee me look for Celidea, whom you have hid in ome other place. Hide her (aid the Druide) no, I do bring her unto you in a better condition then ever he was. Thamires was amazed at this, and could not undertand his meaning; but Celidea taking him about the neck and kiing him; what Thamires (aid he unto him) do you make o little accompt of the preent that is brought you, that you will not o much as thank the bringer? To what purpoe were you o careful to ee me in my firt beauty, ince
now it is is brought unto you, you will not o much as know it? This voice did perfectly undeceive Thamires; and taking her in his arms, O Damon (aid he) how infinitly am I obliged unto thee for this favour? In aying o, he began a new to kie her, ometime her mouth, ometimes her cheeks, and ometimes her eyes; and probably, he had longer continued the expreions of his love and contentment, had he not though himelf obliged alo to thank the Druide, who thought it fit, that before the day was done, he hould go unto Marcelles to give thanks unto Damon, and render him an accompt of Celideas cure.

Thamires prepared himelf for that journey; and Adamas, not knowing what was become of Silvander, asked aloud how he did; and Hylas taking upon him to peak for all the Shepherds, did anwer, that he left him in the company of Tircis, and that as he thought, they were dicouring upon ome buinee of great importance: The Druide asked whether he knew the ubject of their dicoure, and Hylas in a miling manner anwered: Father (aid he) I do not certainly know the ubject, but probably their dicoure harps upon the old melancholly tring; and Silvander, who as they ay can Philoophize upon the ribs of a Gnat, or the beard of a Mandrake, is, perhaps, perwading omething which the other cannot eaily vndertand.

Belinde was well pleaed to hear him talk in that manner; for he had heard tell of his humours, and therefore to make him the freer in his dicoure, he addreed her elf unto him, and aid, that he had formerly heard of all the paages in the love of Tircis and Cleon; but he admired at nothing o much, as at the paionate humour of that Shepherd in till doting upon the cold ahes of his dead Mitree.

Sage Belinde (anwered Hylas) were that fine judge here who condemned Laonice, he would by his Sophitry make you believe, that he hould in extreamly againt the Laws of Love, if he did keep that affection inviolable, but this Leon he did not learn in my chool: It is a mot groe and aburd ignorance, and the wore, becaue it has no ground, and becaue there is no Law which commands us to love that which is not; but this contancy which he o much cries up, and would fain make a goddee, and erect altars unto it, is that which makes him maintain all thee fond opinions, and infect this Province with a doctrine, which ought to be condemned by all thoe that love liberty and quietnee. I wih he were here (replied Belinde) for beides the eteem I have of his merit, I would gladly know what he would anwer unto your dicoure of him. Madam (aid Hylas) were he here, Lignon would ooner leave running then his tongue; and the devil on it is, beides his mot pernicious doctrine in matter of Love, he can o gloe over his arguments with fluent eloquence, as almot all are charmed with it.

With uch dicoure as this, Adamas, Belinde, and the ret, paed away the time, until dinner was ready: whilt Silvander, who was indeed walking with Tircis, and uing all the arguments he could poibly device to divert that ad Shepherd from his intention of leaving Forret; but all his arguments and reaons would not do: for this poor deolate man was weary of having o many witnees of his melancholly, and was fixed to his reolution, imagining that now the banks of Lignon were likely to have too many delightful objects, to ute with his ad temper; and therefore, as oon as he met Silvander in a place convenient for his dicoure, he aid thus unto him.

It is needlee for me, age Silvander, to tell you the ubject of my affliction, becaue you do already know a great part of it; and therefore I will only acquaint you with my deign of eeking out my bet conveniency, to render what I ow unto the memory of my dear Cleon. You know, however, ince the judgement which you pronounced in my favour, againt the importunities of Laonice, I have been perecuted by her, until I heard from her own mouth, the Treaon which by way of revenge he intended to ue againt you, and againt Phillis; and then I began to be o extreamly incened againt her, as immediately upon it he forook Forrets. And certainly it was well he did, for I verily believe, I hould have trangreed what I ow unto her ex. to have done her ome ignal dipleaure. Now
being, rid of this troubleome woman, who I hated as I doe a divil, and deiring never to meet with her again, I am reolved to retire my elf into ome olitary place, where none can come to interrupt my meditations, nor divert mee from expreing my fidelity unto my dear Cleon. I mut confes my elf ahamed to depart with out bidding my lat adieu unto Adamas, and the ret of the hephards of my acquaintance; But I hope, dear Silvander that you will excue mee to them, and move them rather to pitty my misfortunes, then to bee angry with me for my faults: Upon this Tircis held his peace, and Silvander having oberved what he aid concerning the treaon of Laonice, he beeeched him for a relation of it: which Tircis did; And Silvander admiring at the artifice which he had invented to revenge her elf, he learned alo at the ame time what was the caue of Dianas anger, which Phillis had o ubtily diembled. This ign of jealouie in his Mitres, was unto him a main argument of her affection: And though this contentment was enough to take up all his thoughts, yet he did put Tircis in mind of the little reaon that he had to abent himelf from a place where every one loved him, and to go and live in a deart, where will beats were ready every minute to devoure him.

But the poor dejected man in leiu of being moved by his reaons; The cruelty of thoe beats (anwered he) cannot torment me o much, as that vat number of cares which continually afflicts me: uch is my depaire as it makes me love any thing that is likely to advance my end; and I wih with all my heart, I might without offence doe the ame office my elf. Thou hould't then know Cleon, how little value I doe et upon my blood; and thou houldet ee how oon I would preent thee with the oul of Tircis which languiheth in a torment ten thouand times wore then any death, in taying untill I ee thee, and have the honour to enjoy the heaven of thy imbraces with out diturbance. In aying o, his eyes which he lifted up towards heaven, began to flow with tears; at which Silvander was o much moved, as he was not able to retrain his, and whilt he topped the coure of them with his handkerchief he thought upon the contancy of Tircis, and afterwards making reflections upon himelf, he conidered in what a ad condition he hould be, if by the like accident, he hould loe Diana. Thus they tood a while with out uttering one word, but walked together in the wood: At lat Silvander broke ilence: I doe find dear Tircis (aid he unto him) That your reentments are o jut: as nothing in your adnes can be condemned, but that exces of it which moves you unto a deire to leave us: For having contracted here ome habitudes which may conduce much unto your quietnes, I conceve, that unles you be an enemy unto your elf, you cannot part from us: The way of our lives is weet, our converation not at all babarous: and if any evill hould happen unto you, there is no place in the world where you can find better helps then amongt us. My quietnes, replied Tircis, depends upon the lat munite of my life, which cannot come o oon as it is deired, and Cleon, who doubles loves me more then ever he did, does blame me for being o long from her: I beeech you therfore even by that with is mot dear unto you, not to take it ill, if I follow my firt reolution, and that you take o much pains as to aure Adamas, and all thoe unto whom my name is known, that what place oever my fate does guide me, I hall mot inviolably preerve the memory of their courtiies.

But (aid Silvander) I beeech you tell me whither you intend to go, that we may ometimes have the happines to hear from you; and let you know the paages upon the banks of Lignon. It will be hard for me (replied the diconolate hepheard) to tell you that which I do not know my elf. I hall confine my elf to the woods and rocks, where I hall not merit the honour of your memory; and where I preume you will not betow any thoughts upon an object o dipleaing as mine: In aying o, he embraced Silvander, and Silvander doing the like unto him; May you even (aid he) find full atisfaction unto all your deires: And may you Silvander, (replied Tircis) ever enjoy thoe favours, and that happines which heaven owes unto your merit. Upon this they parted; and Tircis wandering into the woods, not knowing which way to take, Silvander went towards
the houe of Adamas; He did not yet know the ad news with the return of Paris brought unto him; and had been longer ignorant of it, if Lucinder, by fortune walking with a young man, who brought him the news from Lyons, had not informed him of it as very welcome news; He told him alo of Bellinde; and that hepheard, who preently began to upect the caue of their coming, was o damped at it, that he could not chue but let his orrows appear in his face; yet he did conceal from that Cavelier, the caue of his reentment, and leat knowing of Bellindes coming, they hould tax him with incivility if he did not go and preent his ervice unto her; he gave a check unto thoe thoughts which perwaded him, that ince her coming was only about the contentment if Paris, he ought to fly from her preence: He went therefore into the houe, where Bellinde receved him with extraordinary kindnes: And ince he was come, dinner was brought up, and all the Company at down at the Table.

Dinner was no ooner done; but Alcander, Silenies, and Lucindor, reolved to leave forrets, and go unto the bankes of Arar, and there reap thoe weet contentments which they expected from the enjoyment of their Mitrees, Cercenea, Palanice, and Florice, were eaily perwaded therunto; and therefore, as oon as they roe from the table, they went unto Adamas; And after a thouand wel-expreed complements of thanks, for his love, and civilities to them, they bad adieu unto him, and all the ret if the Company, and eemed very orry to part. Florica, Circenea, and Palanice; could not retrain their tears, when they took their leaves of Alexis, Diana, Atrea, epecially Phillis, unto whom they thought themelves mot particularly obliged for drawing them out of thoe perplexities, in which the Oracle had long held them; yet conidering that they came not thither to tay always there, after they had obtained the end of their coming, they bad their adieus with les regret, and et forwards, notwithtanding the earnet entreaties of Adamas to tay longer at his houe. Thaumantes, Delphire, Doriea, and the ret of that Company, not thinking to find a fairer day for their return into their everal habitations, from which they had been o long abent, they alo deired the Druides leave to be gone; unto which he conenting, becaue he would tay them no longer from the pleaure of eeing their friends and flocks, he heartily beeeched them to viit him ometimes, and proteted they hould be mot heartily wellcome unto him; the heapheards gave him a thouand thanks, and after they had taken leave of all the Company, they departed extreamly well atisfied with the Druides entertainment of them, and thoe fair hepherdees whom they left in his houe.

Alexis was not a little glad of their departure, becaue he thought that now he could with les contraint enjoy the carees of Atrea, and talk of her paion: But Silvander, who hoped to find better opportunities of talk with Diana, amongt uch a multitude of Company, he was very orry for their departure, and heartily deired they would have tayed longer at the Druides deires. In the mean time Adamas, who could not forget his reolution not to let the day pas before he had undeceived Atrea, as oon as he had rendred all civilities unto thoe that went from his houe, he went into his garden, where after two or three turns, thinking what coure he had bet take to bring his intention to pas; he caued Leonide to be called; and communicated his deign unto her. After this, he carried her into his cloet, and having made choice amongt his books of one which he thought mot fit for the ue he did intend it, he put it into the hands of his Neece and directed her what to doe, and how he hould carry her elf to make Celadon happy in his dear Atrea; The Nimph did promie to obey him mot faithfully: and returning into the great Chamber he addreed her elf unto Alexis who was talking with Silvander and Atrea, whilt Diana was puzled to find out anweres unto the dicoure of Paris: For though he gave him but cold entertainement yet he did not tick • to hy them unto her: Can any wih, fairet Diana to be more happy then I am, ince the Gods are pleaed to let me enjoy her whom of all the world I love bet? I cannot tell, anwered Diana (very faintly) whom you mean, But I doe not wonder at your good fortune, for it cannot be better then you deerve: My meaning is (replied Paris) that the
gods have aured me by their Oracle, that you mut be mine, and that's the reaon why I am o full of joy: for to tell you mot truly, my affection unto you i mot violent, and of all the favours that heaven can hower upon me, none can be more dear unto me, then the honour to enjoy you. Diana then cating her eye upon Silvander, who had fixed his upon her: That (aid he with a deep igh) is the leat of ten thouand, and I cannot chue but wonder you hould take the pains to look after it: I am o mean a thing in comparion of you, that the diproportion affrights me, and hinders me from any joy in that, from whence any other then my elf, would draw a happinee. O Diana (aid Paris) do not in o much, as to eteem your elf o little, whoe beauty and perfections are uch, as merit ten thouand times better then my elf.

Could I dipoe of Scepters and Empires, as freely as I can of that etate which the affection of a Father will confer upon me, I wear, my fairet Diana, I hould humbly cat them at your feet; and hould be as prodigal of them as I am of my liberty: See, replied Diana, how the gods are pleaed to mingle bitters with the weets of our lives; ince in ordaining me to be yours, they will not let my conent go along with them: but will have that honour which would accrue unto me by your alliance, to be accompanied with my orrows, that I can have no inclination unto it. How? (aid Paris much atonihed) I beeech you from whence proceeds this repugnancy? Did not you freely conent that I hould go and ask Belindes conent unto our marriage? I mut needs ay (anwered Diana) that I did o far conent unto your eeming deires of having it o, not remembring that Atrea and I, had made a vow never to part from one another: Now ince your departure, it hath o fallen out, that he has an intention to go and live amongt the Carnates: o as I being more obliged unto her then unto you, I mut needs follow her, and have engaged my elf to no kind of life, but what he lives.

I cannot tell, aid Paris, how heaven will dipoe of Astrea; but I am ure, that unlee you do openly infringe the doom of your Detiny, you cannot oppoe your elf againt that happinee which I beg from you: Come, come, my fairet, you mut give your elf unto Paris, as Paris does mot inviolably vow never to be anyes but Dianas. In aying o, he took her hand, and lifting it unto his mouth againt her will, alas continued he, how unfortunate hould I be, if in leiu of the highet happinee I can ever wih, I hould find all my hopes blated? has any of my actions, dearet Diana, offended you? If I have inned, let me know wherein, for I have courage enough to punih my elf, and love enough to make you atisfaction. Upon this he leaned towards her, and Diana, who for all her good will unto Silvander, could not hate Paris. The greatet fault which you have committed (anwered he) is againt your elf, in addreing your elf unto one, in whom you cannot find any thing anwerable unto your merits, I wih you had placed your thoughts upon ome more noble object then my elf; for as there you would find more honour, o alo would you meet with more contentment: not but that I do et a high rate of eteem upon you, and value you as your virtue and quality deerves; but I mut needs confee, that I hould think my elf infinitly obliged unto you, if you would ceae this addree unto me, and not oppoe that earnet deire which I have of going with Atrea, and ending my dayes amongt the profeed Virgins.

Paris was ready to reply when one came unto him from Adamas, who was in his cloet with Belinde; o as uppoing that he was ent for to treat concerning this match, he aid nothing unto Atrea but this; your Fate and mine, fairet Diana, are in the hands of thoe who can dipoe of us, and I believe you will think it a crime to diobey them: for my part, I am fully reolved to oberve whatoever they hall ordain concerning me. In aying o, he kied her hand, and went to the place where Adamas and Belinde tayed for him. Silvander no ooner aw him out of the chamber, but he left Alexis, Leonede, and Atrea, and came unto Diana, but o dejected in his countenance, as if he would have died. Firt he fell down upon his knees, becaue none remained in the room whom he mitruted, and cating his eyes upon Dianas, which tood already in water; well,
my fairet Mitree (aid he unto her) now am I utterly undone. Belinde is now come; Paris is all joy, in hopes ere long to enjoy you: Dianas deires are now accomplihed, and poor Silvanders hopes quite blated. O heavens! anwered Diana, why will you wound me to the oul o mortally? Is it not enough that I am contrained to uffer the Tyranny of a Mother, and that I languih in the mot affliction ever poor woman endured, but you, Silvander, mut grieve me more by your upitions, and think me guilty of a miery which is to befal us? My upitions (anwered Silvander faintly) were turned into aurances, that very minute you firt permitted Paris to make his addrees to you, it was an eaie matter to judge, that his quality would win upon the will of Belinde, and that the honour of being the on of Adamas, was of it elf ufficient to make him merit that happinee which he is going to enjoy; but Diana, I do wih you all joy, at the rate of my own miery: may you long live contented in the enjoyment of my rival: betow upon his quality, that which my love might very well obtain; if I do murmure, it hall not be againt you. Heaven had been unjut, had it endued you with more fidilety: it is not fit you hould be the conquet of a Vagabond, a Stranger, a mierable wretch, upon whom the Stars have hot their mot malignant influences: Paris only is worthy to poee you, not becaue he loves you more, but becaue he is more rich and more fortunate then I. The lat entence which mut doom me unto him, replied Diana, is not yet pronounced, and I do promie you to put as many obtacles, as my duty will in any handomnee give me leave: I have already told him, that I had made a vow to confine my elf unto the Carnates, and that I could, with lee violence upon my elf, execute that deign, then receive his alliance; but he protets he undertands from an Oracle, that I mut infallibly be his: that I confee does mot trouble me, becaue if it be the decree of the gods, I am afraid all our endeavours are not able to thwart it. I alo mut confee (aid Silvander) that it were an impardonable piece of folly in me, to deire a happinee, which by eternal decree is forbidden me: The gods cannot lye; and ince they have ordained that Diana mut marry Paris, and that Silvander mut die, it is mot jut we hould ubmit unto their wills. I will go therefore, fairet Diana, and eek out ome means to obey them, and deliver my elf all at once from thoe mieries which perecute me: In aying o, he roe up; but the Shepherdee laying hold upon him, whither will you go Silvander, aid he unto him? will you offer to attempt any thing againt my contentment? your love unto me ought to be above all other coniderations, and you can by no Law be dipened from that obedience which you ow unto me; The Law which bids me depair (anwered Silvander) ought to be the mot inviolable, becaue it is mot utable unto the will of the gods: Their intention is, that I hould ceae to live, and ince they would have it o, both you and I are obliged to be alo conformable. Therefore, Diana, do not hinder me from that benefit; by it I hall have the accomplihment of my deires; if you love me, you will not deny that which end all my mieries, and begin all my delights: hould I follow your inclination, and prolong the coure of my mierable dayes, what would it advantage you further, then to be a witnee of your violated faith? and Diana, what do you think would become of me? Do you think me able to urvive that fatal ight of eeing you in the power of another. Alas, alas, Diana, aure your elf I hould run tark mad, and do uch trange things, as poterity hould wonder at. It is therefore better for me to ditance my elf from you betimes, and by one udden death, avoid ten thouand which your marriage would put me to, and o tetifie to the world, that I have more love and more courage then you have.

Silvander expreed himelf in uch a manner as made Diana extreamly pity him; and becaue it vexed her to ee him in uch a fury, it was long before he anwered him in any other language but that of tears: at lat, clearing up her voice, and looking him in the face. did I think Silvander (aid he unto him) that death were an argument of my affection and courage, perhaps I hould open my veins ooner then you imagine; but I am afraid, it would be in me a mark of infamy, and would give unto my urvivers a ubject to accue me of ome greater fault,
then that of loving you: Life is not o dear unto me as my honour, and were it poible to leave the one and not the other, Paris hould nere triumph over Diana, nor would I ever be forced to receive any other husband then you: Believe this Silvander, for a mot certain truth; I do invoke the gods to be witnee of it; and let heaven never pardon me, if I would not execute that deign with as much courage as now I do mention it. I perceive for all this (replied Silvander dejectly) that all you ay, is only to aure me that I mut not pretend any more unto you; and ince o, can you think that I can ever receive any comfort after uch a loe? O my dearet Diana, do not injure me o much, as to think I can live in this world after all hopes of you is gone: Let what arguments be alledged that will or can, I will not tay in it; nor do I think any can be found trong enough to condemn my depair.

Upon this, Belinde entred into the room, which did not a little urprize Diana, who being infinitly afraid to loe Silvander, was very deirous to weeten in ome ort, thoe bitter dipleaures which he aw him reent. She hated therefore to ay unto him in a low voice: Servant, if I have any power over you, I do command you to live, at the leat until you hear for certain, that my marriage is conummated: upon this word, he roe up to go unto her mother, who made a ign unto her, o to do.

Alexis, Leonide, and Atrea, who had alo dicoured upon their affairs, did rie up at the ame time, and joyning themelves with Diana, went altogether unto Belinde; who carrying them into the garden, deired that he might have ome privacy with Diana, to tell her of ome particular buinee which he had to communicate unto her. Upon this they evered themelves: Leonide, Astrea, and Alexis, went into the thick of the Grove, whilt poor Silvander, not knowing which way to go, went out of the houe, and took the firt way that his foot tepped into.

He came by Fortune unto the place, where formerly he had taken delight in dicouring unto the rocks concerning the beginning of his Love; and leaning himelf againt the trunk of an old willow, which the river had inenibly undermined, he topped a while to look upon the roots of it; and finding them to be almot all quite bare and out of the earth, he compared the tate of that tree unto that of his love.

Poor tump (ait he) upon how mall a thred does thy life and mine now hang? thou art utained only by two or three mall trings of a root, which the welling of the river Lignon will looen from the earth, and carry thee away. So likewie mierable I, who only do ubit by one bare command of Dianas, and cannot live any longer, until the anger of heaven do put me out of all hopes to enjoy her: Afterwards, cating his eyes upon the little waves which dahed againt the banks, and preently retired back: Clear waves (aid he) is it not me whom ye call unto you? and do not you invite me to follow you? This weet murmure wherewith you flatter my griefs, does it not aure me, that you will be more kind unto me then Diana? do you not tell me, that you are o pitiful, that you will mot willingly receive me into your boome? Ah Celadon (continued he) how happy thou art, in finding amongt thee waves a remedy to all thy orrows? For let them talk what they will, in lieu of falling into the water to help Astrea, I believe thou didt cat in thy elf, only to help thy elf, and be afe from thoe torms which her anger, or perhaps jealouie, had raied againt thee. O Heavens! O Celadon? why hould not I do the ame? Lignon does offer me the ame help; Diana does give me the ame caue; but cruel woman that he is, he takes away from me the power of doing it, and mot unjutly does oblige me unto the obervation of a vow which I have made to obey her. After this, leaving unto his thoughts the liberty of wandering whither they would, he tood near an hower tudying upon the everal accidents of his life; but after a thouand thoughts, he fixed them all upon his love: and comparing all the pleaures that ever he received with his preent pains, he found o great a diproportion, as he had much ado to remember that ever he enjoyed any contentment; this made him cure his firt flames, and not being able to check the firt motion, made him repent
that ever he lived; yet calling to memory the perfections of Diana, and conidering, that ince it was his Fate to die, he could not loe his life in a better caue: he condemned his firt thoughts; and as if he would profee himelf an enemy unto himelf, in loving this Shepherdee till, he wihed more miery upon himelf, that he might be the more her Martyr.

Probably he had pent all the ret of the day in thee imaginations, unlee by Fortune he had coughed, and a neighbouring Eccho returned the noie back again unto him; and though he knew well enough from whence that hollow voice came, yet would he needs conult with it upon the preent condition of his life; and therefore he fell to interrogatories with the Eccho, which till anwered him, that the heart of his Mitree was as hard as any Rock.

After he had dicoured thus a long while, he held his peace; and then broke out again in thee terms: Ceae, ceae, poor mierable wretch, ceae for ever all complaints, and without conuming thy elf in unprofitable orrows, begin to think, that perhaps this is the fatal day, in which Paris mut triumph over Diana: O mot dimal day, wherein I mut ee my Mitree a ubject unto my Rival; or rather a day of Jubile, wherein I will deliver my freeborn oul from the prion of this wretched body: Thou halt be unto me the mot joyful day of all my life, and I will mark thee in my Almanack with the red Letters of my blood.

Thus did Silvander expree his grief for the loe of Diana; and o great was his depair, as he wore that he would never enter into the houe of Adamas, until he certainly knew what was reolved upon, concerning the marriage of this Shepherdee: and whilt he was thus diputing with himelf, he retired himelf into his own Town, and there he would loe himelf in ome olitude or other; but then, he began to think upon the fault which he had committed againt the Druide, in going from his houe without any return of thanks for his favours, or o much as bidding him adieu: yet he followed his firt thoughts, and reolved to ee him no more until he heard the doom of death or life pronounced upon him. I know very well (aid he to himelf) that Adamas has caue to complain againt my ingratitude, and to have an ill opinion of my humour; but I do find the inconvenience which may happen unto me upon it, much les which I hould uffer, if I hould give him the opportunity of uing that authority which he hath over me, and if he hould command me not to depart from his houe until I were preent at the marriage of Paris, which he does not think would be o fatal unto me, as it would. In aying o, he till wandred on; and at lat, never o much as minding which way he went, he came unto his own Cabine: where not finding his flock, becaue the boy which kept them, had driven them out very early, he tayed o little a time there, as did apparently hew, that the cares of his Love did much more buie his mind, then the cares of his etate. So leaving his own home, to pleae himelf in his inquietudes, he took the firt way his foot light upon, not o much as minding or knowing which way it would conduct him.

Belinde, on the other ide, being alone with Diana, and wanting nothing but her conent to marry her unto Paris, he began this dicoure: Diana (aid he) the authority which I may jutly clame over your will, would allow me to dipoe of you without conulting with any but my elf: yet being unwilling to make ue of that power which Nature hath o abolutely given me over you, I conceive it requiite to communicate unto you, my deign of marrying you. I am ure you cannot be ignorant that Paris loves you, and I make no doubt but you love him alo: The journey that he took unto me, makes me o well knowing in it, that had it not been for the iege of Marcelles, I had been here ooner to give him that contentment which I ee he courts with o much zeal and incerity: now his affection aiming at no other end but marriage, and ince you can never meet with a more advantageous match, I was very deirous to know your mind, and to tell you mine, that you may ee how great a care I have of your good. My deign is, not to let him languih any longer in his quet; but to conummate the marriage as oon as may be: Delay in uch caes does often prove prejudicial; and it is as groe implicity not to take a happinee when it is offered, as it is to bewail
it after is lot. Tell me therfore freely Diana, what you think upon the motion, and • p • n unto me your mot ecret thoughts, auring your elf, that I do love you as much as a Mother can a child, and have as indulgent a care over you, as any thing in this world.

Diana who all the while Bellinde talked, held her eyes fixed upon the ground, now lifting them up, Madam (anwered he) I need not tell you what inclination I have unto Paris, nor in what manner I receive his addrees, ince I know but too will, that you are reolved I hould be his, and ince what reaons oever I alledg to the contrary, it will be perhaps impoible for me to alter your determination. Yet to give you atisfaction and to leave you no longer in an opinion that I have any affection towards him, I will tell you that truely I doe not hate him; but I mot tell you withall that I doe not love him o faire as to deire to be his wife: Not that I will ever contradict any thing that you hall command me, but doe refer my elf more unto your judgement then my own, and uch is my conformity unto all your commands, that my very deires hall never contradict yours.

Bellinde, who knew nothing of her love to Silvander, and imagined that all this language was only hid from her, for the affection he had unto Paris: Diana (aid he) all thee trivial excues are not now eaonable: • have not o much forgotten the paages betwixt me and Colion, your Father; but I know what a young woman can ay, who is ahamed to confee her thoughts: I know that you do love Paris, and I am glad on's: his merits may well pretend unto a better fortune then you have, and therefore you are the more beholding to him, ince he does value only your virtue, and your elf, not your fortune; Madam, replied Diana, I protet unto you, that Paris is as indifferent unto me, as all other men are; There is only one thing which moves me to eteem him, which is; That in all his good will towards me, his dicretion hath been o great; as it was impoible but I hould a little wih him well: But Madam, this good will which you are pleaed to peak of, goes no farther; and I dare ay, never will go farther in terms of amity then uch as a iter bears unto a brother: And therefore I mot humbly beeech you, not to think that in betowing me upon him you procure me uch advantage as will bring me any contentment; I protet, I wih with all my heart, that he had never looked upon my face, but with eyes of indifferency: And the greatet favour you can do me, is to let me continues as I am, and to live as I have done hitherto: the demand, replied Bellinde, is not jut, and I were extremely to blame if I did conent unto it: The tronget law that I can impoe upon you, is my peremptory command: But that you may not think I will contrain you unto any thing but what reaon dictates unto me; I would have you conider whether it be poible I hould uffer what you deire; firt, this amity which you have contracted with Atrea, and Phillis, will at the l • t have an and, or at the leat, not afford you that ple • ure which formerly it hath, becaue you mut all part; and though not on your ide, yet probably on theirs; then will you not find any felicities in life, when two Companions, who are o dear unto you, are gone the very places where you lived together, will after you have lot them, preent you every moment with freh ubjects of orrow: But uppoe it poible that this knot of amity hould lat eternally, and that you were ineperable; you mut yet know Diana, that you cannot reit the power of a few years, which will wrincle you with age; and then God know, how much you will be ahamed of a thouand diadvantageous reports that will go upon you. Some will ay, that it was in you a ign of a weak judgement, that could not take a good match when it was offered; others will ay, that you are a woman of uch hallow merit, that none has a mind to make any addrees unto you: And almot all, without any farther inquiry into your life, will he quibbing againt you any thing that comes into their fancies: whereas by living under the power of a husband, you are afe from all thee landers, and quietly enjoy the pleaure of being ineperable from one that perfectly loves you: Madam (aid the hepherdes) Marriage is not always the m • a ••• to top the black mouths of candalous people: Thoe who have a mind to blat the actions of others, will
oon find matter enough to work upon in any kind of life that one can live: I have heard ay, that lander reembles an arrow which is hot and mut necearily light ome where, and has this ill quality with all, that mot comonly it hurts the innocent, and makes the let actions condemned as crimes: So as Madam, if any have an intended deign to blat my reputation, I cannot avoid the blow, nor do I think the name of wife a better armour, then the name of a maid: however it be (aid Bellinde) I mut of neceity dicharge my elf of that care with I am bound to have of you, to the end, that thoe few days I have to live, may be the more eriouly imployed in the ervice of our Gods. But I beeech you Madam, (aid the hepherdes) if you find o much atisfaction in the ervice of thoe divinities, may not I alo pretend to be imployed in the ame? Doubtles you may, (aid Bellinde) but the gods have made known their pleaures unto me, and have commanded me to Marry you unto Paris: For you mut know Diana, that as it is not my humour to do things rahly, o would I not at the firt hearken unto the requet which Paris made unto me; but taking a little time to conider upon it, I firt did what I could to know whether his inclination unto you were as real as he pretended it; And in order thereto, I conulted with the Oracle of that Deity, whom I adore, who commanded me to conent unto it, in thee very words,

div.head: The Oracle.
div.l: ENquire no more Bellinde: Go
Order and contrive the matter o,
As he whom ere Diana marryes
Be on to Adamas, calld'd Paris.

div.p:
Oh good gods! (cryed out Diana) how inufferable is this neceity which is impoed upon me; and how hall I ere be able to endure the tyranny of this huband? In aying o, her eyes began to flow in tears; with Bellinde perceiving; But what abundance of pleaure (replied he) will you enjoy in the poeion of this lover who will be a econd elf unto you? Madam, replied Diana, and kneeling down) I do conjure you by the memory of my dear Father, and by that love which once you bore him, to conent that I may end my days no where but in your Company: you cannot procure unto me a greater advancement; and if it be true that you do value my contentment, out of pitty, grant this requet unto me: Bellinde, who imagined that the tears and expreions of Diana did not proceed from her apprehenions of being under the power of Paris, but rather from a kind of bahfullnes, which is ineperably incident to her ex: Diana (aid he unto her) I do know better then you, what is mot convenient for you; and unles you will exceedingly dipleae me, you mut not oppoe your elf againt him whom I have propounded unto you: In aying o, he commanded her to rie up, and afterwards he continued thus, though the quality of Paris were not o coniderable as it is, yet his virtue being in o high a degree, you have no caue to doubt but you may be more happy in being his, then you can deerve: and therfore I charge you to let me ee no more of any uch ignes of dicontent to appear in your face: if I do, I hall take them for o many tetimonies of your diobedience: I think Madam, (anwered the hepheardes) I hall have o much power over my face as to keep it from telling you my dipleaures: but I am afraid I have not o much power over my inclination, as to make me receive the alliance with Paris, with any joy: I do much better love Sil— heere he made a top; and was urpried that the name of Silvander was o neer comming out: And Bellinde commanding her to go on, Diana, who knew that if he had named Silvander, her mother would not have liked of it therefore he replied thus: I ay Madam, that I do much better love Silence in my grave, or to live amongt the Carnates, if you would be pleaed, the in the
company of Paris. I tell you once for all (anwered Belinde, eemed to be angry) that you ought to have no other will but mine; and ince I deire to be obedient unto the gods, who would have me betow you upon Paris, you will extreamly anger me if you be in the leat againt it. Begin therefore betimes to prepare your elf; for ince Adamas hath conented unto it, I will have the buinee fully reolved upon this very night: Upon this, he left her to the mercy of a thouand tormenting thoughts, which came into her mind; and not taying to hear any anwer, he went unto Adamas.

Diana no ooner aw her elf alone, but he opened a paage for thoe tears which that repect he bore unto her mother had kept within her eyes; and now being at liberty to igh. Though (aid he) they will not pleae me, yet they cannot hinder me from complaining: Afterwards, conidering the abundance of tears which flowed from her eyes, and down her Roie cheeks, like rivers: alas, poor feeble tears (aid he) why will you attempt a thing o full of difficulty? Alas, you can only bedew and make grow thoe flowers which the earth brings forth, whilt you drown and wither thoe that Nature has placed in my cheeks: Alas, they require ome nourihment that is a little more mild and weet; you, cruel tears, are too harp and bitter for them; you do proceed from a caue too ad, and would, in any other then my elf, be a caue rather of death then life. In aying o, he topt a little, and afterwards broke out again: Alas (continued he) you are arguments of my faint courage, ince I dare not have recoure unto no other remedies then you, as if Nature did not offer unto me other arms, wherewith to revenge my elf upon the injuries of Fortune. For what ue were poyons created? what are words for? what Precipices? what flames? what waters? but to be imployed in the relief of mierable wretches: Courage therefore Diana; make ue of ome one of thee remedies to eae thee of thy miery: make choice of the mot violent, that the act may be the ooner done, and endeavour to prevent this very minute which is to blat all thy hopes of any joy. Upon this, he went out of the Garden, not to go into the houe of Adamas, for that was odious unto her, but to go into the wood, in hopes to meet with ome of her companions, to whom he might without fear, igh out the caue of her grief: She was almot at the very banks of Lignon, before he met with any; but at lat he pied Atrea, who was et under an old oak, holding a handkerchief in one hand, and leaning her head upon the other: Diana much wondered to ee her elf out of the company of Alexis and Leonide, becaue he knew they went out together, and knowing that he would never have parted from them without ome reaon, he was very deirous to know the caue, and made o litle noie in coming to her, as he was within four or five paces of the Shepherdee and was never perceived.

The ighs and groans which Atrea ent forth, made Diana believe that he had received ome extraordinary dipleaure, epecially when he heard her ay with a deep igh, traiterous and perideous wretch, durt thou be o bold as to offend me o extreamly? Cruel Shepherd, wouldt thou offer to abue my innocence o long, as in the end to blat my reputation? Then topping, as if the violence of her ighs would not let her peak any more; mierable wretch that I am (aid he again) how dare I ever appear in the world again? I ee my elf now obliged to bluh eternally, and to eem as if I were guilty of a crime which I never committed.

Upon this, flowing with tears again, and till lifting her handkerchief to her eyes, he fell into a deep tudy, and that o deep, as Diana came and it down by her, and tayed a long while before Atrea ever perceived her; at lat, Diana being deirous to apply ome remedy to her troubled mind, though he tood in as great need her elf: Siter (aid he and pulled her gently) what new affliction is this that is fallen upon you? Atrea then rowing her elf, as out of a deep leep, and eeing one o near her whom he o much eteemed, yet never anwering to Dianas quetion; for he no ooner heard her voice, but we embraced her, and fell into uch a flow of tears, that Diana was no lee afflicted then he, and finding uch an object of pity could not retrain her tears neither: o being both
ilent, they ate a long while embracing and crying together. At lat, Atrea, in a voice interrupted with ighs: ah Siter (aid he unto her) ah Siter, Siter, I am utterly undone: Why Siter (aid Diana) what's the matter, and who has caued all this orrow unto you? Celadon (replied Atrea) Diana then imagining, that the death of this Shepherd came freh into her memory, and that being o near Lignon, he could not chue but reent the ad accident. Siter (anwered he) I will not condemn your tears, but you mut give me leave to tell you, that if all the tears which you have hed for him, ince his loe, were all together, they would make a river as big as that wherein he was drown'd: Come, come, companion, believe it, you have wept enough. Ah me, dear Siter (aid Atrea, and interrupted her) you know not what caue I have to weep: I would to God when he threw himelf into the River, I had been drown'd with him, then hould I not at this hour be o grieved as I am, nor hould I have been the common talk of all the world, as now I mut: Diana, not being able to undertand her meaning, Believe it Siter, replied he, I hall be long ignorant, unlee you do better inform me, but I beeech you peak freely unto me, and let me know the caue of your dipleaure, auring your elf, that I hall as freely dicover a thing unto you which troubles me extreamly, and the more, becaue I am out of all hopes to find any remedy.

I will tell you what it is which troubles me (anwered Atrea, beginning to wipe her eyes and it down in her place again) for though I would not render that duty unto the affection which is common betwixt us, yet hould I do it out of another prevalent conideration, which is, that we two having been almot all one, and our very thoughts no more hid from one another, then our actions, it is neceary that you hould anwer for my deportment, and that thoe who hall make any doubt of my virtue, may ceae to entertain any ill opinion of me, by the reports which you will make in my advantage: I do not think (replied Diana) any man can be o imple as to blame you for any thing you ever did; but if there hould, I promie mot faithfully to vindicate you, and to peak in your behalf as I ought to do. And therefore, my dear companion, I conjure you to conceal nothing from me, but freely open your oul unto me, with this aurance, that I will never deny any thing you hall deire of me. Then Astrea having dryed her eyes: I ever thought (aid he unto her) that your affection unto me was as perfect as I could deire, nay more then I could deerve: and to the end you hould not exceed me in love, I will make a dicoure which none but you or Phillis hould ever get out of me: Know therefore, my dear companion, that whilt Paris was talking with you, Leonide came unto Alexis and me, and after he had asked what was the ubject of our dicoure, he aid unto me, what will you give me Atrea, if I do tell you as good news as you can poible deire. Fair Nymph (anwered I) I have nothing that I can dipoe of; for all that I have is this day transferred into the power of my dearet Mitree; but I hall be very obliged unto you, if you will tell me any thing which imports either her contentment or mine: what I have to tell you (aid Diana) does equally relate unto you both; and to hold you no longer in upence, Adamas came to aure me, that it hould be only your fault, if you did not tye uch a knot, as death only could unlooe: Then he knows (anwered I unto her) that I hall obtain amongt the Carnates, that place which I deired. He is mot certain of it (anwered he) for he commanded me to bring you the news of it, that you might betimes prepare your elf for it, and rejoyce: I have o long dipoed my elf for it, anwered I, that I am ready at an intant, but I durt never build any certain hopes of it until now; and therefore I will with a mot joyful heart go unto him, and thank him for the remembrance he had of my Fortune. Thus we went on talking together, when Leonide, after a while of ilence, whipered me in the ear, Atrea (aid he) tell me truly; will not the company of Celadon be as pleaing unto you, as the company of Alexis? Sage Nymyh (anwered I) why do you ask me that quetion? Becaue, aid he, it is very neceary that I know it for ome coniderations which I hall tell you. Upon this I oberved that Alexis did withdraw a little from us, and under a pretence of looking upon ome Pictures,
he began to walk up and down the room. I being then alone with the Nymph: Celadon (aid I unto her) was a Shepherd unto whom I ought to have no great inclination, by reaon of the enmity that was betwixt our Parents; and Alexis is a Druides daughter, whom all things do oblige me mot perfectly to love: and therefore in all probability, I hall be more delighted in her company, then in that Shepherds, who can never be, in my opinion, more then in a condition of indifferency.

This diimulation (aid Leonide unto me) might be good at another eaon, or before one who has not o much knowledge of your affairs as I have; but to me, who knows to a yllable all the Letters that ever you writ unto him, and who am not ignorant in any one of all the accidents that ever befel you, witnee your jealouie, which was the caue of his throwing himelf into Lignon; it is to be thought, fair Astrea, that thee diimulations are to no purpoe, and that you do your elf an injury, if you do not peak more freely unto me.

Judge Diana, whether or no, I was urprized when I heard her talk thus: really it did almot ravih me; but deiring to know more, how (asked I) came you to know all this that you have told me? I hall tell you (anwered he) but I beeech you never peak of it unto any, and wear unto me, that of all the ecrets you know, this hall be the mot inviolable. I who never in all my life deired any thing more paionatly, then to know how he came by all thee things, I wore unto her even what he would, and then he went on thus: You mut know Astrea, that my uncle, as he is in a quility much above the common ort of men, o he is owner of uch rare qualities, as makes him come near unto a Diety: few men ever equall'd him in excellency of wit, or profundity of Science: his humility, which is incomparable, makes him even with care hide that, which another out of oftentation would make appear; I who have relation to him, have o great a hare in his affection, as he eldome ever conceals any thing from me: I can ay, that he hath very few ecrets, of which I have not had ome experience.

Mow, being ome dayes in Marcelles, and in my chamber there, he came unto me, and I know not upon what fancy, asking me ome quetions concerning you, at the firt I was very hie in making him any anwers: At lat, know Leonide (aid he unto me) that this Shepherdee is born under a contellation which doth promie unto her abondance of happinee, but this happines is mixed with o many bitter diaters, as very few perons would condition to be happy upon the ame terms: She had a mot paionate affection unto Celadon, and doubtlee he does yet burn with the ame fire which that dicreet Shepherd did kindle in her oul; but this flame has o few witnees, as Diana, Phillis, and Alexis, are the only perons unto whom he does dicover the violence of it. If you deire to know what uccee hall befal her, here is that which will make you more knowing: Then he told me, that Adamas gave unto her a book, and that opening of it, he had no ooner inerted certain Characters unto thoe that were before in the book, but thereby he found all that heretofore I told you concerning my life, and the life of Celadon; and having related a great part unto me, he continued thus, you ee Atrea, how little reaon you have to conceal any thing from me: what I have already told you, is enough to make you trut me; confee therefore freely unto me, that you hall meet with more contentment in ending your dayes with him, then in living with Alexis, who in the quality of a Druides daughter, cannot, as I conceive, afford you more then common delights.

Since fair Nymph (aid I unto her) all the actions of my life are as well known unto you, as unto my elf; and ince this prodigious Science of Adamas can tell you them to the leat circumtance, I will not deny, but that I did love Celadon, with a mot pure and holy affection; and that the mot enible dipleaure I ever reented, was the loe of him: But the gods, who do all things for our good, not permitting our loves to arrive at a happy end, I have brought my mind to endure this eparation with patience; and it is only upon this accompt, that I have devoted my will unto the merits of Alexis, not conceiving that the ghot of my
beloved Shepherd will be any thing offended, if to avoid the entertainment of any other I do confine my elf unto her, and to live with her in any place where my thoughts may be free, where I hall be little in the company of Calidon, or any other whom Pho • ion would have me to marry: Your deign (anwered Leonide) is o jut handome, that Adamas is reolved to procure your contentment which you deire; but becaue that confinement is a kind of death, I wih Atrea, you would tell me ingeniouly, whether before you die to the world, and leave all thoe delightful habitations, where you have heretofore pent o many merry dayes with your dear Shepherd, you would not be very glad to have a ight of him once more, and to let him know that it is for the love of him you leave this countrey, where ince his abence you never found any thing dilectable.

Alas, fair Nymph (anwered I) what contentment could I ever receive, ince it is only to aggravate my grief, and to aure me that is impoible ever to be happy again: No, no, age Leonide, I have too much offended his love not to be eternally punihed with the torment I endure, in aurance that I hall never ee him again: That time, in which I aw him cat himelf headlong into Lignon, his head down, his arms pread, as if he were deirous to embrace that element which was more kind unto him then I was; That time (I ay) that Fatal time, was it, which taking him out of my ight, did alo take away all my hopes of his ever loving me again.
