Do not ask me (aid he unto me) whether or no it be impoible I hould give you that contentment: leave the care of that unto me, and the thing perhaps will not be o difficult as you imagine, only tell me whether or no you have any deire to ee him: for to tell you truly, I am able to do it; this very book which my Uncle gave me, is it which will help me to hew you the Image of your o much loved Celadon: In aying o, he opened a book which he held in her hand, wheae I aw a great number of figures and characters, which were unknown to me; o as when I cat my eyes upon it, I knew not whether it was only a meer effect of my own imagination, or really ome kind of virtue contained in it; but certain it is, I found my elf eized with an unaccutomed fear, and my blood began to rie; therefore it was a long time before I poke a word, which Leonide oberving: Atrea (aid he) have a good heart, and put on a trong reolution: for this is the umm of all; you do either love Celadon, or you do not love him: if you do love him, commit your caue unto the god of love; he is a puiant god, and able to give good uccee unto all our enterprizes; if you do not love him, then blot his very name out of your memory, and ave me the labour of hewing him unto you; for I have no deire unto it, further then as coaducing unto your contentment. Ah fair Nymph (anwered I) you touch upon the mot enible part of my oul: Alas, why do you make any doubt whether or no I do love the memory of Celadon; if you have of late read the ecrets of my life, certainly, Leonide, you know, that if you do find in me any repugnancy unto your motion, it is not but that I have a mot earnet deire of eeing Celadon again; but it is, becaue I am afraid I have not courage enough to oberve all that you hall perhaps command me; but if you will be pleaed to tell me firt, what you would have me to do, I hall prepare my pirit for it. In that (anwered he) I hall eaily atisfie oou, and tell you, that in the firt place, you and I mut retire our elves into ome place within the wood, where none can come to molet our armorous mitery: O heavens (aid I and interrupted her) I am certain this is impoible for me to do; if you do put me to go alone with you unto the place where you will make your figures and characters, and where perhaps you will ue ome black inchantment, I am afraid my pirit will be troubled as well as the air, which you perhaps will darken, and the images which you preent unto my eyes, will be o affrighting, that they will make me die before I can ee poor Celadon.

Let that be the leat of your fears (aid he unto me) for what I hall do will not offend the air, nor hall the Sun grow dark; but on the contrary, the flowers hall appear more beautiful, and you hall ee every thing mile at the pleaure which you will receive; but you mut be alone, for it is to be feared, that in the
habit wherein Celadon will appear unto you, he will be ahamed to be een by any trang eye: why (age Nimph, (aid I unto her) do you think the goat of Celadon will be offended at the preence of Alexis? Leonide eeming as if he thought letter upon it: I beleive (replied he) that the good will you have unto her will rather be pleaing unto Celadon then offenive, and therfore I think though you hould invite her unto this ceremony, it will be no hindrance unto it: well (aid I unto her) o my Mitres be there, I will go whereoever you pleae, nor hall I fear any thing as long as you will let me be in her Company: Let us then ee (aid Leonide whether he will conent unto it; and afterwards we will go about the buines.

Upon this I went unto her, as you might oberve I did: I protet iter, (aid Diana) I did not oberve it: For as I believe, it was at the ame time when I was talking with Silvander: right, iter, replied Atrea, I aw Silvander then with you: but to continue the dicoure which I began: I told you that I went unto Alexes; who as you heard before; was walking about the Room, and looking upon ome Pictures: As oon as I came unto her, Mitres, (aid I unto her) I come to aske your aduice, and beeech your aitance in a buines which much concern me. Servant, anwered he, you may command me any thing, and you need not doubt but I hall do it with all my heart; But I am afraid (aid I unto her,) that the prayer which I hall make unto you will not be pleaing, becaue perhaps you will think, that it does omething contradict my duty unto you; Noe (aid he) for be certaine, I hall take any thing in good part that proceeds from you; will you promie me Mitres, (aid I) that it hall not dipleae you, and that you will lend me a little of your courage, to execute my deign? I doe promie (anwered he) to give you, not only my courage, but my elf alo, if it will any thing conduce unto your contentment: Is is mot eentially neceary (aid I unto her) for Mitres, be pleaed to know; That Leonide having read, perhaps in my oul, that there are yet ome of thoe flames which Celadon kindled, unextinguihed; and eeing that I am to go with you amongt the virgine Druides, o for ever leave thoe places where the preence of my hepheards were o pleaing unto me, he is reolved before my departure, to give me the delight of once more eeing his Image. I oberved, dear iter, that as oon as ever Alexis heard my propoition, he bluh't; and preently after, thoe Roes in her cheecks vanihing, he grew as pale as one upon whom the doom of death had paed: but not being able to divine the reaon; I asked her, from whence that alteration which I oberved in her might proceed: at the firt, he was extreamly put unto it for an anwer: but at lat he aid unto me, I aure you ervant, the deign of Leonide does exceedingly affright me and I cannot comprehend what invention he can ue to atisfie your curioitie. Oh Mitres (aid I unto her) did you but know what things he has already tole me, and how he can when he pleaes; panetrate into the mot hiden ecrets of a oul, you would ceae your wonder: I was at the firt as much amaed as you are: but when he told me all the particulars of my life which certainly none ele but the gods, Celadon, and my elf, could know, I thought that what he promied me was noe more impoible then the ret. For my part (aid Alexis, and was much troubled) I hal do what oever you would have me; but I conceive it very good, that before you engage your elf any farther in the matter, you prepare your elf for any vexatious accident that may happen unto you, for I can tell with what eye you wil behold this hepheard: perhaps he wil appear unto you o dipleaing, as you wil hate him, as much as now you imagine you love him: hould it o happen that any of your thoughts hould procure unto him that dicontent, doubtles it wil drive him into a econd dipair: a thouand times wore then the firt: That would be a means to loe him eternally without any hopes that any art of magique is ever able to raie him again from the place unto which his oul hal retire it elf. Mitres (ayd I unto her) I do not o much fear my hatred wil drive him away, as I doubt whether my love wil retain him; But ince this officious Leonide, wil do me the favour to hew him unto me, though but for a quarter of an houre, I beeech you do not hinder me
of the delight which I expect: upon this with tears, in my eyes, I innocently took her hand, and kiing it a hundred times, I carryed her unto the Nimph, who undertanding that Alexis conented to go with me, did place her elf betwixt us; and when Bellinde, and you were gone out, he carried us into the wood, where I received the mot enible dipleaure, that ever poor innocent, harmles woman ever reented.

Upon thee words, Atrea began to weep, and o violently, that he was forced to leave of dicoure; and Diana beginning; I protet iter, (aid he unto her, it was about the very ame time that I alo was afflicted with the mot bitter pill of orrow, that ever I received; but if you deire I hould relate it unto you, I pray do not leave me in a languihing deire of knowing what was the event of your buines, that I may mingle my tears with yours, and that our afflictions being participated, they may the more eaily be endured: I beeech your iter, replied Atrea, to excue the exces of my orrow, and do not wonder it hould hinder my peech, ince it is enough to take away my life.

But before my orrowes reduce me to that extremitie, I wil relate unto you the ret of this adventure. Upon this Atrea was ready to proceed when he heard the voice of Phillis who now knowing where her Companions, were went al over to eek them; and was now inging a onge which Licidas gave unto her the day before. Thus this heapheardes went on inging, little thinking he had o much caue of orrow, in the behalf of her Companions: As oon as he had ended her ong he came unto the tree under which Atrea and Diana ate o as he pied them: At the firt, he advanced towards them with a face full of joy: But when he aw their countenances o full of orrow, he was amaed; therefore he erted her elf down by them without peaking a word, and not knowing which of the two he ought to peak unto, o equally were they both dejected, for a long while together he did nothing but look upon them, ometimes upon one, and ometimes upon the other; at lat loing al patience, my dear Companions (aid he unto then) do you only counterfeit this adnes to make me afraid, or have you any real reaons for your being o melancholly? Alas iter, aid Atrea with a deep igh) any affliction is but too real, and arived to the highet point it poibly can. And mine (aid Diana) is nothing different from yours; for it is in the highet degree: you cannot find (replied Phillis) a more competent judge in this matter, nor one more equitable then my elf, if the laves of our friendhip wil but al • ow you to relate unto me what it is which makes you thus ad: For my part (aid Astrea) I hal quickly do it, for when you came, I was then began to make the dicoure of it unto Diana; and I beleive he wil be as willing to relate her baines unto you; upon this he began to make a hort repetition of al that he had told Diana, and afterwards continued thus: Now my Companions you mut know, that whilt we were going unto the thick of the wood, Alexis appeared to be very timerous & by her countenance eemed as if he had much rather have gone to her death then to the place, where I hoped to receive ome aitance from her: her pace was low, and her leggs fainted, and there was no more colour in her face then in that of Adrates when he was ditracted: I who took notice of it, and aw her every moment to faint more and more, Mitres (aid I unto her) I thought my elf the mot faint hearted woman in the world: but for ought I ee, you are no more courageous then I am. Truly ervant (aid Alexis to me, I do know o little whither Leonide will carry us, nor what he intends to do with us, with this incertainty does amae me, and makes me doubt whether the place where he will carry us, will prove a place of torment or a place of happines unto me. I believe, (aid I) we hall quickly know that, for we are already under uch a hade of trees whoe leaves are o thick, that there is hardly light enough to know our faces: and to facilitate her enterprie, hee has found out a place to oberve, that he cannot find the like in all the wood: The place (aid Alexis) is indeed very olitarie, and I cannot conceive how it is poible Leonide hould preent you with any pleaing object in it: So he perform her promie (anwered I) and hew me Celadon, I hall be contented, and what horrour oever the place does promie, doubtles it
will all vanih upon the firt appearance of my hepherd: Are you then fully contented, replied he, that he hould appeare before you: o fully contented, anwered I, that I do command it a thouand times, and I did never deire to ee any thing o paionately in all my life as I do to ee him, ince it is o (aid Alexis unto me with a more confident countenance then before) let us go fairet Atrea, unto the place where heaven, by the mouth of Leonide is to pronounce the entence of our felicitie: I who thought that he poke of our being admitted amongt the Carnutes, and tayed by nothing but my deire of eeing Celadon, once more before I went; Let us go Mitree (anwered I) unto the place where heaven wil free me from all obtacles of my felicity. In aying o, I oberved that Leonide topt, and turning her elf towards us with a voice more loud, and a tone more grave then ordinary, he aid thus unto us: Here Atrea, is the place where the gods have ordained that Celadon hall be retored unto you: be ure you be very attentive unto the ceremonie, and reolve with your elf to keep ilence for a while, leat you hould prophane it with your words: upon this he began to open her book; and kneeling on the ground with her left knee, her face turned towards the un riing, he took a knife out of her pocket, and engraved ome characters; then pronounced ome words which I undertood not, after this ske roe up, and coming to us; Remember Atrea (aid he unto me) you punctually oberved all that I hall command you: be ure you faile not in the leat tittle upon pain of offending thoe pririts, whoe aitance I have invoked: In aying o, he turned her elf towards the Eat, afterwards towards the South, then the Wet, and lat of all towards the North, and at every removal muttered omething: At lat he came unto me, and after he had made a circle upon the ground, Stand here fair Atrea (aid he unto me,) and prepare your elf to receive far greater contentment then ever you had: Afterwards turning her elf towards Alexis, and placing her in another circle: Oh ye mot puiant gods (aid he in a loud voice) ye who command the detinyes, epecially thou puiant god of Love, by whoe favour I do put a ecret into practice which was never known unto any mortall, but only Adamas: oh ye mot bleed p • rits, who do enjoy thoe pleaures which does produce an inviolable amity: oh ye gods! oh love! oh ye pirits! I do call you all for witnees, or rather for authors of this miracle, and conjure you to retore back unto the hepherdee Atrea, the Image, or rather the peron of Celadon: upon this, looking upon me with a miling countenance, and coming to me with a very grave pace; I perceive (aid he unto me) that the only reaon why Celadon does not preent himelf before you, is becaue you did forbid him ever appearing in your preence untill you did command him; Will you therefore be pleaed to command him? I will age nimph, (anwered I) did I but know in what manner, and in what termes I hould pronounce it. To ave you that pains, replied Leonide, do you only repeat what I hall ay: Then he beginning in a loud voice, Celadon, Celadon, aid I after her, I command you (aid he) I command you (aid I after her) to preent your elf before me (aid he) to preent your elf before me (aid I) after this, firt looking upon me, and then upon Alexis. Now fair Atrea (aid he) do you not ee Celadon? I ee nothing yet (anwered I) then was I afraid, that to punih me for the offence which I had committed againt his love he would deprive me of the Joyes of asking him pardon: Then I cat my eye upon Alexis, and eeing her in a trembling poture, perhaps Mitree (aid I unto her) that you do ee him: Alas, alas, anwered he) indeed I do ee him, and touch him, but as oon as ever he had aid o, her voice failed her; and Leonide peaking, probably Atrea (aid he) you have failed in omething which I commanded you, though not in words yet perhaps in thoughts. I aure you, fair Nimph (aid I unto her) I do not think I have failed in either. Then having made me repeate thee words three times over; Celadon I command you upon pain of my dipleaure, to preent your elf before me: Oh heavens! my Companions, what hall I ay! I aw wretch that I am Alexis, or rather Celadon protrate at my feet, and kiing them, here, my fairet Atrea (aid he unto me) here is your on whom the waters have pared and could not extinguih the
leat park of his zealous flame. I who thought till that it was Alexis, oh Mitres, (aid I unto her and embraced her) could you be o cruel as mock me thus? Fairet Atrea (replied Celadon) it is not now fit I hould be called your Mitree, it is glorie enough for me to bear the name of your mot humble ervant: and in tetimony that formerly that honour was conferred upon me, ee here (aid he and pulled out the ame riband which he natched from her the ame day he cat himelf into Lignon) this is the lat tetimony of your anger. Then opening the cae wherin my Picture was, and preenting it unto me: be not o ungratefull, (aid he) as to dilown your own fair face; and though I be o unfortunate as to be worn out of your knowledge, yet do not execute your rigour upon your elf; upon this he was ilent, and his ilence was uch a caue of mine, as I tood till, and was not able to utter one illable.

Truely (aid Phillis and interrupted) I do not wonder at it, for well may you be urprid, when we that only hear of it can hardly tell whether it be a dream or a truth: Alas (aid Atrea) it is but too true, that this cruel traytor thus betrayed me: And to make it only a dream, I would it would pleae the gods I might leep an eternall leep, why, why? replied Diana, are you troubled at the knowledge of that which you o paionately deired? I did not think (anwered Astrea) that it would ere have been o diadvantageous to me, nor that it was poible it hould fall out o: I was ignorant of Leonides artifice and of Celadons triumphing over my innocence under a pretence of Alexis nor did I think that Nimph would have abued my credulity under couler of a cience which was never known unto her. However it be replied Phillis, it is very happy newes that Celadon is alive, and will be no male Joy unto my Licidas, However it be, anwered Atrea; it is a misfortune unto me to be thus deceived, and that this perfideous hepheard hould be the caue of a thouand crimes which I have committed to the great hazard of my reputation. I do not believe (aid Diana) that any in the world has any caue to blame your actions: But if any be o malicious as to condemn you, you have a good way to top their mouthes by marrying Celadon, who I? (aid Atrea in a great rage) perhaps he is out of the world by this. How? aid Phillis, what hould take him out of it? have you committed a econd fault, after you payed o dear for the firt. I do not think (anwered Atrea,) I committed any fault when I tetified my reentments againt him for deceiving me. For god ake iter (aid Diana) let us have the full relation of the matter. I will, replied the hepherdes, provided that Phillis will afterwards Judge without paion, whether I had not reaon to do as I did. Proceed then, aid Phillis, and doubt not but I hall freely tell you my opinion. Then Atrea continued her dicoure thus.

As oon as I had cat my eyes upon my Picture, upon the ring and the riband which Celadon preented unto me, I fixed my looks upon him, and did o perfectly know his face, as I wondered I hould be o long mitaken: At the firt, I was upon the point to embrace him, and to follow the firt uggetion of my love: but then calling preently to memory the condition wherein he had een me, the favours he had received from me, and how I had given him liberty to kie my cheek, my neck; my eyes and my mouth, this put me into uch a confuion, as I tood immovable; then did a combate begin in my oul betwixt love and reaon; pity took part with one of them, and honour the other; love pleaded the extream obedience of the hepherd, his inviolable fidelity, his paion, and his fortune; and pity would needs perwade me to put an end unto his mieryes. But reaon and honour did cleerly demontrate unto me the bad deigns he had cloaked under this diguie, and commanded me to do ome act which might tetifie to the world that I was in no wie an acceory unto that diguiment: In concluion I fixed upon this lat reolution, and entring into a greater anger againt him then ever I was, not conidering how long he had been upon his knees, nor o much as bidding him to rie: cruel wretch, (aid I unto him) that has attempted againt my honour, and who with inufferable impudence durt yet preent himelf before that peron who has all the reaon in the world to hate thee; how cant thou forbear bluhing at thy arrogant boldnes? Perfideous
and deceitfull Alexis, no les then death can expiate thy crime; How couldet thou find malice enough to betray me? upon this, haking of his Arm as well as I could, I began to fly from him: but he holding me by my coat: Alas fair Atrea, (aid he unto me) I did not expect from your rigour, a reception more favorable: I knew my fault did deerve a punihment as great; but ince it is my fate to die, and ince your own fairet elf hath doomed it o: I beeech you even for pities ake, to tell me what kind of death it is your pleaure I hould die, to the end my repentance and obedience which I will tender unto you in that lat moment, may in ome ort atisfie your anger: I mut confee, the tone wherein he ultered thee expreions did mot enibly move me, and I was even ready to yeild unto the uggetions of compaion: but being already fully reolved to do ome violence, not only upon him, but upon my elf, I eemed to be very obtinate in my firt deign; and pulling my coat away from him by force: Die what death thou wilt, (aid I unto him) o I may be no more troubled with thee. Upon this I left him, and Leonide followed me ome twenty or thirty paces; but eeing that Celadon took another way, he lift me to follow him, being unwilling, as I beleive, to forake him in that ad affliction wherein I left him. As oon as they were out of ight, I began to dipute with my elf, whether I had done well or ill: and in the time that I was coming hither, I think I did a hundred times approve of my actions, and a hundred times repent I ever did it: but finding no way to revoke what I had aid, and not being able to put out of my mind thoe favours which his diguiement had obtained from me; at lat I eated my elf under this tree, where, when Diana came unto me, I had began to lament both my own fortune and Celadons.

Thus Atrea ended the dicoure of all the paages which hapned unto her in the new acquaintance that he had with her hepherd: and Phillis, who was extreamly greived that the cruelty of her Companions had impoed upon Celadon a more dangerous penance then he firt: Siter (aid he unto her) I do not wonder, nor hall hardly pity you; if you uffer any more miery, and if heaven hould condemn you unto ome now ubject of grief: for I profee you have mot trange, odd, and perticular wayes to bring orrow upon your elf, and uch as I believe no other but your elf would ere have thought upon; Fie, fie, what neceity was there to drive away this hepherd from you again? If you did think thereby to top the mouths of uch as might accue you of any crime, did you not plainly ee there was no neceity of any uch extreams, ince the authority of Adamas was enough to free you from all upition? Ah iter (anwered Atrea though there be ome likly hood that Adamas does know ome of thee paages, yet am I not aured that he does: and to tell you truly, I never thought upon him; I was taken upon uch a udden, and my judgment o urpried and intangled, that it was very hard for me to entertain any other coniderations, then uch as prompted me to condemn this hepherd of the greatet treaon he could ere commit againt me: Well, well, replied Phillis, perhaps ere long, heaven will let you know the ecret of all this buines, to the end you may be tormented with more enible remore, For o ill uing the favour that was hewed you, in rendring Celadon again, Mean while, becaue I will not be o uncharitable as you, I will go and think upon ome means which may prevent that hepherd from doing any harm unto himelf, and acquaint Lycidas with all that hath hapned.

Upon this, never taying to hear the anwer of Atrea, nor what Diana promied to tell her, he roe up and went towards the houe where he thought to find Lycidas. Atrea and Diana began to follow her, and conceiving that as they went, they had time enough to talk of their buines; Diana began to relate almot word for word all the dicoure which Paris and he had together, he told her of Silvanders depair, and latly of Bellindes command upon her: and having throughly informed her of all, he proceeded thus: Now iter, to open unto you the very cloet of my oul, I mut freely tell you, that I have nothing o great an averion to be marryed unto my grave, then unto Paris; Not that I have any caue to hate him, nor o little Judgment as not to know what honour
and advancement it would be unto me: but to confes ingeniouly, I do love Silvander better; and though nature has put an inequality betwixt them, yet beleive me, love is revenged, ince the ame advantages which birth gives unto Paris above Silvander, my affection does give them unto Silvander above Paris. See how heaven does play with me: in giving me an inclination unto one, whom I mut not pretend unto, and an averion unto him, to whom I mut be acrified. Your misfortune (aid Astrea) is not yet comparable unto mine: For in the accidents of your life nothing has hapned which can wound your reputation: whereas in the diguiement of Celadon, the mot innocent of my actions may with ome colourable pretence be taken for a crime. Beides; whether you marry Paris, or Silvander, yet fortune offers you ome hopes of contentment: But whether I do marry Celadon, or never ee his face again, yet till I mut bear all the faults that every evel pirit can charge me withall: But (aid he and ighed,) I am reolved ere long to find out the remedy which dipair ues to teach uch ouls as cannot bear them. Upon this he was ilent and Diana began: Companion (aid he unto her) you do find your miery to be greater then mine, becaue you think it o: But I do find mine to be greater then yours, becaue I know them to be more tinging: aure your elf the caues which make any calamity intolerable, are more eaily to be found in my affliction, then in yours: For as the tate tands with me, I have the ame dipleaure which you have, which is not to enjoy the peron whom I love yet I have one which you know not, which is, that I am contrained to ubmit my elf unto the tyranny of her who can dipoe of me: yet iter, I am reolved as well as you, to have recoure unto that common remedy which cannot be denied unto any; and I will ooner die then pronounce that fatal word, Yes, which will be the firt munite of my miery.

With uch dicoure as this, thee fair ones came o nere the Druides houe, that they perceived Lycidas coming out with Phillis, and eemed by his countenance to have ome very earnet buines in hand: Atrea deired Diana to tep a little aide, and avoide the meeting them, which Diana eaily conented unto; and they went into a by walk, on the ide of that where they were to pas, and hiding themelves behind a buh; It was not long before they heard Lycidas walk a great pace, and ay: but Phillis, do you not know from that cruel woman, in what place this tragedy is to be? I protet, anwered he, it is the only thing I have forgot; But look well about you, perhaps we hall meet Leonide, and he can tell us all. Oh heavens, replied Lycidas (and hated away) if Atrea would, he might pare me all this pains; But I think, he was born to be the ruine of our houe. This was the lat word they could hear; and when they thought them out of ight, they came out again; And were no ooner entred into the great walk, but they aw Phillis returning alone: They therefore tayed for her; and as oon as the was come unto them: Well Phillis (aid Atrea unto her) I beleive Lycidas is very angry with me; has he not good reaon? (anwered Phillis) do you think he has o little interet in Celadon, as not to hate all thoe that are the caue of his ruine? Alas iter (replied Astrea) I mut confes that I was the caue of his firt being lot, and that I was to blame in condemning him o lightly; But now he may blame himelf for his misfortune: unto whom can be impute any fault, but unto his own curvy humour which moved him o indicreetly to obtain a thouand favours from my innocency, under a fale diguiement? Indeed Phillis the preervation of this hepherd ought to be very dear unto me; But my honour ought to be no les conidered: you have een how oft he has imbraced and kied me, inolently abuing the liberty which I gave him under the notion of Alexis, and whereof I might have been blamed had it been from the peron of Celadon: Not but that I beleive I hould in a little time have pardoned the offence; But when I call to memory the Image of things pat, I am o tranported, as I could ordain him a wore punihment, then I have, if I could think upon it iter (aid Phillis) is this your repentance for ditroying Celadon before? Come come Astrea, you had better abate omething of your rigour, then be put to the pains you were before. Siter replied Atrea, thoe that can temper their paions and motions, are more then Men: we are all too weak
to have that dominion over our elves: we mut, whether we will or no, oberve uch lawes as our paions will impoe upon us: we cannot upon a udden foreee uch accidents as may happen: Do you think, if at that intant, honour had told me. Celadon was unworthy to live, can you think I ay; that I hould repent bidding him die? No no: beleive me, but on the contrary, I hould have thought, that I owed uch a revenge unto my reputation, and hould have been glad to have preerved it, at the rate of that very hepherds life; But on the other ide, (aid Phillis) perhaps you would not have been angry with him, but have received him with Joy, a little before Leonide preented him unto you. I wih, anwered Atrea, that he had never undertaken to delude, and deceive me, that I might without any harm unto my elf, have paid what I owed unto that affection which he bore me: but ince that misfortune is hapned, I mut confes that what regret oever I reent, I cannot condemn my elf for wha • I have done.

In aying o, Atrea went forward, as being deirous to retire into the houe becaue it began to grow late: But Diana, who oberved it, and who had no les horror to that place then to a dark Dangron, having no mind to go into it till the obcurity of night did force it; Companion (aid he unto her) me thinks we have yet time and light enough to go as far as the labyrinth; I beeech you, let us go and walk o far as it. I will go, (anwered Atrea) whither you pleae; Then they turned a little upon the left hand, and being entred into the walk which led that way, preently they pied Leonide, coming a great pace, and having the countenance and garb of one that had ome great caue of orrow. This wrought a trange effect upon the oul of Atrea: for he being in ome hope that Leonide would hinder Celadon from attempting any harm unto himelf, as oon as the aw her return alone, he was even ready to fall down for greif. Firt her greif appeared in her face, and afterwards beginning to igh; Oh my Companions (aid he) yonder is Leonide coming to tell of Celadons death. That, anwered Phillis, does not much trouble you, becaue you deired it, and did abolutly command him to die. In aying o, the Nimph came o neare unto them, that they could eaily perceive the trouble wherein her mind was; And becaue Leonide was a little angry with Atrea for treating Celadon o ill, as oon as he perceived her, he offered to turn into another walk to avoid meeting with her; But Phillis ran after her, and entreated her to tay which he condecending unto, as oon as he came into the preence of Atrea; You have reaon (age Nimph) aid the hepherdes unto her) to hun the Company of a mierable woman, who yet has more caue to complain againt you then you have to hate her; You have reaon to complain againt me, (aid Leonide a little faintly) as againt one who has taken abundance of cure and pain to procure you a happines which you have rejected, and which you will never enjoy; For the gods are mot jut, and will punih your cruelty by ome trange chatiements. The gods, replied Atrea, do know my oul, and all my thoughts: It they do find any crime there, I do not refue any chatiement they will impoe upon me: But I am mot confident they will compaionate my innocency, and will not find any caue to condemn me. None of all this dicoure (aid Phillis) is atisfaction to my mind: I would gladly know where Celadon is: and therefore, good Leonide, tell me. Do you know then (anwered Leonide) that Celadon is alive? I do know (replied Phillis) ome part of this dayes paage, and how cruelly this peevih peice condemned him the econd time unto dipair. Since o (aid the Nimph) I will acquaint you with what has hapned unto him ince, that you may judge whether Atrea have any caue to complain againt me: upon this, Leonide ate down upon the gras, and Diana, Atrea, and Phillis itting about her, the Nimph began thus; Did I not e the day almot done, and that I have not time enough to ay much, I would atisfie you all in every doubt that can arie in your minds, concerning the life which Celadon hath led ince he was taken out of the water; But refferring the relation of that Hitory untill we have more time, I will tell you, that as oon as ever Atrea parted from us, I ran after Celadon; and quickly overtaking him becaue he did not think I followed, and taking hold of his arme, as if I had ome
fears he was in a condition to do himelf ome harm: Shepherd aid I unto him, Atrea commands you to live and to love her: he was a little urprized at this: for as I told you, he did not dream I was o near him, ince he aw me go after Atrea; but turning himelf towards me, and gazing upon me with a trange amazment; Atrea, anwered he, does not deire that I hould live, for he has commanded me to die; and he does me wrong in commanding me to love her, for maugre her harpet rigour, my oul cannot chue but adore her more religiouly then ever. I mut confee I wondered to ee him o calmly compoed, for I expected to find him all fury; but yet till fearing the wort: Celadon, aid I, I tell you nothing but what Atrea her elf will ay, if you will take o much pains as to ee her again: who I? cried he and tarted back, alas Leonide it is not in my power: you heard the entence which he pronounced againt me, it is my full intent to execute it; nor do I make the leat dor at it. I am at all times ready to oberve all her ordinances, and the delight I hall take in living, is not o great as that which I hall take in obeying her; but replied I, what do you think will become of me? can you imagine that I will leave you in this tranport? aure your elf Celadon I will not, but will hinder you as much as poibly I can from doing any harm unto your elf: Sage Nymph, anwered he, though you do not intend to leave me, yet the night will force you unto it, and will be more prevalent with you then all my entreaties; nor will I take much pains to ollicite you, the horrour of darknee and olitude of thee woods will not agree with the oft and tender mind of a woman, and therefore you ought to value your own afty and ret, above mine, and not to be more careful in preventing my death, then in preerving your own life: all this will not do, aid I unto him, for I am reolved upon it, and will not part from you as long as you are in o bad a humour. If the horrour of this olitude do beget any fears in my oul, I hope the gods will enable me to overcome them.

In this you are much mitaken, anwered he preently, for the bet office that you can do unto me, is to let me do as the jutice of Atrea hath commanded: believe it Leonide, that Shepherdee never was, nor never hall be, diobeyed by me: give me leave therefore to do as he did bid me, and give her no caue to hate you for hindering me.

Whilt he was uing all thee perwaive arguments unto me, I called into my memory the words which you poke unto him in the heat of your anger, and conceiving I had found out a good invention to comfort him: Celadon (aid I unto him) I will not hinder you from rendring unto your Shepherdee all that obedience which you do ow unto her; but withal, I would not have you go beyond it, nor to afflict your elf in imagining uch things as never were: I pray let us ee what it was which he commanded, and if we conider well upon it, we hall find no great caue of complaint: nor (aid he) will I o much as murmure againt it: it is ufficient I know, he would have me out of the world; and death being the only way, I mut, I ought, and I will take it. I do not think (aid I unto him) he ever had any uch thought, for if he had, he would have otherwie expreed her elf. I do believe indeed, her intention was to hew you how much he was ahamed at her being o deceived, and at her affording you ome, perhaps, over particular privacies; but when any matter of pennance came into quetion, believe it Celadon he never intended any unto you: To whom then (aid he) to Alexis, anwered I: ah Leonide (replied he preently) you are much mitaken, I did o clearly read in the face of Atrea her deires and intention to ruine me, that if he did name Alexis in lieu of Celadon, it was only becaue that name was more frequent in her mouth then mine; but however it was, I am ure it was unto me he poke, it was me that he condemned by the fury of her looks, and it was from me he broke away with more hatred then if I had been ome Tiger or ome Satyr.

With uch expreions as thee, he till went further from me; and I eeing the night coming on, and knowing that as good a face as I et upon it, yet I was not able to undergo the horrours of the night; but good Celadon (aid I unto him) what is it that you reolve upon? to conform my elf, anwered he, unto that
which Atrea hath commanded me. Then, aid I, you mut not attempt any thing againt your elf: for though he did command you to die; yet he did not command you to kill your elf. Upon this, he began to conider a little; and when I aw, he did not anwer me: I cannot conceive, aid I, that this command of hers ought to trouble you, no more then that command which Nature gave when you came into the world; for Nature, as oon as you began to live, did command you to die; and certainly, ince Astrea did not aign you any time, you ought to tay till he prefix it, or till the weaknee of your humanity, does exact from you that tribute which all creatures pay.

Fair Nymph, aid he then unto me, Atrea did not aign me any time, becaue he knew I ought to be as ready to execute her commands, as he to pronounce them: quetionlee he meant the ame day whereon he let me know my fault, hould be the day whereon I hould be punihed: I do therefore conjure you not to croe my deires any longer: tell that unthankful fair one (for doubtlee you will find her full of joy at my misfortune) that I dare not o much as grieve at my death, let my orrows hould provoke hers unto the like: aure her that of all the favours he ever hewed me, I hold this for the greatet, ince in a moment he has delivered me from all the torments he was able to make me uffer: for when I am dead, that fair one will not be angry at me; but if by ill fortune her mind be not enough revenged, even for pities ake move her to pardon the urplus of my crime. I would willingly come and do my pennance before her, but not having time, nor knowing how to do it better then in the loe of my life: Tell her, fair Nymph, that I am going to finih it for the love of her; and that as there is none but he for whom I would live, o there is none but he for whom I would dy.

Fair Shepherdees; I mut confee that I heard all this, without aying any thing unto him: for my heart was o adly compaionate, that I could do nothing but dry up my tears which began to trickle down my cheeks: o as when I began to peak, he interrupted me thus: but why am I o lack in uch a noble act? Why do I reit the will of Atrea, who would have a freh caue to condemn me, did he know how I delay the pleaure which he will take in my death: Adieu fair Nymph, adieu age Leonide; be not, as Atrea is, inenible unto the motions of compaion. Give me leave, I beeech you to teal one poor kie upon your fair hand, in aurance that you will obtain one from the Shepherdee, or at the leat, that you will take o much pains as to ask it, as a tetimony that he will forget all my offences: upon this, O how ad my oul is to think upon it, he took my hand, and having lifted it to his lips three times, he ran away from me as fat as ever he could, and though I made as much hate after him as poibly I could, yet I lot the ight of him preently: This accident made me almot mad; I knew not what to do: I was out of all hopes to find him, and yet I could not find in my heart to return without him. At lat, in this confuion of thoughts, one while apprehending the harm that might happen unto him, and another while blaming your too udden rigour, I aw the day did bid farewel to the world: o eeing no poible remedy againt this diater, I returned back, till calling Alexis, Alexis, Celadon, Celadon; but hearing none return any anwer unto my call, my orrows began to be almot intollerable, and imprinted in my face uch igns of death, as doubtlee you aw, when firt I came unto you.

Such was the dicoure of Leonide, which infued uch trange affrights into the mind of Atrea, that he was even rady to run out of her wits, her eye was not at this time able to drop a tear: for her heart was o infinitly oppreed with orrow, as it was impoible he hould weep; but in exchange, ighs and groans iued in uch abundance, as did quite take away the liberty of peech: Phillis, who knew the humour of her companion, and feared let this lat dipair of Celadon hould drive her into dipair alo, he reolved to apply ome remedy: fair Nymph, aid he unto Leonide, ince Licidas is abroad, I am very confident he will remedy all thee diorders, and will never return until he has et all treight again, or at the leat, till he have hared in his brothers orrows. Alas, alas, iter, aid Astrea, and could hardly peak, it is to be feared that the fury of Celadon, will prevent the
help of Licidas; or that the depair of the one urmounting the perwaions of the other, cannot ave him from the ame precipice, in which, perhaps, both are already fallen: And hould it be o, I hould be doubly criminal, by committing two murders in the peron of Celadon, and in making my revenge to reach the innocence of Licidas.

Upon this, Leonide riing, and taking Atrea by the hand, the very truth is (aid he unto her) I cannot tell how to excue your cruelty; for indeed it has been extraordinary: but ince you are not now in a condition to help it, I conceive it bet to talk no more of this accident, unlee unto uch as are in a capacity to apply ome remedy. Diana, Atrea, and Phillis, finding this motion to be good, all four took the way unto the houe, and came thither jut as Adamas had concluded the Articles of Paris his marriage: the conditions whereof were not o ecretly carried, but ome of the Dometiques came to know them, and divulging it frome one to another, the noie of it went through the houe, and from thence into all the neighbouring Towns.

Belinde no ooner aw Diana, but calling unto her, he gave her an accompt of what was concluded upon with the Druide: at which the Shepherdee was o urprized, that notwithtanding all the good councel which her mother gave unto her, he was ready to fall into a wound: yet being a peron of a mot admirable judgement, and dicreet, above all the Shepherdees in Forrets, he diembled her orrows as well as he could, and addreing her elf unto Belinde; but Madam (aid he unto ber) methinks the buinee is done with a little too much precipitation: Daughter (anwered Belinde) a good action can never be done too oon; beides, I have not long time to tay here, for you know that my profeion calls me another way, and therefore this very night the marriage mut be conummated. As oon as he had aid o, he went unto her chamber to make ome prayers unto Hymen for a properous event of this match, and left Diana alone.

This Shepherdee, whoe oul was over-welled with orrow, he would needs go immediatly out of the houe, perhaps to do ome deperate act upon her elf; but Phillis, who was alo by her elf, whilt Adamas was talking unto Leonide and Atrea, he ran unto her, and began to talk with her. Diana, who could not hide her dipleaure, though he had been the cunninget woman in the world; and who beides, knew that he might confidently open her oul unto her companion, he began to hold this dicoure, but with o many ighs and tears, that Phillis was extreamly moved to pity her, and to wonder that Belinde hould o tyrannize over her will.

In the mean time Adamas who was very deirous to hear of Leonides negotiation, and hearing what uccee he had, O heavens, Atrea (cried he out) what do you mean? will you be the caue of the loe of the mot amiable and faithful Shepherd that ever lived upon the banks of Lignon? Father (anwered Atrea) it will not be long before you will be rid both of him and me: for if I be the caue of his death, he hall be the authour of mine, only it angers me that his way of treating me, hinders me from dying with honour: for I am extreamly afraid, there will be uch a blame upon me, for permitting him o many favours, unto which he would never have apired, unlee he had been faulty, both in his love and dicretion. Daughter, replied Adamas, thee faults whereof you accue him, are the perfections which might well make him hope for a better entertainment then he hath received from you; but he never failed either in his repect or in his love: and were you well acquainted with the actions of his life, doubtlee your opinion would concur with mine. Father, replied Atrea, I never enquired after him ince he threw himelf into Lignon: for never thinking he had ecaped that danger, I thought upon him only as a peron whom I did eteem, and unto whom I had a greater inclination then the enmity that was between our Parents required. Well (aid the Druide) I will better inform you, as oon as I have commanded ome to follow him. Lycidas, aid Atrea, is already gone to that purpoe: it is enough, replied the Druide, for that Shepherd will not neglect any coure that is requiite for his preervation: in aying o, he took Atrea
by the hand, and leading her into a corner of the room, he commanded Leonide to go and entertain Diana and Phillis, and then began his di ••• ure thus; I have told you, (my dear Daughter) o many paages of this hepherds paion, that though you had no other tetimonies of his love then uch as I hall give you, it were enough to make you love him above all Men living: you think him deficient in his love, and in his dicretion; but in the relation which I hall make, you will oberve uch trange tetimonies, both of the one, and the other, as you will admire his contancy, and wonder at his virtue: You mut not think Atrea, that I am ignorant of any accident in the whole coure of your life: I have been intructed by him who caued, and reented them, and who would not tell a lie for a world; And that you may not wonder why I have been o carefull for his preervation; you mut know, that the gods have linked the happines of my old age unto that which this hepherd is to enjoy; and the tranquility of my dayes is to be uch as I procure unto Celadon: Judge therefore whether I have not good caue to complain againt you ince you have ruined all my hopes, and under a crupulous pretence of honour, you have put me into uch a condition, as never to enjoy any contentment in the world. Yet I dare not depair of the goodnes in the gods, leat they hould render me unworthy of their bleings, and therefore I take all in good part, and reign my elf wholly unto their wills: But that you may not accue Celadon, as any way acceary unto the misfortune that may happen unto me; but that on the contrary, all the fault may be imputed unto your rigour, I will acquaint you with her life ever ince you banihed him from you.

You know very well Atrea, that then he threw himelf into Lignon: But yet he was no drownd: for the current of the tream having cat him upon the and on the other ide of the river, he was ayded by Galathea, Silvia, and Leonide, who carried him ecretly into the Pallace of Iaures: then he related unto her the paionate affection of Galathea unto him; the lamentations which Celadon made when his letters were filched from him: his contraint in not knowing how to avoid the offers of the Nimph, his icknes, his relappes, and in fine his coming in the habit and under the name and notion of Lucinde: After which he told her the life he began to lead in his ca •• ; the tratage •• which Leonide invented to get him out; The laborious indutry he ued in erecting the Temple of the goddes Atrea: his ravihments that morning when he erected an emptie monument for him in the Company of all the hepherds and and hepherdees of Lignon: and latly by what meanes he perwaded him to pas in the habit and name of Alexis: Now, aid Adamas and continued, you know better then I, all that has hapned unto him ince. But that you may be no longer angry at him and your elf for permitting o many privacies, let me tell you, that thoe things which another would have taken for high favours, he received them as extream punihments, and I have een him o often afflicted and greived, as I have wihed a thouand times that you had not o much affection to him as you expreed: And indeed Atrea, if you will but take o much paines as to examine your memorie, you will find, that it was you alwayes, which began to Carres and to kis, for I dare lay my life, he had rather have dyed then ever offer it; and he did retrain himelf leat you hould upect any thing of his diguiment. This Daughter, has been the life of Celadon, whom you have mot earnetly deired to enjoy; and of whom you have et o great a value, though now make no accompt of him when it is permitted you to obtain him. If heaven do help Lycidas to bring him backe, good Atrea promie me, to look upon him with a kind apect, and that you will forgive and forget all the injuries which you think he has comitted againt you.

Atrea who did not forget one yllable of all the Druides dicoure, and who by the conideration of o many uccees was confirmed in a belief that her hepherd was really innocent: Father (aid he unto him) if Lycidas do bring him backe, which I do not expect, knowing how udden he is in all his reolutions, I do promie to behave my elf towards him, as you will appoint me, and upon the leat ign that I hall ee of his repentance, I hall be ready to acknowledge, that as
evere as I have been towards him, I will not here after be difficient in the remuneration of all his ervices.

Upon this promie, Adamas kied her cheek, and carried her backe unto Leonide, Phillis, and Diana; then went into Bellindes Chamber to entreat her that the marriage might be deferred until the next day, when he thought he hould not have any caue of orrow, in hopes to hear good newes of Alexis. Unto which Bellinde conenting, Diana was preently advertied of it: who eeing his miery one night further off, did a little leen that extream grief which hung upon her oul.

Thus did this day pas in the houe of Adamas, whilt love produced contrarie effects in Marcelles. Amais was every day in hopes to obtain a firm and univerall peace very hortly. Sigimond was ravihed with thoe charmes with he found in the face and affection of Dorinde: Roilion fully aured of Roaniras contancy and love was retles till he went to enjoy thoe favours, which he could not grant him, but in the preence of her Argira. Damon was even upon the point of marriage with Madonthe, who thought he owed her elf unto the merits and valour of her Cavelier: Alcidon found nothing in the mind of Daphnide to contend with, and waited for nothing but the dienchantment of the foutain, to commemorate his joyes. Ligdamon, and Silvia alo held good correpondency: But amongt all thee felicities, the happines of Lindamor might pas for extream.

This Cavelier being reolved to follow the Counel which Adamas gave him, he was no ooner out of bed, but he went into Sigimonds Chamber, where finding Roilion, who came to go a hunting with him, he was very glad to meet with this opportunity of talking with them when they were both together: So after he had bidden them good morrow, and told them that he would hew them the bet places to find port: But Sirs (aid he unto them, and miled:) If I do take upon me the honour to wait upon you in this chae, may I not hope you will be pleaed to favour me in that which I do intend to purue? Sigimond, who partly knew his meaning, (for Dorinde had told him ome particulars of the Caveliers love) for my part (anwered he) you need not doubt but I hall be mot ready to erve you, and give all the aitance that poibly I can, provided you will but direct me which way. And for my part, (aid Roilion preently) I am mot confident, that Lindamor makes no doubt of me; For he knows how much I eteem him: Sirs replied Lindamor, I do embrace your good wills, as my mot Soveraign happines, and I will aume the boldnes to acquaint you with my buines, that you may judge whether the aitance which I deire from you be fit to be obtained. If I mitake not (aid Sigimond) we have now leaure to tell you, for I do not think we hall ee the Nimph untill it be late. Yet Sirs (replied Lindamor) that is not the principal caue of my coming hither, for my deign was only to come and preent my mot humble ervice unto you: But ince you are pleaed I hould make ue of this time, and that in relating unto you the mot ecret actions of my life, I hall let you know uch thoughts as my heart has harboured this two or three years lat pat: I do mot humbly beeech you not to condemn my preumption, in uffering my ambition to oar far higher then eyther my merit or my birth ought to apire; but rather to believe that it is an effect of Galatheas power, who robbing me of my reaon, has not left my judgment o ound as it ought to be; but yet ound enough to know that I am no way worthy of her. Give me then leave to tell you, great Sirs, that Adamas being pleaed to take o much pains at to come unto my Chamber this morning, and like an officious and charitable friend, having propounded unto me ome expedients to render me the proeion of this fair Nimph, the more eaily, he found none more neceary nor more likely to prove effectuall, then your favours; upon which he advied me to build the foundation of my fortune: For (aid he unto me, if thoe Princes will but honour you o far as to become your advocate, and intercede for you unto the Nimph, mot certainly he will deny them nothing they can ask. This, great Sirs, was the advice of this grave Druide, which without any farther dipute, I am reolved to follow, though I mut confes, how great oever the neceity be of your aitance, yet it is grand preumpiton
in me to offer o much trouble unto you. But ince your flowing goodnes towards me, bids me hope for the honour of your aitance, let me freely tell you, that the happines, or the miery of my life, does meerly depend upon the confeion, or deniall of Amais, unto the requet which you hall prefer unto her in my behalf for the poeion of Galathea. And that you may know, your only difficulty is to obtain the conent of that great Nimph, though it be a little vanity in me to ay it, yet I mut tell you that her fair complaence towards me, does put me into great hopes of gaining her conent.

Upon this, Lindamor began to relate ome arguments of Galatheas good will; after he had hinted upon the mot probable and remarkable accidents; Generous Lindamor (replied Roilion) you need no other mediators in your behalf, but thoe qualities which are eminent in your courage and virtue: they alone are able to acquire Empires, ince they do adorn you with illutrious merit. However, I am mot willing to take upon me this commiion with Sigimond and Godomar; who doubtles are better able to erve you, then I am: but however, I am infinitely deirous to have the glory of contributing omething unto your contenment. T'is true indeed (anwered Sigimond) I do not think that my brother and I, are altogether unproffitable; but I cannot grant that we have more prevalency then you, unto whom Amais is highly beholding. However it be (aid Godomar) we do all owe this office unto the valour of Lindamor: and I conceive it requiite, that upon the firt opportunity we find, we ound the mind of Amais, who doubles will be inclinable unto it by way of recompence for all the great ervices which he hath received from him. Lindamor having committed the matter to them he accompanied them into the Nimphes Chamber, where Roanira, Galathea, Daphnide, Madonthe, Silvia, and many others were already come. Afterwards all went unto the Temple, and tayed there till dinner time: After which Amais was very deirous to take the air, and hew unto her princely guets, the port of hunting, and many other delightfull diverions.

On the other ide Clotilda deiring to trike when the iron was hot, and to take Gondebaut when he was in a good mind, leat he hould forget the promies which he had made in Sigimonds favour, he went unto him in his cloet, in hopes to make all friends. She found him with that Princes lettet in his hand; yet his browe eemed as if his mind was not well atisfied: But he in a urpried manner aid unto him: think no more upon it Sir; The promie which you have already made, mut without more thinking upon it, be out of hand performed; Do not uffer this eperation of your two ons Sigimond, and Godomar, from you, to be laid in your dih, or accued as a bad father: And let not the world look upon them any longer as bad one. I wear Clotilda (anwered the king) you have hit upon my very thought, but not of all; For I was thinking too, what will become of Dorinde; hould I conent unto her return, Sigimond would doubtles dote upon her as he did before, and I hould be very orry to be an eye witnes of it: It he remain with Amais, I fear that—at this word he topt and shook his head two or three times, and ighed: but Clotilda, who melt his meaning, and knew he feared that her abence would be a great regret of heart unto him, yet he would not take the leat notice of it: but diembling her, thoughts as well as he could, Sir replied he, if he do remain with Amais, you need not doubt but to find out many wayes to cure the mind of Sigimond of his paion towards her: Be pleaed therefore to leth live till with that age Nimph, and command your ons to return home, for abence is an excellent remedie to cure the wounds of love, beides uch others as your widom may make ue of. Gondebaut began to mile at the thought of Clotilda, little thinking that he had hit right upon his: And this young Princes knowing very well how to lay hold upon this opportunity, and take him in that good humour. Oh Sir (aid he) I do long exceedingly to ee Sigimond again that I may chide him for his follies, and hew him how little care he has of his honour, in engaging himelf o inconiderately to love a woman far below his merit, and quality: Ah Cotilda (aid the king with a deep igh) it is not without reaon that love is always painted blind: For, (and I peak it knowingly) he does blind our eyes, and o much diorder our
judgments, that we cannot conider any thing but our own pleaures. In aying o, he began to walk; and Clotilda fearing to waken that paion which the abence of Dorinde had lulled aleep; But good Sir, (aid he unto him) is it your pleaure that Amais hould enjoy that peace which our Princes have deired in her behalf? All your people doe abhor that war: and for your part, I cannot think it will be properous or any way advantageous to you, becaue it is began upon uch a weak foundation: Though I hould make a peace with Amais (anwered Gondebaut, Dorinde will not be included: Clotilda, who knew the thoughts of his heart, and knew that all this dicoure proceeded from his paion, but eeming not to undertand his meaning; Sir (aid he) I cannot think but you will pardon her; for alas he is unworthy of your prinely anger. Upon this Gondebaut was even ready to ay that he was not unworthy of his love: yet being unwilling to hew that he entertained any advantageous thoughts of Dorinde, he turned his dicoure, and looking upon Clotilda, ince you deire the return of Sigimond (aid he unto her) and of Godomar, you hall ee how willing I am to content you, and how ready I am to forgive and forget their faults; let me therefore give Ligonias that anwer which he tays for, and leave me for a while, that I may dipatch ome letters. Clotilda upon this kneeled down, and having kied his hand, he went out of the cloet, and et to eek for Ligonias, with whom he talked, whilt Gondebaut was writing. As oon as he thought the king had done, he entred in with him; and Gondebaut, cauing him to come neerer, Cavalier (aid he unto him) I do give you full and abolute power to treat and conclude a peace with Amais tell her that no other coniderations moved me unto it, but the knowledge which I have of her virtue and goodnes: Aure her, that if the wicked deign of Polemas had been well known unto me, I had never offered to countenance his peridy: for injutice did never pleae me. Here (aid he) is a letter unto Sigimond: tell that on of mine, that I do pardon him, and command him to leave Dorinde there, and bring Godomar with him: In aying o, he permitted Ligonias to kis his hand: and the king embracing him as a tetimony of that eteem which he had of him, he gave him leave to depart, and commanded ix of the bravet Cavaliers in all his court to accompany him in his journey; Ligonias alo received Clotildas letter, and commands, not without returning unto that young Prince • many mot hearty thanks for her good negotiaton; After which he departed with a reolution to make as much hate as poibly he could.

Ligonias riding mot part of the night, he came to Marcelles in the morning before Amais was up He went firt unto the quarters of Prince Sigimond, whom he found newly out of his bed: after a aluting complement, he preented King Gondebauts letter unto him; At the firt, Sigimond durt not ask him what was the ucces of his comiion, leat he hould hear ome ill newes: but after he had embraced him, and found more igns of Joy then orrow in his face; well Ligonias (aid he unto him) what does the Burgundian King intend to do? To have you with him again Sir (anwered the Cavalier) upon any termes in the wor • d: I do beleive it (aid the Prince) but upon what termes does he mean; termes of his anger, or termes of his goodnes; Ligonias miling at this quetion, Sir aid he unto him, upon uch termes as an indulgent Father, deires to ee his child: he does deire to ee you Sir with a thouand protetations and aurances, to forgive and forget that offence which (as he conceived) he had received from you: And to promie to correpond with Amais as you would have him, and as I hall conclude with her, by virtue of that power which he hath given unto me: This, replied Sigimond, is the bet newes that ever could come, or I expect; but, aid he, did he not mention Dorinde? Yes Sir; anwered Ligonias, the mot expres command of all concernes her: for he does deire that you will leave her here, and bring Prince Godomar with you. In this, (aid Sigimond) he has fully atisfied my own deire; for I was reolved not to expoe her any more unto the mercy of his paion, and am extreamly glad, he has commanded it to be o, ince I can o willingly and o eaily obey him: In aying o he opened King Gondebauts letter, and found it thus written.

body.head: GONDEBAUTS Letter unto SIGISMOND.
body.p: THat pity makes a thunder bolt to fall out of the hands of the gods, is it which diarmes me of that anger where with I intended to detroy you. Your repentance has a trong influence upon me, and your Letter, which deires a peace with Amais, has this operation, to remember me, that I am your Father, and to forget that I was her enemy: My hatred towards her, was not o jut as my reentments againt you, and yet I am dipoed equally to forget both; to the end, your obligation being the greater, the greater alo may be your acknowledgment of it: That which I do now deire of you, is your return, and you will no ooner return unto that duty which nature obliges you unto, but you hall find me extreamly affectionate unto my own blood. Let your preence then be accompanied with Godomar, and live o hereafter, as there may no <> correpondency arie betwixt us, Adieu.

div.p: The reading of this Letter did go to the very heart of Sigimond, and did let him know, that with what fury oever the heart of a Father be incened againt his children, it is hard for him to forget that duty which, Nature, does exact from his affection: now did Sigimond in ome ort repent that ever he had dipleaed him; and when he began to conider how happily things tood, he did auredly believe it to be done by the Providence of the gods and heartily rejoyced at the peace which was procured unto the two Princees, Amais and Galathea. He was till upon this thought, when he opened the Letter from Clotilda; and finding therein her earnet deires of his peedy return, and her joyes for his victory, he was pleaed beyond all expreion or thought, and reolved with himelf to give her that atisfaction. In fine, after ome dicoure upon Clotilda with Ligonias; without any more tay in this place (continued he) let us go unto Roilion; my brother is already gone to his chamber, and let us impart unto them the good news you have brought us.

I hall wait upon you Sir, anwered Ligonias, whither you pleae, provided we loe no time to advertie the Nymph, for I would not upon any terms hinder her one minute of that pleaure which he will have when he hears the news. With uch dicoure as this Sigimond dreed himelf, and hearing that Gondebaut had ent ome Cavaliers to accompany him, he caued them to be ent for, and kindly entertained them. After this, they went all out, and as oon as they entred into Roilions chamber, both he and Godomar ran to embrace Ligonias, and wondering at the hate which he had made, they asked him concerning all thoe things whereof Sigimond was fully informed; and having anwered that Sigimond could tell them: See here, aid Sigimond, what tetimonies I have received of the Kings clemency: Pray ee (continued he and the Letter unto Roilion) how kindly he writes: That Prince then having read the Letter: Now (aid he) may Amais rejoyce, and believe that her afety is ettled upon uch a ure foundation as cannot be haken: I am o full of joy (aid Godomar) as I will accompt this day the happiet day of my life: It hall be a holy day to us all; aid Sigimond, and I do believe Lindamor will have a hare in it.

As they were thus dicouring, they undertood that the Nymph was ready, and might be een: Godomar tayed with Ligonias, and Sigimond with Railion went to bid her good morrow, and acquaint her with the happy return of that Cavalier: at which Amais was o joyed, as one might judge he built all the happinee of her life upon it: But becaue he was to receive Ligonias as an Envoy from the Burgundian King, to treat and conclude o olemn a peace: As oon as Roanira, Galathea, Madonthe, Dorinde, Daphnide, Silvia, and the ret were come into her chamber, he went down into the Hall to give audience unto this welcome
Embaadour: Godomar was preently advertied of it, and preparing himelf to bring in Ligonias, he caued him to walk before the ix Cavaliers of Gondebaut, and Godomar leading him by the hand, conducted him unto Amais. The Nymph advanced two or three teps to receive him, and the Cavalier kneeling down upon the ground, and at the Nymphs requet riing up again, Madam (aid he unto her) Gondebaut, the King of the Burgundians, does conent unto the peace which you deired: He would have it ever hereafter to be o olid and firm, as that it cannot be broken, without the in of perjury upon the firt Violator: He never had begun this warre, but at the olicitation of Polemas, who colouring his perfidie with pecious pretences of right, implored his Arms; but ince that rebellious ubject has found the punihment of his treaon, he is reolved that the end of his life hall be the end of all your dientions: and in lieu of ever attempting any thing that may be prejudicial unto you, he will live with you no longer as an enemy, but as a neighbour and friend.

After this, Ligonias held his peace, and Amais anwered him: I do, with abundance of joy, accept the favour and kindnee of Gondebaut; I hall hold it alwayes a great glory to render him what is due unto his merit and quality; and ince he is pleaed t • honour me o far as to live peaceably and in quiet with me, I hall cherih his amity as one of the principal upporters of my etate. In aying o, he pulled off her glove, and laying her hand upon that of Ligonias: This (aid he) is a Symbole of that Faith which I do wear in the preence of gods and men never to violate or falifie: Ligonias having worn the ame; and this, aid he, (taking two pieces of a broken Javelin) hall be a tetimony of our Re-union. In aying o, he tied both the pieces of the Javelin together; and the aid, for a tetimony unto future times, that this peace hall be pure and inviolable, this Javelin hall be conumed by the puret of all the elements: and then in the preence of all the company, he threw it into a fire, which was expreely kindled for it. This Ceremony was no ooner ended, but Amais caued the Peace to be proclaimed, and the People, in joy of uch good news, made Bonfires in every part of the Town, and every one danced and feated in ign of joy.

Adamas was preently advertied of it by a Cavalier whom the Nymph ent unto him; and though he reented this good news with joy, yet was there a mixture of thoe misfortunes which hapned the day before in his houe: The properity of Amais did extreamly glad him, but the digrace of Celadon did infinitly afflict him. He knew very well that his duty was to wait upon the Nymph, and to rejoyce with her at this new peace; but the interet he had in this Shepherd was a chain which tied him to his houe. So not being able to forake Celadon in this ditree, he beeeched Amais to excue him, for he had ome buinee of great conequ • n • e at home, of which he would come and give her an accompt as oon as ever he had any leiure. Amais received thee excues, and Sigimond, left he hould give his Father any dicontent, reolved to depart that very ame day, after ome dicoure with Dorinde: he bad Godomar therefore prepare himelf, and deired him to invite Roilion, Lindamor, Damon, Alcidon, and other Cavaliers, to come and pend ome dayes at Lions in the court of Gondebaut, which Godomar promiing to do, he acquitted himelf o well, as he obtained a promie from Roilion, upon condition he hould not tay above three dayes at the mot. Lindamor, Damon, Alcidon, Ligonias, Ligdamon, and the ret thought it fit not to promie any thing without the conent of Amais, who knowing that Roilion had promied, was well pleaed they hould bear her company.

As oon then as they had dined, •• d Amais gone unto her cloet to reolve upon omething concerning the departure of Sigimond, that Prince addreing himelf unto Roanira and Galathea, who held Dorinde by the hand. I think fair Ladies (aid he unto them) that if my journey hould be according to your wihes, it would be very bad, ince doubtlee you do wih me very ill, for the crime which I hall commit, in taking from you your Cavaliers. It is very true, anwered Roanira, and did I think the return of Roilion would not be very peedy, I hall never conent unto his departure, and hould have a jut action of
complaint againt you; but being confident you will not offer to take him away, but with intention to return him afe and oon again, I can with more patience put up the injury you do me, without any thoughts of revenge. This, fair Nymph, (aid Sigimond, and addreed himelf unto Galathea) perhaps is not your humour: Sir, anwered Galathea, in this her mind concurrs with mine, and I cannot anwer you better then in her words: Is it you then fair Dorinde, aid he, that will not pardon this crime? Dorinde would have anwered, but Sigimond interrupted: Nay fairet, aid he, I would not have you pronounce your doom before o many witnees; I would have you, by the leave of both thee fair ones, peak it unto none but my elf. Upon this Roanira and Galathea withdrawing a little from Dorinde, Sigimond took her hand, and leading her unto a place where ome eats were, deired her to it down, and then poke to her in thee terms: Did I think, dear Dorinde, that my departure would make you judge otherwie of me then as I deire, certainly the time of my departure would be the time of my death, or at leat, I would not upon any terms in the world conent unto uch a ad eparation: I do know exactly how much I ow unto the commands of a Father, and I know alo what obedience is to be given unto the commands of love; and if my Father command any thing which hall croe the affection which I do hear unto you, I think it no in to diobey him: I conceive the tay that you are to make here will not be tedious unto you, and the lee, becaue you will not be hanted with the impertinent courthip of Gondebaut, and becaue I hall every ment be aluting you with Letters of love and aurances of my fidelity: If you think you hould enjoy more contentment in another place, honour me o far as to tell me into what part of the world •• u would have me carry you: I protet I will do it, and lay aide all coniderations in the world to pleae you. Sir (anwered Dorinde) I ee o little ground to hope for any good from your abence, as I am not to be blamed if I fear, that the day which takes me from your preence, will take out of your oul all this love you talk of: Had I any qualities either in my birth, wit, or Fortune, able to keep an affection after it is once got, I hould not be altogether in uch a deperate opinion; but knowing how extreamly defective I am in all, or at the leat in comparion of you, I expect all the rigours of a bitter abence, after I am once at a ditance from you. Not but that I do conent unto this departure: for I will not have o much care of that amity you are pleaed to honour me withal, as I have of your Fortunes: but I mut confee freely, I do not expect any good unto my elf by it, but I do infallibly believe, that either the perwaions of King Gondebaut, or the mallice of my enemies, will extinguih all your love to me.

Mitree (replied Sigimond) for I dare wear you merit that name, and hall have it before any woman in the world; be fully aured, that this hall never be, and that it hall be more eaie for them to take away my life then my love. Know Dorinde, that I have prepared my elf long ince to anwer unto all uch points as they dare propoe unto me: for indeed, what can they object, but that there is a great inequality between our conditions; and that you being born a ubject unto the King my Father, it will be little honourable for me to marry you? This is all they can alledge againt my affection to you: for as concerning your virtue, they know it is without any exception, all the malice and candal upon earth is not able to blemih it. But I hall anwer them, that I being no lave, but a Prince, born free in my own choie and will, it were mot abominable Tyranny and injutice to contrain me unto any other alliance, then where my own free-born inclination moves me unto. I'll tell them, that the knowledge which I have of your humour and wit, does promie me more contentment then I can find in any trange Princee, who being born and educated in a clime contrary unto mine, will be of a contrary Genius, and not o utable and pliant unto my deires and mind; and for a concluion I'll tell them, that it is the property of Kings to do memorable acts, and I hall take delight in urmounting Nature, giving the quality of Queen unto a woman, whoe birth denied it unto her; but if thee arguments hould not prove valid and full enough to top their mouths, I have another which is more trong and prevalent, and I know they cannot gain ay it, when I hall peremptorily
tell them that it is my will. Therefore, my dearet Dorinde, you have no reaon to fear, but that my paion unto you will have as good a uccee as we can deire. Alas Sir, (aid Dorinde and ighed) If I do fear, it is becaue I do eteem you, and fear and amity are alwayes ineperable. I do not doubt but you mean well, and will to your power perform what you promie. But when I conider, with what tratagems and arguments they will endeavour to ubvert your contancy; and what malicious devices they will ue to ruine me in your opinion: I mut confee, I cannot believe you will be able to reit them. I do freely confee Sir, that I have an inclination to you, perhaps more then becomes me to have unto any man; but I do wear, that if even I hear you begin to fail in that fidelity which you have vowed unto me, I will hate you o abominably, as though I cannot be revenged upon you, yet I will upon my elf for loving you more then I ought: I hope, dearet Dorinde (aid Sigimond) that you will ooner hear of my death then my incontancy: and if it hould o happen, that the malice of any Rival, or perhaps Gondebaut, hould raie ome fale reports which hall belie thee aurances which now I do give unto you, if you love me believe them not, nor upect me as faulty in any one of thoe promies which I have made. I pray heaven (anwered Dorinde) I never be deceived in my hopes and pretentions: for if I do fall from that height unto which you have raied my ambition, the fall will mot certainly be mortal unto me, and it will be you only that would be culpable of all the harm that happens.

Dearet Dorinde, for pities ake, drive all upicions out of your oul, and be aured, that as oon as ever I am at my own liberty and dipoe, I will add unto the quality of a Lover, the title of a husband, and hall be more proud of that happy name, then of uch a Scepter as would make me poeour of all the world. Alas, heaven would be the puniher of my elfnee, and hell would let looe all its Furies to torment me, hould I falifie my word, or well you up with vain hopes: No, no, Dorinde, believe it, my love is a pure and a holy flame, and conequently pleaing unto the Gods; I never entertained any thought of you which was not holy and lawful: and ince it hath pleaed the gods to uffer the continuance of my paion thus long, certainly they will never let it die: At the leat, I do protet and wear unto you by all the Divinities which inhabit heaven, by that love which I bear unto your fairet elf, nay, by your adored elf, my Dorinde, that all the care which a devoted lover can have for the preervation of his zealous flame, I will imploy to the preervation of mine, to the end that if it be poible it may live even after my death.

In aying o he took her hand, and lifted it to his mouth, which Dorinde did not deny, for he was o taken up with ad thoughts of this doleful eparation, as he hardly knew what he did, but becaue Sigimond did in an amorous rapture, as it were, dwell upon her fair hand, he uddenly pulled it away, and aid unto him, what protetations and oathes oever you make to aure me of your fidelity, yet my fears, Sirr of your change makes me doubt, that they are not able to make your words good, unto which I do give all the credit and faith that can be given unto the word of a Prince. I will, to my conolation, believe that you will not change, and will be perwaded that you do love me: I will think your paion to be very high, and that it cannot admit of any deminution; but however, give me leave to reent your departure, as the greatet injury that Fortune could do unto me; and if you do need any further tetimony of my happy wihes of your welfare, receive my tears as the greatet that I can give. Upon this he let fall ome tears, which he offered to retrain but could not, which Sigimond no ooner perceived, but he cried out, O my dearet Dorinde, preerve thoe pearls only for the god of Love, and do not recompence my love with Jewels of o high a price: wipe away thoe obliging tears, let they hould move too much orrow, and force me after your example unto the like.
