Dorinde then, lifting her handkerchief up to her eyes, provided (aid he) that my eyes may never be provoked unto this ad office by your infidelity, I will not hed any more at your departure; but if it happen (as heaven forbid it hould) that I hould ever have any caue to accue you of infidelity, I hall chide thoe tears which now I have
propped, and condemn them as accearies unto your Treaon. I do protet once more, dearet Dorinde, replied Sigimond, that you hall never have any caue to condemn either your tears or my love: I will mot inviolably oberve my promies, and you hall find that the end of my affection hall not be ooner then the end of my life; you may believe it, and the ooner, becaue I ay it without contraint, or without any deign in the world. Make me o happy as to be no lee religious in the obervances of all your promies, then I hall be in mine; and know, that I hall enjoy no happy minutes during this abence from you, but uch as are imployed in the thoughts of you: In aying o, he kied her hand three times, and went away without giving her o much leiure as no anwer; not being able to reit thoe violences, which his love and compaion raied in his oul.

Roilion at the ame time, asked Roanira leave to go and ee Gondebaut; and though at the firt he was hardly to be perwaded unto it, yet at lat being overcome by his reaons, he conented he hould go, upon condition of return within five or ix dayes at the furthet limit. For (aid he unto him) if the Queen Argira hould end, and precribe limits unto our return, how hall I be able to obey her, when you are o far ditant from hence? I do not know any thing in the world that hould be more dear unto you then her preence; and the rather, becaue if you love me, you know it is he only from whom you are to expect the accomplihment of your deires and mine: My fairet Princee, anwered Roilion, the deign which carries me unto Gondebaut, perhaps, is greater then you imagine: you know how puiant that Prince is, and how much his amity is to be ought after: Now I do hope by that inviolable contract of friendhip which is betwixt Sigimond, Godomar, and me, to gain omething upon the good will of the Father; and to make him my Allie. I do not enquire, replied Roanira, after the caue which moves you to go, but I do only olicite you to a certain the time of your return. I know all you propoitions and deigns, have ome legal and noble object for their end; but I fearmdash;upon this Roanira topt; and Roilion oberving by her countenance ome impreion of fears; what does my dearet Princee fear? (aid he unto her) is it that I hall die of thoe torments I hall endure when I am out of your ight? No (replied he very dejectedly) I rather fear, that when you ee Clotilda, you will die for love of her. Jealous Princee, replied Roilion, your upicions wound me to the oul, but I will not go; and though I did conceive ome neceity in making this voyage, yet I will light it for your ake, and will let you ee, that the conervation of your amity is more dear and coniderable unto me, then the afety of that etate which is to fall unto me.

Roanira then quitting her firt apprehenions, and looking upon Roilion with a miling eye: pray Sir, aid he, excue my fears, which ought to be arguments unto you of my love, ince I do fear the loing of you; but for all that, do not alter your intentions of going with Sigimond: for I do promie to endure your abence, rather with longing impatience of your return, then any fears of acrificing your elf unto another: Me thinks (anwered Roilion) that my ervices may merit that belief from you; and if there do remain in you any doubts of my fidelity, I have as much love as ever I had, and can begin new aurances of my elf: believe it fair Roanira, I can be none but yours; and things abolutely impoible hall become eaie to all the world, before I ceae loving you with the ame zeal I firt reented when I made profeion of it unto you. I do believe it, aid Roanira, and do vow, never to doubt it any more, provided dear Roilion that you will alo believe my faith to be inviolable. After this, Roilion asking her whether he would honour him with any ervice: All that I deire from you (anwered he) is to return oon again, and not to let the luter of Lions Court, make you forget that which will make you Lord of many Provinces, as you are already of my inclination.

Roilion promiing to make his tay as hort as poible, he went unto Sigimond, and finding him much troubled and ad; for he was then ready to leave Dorinde, he deired him in all love, to tell him the caue; and Sigimond whipering him in
the eare, look (aid he) in the face of Dorinde, and tell me whether it be poible to part from her without extream dipleaure: I do protet continued he) that now I do mot enibly find love to be the mot marting of all other paions, ince the affection which I bear unto that fair one, is able to make me forget both my Father and my Fortunes, and all things ele but her: I did ever think, replied Roilion, that when this paion does meet in a brave pirit, it is mot difficult, nay even impoible to eparate, unlee it be mothered by ome great injury received, as it will by didain or change; and therefore I do not wonder that you being once taken by the charms of Dorinde, hould believe this love can never die in you: for I believe mot confidently, that he will live in your oul as long as that fair one hall endeauour to keep the fire alive. This, replied Sigimond, does make the tyranny of Fathers mot odious unto me, who under a pretence of that authority which Nature hath conferred upon them, do contrain the will of their children, and force them with intollerable violence, to deny their own inclinations, only to follow uch motions as their ambition or avarice does prompt them unto; as if it were not reaonable we hould enjoy the ame priviledges that is allowed unto other animals, who in their harmlee paions do without any contraint follow that party which they bet like Let me not live (continued he) if I have not ever, ince I knew the merits of Dorinde, extreamly envyed all thoe, who in condition far inferiour unto mine, yet may do what they will with themelves, and are not forced to comply and pleae any but their own deires. Such (aid Roilion) do meet with obtacles that are wore, and which hinder them from a perfect gut of uch contentments as men do enjoy; therefore we ought all to remain contented in the Sphaere of our own conditions, without any envy unto any: for doubtlee, even thoe whom we do envy, would, were it in their Liberties to chue, mot willingly ceae being what they are, to become what we are.

The held on ome further dicoure, whilt Lindamor related unto Galathea, how the Princes had promied to do unto Amais; and he being a little troubled that they had not alread poken unto the Nymph. Madam (aid he unto her) I cannot think they wil forget the promie which they made unto me; & though they have not made any olicitations in my behalf, yet doubtlee they have worn too ollemnly, to fail me. However it be, replied Galathea, you ee they are upon the very point of their departure, and to reolve upon a thing of that great importance, there will be required more time then they have to tay. Madam, replied Lindam •• , we need no more but the Nymphs conent; and I hope, that to obtain it, there needs no more but to ask it: o as there being time enough for that, there is yet time enough to make me the mot happy man upon earth. Do you think then (aid Galathea and miled) that it is o eaie a matter to obtain my conent? Madam, replied Lindamor, it is much more hard to merit. Truly it (aid Galathea) you are full of vanity, but fuller of love (anwered he) and of uch hopes as you have given me; but I hall be extreamly orry that it does dipleae you: Upon this word Galathea interrupted him, and fearing that he had angred him; my Cavalier (aid he unto him) you cannot anger me, and whatoever you deire hall not dipleae me; and to hew you, that how great oever your deires are to enjoy me, they are not greater then mine to be yours; know that I am already wholly devoted to be yours, and if by croe Fate my mothers will hould thwart ours, I will die before he hall give me unto any other but Lindamor: in aying o, he oberved that Roanira was a little parted from Roilion, and went to Dorinde, and therefore he left Lindamor to go and put the Princes in memory of their promie.

Almot at the ame time, Amais came out of her cloet, with eyes which indeed were omething watry; for he till grieved to think he was to loe them, unto whom he was obliged for her life and liberty: and Sigimond, who had already given order to make all things ready, he came unto her to bid her adieu. As oon as the Nymph aw him coming, he went into her cloet again, where the Prince following her, with Roilion and Godomar with him, he poke to her in thee terms: You have een, Madam, what command I have received from the
King my Father, and how earnetly he deires my return unto him. My fears to incene his haty humour again againt me, and make him repent of the pardon which he gave me, moves me mot humbly to beeech you I may give him that contentment which he deires: proteting unto you, Madam, that if the deire which he has to ee Godomar and me again, were any thing againt your afety and ret, I believe I hould rather uffer the inconveniency of his anger, then ever return unto him.

Sir, anwered Amais, you need not doubt but your departure will much afflict me, and make me enible of that loe, as of the etate which I am obliged unto you for preerving. Not but that I think it mot jut you hould obey the commands of Gondebaut, ince he intends only to deliver you from the inconveniences which you receive here, and to retore you unto the firt luter an magnificence of his Court; but I mut needs confee, it grieves me extreamly to part with you, and to know, that being in no degree able to requite o many good offices done, I am contrained to eem ungrateful towards you. Methinks, Madam (aid Roilion) that you ought not to take any care how to recompence us, ince we have reaon to think our elves infinitly obliged unto you, for furnihing us with the means of acquiring glory, and given us an honourable ubject wherin to exercie our arms lawfully.

Sir, replied the Nymph, your reputations were before at as high a pitch as they could attain unto, and this lat occaion wherein you have made your courages to appear, can be nothing ele but arguments of that pity which you had of me: the truth is, I am he that only reaps the benefit of it, and am mot obliged unto you; and when I conider, that after o many benefits and favours received, I mut loe you, and uffer you to depart without any tetimonies of reentment, it does grieve me o to the heart, as I do hardly enjoy that happinee and well being which you have gotten me: And your departure is almot as ad unto me, as all thoe fears which the inolence of Polemas did caue unto me. Madam (aid Godomar) probably our departure does a little trouble you, becaue it takes out of your preence two perons over whom your merit gives you a mot abolute power; but there is no reaon in the world it hould grieve you, becaue in what parts of the world oever we live, our affections and ervices hall alwaies tetifie that we are mot perfectly yours: The truth is (aid Amais) I have already received o many tetimonies of your good will, as I have no reaon to doubt but you imploy it for me, upon all occaions wherein your aitance is requiite; but this does not comfort me in thoe orrows which this ad eparation caues in me: for I would have you depart better atisfied from me, and would gladly acquit my elf, in ome meaure, of thoe obligations wherein I am bound unto your valour.

Madam, replied Sigimond, the care you have had of Godomar and Dorinde, ince they came into Marcelles, is no way inferiour then that which I have imployed to erve and help you, though I dare ay, that the favours which they have received from you, does much urpas all that I have done: becaue you were les obliged to receive them, then I was to free you from all uch inconveniences as might have hapned unto you for their akes: o it is I who am the obliged party, and am mot concerned to complain, that Fortune offers me no better means of grateful returns. Yet, Madam (continued he) if it be your pleaure I hould attribute this unto your civilitie, and that I hould think what I have done for you, deerves ome kind of recompence, I will believe it o, ince it is your pleaure, and to the end I may have ome kind of right to hope, that you will be pleaed to grant two humble requets which I have unto you: Sir, anwered Amais (with a countenance lee ad then before) no greater pleaure can come unto me in all the world, then to do any thing you hall deire, I beeech you therefore, and conjure you unto it, to command me whatoever you deire, that I may tetifie how great a deire I have to obey you.

The firt thing then that I deire, Madam (aid Sigimond) relates unto the Interet of Dorinde, whom I beeech you permit to tay a while with you: I think there is no need I hould tell you my reaons; for you knowing both her life and
mine, doubtlee you know them alo as well as my elf. Only I aure you, that the favours which he hath already received from you, and thoe which he expects from your amity, hall be put upon my accompt of obligations to you, and hall be o well imprinted in my memory, as I will never forget them.

As to the other humble requet which I am to make, it conceirns as well the Interet of Roilion and Godomar, as my own, for they alo engaged themelves to preent it; but yet it conceirns a Cavalier, whoe virtue may without otentation, apire unto the highet degree that Fortune can raie a man: And, Madam, to leave you no longer in a dubious upence, I will freely tell you, that Roilion, my brother, and I, do mut humbly beeech you to give the poeion of Galathea unto the merits of Lindamor: You, Madam, do know, better then any, the qualities of which he is owner, and what proofs he has given you of his valour and courage; you know all, that if your Etate is to be utained by the valour and judgment of a man, none can more legitimately pretend unto it then he: Therefore, Madam, if it be your pleaure to confer upon him any recompence for the perils he hath undergone, and whereunto he expoed himelf for your ake, and if you will not hame us with the denial of a requet o jut, we conjure you by the memory of Clidemant whom he hath o faithfully erved, and by the properity and welfare which you and your dominions are to enjoy, to approve of this his humble deire, and of our motion in his behalf. As he aid o, Sigimond took the hand of Amais, and tooping to kis it, the Nimph miled: Sir aid he unto him, I doe with all my heart conent unto all you ask: Dorinde hall never far wore, nor be les dear unto me then Galathea her elf: And though I were not obliged to give Lindamor what he deires of me as a recompence which I owe unto his courage, yet I doe know his quallity and merits o well, that I would grant him what he now requets: I doe deire only to conult with Galathea and know her mind, yet auring my elf he will not diapprove of any thing I hall doe. Madam (aid Roilion) though Sigimond only did preent the requet unto you, and you have been pleaed to grant it, yet I mut needs give you mut humble thanks, and do protet, I doe think my elf no les obliged for any favour you do unto Lindamor, then if I had received it my elf; this hall make me haten my return that I may be preent at this happy marriage, and I dear ay the dayes that Lindamor does pend in Lions, he will not think, the mot pleaant of his life.

Indeed (aid Godomar) neither you nor he will take much pleaure in being there, but however, you hall be bid mot kindly welcome: and if the King will give me leave, I will return with you, to be a witnes of Lindomar or, & your happines: Indeed (aid Amais and ighed) I hould be happy if you would be as good as you ay: That Madam, replied Godomar, does wholy depend upon the will of Gondebaut: I hould think my elf infinitly happy (aid Amais) if he would be pleaed to conent unto it; nor hould I ever be poeed with frights, and terrors, as long as I hould be o happy as to have your preence: It hall not be long of me Madam, aid Sigimond, if my Brother doe not obtain that leave, for I will undertake to aske it for him, and will ue the bet endeavors I can to move the King, that he may have the honour of eeing you again: In the mean time Madam, the lat favour which I deire to obtain from you, is the continuation of your good will, and doe mot humbly beeech you to beleive, that what fortune oever I be in, I will never forget the oath which I have made to erve you againt all your enemies: In aying o, he kied her and bad adieu, but Amais holding him in her armes, alas Sir, aid he unto him mut we be o mierable as to loe you? Heaven was not o kind in giving me the happy honour of your acquaintance, as it is mortally cruell in depriving me o oon of you: Upon this he could not refrain from teares; and Sigimond, who was extreamly moved, Madam replied he, what neceitie oever it be which calls me unto the King my Father, yet it hall not be o prevalent as your command if you doe bid me not to go: Indeed eeing I could not now be much ervicable unto you, I though you would dipence with my obedience unto him, and not complain of my departure. Your obedience unto him (replied Amais with teares in her eyes) cannot
be condemned, noe more then my ad reentment of your departure: Pay unto Gondebaut that which nature does exact from you: And I will pay that unto you, which unles I were the mot ungratfull woman in the world, I cannot deny unto thoe great benefits which have obliged me unto you. Yet ince it is more reaonable that the interets of a Father, hould be more coniderable unto you then mine, I will receive this adieu which you bid me, yet upon condition that you will honour me o far as to promie, though I be at a ditance from you, yet you will ometimes call me into your memorie. Upon this, he embraced him again, and Sigimond embracing her, I doe not only promie it Madam (aid he) but alo wear it by the oul of my Father, and all the oathes that ought to be inviolably kept: beeeching the gods to afflict me with all manner of torments, the firt moment I offer to break them: And I Sir (anwered Amais with teares and ighes) doe vow ooner to die then ceae to honour you and love you as I am obliged. In aying o, he left Sigimond, whom he had all be dewed with her teares, and addreing her elf unto Roilion; and you Sir (continued he) if ever you intend to oblige me any farther, I beeech you hew it in contriving it o as Gondebaut may not deny Godomar the libertie of returning to me: Roilion having promied to imploy the utmot of his endeavours Godomar, advanced, who making a low conge to bid her adieu; Pardon me Madam (aid he unto her) if I fail in any of thoe repects which I doe owe unto you, auring you that I am mot ready to make reparation as you hall ordain: Nay Sir, anwered he, I beeech you the mieries which I reent, if during the tay you have made here, I have omitted any thing which was due unto your birth: Proteting that if any where, they proceeded not from want of any affection, for I have as much to you, as ever I had to Clidemant. Upon this hedding ome tears in ign of her orrows, he went out of her cloet with a countenance o ad, that all the Ladies who were in the Chamber, epecially Dorinde, began to loe their collours as they did in the time of their calamities, Galathea was ready to drop down for fear the Princes had forgotten their promies unto Lindamor: And that Cavelier who knew that their favours was the bet foundation he had for his hopes of his Mitree, he was alo in a mot pitifull impatience to know what ucces they had obtained for him: yet not daring to let his perplexities appear, he wihed himelf already in the Country, that he might know the doom of his good or bad fortune. Galathea who at upon thorns, and as wel as he was once upon the point to put Dorinde upon it, to ask Sigimond what news: yet conidering that it was too much againt the hair of a womans modety, he reolved to enquire no further; but patiently to tay till the time came. So when the Princes came unto her to alute her, and bid her adieu, he returned her complement as handomely as he could: Roanira, Dorinde, Daphnide, Madonthe, Silvia and the ret of the Ladies, having done the ame, Sigimond enquired by what meanes he might aure Adamas of his good affection, and charged Thamires with that commiion, becaue he was to goe unto that Druide, deiring Thamires to tell him, that though he departed without eeing him, yet would he be his perfect friend, Roilion and Godomar did the like, and afterwards bad their lat adieu unto the Nimph and all the Ladies, and then took hore.

Godomar had already urrendred the office of Publique Dictator unto which he was elected, as well to drive the nailes for Roilion and Adrates, as for other particular affaires of Amais; o as there being nothing that could tay them any longer, they all departed, and the Nimph cauing her chariot to be made ready, he would needs accompany them a little way out of the Town.

It was a mot goodly ight to ee thee Princes o bravely mounted, their mannage of their hores was incomparable, and they alo made a very glorious hew. For beides all thoe who were no trangers, as Perlandor, Merindor, Lidius, Ligdamon, Lipandas, Silrines, Alcidon, Damon, and many others; Roilion took with him the hundred Caveliers which the Queen Argira left with him, for the afety of Marcelles • s in this Equipage then they went out of the catle court, where they were all aembled: And the inhabitants being advertied of this departure, conidering that they, who departed, were the deliverers of their Town, they did rank
themelves on both ides the treets, where they were to pas: and there, upon their knees, and with hands lifted up to heaven, ome weeping for joy others for orrows, all, even the very children, prayed heartily for all properity upon them. Clindor amongt the ret, would needs ee them depart, and calling to memory that Alcippes and he had been uch Cavaliers in their dayes, he could not chue but pay ome ighs for the loe of o dear and faithful a friend.

When they were a little way out of the Town, the Princes were advertied that the Nymph followed, and therefore they turned back, and mot earnetly beeeching her to go no further, they had their lat adieu unto her, and all the Ladies that accompanied her, and afterwards continued on their journey. Lindamor, who was not able to live any longer in that impatiency, but longed beyond expreion to know what anwer Amais returned unto his requet which he doubted whether the Princes had preented or no, he addreed himelf unto Godomar, becaue Sigimond and Roilion were in dicoure together; and beeeching him to tell him what uccee he might expect from his amorous requet, that young Prince did at the lat et his heart at ret, and aured him, that the Nymph liked o well of it, as he had faithfully promied to be no obtacle againt it. Lindamor, even ravihed at o good an anwer, did firt lift up his eyes to heaven, afterwards, looking upon Godomar Generous Prince (aid he unto him) may heaven be propitious unto you in all your attempts, for being o great a Patron unto me in my love to Galathea. But good Sir, continued he, do you not flatter up my paion with thee weet hopes, and endeavour to deceive that dipair which the refual of Amais would have driven me into? Brave Lindamor (anwered Godomar) do not think I disguie the truth I tell, you with any tricks; I aure you Amais is all yours, and never propoed any other condition unto the requet which Sigimond made in your behalf, but only to conult upon it with her daughter Galathea, whether it tood with her will: Now if Galathea be not againt it, the buines is done, and probably will be accomplihed at your return. But Lindamor (continued he) I hould not have told you this good news for I am afraid your impatiency to enjoy thoe favours which you have already o long ince purchaed, will make you think your journey with us tedious: Sir, replied the Cavalier, the honour to be in your company is as great a delight unto me as any other; but I mut ingeniouly confee unto you, that if my ervice were not neceary, I hould be very glad if you would command me to return unto the Nymph, that I may put her in memory of that promie, which he has made unto you in my favour, and to olicite the accomplihment of it. Koow Lindamor, replied Godomar, that where we are to go, you hall have no lee liberty then my elf; and I will be o far from hindring your return, that I will accompany you, if it will pleae the King to permit me: for believe it, I find o much weetnee in the converation of Amais and her Nymphs and ee them enjoy uch a weet and dilectable tranquility, that I would willingly buy the liberty of being amongt them at the price of my blood: Sir (replied Lindamor) you have een only a hadow of thoe pleaures and delights which that little countrey ued to enjoy: for the los of Clidemant, the rebellion of Polemas, and the Army of the King your Father, and others, have o diturbed that Tranquility and Felicity which Amais and her people were wont to enjoy, that whilt you were in Marcelles, I dare ay, you aw but a fale of thoe we ••• which accompanied their lives in the time of peace. This is it which makes me ay (aid the Prince) that now their contentments mut needs be high, ince I received o much amongt them during the time of their adverity.

With uch dicoure as this they made the length of the way eem hort; and Amais, who took towards the Town, was no ooner entred into the Catle, but leaving unto Galathea the care of entertaining of all the company he went into her cloet to find out of her own virtue ome conolation for the abence of the Princes; and as he was calling to mind all the various uccees which had hapned unto her during the whole coure of her life, and found by the death of her son; how irrevocable is that Law which condemneth all to die he reolved at the return of Lindamor to accomplih his marriage with Galathea, and after he
had conferred the government of the tate unto him, to retire her elf into Mountbrion, or into the Pallace of Ioures, there to pend the ret of her dayes.

Galathea, whoe age ued not to entertain any uch holy coniderations, began to think upon a hundred ports wherein to divert her elf, till Lindamor returned with the ret of the Cavaliers; but finding none that could urmount thoe orrows which their departure had caued, at lat after a little tudy, he addreed her elf unto Roanira, and aid unto her. You can judge, Madam, upon what I am now thinking: It is very true, anwered Roanira, for my eyes are not good enough to ee into your oul: Truly, replied the Nymph, I am thinking upon the dicoure which Thamires had yeterday concerning the cure of Celidea; and I believe it would be much pleaure unto us to ee her now: for before he had disfigured her elf, he was reputed for one of the fairet women that ever came upon the Banks of Lignon. I believe (replied the Princee) that the leat intimation of your deire to ee her would be enough to make her come hither: I do indeed believe, replied Galathea, that he would not deny me that contentment if I hould deire it, but I conceive it better to ee her where he is, if you would but do as I would contrive it: Galathea then deiring to be pleaant, and Roanira deiring to tell her how he would contrive it; I would have us (aid the Nymph) to dree our elves like Shepherdees, and go and urprize Adamas in his houe; there we hall ee Celidea; Atrea perhaps will be there alo, unto whom I hall be very glad to impart a ecret which I know will be welcome unto her: Silvander likewie, is doubtlee there, and if we chance to find Hylas there alo, we hall not want diverion enough.

Dorinde, who till then aid nothing, becaue the thoughts of Sigimonds departure took up her mind, he preently began to put in her vie: I have yet my Shepherdees habit (aid he) and Madonthe and Daphnide I believe have not parted with theirs, o as if you will provide habits for your elves againt to morrow morning, we will all wait upon you thither. Daphnide and Madonthe, liking the propoition of Roanira, did willingly conent unto it. I believe, aid Dorinde, that I hall be the leat merry in the company, but I hall endeavour to do as I can. For my part, aid Galathea, I hall contribute all I can to make you o; but (continued he) we do only want the conent of Amais unto the deign: None can do that (aid Madonthe) better then your elf: I conceive it good therefore, that you make the motion unto her: I conceive not o (replied the Nymph and miled) and therefore I deire that it may be put to the vote who hall ask her, and let the plurality of voices carry it. I will give mine unto you (aid Roanira) and I the ame (aid Daphnide) then fair Galathea, aid Dorinde, prepare your elf for this commiion, for the vote falls upon you. Here is a controverie (aid the Nymph) oon determined, and ince you command it, hall be as oon obeyed.

Upon this, he went very confidently into the cloet of Amais, whom he found very penive and ad; and having propounded the motion unto her, he approved of it, and reolved to go her elf unto Mountbrion, and pend her time there, whilt they were merry at the houe of Adamas: Galathea having made an humble Coage unto her, he would have gone away, but the Nymph called her back again; and after he had looked a little eriouly upon her, Galathea, aid he, tell me truly: If Lindamor hould take part with Gondebaut, and forake my ervice as he intends, would you not accue him of extream ingratitude? I cannot believe, Madam, anwered Galathea, that he has any uch intention; for he ets a greater value upon your Interet then o: But, replied Amais, I have now no great need of him, ince Gondebaur and I am friends. No matter for that, Madam (replied the Nymph) it is enough he once erved you, to make him never erve Gondebaut, unlee you do exprely command him; you think o very well of him (aid Amais) that I do believe you bear ome good will unto him: Truth is Madam (anwered Galathea and bluht a little). I have no reaon to hate him: Well, well, (aid Amais) go and look unto your flocks, ince you are all reolved to become Shepherdees; and we will talk more of this another time:
Amais miled as he poke thee words, and Galathea, who oberved all her motions, did from thence draw good hopes of ucces to her deires.

As he went out, Thamires came to the cloet dore, and Galathea taking him by the hand, carried him to the Nymph, who knowing that he came purpoly to receive her commands, charged him to tell the grand Druide, that he was very orry he had not his preence at the concluion of peace; yet if any news of conequence fell out, he would advertie him: Thamires humbly bowing himelf promied to do all her commands and after he had bid adieu unto the ret of the Ladies, he went to ee his dear Celedea, who thought one dayes abence from him, an age.

He was no ooner come within a hundred paces of the Druides houe, but he met her, yet with o ad a countenance, that he was exceedingly troubled at it and deired to know the caue. The hepherdes, who loved him as her own oul, and had no other deires but to pleae him. The adnes which you ee in my looks (aid he unto him) proceeds more from the interet of others then my own, and if you take o much paines as to go into the houe of Adamas, unles you be very inenible, you will be as ad as I am: All are there in extream diorder: almot all thoe whom you left there, went away yeterday preently after you, and there is uch an confuion amongt thoe hepherds and hepherdees that remain, as is impoible to be expreed unto you. Alexis is lot: Silvander never was heard of ince yeterday: Diana and Astrea, went out of their chambers this morning before day, and no news can be told of them Paris is gone to look them: Leonide, Phillis, Licidas, Stella, Hylas, Doris, Adrates, and the ret, are gone to do the like: and had I not thought that you would have returned about this time, I would have gone after them. This is a trange alteration indeed (aid Thamires:) but that they may not think we have les good will unto them then the ret. Let us do the Druide the bet ervice we can, after I have given him an accompt of what Amais has particularly commanded me to tell him. All we can do (anwered Celedea) is to eek out Atrea and Diana, for his greatet cares are for them: well (aid Thamires) wee will do our bet: In the mean time ret your elf here under this hade of trees, and I will return as oon as poible I can: o Celedea kiing him, he at down, and Thamires went to the Druides houe.

He went firt to the chamber of Adamas without meeting any living oul, and becaue he found the dore hut, whilt he was diputing with himelf whether he hould knocke or no, he heard Adamas ay in a loud voice: but Bellinde, to what purpoe are all thee teares? They will not do any good at all, but are dipleaing unto the gods: Thee few words, made Thamires liten the more attentively, and he heard Bellinde anwere with a deep igh: Alas alas, all the teares in the world cannot wah away the crime which Diana hath comitted: but I will make her reent it, as well as I do, and make it appear unto the world how much I diapprove of <…> , and that I did not expect uch bad fruit from uch good education as I gave her. Yet, replied the Druide, I dare not accue her: for he has been but half a day abent from you, and perhaps when he returns has a jut and lawfull excue for it.

Oh Heaven (anwered Bellinde) was it uch a heard matter to have asked my leave before he went? But when I call to memorie her hifting anweres which he gave me yeterday when I founded her mind, concerning her marriage with Paris (of whom he is not worthy) I eaily apprehend that he had ome deign in her • ancy which is dangerous to dicloe, becaue happly it might be prejudiciall unto her reputation and mine, we hall ee ere long (aid Adamas) whether he be to blame or no: mean time have no reaon to afflict your elf as you do, in aying o, the Druide went a little towards the dore, and Thamires fearing to be urpried, he knocked, as one that had ome earnet buines: Adamas therefore opened the dore, and Thamires eeing him alone with Bellinde he retreated two or three paces, as if he were afraid to diturbe them, but the Druide deiring him to enter, did ask him what news from Marcelles, to whom Thamires anwered thus: Reverend Father the Nimph Amais commanded me to tell you, that
now he enjoyes a perfect peace by the olemn treaty which he had with Ligonias, who came exprely from to Burgudian King to conclude it: he has deferred the day which once he had appointed for the acrifice, untill the return of Roilion, who as he beleives will be back within thee five or ix dayes: And the Princes commanded me to aure you from them that they will be ready to erve you upon all occaions I do hartily rejoyce (aid the Druide) at the happy etate wherein the affaires of that great Nimph are: and I am very glad he has deferred the acrafice, by reaon of ome accidents that are faln upon me, Celedea, replied Thamires, told me omething confuedly concerning Diana and Atrea, but I did not undertand her meaning; it is (anwered Adamas) that thoe hepherdees have not been within, all the day, and we are now in quet to know what is become if them. I will go then (aid Thamires) and do my endeavours to find them: upon this, he humbly bowed himelf, and whilt the Druide returned unto his dicoure with Bellinde, he returned to Celedea. As oon as he awe him coming he roe up, and taking his hand they went both togeather in quet of thee hepherdees.

But it had been trange if they had found them, for they fearing to be diverted from the deign which they had concluded upon the night before, and doubting they hould be followed and ought after, they were o carefull in hiding themelves, as it was almot impoible to find them out.

They lay all the night togeather in a bed, and Leonide, who in the abence of Alexis, would needs lie in their chamber, he deired Phillis to keep her Company: So as Atrea and Diana, after ome triviall dicoure with Leonide and Phillis, as oon as they thought them aleep, they began to talke freely of their common affliction. But Atrea being overcome with the dicoure of the Druide concerning the fortune of Celadon he was the firt who began to talke in thee termes: Alas Siter (aid he and ighed) mut our mieryes be eternall? are we predetined never to enjoy any contentment? I am no ooner faln into one calamitie but in lieu of being delivered from it, I do find my elf econded with another more enible and great: I have heard Silvander ometimes ay that all things have their viciitude and change, but my miery has none: and ince fate began to perplexe the condition of my life, I never found any alteration. Siter (aid Diana) certainly we are not uch whom fortune is pleaed to mile upon, nor whom heaven is pleaed to hower any favours: For my part, I am ure that ince Silander died, I never found any kind of weetnes in my life, and I dare ay it betwixt you and me, that the leat offence I received, has been the affection of Silvander, but as if fate were a profeed enemy unto my properitie, I had no ooner grounded om • hopes in the amitie of that hepherd, but a thouand obtacles do intervene and oppoe my happines: And o untowardly have I been croed, as the bitternes of it does not proceed from another but from my elf who gave the greatet blow unto my happines: for I mut needs ay, that had I not given any credit unto thoe reports which Laonice made unto me, I had never permitted Paris to go and treat with Bellinde concerning a marriage twixt him and me, nor ever eemed to like of his addres: Nor did I ever think he would have offered to poes me againt my conent, or that I hould; as I am now, be forced to commit an impardonable fault both againt my own Love, and the atisfaction of Silvander. The gods me thinks (replied Atrea) hould be atisfied, ince by the mieryes which we have endured, they have ufficientely revenged thoe faults which we have committed, you againt Silvander, and I againt Celadon. And yet they perecute us till, nor do I think they will ceae untill our lives do ceae. If they will ceae then (aid Diana) their anger hall not lat long: for I am reolved to put an end unto my mieryes ere long: and truely I think I hall be forced unto it, for I am not able to live one hour under the power of Paris. Upon this he topped a little, and then beginning again, ah Siter, (continued he) you have ued a terme which goes unto my very heart when you aid, that you would applie that remedie unto your mieryes, which dipairs does teach uch as cannot uffer them, and I wear, that I do wih for death which as eager a deire, as ever I did for any of fortunes favours. When I aid
o (anwered Atrea) I poke it in my paion and as I thought. And I aure you my reolution is as unalterable as the doom of fate is: for to what purpoe hould I live, unles to tat the bitternes of my misfortunes, and to conider that mot certainly I have committed ome great in againt the gods, ince to punih me, they invent every day new tortures to torment me? No no Diana, it is much better to live with them, who, as they ay, caroue in full bow • s of Nectar and Ambroia, in the Elizian fields: Let them deire to live, who drink of uch weet Liquors here, and live only in the world to tate the favours of Fortune; but uch as I, mut not hope for any felicity in it, and therefore it is groe folly to deire life: Did I not mot perfectly know the humour of Celadon, and that when I commanded him to die, he would mot infallibly do it, I might have ome ground of hope to keep me alive; but ince he is mot certainly dead, I mut confee I cannot live.

And I (replied Diana) could find invitations enough to move me unto the ame, and when I do conider the preent condition of my oul, doubtlee it is a lawful caue to deire death: for if life be not weet, unlee it be accompanied with ome, contentments, why hould I value mine, ince I have lot all hopes of any: As you could deire to live for Celadons ake, o could I for my Shepherd; but I ee that cannot be, unles I accept of an alliance with Paris, and by conequence, be a caue of Silvanders ruine, who hath worn not to live a minute after he hears it. Ah, dear Atrea, if we hould attempt to look death in the face, I am afraid we have not courage enough to grapple with it. As for you, replied Atrea, probably you may be afraid of death; but as for me, I have found out the bet and mot lawful way of dying, that any in the whole world can make choice of: I will die, for the happines and tranquility, not only of a Province, but of the whole Univere.

Diana, who did not know her meaning, ah Siter (aid he) I beeech you let me know how you mean, that I may do the ame: I do not think (anwered Atrea) that any other then my elf ought to apire unto it: but yet I will tell you which way I mean, becaue you hall not think I will conceal any thing from you, it is this: The Fountain of verity is as you know, o enchanted, as that enchantment can never have an end, but by the death of the mot faithful he lover, and he lover, that ever came into this Province. Now knowing that my fidelity is arrived at the highet pitch, that ever any womans can, I am reolved to acrifice my elf for the Publick, till after my example ome Shepherd will be found, who will expoe himelf for the worlds content alo. Indeed (replied Diana) this is the bravet and mot glorious reolution that ever entred into the thoughts of a woman: ah, Siter, I hall eteem my elf mot happy to accompany you, and hare with you in the ame Fortune.

Siter (aid Atrea) I hould not refue your company, did I not know, that it is only one of our ex that is to die: and I would not wih you to incur the danger: Come what danger the gods pleae, replied Diana, I will not forake you, but will expoe my elf unto any peril that can come. If you be o reolved (aid Atrea) then we mut carry our deign as cloe as poibly we can, and mut not acquaint Phillis with it; for he loving us as he doth, he will not uffer us to take that way, but will o obtruct our deign, as we hall never bring it to pae: To prevent which (aid Diana) let us go from hence before either Adamas or my mother be out of bed, for I fear they will end for us as oon as it is day, to make me marry Parris: But (aid Atrea) as oon as they mie us out of our chambers, they will follow after us, and if they find us, they will bring us back; and after that we hall never hope to teal away from their vigilant eyes: As for that, anwered the Shepherdes, we hall not want a remedy; for as oon as ever we are gone out, we will hide our elves in ome place or other all the day long, and when night comes, we will go unto the place which mut put an end unto all our calamities. If we hould fall aleep again (aid Atrea) it would but diorder our deign: I do not fear that (replied Diana) for though I would, yet it is impoible for me to take any ret; and therefore Siter let us dres our elves, now Leonide and Phillis are fat aleep, and cannot hear any noie we make. Upon
this, Diana aroe out of her bed, and finding her clothes; by the help of the Moon, did dree her elf very handomely: Atrea did the like; and afterwards both lay down upon the bed again, till the night was a little further pent.

They were no ooner laid down, but they heard Phillis igh, and becaue her ighs were mixed with ome lamentable groans, they thought that perhaps their deign was dicovered; and to make them the more believe it, he began to cry out; what? without me? Ah Siter, ah Diana, no, no, no: by thee words of Siter; and Diana, they thought all was dicovered, and were o affrighted, that Atrea roe up to tell her all the ecret of their voyage; but tooping to whiper her in the ear, left Leonide hould hear, he aw her eyes hut, upon which Atrea did infallibly conclude, that certainly he only poke in her leep: he aw alo tears trickle down her cheeks; which moved Atrea unto o much compaion, as he alo could not chue but weep.

So he returned to her companion, and auring her, that Phillis was aleep, Siter (aid Diana unto her) let us go out of the chamber, and try if we can get out of the houe; it will be day before we are aware. Let us go then (aid Atrea) but make as little noie as we can, left we hould waken Leonide or Phillis. In aying o, he gently opened the door, and oftly treading down the tairs, they came into the Court.

As oon as they appeared in the Court, two great doggs, which were kept for the guard of the houe, began to bark, & put them into uch a fright, as they turned back and uddenly hut the door at the tair foot: afterwards, they aw the fellow who kept the keyes of the gates, and who roe up at the noie which the doggs made: a little after they aw him open the gates and look about him, and went in again with his doggs into a little room, and hut the door after him, leaving the key of the gates in the lock: This made them a little more confident, o as they thought, that if they tayed but a while till the fellow was aleep, they might gently cros the Court, and get out; which they did, with as many timerous apprehenions, as if they had committed ome great crime.

As oon as they were out, they took upon the left hand, and began to run as fat as ever they could, till looking back to ee whether any followed. When they were quite out of breath they topped; and after they had blowed, and a little recovered themelves, Diana, who was mot affrighted: O my God, Siter (aid he) what hall I do? hall I have courage enough to compleat our deign, who have o little at the beginning of it? We are about to accomplih a reolution (aid Atrea which will free us from the Tyranny of all thoe mieries which have tormented us; and therefore we mut not faint but take courage, ince upon this action depends the ret which we are to enjoy in the econd life. I do know very well (replied Diana) what benefit will acrue unto us by it; but for all that I cannot chue but tartle at the way, by which we are to arrive at it. Yet dear companion (continued he and kied Atrea) your preence does put me into ome heart, and makes me think, that no ill which can happen unto me, can be o great, but the pleaure I take in your company is greater. Siter (replied Atrea) in that you will find but mall contentment, and I much; but not to trifle away our time in uch dicoure, let us look out ome convenient place to hide our elves, and make proviion of uch fruits as we can find upon the trees; for I conider, that ince we mut not tirr from our ecret lodging all the day, probably we hall find a neceity of eating: Truly (aid Diana) it is trange, to find in one and the ame mind, two uch different wills: We came out this morning with an unalterable reolution to die, and yet we talk of eating, as if we had ome extraordinary care of our lives. And o I have, anwered Astrea, becaue I would not for a world die any other death, then uch as will dienchant the Fountain unto which we are going. Well, aid Diana, let us then gather ome fruits; let us eat, and let us die, I will do whatere you pleae.

In aying o, they went forwards towards the banks of Lignon, reolving to tay at the firt place which they hould think fit for a lurking hole all the day. As they went, they gathered fruits, and after a long walk, Artea aw Aurora to appear,
and afterwards the Sun, gilding the tops of the mountains, and by degrees decending into the valleyes to give them the ame luter, they made the more hate to find out a cloe habitation; and were more inquiitive then before, they lodged themelves in everal places; but like Criminals, who never think their place of retreat afe enough, unlee it be the very center of the earth, and till imagine themelves expoed to the ight of all the world; o did they, in what place oever they found. At lat, after much wandering and eeking up and down, they found upon the ide of the River a little Cavern, which eemed to ute very well with their minds, and there they reolved to tay. Into it they entred then, though with much ado, by reaon of the thick buhes which hindred them; and itting down upon the Cuions of Moe, which eemed as if they had been made by Art, they waited, and prepared themelves for any Fortune that heaven would end them.

Almot at the very ame time, Phillis, whom they left in bed, did waken; and becaue he had till a confued memory of ome troubleome dreams which had diturbed her all night long, he aroe gently from Leonide, to go unto her companions bed, and give them an accompt of her melancholy Fancies; but when he found them not there, nor aw any of their clothes, he began to doubt omthing, and to fear uch misfortunes as her dreams bad threatned her withall. Firt he drew the window curtains, and eeing the Sun up; what trange hate (aid he to her elf) has Atrea and Diana made to rie more early then uual? afterwards, bethinking her elf why they hould go out of the chamber without telling her; but why (aid he) hould they leave me in bed? how long have I been held in upicion amongt them? ah Siter, ah Diana, I did not think you would ever have failed in that duty which was owing unto our common Amity? In aying thus, this Shepherdee did, by little and little, dree her elf; and as oon as he was ready, he went down the tairs, and went into the Hall; but finding no body, he ran into the gallery: afterwards going into the Court, and not meeting any one of the dometiques, he was even at deaths door; and not knowing what coure to take in that extremity, he returned into her chamber, and wakening Leonide: Pardon me fair Nymph, aid he, for interrupting your ret; I am undone, if you do not help me unto ome remedie againt my perplexities. Atrea and Diana are not here, and I fear, ince they conceal their flight from me, that they are gone to do ome violence upon themelves in ome place or other. Leonide extreamly atonihed at this, for he knew the tate of their ouls and their loves, he dreed her elf as fat as ever he could; and afterwards both went together unto him who kept the gates, to know of him whether any went out. The fellow wore unto them, that he opened not the door unto any: True it was, he heard the doggs barks a little before day; but riing up and eeing no body, he went to bed again, and lept ever ince without hearing any noie.

Leonide and Phillis, in a great amazement went to the gates, and finding the Key in the door, they knew then the Shepherdees paed out that way. They conceived the bet way was to acquaint the Druide, and waiting till he was up, they went into the gallery; in which they no ooner were, but Phillis being unable to withold her tears any longer: Alas Madam, aid he, my heart foretold me all this; and to my grief, I was but too true a Prophet of that which falls our. I have been tormented all the night long with trange inquietudes, and troubled with o many melancholly imaginations, as I never lept wore in all my life. Dreams, anwered Leonide, are only illuions and Fancies, and no truth or credit is to be grounded upon them.

Ah, age Nymph, replied the Shepherdee, aure your elf they are not o at this time, for I aw every thing as perfectly, as if I had been awake: For, Madam, be pleaed to know, that after I was aleep, and thought it about midnight, me thought I aw the ghots of Celadon and Silvander approch unto the bed of Atrea and Diana; and that of Celadon being more offended then the other, it aid unto my iter, in a tone mixed both of love and anger, ungrateful Shepherdee, Celadon is dead, and indeed in obedience to your unjut command; and it is your duty alo to die at his mot jut requet: behold here his ghot which waits
to conduct you into the Elizian fields, and which will never ceae tormenting you, until the very lat minute of your life.

Then the other, me thought, began to peak; and you Diana (aid he unto her) who by the power of your charms has triumphed over me, if you retain any memory of my fidelity, keep contant unto the affection which you promied me; and after my example rather reolve to die, then live under the reproach of infidelite. After this, the ghot was ilent, as I think, to harken unto Atrea, who in anwere to the firt, yes, yes Celadon (aid he) I will atisfie thy requet; I will with all my heart lay off the burthen of this body and accompany thy oul whither oever thou wilt conduct me.

Afterwards Diana in anwere, and you Silvander (aid he) be ure thou dot not depart from me, I will make my elf ineperable from thy bleed oul, o as though we could not unite our elves during our lives, yet we will after our deaths. In aying o they dreed themelves, and afterwards following thee two ghots who were their guides, they are gone to cat themelves into the armes of love, who having ome compaion upon them, has given them that contentment which they asked. I remember well, that I did what I could to keep them from following; I wept, I was angrey, I cryed out ometimes againt Atrea, ometimes againt Diana, telling them they ought not to attempt any thing without me: but thee ungratfull Companions lighted me, and went away without o much as bidding me adieu. Thoe accidents which hapned yeterday (aid Leonide) are the caue of thee imaginations: for they ay, it is the qualitie of dreams to fill our fancies in the night time, with uch things as entertained it in the day: And thee ghots of Celadon and Silvander: their dicoure with the hepherdees, their anwers and reolutions, all thee are drawn from the deign which Celadon reolved upon to die, from the complaints which he made againt Atrea, and from the reaon which Silvander had to hinder Diana, from marrying Paris. However it be, replied Phillis, you ee, Diana and Atrea are gone, and you ee ome part of my dream is more then fancy. That, anwered the Nymph, is rather from ome other accident: for it may be, that thoe two fair ones waking betimes in the morning they went to divert themelves without any uch deigns as you upect, no no Madam (aid Phillis) they would never have gone without telling me, unles they had ome trange reolution to execute: but (continued he) I will follow them whether they will or no, and as cunning as they are to hide themelves from me, It hall go heard, but I will find them out:

In aying o, they went out of the Gallery; and hearing that Adamas was out of bed, Phillis went unto him to acquaint him with the flight of her Companions: At the firt, the Druide laughed at it: for he thought it to be only ome paage of merriment: but when he heard and conidered all circumtances, and examined the porter, he thought what Phillis aid was not without ome probabilitie. Then began he to call into memory the lat command which Atrea laid upon Celadon, and that to make him ome atisfaction, he might attempt ome deperate act; Then did he think the apprehenions of Phillis to be jut: but earching into the caue why Diana alo hould fly away, he thought that the intimacy of friendhip which was between her and Atrea, might perhaps make her forget her duty unto the commands of Bellinde: o being confirmed in his fears that thee fair ones might make ome deperate attempts upon themelves he deired all the hepherds and hepherdees in the houe, to run after them, which they did: For, Hylas, Stella, Celadon, Phillis, Adrates, Doris, Leonide alo, and others, they all went imediatly in quet after them, and none was left behind but Celedea, who tayed for the return of Thamires, to oblige him alo to go with her, after them.

Every one that went in this quet took a everall way: ome went into the woods; others into the plaines, and Phillis guided by a better genius, took all along the river Lignon: he had not walked much above half an hower, before he pide Lycidas lying all along upon the gras, by the river ide, and o neer the water that he dipped his hand in the little waves which the wind did gently dah againt the bankes; this encounter did infinitely joy her, for he longed extreamly
to ee him, that he might acquaint him with the condition of Celadon: making therefore a little more hate he urprized him; good morrow Lycidas (aid he unto him) where is Celadon? Upon this he ate down by him, and the Shepherd turning himelf towards her, much amazed to meet her alone, in a place o little frequented; Mitree (anwered he with a igh) certainly he is not in our coats, ince I find him not here: I have taken all the pains that poibly I could to find him, o as I believe he has cat himelf again into the river of Lignon: for there is not any cloe corner in all the Woods, which ince yeterday I have not mot carefully earched: if he be dead, replied Phillis, I fear Atrea is followed him; for he tole away from me, and I cannot devie which way he is gone: Diana, I believe is with her; for no news can be heard of either: I know very well he repents heartily of her uing Celadon o harhly, and is in uch a rage as is apt enough to drive into depair. Her repentance, replied Lycidas, cannot be o great as the crime which he has committed both agai ••• my brother and me; and herein, it reflects upon you: for it, as you have often told me, you think your elf concerned in any accidents which befal me, certainly he has diobeyed you, by the injuries which he has done unto me: ah Licidas (aid Phillis) he has angred me exceedingly by offending you; but I mut tell you, that if it were as eaie a matter to remedy thoe misfortunes which are hapned, as it is for me to pardon her, we hould quickly enjoy that happinee, which now we cannot hope for: for you mut know Lycidas, that as great as you think the faults are which Atrea hath committed, he does not want arguments to excue her elf, and to jutifie all thoe reentments which he hath tetified. Phillis (aid Licidas and interrupted her) if you will have me believe you love me, for god ake do not take part with that inhumane woman: I doubt not but he has invented all that her wit can devie to dicharge her elf of her ins; but you and I have been long acquainted, and knows her humour to a hairs bredth: We, I ay, cannot doubt of the crime, in inning againt the fidelity of Celadon: Alas, alas, (continued he) when I call to mind how he has lived, and what he has uffered for this pievih woman, it would make any other heart, but this inenible womans, to bleed: in what a hell of miery did he live, when he confined himelf to the Cave? never was man more undone then he: his hair was grown long and diorderly like a wilde mans: his face was grown o lean, as it eemed longer by half then it was when he was well: his eyes, which you know were beautiful and lovely, they were o hrunk into his head, that you could not ee them: his comp • exion was grown yellow, and o changed, as none could know him: As I remember (aid Phillis) you told me that his cave was cloe by the river Lignon: o it was, anwered Licidas, and if you deire to ee it, you need only but turn your head, for it is within ten paces of you: The entrance into it is not very eaie; for I ee many buhes, briers, and ruhes at the mouth of it, but it is very handome within.

In aying o, Phillis and Licidas roe up, and went unto the door of this Grotto: As oon as Phillis was near, he put forward her head to look in; but not being able to ee any thing, by reaon of the buhes and obcurity, he began to make her way through: I have o great a deire (aid he) to ee Celadons habitation, that though I tear half my skin with thee bryers, yet I will enter in. The Shepherd, who feared that he would do her elf ome harm, he tayed her, and aid, that rather then he hould receive any hurt, he would make the way more eaie for her: and indeed he took his heephook, and broke down the buhes and bryers that grew before the entrance.

God knows how extreamly Atrea and Diana were atonihed at this; for thoe two Shepherdees who were hid in this cave, as a place of afety, they heard every word that paed between Licidas and Phillis: At firt they thought that chance only had brought them to that place; but when they heard Phillis come near the Grotto, and would needs look in, they thought it a piece of witchcraft; and that it was impoible he hould find out that place, but that way. Yet rereolving to tay and ee the furthet, at the firt blow which Licidas gave to break down the bryers, they roe up, and placed themelves in the darket corner they
could find. They had no ooner hid themelves as well as they could but Phillis entred, who having but a very little light, becaue he tanding in the dore, did take away the mot, he durt not go very much further; but topping at the firt tep, Licidas (aid he) was Celadon here ix months together? He was there, anwered the Shepherd, all the while his banihment lated: for he never came out, unlee ometimes to mingle his tears with the waves of the water, and trut it with the ecrets of his amorous thoughts. Truly, replied he, I could not hold out half a day here, for the place is too full of horrour for me, becaue I fear nothing in the world more then darknee. When one is within, replied the Shepherd, it will not eem o dark, epecially: after a little tay there; which I do not intend to try (aid Phillis) and went hatily back, for the place is fitter for erpents then men or women.

In aying o, he went out, to the great contentment of Atrea and Diana, who feared extreamly, that he would find them out, which certainly he had done, if he had tayed never o little longer: for then her eyes would have been accutomed unto the gloominee of the place, which at the firt coming out of the Suns brightnee, eemed there to be blind. As oon as he was out, Licidas and he went unto the place where they ate before; and the Shepherd beginning dicoure firt: But my dearet Phillis (aid he unto her) is it poible Atrea hould undertake any deign without acquainting you? believe it (anwered Phillis) it angers me he hould; and if ever I do ee her again, I hall chide her more then perhaps he imagines I will. But not with o much reaon as I have (aid Licidas) for abuing Celadon as he hath. However, replied the Shepherdee, I will let her ee how ill he has oberved thoe Laws that were etablihed amongt us. Alas, alas, replied the Shepherd: how hould he oberve the Laws of friendhip, when he has o cruelly offended againt the Laws of Love? We have the greater caue to complain againt her (aid Phillis) and that it were only to punih her for it, I will continue on my voyage, and will not pare any pains of care to find out this ungrateful woman. Well, aid Licidas, I am ure you have more pity and care of her, then he hath of us; and ince you deire it, I do wih you as much contentment in your quet of that cruel one, us I do unto my elf in eeking Celadon.

After ome other dicoure they parted: and Phillis taking her way, Licidas tayed till by the ide of the river, where a plump of Willows, made a very delectable hade; and after he had pent a good part of the day under it (for he was very weary with looking up and down) he aid himelf all along upon the grae, not being able to reit a heavy inclination to leep which urprized him, for he had neither lept nor reted all the night before.

But how great oever the inquietudes of Licidas were, yet were they nothing comparable to the retlee cares and cold fears of Silvander: For this amorous Shepherd having lot himelf in the thick of the wood, and being urprized by the obcurity of the night, he reolved to tay and enjoy the freh air, although it was nothing able to allay or cool the flame which conumed him. He eated himelf therefore upon the ground, and leaning his head againt the bulk of an ancient and hady oak, there was not one accident of all his life, which did not preent it elf into his memory, not to comfort him, but to make him think the condition whereunto he was reduced the more intollerable: He continued in thee retlee thoughts very near two hours; but when he aw the Moon appear, then did his orrows encreae, as if it were fatal unto him to have his fury take beginning from her: yet taking this Planet for a witnee of his misfortunes, fair Cinthia (aid he) who by the luter of thy radiant beams eems to dipute with thy brother, the Sun, for upremacy of brightnee: Glorious light, which in thy coure about the world, is pleaed to make another day where ere thou hewet thy elf: Clear Planet, which does dicover and ee all thoe weet ecrets which are taught in the Schools of Love, tell me, for pities ake, if ever thou didt hear any complaints more jut then thee I make, and whether it be poible any mortal hould be a more real Lover, or more afflicted then my elf: then taying, and muing a while, and afterwards breaking out again: O thou delightful flame,
glorious Moon, halt thou never ee me contented? Wilt thou never blee me with any kind influence? I conjure the by my love, to hower down ome weet influences upon my Mitree: Move her heart: he is fair, and he is Diana, as thou art. Upon this Silvander was ilent, and in his ilence giving his greifes their full liberty, he wiht for death a hundred times, and complained againt Diana, the Hunteres, who formely did dwell in forrets, that he and her Nymph had ditroyed all the Lyons and Tigers in the Countrey, and not left one to devour him. After this, conidering what little or no hopes he had ever to enjoy Diana, he did o abundon himelf unto greif, that is probable he had been for ever lot, if leep more kind unto him then himelf, had not in ome for, allayed the bitternes of it and made him find ome eae in his inquietudes. But as if this ret were only to enable him for the enduring of more mieryes, he no ooner waked and eeing the un a good height, he reolved to enquire of ome or other what ucces the deign had of marrying Diana: Up therefore he got, and finding a path way, he followed it yet not knowing which way it would lead him: he had not walked above a quarter of an hower or there abouts, but he heard very near him the ound of a flute; and turning that way, he epied ome heep paing a long, and after them a young boy dancing and playing both togeather. This boy was all alone, which made Silvander imagine, that he had ome great caue of mirth, ince he was o merry by himelf: Silvander no ooner came near him, but the young hepherd left of dancing and turning his face towards Silvander, Silvander knew him for it was the boy that looked to his flocks.

As oon as the young fellow aw his Mater, he ran unto him, and eemed to wonder that he was not amongt the ret of the hepherds. Silvander, who ometimes took delight in talking with him, becaue of his pritty innocent anweres, where wouldt thou have me be but with my flocks (aid Silvander) ah Mater (aid the boy) it is o long ince you ued to have o much care as to viit them, as I cannot beleive any thoughts of them brought you unto them now. Indeed (aid Silvander) it is a meer chance I met thee now: but ince I am here, I am reolved not to forake them any more. I beleive (aid the boy) you do not intend to be abent o long again: but I know you will leave your flocks a little, if it be but to go unto the houe of Adamas where a great feat is kept: what feat? (asked Silvander and was a little urpried) a feat (replied the boy) for the marriage of Paris with a young hepherdes, who is the daughter of a certaine woman, whom they call, I know not what: Doubtles (aid Silvander) it is Bellinde: the very ame (aid the boy,) and he who keeps the flock of Lycidas told me, that they ay the marriage is pat, for Hoboyes and Bagpipes were gone thither, that the hepherds and hepherdees might dance and be merry togeather. Silvander ravihed at the diorder of his anwere, but confirmed in his opinion, that this marriage was in effect accomplihed, he retired himelf without any hew of tranport, and without recomending his flocks unto him that had the charge of them, as having neither any hopes or mind ever to ee them again: he went once more into the thick of the wood again, and having walked a little way, his trength began to faile, and a great trembling eized upon him; and therefore not being able to utaine himelf, he leaned againt a tree, and by degrees inking down to the ground he fell all along at the tree roote: he lay neer an howre as if he had been in a wound: but at lat, eeing his faintres would not give him that death which he deired, he reolved to give himelf that eae which nothing ele would: Now did he know that it is much eaier to give good counell unto others, then to take it himelf, for he who had often blamed all uch who for want of courage to graple and bear an affliction, did uffer themelves to ink under the burthen of dipair, he himelf was ready to commit the ame fault and yeild unto the violence of it. The greatet enemy he had was his own imagination which never thought upon Dianas obedience but he found ome uggetion to taxe her with ingratitude & infidelitie. Afterwards thinking upon the good fortune of Paris, and of his own ill fortune, alas (aid he) how blindly are the detinies of men decreed? Good gods? mut I becaue I, am not rich enough, nor well enough known, loe in one moment all that my affiduitie and
faithfull ervices have meritted from that fickle Shepherdes? Was • ver age o depraved as this? Did nature ever govern with uch little order as now? Mut men be weighed, and eteemed according to their riches? Is money the only thing that makes a man? Ah Bellinde: Ah Diana: what an unworthy etimate is this? Then topping a little: but enles man that I am, (aid he upon a udden, and reprehended him) I am extreamly to blame my elf for finding fault with the choie which they have made, as if Paris were deficient in any thing which may render a man mot exquiitly accomplihed: No no Bellinde, you owed unto his merit as much as you did; but Diana, he owed her elf unto my love, he, he, alone, is too blame; for how great oever the qualitie of Paris be, and let the virtues of his oul be never o many, yet he has hewed more affection unto me, then him; and it was he only who gave my ambition leave to apire o high as the glorie of pretending unto her: And yet will this incontant woman, acrifice me upon that altar of which Paris is the god. This perfideous fair one Laughes at my miery, and has forgot all oathes of fidelitie, that ever he wore unto me: Ah mot cruel fair one, I do ee you joyed in the weets of his embraces, whilt I die in that horrid dipaire into which your incontancy hath brought me: I ee you, Diana, take life from the moit and warme lippes of my Rivall; but I hall never ee any of my hopes ever revive again, for you have tifled them under the rigour of your change: ah happy Paris, how many glorious beauties are this day ubmitted unto thy mercy? How gloriouly mayet thou tryumph over thy rich poiles? Ah Silvander, how unfortunate thou art, in ever deiring them, in ever hoping for them, and in being o mierably ditant from all meanes of ever enjoying them.

Upon this he topt to give the more liberty unto thoe ighes and groanes which his orrowes ent from his bret: And after he had long ighed and obbed, till thinking upon thoe delights which he fancied Paris to enjoy: but poor and unfortunate Shepherd (aid he upon a udden) to what purpoe is it to murmure eyther againt the detinies, or her? The doome which hath ubmitted Diana unto the power of Paris, is irrevocable: and ince he has o much power over her elf as to conent unto it, I have now o much libertie as to do what I will with my elf: in aying o, he remembred the lat words which he heard Diana peak, and knowing that he did not forbid him any longer then till he heard of her marriage: Now (aid he) my diign has no obtacle, and ince there is no park of any hope left in my oul, her forbiddance to die is determined: dye then Silvander, and oon, ince the detines will have it o, and ince Diana conents unto it. Then being fully reolved to put an end unto his life, he began to think of uch meanes as might mot eaily hew him the way, and after he had thought upon the way of poion, upon the way of word, and upon the way of water: Thee remedies (aid he to himelf) me thinks are very incertaine, and too far off to be applied unto a dieae o deperate, as requires a more near and peedy aitance: for it is to be feared that if I hould make ue of poion, I may be deceaved, as Ligdamon was, and o make my intention too much known: Should I imploy a word, Cryerde he opened her veines, and the blood which congealed in the orifice of the wound, was a caue that he did not die: and hould I throw my elf into Lignon perhaps ome fiherman will take me up as Damon was; o as I doubt that none of thee three wayes can give me uch a death as I deire: then beginning to think upon it, by fortune he cat his eye upon the ame rock, from whence Laonice ued ometimes to veiw thoe beauties, which the plain of Forrets did preent unto the eyes of the inhabitants: And imagining that it was a thing mot impoible he hould not perih there if he did precipitate himelf from that top to the bottom, he tayed himelf upon the thoughts of this kind of death: Yes yes • aid he this death will be the mot honourable I can chue, and mot utable unto the tate of my love: for punihments ought in ome ort to equall the offences; and is it not jut that ince I apired higher then it was my humble duty to pretend unto, I hould fall from uch a precipice as wil be mortall unto me? Now this which almot reaches heaven, may be taken for an Emblem of Dianas perfections, which are as far above the common ort, as it is from the level of the
earth: I, out of an indicreet vanitie did think to arrive at the top of my hopes: afterwards; precipitating my elf, I find my elf almot reduced to dut and all my rah deires converted into moak: In aying o, he went towards Mount-Verdun, yet chaing the leat frequented way, leat he hould be hindred in his diign by meeting any.

On the other ide: Alexis was no ooner ecaped out of Leonides hands but he began to prepare himelf for the execution of Atreas command, and as if the gods were minded to make his fortune, in ome ort, equall unto Silvanders, as oon as he was at libertie, and amongt the horrors of darknee, he diputed whether the night or her orrows were the blacker, or whether both were o dimall as the cruelty of Atrea; he began to conult with her oul which way he hould take to find a uddain death. There was no invention to make one elf away which came not into her fancy. But a good genius, and perhaps the very ame which inpired Atrea did perwade him, that he could not loe his life more gloriouly then in helping to dienchant the fountain of loves veritie: o he fixed upon this reolution: The only obtacle in her diign was, he knew not where to find a female lover o faithfull as to attempt the ame: for (aid he to her elf) Atrea doubtlee does love her life too well, and ince he who is to die, mut be one that has lived in a mot inviolable fidelitie what know I but that ungratful Shepherdee is tained with the crime of ome new change? Diana me thinks alo hould not be accepted off for he has burned in two everall flames through thee love of two Shepherds who erved her: and Phillis who has to her very hearts deire guted all the delight of a pure and holy amitie, he will not forake Lycidas upon any termes in the world: yet Celadon (aid he) it is not for the to prye too narrowly into the ecrets of the gods: Content thy elf, with this, that thou mut die: never tay therefore untill dipair have driven ome femal lover to be the Companion of thy fate: it is ufficient for thee to hew the way, and to make it known unto poteritie, that never any love was more pure and holy then thine. Then did he lift up his eyes to heaven, and oberving that darknee did begin to vanih by reaon of the moones new light, he ate down upon the ground untill it was a little lighter: but being very weary with walking, he was no ooner upon the green grae, but being overcome with leep, he lept till morning.

Aurora urpried him at his waking, and as if he would hed ome teares for the digrace of this Shepherd, he had wet his checks, with the humiditie of her dew. When he waked, and knew not whether he hould be ad or glad for paing away the night without any farther progree in his deign; This ret I have taken (aid he) has made me waite with lee impatience for that glorious light which is to be a witnee of my love and courage. It is for criminalls to fie the light, but to uch whoe actions are honorable, the day cannot be too clear. Upon this Alexis aroe, with a deign to go away: but hearing ome noie he tayed, and pied Silvander, who having broken ome branches which hindred his paage, did pae through the wood with much hat. The face of this Shepherd, having all the ignes of dipair in it, did much trouble Alexis, becaue he was a reall lover of his virtue: o as deiring to know the caue, and thinking he would not conceale himelf, he began to follow him, and reolved not to leave him untill he had ome long dicoure with him.

Silvander in the mean time who had nothing in his thoughts but a deire of death, at every tep he went, he felt ome new conolation in his oul becaue he drew o much nearer the place which he had choen to put an end unto his dayes: o as not thinking any followed him, nor ever looking back, he came out of the wood, and got up to the toop of the highet rock of all thoe which Joyn unto Moutverdan, having till Alexis at his back, who wondering Silvander hould take o much paines to go unto that place which perhaps never any Shepherd before him, had o much curioitie as to viit: there Silvander tayed; great gods (aid he) whoe pleaure hath been to ubmit my oul, ever ince I was born, unto all orts of orrows. Heer I am, ready to obay that fate which hath followed all the actions of my life; Happy I am at this lat moment, that I have not by any in, rendred my oul neither guilty nor accearie unto the mieryes which are
falne upon me: Now Diana have I found that welcome remedy againt all my mieryes which I have longed to be delivered from. Pardon me Diana, if I have in any manner failed in any repects which I owed unto you: and how great oever any of my faults are, I do conjure you to beleive, that I never failed in my love; And you Bellinde, who by a mot intollerable tiranny has forced Diana to receive the imbraces of Paris, if ere my death do come to be know unto you, never betow any ighes or teares upon me, for it is ufficient, thee rockes will weep, and Zepherus will igh for my ad diater: In aying o, he teped to the very brink if the praecipice, and Celadon who feared extreamly leat he hould cat him elf down, he teped forward to prevent him, and laying hold upon him, fie, fie Silvander (aid Alexis to him) heaven would not have you cat your elf away. Silvander upon this turning himelf about, and looking upon her with the very face of death, ah too pittifull Alexis (aid he) what Demon ent you hither to hinder me from that contentment which the gods did promie unto me? The mot kind one (anwered Alexis) of all thoe that have any care of your life: Nay, aid Silvander; it was rather the greatet enemy unto my tranquilitie: who ever it was (replied Alexis and would not let go her hold) you hall not die at this time, and if you have any repect unto the ranke which my birth conferred upon me, grant unto me one requet which I hall make unto you, which is, to lend an ear unto ome things which I mut comunicate unto you. Silvander eeing himelf obliged to obey the commands of Celadon, whom he thought to be a woman and a Druide, he retired himelf a little from the edge of the praecipice, and both of them being a little removed from it, they at down upon another rock which was convenient for that purpoe: and there Celadon began to talk unto him in thee termes.
