You will wonder Silvander, at the dicoure which I hall make unto you: and the more, becaue you are blinded with the ame mitake which Astrea, Diana, Phillis, Lycidas, and all the Shepherds and Shepherdees are, concerning me: For you mut know Silvander, that this habit wherin I am, is nothing utable to my exe, and though it be the habit of a Druide, yet it is upon the body of a Shepherd, and to be hort Silvander, upon the body of Celadon: at the ound of Celadon, Silvander tood amued; And Alexis contiuning, and to the end (aid he) that you may render unto thoe that urvive me a tetimonie of my dicretion and of my love, I do conjure you to harken with patience unto the relation of my fortune, and afterwards to grant me a requet which I have unto you, and for which only I followed you, not knowing you had any uch ill intentions againt your elf, as you eem to have. Silvander not being able to recover himelf out of his atonihment, he did not anwere one word; but looking him tedfatly in the face, he did let him know by his ilence, that he would willingly hear him; And therefore Celadon related unto him, all that ever hapned unto him ince he threw himelf into Lignon: and having told him in what manner Leonide made him known unto his Shepherdee: Now (aid he) this cruel and ungratfull woman, in lieu of ever conidering the tetimonies which he had received of my love and obedience, he commanded me to die, and that o peremptorily, as it is impoible but I mut needs obey her. Now that which I deire from you, age Silvander, is, that you would be pleaed to take o much paines, as to go tell Lycidas from me, that I deire him as he loves me not to trouble himelf at my death, nor to take any revenge upon Atrea for the crimes which her rigour hath committed againt him, and againt me: In the mean time I will go and content that in humain woman, and expoe my elf unto the rage of thoe Lyons and unicornes which guard the enchanted fountain, that I may in ome ort oblige poteritie, and give Silvander himelf the delight of knowing how truely and incerly he is beloved by his Shepherdee Diana.

Upon this Alexis was ilent, and Silvander who during her dicoure had time to recollect his pirits, and to confirm himelf in a beleif, that it was really Celadon who poke unto him, he took him about the neck and embracing him: Oh heavens Celadon (aid he) is it poible I hould before I die be o happy as to ee you again? In aying o, teares dropped from his eyes, and afterwards continuing, no no Celadon (aid he) it is by no meanes jut, that the anger, or rather the
ill humour of Atrea hould caue the ruine of the mot amiable Shepherd in all Forrets.

Live, live, Celadon; live for Atrea, and let me alone to accomplih the deign which you intended: Let me die; for my fidelity is pure enough, and the ame advantage which you willed me by your death, you may receive from mine: Nay, nay Silvander, replied Alexis, live you for Atrea: Alas, alas, replied the Shepherd, why hould I do o, ince Diana lives only unto Paris? Unto Paris? (aid Alexis in a great amazement) yes unto Paris (aid Silvander) and that is the caue of my tranport; let me therefore, dear Celadon, go and mingle my blood with the water of this Fountain: that is now the only object of all my deires, and o great is my impatiency of it, that it alone is able to be my death. Sage Silvander, replied Alexis faintly, had this deign been jut in you, doubtles the gods would have inpired you with the thoughts of it, as they did me; and therefore I conceive you have no right to contend with me about it nor dipute it any longer, ince no other but my elf can doubtlee obtain it. However (aid Silvander) I beeech you let me joyn my Fortune unto yours, and let us both find the ame Fate. Alexis would have diwaded him; but Silvander beeeched her with o many forcible and importunate arguments, that at the lat he conented, and received him as a companion in this enterprize.

Atrea had no ooner heard Licidus ay, that the Grotto wherein they were was the very ame which formerly harboured Celadon, but he was all amazement, and from that time thought that very rock it elf did tell her of that Shepherds love: all the objects which preented themelves unto her enes, did treat her in the ame manner: for when he heard the hollow murmure of the river Lignon, or the noie which Zepherus made at the entrance of her Cavern, he till thought them compoed of nothing but thoe amorous ighs, wherewith Celadon accompanied the rigour of his voluntary banihment. Diana did very well oberve this atonihment, but not being able to imagine that it did proceed from any other caue then her fears that Phillis would urprize her, he did not peak unto her, but only waited with a little impatience to ee what would become of the deign which Phillis had to look into the Grotto. But when that Shepherdee was gone our, and found the place more full of horrour, then likely to keep alive the flames of a Lover, and when he had bid adieu unto Licidas, and went in quet of thoe whom he left behind her, Diana eeing her companion continue till in the ame aright he was he could nor chue but ask the caue: To whom Atrea anwered, Did not you hear Siter, how Licidas aid that this Grotto wherein we are, is the very ame place where Celadon lived and complained againt my incontancy, when his Father, by a ubtil ininuation, did make him believe that Corebes was to marry me? I heard him ay o, replied Diana, but I did not think that was able to trouble you o much as I ee you are: Truly, aid Atrea, it does not much trouble me; but I mut confee, when I think upon the accidents which befel me at that time, and comparing the preent condition of my life with that I then lived, I cannot chue but grieve to ee how fare will never ceae tormenting me, but is till putting obtacles unto uch felicities, as I promied unto my elf. There are very few (anwered Diana) who have not the ame accuation againt Fortune: you complain: I complain, and I think o does all the world: for it is a mot impoible thing to receive any joy which is not mixed with a thouand ubjects of orrow: I do believe it (anwered Atrea) but till I dare affirm, that of all thoe who ever had any caue of complaint, none ever had o much as I. For if I do but look back upon the uccees of my life, I cannot find one which was not accompanied with ome ad event or other. Siter, replied Diana, we had never lee reaon to complain then now, now I ay, when our mieries are o near their remedy, and when we are upon the very point of eaing our elves from all thoe dipleaures which we have endured: Love has been the caue almot of all, and it mut be love which mut deliver us, to the end the ame hand which gave the wound, may alo give the plaiter. Indeed Siter (aid Atrea) we are arrived at the Eve of our tranquility but yet as near as that moment is, which will end all our mieries, the memory of thoe mieries does torment my
mind. In aying o, he looked a little more eriouly then before upon every thing that was in the Grotto; and finding omething upon her right hand which was engraved upon the rock, he went nearer unto it, and found her own name which Celadon had engraved, almot all over the Cavern: and on one ide he aw written thee enuing lines.
div.q: Judge, fair Atrea, unto what point my Detinies have brought me: I know very well that death is a remedy againt all mieries; and yet I will not have recoure unto it: not that I find it hard to die, but out of fear that being dead, I hall not love you any longer.
div.p: Thee words made her apprehend, that he had at that time a mind to make away himelf, but that ome good genius had diverted him, by putting this conideration into his thoughts. All thoe objects were o ad unto her apprehenions, as they did teal from her eyes many a tear; but as ad as her oul was, yet he could not chue but look upon the tetimonies of her Shepherds inviolable love: At lat, after he had looked all over, and had left no place unearched, he found in one of the corners, a bottle wherein Celadon kept this ink, and alo finding a pen near it: Alas (aid he and ighed) here doubtlee is the very ame pen, wherewith he ued to expree his amorous thoughts and paions: This is the faithful pen which has o often received all his ecrets, and which hath been partly a caue of my knowing the depair of my dear Shepherd: Without thee dear pen (aid he and kied it) I had never known in what part of the world he had been; and in that ignorance, I hould never have found out the means to recal him. But dear pen, what hall I do unto thee in recompence of that good office? Thee tears and thee ighs can do thee no good, for thou art not enible of them: yet, perhaps, they will be acceptable unto thee, becaue they relate unto him that was once thy mater, and who by a high priviledge of Love, did perhaps take away thy inenibility. Upon this he was ilent; and Diana looking upon the ground, Siter (aid he unto her) I ee omething lie at your feet: then Atrea tepping a little back, Diana tooped, and aw that it was a heet of paper lapped up: he preently took it up, and aw it upercribed in large Characters THE SORROWS OF A BETRAYED SHEPHERD, and within it thee words.

I Once thought, fair Atrea, that the river of my tears would have wahed away the crime of your infidelity. But now, when I think upon the many dayes which my eyes have pent in that mierable office, I am quite out of all hopes, and ee that it is death only which can bring any remedy to my griefs • and it only do I call for to cure thoe wounds which your inconstancy have made. It is it only unto whom all my ighs and groans are addresed: and it is it, which a thouand times more pitiful then your elf, will receive uch prayers as I make unto it, to rid me of my pain. Thus do I look for help from it which Nature bids me fly; and I expect my ruine from her, whom reaon commands me mot religiouly to love: A trange effect of your ingratitude, Atrea: ince to be exempted from your peridies, I mut fly unto the pity of my enemies: But will; if you expect from my digrace only the ruine of—

This half ended entence made Diana think that Celadon intended to fill the whole heet with the like compliments: but that he was diverted, perhaps, by the command which Licidas brought him from Atrea, he had not time to write any more then what you ee. Atrea, who was the Reader of it, he was very orry that it was no longer, for it was very pleaing unto her; yet putting it into her boome.
This complaint, poor Celadon (aid he) which thou maket againt me for a crime, whereof I was not guilty, hall erve to condemn me, for that which I committed in the lat entence which I pronounced againt thee; and that it may be a witnee to publih my injutice, I beeech the gods this paper may urvive me, and that it may have as much power to withtand the injuries of time and weather, as I have to punih her that has offended againt the fidelity of Celadon: Upon this he found a great weaknee in her elf; and Diana, who aw her look pale, and feared he would wound, he run unto the river ide to fetch ome water: he had lee ado to go out of the Cavern then he had to enter in, for Licidas had made the paage more eaie: he made hate to the river, but could not return o fat for fear of pilling, o as he had time enough to ee Licidas lying at the root of a Willow: This ight did extreamly atonih her: yet oberving that he was aleep, he went unto the Grotto as fat as ever he could; and finding Atrea a little better, Siter (aid he unto her) let us fly away as fat as we can, unlee we would have Licidas urprize us: Why? asked Atrea; becaue, replied Diana, he is till in the ame place where he talked with Phillis, and I fear he has heard our dicoure, or at the leat will come into this place, to pae away the ret of the day. Is it poible (aid Atrea) that this Shepherd hould be there yet? Doubtlee he is (anwered Diana) and if you have a mind to ee him, it is but going to the entrance of the Cavern, and cating your eye unto the river ide: I would gladly ee him once more, aid Atrea, and in aying o, he went unto the mouth of the Grotto, and aw him lie all along upon the grae, which Nature had covered with a little Mos. As oon as ever he had een him, he would have retired, for he was afraid to be een; but growing a little more confident, he began to fix her eyes o tedfatly upon him, that it was a quarter of an hour before he removed them. Diana, who all the while oberved, he pulled her by the coat, Siter (aid he) I think you are ravihed with looking upon that Shepherd: Truly, anwered Atrea, his innocence makes me to compaionate him extreamly; and I am beyond expreion orry he hould be o enible of Celadons ufferings: for being concious of my own fault, it grieves me he hould have o much caue to complain againt me: yet (continued he) I mean to try his good Nature, and if there be any park of pity in his oul, I am confident he will have much ado to deny that pardon which I hall ask him. In aying o he went into the Grotto, and taking the pen which he found, he dipped it in the bottle of ink which was half full, alo tearing a little piece of paper which he had put in her pocket, he writ a Letter unto Licidas, which was no ooner finihed, but eeing the day almot done, he reolved to leave the Grotto and that paper in the hand of Licidas. Unto which Diana conenting, they went out with as little noie as they could, and coming to Licidas, Atrea kneeled down upon the ground, he pinned the paper to the leev of the Shepherd: O Love (aid he) even for pities ake give good uccee unto this Letter: let it not be lot; but if it be poible, let it touch the very heart of Licidas: Then he aroe, and looking round, they continued their journey.

Phillis was already returned to the houe of Adamas, very orry he could not hear any news of her companions: Leonide came preently after her, and a little after that, all the Shepherds and Shepherdees which were at the houe of Adamas: o as all of them having given an account unto the Druide and Belinde, of their trict inquiition after Diana and Atrea, they began to conclude, that they were both fled together upon ome dangerous deign: Adamas was much troubled for the Shepherdees; but for all that, he could not forget the interet he had in Celadon: Enquiring therefore, whether any could tell where he was; Phillis anwered very plainly, that he thought he was dead, ince Licidas wore he had not let any place in all the plain unearched. The Druide then, eeming to be very angry at her anwer; but (aid he) let us at the leat ave Licidas, and prevent any new diater that may happen unto him: Father (aid Phillis) I left him lying upon the ground a good way from hence; yet very near the river Lignon: and to go unto him, one need but go treight up by the river ide: perhaps (aid Adamas) you left him aleep: if o, it is poible to find him and bring him back,
I believe one may, replied Phillis, but then it mut be by command from ome whom he dares not diobey. Paris (aid the Druide) may perhaps perwade with him. Upon this, commanding Paris to go thither, this new Shepherd went and found Licidas, a little before the Sun was et. Almot at the ame time he awaked, and knowing Paris, he tarted up upon a udden, not taking any notice that the Letter which Atrea pinned at his leev, did fall to the ground: Paris perceiving that Licidas did not ee it, he tooped to take it up, and having it in his hand, here Licidas (aid he unto him) this is doubtlee ome expreion of your Love. I cannot tell what it is, anwered Licidas, but it can be no expreion of my affection, unlee Phillis gave unto it you. Nay, replied Paris; but on the contrary, it may be I that mut give it unto Phillis, and will be willingly the Carryer of it, ince you have writ it. Who I, anwered Licidas, I wear I have not een either ink or paper this two dayes. However (aid Paris) you did let it fall: perhaps (aid Licidas) it was your elf, for I am certain that I had no papers about me. That will be quickly cleared, anwered Paris, for I believe you will acknowledge your own hand: In aying o, he preented the Letter unto Licidas, and the Shepherd cating his eyes upon it: alas, aid he, this Character is as much contrary unto mine, as the cruelty of her who writ it is contrary unto my contentment: Paris not undertanding what he meant, Licidas continued: This Letter, aid he, came from Atrea; • but I cannot imagine which way it hould come into my hands: perhaps (aid Paris) you have had it long: No anwered Licidas, I never aw it till now; and believe he writ it very lately, for the ink is freh: Then he began to read what was within the paper, and found thee words.

body.head: ASTREAS LETTER unto LICIDAS.
body.p: YOur anger againt me, dear Licidas, I find to be mot jut; and the more, becaue not having heard any of thoe reaons which might plead my jutification, it is imposible but your judgement hould be byaed by the interet of your brother. I do excue your reentment, as I do blame his diguiment: And to leave you no longer without ome atisfaction for the crime whereof you accue me, I am going to die, ince the juglings of Celadon are a caue, that I cannot live any longer in the world with honour: I do verily believe, that in the heat of my tranport, I have ued a little too much rigour; but how I impoe a petty pennance upon him, when I conceived his in beyond all parallel or pardon? yet ince you will needs ay that I have done amis, I will ay o too, and confee that my fault deerves no les a punihment then death: I tell you therefore once more Licidas, that I am going to die, and that your anger againt me is to blame, if you do not take my death for a ufficient revenge. If for the ret of my oul, a pardon may be obtained from you, grant it good Shepherd: my tears do beg it; and the love which Celadon once bore unto me, do forbid you to deny it. Adieu Licidas, I have but a moment to live, and let Phillis take it in tetimony of my remembrance: Adieu.

div.p:
At the reading of thee lat words, Licidas could not chue but melt into tears, and pulling out his handkerchief to wipe his eyes: Alas, alas, (aid he) how great reaon he has to confee her elf culpable? for all the misfortunes which have fallen upon us, had their beginnings from a trivial jealouie which once he conceived, and conceived it upon the weaket grounds in the world. I do wonder (aid Paris) that he mentions not a yllable of Diana, ince it is thought they are both together? I cannot tell, anwered Licidas, what may be the caue of it; but doubtlee they are both together: for if Diana had not been with Atrea,
then Atrea would have mentioned her in the end of her letter, as well as Phillis whom you ee he remembers; however it be, aid Paris, I conceive we cannot take a better coure then to go peedily and acquaint Adamas, to ee what he will conceive upon this lat accident. Heere is Atreas letter, replied Lycidas; you may communicate it unto him: and if you pleae, I will waite heere for your commands: Lycidas aid this, becaue he had no great mind to go unto the houe of the Druide: but Paris did o well perwade with him that at lat, he prevailed and carried him along.

It was now night when they came at the houe of Adamas, o as Bellinde being out of any hopes to hear any news of Diana, he grieved extreamly, and all the conolations the Druide could invent to flatter her orrows, did nothing but make her more enible of them. In this condition he was when they told her that Paris and Lycidas were returned, o as he ran unto them as unto her lat refuge: but hearing nothing from them which gave her any hopes, he relaped into her firt ad apprehenions. Adamas, he looked upon the letter which Lycidas received; and finding no mention of Diana in it; he let Bellinde know that in this incertainty of things, he had no reaon to dipair. That it was credible Diana was not o enlee as to expoe her elf unto death, ince it looks with uch a grim and horrid face, and ince Diana being but a woman, there was no likly hood her timerous dipoition durt ever attempt to graple with it, what reolutions oever he had: Perhaps indeed Atrea might infue ome deires unto her off attempting it: but when it came too't neither of them both had o much courage as to execute it; Adamas ued everall other arguments which Bellinde did not take as abolutely good, nor could he abolutely condemn them: and the Druide having waited upon her unto her Chamber, he went unto his own, where calling for all the Shepherds and Shepherdees, he deired them to be all up betimes the next morning to proecute the earch which they had began; and every one promiing to obey, they bad him good night and went to bed.

Atrea and Diana, had in the mean time gone a little way after they parted from Lycidas: But when night came, and they aw the air duskye and full of clouds, and that the heavens amidt the obcuritie did end forth uch flahes of lightning as promied o many Thunder-bolts; Then chill feares did eie upon them, and that courageous pirit which they hewed did now began to droop and vanih when they came to conider that they were but poor illy weak women. The imbecilitie of their exe did infue a thouand coniderations into their ouls, whereof the leat forcible, was trong enough to hinder them from going any furthe •• They reolved therefore to turn fairely back, and eek out a helter from the raine which began to fall, o as they returned into the ame gratto from whence they departed: They were no ooner lodged but the air began to dicharge it elf of uch great abundance of raine, and with uch great clappes of thunder and lighting, as they began to fear that the rockes were not able to preerve their lives from the injury of uch tempetious weather. Lignon began preently to rie, and with a welling pride to overflow its banks: uch torrents fell from the neighboring hills, as till did well it more and more: o as in two howers pace, it came up to the very mouth of the gratto; And that place which once harboured the flames of Celadon, was contrained now to receive the moitur of this cold Element, and it entred in o uddainly, as all that Atrea and Diana could do was to get out: and as good fortune was, they were no ooner out, but the raine ceaed: o as eeing the air begin to clear, and the Moon to hew her argent complexion, they et forward, and never reted till they arived with in three hundred paces of that fountain which they had made choie of, for a remedy againt all their dipleaure. There they found the forme of an altar, raied from the ground upon a little quare, the teps whereof were tained with blood in everall places, and blacked with the moak of victims that had been there acrificed. At the firt; they conceived it to be conecrated unto ome dyety, and imagining, that the dyety of that enchantment, perhaps reided there, they both fell down upon their knees at the bottom of the taires, and Atrea began to pray in this manner: Oh mot puiant god of love, preerver of nature, abolute God of
ouls: take away I beeech thee the maske that blindes thy eyes, and ee whether my fidelity be not as great as my courage; Heere is the female lover that mut appeae thy wrath, and who by the los of her life is to have the glory of topping the mouths of thee Lyons and nicornex which rendring this fountain inacceible, do hide from all lovers the verity of thee great miteryes. Accept oh thou Son and Father of Eternity, of that blood which I hall hed: and to keep me from allignominy that may follow my death, take care, I beeech thee of this my body which I do voluntarily expoe unto the cruelty of thoe mercyles animals: in aying o he went and kied the foote of the altar, and then Diana lifting her eyes up to heaven, great God (aid he) that which Atrea does aske from thy pitty, do I implore from thy hatred: Thy rigour has never ceaed from tormenting me: Let my mieryes and thy tyrannies this day ceae, I will not give the ••• y accompt of my fidelity: thou dot ee it in the ecret of my oul, and knowes that it was even inviolable; Spare, oh god of love, pare the beauty of Atrea: do not let thy Lyons be inenible: inpire their fierce ouls with fear and repect, and do not let them glut their hunger and thy cruelty upon her most beautifull and delicate body.

After this he aroe up, and having kied the foot of the altar three times, he went down to the place where Atrea tood. Oh Siter (aid that Shepherdee unto her) you have done me wronge, for your own preervation ought to have been the ubject of your prayer and not mine, and if the gods hould grant your requet I hould taxe them with injutice, and therefore (aid he and fell down upon her knees again) I beeech thee, oh god of love to punih this iniurious Shepherdes with a deniall: and make her know that as I have more right unto what he prayeth for, o I ought to have more hopes of obtaining it. Then would Diana have kneeled down, but Atrea hindred her: and putting her hand before her mouth. Siter (aid he unto her) if you love me do not dioblige me any longer, for your requet is directely contrary to my deires and tranquility: in aying o, teares came into her eyes: and Diana not being able to retrain hers, they aid not a word more, but began to embrace one another. And itting down upon the ground becaue they were weary with travelling a whole day and a night togeather without any ret, and prompted unto it as I think by the inchantment, they both fell aleep, and remained thus embracing each other, as they did before the leep did urprie them.

They were no ooner falen a leep but day appeared; and appeared much fairer then the winds and torms of the precedent night promied: Alexis, and Silvander were not yet awake; But Bellinde who hardly ever cloed an eye by reaon of her great inquietudes, he no ooner pied the firt bluh of Aurora, but he tarted out of her bed; and putting on her gown, he ran unto Leonides chamber, and deired her to olicite Phillis unto o much paines as he had taken the day before in the quet of her Companions; he found that Nymph already dret and Phillis alo for both of them were o zealous in behalf of their two friends, as they both got up betimes purpoely to go and look after them.

Bellinde wondered at their early diligency: and as he began to tell Leonide the caue of her comming unto their chamber, he was prevented by Phillis who addreing her elf unto her; You ee Madam (aid he) what a deal of trouble and paines Atrea and Diana does put me unto; but if ere I find them, this crime which they have committed againt me, hall not be unpunihed. Alas fair Shepherdes (anwered Bellinde) I am afraid you are already ufficiently revenged: Madam replied Phillis, I am not o eaily atisfied as perhaps you imagine For I am of uch an humour that I never think ufficient reaon is done me, unles I take revenge my elf. Pray heavens, replied Bellinde, is ever come into your power; I am afraid the penance you would enjoyn them, is far inferior unto that which they have already uffered. Madam (aid Leonide) it is impoible but before this day be at an end, all our doubt will be cleared: we hall imploy o many people in the quet, that though they be drowned in Lignon, (which I do not think) yet we hall find ome markes of their death; I pray the heavens, replied Bellinde, that my feare prove fale, and that you may bring better news of them then I expect. In aying o he went out; and with her Leonide and Phillis,
who having found <…> with him all the <…> they all went in <…> .

On the other <…> with a trange impatiency to talk with Atrea,
<…>
Celadon,
<…> the morning and <…> of Shepherdees <…> provided the day <…> and Silvia, did <…> they went into the cham • er of Amais, who <…> had admired the comlines of <> drees, though far hort of their uual • ear, he <…> a good peed and dimied them.

They went in a coach, and ent it back, as oon as <…> the Druides houe and then Madonthe, and Daph •••
who were <> well vered in the way of Shepherdees, they taught the <> how they should hold their heep
• ooks, • nd by what language they mut make the heep to undertand them: After this they entred into the Court, and met no living body; at which Galathea wondering and not being able to imagine what hould be <…> in the houe: at lat he believed all the Shepherds and Shepherdees were gone into the Woods, to divert themelves under ome cool hade in the heat of the day.

In this thought they went up the tairs, and Adamas being advertied by him • ho looked to the gates, that ome Shepherdees were entred, he came to receive them at the tairs top. At the firt ight he knew Madonthe and <> for he had een them in that dres before; and afterwards knowing the ret alo, O heavens, my mot honoured Ladies (aid he with a pleaant apect unto <> and Galathea) what good Fortune is it that honours me with o much happines as to bring you hither Surely Father, anwered Galathea, it is not the cutome to peak with o much repect unto Shepherdees; but let me tell you; that ince the departure of Sigimond, Roilion, Godomar, Damon, and all the ret of • ur Cav • lier • ; we f ••• a deign of coming to viit you, and participate of thoe innocent pleaure which are to be found, under the habits wherein you <…> (replied the Druide with a igh) you come to be witnees of thoe <…> wherewith the innocence of this kind of life is <> for be pleaed to know, <…> diorder at <…> which have befallen u • within thee two dayes. I profes, replied <…> do both atonih and grieve me, for if did not think to find you in uch a great confuion.

In aying o, they went into the dining room, through which they went into the chamber of Adamas: and there the Druide began to peak unto them. <> make you acquainted with our orrows, aid he, I need but only hew you the face of Belinde, who is mother unto Diana: for yeterday he lot her daughter, who tole away from hence with Atrea; and all this, as I believe, is come to pas becaue Alexis was lot the day before: How I (aid Galathea) is not Alexis the • here? We do not know where he is, replied the Druide, but perhaps <…> glad to hear her Fortune, for you have ome interet in it. Galathea
• ot • eing able to undertand his meaning, I cannot chue but be much <…> her (aid he) ince he did belong unto you.

Upon this Belinde being called, and knowing the names of all thee new Shepherdees, he rendred what was due unto their birth and <…> with a countenance full of cares and grief, Roanira,
<> he had aluted her; <> thought, (aid the Princes unto her) that we were <…> admire the beauty and perfections of your daughter but I perceive; that we have thoe <> to give ome comfort unto you. Madam, anwered <…> but ince you do <…> I am not ahamed to confes before you, <…> as makes me almot incapable of any <…> ( • aid Galathea) and by conequence
mut needs be enible of what concerns your own blood: but I hope your orrows are not without ome remedy, if heaven do but love you half o well as we eteem and love you.

Upon this, Adamas beeeched them to it down; and being deired by Galathea, to tell them all that related unto the los of Alexis, and of the flight of Atrea and Diana, he acquainted them with every particular circumtance; So as Galathea undertanding that Alexis was the very ame Lacinde, who ecaped out of the Pallace of Ioures: I do not wonder (aid he and was much urprized) that you have alwayes kept her out of my ight: for doubtles you know that I hould have known her: I did at the leat fear it, replied the Druide, and I was ure, that acquaintance would not at all have helped Celadon: for he was then o obtinately unwilling to appear before Atrea, that he had rather have died a hundred deaths, then I hould have dicovered his diguiment.

This dicoure lated until it was dinner time: after which Roanira having a deire to ee the Gallery, Adamas conducted all the company thither; and they had not been there above a quarter of an hour, but word was brought unto Adamas, that there was three men at the gates which deired to peak with him: He preently commanded they hould be let enter: and the firt that appeared was Halladine, whom Adamas and others did preently know. Halladine had no ooner aluted the Druide, but he did his reverence unto Madonthe: and hearing that Damon was at Lions, he beeeched their leave to go thither; but Madonthe telling him how hort a time Damon would tay: I had rather (continued he) that you would give us an accompt of your journey, and tell us how Celidea was cured. Madam, anwered Halladine, to tell it exactly unto you, requires a better wit then mine; but here is a man come with me, who is able to relate every circumtance unto you: Upon this, he told them that thoe two who came in with him, the one was the great Olicaris the African, and Authour of Celideas cure: The other was Azahides, and that no man in the world was better able to tell her what he deired to know, then he.

Upon this, all the company fixed their looks upon thee two men: one of which was Olicaris, whoe habit, tature, and deportment, was no mall ubject of atonihment unto them. Adamas went unto them, and knowing by Damons report how coniderable this old man was, for his rare and admirable qualities, he received them with all poible demontrations of kindnes: and Olicaris, who though a Barbarian by birth, yet not o by humour, he thought himelf o obliged by the kind expreions of the Druide, as from thence forward he began to have a mot particular affection unto him.

After the firt complements were performed, the Druide deired them to it down with all that good company; and by Fortune, Olicaris at the ame time, did cat his eye upon ome Pictures, wherewith that Gallery was admirably well furnihed: and chancing to know one of them, I think (aid he) that yonder Piece is the Picture of Eudoxe, whom Generick brought into Africa, after he had triumphed over Rome and Sicilie: Mot true, anwered Adamas, and all the principal accidents which befel that Princes from her birth, until that time, have been related unto us by uch perons as were mot irreproachable witnees; but ince rcaes and Olimbres went from the Mailians into Africa, we never heard any thing at all. Alas, replied Olicaris, Fortune has been a mot cruel Perecutor of that Sage Princes, ince that; and did I not think I hould be too tedious, I hould relate unto you many remarkable accidents that have befel her: All the company eemed very deirous to hear him, epecially Adamas. So Olicaris began his dicoure in this manner.

div.head: The Sequel of the Hitory of EUDOXE, of URSACES, and of OLIMBRES.
div.p: GEnerick, loadned with the rich poils of Rome, and proud of o many glorious conquets, he no ooner came to Carthage, but the People is honour of his valour, began to chant and extol his triumphs; and himelf tickled with that happy ucces which followed all his enterprizes (being reolved to let his ambition have its full wing) he began to think of arming himelf the econd time, and trike a terrour, not only unto Italy, but all the world. Yet, firt being willing to allow ome time unto that ret which he thought he had deerved, he intended, till all things was in readines for his econd voyage, to enjoy all thoe pleaures and delights that his heart could deire: and the firt that he propoed unto himelf, was, to triumph over the chatity of Eudoxe, as he had already over her Empire. The memory of thoe obligations which he had unto this Princes, did not at all move him; but on the contrary inpired him with a ecret fear; that as he had called him out of Africa into Italy to deliver her from the Tyranny of Maximus, and to revenge the Parricide committed on the peron of Valentinian, o he might draw the odium of every one upon him, and in the end become the ruine of him and his Etates. This apprehenion was a caue that he kept her up very carefully in a Pallace, where leaving her without any company but her two daughters, he ordained that none whooever hould come unto her without pecial permiion from him, upon pain of death. Some Eunuchs only were appointed to wait upon her; and that but at ome certain hours neither, when he eat her meat. The reentments which this Princes had of her captivity, and her grief for the los of races, who only he loved, did bring her in a few dayes to uch a ad and mierable condition, that thoe who waited upon her thought fit to make report of it unto Generick.

This barbarous King being moved at the news, yet only to keep her alive, that he might act his impious deigne, he ent for me; and adding mountains of promies unto his earnet deires and commands, he appointed me to viit her, and to ue my utmot endeavours to cure her. He knew before by many experiences, what I was able to do in the mot deperate dieaes, and the life which I retored unto Thraimond his on, after all Phyicians had given him over, was a ufficient tetimony unto him, that I could do whatoever it pleaed me to undertake.

This good opinion which he had of my skill did o prejudicate his mind, that he imployed me; and I who did not deire any thing with more paion then to ee that Princes, whoe Ancetors I knew, I accepted of this commiion, as the greatet advantage that fortune could offer me. Being brought then into her Pallace, or rather her prion, I was conducted into her chamber; but O heavens? how pleaing, and how deplorable both, was this firt ight which I had of her? he was that day in a gown of carnation Satten, imbroidered with Pearls: her leeves were of Satten, white as her complexion, imbroidered with gold and Dearls, and enriched almot all over with an infinite number of mall Diamonds: her hands were bare, and in one, he held a handkerchief, which he was often lifting to her eyes: her hair was in her night dres, and yet I aw ome little curled locks which hung negligently about her cheeks: he had a carf about her neck, her face eemed to be very much hrunk and lean, as if it were impoible to preerve that natural plumpnes which he had of her own: This Princes was given up to orrow, that her eyes, which ince her captivity were eldome without tears, had quite lot their luter, and eemed to burn: he walked up and down the chamber, and holding her eyes down, eemed to mue mot profoundly upon omthing.

I mut needs confes, that as it was long before he perceived me, o it was long before I could do any thing ele but admire her: and as if I tood in need to recollect
my elf, I durt not enter, till he by fortune cating her look towards the dore, he pied me, and knew that I did not tand there but upon ome deign.

Se had heard what a trickt command was given concerning her: o as eeing me in another kind of habit then comonly was worn, he was exceedingly urpried, and I cannot tell whether it was with fear, or with deire of death: but o it was, that when he aw me put my foot into her chamber, he came to meet me, well (aid he) how does Generick intend to dipoe of my life? Will he, to make me infamous unto potentie, that I hould loe it by ome digracefull way? And has he commanded you to bring me the news, that I may prepare my elf for it. She looked upon me all this while with a fixed eye, and I oberving that he expected my anwere: Madam (aid I unto her) if the King hould have any ill deignes againt you, it is more then I do know, nor would I ever be the meenger of any ad news unto you; He eemed unto me to be very indulgent over you, and to have a care of your health, and therefore commanded me to ee you, and to contribute all that was in me to preerve your health; Thee few wordes were enough to let this Princee know, what my profeion was: o as laying aide her firt opinion of me; Alas (aid he unto me with a deep igh) my dieae is not any of thoe with in the compas of Phiique; If that Barbarous Prince who keeps me a peroner has any mind to put me out of my mieryes, let him make hat and take away my life, which after the los of my dominions and liberty cannot be pleaing unto me: we are three victimes heere, and I hould ay four, which that tyrant may acrifice unto his fury when he will: good gods? Why hould he pare us, after he ruined the tately temples of Rome? After this, Eudoxe began to walk again, and the teares he hed, did eaily make me know that in the reentment of her great loes, her oul tood more in need of remedies then her body: and ee how much compaion may work upon a pirit which is not altogeather void of reentment; I protet I was o much moved at her mieryes, that I would have attempted any thing in the world to erve her.

I gave her all the tetimonies of it that I could, but I perceived that her fears of being deceived was a caue, that at the firt he did not much value what I aid: yet he thanked me, but in uch a cold manner as made me judge he doubted my fidelity. After he had commanded me to report unto the King a thouand complaints which her paion did ugget unto her, he gave me leave to retire; And Genericke who waited for my return with much impatiency, to know how Eudoxe did, he knew no more by me then was neceary for his tranquility.

I did not tell him what the Princee commanded me, but only made a faithfull relation of the condition wherin I found her; and poke o highly of thoe charmes which I oberved in her, as I did innocently et an edge upon that word, which ince, had like to have killed us all. I thought that as I was moved unto compaion by eeing her in that condition, o urely would he upon the report which I hould make unto him: but in lieu of being enible, it did o blow that fire which had begun to burn in him, as he dipaired ever to quench it: had I had but any knowledge of his deign, I hould have been very far from adding any fuell unto it ince it was not honet nor lawfull; But not knowing he had any thoughts againt the honour of that Princee; truly I thought that I had done very much in her behalf, in peaking unto him of thoe merits which I found in her.

Generick then knowing that Eudoxes malady was mot in her mind, and conceaving that the olitude wherin he detained her, would never be a remedy againt it, he commanded me to go and viit her often, and gave a me permiion to go as often as I pleaed; and therefore, after many viits, having at lat made known unto that Princee, the great deire which I had to do her any ervice I did oblige her to put ome confidence in me, and to protet that he would communicate even her very heart and thoughts unto me.

It hapned one day, that remembring the dicoure which formerly we had; and asking her what he meant by the three victims which might be acrified unto the fury of Generick, and by the fourth which might be added; he made me it
down upon her bed ide; and there whilt the young Eudoxe and her Siter Placidia were buie playing in a cloet, he related unto me all the Storie of Vrcaes his love: he told me all the circumtances which fell out in the beginning of that Caveliers affection; her ort ows when he married Valentinian; the love of that young Emperor unto Iidore; The violence he offered unto her: the revenge which Maximus took: and latly, he told me her deign which he had with Vrcaes, to fly unto Marcias who then commanded the Empire of the Eat; The promie he then made unto that Cavelier never to marry any but him: her dipaires when he was contrained to give her elf unto Maximus; And latly how he called Generick to Rome to deliver her from the tiranny of this new husband: but when he came to peak of Genericks reolution, to plunder, and to carry her into Affrica as the glory of his Tryumphes: he told me what Vrcaes did to carry her away: and afterwards of his death which he thought to be certain, and all this with o many teares, ighes and groanes, as I was once afraid they would have topped her breath. Truth is, he fell into my armes in a wound, and I had much a do to recover her. At lat, after he had gathered ome trength, he acquainted me with the affection which Olimbres had unto Placidia, and told me that this was the fourth peron of whom he poke, auring her elf that he would not urvive his Mitree, if by fortune any perticular conideration had kept him alive after the los of Vrcaes. She had no ooner done relating her fortunes, but I ued my bet endeavours to comfort her: I did not omit any argument which I thought would perwade her unto what I deired; and in concluion I offered her all the ervice he could expect from a man of my condition. I told her that my age, and the qualities wherwith heaven had endued me, had given me o much credit with the King; that I hoped to obtain any thing I hould aske him; That it was true, as for her liberty, it was above my reach, and I durt not o much as think of it; But as for any thing which conduced unto the mitigation of her greif or feares from her detention, I did not think he would deny me any thing. This Princee accepted of my offers with uch a charming weetnes, that I did protet I would not pare my very life to procure her contentment; and I cannot tell whether my expreions infued any hopes into her: but o it was, he appeared not o ad nor o dejected as before, and in a hort time became as plump and freh and fair as ever he was.

Geneerick, who was quickly advertied of it, and did give me many thanks for the good effects I had wrought upon this Princee: and as the fire of his love inflamed him with a deire of enjoying her, above all the world; o he thought that it was but o much labour as to aske her the quetion: ince in the condition he was, it was not likely he would denye the leat of his deires: In order to this then, he prepared himelf for a viit: and leat his deign hould make over great a noie he took none with him but Thraimond to entertaine the two daughters. I do o much abhor the memorie of this accident, as I am not able to tell you, with what importunity this Barbarian accoted Eudoxe, let it uffice to know that after this tyrant had ued a thouand gilded expreions of his paion, eeing her till obtinate in deniall he betook himelf unto violence, and wore that whatoever it cot him he would overcome her. The Princee fearing the Barbarime of this incened King, he did a little diminih her rigour, and beeeched him to give her ome dayes time to conider upon it.

Geneerick conceiving that the les force he ued in this victory the more pleaure it would be unto him, he did conent unto her requet: after which he retired, and carried Thraimond with him whom the charmes of the young Eudoxe had o captivated, that he could never ince hake of her fetters: and certainly if ever beauty could inpire love, it was he: and without flattery one may ay of her as the Philoopher Leonitias aid formerly of Eudoxe his Daugher, who afterwards was wie unto Theodoius and grand Mother of this: for being, asked why he gave all his etate by will unto his two Sonnes, and nothing at all unto his Daughter; It is portion enough (anwered he) if I leave her but that which fortune doth promie her: Meaning, that he oberved o much virtue, beauty and merit in her, as was beyond all portions he could give her.

But to return unto my dicoure: Generick had no ooner left Eudoxe alone, but by fortune I came in; and finding her all in tears, I wondered at o udden a change; but when I knew the caue, I mut confes, I found he had mot jut caue for it. Now did I begin to ee clearly what the drift of Generick was, which was before unknown unto me; but now I found all his compaion of this Princes was meerly paion, which made him wih for her recovery: he told me every yllable he aid unto her, and when he told me what term of time he had taken, was only to acquaint me with her misfortune, and to pray me that I would apply the bet remedy I could. Madam (anwered I) tomorrow I will take the honour to talk with you more particularly, and do promie you to think upon it all the night: Mean time, be of good comfort, and be aured, that if my life and blood will deliver you from thee fears that afflict you, you hall not be long before you be delivered.

Upon this, I went out of her chamber, and retired home, where, according to my promie, I pent all the night in thinking which way I hould bet erve this age Princes; but after I had tretched my brains, and turned every tone, I could not hit upon one expedient, the execution whereof eemed poible unto me: for if I thought of getting her out of captivity by flight, I aw that we had not time enough to gain the guards, nor to furnih our elves with all things neceary for our enlargement: To divert the King from this amorous fury, I aw but little likelyhood: for very well knowing his vicious Nature, I know that nothing but death would quench his lut.

To kill him, beides the enormity of the crime, and the inevitable danger that would fall upon my elf, I did foreee this perhaps was not the way to deliver Eudoxe, ince he would leave two ons, who doubtles would ucceed him in his humour, as well as his Empire. Thus, not being able to invent any thing that would do her good, as oon as night was pat, and her chamber door open in the morning, I went to give her an accompt of my thoughts and this Princes finding what difficulties I met withal: but Olicaris (aid he) there is one remedy which you have not thought upon, and which is a very eaie one. I asking then what it was, you know (replied he) what Cleopatria did before he would fall into the hand of Cear: now ince I find a great conformity between her misfortunes and mine, it is but fit I hould imitate her in her violent end: he would not urvive the los of her dearet Anthony, and why hould I live after the los of my dearet races, who was o infinitly dear unto my oul? Upon this, Eudoxe held her peace, hewing by her countenance that this reolution was pleaing unto her, and that he wanted not courage to execute it. And therefore I told her, that indeed this remedy was the mot ure of all, but yet I did not think it fit he hould have recoure unto it, until the utmot extremity: I told her, that I would firt talk with Generick, and try whether I could divert him from his vicious deign, and after that, I would not be againt that expedient which he had propounded unto me, but on the contrary would help her the bet I could, and if need were, I would erve her as a guide through that dimal paage, and advie her rather to die then loe her reputation. I preently found, that my dicoure did pleae her humour: for taking my hand, go dear Olicaris (aid he unto me) the mot generous peron alive; go, and if you can bend the oul of yonder Tyrant do: Remember what you have promied unto me; and be aured that I will die a Princes. Upon this compaion moved me to drop ome tears; and having left her, I went unto Generick.

I was no ooner out of the chamber door, but a young man whoe face I knew, asked to peak with Eudoxe from Thraimond, and as oon as he was brought into the chamber, he kneeled down upon the ground: and having told her that he came from his Mater, to deire leave that he might deliver a meage unto the young Eudoxe her daughter, the Princes did preently conent unto it; and to give him the fairer oportunity, he retired into her cloet, leaving none with her but Placidia. The young man whom Thraimond had truted with his life, did preently take a Letter out of his pocket, Madam (aid he unto her) here is a pledge of thoe promies which my Mater made yeterday unto you: by which
you will find, in what tate his oul is, ince you did wound it. At this the young Princes miled, and not daring to take the Letter; Thraimond (aid he) mut excue me if I do not receive it; but upon condition to open it in the preence of my Lady and Mother: If you think not that fit, you may carry it back, and tell him, that I do give him mot humble thanks for honouring me o far at to remember me- Madam, replied the young man, Thraimond is o much your mot humbly devoted ervant, as he will not deire any thing, but what you hall think fit; but I beeech you let me not return till I know whether you will ordain him death or life: In aying o, he offered her the Letter, and the young Eudoxe taking it, he went with Placidia into her Mothers cloet, where opening it, they read thee words.

body.head: THRASIMONDS Letter unto the young EUDOXE.
body.p: I Am mot ininitly in love with you, and if my pasion be not as pure and Legitimate as ever was any, then may your rigour make me the mot mierable amongt men. I do know very well, that my affection is a tetimony of my rahnee; but it is alo a tetimony of my reentment, and your merit: If you think the one worthy of punihment, I hope the other is as worthy of recompence: Thus in this uncertainty, whether you hould punih or recompence, refer it unto the deciion of time, which is the bet Judge of all things: Punih me if I lie; and if I love you, love me again: I vow, dearet Eudoxe, I do pity your Fortune, ince I became a lave as you are.

div.p: The knowledge which Eudoxe had of Thraimonds love, did put her into great hopes, imagining that he could make him do great matters: and therefore he her elf came with the two young Princees to give an anwer unto this welcome meenger, and to tell him, that he received the affection of his Mater, as a mot high honour; that for want of paper and ink, they could not thank him any other way but by voice; and if he expected any other anwer from them, they hould be glad to give it unto himelf, the next time he honoured them with a viit. The young man told them, that he was gone abroad and would not return till night, but as oon as he did, he would obey their commands: After this, he went out.

In the mean time, as I told you before, I went unto Generick, and falling upon the ubject whereupon I intended to talk with him, I told him in what a ad and mierable condition I found Eudoxe after he left her: I told him alo what inventions I ued to make her tell me the caue of her grief; and that when I knew it, I came exprely from her, mot humbly to beeech him once more not to make any attempts againt her: I laid before him how ang • y the gods would be at uch ingratitude, and that he rendred himelf culpable of a mot horrid crime, if after the poils, over which he had made him triumph, he hould ravih away her honour. I put him in mind of the Ancetors from whom that Princee was decended, and of uch men unto whom he had the honour to be allied: That it was abominable, he who is the daughter and wife of Emperours, hould be treated as a lave, epecially ince he had never thought upon the conquet of Rome, if he had not invited him: I told him alo, that he was beholding unto her for the glory wherewith hitory would honour his life, and that it was not jut, but hamefully, he hould eclipe the luter of it, by an act. To foul and horrid: and indeed, I ued all the bet Rhetorick I had to perwade with
him; but in lieu of lending any ear to reaon, became all rage, and mixing jealouie with his fury, he began, unhappily for me, to fear that I had ome thoughts to enjoy the ame happinee, over which he was reolved to triumph. This blind paion did o diorder his judgement, as without any thoughts of Eudoxes virtue, he upected me to be guilty of that crime, from which I would have reclaimed him; and therefore with a fury that parkled in his eyes, he wore he would that very night have his fill either of love or revenge: and forbidding me ever to ee her again, he commanded me to retire unto my own houe, where my chamber was to be my prion, upon pain of the greatet punihments his anger could invent.

I mut tell you, it was not the fear of death that made me obey him; but being reolved to give unto that wie Princes, the remedy which he intended to imploy when all things were in deperation, I went and confined my elf to my chamber, hoping my captivity would not continue long, ince it would end by the death of Eudoxe and my elf. I no ooner came into my chamber, but I went into my cloet, where I kept all thoe ecrets and wonders in Nature, which I had been in collecting above fourty years: and becaue, with abundance of tudy, I had knowledge in all rare and admirable ecrets, it was not long before I found uch ingredients, as would compound a poyon o ubtil, as would quickly accomplih my deign: firt I took black Agarick, which I had pounded into powder, and having incorporated it with the juice of Thapis, I mingled an eence with it which was extracted from the leaves of Lethale, commonly called deadly Nighthade; and the leaves of Texo, which the Gauls call, If, or Ewe: afterwards I put into it Aconite, or Wolf-bane; and of all thee together, having made an extract, I put in a little cumm of the deaf Apick: and as oon as I had put the one half of this into a little glas, I took ink and paper, and writ this note unto Eudoxe.

body.head: The Note of OLICARSIS unto EVDOXE.
body.p: IT is now time, Madam, to take that remedie which I have prepared againt your mieries: The injustice of Generick hath lighted my perwaions; and having involved me in your misfortunes, he hath inpired me alo to die with you. This night he hath vowed to accomplih his wicked deigns, by the los of your honour, unles you prevent him by the loe of your life: Conult therefore with your courage upon it, and be aured that you never had a more glorious occaion to imploy it.

div.p: All things being ready, I called a lave which waited upon me, and who ued to follow me when I went to viit the Princee: with one hand I gave him the little glas, telling him it was a Medicine which he deired of me, and indeed I did not lie: with my other hand I gave him the Note, which I pretended to be a direction how he hould ue it; but above all, I charged him to be very ecret, and to make as much hate back as poibly he could.

Be pleaed to know, that becaue I would be out of the dinn and trouble of the people, I lodged in the mot dark and private corner of the Town I could chue; and becaue uch places are commonly the receptacles of Thieves and Rogues, rather then tudents, it chanced that three or four young men that were concious of ome robberies & murders, were come for a refuge into a lodging very near mine. Jutices were preently advertied of their coming, and intended to urprize them in the beginning of the night: Thee Thieves were tout and deperate, and by conequence terrible unto almot every one: o as to run the lee danger, it was contrived to catch them in nares; and in order thereunto, they laid in the treets everal cords, about a foot from the ground; and ditant one from another about five or ix paces. After this, all the neighbours were commanded to tand ready in their Arms, to fall upon them when they were caught in the
nares; The tratagem did take according to their deires: but harke I beeech you what hapned before: my lave, who as I told you, was gone upon his errand, and as fortune was, went through this treet; And had not gone above twenty or thirty paces, but running very fat, his foot was catched in a nare and down fell he with his noe next the ground: now as it is naturall upon uch accidents to ave the face with the hands as much as one can, he broke the glas in a hundred peices, and had like to have broak his neck. At the noie and out-cry which he made upon his fall, ome neighbours opened their dores, who as I told you had command to fall upon thoe theeves and thought that it was now their time to fall on; But when they aw only the poor lave whoe blood guhed out at his noe they came gently to him, and without farther enquiry whither he went would have lent him a light, to pas the treet with more afty: but he who aw the caue of his voyage broken, he tood till lamenting and complaining, whilt as ill luck was, two great dogges wherewith one of the neighbours ued to bait, bulls, at Publique hews, did come into the treets: and being greedy of blood, they preently began to licke that which the lave had innocently mingled with the poyon.

They had not lapped with their tongues above three times, but they tumbled with their feet upwards and died imediately: at which the owner of them was o extreamly angry, that needs would he kill my lave the very ame intant: and to know the caue of o uddain and trange an end, he eied upon him, and carryed him to his houe: where the poor lave having given him an accompt of the buines wherin I imployed him he gave him the paper alo, auring himelf, that it would erve for his jutification. The man did quickly find out my deign, and conceiving it mot fit to acquaint the King, he went preently to advertie him of it. I undertood ince that Generick was ready to fall down at the ight of my letter: but at lat recollecting himelf, and turning all his fury againt me, he commanded twelve or fifteen of his guard to go imediatly to my houe and eie upon me, and to put me in that prion where traytors ued to be locked up: which command was preently obayed; And I being prepared to die, taying only for the return of my lave, they found my dores open, and a glas upon the table full of the ame poion, which I thought Eudoxe had received. I will not tell you in what a condition I was when I aw this obtacle unto, my reolution it will uffice you know that imagining the Princee to be dead I did exceedingly rejoice at all thoe tortures which I conceived were preparing for me.

Thraimond was returned from hunting a little before: and being extreamly impatient to ee his Mitree that he might know what effect his letter produced, he went unto the Palace where Eudoxe was, and telling her all the torye which you have heard, he made the Princee think that her reolution was not unknown unto him no more then the wicked deign of Generick.

Eudoxe then eeing all was dicovered, and fearing leat the King hould that night execute what he threatned, he thought good to make ue or Thraimonds love, hoping that the honet and legitimate paion of the on would give a top unto the burning and unlawfull lut of the Father: And indeed, he armed her eyes with all the perawive charmes he could to move pitty: he took her hand-handkercheif, and liting it to her eyes two or three times, he began to peak unto him in this manner. Since Sir you know what intentions Generick has upon me it is impoible but you hould approve of the deign which I have to prevent by my death that hamefull taine wherewith he would ully my honour and reputation. Though nature had not made me the Daughter unto Theodoius: and though fortune had not twice ubmitted the Emperedom of the Eat unto me, yet it is enough that I do know what a wife and a woman does owe unto virtue, never to conent unto the los of a thing the price whereof is beyond all value; And certainly what tiranny oever Generick is reolved to ue unto me, his paion hall till find reitance. That which his violence will not let me execute upon my own peron, my rage hall attempt upon his: and perhaps he hall to his woe, find what dipair can do in the incened pirit of an honet woman, if he be weary of her life which he has undertaken to protect: and if it anger him to hear himelf
accued for violating faith: let him with all my heart take away this life with I live with orrow: and if he will let me die gloriouly and with honour, he hall ee how little I will tartle at death; By this, generous Thraimond, you may perceive that if there be no remedy to top the fury of Generick, there is no hopes of my life, or of my two Daughters whom heaven has only left me for witnees, or rather Companions in my misfortunes. If, as our lat refuge, the love which you profes unto young Eudoxe be grounded upon honour, certainly you will be her Protector, and will be ahamed to marry her, after her Mother has lot that only thing which will be a glory unto her in the match: hall it be ever recorded to future ages in hitory, that Generick would glut his brutih lut upon Eudoxe the captive, and that Thraimond, the glory of his time, tood till and would never offer to be an obtacle unto uch a blacke deign? Oh good Sir do not uffer uch a blur to dim the tory of your life: And if the young Eudoxe have any power with you, or if you have any pitty upon mierable perons, let me execute what Olicaris had prepared for me; And good Sir, let not that mans innocence bear the blame of that crime which I only committed: it was I who forced him to prepare that poion: and his feares only, that I would attempt upon the peron of the King, made him conent unto it. Now Sir if for any particular interet you may have in my life, you do intend to hinder my death turn, if it be poible, the mind of Generick I conjure you; I do conjure you unto it even, by Eudoxe if you love her, by thee teares which I drop at the memorie of my mieryes; by your elf: and by thee armes which I fixe about your knees, which I will never let go untill you promie what I implore from you. In aying o, he fell down at the feet of Thraimond, and claped about the leggs of that Prince with o much trength as he was not able to rie o oon as he would: at this, he was o milted into pity, and Eudoxes deires to preerve her honour did pleae him o well, that his love encreaed, and made him think that no greater advantage could be unto his fortune then to marry the Daughter of o virtuous a Mother; Beides this, the glory to ee at his feet a Princes whom o many millions of people had obeyed, did o pleaingly flatter him that from thence forward he reolved to ue his very utmot endeavours for her delivery out of thoe paines which her feares had infued into her: and therefore unlooing Eudoxes armes as well as he could, he preently kneeled down upon the ground, and helping her up, Madam (aid he unto her) hope well in the goodnes of heaven and in my love: Generick hall joyn my death unto yours; or if his pity preerve me, his paion hall never hurt you.

Upon this, he left her to go unto the King: but he found him not in the Catle: for that Barbarian having no thoughts in his mind but the ruine of Eudoxe, and fearing that by the accident which hapned the death of that Princee would be ome obtacle unto his deires, he reolved to prevent it: and therefore when night came he took two or three eunuchs with him, and by a backe dore, went into the Palace where Eudoxe was detained. As oon as Thraimond was gone out, by fortune the Princee had hut her Chamber dore, o as Generick was contrained to knock: and Eudoxe knowing his voice, alo hearing the eunuchs murmure, he doubted what deign brought him thither: eeing her elf out of all meanes then to defend her elf, he put the table and all he could lay her hands upon, againt the dore: hoping perhaps Thraimond would come to her releif. But when he had a while utained this eige wherin the paion of Generick warred againt the virtue of Eudoxe: he reolved upon a mot generous deign for a woman. She with the help of her two daughters, took all the mattes that were under their beds, and other combutible things and heaping them togeather in the midt of the Chamber, he took two lighted candles, and etting them a fire: dear flames (aid he in a loud voice) be more pure then thoe of Generick, revenge upon me the pernitious deignes of that Barbarian and be as mercylee unto him as he is unto me: he pronounced thee words o loud and ditinctly that the King heard every illable: o as finding thereby the intention of the Princee, and fearing ome misfortune hould follow, he and his eunuchs redoubled their trength and at lat broke upon the dore: but the fire being kindled
and the moke being incloed triving for a paage, it found it at the opening of the door, and that with uch violence, as two of thoe that were at the door were choaked. Generick, urprized at this accident, began to flie, and never thinking of any way to quench this fire, only thought of aving himelf. But Thraimond, after a long earch after the King, and coming again to the place where Eudoxe was, he no ooner aw her Pallace on fire; but he preently thought it an effect of that Princee her courage, or of the revenge of Generick. And becaue he aw thoe flames were like to devour all the weet hopes he had of enjoying his Mitree, he was two or three times ready to cat himelf alo into the flame; yet deiring firt to know all particulars of the truth, he began to enquire of all he met, but none could tell him any thing more, then that Eudoxe her elf ued this extremity to free her elf from ervitude.

In the mean while Vraces and Olimbres, unto whom the Councel of ix hundred had refued the poion, imbarquing at the Port of the Mailians, and flattered (as I undertood ince) with a thouand weet hopes which an Atrologer had infued into them, they et forward: But as heaven took delight in putting every day new obtacles unto their properity, it uffered them to fall into the hands of a Pirate, who in taking away their liberty, took away all the contentments which were promied unto them. The name of this Pirate was Clorohalantes, vulgarly called the bloody Pirate; becaue, beides his being a Native Barbarian, and banihed Africa for a thouand crimes committed by him, he had made a olemn vow, never to pardon any whom Fortune made his laves. He pulled out the eyes of ome, cut off the noes, ears, and tongues of others: thus took he delight in torturing men. Sometimes when he was enraged he would pull out the hearts of ome, and others he would acrifice; ometimes unto Neptune, and ometimes unto Mercury, as the god of theft. His retreat was mot commonly into the Ile of great Brittany, where he found many that was utable to his own humour, and by that means found a more afe refuge. So as he coured up and fro the Ocean, and often paing the traits of Gibralter, otherwie called high Earth, he fell into the Mediterranean Sea, and mot inolently roved about the Coats of Spain. This was the Barbarian that met with the hip wherein Vraces & Olimbres were, and in a hort time borded her: But thoe two Cavaliers who never ued to be tartled at any dangers, they eized each of them upon a word and buckler, inciting ome Merchants to defend themelves, advanced themelves to hinder any from leaping into their hip: Some Marriners, to whom the name and trade of Pirats were odious, eeing an inevitable death had urrounded them, them, they reolved to ell their lives at as dear and noble a rate as they could: So as eizing upon Arms, and joyning themelves unto Vraces and Olimbres, there began a mot harp dipute. When they firt began Clorohalantes did nothing but laugh, eeing the inequality of forces: But when by the valour of his enemies he aw many of his men dead, he began to be very angry, and arming himelf, he himelf would needs become a combatant. At the ight of their Commander, all thoe who followed his Fortune aumed freh forces, and having him for their guide, did leap into the hip where Vraces and Olimbres did o bravely dipute for their lives, as every blow that fell from their Arms were mortal unto all upon whom they light. But not to init upon every particular, it will uffice you know that Clorohalantes, eeing what little advantage his ide got, he commanded that they hould at the ame time charge on in the Poup: which was done accordingly, and o harply, that thoe which defended themelves, not being able to withtand the over numeroity of their enemies, they let them have uch free accee as in lee then a quarter of an hour they were maters of the hip; and the ooner becaue Vraces and Olimbres, after a long reitance, fell at the lat one by the other, and were exceedingly weak with los of abundance of blood. Clorohalantes more proud of this victory then of any he ever got before, he quite forgot the price at which he bought it; but till he retained in his memory the brave reitance which Olimbres made, and a lave that fought next him. Therefore he caued them to be brought into his hip, and commanded their wounds to
be dreed, being reolved to make a mot olemn acrifice of them as of the mot glorious prey that ever he got ince he knew what belonged unto Arms or Sea.

In order to this deign he turned ail towards great Brittain, and eeing he had a very favourable wind, he would needs by way of diverion know, who thoe were, which by their valour had killed o many of his men. And therefore as oon as races and Olimbres, had recovered themelves a little better, they were brought before this Pirate, who addreing himelf unto Olimbres, as unto him who eemed to be the Mater, he asked him who he was, and from whence he came? Clorohalantes (aid Olimbres unto him, with a deportment that hewed the generoity of his pirit) I am a Cavalier and a Patrician of Rome: My name is Olimbres; and if thou wilt know by what Fortune I am become thy lave, then know, that to ave the life of a friend, I did not follow Generick, when loadned with the poils of Rome, he returned into Africa; Since that, finding no felicity in life, many coniderations moved me to eek out for death; and in order to that, I went to demand poion from the councel of ix hundred, which being denied me, I was contrained to conult with an Oracle, the anwer whereof made me wend my coure towards Africa: So I did, imbarquing my elf in this hip, over which thy Arms hath triumphed, and ubmitted me unto thy will: As for this lave, whom thou eet with me, I do not know his Fortune, nor what he is: for having bought him but a while ince, I have no knowledge of him; only I begin to think, by the fight which he hath made with me, that his courage and affection deerves a better Fate then that which is fallen upon him.

This was all that Olimbres aid unto him, and Clorohalantes remembring that he had formerly heard of the name: Was it not you (aid he) whom Eudoxe ent unto the King of the Vandals to olicite him to deliver her from the Tyranny of Maximus? Olimbres anwering that it was, the Pirate miled, and biting his fingers ends: 'Tis very well (aid he) the innocent hall once uffer for the culpable. In aying o, he caued them to be carried away, and commanded their wounds hould be carefully dreed: from hence forward, he reolved to be revenged on the peron of this Cavalier, for all the injuries that he had received from Generick; and imagining that he hould do an extream dipleaure unto that barbarous King, if he hewed his hatred upon this occaion, he reolved to make Olimbres uffer all the infamous tortures he could invent: And to begin his affliction betimes, he ent him word what he was to expect: which meage Olimbres received without the leat dimay; but fearing what would become of Vraces, he began to make uch ad complaints, that even Clorohalantes himelf, though a Barbarian, could not hear them without compaion. Olimbres knew, that but for him, the life of his friend had never been expoed unto o many mifortunes: So as finding himelf culpable of all the mieries which Vraces uffered, and of thoe which were menaced, he could not chue but cure the very day of his birth. Olimbres prepared himelf for the wort, he did all that poibly he could to comfort himelf in this thought, that the lat minute of his life would be the mot glorious unto him, ince it gave him a means to make it appear unto what degree his affection was arrived.

Thus they continued ome dayes; during which, their wounds healed o fat, as they were perfectly cured: and as if heaven were weary with tormenting them with any longer mieries, a tempet aroe at Sea, and o violent it was, that the hips of Clorohalantes, being forced to yield unto the violence of the torm, they were driven by the wind and we then amongt the ret of thoe hips which Generick had loadned with the plunder of Rome, and which lying at Anchor for a favourable wind: Then Clorohalantes, becaue he would not fall into the hands of Generick he killed himelf: This unlookt for deliverance was an Omen of good Fortune unto Vraces and Olimbres, who being releaed from their fetters, longed to embrace each other; but they forbore, let their Carees hould too much undiguie them and make them known. It was not long before they had a wind according to their wih o preently after, they came within ight of the Towers in Carthage; and becaue he who commanded in chief would end unto
Generick, not only the news of their arrivall, but alo of taking and defeat of Clorohalantes, Olimbres as being the mot undeniable witnes of it, was put upon this commiion, he went therefore into a cockboate, and taking Vraces, and ome other with him, he made towards the port in the beginning of the night: and whem they came near they perceived ome little lights like unto tarres in the Firmament which made them conceive they were very near the Town, the weet hopes of eeing Eudoxe and Placidia, filled Vraces, and Olimbres with o great a joy, that they were even tranported: and whilt they were conulting how they hould carry themelves in this buines they preently perceived a great moak, in which appeared many great flahes of fire, which ometimes broke out into flames, which eemed to proceed from ome furious conflagration. This made them fixe their looks upon that deplorable object: and as they drew near they aw the fire greater, and ometimes they heard a confued murmure of many voices togeather, they could not chue but greive to ee the fury of this inatiable element, and though they did not know that they themelves were more intereted in the misfortune then any, for it was the ame fire which Eudoxe kindled to avoid the violence of Generick, yet were they much troubled at it. They were no ooner come to the port, but Olimbres making himelf known, they ran preently to acquaint the King: In the mean while enquiring only out of curioity, the caue of that fire, he preently undertood by the common bruit of the Town, that the fire was in the place where Eudoxe, and her daughters were detained, that it was almot impoible they hould ecape, and that conequently they were perihed in the flames: and that it was generally beleived Eudoxe her elf did et the houe on fire, to free her elf from captivity. At this ad news Vraces fell down: and Olimbres tood o confued, that it was long before he was able to open his mouth; but to pend no time in needles relation of their orrowes, ince you may eaily imagine them let me only tell you, that after many a complaint againt heaven for preerving them o oft from everall perills, they accued the gods of injutice, as if they had preerved them from a leer burthen of mieryes to endure a greater.

At lat, hindring each other from making any attempts upon their perons, they intended to return unto the Mailians auring themelves that now they had uch good reaons to die, as it was impoible the poion hould be denied them. They had no ooner fixed themelves upon this coure but Thraimond came unto the place where Olimbres was: and becaue thoe who went to carry the news of Olimbres arivall, could not peak with the Father, they were contrained to make their addrees unto the on: and becaue Olimbres in his African voyage had gotten the affectionate freindhip of that Prince, Thraimond went with joy to receive him; They had no ooner embraced each other, but Thraimond began firt to peak: dear Olimbres (aid he in a loud voice) you are arrived at a time wherin you will find all our court in great diorder. If I be not mitaken (anwered the ad Olimbres) I do know the principall caue, and certainly, after the death of three uch fair Princees, joy were far out of eaon, Olimbres could not chue but end forth a mot profound igh as he aid o: and Thraimond to conceal his joyes whipered that Cavelier in the ear; The misfortune (aid he unto him) is nothing o great as is beleived: upon this taking him by the arme he carried backe into the boate, wherin none was but races who was triving betwixt life and death: and cauing all the men to tand at a ditance and candles to be taken away, when he thought none could hear but Olimbres, he began this dicoure.
