Dear freind (aid he unto him) I mut make two very particular confeions unto you; by the one I mut confee my own rahnee, and by the other, my Fathers hame: upon this, he related unto him, how he was in love with the young Eudoxe, and how he received him: afterwards he related the violence which Generick ued towards Eudoxe, the Mother; He told him of my imprionment by reaon of the poion which I had prepared for her: at lat he told him of all the attempts which the King had made upon the Chamber of that Princee, and how he et it on fire: after this; Now dear Olimbres (continued he) you mut know, that Eudoxe had no ooner kindled the fire, not any horrors of
death, but orrowes to be a caue of her two Daughters death did o far enter into her oul, as he could not chue but retire her elf into another Chamber where the two Princees lay; Then hutting the door, and remembring the affection which I had profeed, he began to think, that perhaps if he could ecape this danger, Generick would leave puruing her or that I would find out ome way to top him. This conideration made her conent not to die yet: o as opening the window towards the garden, by fortune he epied at her feet two heets which he tyed togeather, and by them he firt let down Eudoxe, next Placidia, and latly her elf; Olimbres having no patience: How? (aid he, and interrupted) is not Eudoxe dead? he is not (anwered Thraimond) he ran unto a little houe in the corner of the garden belonging to the Gardiner, whom he awaked, (for as you know, thoe kind of men go to bed betimes) he made him open the door, and as oon as he was entred: freind (aid he unto him) the palace is all on fire. Upon this the Gardiner who by reaon of the darknes did not know Eudoxe, he went out, and was not long before he aw the flames flah out of the Chamber from whence the Princees came; then coming in again in a great amae, good gods (aid he) what will become of the fair prioners? They are in a place (anwered Eudoxe) where their lives do depend upon thee; and if thou wilt preerve them, I will make thee happy for ever. Upon this, he caued him to light up a candle; and the poor fellow in a mighty confuion asking her what he would have him to do; all that I would have thee do (aid Eudoxe) is to hide us, leat ome hould come and urprie us; then would I have thee ran in all hat and acquaint Thraimond where we are but above all, be ure that no living oul know it but only he.

The Gardiner then finding no afer place to put them in then a little cave which was near his houe, their he hid them, and came to tell me what Eudoxe commanded. He had as much a do to get unto me, as I had to get out of the croud; for you mut know Olimbres, that the town is in uch a confuion, o as one could hardly know another in the diorder. But at lat I followed him to his little houe, upon which abundance of parks began already to fall; which making me fear it would at length be burned I could not not give any tetimones of my joy unto the Princees: but carrying them as ecretly as I could unto the houe of one of my dometiques not far from thence, I gave ome money to the Gardiner, and charged him upon paine of his life to be ilent. Leaving them then in afty there, I returned unto the Catle to ee the King, but I could not: for the horror of this accident had o terified him that he would not be een by any. Thus was I the firt that knew of your return where at I much rejoyce, and aure you, dear Olimbres, that I will continue in the ame deires which I have, and ever had to love and erve you. This was the dicoure of Thraimond, which was abundance of joy unto Olimbres and I hould have aid it had bin the highet degree, if the joyes of races had been comparable unto his. That diguied Cavelier heard all that the Prince aid, for he being behind in the boate, they took no notice of him; And his joyes to hear that his Mitree was alive did o tranport him into the other extream, as formerly he was in his mieryes and greif. Yet heaven which would preerve him for the felicity of Eudoxe, would not uffer him to die upon this excee of delight: but following Olimbres, whom Thraimond would needs have to lodge in the Catle, they were no ooner alone, but they began to embrace each other, and pent almot all the night in relating their adventures.

The next morning Generick heard of the return, and of his hippes, and of Olimbres but the memory of this late dimall accident, would not uffer him to be enible of thoe joyes which at another time, he had reented. Yet he welcomed Olimbres as well as he could: and deiring to hide from poterity the true caue of Eudoxes death, he began to invent, all the excues he could devie to palliate that crime which he had committed. Olimbres eemed to beleive all the King aid, and fetching a hundred diembled ighes for the loe of thee three Princees, he oberved, that the memory of this ad tragedy had infued ome repentance into the King: and indeed, he greived o extreamly at it, as one might read repentant orrow in his eyes: and to leave ome tetimony of that eteem which he had
of Eudoxe, though a captive, he caued her corps to be earched amongt the reliques of the combution. They found the bodies of the three Eunuches which the flame had mothered, but o conumed as none of them retaining any form, they were taken for the corpes of the Princee, and her two daughters; Generick he prepared a mot tatly monument to be erected for them, and commanding them to be put into coffins of ilver he alo gave orders they hould be very carefully guarden.

In the mean Thraimond who feared that Eudoxe was not afe enough in the Town, he caued her to be carried unto a very fair houe which he had in the Countrey, not far from Carthage. As oon as conveniently he could, he carryed Olimbres thither alo, under a pretence of diverting him: but as oon as Eudoxe aw him, he was o urpried as he fell into a wond, yet at lat recovering, and deiring to peak with him in private, he carried him into another chamber, leaving Thraimond with the young Eudoxe and Placidia. As oon as he was alone with Olimbres, he called into her memory all the ervices of Vraces, and the thoughts of his death did o afflict her, that her teares, and her ighes would not of a long time let her tongue do its office. At lat, as oon as he could peak, well Olimbres (aid he unto him) what do you think of my fortune? Am I not extreamly mierable that whether I would or no, mut live after the los of your freind? In aying o, her voice was lot again, amongt her ighes, and teares, and Olimbres beginning to peak, Madam, anwered he, ince heaven has o ordained it, you are infinitly to be commended, for conforming your will unto it: and perhaps in recompence, it will one day deliver you from the memory of that ad accident. Alas (replied Eudoxe) it will rather to punih me: for know Olimbres, that let this memory bring me what mieryes, and affliction it will, I had rather die then not preerve it. But ince all my teares cannot call Vraces backe, good Olimbres acquaint me with the particulars of your voyage, and I hall relate my misfortunes unto you. Madam (aid the Cavelier) Prince Thraimond has made me acquainted with mot of your affaires: and a • in relation to my elf I hall quickly atisfy your curioity. Then he told her of the lat freindly office, which he eemed to have done unto Vraces, and afterwards told her how he was taken captive by Clorohalantes: then how the counell of ixe hundred had denied him poyon; how he was delivered and latly how he came to Carthage, without any other trayn but a lave which he bought to betow upon her. What oever it be (aid Eudoxe) that comes from the hand of Olimbres, I hall hold it in a mot particular eteem: but if you will betow him upon me it hall be upon a condition that I hall give him his liberty. Madam, (aid Olimbres) I do not think that he would have it: upon this he went out to look for Vraces, who was in uch impatience to her who had the dipoition of his life, as his oul was enible of all extraordinary motions; At lat, being welled with love, with fear, and with repect, he was brought into the preence of Eudoxe: as oon as he entred into her chamber he cat himelf at her feet; Then the Princee laying her hand upon his head, I do take you for mine (aid he unto him) ince Olimbres will have it o, and will from hence forward take away the name of lave, and make you free. Upon this, he commanded him to rie: Madam, (aid Vraces) another would give you thanks for this favour; But truly I think no felicity comparable unto my ervitude: I told you (replied Olimbres) that he would not take the liberty which you would give him: In aying o, he cat his eyes upon the Princee, and oberved her to change collour: and indeed, at the voice of Vraces all her blood came into her face, and tepping back to looke upon him, Vraces roe up: and Eudoxe in a trange urprie. Good gods (aid he) is not this Vraces whom I ee? It is he Madam, (anwered Vraces, and went unto her) who is come to eek from you that death which both gods, and men have denied unto: Oh my dear Vraces (cryed out Eudoxe) upon this he took him about the neck and for a while remained in an extaie with in his armes. At lat, being recollected, Vraces rendred her an accompt of all the accidents that had hapned unto him: and after that Olimbres beginning to peak Madam (aid he unto her) firt, the habit which Vraces weares do ute well with the
condition wherin his oul is to you wards: econdly I thought it the bet way, to hide him from the knowledge of Generick for he knows it was that Cavelier who killed Maximus, and having committed almot the ame fault againt you, he has reaon to fear the like punihment; and therefore I conceive it bet to conceale your joyes, to the end Thraimond, who perhaps being like unto his Father, may not dicover his diguiement. Eudoxe did approve of Olimbres counell: o as after he had given thanks unto the gods for the preervation and return of Vraces, he went unto Thraimond, who after many tetimonies of joy at the favours which he received from his Mitree, told Olimbres it was time to return unto Carthage, to ee in what humour Generick was.

races, yet he tayed with Eudoxe; but I will not mention thoe weet entertainments which they had together: for at the ame time Generick would be revenged upon me for all the dipleaures which he reented by the pretended death of Eudoxe; and had not Thraimond told him, that ince Olicaris had aved his life, he could do no les then do the like for him, I verily believe he had put me to ome ignominious death.

Olimbres continued ome dayes at Court, and had no other contentment but what he received from the friendhip of Thraimond and Placidia, whom he viited very often under the pretence of waiting upon the Prince a hunting; for the King grieved o extreamly at the memory of that Fatal fire, as he could not look upon any with a kind apect. He is, as I told you before, of a nature barbarous enough, and yet he did much value his honour: o as knowing how this lat action of his would tain it, he grieved beyond meaure, and did all that poibly he could to tifle the memory of it.

Olimbres then eeing he could not be any more erviceable unto Eudoxe, he deigned to return unto Marcian, hoping the authority of that Emperour might procure the liberty of this Princee: But Thraimond who had other thoughts, when Olimbres did communicate his intention to him, I would have you eem (aid he unto Olimbres) as if you did take your leave of the King, that you may o try his affection unto you; but I would not have you leave me, for I hall imploy you in the ervice of Eudoxe. Olimbres promiing to obey all his commands, he went unto Generick, and mot humbly beought him for leave to return, ince he had no ervice to command him there: auring him that he hould think himelf infinitly honoured in the continuance of his friendhip. The King, who loved this Cavalier well; and knew that the death of Placidia who was promied unto him, had extreamly offended him; he reolved not to let him go without ome atisfaction, and therefore deired him, not to think of his departure for ome certain dayes, after which he hould be at liberty to do what he pleaed. Olimbres was contented to tay as long as the King commanded, and the King, communicating unto Thraimond his deign unto Olimbres, he asked him what he hould do to oblige that Cavalier: The Prince propounded everal wayes, and was very glad to find the Kings affection beyond his hopes: He acquainted Olimbres with it, and told him, that if he could but comply handomly with that opportunity, he might dipoe Generick unto what he would. Olimbres even ravihed at this, beeeched him to negotiate o with the King, as to get him to go unto the houe where Eudoxe was; and told him that the only expedient was to invite him unto a dinner in that place, which indeed was the finet eat about all Carthage: Thraimond thought this no hard matter to do, and therefore making the propoition unto the King, they appointed a day for it.

In the interim the Cavalier acquainted Eudoxe with his reolution, and though he did find ome difficulty in it, yet he did approve on't, being aured of Vraces his love, of Thraimonds promies, and Olimbres his fidelity. The day appointed being come, Generick, Thraimond, Olimbres, and many others of the bet rank in all Carthage, went betimes in the morning unto the houe where the Prince had ordered the Tables in the dining room, to be near unto the chamber of the Princees. And there, as oon as dinner was done, Olimbres addreing himelf unto the King, did beg that leave which before he had asked: Generick then in a mot affectionate manner, dear Olimbres (aid he unto him) I do
find your deires o jut and reaonable, as I hould be extreamly ahamed to oppoe them any longer. 'Tis true I am very orry that I have not given any tetimony of that affection which I bear unto you; but till occaions fall out that I may, I beeech you accept of my good intentions, and be aured, that I would do any thing which would be contentment unto you. Sir, replied Olimbres, after many thanks, you may if you pleae do two high favours for me in one moment, and did I not fear denial, I hould aume o much boldnee as to ask them of you. Upon this, the King making a olemn vow not to deny him any thing he would ask, Olimbres kneeled down upon the ground, Sir (aid he) ince it is your Royal pleaure to ay o, I do ask of you the liberty of Eudoxe and Olicaris. In aying o, Thraimond opened the chamber door where the Princee was trembling with her two daughters: and the King urprized at an accident o little expected, tood a while and knew not what he did. At lat, being moved at the tears of Eudoxe, who came preently and cat her elf at his feet, having Placidia in one hand, and her iter in the other, he granted the requet of Olimbres, and promied for the future to treat her as a Princes, not as a lave. Thraimond, who would alo make ue of his time, he beeeched Generick to give him the young Eudoxe for his wife; and the King knowing what advantages this would be unto him, did conent unto it. Amidt this common joy, I was not forgotten, for Generick at that very intant ent for me; but I, who knew I was never to go out of prion, until I went to execution, I confee that I had o prepared my elf for death, as I thought they only jeted with me: At lat my own eyes cleared me all thoe upicions: for being brought into the Kings preence there I aw Eudoxe at liberty, and received a pardon for my life.

The news of this accident was quickly pred all over the Town, and the Princees were waited upon unto their lodgings with all uual magnificence. Vraces was the only one unatisfied, as fearing the King would fall into his paionate fits again; but preently after, he found by the King • repentant tears, that he would never make more attempts againt the chatity of Eudoxe, but had quenched his flames with tears, and indeed a little while after, he ent her back to Contantinople, with her two Daughters, in a mot honourable Equipage: unto which he was no ooner come, but Vraces having married Eudoxe in great olemnity, he received that happines which Fortune had made him pay o dear for: And where Olimbres, by the command of Marcian, and conent of Eudoxe, he found his long'd for happinee in the arms of Placidia, as a reward of his fidelity.

The great Olicaris had no ooner ended his dicoure, but Phillis entred, yet o out of breath, that he atonihed all the company, epecially Adamas and Belinde, who feared extreamly that he brought them ome ill news concerning Atrea, Diana, and Alexis: therefore the Druide, who thought it bet, that if any diater had hapned, not to acquaint Belinde with it upon uch a udden, he roe up and went to meet her: and Phillis no ooner was come up to him, but with extream amazement, O Father (aid he unto him) I can tell you the tranget accident, that ever was heard or een: Astrea and Diana are found; they are both aleep cloe by the Fountain of Loves verity. Abundance of Shepherds & Shepherdees tand looking upon them, but not one has o much courage as to go near them. For (and this is the greatet wonder) the two Unicorns lie cloe by them, with their heads upon the knees of my companions: they grinn and roar o terribly at any that offer to come near them, that not a Shepherd dares attempt it.

This did extreamly atonih the Druide; for he plainly aw the deign of the two Shepherdees, but that which mot troubled him was, his fears that they were dead already; and that none daring to come nearer them, it was credible they all thought them o: yet being unwilling to tell Belinde what he thought, he went unto her, and told her what Phillis had een: Belinde roe up preently, and in her exces of joy, forgetting her duty unto Roanira and Galathea, he went out of the Gallery, intending to run unto the place where he thought Diana was; but Adamas would not uffer her; be not o haty (age Belinde, aid
he unto her) you need not take the pains of going to them, for we will end ome others: Pardon me, anwered Belinde, I mut not defer it one minute longer: I cannot live, if I do not immediatly ee her, and ince Phillis has told me where he is, if you love me let me go unto her and bring her back. My intention, Madam (anwered the Druide) is not to hinder you from eeing her, but on the contrary, I will make as much hate as you: yet ince Phillis does know o well where thee two Shepherdees are, let her be my guide, and never trouble your elf, for I will take upon me the charge of bringing her back. However, Father, aid Galathea, do not refue our company, for it is a ight o remarkable, as all of us will be glad to be pectatours of it. Surely (aid Belinde, when he aw Adamas conenting unto it) I am he that has mot interet in thee women, and why hould not I alo ee them? and believe it I mut, for I had rather incur your dipleaure, in diobeying you, then not ee them in what place oever they be.

Adamas would willingly have diwaded her, as thinking till that thee fair ones were not in uch a condition as would give her any contentment: but all his arguments being not o prevalent as the love and impatiency of Belinde, it was reolved upon, that he would make one of the company. They et forward then altogether: and the Druide asking Phillis, how, and in what manner, Atrea and Diana were found, you mut know Father (anwered he) that this morning we all parted, every one taking a everal way as we did yeterday; Licidas he took towards the Fountain, I told him alo which way I would go, and in cae any of us heard any news of them, we agreed to meet all at noon, at the ame place where we met yeterday, which was by the ide of the river Lignon: I came unto the rendezvous before him, for to tell you truly I began to depair in my quet: After I had been there a while, I aw him coming a great pace towards me, but as ad as he was in the morning when we parted: As oon as he was come unto me: Ah Phillis (aid he very adly) if you would ee Atrea and Diana, they are not far from hence: I aw them cloe by one another fat aleep: Then I interrupting him, have you een them? (aid I in a great amazement) for god ake, good Lycidas conduct me to them, and make no more delay: Indeed (anwered he) I did ee them, and will let you ee them alo; but if you love me, do not oblige me to peak unto them, or go near them: for if I do, it will prove as fatal unto me as death it elf. You think (aid I unto him) that Atrea is angry with you; but you may very well be atisfied, ince he has asked you pardon: Alas, alas, replied the Shepherd, words are never able to repair that injury which I received from her in the peron of my brother: whilt we were thus talking, we came nearer; and as oon as he hewed me the place where my companions were, or at the leat where he left them: Do you ee yonder old Altar (aid he unto me) which time hath demolihed? They do lie at the feet of thoe tairs upon which it is erected: I did ee the place to which he pointed with his finger; but being unwilling he hould leave me, I till went on, and eemed as if I did not ee it. At lat, when I began to perceive Atrea and Diana, me thinks (aid I unto him) that I do ee omething; but it is o confuedly, as if you do not go along with me, I hall hardly hit the way unto them: Alas Phillis (anwered he) why will you be any caue of o much orrows unto me? upon this looking up, and eeing we were nearer then he thought: unles you be blind (aid he) you cannot mis the place where they are: as he aid o, I oberved that he looked upon them very attentively, but (aid he) I ee omething there, which was not there when I left them; perhaps (aid I) it is Alexis: This hope made us go omething nearer, but when we were within fourty or fifty paces, Licidas made a udden top. Mitres (aid he) for gods ake go no further, for I ee two fierce beats with them, and if I be not mitaken, they are the U • nicorns which ue to guard the Fountain of verity in Love. I mut needs confes Father, that a ecret chill fear glided through all my veins; and I was glad that at the very ame intant, Hylas and Adrates appeared in ight: for under pretence of going to advertie them of this Novelty, I got further off from their fury; but yet, taking a little courage, I returned with them, and finding my elf more trong in their company, I looked
more confidently upon my companions: I aw them in the ame condition as Licidas told me, to wit, lying at the tairs foot of that Altar: Moreover, I oberved they embraced each other, and the two Unicorns leaned their heads upon them. I could have wihed with all my heart, that thee two cruel creatures had tood in as much fear of me, as I did of them, that we might have had more free acces unto my companions; but they would not tir from thoe fair Shepherdees, and there was not a Shepherd that durt tir a tep nearer them. Seeing then, that my tay there would not at all advantage them, I thought bet to come, and acquaint you, and in comming, I met Celidea, Thamires St • lla, Do • is, and everall others, whom I told where they might be witnees of this adventure: Alas alas (aid Adamas) this is a mot ad adventure: for Atrea who feares the world has an ill opinion of her virtue, by reaon of Celadons diguiement, will have this way to be a tryall of her purity: becaue it is the property of thoe beats never to come near any have been once poluted.

Thus all the Company talked as they went, whilt at the ame time Alexis and Silvander were in their way to execute that enterprie which they reolved upon the day before: They awaked not o oon as they deired: for they feared that if the Sun were up they hould meet ome who would be obtacles unto their deign; yet being fully reolved to go on through all difficulties, and thinking upon nothing but this lat munite which would free them from all the Tyrannies of fortune, they went o fat that they came in a very hort time unto the Altar where Atrea, and Diana lay aleep; Alexis was the firt that epied them, and being upried at this encounter he made a udden top: Silvander who oberved her atonihment, and asking her the caue; Alas dear freind (anwered Alexis) would not you be a mot uppried peron, if as Atrea does preent her elf before me, Diana hould once more honour you with a veiw of her fair face? Indeed I hould (aid Silvander) but that were a happines, which is o far beyond my hopes, as I think it impoible to be. Yet, replied Alexis, if you turn but your eye towards yonder altar, which is a little raied up above the levell of the plain, and which is not far ditant from us, you hall ee with Atrea a hepherdes to whom you wih no ill. Silvander then looking that way, and eeing Diana, his colour went, and came into his face two or three times; and in this amazement being hardly able to peak: Oh heavens (cryed he out) oh Diana? Upon this, making more hat towards them, they came o near thoe hepherdees that they could dicern every feature in their faces, and Alexis, who fell down at the feet of Atrea, cruell fair one (aid he in a low voice, and with a deep igh, heaven is unjut to grant unto you o much ret after you have by your hatred caue myne to ceae. And you Diana (aid Silvander unto her) do you come unto this alter to thank the gods for giving you the poeion of Paris? or do you come to complain againt them for ravihing you from the inviolable love of Silvander? after this, both being ilent a while; But fair Atrea (replied Alexis) who maugre all your rigours, is mot dear unto me; cannot I read in thoe fair eyes, the caue your comming hither? Oh leep, be not thou as cruell unto me, as thou art weet unto this in humain fair one: Oh thou god of ret and comfort, let her look once upon me, before I die; But (continued he, and reprehended her elf) I have no reaon to invoke thee, ince the cruelty of Atrea hews me, that Divinities themelves are ometimes inenible.

Fairet Diana (aid Silvander, and gently kied her fair hands) receive thee few teares, which I now drop upon the Lillies of your hand as the lat tetimony of your hepherds love: Receive oh ye fairet lips this ad, and deplorable adieu: and if it be poible my paion can inpire any thing into your oul, let not my name die in your memory. In aying o be adventured to kie her, and yet he did not waken: for he had been o long without leep, and was o very weary, as he lept mot oundly; Alexis on her ide, he tole the ame favour from the ruby lips of Atrea, and afterwards, looking upon Silvander, but hepherd (aid he unto him) unto whom are we debtors for thee favours, but to their inenibility? Let us retreat Silvander, and not mixe uch weets with o many bitters which we ue to tat, let us leave thee beauties whom we have o religiouly
adored unto their ret, and not tay till they hall awake, and condemn this lat action of our lives, of too much preumption; Let us go Silvander whither our detinies do call us: come on, anwered Silvander, let us go and die; But (aid he before he went, and kied the hand of Diana) adieu, the fairet that ever lived upon the bankes of Lignon; adieu Diana: adieu the object of my love, and the caue of my torments. Upon this he roe up, and heard Alexis ay: and thou the fairet, and mot inhumane that ever was, dear Atrea, if it happen that the fury of the Lyons, and Unicornes do leave o much reliques of me as may let you know my deplorable, and generous end; know alo that my love made choie of this kind of death, and your rigour was the caue of it; I do not deire from heaven any revenge upon your cruelty; but I beeech the gods to make my innocency, and fidelity to known unto you, as you may never doubt but that as I have been the mot faithfull of all lovers, o you have been the mot cruell of all Mitrees; in aying o he roe up, and taking Silvander by the hand; they went both togeather towards the fountain.

This encounter paed whilt Lycidas went to advertie Phillis of the place where he had found the hepherdees, and before they returned Alexis, and Silvander were got o near the inchanted fountain that the two Unicornes which firt epied them, left the Lyons to guard it, and came traight towards them. Alexis who looked for nothing but death, tood till: and Silvander who looked for no les, did open his armes to receive that mortall wound which would take him away from the number of men, but the Unicornes, which came mot furious towards them, paed by, and did them no harm. This accident which was far beyond their hopes did extreamly atonih them: but deiring to know what would be the iue, they turned about, and looked after them. They aw them go gently towards Diana, and Atrea, and after they had gazed a while upon the ground, they layed themelves down upon the ground, and leaned their heades upon thoe hepherdees: at firt they feared that thee Animals would have done them ome injury, and therefore they advanced to releive them: yet as oon as they aw them laid down, they topt, and admired to ee o much weetnes from them as in nature they might well expect mot cruelty.

They were in thee coniderations when they aw Lycidas, and Phillis comming: o as fearing to be perceived they laid them down upon the groud, and hiding themelves behind a little buh, oberved a while their actions, and atonihment: at lat, when they aw Phillis leave Lycidas, a while after epied Hylas and Adrates, and all the ret unto whom that hepherdes had told the newes of finding Atrea, and Diana. Alexis then eeing a great number of perons aembling themelves togeather, he turned towards Silvander: hepherd (aid he unto him) pray go you unto that good company: you had much better be with them then with me whoe Company is o contageous as does infect all that are with me, with a deire of d • ing. Your Company (anwered Silvander) does not produce the ame effects in me, ince on the contrary I may ay it has hindred me, or at leat deferred my death; For certainly had not you diverted me yeterday from my reolution, I hould ere this have paid that tribute which I owe unto nature. But as for you Celadon (continued he) why hould you o willfully fly from the looks of your fair hepherdes? though Atrea was angry with you, yet it was only out of a paionate fit which he could not reit, and ince it was o violent as could not lat long; Follow my advice go, and appeae the pirit of that fair hepherdes, who doubtles is in extream impatience to know what is become of you: you will thereby oblige all the hepherds, and hepherdees in this Countrey; for I am ure there is not one who is not much intereted in you eyther by blood or affection; But I, poor illy wretch I, wonder who would care whether I do live or die; Firt Diana: he will find a ubject of incomparable atisfaction by my death, becaue thereby he will be rid of him, whoe preence will eternally accue her, and make her appear culpable of perfidy: as for the ret of hepherds, and hepherdees: alas why hould any of them be enible of my mieryes, ince my death mut needs be as indifferent unto them as my life; For not being known unto any, no my own elf, not knowing what I am, why
hould any make me the object of his amity? a vagabond, and a mierable wretch who has reented the very wort of fortunes malice. Your merit replied Alexis, hath upplied all thoe defects which you alleadge, and has given you as much eteem from all of any quality in this Countrey then if you had been decended from the mot illutrious families in all Forrets, No no, aure your elf Silvander, your death would be infinitly lamented by all, and every one will lament your los: as loing the glory of the Province in loing you who are the mot perfectly accomplihed hepherd in it: o as your will in expoing your elf unto the fury of the Lyons is not jut: becaue you do not only offend the gods, by ditroying their mot perfect work, but alo men, by ravihing from them the raret example of virtue they ever had. Follow my advice Silvander; let me die alone, reerve the remainder of your dayes for actions that will be glorious unto you: and retore him back unto Diana, for who I know her oul has ent forth a thouand ighes of love; whatoever you make conjecture, I am fully perwaded but he has done ome violence to keep her elf from falling into the power of Paris: and the condition wherin now he is, me thinks is a trong argument that the marriage is not conummated; For why hould he come with Atrea unto a place o little frequented ince the inchantment of the fountain, but only to conceall her elf from Bellinde for ome dayes, and to give her time of conideration how little inclination her Daughter has unto that alliance? alas (aid Silvander, and interrupted her) this mall abenting her elf, and this elf are arguments more trong to confirm me in a beleif that my dipair is jut, and that her infidelity is true; For may I not well think that this ungratefull woman did abent her elf, to kindle the flames of Paris the more, and that this leep is part of that ret which my rivall would have toln from her the firt night, by his carrees? oh what dimal caues of jealouy do I find? and how this paion tranports me into fury? Can you think it jut, Celadon, that I hould live to be a witnes of all thoe kies which this husband will gather from thoe lippes which have pronounced the entence of my death, and his happines? Do you not think that thoe favours which this fickle one publiquely conferres upon him as innocent as they are yet, do not appear unto me mot horrid crimes? alas you do not love aright if you think they are not enough to kill me: aure your elf every look he cats upon him is a dagger to my heart; No no hepherd, I had better let them alone, to enjoy their delights freely: my preence will but diturbe them, every thing does invite me unto this deign more then you, who has no legall warrant to authorie the reolution which you have taken but only the bare paionate humour of Atrea, which perhaps has made her weep a thouand times ince, and repent he ere concealed from you the good, though ecret, acceptance he had of all your ervices; Therefore dear Celadon if my prayers have any prevalence with you, I beeech you let me only run this adventure: it is a faithfull lover who ought to die: do not dipute the matter any longer with me; And pardon me, if I ay out of the knowledge I have of my love, and humour, that it is mot impoible to find one man in the whole world who can excell me. In aying o, he embraced Celadon, and conjured him again to let him obtain this favour which he required: but Celadon eeming ill atisfied with his requet, truly Silvander (anwered he) you do reemble him who received as a harer only in a treaure, yet will needs become the ole mater of it, and drive out him who firt admitted him only at a haring Companion in his fortune; It was I who firt deigned this dienchantment by giving my life, and now I have communicated my deign unto you, it is you that would hinder me from the execution of it, and would your elf take all that glory which the gods reerved only for me. Dear Celadon (aid Silvander, and interrupted him) do not blame me for deiring to take that advantage from you, which will procure you a far greater; I mean the enjoyment of Atrea; I dare wear that fair hepherdee would think your preence at this hower her greatet happines; Take my advice Celadon, preent your elf before her once more & if he do not forbid you to die, I will confes my elf injurious in adviing you to live. Nay (anwered Alexis) that cruell one hall never have the pleaure of condemning me the econd time. I know what obedience I owe unto all her commands, and will not put her to o
much pains as to pronounce them often. But as for you Silvander, live, and live for Diana, ince you know he deires it, and did never command the contrary: all the arguments, perwaions, and reaons, that you can poibly devie, can never alter me from that reolution which I am fixed upon to die, by the mortal claws of thee furious Lions, which cannot be o cruel, but will leave me o much time as they are tearing me in pieces, as to remember that Atrea is more pittiles.

Thee lat words tole ome tears from the eyes of Alexis, who eeing how contrary her end was unto thoe weet hopes which he had conceived in the beginning of her affection, her heart could not chue but melt at the memory of thoe kind promies which Astrea once made unto her: and Silvander, who alo had the ame coniderations, he began to embrace Alexis, and aw thoe tears which dropped from her eyes: they embraced each other a long while, and perhaps had done longer, if Alexis, who alwayes looked towards Astrea, had not epied a great company coming towards them: he preently advertied Silvander of it, and both looking earnetly at them, it was not long before they aw it was Adamas, Belinde, and Phillis; but Silvander knew not Galathea, Roanira, nor the ret of the Nymphs, becaue of the change in their habits. Fearing then, that if the Druide aw them, he would hinder them in their deigne: Come, come, dear Silvander (aid Alexis and roe up hatily) let us not dipute any longer upon this point, let us go and ee to which of us the gods will judge the price of fidelity; and ince they only can decide our difference, it is folly to conult upon it any longer here.

Upon this, he went towards the Fountain, and Silvander following her, if it happen (aid he) that we both die, we hall have this advantage at the leat, to hut up in one Tombe two friends, who have almot the very ame Fates in their loves, would uffer the ame deaths. In aying o, they were come o near the Lions, that thoe fierce Animals heard them, and looked upon them with mot affrighting looks; but the Shepherds were o far from any ignes of fear, that there was a freh vermilion in their cheeks: and as if an horrid object were an object of joy and felicity, they began to mile, and to hew, that their courages were not lee then the Ferocity of thoe mercilee Guardians. Alexis, who came thither only to die, and not to fight, did at the firt prepare her elf to receive their cruelty: whilt the Lions, at the ight of this new prey, did beat their ides and the ground with their tails, and were rowing up anger enough to devour thee Lovers, he kneeled down upon the ground, and looking up to heaven, O ye merciful gods (aid he) who have inpired me with this remedy to keep my mieries from being infinite, as is your power; accept, I beeech you, of this acrifice which I offer unto you of my body, and I would ay of my oul alo, did you not know that it is till a captive in the charms of the fairet, but mot ungrateful Shepherdes that ever was; even for pities ake, O mot puiant Divinities, let my death atisfie you for all her injuries: and as great as her crimes are which he hath committed againt Love, for my ake ceae your reentments of them; and let that caue which moved her to deire my death, be a motive unto you to prolong her happines and life.

Alexis had no ooner ended her prayer, but Silvander began: O ye pittilee Detinies, cryed he out, who by irrevocable Laws have ordained I hould pend my mierable dayes, in all the afflictions which any oul is capable to reent, now, I beeech you, ee your own doom executed. As you have poke all truth, concerning the mieries that menaced my life, be you as true alo in what you have poken concerning my death: In aying o, he opened his bret, and joyfully prepared himelf to receive thoe wounds, which would let out his oul with his blood: he aw the Lions approaching towards them with eyes that parkled fire, and lifting up their paws, they hewed their crooked claws, whoe points were as harp as any needles.

In the mean while Adamas and the ret, were come within fourcore or a hundred paces of Atrea and Diana: The two Shepherdees waked at the ame time, and were o affrighted to ee the two Unicorns o near them, that they never
looked towards the place where Licidas was, with Thamires, Celidea, Doris, Adrates, and the ret, nor towards the place where Galathea and Roanira were with Adamas and Belinde: All they could do in that amazement, or rather that affright, was to offer themelves unto thoe Animals, as thinking they came thither only to devour them: but eeing them upon a udden to run towards the Fountain, they thought that it was there only where they were to die, and that the Unicorns did only hew them the way. Atrea and Diana therefore ran after them, and were no ooner come to the place where Alexis and Silvander were expecting their deaths, but they aw thoe two Shepherds upon their knees, within ten paces of them, and the Lions, with enraged fury, ready to tear them in pieces. This encounter did extreamly urprize them; but having no time to conider what to do, they followed the firt uggetion of their paion, and tepping betwixt them, it is we that are to die (aid they) and not thoe Shepherds, who are not culpable of any crime.

Alexis and Silvander, ravihed at this pectacle, and fearing let thoe Shepherdees hould receive ome harm, they fell upon the Lions, and began to fight with them more for the interet of their Mitrees, then their own preervation; but being without any arms, they were quickly thrown down, and the two Unicorns, as taking their parts, came at the very ame intant, and falling upon the Lions, there began a mot harp combat betwixt them. Adamas, Belinde, and the ret, who aw Atrea and Diana go away, did follow them, but they came not time enough, for the combate was almot ended: the heavens, which before were clear and erene, was now all cloudy; and the Sun was o obcured, as if the world were to perih in horrid darknes. The fields, which with variety of flowers ued to render us mot fragrant odour, now lot that weetnee, and tunk of ulphure: No light was to be een but that of lightning, with uch horrid claps of thunder, which peaking the anger of the gods, it is eaie to be be believed, that they intend • d to detroy the world, and reduce it unto the confuion of its firt Chaos.

This made the mot courageous to be enible of fear: Adamas himelf in this diorder, who by his profeion had learned to reign himelf unto the will of the upream powers, did wonder, and was amazed when the earth trembled under him. Often did he offer to peak, but the horrible claps of thunder put him out of all hopes to be heard; and when he would have looked upon thoe who were in his company, he found the ue of his ight as much hindred as his peech. Sometimes he wihed they were all in his houe, for a helter againt thoe torms that menaced them; but when he conidered, that uch blutering torms were able to throw down the tronget buildings, he condemned his firt wih, and found it unjut, becaue the mot ecret places were open to the knowledge of the gods, and there was no place that could helter a mortal from the anger of the Dieties.

Galathea and Roanira wihed a thouand times, that their journey were to begin again: but as great as their fears were, their loves had made o deep an impreion in their memories, that in lieu of having recoure unto the mercy of heaven, they never ceaed invoking Roilion and Lindamor as their Divinities. Belinde, thinking Diana was dead, was ready to wih for her own: giving her elf therefore over unto grief, he laid her elf all along upon the ground, leaning her head upon her two arms which lay acroe, not daring to lift up her eyes to heaven, becaue he thought it her mot mortal enemy; ah Diana (aid he to her elf) how dear does thy indicretion cot us? Thy fault has louly offended the gods, ince they take o great revenge. Immortal Dieties (continued he) whoe jutice does exceed your pity: if punihment be ineparable from the crime which this woman has committed, why did you not inflict only upon me? Was not a Victime able to appeae you? had not I blood enough to wah away the crime? O mot cruel! you have depied that blood which I would mot willingly have hed for the afety of this inner: and to hew how odious the diobedience of children is unto you, you have punihed her with o much everity, as renders your anger remarkable unto all poterity.

Upon this thought, Belinde fell into a flood of tears; and Adamas, who was already upon his knees to pacifie the anger of the gods by his prayers, cating his eye accidentally towards the place where he was; a flah of lightning, made o much light at the very ame time as he could plainly ee in what condition he was: eeing her • hen lie all along upon the ground, and thinking her killed by ome clap of thunder, uch a orrow eized upon him, as he became almot enlee. He went unto her as near as poibly he could, and as if he would make her hear, maugre the thunder, alas (age Belinde cried be out as loud as he could) what infortunate accident was it that eparated us? and why hould it be mortal unto you and not unto me? Belinde did hear the voice of the Druide, but he could not ditinguih his words: and Galathea, who was not far off, hearing confuedly the words: Belinde, and mortal, he thought her and all, but dead people: Roanira, who held her by the arm believed the ame, and their opinions paing unto Dorinde, it went from one to another till it came to Hylas, who knowing no reaon why he hould bear the punihment of anothers fault, he wi • hed himelf heartily in Carmagues, although it were upon the condition of never eeing Stella again or any of the Shepherdees, unto whom he had any inclination; But when they were all in the deepet apprehenion and belief of this danger, the lightning and thunder upon a udden ceaed, but not the darknes, for it remained as obcure as before: And in this dimal ilence, none durt begin to peak, for every one thinking themelves the only one alive, were afraid to incur the ame misfortune. In fine, the darknee began to diipate by little and little; the Sun gave light to the world again, flowers aumed their fragrancy, and trees gave hadows again.

Adamas was very glad to ee this hidious torm ceaed, and the Sun to break through all thee dusky clouds; but his joyes to ee Belinde alive, urpaed all other contentments: o as he went to embrace her and acquaint her with his fears. Yet Belinde, till thinking upon the los of Diana; and not thinking the fairnes of the day any comfort unto her, he told him that heaven would have obliged her, if out of pity it had uffered her to follow the Fate of her daughter: The life (aid he) which it has left me, and for which you eem o much joyed, is a mot intollerable burthen unto me, ince my Detiny will not let it be accompanied with thoe comforts which I expected from the virtue of Diana. Upon this, Belinde began to grieve again: and Roanira, Galathea, Silvia, and the ret coming unto her, every one endeavoured to give ome comfort unto her; but her grief was too great to be o eaily allayed, epecially by uch weak remedies as words. She therefore giving no intermiion into her tears and ighs, they all reolved to refer her cure unto time; and in the interim they oberved that the clouds wherewith the air was obcured for a time were all gathered together over the Fountain, from whence all this enchantment proceeded. This obcurity made it in • cceible and Belinde, who extreamly deired to give up her oul upon the cold and pale lips of her daughter, and eeing this obtacle was unto her deire. Wilt thou not. O pitilee heaven, give my misfortunes o weak a comfort, as to ee the marks of thy cruelty upon the body of my daughter? O ye Detinies, whoe rigour has ravihed her from me, are ye more deaf then trees and rocks? Hearken, I beeech you, vnto the prayers of a wronged mother, and render her unto me, for one hour only, who ought to be mine all her life: I do ask you nothing but what belongs unto me: The oul of Diana is indeed the gods, and they may take it when they pleae; but her body is abolutely mine, I would have it, and without extream in jutice you cannot deny it unto me. In aying this, he had her eyes till towards the Fountain. Adamas and the ret, after her example they looked upon the thick darknes which overhaded it, out of which one might often ee proceed a thick moak, as from ome great combution, and ometimes a blue flame, like unto that of Sulphure and Aqua vit •• fined.

After they had gazed a while upon thoe Prodigies, they perceived, that with this moak many of the clouds were diipated which gave ome good hopes unto the Druide: and Belinde, who thought now to have light enough to find either
her Daughter, or the Lions that had devoured her; he advanced as near the fountain as he could: But Adamas, pulling her back to look upon omething which he had oberved, they perceived that all the thick darknes which remained was rien a yeard from the ground: thinking therefore that it alo would vanih as the ret did they reolved to tay a while; and then upon a uddain they perceived in the midt of this obcurity, a cupid full of hining brightnes, who riing up by little and little, eated himelf upon the top of a Piramide of Porpherye. At the ight of this god, all fell down upon their knees: and when Adamas, Bellinde and the ret were in their height of admiration at this, o little expected novelty, they aw that he held in one of his hands a table of black marble wherin were written thee words in capitall Letters.

q.l: Be not Amazed nor murmure at thee miracles
But caue thee bodies to be caryed away
And tomorrow come, and conult with my Oracles.

div.p:
They no ooner knew the will of this god of love, but this god did throw himelf unto the fountain, and left no markes of himelf but immediatly all the clouds vanihed, no darknes remained, only o much as hindred from looking into the water. Bellinde, ravihed with joy at this permiion, he lot not a munite of time, but paing cloe by the Unicornes and Lyons, he went traight to the place where Atrea, and her Daughter lay upon the ground eeming as if they had given up their lat breath. Adamas after he had bidden Paris to go, and fetch the coach, that he might obey the commands of the god of love he followed Bellinde, and was all amazement to ee that thee four beats had no motion in them, and this gave him o much boldnes as to approach nearer them: but then, he found them abolutly imoveable indeed: And indeed, by the power of this great inchantor, whó firt placed them for guards of the fountain, they were all turned into four figures of marble, yet till retaining their hapes, and coulours? As oon as all the Company was advertied of it, and come near to be witnees of this miraculous metamorphois, they were all eied with incredible atonihment but yet not comparable to that which they reented, when in lieu of two corpes which they expected to find their, they perceived four, two of which were known to be Alexis, and Silvander. In the mean while Bellinde would needs embrace the body of Diana, and finding it without any pule or motion, he fell into uch extreames of greif as was able to move deaf death it elf: Phillis, he ran unto the body of Astrea, and Lycidas being gone to that of his brother, the Druid went unto the body of Silvander; They thought to have found them full of wounds, and torne in peices by the Lyons; but they did not find o much as one drope of blood upon them which made them think they were only tifled by the weight of thoe furious animals. Galathea who at that intant remembred thoe flames which Celadon had kindled in her oul, he could not chue but be o enible as to hed ome teares; Roanira and the ret, after her example, much greived to ee all things in uch a ad diorder: and certainly they had no ouls that would not be moved unto Compaion by uch ad pectacles, epecially by the lamentations of Bellinde; For that adly afflicted mother tearing her hair, and cratching her face: ah my Diana (aid he) art thou dead, all cold as ice? what? my dear child not one look? Ingratefull child, or rather ungratefull detines who have ravihed her from me, is it not jut my hopes hould have a more happy ucces? Such were the complaints of Bellinde whilt Lycidas whoe complaints were no les: who in the reentment of his orrowes, did taxe heaven with all the injuries he ever received: he called it a hundred times cruell, unjut and Barbarous; and till harping upon the rigour of Atrea, he eemed angry with Phillis, for the aitance which he gave unto that hepherdes. But this did not hinder Phillis from continuing all her endeavours to help her, or at the leat bidding her a lat adieu. Yet eeing all her teares were in vaine, and that Atrea could neither ee nor hear her: Oh Lycidas (cryed he) how cruelly are you revenged: in aying o, orrowes did o eie upon her, that he fell down to the ground,
and remained as in a wound upon the body of he • Companion. This did a little trouble Lycidas: for being poied betwixt love and amity, he knew not whether or no he hould leave his brother to go, and help Phillis; and doubtles if he had found any armes wherewith to have killed himelf, he had followed his firt apprehenions which prompted him to give that remedy unto all his mieryes: but having nothing wherewith he could hurt himelf, he was forced, whether he would or no to live, and be a witnes of the accidents that were to happen. He was till grieving that he could not die, when he heard Adamas command every one to make themelves ready to put the corpes of Atrea, Diana, Alexis, and Silvander into the coach: which was quickly done by the aitance of everall hepherds who came in to ee this pectacle: And as oon as they all came unto the Druides houe, Atrea, and Diana were laid in one Chamber; and Alexis, and Silvander in another. The news of this accident was quickly pred throughout all Forrets, and Amais was oon advertied of it; who having writ the news of it unto Roilion and Lindamor, he left Moutbrion, and came to her Palace of Ioures, where he intended to entertain Roanira, it being the mot pleaant Place for diverion.

div.head: The Sequell of the Hitory of TIRCIS, and LAONICE.
div.p: IN the mean time Tircis, ince the time he left the houe of Adamas, or to ay better, all the hepherds and hepherdees of Lignon, he had a fate that was very trange. For that ad hepherd, who as I told you before parted from Silvander, he no ooner aw himelf out of that hepherds preence, but lifting up his eyes to heaven: Now, great gods (aid he) I can ay that I am at liberty, and that I can without contraint pay unto my dearet Cleon, thoe tetimonies of my love which he may as tribute expect from me: my teares and my ighes will not have no beholders that can condemn them: but on the contrary, the winds will help me to lament the los of o fair a Mitree. As he aid this, he walked till on untill he came unto the bridge of Bouteres, there he tayed upon the midt of it: and from thence he beheld thoe places, where he had reided, and bad them for ever adieu. Upon this ubject, thee thoughts preented him with a thouand imaginations, whereof ome begot a orrow in his oul, that he was to leave a habitation, where o many lovely hepherdees did o weetly pas away there dayes: and other imaginations did comfort him with this, That ince the death of his deeret Cleon, he was obliged to renounce all the delights of life. This lat conideration being tronger then the firt, he continued on his voyage: and he was no ooner ome two or three hundred paces from the bridge, but as if ome ecret violence had tayed him, he topped; and once more turning his face towards the Town where Atrea, Diana, and Phillis dwelt: I do not wonder (aid he to himef) I hould be o loath to part from thoe groves, where the jutice of Silvander, and the eloquence of Phillis, did deliver me from the importunities of Laonice: that only were enough to oblige me never to be abent from them, if my griefs, which make me weariome to all the world, did not perwade me, that I hall do them a good office in taking from their preence, an afflicted peron, whoe converation is intolerable. But (continued he) I do not conider, that thinking not to eparate my elf from them, I ditance my elf farther from the place, where her acred dut does ret, who was once my very life. Ah Tircis, Tircis, the mot mierable of all thoe that ever loved. Since thou art obliged to take thy delights in that which is the punihment of others: Alas, were it not better for thee to go, and once more view thoe acred reliques, and hed uch a flood of teares upon the grave of Cleon, as drowning thy elf, and misfortunes in them, thou mayet obtain the glory to be incloed in the ame epulcher.

He had no ooner uttered thee words, but reolving with himelf to return unto the banks of Arar, he turned back again, and when he was upon the bridge of Bouberes. But why, aid he, hould I go and eek the body of Cleon, as long as I carry her oul with me? and why hould I go viit her ahes, as long as I retain thoe very flames in my heart, which he kindled towards me? No, no, (continued he) go on in thy firt deign: Go Tircis and loe thy elf in the horrours of ome dreadful Defart, where the air, the earth, olitude, and affrighting hades, will take away from me that life which is odious unto every one, and intollerable to my elf.

Upon this lat reolution, he looked towards Mount-brion, and loing all thoughts of returning to Lions, he prepared himelf for the woods and Forrets which cover the mountain of Ioures, and there eek ome contentment to his melancholly humour. He did not know that Laonice was already retired thither; for doubtles, had he had the leat thought of that, he would never have wended that way; but fancying to find that olitude and liberty of life which he deired, he reolved upon it: and without more dipute with himelf, he went to take up his lodging almot upon the very top of all the mountain. There eeing himelf omething nearer heaven, he conceived himelf omething nearer Cleon: and not imagining he could ever be diverted from that olitude which eemed already o weet and pleaing unto him, he reolved to pae away in quietnee that little time which he had to live. For the firt and econd dayes he did nothing ele but contemplate upon Cleon, who was freh in his memory; and having none to impart his orrows unto, the rocks and the trees became the confidents of his ecrets; unto the one he related every particular accident that befell him, ever ince he firt loved her; and upon the bark of the other he engraved the name of Cleon: but imagining, that without a grand crime he could not eparate that acred name; and the name of Tircis aunder, he engraved it alo. Sometimes loadned with ome fruits which he had gathered, he would go unto a little rivolet, which falling down into the plain, does water ome pleaant meadows, and afterwards empties it elf into Lignon; and there contemplating upon the cataracts, and great falls of this water: This (aid he to himelf) has a great reemblance unto my misfortune. Heaven would never let me take any ret, and if ever I hope for it, urely it will be when I am ready to enter into my grave, like to this little rivolet, which is never in quietnes until it has lot it elf in Lignon, which is its grave.

In uch kind of olitary entertainments he paed away the day; after which he went unto his ad habitation, and never tirred from thence, until the Sun had dried up the tears of Aurora: he had met with a cave not much unlike that of Laonices, which was not far off; probably thee caves were made by other hands then thoe of Nature; and the Druides, in the infancy of Religion not being much converant amongt men, made choice of thee retreats o near each other, as they might meet and confer about matters of Religion. It hapned, that the third day after Tircis came thither, that he began his cutomary exercie, and went out of his cave, as oon as the Sun had cleared the day; but not wending his coure towards that little rivolet, he paed away almot all the day in contemplating the beauties of that place, which he had choen for his lat reidence. On the one ide he viewed all the Forrets, and aw as far as the farthet part of the Sebuians: and on the other ide, his propect reached as far as that tately city, which the Rhone and the Arrar do wah with their crytal treams. Sometimes he admired the talnes of the trees, whoe leavy branches did hade him from the corching heat of the Sun: Otherwhiles looking upon the ground, in which his eyes took deep root, he was atonihed to ee it o clean and neat, and o even, that there was not o much as one hrub to hinder his walk. Being thus taken up in thee little ravihments, he took no notice that night urprized him: So as being a good ditance from his cave, and not well knowing the paages, the night alo growing dark, he could not hit the way unto his habitation. He laid him down therefore under the firt tree he came unto, where it was long before leep came upon him: yet at lat, after he had pent a good part of the
night in his ordinary contemplations, his wearied limbs received that pleaing refrehment.

Laonice on the other ide, who thought that help which the gods had promied unto her, long in coming, he wakened very early, to go according to her cutome, and talk of her orrows unto the flowers and the winds: yet he walked not long before he found ome engravements upon the barks of trees, which being frehly done, did eaily dicover themelves. She went preently unto them; and her thoughts being alwayes upon Tircis, as Tircis was upon Cleon, jealouie, which opened her eyes and judgement, made her know that there they were both together. This did extreamly atonih her; and not being able to imagine what Demon it hould be that did her this ill office, he was more and more amazed: and to compleat her amazement, he perceived Tircis himelf lying all along under an oak, ome ten or twelve paces from the place where he was. Amidt her joyes to ee him, he was eized with an extream fear to appear before him; becaue at that intant, all the contempts, lights, and rigours, of that Shepherd againt her, did come into her memory. Remembring then principally his lat words, as being the mot bitter that ever his tongue uttered againt her: This Shepherd (aid he to her elf) does meaure his hatred according to my love, and takes delight in eeing both extream: he thinks he has banihed me out of Forrets, and perhaps would drive me out of the world, if he hould ee me again: I will not therefore hew my elf unto him; but, aid he upon a udden, why hould the gods promie me a cure, unlee that Tircis be the remedy? Perhaps thoe kind Dieties have dipoed his pirit to pardon me, and his oul to receive me in lieu of her, for whoe love he rejected me. Upon this conideration, he went gently nearer him, and finding his eyes cloed: I with, O love (aid he) that his heart were not as fat aleep towards me: permit, O heavens, that the deires of this Shepherd may not any longer be contrary to my happinee, but that my oul may hare with him in that ret which his body now enjoyes: In aying o, he oberved, that the Sun made o much entrance through the leaves, as with his Rayes to kie him: whereat he appearing a little jealous, he kneeled down: Thoe kies, lovely Tircis (aid he) would be better imployed, if thou wouldt give them unto me in recompence of thoe mieries which thy cruelty hath made me uffer; Why, why? is my paion o full of crime, as it takes away from thee all deires of enjoying me? O good gods (continued he and ighed) can loving thee perfectly merit thy hatred? this is mot cruel and barbarous: Upon this, he bended her elf to kie him; but fearing to waken him, he aroe up without tealing that contentment: yet wondering at her want of courage; but why (aid he) hould I not have as much courage as love? Alas (continued he) what could this Shepherd do if he were awake, if he can make himelf thus feared when he is in the arms of death, or at leat of leep, which is the image of death? Upon thee lat words he topt, and Tircis began to groan; at which Laonice was o urprized, that he got further off, let he hould perceive her: yet hiding her elf behind a great tree, ome twelve or fifteen paces from him, he put forth her head as oftly as he could, and oberving that he till lept: Perhaps (aid he) he was not aleep when • poke and when he groaned it was out of compaion; but if o, why then hould he leep on? and why does he not give unto my paion better tetimonies of his? No, no, Laonice (aid he) never flatter thy elf with thee pleaing imaginations: Tircis does hate thee as much as he loves Cleon: he does abhor thy memory, as much as he does adore hers; and thou mayet well believe, that if he would die for the love of her, he will never live for any love of thee. Upon this he would have gone away, but cating her eye once more upon Tircis, he aw him awake, tretching out his arms, and rubbing his eyes: This made her lurk cloe behind the tree, & make no noie; and by Fortune, the Shepherd riing up, and eeing the Sun a good hight, he went the other way, thinking upon nothing ele, but how to find out his cave.

p.U:
eeing him go away, he felt no lee pain then if her heart had been pulling out; and never thinking what he did, nor loing the ight of this Shepherd, he followed him from tree to tree, until he found what he ought for; and
it was not long firt: for he found the little Rivolet, unto which he paying his tribute of a few teares, he preently after went traight to his cave. As oon as he came their he entred in: and as oon as Laonice lot the ight of him, he doubled her pace, and without any feares of being een, he got as near the mouth of it as he could, and there lending a mot litning ear to hear what the deignes of Tircis might be, he heard him ay; Dear habitation which may cover me from the injuries of heaven, as thou dot from the importunities of Laonice; Pardon me, for having lot my way in the confuion of my thoughts, I abented my elf from thee a whole night. Into what a lamentable dump did thee words trike Laonice: he was even ready to run out of her wits, and now eeing all her weet hopes blated, he was even ready to die. Yet hearing Tircis ay omething ele, he wihed for life only to hear him, and therefore heard him proceed thus: But dear cave, if thou wilt make me the mot happy man that ever was, I beeech thee let me live no longer; to kill another would be Barbarime, but to kill Tircis, charity. If becaue thou knowet not the dimall uccees of my diaterous life thou beet ignorant of the caue I have to wih for death; Know, dear Cell. That I did love Cleon: That her death did eperate me from her, and that my death is the only was to reunite us: upon this he was ilent, and becaue he continued o long, Laonice thought that his teares had drownded his peech, or that perhaps he was kiing the rock in which he was hut: Needing therefore to hear no more: he retired her elf the mot adly afflicted woman in the world, only he received a little poor conolation when he conidered that ince he intended to inhabite no where ele but there, he might often have the pleaure of eeing, and hearing him. So leaving him in his Cell, he returned to her own, out of which he durt not tir all the day. Tircis did not o; for after he had ighed a while in his little Grotto he went out; but durt not go far, leat he hould loe himelf as he did the day before: he ate him down under a hady tree: and there he pulled out of his pocket, all the favours, and Letters which formerly he had received from Cleon: and reading then one after another, all the paages of his love came o freh into his memory, as at that intant he fancied her to be yet alive: but this pleaing imagination lating no longer then the time he imployed in reading them, he had no ooner ended, but his orrowes began again. Thus having kied them, and lapped all thoe dear Letters in a bag which he called his treaury, he roe up, and walked up and down till night invited him unto his Cave.

div.p:
Laonice did not pend the day o: for he durt not tir out of hers, leat if Tircis hould, it would make him quit his habitation for ever; which he had choen for the tranquility of his lat dayes: yet not being able to leave thinking upon him, he never let contriving out ome way or other which might in ome meaure allay that irreconcilable hatred which was in the oul of this hepherd towards her. Amongt all her thoughts which mot touched her to the quick, the Oracle which he had received, held the prime place: o as continually thinking upon it; But if the gods (aid he) have promied a kind remedy unto my paion, is it not mot jut I hould hope well in their goodnes: and if I may hope why may I not think upon uch meanes as may obtain it; a ghot (did thy tell me) mut be the remedy unto my affliction; but what ghot can this be? It cannot be the ghot of Tircis. For if Tircis were only a ghot, my miery in lieu of being les, would be extream; I value his life at uch a rate of love, as if any fatal accident hould ravih it away, I hould conpire againt my own; It cannot therefore be Cleons: for the dead do either know the actions of this life, or ele they do not know them: if they do know them, then it is impoible but the oul of that fair one mut rejoyce to ee Tircis continue his love, and fidelity unto her. So as it is in vain to expect any aitance from her, ince it concernes her interet rather to prejudice then to help me. If the dead do not know what we of this life do, why hould I look for any help from a place where oblivion raignes with o much Empire? No no Laonice, thy mieryes mut be eternall: and thou mayet think that if the gods had any mind to put a period unto them, they would have inpired thee with ome invention more eay. But (aid he) is it not a beginning of happines, that Tircis is brought o near me? Has not the world other deerts?
Forrets it elf has other woods vvhere this hepherd might have found his olitude, if ome kind Demon had not brought him hither to cae thee:

Upon this thought he opened the table book where we had written down the Oracle that concerned her: and having read it over everall times; The gods (aid he) do aure that if Laonice be firm in her affection, the heavens will end a remedy unto her paion; Does this remedy depend upon the affection of Laonice, or upon Laonice her elf, or upon the ghot? or are not Laonice, and the ghot one and the ame thing? Upon this he topt; and falling into a mot profound tudy, as if he had ome deep deign in her head: come what will on • (aid he upon a uddain) I will venture an undoeing, it is credible the gods would never have put it into my mind unles they did intend it hould take effect. She pent all the ret of the day upon this thought, and as oon as night came, he went out of her Cell, unto that of Tircis. All the way he went he was ravelled with a thouand irreolutions, and her feares not to bring her enterprie to pas, made find her almot an impoibility in thoe things that were mot eaie. Sometimes he conceited that to get the love of Tircis by fallacies was the way not to keep it long; otherwhiles he perwaded her elf that he would know her voice, or that when the Moon hined, it would dicover that ecret which he would not trut unto any thing but darknes. But when he remembred, that in love all ubtilties even the fits are allowed, and began to think he could hardly know her voice, alo that the Moon might perhaps not hine into his Cell, he took a little courage, and kept to her firt reolution. Her greatet fear was to meet him out of his cave: for no other place but it, could be favorable unto her deign; And therefore as he went thither he looked about her very circumpectly on all ides to ee whither he could py him, and eeing nothing of him, he came in the midt of the night unto the ame place where he had lodged him a little before: at the firt, tanding till at the mouth of the cave, he litned with her ear to hear whether or no, he was a leep; with he was no ooner aured off, but recommending her elf unto love, and to the god of leep and dreames, he began to name Tircis, three times: at that name, the hepherd half wakned, and fetching a deep igh he turned towards Laonice, who began to hope well, in her deign; Know Tircis (continued he in the ame tone) that I do come from the gods to command thee, that thou ceae thy unjut hatred againt the beauty of Laonice: her love ought to be the ole object of all thy deires upon paine to incur the wrath, and anger of that diety who commands it: and that thou mayet more clearly know, that this is the will of the upream powers, be aured that to morrow thou halt find this hepherdes near unto this place o dipoed to pardon all thy rigours, as thou oughtet to repent of them. Faile not therefore to comply with her: never fear offending Cleon, ince it is he her elf who brings this command unto thee. Upon this Laonice retired, and Tircis who at the name of Cleon began to open his eyes, he had o much time only as to ee her vanih: For at that intant the Moon hined o clear into his Cell, that the hepherd not being able to endure the light, was contrained to turn the other way. He had confuedly heard what Laonice aid, and retained the ence in his memory: but as if he were not well wakned, he fell a leep again after he had ighingly pronounced the name of Cleon twice. Which Laonice ditinctly heard for he had no ooner retired her elf out of the Cell, but he litned with her ear at the mouth of the Cave to hear what Tircis aid; Being certain then that he was heard he retired her elf to her own Cell, and reted her elf as well as he could untill it was day.

Tircis on the other ide he got up very early: and having nothing more preent in his thoughts then the love he preerved for the ahes of Cleon, it was not long before he fell to mue upon the paage in the night time; at the firt, he fancied it only a dream: But then remembring what he had heard, he made not doubt but that was a Viion. Alo never thinking upon any uch fallacy as was put upon him; but infallibly beleiving that it was the ghot of Cleon which he aw. But dearet ghot (aid he with teares in his eyes) is it poible thou houldt be o oon weary of my ighes and teares? is that inviolable paion I have entertained
with uch holy purity, become o far troubleome as to dipleae and anger thee? If in that felicity which thou dot enjoy; and whereof this great plendour which waits upon thee even in the horrours of night, is a mot undeniable proof unto me: If, I ay in that happy etate it does grieve thee to ee that I can give but poor and weak tetimonies of my love: Conider, I beeech thee, dearet Ghot, that in this the effects are far different from their caue; and thee poor tetimonies of my affection, do perih almot in their conceptions, yet my love which produceth them, will lat to all eternity.

Upon this he was ilent for a while, and afterwards beginning again: But Cleon (continued he) who is pleaed to put thee upon things the mot difficult, does command thee to love Laonice, knowing well thou mightet as well attempt an impoibility: If thou dot diobey her, though it be the firt fault thou didt ever commit againt her, it is a crime no lee punihable, then if it were committed againt a Diety. And if thou dot obey her, who will dipence with thee for all the vowes and oathes which thou hat o often worn, never to have any inclination unto any but only her? Doubtles he her elf (aid he) for as he had o much power to make me wear them, o has he the power to make me break them, after uch an abolute command. Ah dearet Cleon (aid he and reprehended himelf) how intollerable is this lat rigour which thou dot inflict upon me? It were far more jut to command me to die, then to live with Laonice.

Upon this, he went out of his cave, not to go and eek for this Shepherdee, but only to divert himelf, and to ee which way he hould dipoe of himelf to do as he thought Cleon had commanded him. But as it was impoible, that now Laonice hould have no room in his thoughts there was not one tetimony of love which ever he had given him, but it came into his remembrance. And this wrought more effect upon his oul, when he conidered that he continued her love, notwithtanding all his hatred and didain. After this, he being very fair, the remembrance of the features in her face eemed to inpire him with pity; and as often as he thought upon thoe cruelties wherewith he requited her affection, he was moved unto a kind of repentance: the only thing which did mot of all retain his anger, was the memory of that revenge which he took upon Silvander and Phillis, thinking uch premeditated wickednes, and carryed with o much art, did argue a trayterous and malitious pirit. But as if he would not condemn her without a hearing: yet (aid he to himelf) revenge is weet in what mind oever it be; and how is it poible a weak woman hould defend her elf againt it, ince the greatet perons which our Hitories mention, found more ado to reit the motions of this paion, then to conquer Kingdomes? It were unreasonable to think that Laonice had not her imperfections, as well as other mortals; and perhaps this was it which made Hylas ay lately unto me, that were he at leaure, he would make me confes that Shepherdes was not o much to blame as I imagined: Doubtles he would have told me, that her reentment was advantageous to me, and that I was obliged to her, ince he had made it appear, that in loing me, he had lot the only thing that could force her to commit a treaon. He would have repreented unto me, that he had imitated thoe deperate perons, who not knowing how to regain that which death or Fortune had taken from them, they would be revenged upon the gods, and break down thoe Statues which before they had erected unto their honour.

With uch, or uch like dicoure as this, Tircis entertained himelf: Sometimes condemning the ubtilties of Laonice, and otherwhiles excuing them; and ometimes condemning himelf for being the principal Authour of the evil which he had done; but as oon as ever Cleon came into his thoughts, the memory of her tranported him, and kept him from thinking upon any thing ele a long time after. In this Combate of thoughts he paed away almot all the day, and tirred not from his cave, but only to drink at the little rivolet, which relieved him in that neceity. But Laonice, eeing the day almot gone before he heard any news of Tircis, he began to fear that her devie was dicovered: yet he waited till at the entrance into the wood, where the trees gave a more delectable hade then in any other place; and uch was her impatience, that at every blat which
moved the trees, he looked about, imagining it to be Tircis. At lat, having thus pent the day in uch inquietudes as are uual unto one that loves perfectly, he reolved to counterfeit a Ghot the econd time, with an oath never to become her elf again, in cae her plot took no better succes then it had before. Then (aid he to her elf) will I intent this Barbarian eternally. I will never let him take a minutes ret: I will kindle a flame at the fire of my love, which a thouand times wore then that of the Furies, hall corch him without intermiion, and without conforming him. In this deign, he prepared her elf to go into the place where Tircis was, about the ame time of night he did before; but fearing the Shepherd hould be awake, in hopes to ee Cleon the econd time, he thought it better to go thither a little before day. So he paed away mot part of the night under thoe trees, and when he thought it time, he went to execute what he had propoed.
