As oon as he came to the caves mouth, he litned with her ear as he did before, and when he was aured that Tircis was aleep, he entered in with as little noie as poibly he could make: the firt thing he did was to cal him by his name, knowing very well, that naturally every one has a greater dipoition to hearken unto his own name, then to any other word; and indeed, the Shepherd upon the intant of naming him, did give ome tetimonies that he was not fat aleep: and therefore Laonice aid unto him: Tircis, thy diobedience hath offended the gods and Cleon, and the rigour of Laonice unto thee hall be the punihment of thy crime; unlee thou wouldet have her pirit become inexorable unto thee, prepare thy elf to repair that fault this day, which thou didt commit yeterday: and once again conider, that it is Cleon which commands it, and thou mut never expect any favour from her, if thou dot not obey me.

Upon this, he went out again; and hearkning at the door, he heard Tircis fetch a deep igh, and afterwards raiing his voice: Alas, my dearet Cleon (aid he) why dot thou o oon fly out of the preence of him, who once was half thy life? or why dot thou now impoe that upon me, which thou didt abhor? Good gods! Is it poible there hould be any alteration? Can you be guilty of that common fault in men? Then he held his peace, and Laonice, who thought he had now aid enough, he was now ready to return, but upon a udden he heard him ay; Well Cleon (aid he) I will follow thy councel, and obey thy commands; and ince the gods have inpired thee with ome pity upon Laonice, it is not jut I hould be lee enible of her mieries then thou art. In aying o, he began again to igh, and the Shepherdes being all joy to hear it, he would not tay to hear any more; but going ome two or three hundred paces off, he reolved to give him all opportunities, to render reall obedience unto the faigned command which he had impoed upon him.

In the mean time, Tircis could not leep any more, but thinking upon the qualities of Laonices body and mind, and now having no more averion to make him abominate all he did, he began to think that the time he hould pae away with her, would be omething more pleaing unto him then that which he hould pend in the olitude which he had choen. In order hereunto, he got up as oon as day dawned; and not being able to imagine where he hould meet with this Shepherdes: but why hould I trouble my elf about it? (aid he upon a udden) the ame gods who commanded me to love her, will doubtlee give me the opportunity to ee her.

Upon this he went out, and not knowing which way to wend his coure, he followed the firt path his foot fell into. Laonice, who was within ken, was not long before he aw him appear; and going into his path, he at down, and when he was within hearing the began to ing. At this voice Tircis tood amazed; and admiring the providence of the gods, in the conduct of this affection, he tole from tree to tree, till he came jut unto the place where he was, as he had ended her ong: He preently fell down upon his knees; and the Shepherdes eeming to be extreamly afraid, he got up, and would have fled away: But Tircis catching hold of her: Fair Laonice (aid he) as Cleon was formerly the caue of that little eteem which I did et upon your beauty: o he is now the caue of
that love which I come to offer unto you, and doubly happy hall I be, if I can but find a favourable reception.

p.U: eeming till to wonder at all this; cruel man (anwered he) are you not yet weary with tormenting me? how came you hither to perecute me, in a place which I had choen as a remedy againt your cruelty? If you be the ame Tircis who has o often and o cruelly tortured me, what moves you to come now and flatter me with fair promies of happinee, which you have o often put me out of all hopes ere to obtain? And if you be but only his Ghot, then tell me, what makes thee forake the oul of that Cleon, whoe ahes you have o long Idoliz'd? I am really the ame Tircis, replied the Shepherd, who not being able to ceae loving that fair one, would rather have died then changed; but ince I have the command of Cleon for it, no other upon earth but only Laonice, is to have the glory of poeing me. In aying o, he offered to take her hand, and the Shepherdes tepping back, as not daring to touch him: Stay Tircis (aid he unto him) I am yet in a doubt, whether what I ee be real, or only an illuion; either let me recollect my pirits, or you will affright me to death. Ah Laonice, replied Tircis, could we as eaily believe miracles as the gods can do them, you would oon ceae your wonder. Indeed (aid Laonice and interrupted him) to ee Tircis upon his knees before Laonice, and to hear him talk of any love to her, are two no mall miracles; and yet (aid Tircis) it is not more certain that I live, then it is that I love you. I do equally make a doubt of both (anwered Laonice) and that which troubles me, is to know what proofs I ought to ask of what you ay. Proofs mot infallible (replied the Shepherd) which is my hearty repentance of the rigours which formerly I have returned you for the good will you had unto me, and an inviolable vow never to be any ones but yours: Upon this, he uddenly took her hand, and kied it: and Laonice miling, now (aid he) I know that you have a body and are no illuion; but I will think, that certainly there is ome deluion in this, unles you further acquaint me with your intention: My intention (anwered the Shepherd) is utable to my words, and if the affection which I offer unto you, do merit a kind of reception which I deire, then I do conjure you, for my ake, to quit thee dearts, which are places more proper for Bears and Tigers, then uch beauties as yours: and let us both go together unto Mountverdune, where you hall receive from me the lat tetimony of my incere affection.

div.p: Laonice, who asked no more, yet was at firt omething hie in the matter, did ac lat conent unto the deires of Tircis: As they went on the way, Tircis asked by what Fate it was, that they both met o hapyily in that Forret, and Laonice hewed unto him the Oracle which he had received. Afterwards Tircis told her with abundance of innoceney, all the paages of the Ghot which appeared unto him: at which Laonice could not chue but mile, to ee what happy ucces her artifice had effected, which the Shepherd attributing unto her joyes to poes him, he never had the leat upition of her cunning: At lat being come unto a Temple, Tircis deired Laonice to give her conent, that a Druide might marry them; which he conenting unto, the marriage was preently after olemnized: and then they went down together into the plain, to tell the news of their unlookt for marriage unto the Shepherds and Shepherdees of their acquaintance.

Thee accidents hapned unto Tircis, whilt the ret of the Shepherdees of Lignon were in extream diorder, by reaon of the interet which every one had in the perons of Celadon, Atrea, Diana, and Silvander; but above all, Licidas eemed mot worthy of compaion, by reaon of that fury which the death of Alexis had caued in him: And indeed, all the way as they went, Adamas did not interpoe one word unto the complaints of that Shepherd, for he found them all o jut, as he could not condemn him for it. But as oon as all the company was come unto his houe, and Atrea, Diana, Celadon, and Silvander were laid in thoe chambers which the Druide had appointed for them: Belinde and Phillis, who till kept the one with Diana, and the other with Atrea, they oberved that by little and little they opened their eyes, and by ome ighs which they ent forth
eemed to be yet in life. Phillis ran as fat as hee could to acquaint Adamas; who very glad of this newes, went immediately unto Celadon, to ee whether any ignes of life were in her: But hee found both him and Silvander alo, in the ame tate they were at the Fountain: But though hee aw no hopes of recovery, yet hee and Lycidas undreed Celadon, whilt Thamiris and Hylas got Silvander into bed. And when they were both in bed, the Druid laid his hand to the heart of Alexis, and found that till there remained ome heat. And indeed, hee was only in a wound, but uch a wound as by force of the Inchantment was much longer and more violent then ordinary. This did o over-joy him, that he went immediately unto his Cloet for uch remedies as he thought more proper to fetch life again; and indeed they had uch good operation, as in lee then a quarter of an hour, they both revived out of that Lethargy into which they were fallen. Lycidas no ooner aw his brother alive, but repenting himelf of all his furious impieties which hee had uttered, hee kneeled down at the beds feet, and lifting up his eyes: Oh yee great Gods (aid hee) who by a great Providence unknown unto us, do govern all things, I render unto you mot hearty thanks, for the favour you have done me in, in retoring Celadon. Oh yee puiant Divinities, againt whom my Fury did belch out Blaphemies: I do confee the horridnee of my Crime, and beg your Pardon. Upon this hee roe up; all joyed to ee Celadon not dead.

On the other ide, the hepherd no ooner opened his eyes, but hee remembred the danger unto which hee had expoed himelf: and thinking to finde himelf lying upon the ground full of wounds and all bloudy, hee was amazed when hee aw himelf in a delicate bed; where there was not Lions nor Unicornes, but in lieu of them, Adamas and his brethren tanding by him. The accident which hapned unto him in Galatheas Chamber after they had taken him out of the water, ame preently into his mind: yet not being able to imagine how he came to be recued from the clawes of the Lions, which hee thought would have torn him in a thouand pieces, he cat his languihing eyes upon the Druid, and putting one arme out of bed, hee took his hand and poke not a word, as doubting whether the objects hee had een were reall or only imaginary: And therefore the Druid leaning over the bed, Celadon (aid hee unto him, and kied his cheek) the Gods have been kinde unto us, and prevented the ill deignes which you had againt your elfe: you are till alive, my Son, maugre all your attempts to dye; and ince there is a kinde of trange Fatality which will not let us loe you o oon, I do hope it will prove both unto your contentment and minde: Father, (anwered Celadon then in a weak and languihing tone) I am afraid, that the ame ubject from whence you draw ome hopes of contentment, will caue in mee a more violent depair then ever yet I reented: For if this part of life which remaines to mee mut be imployed to mourne for the death of Atrea, whom I aw with mee in the ame danger, and who (doubtlee) has received from the Lions that injury which they refued mee: believe it Father, every minute that I live will be a torture to mee ten thouand times wore then death. Upon this Lycidas took him about the neck, and embracing him with a million of carrees; No no, dear Brother (aid hee unto him) Atrea is as well as you are, I heard Phillis tell the Druid as much. Oh good God (cryed out Celadon) in this you have hewed your Jutice: But Father (aid hee to Adamas) may I believe what Lycidas aies? You may (anwered the Druid) for all this is but an effect of the great enchantment; and the Lions and Unicornes are turned into tatues of Marble, till keeping their form and colour: Moreover, the ame things that have hapned unto you, are hapned unto Atrea, Diana, and Silvander. How? (aid Celadon) is not Silvander dead? No (aid the Druid). In aying o, hee drew the curtain a little, and let him ee that hepherd whom Thamiris and Hylas were comforting as well as they could: For not knowing the true caue which induced him to look for a death, they thought that his orrowes, to live o ignorant of himelf, did make him deire to die: and therefore they ued all the bet arguments they could to perwade with him: They told him that his misfortune of being ignorant of himelf, ought not to trouble him, ince
the door of heaven was open unto all well qualified men alike; That his merits had gotten him the effectionate hearts of o many hepherds, as would at all times upply his neceities, and make him live as well as themelves. In fine, they gave him the bet language and comfort they could; but not touching the right tring, nor hitting right upon his maladie, their muick did but jarre in his ears, & did not work upon his humour, nor could they get any anwers from him, but uch as made them think that his orrowes being o extreame, they did proceed from ome caue unknown to them. They left him therefore in this condition: For the Druid, at the intance of Celadon, who deired no other witnees but Lycidas, did draw them out of the room. As oon as they were gone, Silvander went into Celadons bed; who having received him, Shepherd (aid he unto him) I have no reaon to wih you well. Why? (aid Celadon) Becaue (anwered Silvander) you did divert mee from my deigne of precipitating my elfe; for had it not been better for you to have been a witnee of my death, then of the continuation of my mieries? But ee now, unto what a ad condition I am reduced, ince I can no longer avoid the preence of Paris and Diana: the envie unto one, and the change of the other, will be double death unto mee. I cannot repent of what I did (aid Celadon) for it is my glory to have contributed any thing unto the preervation of uch a hepherd as you are; but I am very orry that you have made your elf a companion of my Fortune, ince you are the only caue of my not dying in this adventure: and the Gods would not have let mee live, but onely to punih mee for uffering you to hazzard your life in uch an occaion wherein no other Lover but my elf ought to have perihed. That is a ecret (aid Silvander) known onely to Tautates: But Celadon, to let thee deep mieries alone, pray tell mee if you know any thing of Diana? I had not o much leaure (anwered Celadon) as to enquire, but I heard that Atrea was till alive: yet Lycidas perhaps can atisfie you. Upon this hee called him; and Lycidas itting down at the beds feet, related what Phillis told unto the Druid: which joyed Silvander a little; but upon a udden, fetching a deep igh, Alas, alas replied hee, Paris is doubtlee now with her wimming in carrees of Love. No, anwered Lycidas, Paris is very buie in giving the entertainments of the houe; and though the accident which hapned unto Diana did not a little trouble him, yet hee was contrained to that civility by the command of Adamas, who would needs have him entertaine Galathea, Roanira, Daphnide, Medonthe, and other Nymphes which came from Marcelles. Celadon upon this asked his brother, how long it was ince they came? to whom Lycidas anwered, that they came in the morning, and were all trimmed in the habit of heperdees, purpoely to pae away the time more pleaantly. At this, Silvander began to igh; but Lycidas even ravihed with joy to ee his brother, hee could not chue but laugh. Celadon asked him the caue of his laughing. I laugh, anwered Lycidas, to ee Silvander jealous, and to ee how that paion does produce the ame effects in him, which it did in mee when hee made it his port to vexe mee in that angry mood: and certainly to heare him talk, would make one believe that Diana has had two or three children by Paris, when God knowes, that not o much as a promie of marriage has paed between them. Silvander, who thought that Lycidas only mocked, hee changed neither face nor humour; but, on the contrary, eemed more troubled then before.

Alas hepherd, aid hee unto him, have you no more compaion ten to rub upon my oret wound? What great offence have I committed againt you, that can deerve o cruel a revenge? I protet, replied Lycidas, I have no thoughts of any revenge upon you: But if you could as easily hinder Paris from marrying Diana, as it is certain they are not yet married, you would quickly put an end to all your mieries. Silvander then eeming to be extreamly glad of the newes; The Gods (aid hee) are my Friends: For had I dyed, I had diobeyed Diana, who did abolutely forbid mee dying, untill I hear her marriage was conummated. But, aid Lycidas, what made you believe hee was married? I had no other aurance of it (anwered Silvander) but the report of a boy which looks to my
Flock, and told mee of it with o much innocent implicity, as I could not upect the truth of it. The ame encounter is hapned unto you, aid Celadon, that happens unto many others, when reports do pae through many mouthes, for every one addes a little, and the lat will weare they aw that which neither is, nor ever was. Mot true (anwered Silvander); for this young boy wore unto mee, that hee who erves Lycidas did aure him, that hee aw all the Ceremonies, & danced after the muick of the Ho-boyes, which ounded all over the Plaines: But ince this Fatal Ceremonie is not yet pat, Good Gods (aid hee, and looked up to heaven) for pities ake prevent it, or ele let my death preceed it.

Silvander had no ooner uttered thee few words, but hee looked upon Celadon, Shepherd (aid hee unto him) why hould wee thus lugg away the time in bed? there is nothing that hinders us from riing. True, aid Celadon; Though Adamas will not let us tirre from hence, yet wee may walk up and down the Room. Upon this, Silvander took his cloaths, and whilt Celadon was eeking for his, hee had almot dret himelfe: But neither Celadon nor Lycidas could finde his cloaths; for the Druid, who as hee went out, had carried away the cloaths of Alexis, hee had forgot to put Celadons in lieu of them: o, as being forced to keep his bed, Silvander and Lycidas ate down by him: And falling into dicoure concerning the Inchantment, Lycidas related unto them all that hee had een.

In the mean time, Adamas went to ee Atrea, and that hepherdee no ooner aw him near her bed, but looking upon him with uch: an eye as plainly tetified the atonihment wherein hee was; Father, aid hee unto him, how comes it to pae you hould now ee mee in this bed, and nor rather in my coffin? and by what misfortune am I evered from Alexis? To this, anwered the Druid, I cannot anwer; for I know nothing of the accidents: But if the Gods hould never let you ee her again, I hould think them jut in it, ince you have already treated her with o much didain, as they may think they are kinde unto you in it. But Father, replied the hepherdee, would you have mee pardon the offence which I have received from her diguie? You have told mee o much of her innocence, that I do conent to love him no lee then formerly I did: and ince they know that I am not now angry againt her, nor can live without her, why do they not retore her unto mee?

When I told you of her innocence, replied the Druid, I told you but what I thought obliged mee not to conceale, knowing her dicretion o well; and you have not known ince, that I aid nothing but truth. Since the Unicornes were een by you, and it is a mot infallible truth, that thoe Animals never come near a woman who is in the leat blemihed in her Chatity. But the greater the innocency of Alexis is, the greater is your crime; and therefore I am afraid, that the Gods do intend to punih you for it, and will never uffer you to enjoy a peron whom you have without any reaon twice banihed from your preence. I perceive Father, aid Atrea, faintly, that Alexis is dead, and that the Gods are jut in punihing mee o. But they will not be jut, if they let mee live, or at leat will not uffer mee, after I have been punihed for the unjut anger I conceived againt Celadon, to be recompenced for the Love which I preerved for him in the midt of our greatet misfortunes. In aying o, her eyes guhed out with Tears: And Adamas having compaion upon her, Daughter, aid hee do not thus immoderately afflict your elf, until you hear more particulars of the loe of Alexis: my cares of bringing you hither, were a caue of my not knowing what was hapned unto her: but if you will promie to tay untill I returne with patience, I will promie to bring you a faithfull relation. Father, anwered Atrea, though the condition wherein I aw her, makes mee more certain of her death, yet ince you command it, I will tay till you return, that you may afterwards think my deign of following her the more jut: But, Father, (continued hee) even for pities ake, do not latter mee, in thinking to comfort mee, you will make mee the more deperate. Adamas did promie to do whatoever hee deired, and eeing Bellinde in talk with Diana, hee would
not interrupt them, but went traight into Celadons chamber, where finding Silvander out of bed, and his countenance not o ad as before, hee eemed to rejoyce much at it. Afterwards going unto Celadon; How comes it to pae (aid hee unto him) that you are not up as well as Silvander? Is not your courag • as good, or are you not o well as hee? Lycidas prevented his brother in his anwer; Father (aid hee) neither of thoe are the reaon of it, but becaue I cannot finde his cloaths. Then Adamas remembring that hee had locked them up, hee went and brought thoe that hee was wont to wear before his diguiement; and giving them unto him, Here on, aid hee unto him, may you be happy in that habit, and enjoy her whom you love bet. Celadon did take them with a thouand thanks for his good wihes, and as oon as hee began to cat his eies upon them, o many thoughts came into his minde, that hee could not chue but fetch a deep igh: which the Druid oberving, How now Celadon (aid hee)? had you rather continue in your diguie, then aume this habit? I cannot tell Father, (anwered the hepherd faintly) which of the two make me the more happy: For under the habit of Alexis, Atrea commanded mee to die, and under that of Celadon hee banihed mee her preence. Adamas, who aw that the memory of thee things did trouble him, and having no minde to talk any more of them, but withdrawing a little, to give him the more time to dree him, Celadon (aid hee) do not dipute upon the choie any longer, but weare this that I have brought unto you; and if you will referre all the ret unto mee, I will finde out a way to make you happy. Upon this, Celadon dreed himelf; and when hee was ready, Adamas embraced him: Then Lycidas did the ame with o many tears and expreions of Love, as it was eaie to judge, that the affection which tyed them together, proceeded from ome tronger caues than conanguinity. Silvander was extreamly joyed to ee it; and as handome as hee had appeared under the diguie of a Druides daughter, hee appeared much handomer in the habit of a hepherd.

Adamas took him by the hand, and carrying him out of the chamber, Sonne (aid hee unto him) you mut know, that Atrea does infinitely deire to know what is become of you, and becaue uch welcom newes will be bet from your own mouth, I think it mot fit you hould carry it your elfe. At this Celadon changed colour: But Father (aid hee) hee has commanded mee to die, and though I did endeavour to obey her, yet it is to be feared hee will not take my endeavour for good payment. Never let that trouble you, (replied the Druid) I have o well prepared her minde in your abence, as hee is reolved never to give you any more caue of dicontent. If you do love her, you mut not refue to ee her; for all the hopes hee has, is now only that you are alive. In aying o, hee entreated Silvander and Lycidas to accompany them unto her chamber: Celadon did tremble at every tep, till hee came to the beds ide of that hepherdee, and then began to igh, and was not able to peak one word. Atrea did mildly cat her eyes upon the Druid, and eeing him o ilent, did think at firt that hee brought her bad newes: Ah Father (aid hee) your ilence does peak my ill fortune. Tell mee truly, is Alexis dead? Then Adamas looking upon her with a eeming ad eye, Daughter (aid hee) I hould never be the meenger of uch ad newes, but that I am forced unto it. Upon this, Atrea began to tremble: Good Father (aid hee) hold mee no longer in upence, peak plainly, and relate unto mee all the accidents that have hapned unto Alexis: as hee aid o, hee eemed to be o adly afflicted, as if hee had not a minute to live. Good Atrea (aid Adamas) why hould I relate the uccee of a thing that will but dipleae and trouble you? You your elf knowes more concerning Alexis then I do: you aw her in combare with the Lions: and by that may judge what is become of her? But good Father (anwered Atrea) did the Lions turn their fury only againt her? Could not I as well have atisfied their rage and hunger? Oh mot cruel Fate! (continued hee with eyes flowing in teares: Mierable Atrea! Poor unfortunate Alexis, art thou dead, and my rigour the caue of it? Then hee began to tear her hair, but the Druid held her hand: Dear Daughter (aid hee) firt hear mee with patience what I hall ay,
and afterwards execute upon your elf all the violences that dipair can prompt you unto. Upon this Atrea was ilent, and Adamas continued; ince you will not have any thing concealed from you (aid he unto her) let me tell you Daughter that it is true, Alexis is not alive, and to the end you may believe, that at the lat munite of life nothing was more dear unto her then the memory of Atrea, I will retore unto you a pledge which he hath left, and which belongs only unto you. Atrea thought that Adamas would have retored unto her, the knot, the ringe, and the Picture which Celadon had of hers; and preparing her elf to live o long as to receive thoe tetimonies of her dear hepherds love and fidelity, he held her hand out unto the Druide: come Father (aid he) give me that which Alexis has kept better then I have deerved.

Upon this, Adamas drawing the cartaine, and taking Celadon by the hand: heere, fair Atrea (aid he) heere is Celadon whom Alexis commandes you to receive, and whoe life ought to be the dearer unto you, becaue it is preerved only for your glory, and contentment: as oon as Atrea cat her eyes upon him, and knew him, he was o extreamly urpried, and in uch a confuion of thoughts as he tood for a while as inmoveable as any tatue: But Celadon on the contrary, kneeling down upon the ground, and taking her hand, My fairet Atrea, aid he unto her, if my extream love be worthy of any favour, I do mot humbly beeech you to pardon all the faults that ever I committed againt your beauty: If the mieryes which I have uffered be not enough to atisfie you, oh fairet, let your goodness upply the fault: and to retore me, if not unto the ame place which once I had in your heart, yet at the leat unto o much leave as to render you the ame ervices, which formed eemerly acceptable unto you.

The hepherd uttered thee words in uch a paionate manner that Atrea could not chue but be much moved at them, laying aide them, all termes of modety, and thinking upon nothing but love, he embraced him, and though her wonder, & her teares did much interrupt her peech, yet he through exceive fulnes of, joy forced out thee words: My dearet Celadon, I do not only retore you unto that Room which once you had in my heart, but I do give you my elf my heart and all: and if after o many injuries as I have done you, I have any power with you I beeech and command you to live and love me. At this Celadon tood amazed, and it was long before he was able to open his mouth: But at lat, recollecting himelf. Yes yes, my fairet Atrea (replied he) I will love and live and ince you are pleaed to command it, I will endeavour as much to preerve my life, as I have to ditroy it: when I thought that my paion was not pleaing unto you, every moment of my life was as horrid unto me as death: but now ince your compaion has uffered my pereverance to overcome you, and ince the remembrance of my ervices has inpired you with a kindnes to re-admit me into your favour, oh dearet tar of my life, my dayes hall not be without any nights, and not a hepherd about all Lignon, hall be comparably o full of joyes as I am. My beloved hepherd replied Atrea very weetly, if your joyes and felicity does depend upon my affection, you have good reaon to ay that you hall be highly happy, ince my affection is mot perfect: and to put you out of all doubt of me, be aured Celadon, I will ooner die then faile in the leat fillable I have spoken; and let Lignon be as angry with me as I was with it when I thought it the extinguiher of your life, and flames if I do not mot religiouly oberve all the promies that ever I made in your favour. Beleive me, my dearet Son, I do <> this very preent, renew and confirm unto you all the aurances of my affection My fairet Atrea (aid Celadon, even ravihed with exces of joy and delight,) if I do receive thee weet words as the mot overaign balome againt all thy mieryes may Lignon repent it ever pared my life; and if ever I offer to dipleae you eyther in deed, word or very thought, may the air I breath in be an eternall plague unto me; Dearet Son (aid Atrea, and interrupted) I know that you love me better then I do deerve; but as great as your affection is cannot urpae the deire which I have of your love; for indeed Celadon I would have you wholy mine, for as never any misfortune may be able to break in under thoe chaine • wherewith love has united out wits; In aying o, he embraced him again: and
Celadon was o ravihed with joye as he did not only forget all his pat mieryes but alo did inenibly loe the knowledge of himelf; and doubtles he had died in this rapture if Phillis who was a witnes of this reconciliation had not took him about the neck in expreion of her joyes to ee him again in that habit. Bellinde and Diana were alo very attentive unto their dicoure; and though the orrowes which Diana reented were incapable of any cure; yet it was ome comfort unto her, to ee her Companion o happy.

Adamas on the other ide, who feared that the pirit of Atrea being o uddainly tranported from one extremity unto another might do her ome harm, he was very glad to ee their carrees interrupted, and going to her: Daughter (aid he) if the life of Celadon be dear unto you, you mut uffer him to be carryed away for I am afraid that as your rigours had formerly cot him his life o now your favours will do the ame: Father (anwered Atrea) the benefits which I have received from you, are not comparable unto thoe the gods betow upon us: you alone have given Celadon unto me, and you may take him from me when you pleae without injutice I do intend (aid Adamas(to part you but a hort while; for I protet, before to morrow be expired, I will marry you togeather, and will end exprely to Phocion about it, provided it be not repugnant to your will; Celadon and Atrea both expreing that to be the only object of their deires: my Children, (aid the Druide) may heaven make you happy in each other: The reaon why I deferre the ceremony untill to morrow, is only becaue I would have it done more olemly, and have Phocion a witnes of it. In aying o, he took Celadon by the hand, and carryed him out of the Chamber, after he had advied the hepherdes to take a little ret, for after her two or three dayes travel, it was the only phyique that would recover her health: upon this mall eperation, the eyes of Atrea and Celadon did dart, and communicate unto each other all the hidden ecrets of love under the contraint of ilence; And though the caue of their parting hould not have dicontented them, yet they could not chue but greive at it, and think it one of thoe bitter pilles which heaven does ordinarily mixe amongt the pleaures of life.

Adamas was no ooner gone out, but Bellinde did eat her elf upon her Daughters bed, well Daughter (aid he unto her in a low voice) heere is your Companion, ready to ee all her deires accomplihed, and will uffer mine to find a contrary ucces? She is goeing to enjoy a million of delights in the ociety of Celadon, and are not you ahamed to refue thoe which I do offer unto you in the enjoyment of Paris? You cannot now alleadge one jut exception againt him: for you are now dipened from your vow of going to live with her amongt the Carnutes, ince he her elf will not aume that order upon her, and if you have taken any oath to be a follower of her fortunes as you told me that you had, then ince he prepares her elf for marriage, o mut you prepare your elf for the ame kind of life: Madam (anwered Diana very faintly, and faigning her elf to be as ick in body as in mind) the condition wherein I am me thinks hould move you to make preparation of a coffin for me rather then a husband; I do find the approaches of death o near as I cannot think upon any worldly matter: and if you value my contentment I do conjure you Madam (continued he in a weak, and languihing tone) even by the name of Mother, not to trouble me with any more of uch dicoure, ince all is to no purpoe, and cannot produce your deired effects. Thee expreions did o greive Bellinde, as nothing upecting her cunning, he verily beleived, that he was even ready to expire: and therefore with eyes flowing in teares, he aid unto her; Ah my dear Diana, ince this dicourse is troubleome unto you, I will not ue it any more only promie me to live, and let no dicontents trouble you: for I wear that if you give me any hopes of recovery unto your former health; I will do all that poibly I can to obtain from the gods that you may never marry, and that they will revoke the entence which they have already pronounced in favour of Paris. Diana was very glad that Bellinde did lacke in her everity of contraining her to marriage: o as faining to aume a little trength, and raying her feeble voice, Madam (aid he) if ever I did diobey you without abundance of regret, may the gods punih you:
and I protet that if they will but end me three dayes of life, I will punctually do whatoever you hall command me.

p.U:
poke this only to keep Bellinde in a good humour, and that he hould not mitrut that he had any deign of attempting any thing upon her elf, But her maine drift was to make ue of the time, as o to deceive Bellinde, that he might make an ecape, and follow the fate of Silvander whatoever it was. She du •• not in her Mothers preence enquire one illable of him yet being infinitly impatient to know what was become of him, and conceiving that Phillis might perhaps know, he thought that if Bellinde were once goneu Phillis would tell her all. She heemed therefore to be deirous of leep, and hutting her eyes, faigned a lumber. Bellinde who heard the Druide ay, that leep and ret was abolutely neceary for Atrea, he thought it as convenient for Diana, and was very glad to ee a dipoition of leep upon her: with drawing her elf therefore as oftly as he could, he entreated Phillis to have a care of her whilt he went unto Adamas. Phillis did promie he would, and did verily beleive but Companion was a leep, o well could he counterfet the matter; But as oon as ever Bellinde was out of the Room, the icke hepherdee leaped out of her bed, and went into Atreas: Siter (aid he unto her) I am • riving betwixt ome thoughts that are very different: I am extreamly glad to ee you ready to enjoy the happines which Adamas hath procured you, in retoring you Celadon; And it greives my oul to ee the gods refue Silvander unto me: The interet I have in your contentment does much mitigate the violence of my greif: but I mut needs confee I cannot be quite clear from all orrowes, for beides my greif that the gods will not uffer me to enjoy him, it greives me alo that I cannot hear what is become of him: Companion (anwered Phillis) the very ame which hapned unto you at the fountain by reaon of the enchantment, hath hapned unto him alo: So as hee was brought in the ame coach with you; and being put into the ame Chamber with Celadon, Adamas was o officious about him, that hee is now, as well as you are: and indeed the Druide told me that hee was up, and that hee left him with Lycidas. Alas, (replied Diana) who was infinitly diitrous to ee him, that he might tell him what dicoure he had with Bellinde) to what purpoe is it, there hould be ick a conformity in our humours and lives, as long as the detinies will not uffer our deires to produce the ame effects? In aying o, he could not chue but igh; afterwards addreing her elf unto Atrea. But • iter (aid he) why hould we hut light out of the Room? would Phillis would be pleaed to open the windowes, and that we might both get out of bed where we cannot ret, you by reaon of your joyes, and I by reaon of my orrowes; But iter (anwered Atrea) Adamas has o exprely enjoyned me to keep my bed till morning, as I hould think it a grand crime to diobey him, as for your deires of eeing Silvander (for I know your impatiency proceds from thence) it is probable that the day will not pae away, before it has given you that contentment: Well, (aid Diana) ince hee has commanded it to bee o, we will not diobey: and ince we are to bee left alone, if Silvander do come, my Mother will not bee heere. Well well (aid Phillis preently upon this) I hall propound an expedient unto you: make me your confident, and do not conceale any part of your oul from me; Then hall I do omething for the atisfaction of that hepherd, in exchange of the harm I did him when I took your bracelet from him. Then dear Companion (replied Diana) I beeech you tell him—no no, replied Phillis, and interrupted her) I will not tell him any thing: for perhapes hee will not believe me; but write what you will unto him; and I hall deliver your Letter with as much fidelity as you can deire: Alas (anwered Diana) that cannot bee, becaue we know not how to goe eyther pad, ink, or paper. I will ee, (aid Phillis) in aying o, he opened the window, and go • ing unto a little ebony cabinet, by fortune he found in it, an inborn, and five or ixe heets of paper; For Adamas kept uch a cabinet in every Chamber, for the conveniency of uch as lay in them, in cae they tood in need of them: • ringing them therefore unto Diana, he was o importance with her, that he prevailed, and made her write a Letter; and then took upon her to deliver it unto Silvander
o he left Diana and Atrea alone, after a promie that he would tell all the world that they were aleep: o as none might offer to come and interrupt them.

div.p: Paris all this while was entertaining Roaulra, Galathea, and the bet in the great chamber, where manger all diatrous accidents, he was contrained to put on a face of civility, though he eemed unto his company to be in no manner of contraint: Thee new Shepherdees tayed not long in that room; for they deired to go into the Garden, which was a piece of uch an exquiitnes, that neither Art not Nature could not add any greater ornament unto the houe of the Druide, then it: After they had walked a while, they ate down in an Arbour at the end of a long walk, jut oppoite to the Garden door where they entred: They had not been there above a quarter of an hour, before they aw Adamas enter, holding Silvander in one hand, and another Shepherd in the other, whom at the firt ight they knew not: yet, they concluded him to be a peron of ome conideration, as well by reaon of the eteem which the Druide made of him, as by reason of his handome and comely deportment: Yet, as Adamas drew nearer and nearer, o they began to be out of the doubt wherein they were; for the Nymph Golathea, who ince he firt cat her eye upon him, did find ome extraordinary motion in her oul, he preently cryed out, O, it is Celadon: In aying o, he roe up to go and meet the Druide; and all the ret doing the ame, as oon as Adamas aw them coming he doubled his pace, and when he was near Galathea, Madam (aid he, and preented Celadon unto her) here is one whom your compaion did ave from drowning, and I come to offer him unto you, as unto one whom he belongs unto. Upon this, the Shepherd kneeled down upon the ground, and kied the Nymphs hand; but he, who new the quality and merit of Celadon, did preently take him up, and after he had embraced him, Adamas (aid he) I do receive your preent, and will love him the more dearly, becaue having recued him out of the jaws of death, I may in ome ort ay, he is mine own. Mot true, Madam, anwered the Shepherd, for if I do not ow my birth unto you, yet I do my preervation, which was a favour of o high a dearnes, as I hall ooner die then loe the memory of it: Yes, yes (replied Galathea, taking the Shepherd by the hand, and carrying him to the place where all the company was) you do ow unto me all this freh coulour which is now in your cheek; and but for me; your handome body would have been food for fihes. Madam, replied Celadon, I do know that I ow my life unto you, and will me •• , willingly imploy it in your ervice; but yet, replied Galathea, I make more doubt of you affection, then I do of your courage: for the truth is, you were alwayes inenible of my love, and all my expreion of affection unto you never moved you. Celadon did bluh at this dicoure, remembring how he had been perecuted in the Pallace of Ioures; and after he had looked about and aw none follow, he expected a hrewd combate. Yet being fully reolved to fail, rather in his repects unto the Nymph, then in his fidelity to Atrea: Madam replied he, if ever I failed in my humble acknowledgements, it was rather a fault in my wit, then in my wil: I have ever endeavoured not to appear ungrateful for the favour of your compaion, and if I cannot atisfie uch obligation as you have loadned me withall, it is your own fault, Madam, who has made them too high for me to requite.

Ah Celadon (aid Galathea) I never demanded any Empires of Kingdomes from you; what I required might eaily have been done, my ambition never aimed any higher then to enjoy you: and had you conented unto that, I hould have thought my elf ufficiently paid for all the cares and pains I took for your preervation: I do mot humbly beeech your pardon Madam (aid Celadon adly) if I ay, that I could not atisfie your deire without committing a mot extream injutice: for then I had dipoed of that which was anothers, and had not given you that which was not mine own. If there be any crime in this, the charms of Atrea are guilty of it, or rather the gods themelves, who have uffered that Shepherdes o to overcome me, as it is impoible I hould be anyes but only hers, or ever drawn out of that ervitude, wherein her beauty and merit
keeps me fat prioner. What Celadon (aid Galathea) are you in this mind till? Yes Madam, anwered the Shepherd, and I have neither will nor power to be otherwie. What then mut Galathea do? replied the Nymph, do you think he can urvive o many rigorous corns and didains as you eem to have of her? Fair Nymph (aid Celadon, and looked upon her with an eye full of repect and contraint) if you be orry for aving that life which was ready to perih, command me to retore you that which you preerved: I am mot ready to die, and do protet it will be a great atisfaction unto me to loe my elf in obeying you, and making it appear to the world, that nothing can diolve thoe knots wherewith Love hath enchained me: As he aid o, his eyes tood in water; and Galathea, who held all this dicoure with him, only to try his fidelity, Celadon (aid he and embraced him) live happy in the love of your Shepherdes, I wear unto you, that I will never be jealous, but her contentment hall be a caue of mine: Heaven at the lat, has had compaion upon me, and cured my oul of thoe wounds which that Impotourous Druide had made in it: I do pardon the flight of Lucinde, and the treaon of all her Complices; and to dicover the mot intimate ecret of my oul unto you, know Celadon, that Lindamor is only in my heart: but that you may not think your elf a loer by this change, aure your elf Shepherd, that I will love and eteem you as long as I live: In aying o, he embraced him again, and Celadon tranported with joy, did cat himelf at her feet, and kiing her hand, Madam (aid he) it is now that I mut acknowledge my elf mot really obliged unto you for my life, ince you do give unto my oul, that only thing which could make it live with delight: Upon this, the Nymph took his hand, and carryed him to the ret of the company.

Belinde came into the Garden almot at the ame time, and after her Phillis, of whom Galathea enquired particularly of Atrea and Diana: and this Shepherdes anwering that they were aleep and took good ret, the Nymph turned towards Celadon, and o may you with her (aid he in a low voice) as long as you live; and may all thoe that offer to diturb you be hated of heaven. Celadon had hardly leaure to return her thanks for her good wih, for at the ame time he was mingled amongt the ret. But Phillis, who came only to give Silvander a concontentment above his expectation, did endeavour to have dicoure with him uneen unto any; and yet he was afraid, that if he did not acquaint Licidas, it might revive his paion of jealouie, which had cot her o much trouble before, o as he was contrained to impart her ecret unto him, and thus her freedome was o pleaing unto that Shepherd, as he went preently unto Silvander, and pretending to hew him a flower, the name whereof he deired to know, he drew him a little aide, and told him that Phillis had omething to ay unto him: o as evering himelf by degrees from the company, and Phillis oberving him, he also tole away, and met him in a cloe Arbour, o thick with leaves, that none could ee them. Phillis found Silvander a little urprized; for remembring a command which he once brought him from Diana about a bracelet, he thought he came upon the like meage now, and was extreamly perplexed; but the Shepherdes knowing his fears, Silvander (aid he unto him) I have been o accutomed to do you ill offices, as the very ight of me is an alarm unto you: but, though heretofore you have had ome caue to fear meeting with me, yet you have now reaon to deire it.

Upon this, not giving him o much time as to reply, he gave him Dianas Letter, and aid unto him, here Silvander, take this in full recompence of all the harm I ever did you, when I took my companions bracelet for you: The Shepherd took it, kied it; and afterwards, with a trembling hand opening it, he read thee words.

body.head: DIANA's Letter unto SILVANDER.
body.p: IF you be any thing troubled concerning me, know my dearet Silvander, that I do live only, becaue you are not dead: If your curioity do reach o far, as to enquire after my health, never conult with any other Phyician but your own elf, and according to the tate wherein you find your elf, o judge of me and my condition. They tell me, that tomorrow, Love is to pronounce ome Oracles, perhaps we hall there here omething which concerns our Detinies. In the mean time, have a care of your own preervation for my ake, and be aured, that if they do forbid me from being Silvanders, I will never be the wife of Paris: Live therefore and adieu.

div.p: Silvander had no ooner done readnig this Letter, but he kied it a thouand times; and his oul admiring the affection and fidelity of this Shepherdes, he read it over and over again five or ix times, as if he had doubted whether or no his eyes had deceived him in making him to hope for a bleing o far beyond his expectation. At lat, turning towards Phillis: Mot true fair Shepherdes (aid he unto her) the happines which now you have brought me is a full atisfaction for all the harms you ever did me; but if you will make this favour mot perfectly compleat, do me the honour to tell my fairet Mitres, how I do reent her compaion upon my love and miery: Tell her, dear Phillis, that I will live as long as he keeps her promie inviolable, or as long as there is any hopes to enjoy her: If he meaure her health by mine, tell her he may afely leave her bed, ince I do find no dipoition unto mine: Phillis now repented that he did not bring with her the Inkhorn which Diana made ue of; but thinking that this Shepherdes would give credit unto the report which he hould make, he promied Silvander to deliver the meage faithfully, and bidding adieu unto Licidas, he returned preently to her companions: unto whom, relating all paages, and the joyes which Silvander reented at the reading of the Letter, Diana was infinitly comforted.

In the mean time, Adamas, Galathea, Roanira, Celadon, and the ret, were gone into a walk upon the left hand, which led them inenibly into a little wood, which the Druide had incloed within the pale of his garden: But they were no ooner entred into it, then they heard a voice which made a mot lamentable noie. Adamas, who never heard the like, he was extreamly deirous to know what it was; and remembring how Atrea was carryed away in the time of Polemas his Rebellion, he was afraid, that ome Shepherdes was menaced with the like accident: therefore he ran unto the place, from whence he thought this hideous noie came; and he was no ooner come unto it, with Roanira, Galathea, and the ret who followed him, but they perceived that it was man triving and truggling in the arms of Olicaris.

This ight did extreamly urprize them; and the more, when the man doubling his cries, and Olicaris till triving with him till he was ill in a weat, they appeared to have ome ill deigns one againt the other; and Olicaris, being the tronger, had urmounted the reitance of his enemy. They advanced therefore to part them, but at the very ame time, the man fell to the ground, with o little ign of life, as every one thought him dead. They knew him preently to be the ame man which came with Olicaris and Halladine, which caued them all to fix their looks upon the good old man, who looking alo upon them again without aying a word, but putting his hand into his pocket, he pulled out his handkerchief, and wiped his face. Mean time Adamas extreamly atonihed, and not knowing what to think of this trange accident, he addreed himelf unto Olicaris, whilt the ret went unto him that was fallen, to ee if they could recover
him. But Olicaris, upon a udden raiing up his voice, and being a little recollected: Fair Shepherdees (aid he unto them, for uch he thought Roanira, Galathea, Dorinde, Daphnide, Madonthe, Silvia, and the ret to be) do not wonder to ee that man in uch a condition: it is by an accident which is very ordinary unto him, and is no lee wonderful then the caue from whence it proceeds. Every one eemed extreamly deirous to know what the matter was, epecially Galathea, who could not chue but make her curioity appear: which Olicaris perceiving. I do very well know (aid he unto them) that I cannot make a dicoure of it unto you, without being very tedious; but ince you eem o deirous of it, I will not be paring of my labour; ince the man will give us time enough to do it, for he will not awake out of this Lethargie wherein you ee him, this two hours: So every one eeming till more and more deirous to hear Olicaris, they all ate round about him, and he began thus.:

div.head: The Hitory of OLICARSIS and AZAHIDES.
div.p: THat morning, when this Shepherdes came and interrupted us (meaning Phillis) I was beginning to relate unto you, p • rt of thoe paages which hapned in the Empiredome of the Eat, and in that of the Wet, ince races, Eudoxe, Olimbres, and Placidia, were recompenced all the pains which Love had made them uffer; and becaue it is in ome ort neceary, I hould tell them unto you, to make you the more admire at the Fatality which brought me hither, I will now begin my dicoure where I left lat: firt begging your excue, if by a Narration perhaps too long. I hall offend your ears and patience.

Give me leave to tell you then, that the affection which I tetified unto the age Eudoxe, during her captivity unto Generick, did purchae me o great a hare in the friendhip of Vraces and Olimbres, as we may all ay, that ever ince we have been all one and the ame. This was the reaon, that when they departed, I beeeched the King to let me got with them; and their deign was, to prefer me unto Marcian, as conceiving that age Emperour would love me when he once knew me; but Ginerick, who perhaps doubted or feared, that the remembrance of my imprionment would beget ome reentmeats in me againt him, he would not upon any terms give me leave. But on the contrary, thinking that honours and riches were the mot powerful charms that he could ue to keep me about his peron, he began to put me upon imployments which were very troubleome unto me, ince they diverted me from my tudies; but yet very honourable they were, ince they were the greatet offices in all his Dominions. A correpondency betwixt Vraces, Olimbres, and me, did not yet die, notwithtanding the Rigour of this eparation; but as if abence were a means to link us in affection the more firmly; it did encreae amongt us at that ditance. We were exceedingly vigilant and careful in ending unto each other; and as I gave them an accompt of all my buinee and negotiations, o I believe, they did participate unto me their mot intimate thoughts. Thus I heard of their return unto Marcian; the Carrees wherewith that Emperour did olemnize their marriage, and in fine, the greatet part of that which I hall tell you in the Sequel of this dicoure. Be pleaed to know that Marcian has no ooner entred upon the eventh year of his Empiredome, but as it is the quality of virtue to beget much envy and jealouie, o the merit of that age Emperour did raie thoe two paions in the minds of Ardabures and Apar, who having been much in Contantinople, did think, that to obtain the Empire, there needed no more, but to take the Crown from off the head of Marcian They began therefore to plot and make parties againt him; and finding that his life would be a main obtacle in their way (what will not ambition do to get a Crown) they dipatched him by poyon. Judge, I beeech you, how nearly his death did concern Vraces and Olimbres, and how nearly they reented
it, ince they were beholding unto him for the greatet part of their well-beings. This was the caue, that they, in ome ort, upecting the Authours of this abominable Patricide, they did generally oppoe themelves againt their deignes, and negotiated o well, that Ardabures and Apar, being failed in their pretentions, a great Grecian was choen Emperour, called Leon, and born in the Town of Betique: It is true, that their Faction being extreamly trong, they would not conent unto this election, but upon condition that the Raigns of the Empire, hould be for a time in the hands of Apar. Leon made no difficulty to receive him as a partner; but he made them all know preently after, that Empiredom admits of no Competitours, and that when he conented unto it, he promied no les then an impoibility.

In the mean time, Leon, amidt his joyes to ee the Empire of the Eat ubmitted unto him. he did not forget what Vraces and Olimbres had done in his favour; and knowing that Martians affection unto them was very great, he thought it but jut he hould ucceed him, as well in his love to them, as in his crowns. Expreing himelf then as kindly as poibly he could, he deired them to continue their affections to him, and proteted, that when any opportunities preented themelves, wherein he might honour them, he would prefer them before all other perons whatoever. Look now upon Leon for a while peaceable in the Eat, but o were not we in Africa: for Majoranus, who ucceeded Maximus in the Empire of the Wet, to get Sicily out of the hands of Generick who was become the Mater of it, he made attempts that was worthy of his courage, and in his deign (as they ay) of coming to burn us in our houes, he was mierably murdered by the ame Souldiers who made choice of him. His death, which hewed all the world how hort a while the favours of Fortune do lat, did give us ome ret, and made Generick rouz up his former courage and deigns: o as raiing a Puiant Army, he put himelf into a condition to reit all men whom he accounted his enemies: And certainly his preparations were not in vain, for oon after the death of Majoranus Soverian, who ucceeded him, prepared himelf to proecute the deigns of his Predeceon • ; but hearing of our forces, he preently changed advice, and turned his arms againt the Alans, whom he defeated near Bergamus, and there killed their King Beringus Perhaps this victory had blown up his courage, and carryed him upon ome new enterprise againt us; but his death, which was almot as udden as his Predeceours, thought not o violent, did at once tifle his deigns and hopes upon Rome.

During this time, Generick, as I told you before, had ready hipt a brave and gallant Army, o as not to let it lie idle, he reolved to give Rome a econd viit, invited unto it (as I think) by the memory of his firt poils. His design was not o ecretly carried, but the Emperour Leon was advertied of it, who, not to let Italy perih in that diorder wherein it then was, did end Anthemius to defend it from the invaion of the Vandals. But Generick, who quickly knew that he hould be moleted in his enterprize, by the pretentions of one Gervandus, who ince was exiled, he hated away; and having made Thraimond Lieutenant General of his Army, did leave his other Son in Carthage, with an expres prohibition not to ordain any thing before he had communicated unto me, and taken my advice. I remained therefore by this means in Africa, where, if I had entertained any had intentions, I had not wanted means to put them in execution; but ever being an hater of all evil actions, I would ooner have died then done them. Beides thus, I did extreamly love Thraimond and the young Prince, with whom I tayed as a Governour: o as the interet of this affection, was enough to make me forget the greatet injuries I ever received from their Father.

Generick then embarqued himelf, flattering himelf with hopes, that his voyage would be no lee properous, then the conquet of all the world. But O, how fond and deceitful are all humane intentions? One ingle day aw all this glory, and all this war like Array, vanih to nothing: for Leon, who feared that Anthemius was not trong enough to reit o formidable an Army, did hate away relief under the conduct of one Bailicus, who being, by the favour of the gods and the winds, joyned with him, did defeat Generick, and gave him
o harp a chae, as he was contrained to retire into Carthage, with as much hame and infamy, as his ambition did before promie him glory and honour. In a very hort time, this Bailicus made himelf mater of Sicily, and regained all that the conquets of Generick had ravihed from the Romane power; but not contenting himelf with thoe Trophes which he had already gotten, whilt Anthemius was returned to Rome, he deigned to ubjugate Africa, and not to leave Generick o much ground as to make himelf a grave.

This reolution did put Generick into a greater confuion, then I am able to expree: He aw all his Armies defeated, Bailicus triumphant, Sicily lot, the Vandals ruined, and all Africa affrighted: o as not knowing which way to reit his enemy, one day he did me the honour to communicate himelf unto me: I freely told him, that if he did not think himelf able to defend himelf by force, he had no other way but to have recoure unto Pollicy, and that the mot favourable expedient would be, to top the mouth of his enemy by corrupting him with gifts and promies; and that though he pent herein all the riches that he had gotten by the plunder of Rome, yet would have this advantage by it, that he gave nothing but was their own, and had thereby preerved his life and etate. This propoition did ound well in his ears, and thinking that perhaps I had wit enough to bring this about, he imployed me to go unto Bailicus, and gave me a full power to manage this negotiation as eemed good unto me. Upon this I went, and found Bailicus advanced very far; but not to init upon every circumtance and coure I took to overcome him; let it uffice I tell you, that after I had told him there was no prudence in exaperating an enemy o far as to make him deperate: That the greatet glory he could hope for, was to get by his valour all that which Italy had lot: That Generick did offer to retore it unto him, even all the riches that he had brought from Rome. This Man, who doubtlee was of a greedy and covetous Nature, was wrought upon by the promies which I had made unto him, to keep this negotiation o ecret, that never any could come to the knowledge of it.

Thus did I in ome ort give peace unto Africa, and ret unto Generick, who had no ooner performed the conditions of this ecret treaty; but Bailicus, upected as I believe (for it is impoible uch actions hould long lie hid) was commanded by Leon to return unto Contantinople. This Emperour would never uffer neither Vraces nor Olimbres to be abent from him: for truting in their courages and affections, alo upecting the Factions of Ardabures and Apar, he was very glad to keep them by him, as two Pillars to upport him in caes of neceity; but at this time, when the malice of thee two Factions had broken out anew, and Vraces and Olimbres, after everal skirmihes, little prevailing, he was contrained to end for Bailicus, who had under him the only forces which could ecure him in the poeion of the Empire.

Bailicus then, was no ooner ent for, but Vraces addreing himelf unto Olimbres, and telling him how great a hame unto them it was, that they could not do any ervice unto Leon, and that it was better for them to perih in a brave attempt then to tay and let another have the glory of giving peace unto the Eat: to whom Olimbres, whoe pirit apired unto great actions, anwering that he was ready to avoid that tain upon their honours, they aembled together one day all the Forces they could raie, and charged Ardabures and Apar o furiouly, that after a long and harp Combate, wherein the los of blood was the leat mark of their courages, they took them both Prioners, and brought them to the mercy of Leon, who to top all fears of any further Rebellion, did publickly put them to death.

This was the tate of things, whilt Anthemius found how far the perfidie and ingratitude of a man could go: for Rithimer, a Goth by Nation, whom Severian had made a Citizen of Rome, and Lieutenant of his Army, and unto whom Anthemius married his daughter, he roe up againt him; and forgetting all the benefits which he had received from his father in Law, he trove at the Empire, and endeavoured to uurp the Crown and Authority. Anthemius, more grieved at his ill Nature, then at his pretentions, did generously oppose himelf againt his enterpries,
and had no ooner advertied Leon of Rithimers ingratitude, but the Emperor dipatched Olimbres to him, to deliver him from the oppreions of this kinman-enemy. But the doom of the detinies being inevitable, ome accident or other impeded the voyage of Olimbres o as he came no farther then Ravenna, when Rithimer, having violated the peace which he contracted with Anthemius only to have the more facility to betray him did rebell a new: defeated Belemer, who came with relief unto Anthemius; Entred into Room: plundered the houes: Pillaged the tatly Palaces, burned the Temples, and mierbaly put him to the word who had done him o many benefits.

This violence had like to have killed Olimbres with greif, and the more becaue he conceaved that he might have topped his comming unto Rome. But this horrid cruelty did incene the gods much more, who being unwilling to uffer uch abominable iniquity, and bae treachery to pae unpunihed, they would never uffer uch an impious wretch to raign, but let him die the mot violent death that ever did man.

Olimbres preently after, was declared Emperor, and called unto Rome as the only hope of that deolate etate: which news quickly carried unto Carthage, and was o welcome unto Generick, and Thraimond, becaue of the affection which they ever bare unto him that they reolved to give ome perticular tetimony of their joy: For my part, I mut confee my joyes were far above my expreions or any imagination, and in my excee of gladnee I thought a thouand times of that which an Atrologer foretold him, (which was, that he hould not die untill he was made Emperor, and had commanded the Empire of the wet) not bring able to comprehend how it was poible any mortall man could without a miracle have uch perfect knowledge of future things. At lat, after I had long thought upon it, I found the proverbe true, which ayes, that as one mifortune is alwayes followed with another, o very often one good fortune is accompanied with another: for Generick, who as I aid before, reolved to make appear his joyes at the advancement, and good fortune of Olimbres he would add unto my joyes at this news, another; whith was, to be a witnee of it. He commanded me then, to prepare my elf for this voyage: and I wimming in uch delights as this encounter did promie me, hoping that happily, it would make Placidia come to Rome, and that Eudixe, and races might meet there alo, in two dayes I et all things in uch good order, that I was ready to part away. Generick provided a Ship purpoly for me, in which, he put ome men of war, and loadned me with o many rich preents for Olimbres, as I may mot truly ay, I never aw o much riches togeather in my life. So after Generick, Thraimond, and his Brother had committed me to the protection of the gods, we weighed Anchor: our Marrinors ang himnes to the honour of Neptune, and preently after we lot the ight of Carthage, ome Merchants wich traffiqued into Italy, joyned themelves with us: and having as favorable a Gale as we could wih, every one had good hopes in the concluion our voyage, ince the beginning was o properous.

Thus we ailed ome dayes without any impediment: but as if the Dieties of the Sea, who live in a perpetuall incontancy, were angry at our happines, we quickly found, that the intervall between properity, and adverity is but very male: Indeed, with in your pace of one hower we aw the little curle that was upon the face of the water turned into Mountainous billowes, upon that humide element, which loing themelves in one another, did eem to jutle, and trive which hould give the greatet hoke againt our Ship. The winds which before welled one ailes which a gentle breath, turned into contrarys, and began a war amongt themelves, and contended which hould firt overturn us. Yet we found wore enemyes then all thee: the air at the ame time became obcure, and afforded us no light but lightning, affrighting voyces of thunder, & flaming flahes of lightning et fire upon ome of our Ships, which we aw burning in the midt of the waves, whilt it was impoible for us to ave one man, for uch as thought to avoid the flames, were immediatly wallowed up by the waves. In this horrid confuion, the Pilats did abondon themelves unto the mercy of the enraged Sea:
and the Marriners having no hopes of any afty but in their prayers, they cut their mats and cordage, and left all to violence of the wind and waves. For my part, I mut needs confee that in this danger, death did never preent it elf unto me with a more grime contenance, and it grieved me extreamly that I was to end my dayes before I had enjoyed the happines of eeing Olimbres. This tempet lated eight whole dayes, during which I may ay we hardly ever aw, any day or light: ometimes we were rouled one way, ometimes another, and eemed only as if it were to make choie of a place for Shipwrack, for every where we found the ame dangers. At lat, that Ship wherin I was, being bigger, and tronger then any of the ret, and the lat the perihed, it clahed againt ome rockes toward the Mailian coat; and as if Neptune had reerved us for the lat victime, as oon as ever our Ship was hevered to pieces, the air cleared up; the tormes ceaed, and the Sea was calm: Thoe whom fear had not killed, did perih as I think with the Ship: and I, who was reolved to keep my elf alive as long as I could, I took a little wooden Goffer, wherin I kept ome oyntments, and eenes to help uch as tood in need of them, and with it I cat my elf into the water: My deign was to wim as long as my trength lated, auring my elf that I hould prolong my life two or three howers, and perhaps the gods during that time might end ome help. Thus, ometimes utained by my little wooden Coffer, and ometimes wimming, I perceived that I was not far ditant from the rock againt which our Ship was plit; Then I aumed freh courage, and trength and by the help of heaven which never forook me in any neceity I came to the place where I deired to be. I was no ooner out of the water, but being both weary, and wet, I put off all my cloathes, and lay my elf down by them, which I did not put on again untill the Sun had dryed them. From hence did I ee floating in the Sea the reliques of our Shipwrack: and after I had a little contemplated upon the misfortune which had caued o many men, and o much wealth to perih, I began to conider alo that my own fate was not much more favourable, ince I aw that my life could not be preerved long upon that rock, o naked as I was, and without any upply of food againt hunger. Yet till hoping in the goodnes of heaven whoe anger was appeaed, I trove againt this greedy Monter all the ret of the day, and all the night following: and the next morning, when my heart began to faint for want of food, I reolved to make ue of my eenes, of which when I came from Carthage, I had made good proviion; I laid my hand then upon the little Coffer never remembring that I had left the key of it in the Ship. And therefore when I aw I could not open it, I reolved to break it: but I had no ooner lifted it up to dah it againt the rock, then I conidered that the force of the blow would infallibly break all the glaes, and pill the eenes. Upon this thought I laid the boxe at my feet, and lifting up my eyes unto heaven to aske ome help, I epied a Ship under full aile, and which being very well equipaged, eemed as if he had not been at Sea during the time of the torm. I began preently to crye out as loud as ever I could: but I quickly ound my voice was to no purpoe, and that it was impoible it hould reach o far: Therefore putting off my hirt, I waved it in the air, like a banner; which I had not done above half a quarter of an hower or there about, but I perceived them to untye the Cockboate, and row towards me with four or five men only in it.

Judge how I was joyed at this: indeed I am not able to expres how much: but o it was, that I hated to dree my elf, and in my feares, leat ome new misfortune hould hinder me of this relief which eemed to be o near me, I thought that they did not row o fat as they might have done: yet in leethen half an hower they came unto the rock where I was, and they were no ooner come but I leaped into the boate, never remembring the boxe which was when all my fortune, and the only remedy I had left to comfort me againt the injury of the water. Yet after my pirits were a little recollected I began to think upon the important things that were with in it, and therefore entreated the men to return back, and o they did very willingly. It was not long before we came to the Ship which had ent me this relief, where I received from every one uch expreions of joy, as made in evident, that the life of a man was of no little conideration
in their minds; ome of them gave my Bisket and Wine, other ome, alted meate, and thus did they very charitably feed me in my extreamity of hunger. After this, they deired me to tell them all the particulars of my hipwrack, which they hearkened unto with amazement; and preently after, night did invice us all to ret.

Thus whilt every one was preparing themelves for leep, two of thoe who had releived me did come unto me, and invited me to ret my elf in a Cabine: I durt not refue this kind offer, thinking it not fit to diobey them in any thing, after uch a benefit received. Thus I conented unto all they deired; and as oon as we were all three ate down, the firt of them, who eemed to be o ready and joyful to do me any ervice, after a thouand thanks unto him for it, I was very deireous to know his name; He anwered, that he was called Palemon, and that he was a Seguian: Then calling to memory what I had heard concerning the Adventures of races, and remembring that a man of that Country and (as I thought) of the ame name, had formerly aved him from killing himelf, I asked him whether he was not the man, who in Italy had done that good office for the Caveleir: He told me no; but true it was, that a Seguian did recue raes from the Arms of death; but his name was Celadon, and not Palemon; But however, (continued I) I do find by the help you have afforded, that the gods are friends unto your Country, ince they have made all the men in it o charitable and kind: and doubtles this lat action of yours to me, will find from Heaven a great reward; and be aured, that as far as I am able, Olicaris hall never be found ungrateful.

At the name of Olicaris, he that was on the other ide me, and almot aleep, did tart up, and turning himelf towards me, did ask me whether or no I named Olicaris, and what I aid of him: to whom I anwered, that I did name him, and that it was in auring Palemon that I would upon all occaions be ready to acknowledge the good office he had done me: Do you bear the name of that man, who is o highly eteemed in the world? (aid he unto me) who cannot want friends in what place oever you can go? To this I anwered as modetly as I could; but to omit the relation of that good opinion which he had of me, and what he aid in my advantage; I will only tell you, that I was acknowledged to be the man whom they looked after. And after I had received the Letter from Damon, and told them I was able to atifie that deire which moved them to undertake this voyage; I made them all o full of joy, as they could hardly leep that night.

They undertood that my deign was to go unto Rome to viit Olimbres; o as telling me it would not be a long and difficult Journy by Land; and that if I would ee Damon, and Forrets by the way, I hould not go above four days journey out of my way; I conented to go by Land, and o accordingly we did about break of day.

Then they began to peak unto me concerning Celideas cure, and hewed unto me, the little bloody ticks; but the hopes which I had that I hould ere long dres the wounds themelves, made me deire them to defer this cure until we came there. Upon this, they preed me no further; but knowing that I had a deire to ee the City of the Mailians, becaue there raes, and Olimbres did demand the poion, they went thither with me; And from thence paing unto the Country of Allobroges we came to Vallence, where the Beauty of the place inviting us to tay a day, beides many other rarities, there we aw the Tomb of Tullia, the Daughter of Cicero; and then a large and high Arch, under a hill, where, they ay, one of her Lovers did hed o many tears, that the god of Love did turn them into a Fountain, which was never ince dry. From thence we left upon our left hand, a tately Catle, which, they ay was built by Turnus: Afterwards following upon the Ron, night did urprie us within three Leagues of Vienna. We were then contrained to go no further, becaue we were to pas through a thick and dangerous wood; and the danger was the greater, becaue the Army of the Francks being di-banded, many Souldiers waited for paengers, and either robbed or killed them; But ee how hard a matter it is to
avoid the decrees of Fate: The next morning etting out betimes, and not gone above half a League, we were met by a dozen or fifteen of thee Rovers. At the firt the eemed to begg omething of us; but we no ooner eemed willing to betow omething upon them, but three of the turdiet of them eized upon the bridles of our Hores; and the ret falling pell mell us, pulled us to the ground. Halladiue made as good reitance as he could, and o did Palemon alo, who drawing out his Sword upon a udden, no ooner aw his hand upon his Bridle, but he quite cut off the hand at one blow: But it being a thing impoible for o few to reit o many, epecially o many well armed men who, beides their Swords, had compleat Arms and Daggers; this reitance did but the more incene them, o as they reolved to kill us all. Then they carried us upon the left hand into the thicket part of the wood; where tripping us of all our cloaths, not leaving us o much as our Shirts, they tyed our hands behind us, and then tyed us every one unto a everal Tree. There Palemon found their Barbarity; for he whoe hand he had cut off, being extream impatient of revenge, he no ooner aw tyed, but going unto him; This hand (aid he, and hewed him his right hand) hall punih thee for the los of the other. In aying o, he tabbed him mot inhumanely, five or ix times into the body: He was tyed o near unto me, as I could ee his eyes bid me the lat adieu; for (having handkerchiefs tyed before our mouths leat we hould cry out) we could not peak.

I who thought that Palemon had only got a minutes tart of me, I confes that I anwered him only with my eyes alo, and prepared my oul to follow him without orrow. But I cannot tell whether my age did infue ome repect into thee Rogues, or whether it was my detiny to dye lat; but o it was, that as oon as ever Palemon had given up his lat breath, they turned towards Halladine; and as they were ready to make him feel the fury of their Arms, upon a udden one amongt them, who eemed to have ome command over the ret, did make a ign unto his companions to hold their hands, and that he had omething to ay unto him. Upon this command they tayed, and this man comming nearer Halladine to take away the handkerchief from his mouth, he asked him from whence he came, and from whom? from Roilion, anwered he; and what did you before you came away? (asked the man) I was (aid Halladine) at the Temple: And did none peak unto you? (aid the man) Halladine then thinking a little upon it, no, replied he, none except a young Souldier, who told me he was at the taking of Calice, and having no means to carry him honetly into his own Country, was forced to implore the charity of well-dipoed people: Did you give him any thing? (aid the man) I gave him aid Halladine, a little piece of money, which was all I had about me: Very well (aid the man preently) this hall be either thy life or thy death. In aying o, he turned towards his companions, and perwaded with them o far, as he obtained the life of Halladine; but leat he hould accue them, or make them known, they topped his mouth, blinded his eyes, and untying him from the Tree, they et him upon his hore, wich his face towards the hores tail, his arms tyed behind him, and his leggs tyed under the belly of the hore. In this equipage they let him go, and broke out into extream laughter at him: And whilt they wery thus buie about Halladine, three or four of them were earching in my Pockets for the key of my box, which was behind my Saddle, and preently after, others came to butcher me: But when they were within three or four paces of the Tree where I was tyed, we heard a great out-cry, as of one that was extreamly affrighted: Fear preently began to eize upon them, and not knowing from what caue this noie miget proceed, they preently began to fly away as fat as they could, and the fater, becaue they uppoed that Halladine had brought ome to urprie them.

Thus they were no ooner out of my ight, but turning mine eye towards the place from whence this hideous out-cry came, I epyed through the Trees; one ingle man, whoe affright had made his eyes look wilde and wandring: ometimes he held his hands claped together, ometimes he would lift them
up to his hair, as if he would pull it off: otherwhiles, he would fall down upon his knees, as if he would beg for mercy: afterwards he would rie up again, and run ten or twelve paces as fat as ever he could, till crying out in a mot lamentable tone, and complaining mot pittifully. He was no ooner come near me, but I deired to peak, and intreat his help; but the handkerchief before my mouth would not let me, and beides, I aw him fall down to the ground, without either ene or motion. At firt I thought him dead, but preently after, hearing him breath, as one that was extreamly oppreed in his tomach, I knew that he was till alive.
