Judge, I beeech you, in what condition I was now, and how perplexed I was at his leep, for my fears that thee Rogues would come again and finih their wicked deign, did make me think his leep to be twice as long as it was: for indeed he continued not in this Lethargy above two howers, during which time, I had till for my entertainment, the horrours of a death almot inevitable, and the object of Palemons ad adventure.

In the mean time Halladine was returned to the Town, from whence we came in the morning; for his hore took that way as oon as he felt himelf at liberty: And certainly, it was a pleaant and deplorable patime to behold, for being tark naked, and tied, as I told you before, all the little children followed him, and the people ran in the treets laughing at this odd pectacle; and, I believe, it would have been long before he had found any help, if by Fortune a Sacrificer going unto the Temple, and being ahamed to ee a man in that condition, had not topped his hore, and thrown a long cloak upon Halladine. Preently after, he untied him, and as oon as he could peak, he related unto him the accident which had happened with o many ighs and tears, that the Sacrificer being moved unto compaion, and the people all about him, not being able to endure uch a horrid action, they all preently armed themelves to try if they could apprehend thoe that had unworthily ued him.

This hapned at the ame time when the man who fell down by me in a wound did awaken; and God knows how afraid I was, that he would have continued on his way without relieving me: At lat, by good Fortune he turned his eyes towards me, and eeing me in that condition, near a corps with many wounds, he was o urprized that he tood immoveable, I perceived by his eyes, that leep had ettled his mind, for he did not look o wild and rovingly; but eeing him full of compaion, mixed with amazement, I began to hope that he would take ome pity upon me; and indeed, he came preently to unlooe me, and helped me unto my clothes: I was no ooner dret, but thanking him for the good office he had done me, I told him the whole uccess of our diater. He eemed to be very much concerned at the mifortune of Palemon; and adviing me to return unto the place from whence I came in the morning, to take order for Palemons funeral, he offered to accompany me. I took his councel, and getting upon my hore, I deired him to get upon Palemons, which the Thieves had not carryed away, let, as I believe, he hould have deeryed them: We were no ooner got into the high way, but we met above two hundred perons which Halladine conducted thither. Halladine did think to find me dead, and therefore as oon as ever he aw me, he took me about the neck, and did me a thouand Carrees. After this, we went to the place where Palemon lay, whom we no ooner aw, but Halladine and I were ready to with him for grief.

At lat, having given him an honourable Funeral, we went unto Vienna. There Halladine taking me aide, and telling me how many impediments might happen in the cure of Celidea; he preed me to give Damon that contentment: o as the next morning I took his little bloody ticks, and dreed them as I would have done the wounds themelves.

I doubted not but a preent good effect would follow: for in the compoition of this alve, which I brought in a little box for Olimbres, I had not omitted any ingredient which would not make extreamly ubtil: and by good Fortune, when I came from Carthage, it was not above a month before I had finished that making of it, though it was a whole year before I began it: for beides the oyles which were to be extracted, as the oyl of Flax, and the oyl of Roes, there was yet required
Bol-Armianian, Mans blood, Mummy, Mans greae, and the mos which grows in the cull of a man long expoed to the air. So I had no ooner dreed thoe little ticks, but we parted; and the man who had relieved me, hearing me name Forrets unto Halladine, he beeeched us to let him go with us; but becaue I thought every moment upon the danger from which he had releaed me, as oon as we were got into the way, I asked him as civilly as I could, what good Fortune had brought him thither o opportunely, and from whence proceeded that rapture wherein I aw him? he lifted up his eyes preently to heaven, and afterwards cating them upon me, with a deep igh: Alas (aid he unto me) that which you do call a rapture, is rather a jut punihment which the gods have inflicted upon me, for the expiation of my ins: But ince you deire the dicourse of it, though my dieae be beyond all hopes of cure, I will obey you, provided you permit me to tay no longer upon the relation of it then I deire, left the remembrance of it do drive me into the ame extremities, wherein you aw me: Upon this, whilt Halladine was in deep tudy, ome thirty paces from us, he began his relation thus.

Know, Father, that my name is Azahides: the place of my birth is amongt the Allobroges: My Father was one who ever held a coniderable rank in that Town, which tands upon the Lake of Leman When I was hardly capable of reaon, and when that Province was involved in many troubles, becaue they would take from Gondioch all that he had on this ide the Rhyne, they did put arms into my hands, when I had hardly o much trength as to utain them: After the expiration of ome time, a truce was made, which lated ome yeares: During which, my Father conidering, that he had no child but me for the tay of his Family and age, he reolved to marry me; and o indeed he did unto a very fair and handome wife, whom I kept not above a year, for the died in child-bed after he had left me a daughter, as a pledge of her love. Preently after, the great captain Aetius had the government of Gaul; and renewing the firt deigns which the Romanes had againt us, he prepared himelf for the execution of them. This was the reaon that Abariell (for that was my fathers name) could never keep me with him: for my humour (which found ome particular atifaction in blood and laughter) was tronger them all, the perwaions he ued to hinder me from leaving him: So I parted from him, and until the time that Aetius had command to leave us in peace, I was alwayes in every combate, at the taking of all Towns, and in every dangerous enterprize that was to be executed. One time amongt the ret, much plunder falling to my hare, I gave it all in exchange of a young boy called Silvander, about five or ix yeares of age, and who, they told me, was tollen from ome place beyond the Rhone, and in the Province of Vienna. The apect of this child did pleae me o exceedingly well, as I reolved to give him as good education as poibly I could, and afterwards to take him home unto me, as a man that was obliged unto me for his life. In order hereunto, peace was no ooner concluded, but I ent for him to my houe, and hewed him unto my Father, as the bet booty that ever I got. But here, I beeech you, oberve a very trange effect of divine Providence: This child, whom I detiny'd unto perpetual ervitude, no ooner appeared in my Fathers eye, but conidering the little comfort he had in me, by reaon of my turbulent and tirring Nature, he reolved to bring up this boy, and to etablish upon him the foundation of all his hopes. This reolution was not o cloe, but it came to my knowledge; o as beginning to foreee what might afterwards happen, I began alo to ue all my Art for topping the coure of this growing good will. But all my plots and devices were in vain; for my Father, taking him from me as his own, did end him to the Mailian chools, where he grew o good a proficient, and o every way accomplihed, as for all my envy of him, I could not chue but confee, that my Father could not place his affection upon an object more worthy of eteem. Yet, all my Fathers etate being in his own free dipoition, and fearing left he hould dipoe of it, as well as of his affection, to my diadvantage, I deigned not only to oppoe his Fortune, but againt his life alo, if occaion did offer it self.

In the mean time, the daughter which I had, was no les grown in beauty then he was in body and wit: o as then, being fit for marriage, my Father made a propoition to marry her unto Silvander. And indeed, I took this as an occaion of my revenge: for having commanded my daughter to make my Father believe, that I would never give my conent unto it; and told her, that it was better for her to marry him ecretly; I contrived it o, that poor Silvander appointed a certain hour in the night when he would come, and that he hould come up a rope-ladder in at a window which is over the Lake: At the hour appointed I came into the chamber, I cut the rope when he was half up, and let him fall into the water like a tone, o he was never heard of ince.

You may well judge Father, that though I had no other in but this yet this was enough to merit from the gods a mot evere punihment; but, as if heaven would et me out unto men, as an example of avarice and cruelty, I was loadned with other burthens more heavy and intollerable. Know then, Father, that as oon as Silvander was drown'd, I was the firt that would needs run unto the place where the noie was, and commanding my daughter, upon pain of death, to ay that the cord did break of it elf: I did cat the fault upon the effect, whereof indeed I my elf was the ole caue. My daughter did not fail me, and after I had looked out at the window, I went unto Abariel, and acquainted him with this ad accident. At the firt he broke out into tears and cries, and afterwards finding his orrows to be remediles, he fell into uch a deep wound, as I thought he would have rendred up his pirit: We put him therefore into his bed, where reviving again, he fixed his eyes upon me a long while together: afterwards, with a deep igh ah Azahides (aid he unto me) confes the truth; are not thy plots the caue of this death? Then having compoed my face into a eeming orrow, I anwered no, and that I would ooner have conented unto my own death, then have procured him o much dicontent: Well, well, (replied he) the gods are Judges which cannot be corrupted nor deceived, if thou beet innocent of this crime, I beeech them to pardon thee, as I do all the ret of thy diobedient coures, which thou hat committed againt me; but if thou beet guilty, I beeech them to meaure their punihments according to thy offences. In aying this, his voice began to fail him, and ome of our friends and kindred, who came in upon the noie, did all that poibly they could no comfort him. But he being old and decrepite, he was o feeble to undergo this grief, as we all thought he would not out live that night: which my daughter eeing, he came unto him, and whipered him in the ear a long time together. I was afraid once that he had betrayed me, for he only was a witnes of my wicked act; but certainly, had I thought he would have told him, I would never have uffered her to peak unto him: this made me oberve their motions very exactly, and hould have found, if the dicoure had exaperated him; but on the contrary, the mind of Abariel grew more ettled and trong: yet falling again into his firt weaknes, Daughter (aid he unto her, and took her hand) you ee I have not life enough to atisfie my elf of what you tell me, and therefore I will believe, that this remedy which you would give unto my weaknese, proceeds rather from pity of my pain, then from any truth which obliges you to tell me o. Let me die therefore, dear daughter, and if I have any power over you, go and obey this my lat command: Go this very hour unto my brother (aid he, and pointed unto my uncle) I will leave him enough to ee you well provided for; but above all, never live with your Father again, at leat as little as you can, for he will never be a good example of honour and virtue unto you. Upon this he kied her, and deired my uncle to carry her away, which he did accordingly. Afterwards, turning himelf towards me: I do leave unto you (aid he unto me) that etate which you have o greedily gaped after, I advie you to remember this; That you will never be lee rich, then when you greedily deire to be more. I know not what ecret opinion the gods have inpired into my mind; but I hall die extreamly ill atisfied with your deportment; I pray God all my apprehenions be fale, but if they be true, I will be an eternal torment to thy concience.

Thee words, which he had much ado to utter, were almot the lat he poke:
for he had no ooner pronounced the word Adieu, but his oul expired. This did hake my very oul; for afterwards I eemed to be almot as dead as he, and I began to repent of the crime which I had committed: yet hrowding the reentments of my crime, as well as poibly I could, under thoe teares which I might well hed for the death of a Father, I carryed the matter o well, that in lieu of condemning me, they commended me for the grief I expreed at his death.

I built a very honourable monument for him utable to his quality: as oon as the lat ceremonies were performed, I began to plot how I hould tifle all memory of my fault, imagining that I hould never be at ret as long as there remained any in the World that was able to dicover it: o as I fell almot upon the mot barbarous deign that ever entered into the thoughts of man: and being reolved to trut all things unto your dicretion, I mut tell you that I was upon the point of preparing poyon to give my Daughter, when I heard that they had placed her amongt the Vetals bordering upon the Lake, under the charge of one called Bellinde.

Thus finding my elf at once, without Father without Daughter, but not without ome feares of my treaon againt Silvander to be one day dicovered, I began to enjoy the etate which Abariel left me. But I preently found that my Father was a true prophet, and that there is no man rich which is not contented: for ince the accrue of o great an etate, I found my elf a thouand times poorer then when I had lee. When I thought to put in execution any of thoe deignes which moved me unto a deire of enjoying my Fathers poeions, I found an impoibility in doeing it, eyther in the thing it elf, or in my own humour: for when I wihed my elf mater of an etate that I might make good chear, though I had the etate, yet I wanted the tomack; and ever ince Abariel dyed, I was never preented with any meat which went not againt my appetite: If I wihed it to entertain my friends, I conidered that I had no friend in all the World; for being concious of my crime, I thought all men to be judges, and that my own kindred never came unto me, but to carry me unto condign punihment. Thus finding no peace in any ociety, I betook my elf unto olitude, and in order to that, retired my elf unto a houe which I had in the Country: but which way oever I went, till my in followed me, and gave me no more ret there then in another place: and as if heaven would make my elf my own puniher, nothing did come into my mind for a whole month together; but the thoughts of my crime, and of the punihment which I was to uffer for it. This did o much trouble me as I did by degrees find, that my reaon was lot in the violence of this reentment: for as I aid before, no meat goeing down with a good tomack, the male nourihment which I received by it, helped much to the impairing of my judgment and health. I trove a while againt this growing diease: But the gods whoe hands lay heavy upon me did quickly hew me that they can inflict greater paines upon mortals then the los of their wits and reaon: for one night when I had hut my elf in my Chamber, and laid down upon my bed in hopes to take ome ret, it being long ince I had any, me thought: But why do I ay, me thought, ince what I hall tell you I did hear, I ay I did hear the dore open with a hidious noie: and as oon as I cat my eye that way to ee what the matter was, I aw Abariel bloody in everall places, holding in one hand a candle lighted, and in the other a heart pierced with three or four knives: he had before him one of the furies, and two others on each ide one: all three carrying candles as he did: and armed in their other hands with whips, god knowes how much this fight urpried me, and more his approach for comming to my bed: Azahides (aid he) dot thou ee this heart all pierced and wounded? It is the very ame which the wounds of thy diobedience did murder: and becaue the gods would not have the to loe thy hare of blie in the econd life, they have ent me to punih thee unto repentance in this world, for a crime whereof thy own concience does accue the: after he had aid o, he retired back two or three paces, making a ign unto the furies which accompanied him: They preently eied upon me: and whilt one caued erpents to gnaw upon my bret, another burned me with the candle, and the third did lah me o with a whip, that the more I cryed,
and complained, the more her rage and fury encreaed. I cannot tell what I did not to molifie the oul of my Father; I cat my elf a hundred times at his feet, but when I thought to embrace his legges, I felt nothing but air, becaue he fled from me, fearing (as I think) that my torment would end with his anger: I continued in this torment above an hover; after which, o deep a leep did eie upon me, as it lated untill day: when I wakned, imagining to find my body all marked with the paines that I had endured, I was all amazed, when I found not one ign of any uch torments as I felt. This made me think, that this revenge was divine, ince my oul only reented it: and thinking that acrifices might work ome good effects, I offered many; But for all them my malady continued: o as commonly every eight day, I endured the ame torment; at lat, not being able to live in uch extremity I was inpired to go, and conult with an Oracle, which gave me this anwer.

div.head: The Oracle.
div.l: GO, Azahides, unto a place which Neptune
Was contrained to forake:
There a tranger peaking of thy Fortune
Shall make the Nymphes atonihed:
But mark my words, for never think
Thy torments, Azahides, ere hall end.
Unto the ame who makes thee culpable
Of homicide, hall ee and pardon thee.

div.p: This Oracle (out of which I could not collect any thing, but that I hould nere be cured untill he whom I had killed did ee me, and had pardoned my crime) did put me into uch a confuion, as in effect eeing it altogether impoible, my fury augmented: Yet an old prophet telling me that I mut never dipair in the goodnes of the gods, and that if ever I found any remedy it would be only in Forrets, my pirit was a little calmed. I et forward therefore immediatly: and was no ooner entred into the wood where I found you yeterday but I aw the ame Abariel again with the ame furies, jut in the way in which was to go; I ran preently into the thick of the wood in hopes to avoid meeting this dimall object: but he quickly overtook me, and as if my flight offended him, I was never o much tormented as I was then; This was the caue of that tranport, and rapture wherein you aw me, which moved you unto as much compaion as admiration, and which made me to cry out as you did hear: glad I am that it did produce o good an effect as the aving of your life, and it hall be the more pleaing to me as long as I live.

This (aid Olicaris) was all that Azahides told me there; And though I did abolutly believe that all this fury was only an effect of an imagination extreamly wounded, yet I could not chue but judge, upon the ight of the Oracle which he made me read two or three times over, that it would be very difficult to find a remedy againt his dieae. And indeed, as we were walking together in this wood, this tranport took him again, and forced him unto uch trange actions, as it was impoible to ee him without abundance of horror, and extream pity.

Adamas did harken all this while with extream attention; The gods (aid he) are o jut and good, as they do never inflict more mieryes upon men, then they give power to upport them: This may be een in Azahides, who for all his furious torments yet ubits: Now you mut know, that this Silvander whom he thinks to be dead is not o: for being advertied by his own Daughter of the treaon indented againt him, he tyed his own clothes fall of and unto the rope, and when he heard them fall into the water, he ecaped away.

This made me conceive, that of what quality oever his dieae was, whether
in imagination or otherwie, it may be peedily cured, ince Silvander, who has been many months in this Country, will certainly look kindly upon him, and not deny him the pardon, upon which the cure depends: Thus do we ee the full accomplihment of the Oracle, ince this is the place where Neptune quitted, when Caear did cut a Mountain, through which the waters which over-flowed all this Country, did run out: And you are the tranger the relation of whoe fortune did amaze the Nymphs; for mot of thee whom you ee here in the habit of Shepherdees, are indeed the Nymphs of Amais, the Lady and Mitris of thee Provinces.

Olicaris was extreamly urpried, and contented both, at the Druids dicoure, and beeeched him to make as much hate as he could, that Azahides might receive o great a benefit: Therefore Adamas entreating Celadon to go and fetch Silvander; That Shepherd found him walking another walk, with Lycydas, Doris, Adrates, and ome others, not preuming to come where Roanira and Galathea was, leat he hould interrupt them. As soon as Celadon related unto him part of what he had heard, and having brought him unto Adamas, Azahides, returned out of his Lethargy, who eeing o much company o neer him, offered to go away; But Olicaris and Adamas, tayed him, and after ome dicoure, did let him undertand, that his torments were now near their end; unto which Azahides giving no credit, they preented Silvander unto him, whom he preently knew, though he was much changed as well in condition as habit, who protrating himelf before him, he did nothing a long while but hed tears, at the memory of what he had attempted againt his person: At the lat, Silvander embraced him with much repect, and did o freely Forgive him that offence, as he was comforted in his mind, o as carrying this news unto his daughter, who was confined amongt the Vetals, he never was troubled in mind with thoe torments any more.

The Relation of Olicais, and that which had hapned unto Celadon, unto Silvander, unto Atrea, and unto Diana, as well at the Fountain of Verity, as ince they were brouget unto the houe of Adamas, had taken up o much of the day, as it was almot night when Amais, who was already come unto the Pallace of Ioures, did end a Coach unto Galathea, that he might come thither with Roanira, Dorinde, and the ret of the company.

The Druid, who was in hopes of their company that night, was very orry orry that Amais had debatred him of that happines; yet not daring to complain, becaue obedience vnto the Nymph was but his duty, he conented unto their departure; and waiting upon them part of the way, he beeeched them to honour him with their return the next day: Galathea promied to ask permiion, and afterwards eeming very orry that he had not time enough to talk with Atrea, he went away fully reolved to emply her endeavours to ee her again.

As oon as they came unto Amais, they gave her an exact accompt of all that they had een; and after they had told how much the Inchantment had affrighted them, they told her thot the god of love was to pronounce ome Oracles, and commanded that they hould come and conult with him: This Novelty made the Nymph very deirous to be preent, o as without Galatheas mention of her promie, he commanded to make all things ready, that he might go unto the houe of Adamas, very early in the morning.

Merindor was come from Mount Brion with the Nymph; and becaue he aid he was ent from Sigimond, Dorinde received him as kindly as he could, though he retained till a freh memory of his behaviour towards her: But at this time forgetting all his levity, he bad him welcome; and after Supper, imagining that he durt not not talk of any thing but of the Princes bu •• nes, he gave him uch opportunity of peech with her, as he had time enough to acquit himelf of all that he had in commiion.

Adamas on the other ide, to whom the joys of Celadon was an incomparable contentment, he returned unto the company he left in the Garden; but there hapned to be a change ince he went: For Doris being acquainted with
the death of Palemon, he fell into uch extreamities of griefs, and complaints, as would have moved a tone to compaion. Adrates eemed to be no les greeved then he; and when he conidered that he was the principal caue of that Shepherds death, he could not imagine any thing that was able to comfort him. The Druid thinking he could not do a more charitable office, then to comfort them in their orrows, he took Doris in one hand, and Adrates in the other; and betwixt that place and the houe, he gave them uch cordial Language, as he much allayed the adnes of their ouls, and put them into hope, that as the gods had ent this ad affliction upon them, o certainly out of their goodnes, they would end them comforts. In the mean while, the ighs of Doris, did blow that fire more vehement, which love had long ince kindled in the heart of Adrates: And the tears which that Shepherd hed at the ad reentments of Doris, were o pleaing unto that afflicted Shepherdes, as they erved for a kinde of comforts and eae, unto the pain which he endured.

When Adamas found that his perwaions had a good opperation with them, he left them, and went to ee Bellinde, who was already returned unto the Chamber of Atrea, and Diana: And becaue he feared that if all this company went to viit them, it would be but troubleome to them, he thought it expedient, that none hould ee them till the next morning: Therefore he commanded Paris to wait upon Celadon, Silvander, and the ret into their Chambers, and advied them to be all in readines the next morning, to go and hear the Oracles which the God of Love was to pronounce: Paris was obedient unto this command; and though he had great deire to ee Diana, yet he durt not ask permiion, imagining, that ince Celadon could not ee Atrea, Adamas would not grant unto him more priviledge then unto the other. Bellinde found Diana in a very joyful condition; for the return of Phillis, and the report which he made of Silvanders health, had almot retored her freh complexion into her cheecks; o as after he had rejoyced a while with the Druide, he retired, full of joy that Diana promied her to rie the next morning. Adamas alo, after a while of dicoure with them, he went unto his Chamber, and deired Phillis, and Leonide to lye in the Chamber of Atrea and Diana, that in cae they hould need any help, Leonide might erve them.

Thus every one depoed themelves to ret that night; and the lat that retired themelves was Adrates and Doris; for that hepherd fe ring leat Doris hould upect his greif, and think ome craft, diguied under that veile, he addreed himelf unto her, and looking upon her with an eye that poke the orrows of his oul; Siter (aid he unto her) If my griefs for the death of Polemon, be not the greatet, and the mot real that ever I reented, may I eternally perih. I know my elf guilty of his death, and that but for me, he had till been happy in your love and company: Now in ome ort to atifie the ghot of that dear husband, which Adrates has ravihed from you; It is mot jut I hould punih my elf, and that I eparate my elf from that peron who only can give me any conolation or delight, which peron is your elf. Dear Brother (anwered Doris, with tears in her eyes) Adrates indeed is partly the caue of Palemons death; but for all that, I think it extream in jutice to punih him for it, becaue he did engage himelf voluntarily unto that fatal voyage, and do what I could, I could not divert him from it: Alas, alas, how oft have I feared this mifortune which hath befaln him; It eems as if ome ecret Genius did tell me of the accident; for truly never did any day nor night pas, but either my thoughts or my dreams did menace it: You know it Adrates, you you have een it in my face ince you returned; and for all the good hopes that you gave me, I had till ome ecret fears, which told me, that I hould never ee him again: Ah my dear Palemon (continued he) how fatal a paage were all my orrows at thy departure, of thoe afflictions which were afterwards to fall upon me: Dear Palemon—at this word her peech failed, for her tears and ighs took it away: And Adrates, whoe grief was no les violent, beginning to peak; Fair Doris (aid he unto her (me thinks I find too deep reentment
in your grief: you ought to punih the Author of your diater, and hew me how farre the revenge of a wronged woman can go. It was I that have robd you of Palemon; let mee feel the fury of your anger: If you have not reolution enough to command me unto death, yet command me unto an eternal banihment; for that will be no lee then a death unto mee: But I hall obey, though I hall never finde any delight in the converation of men, ince I am deprived of him whom I loved bet, and whoe affection was dearer unto mee then my life.

Alas (anwered Doris with a deep igh) though I hould be o evere, as to banih you from eeing mee, yet my grief for Palemons death, would not be the lee: Neither your abence nor your death, can make him alive again, nor ever cure mee: I would not therefore have you abent your elf, but on the contrary I hope that your preence will be ome comfort unto mee epecially becaue in eeing you I hall imagine that I do ee omething of him; for it may be aid in point of friendhip, you were both one. All that I deire from you, deare Adrates, is, That you will not go beyond thoe limits which I hall precribe unto your affection: and that loving mee in the degree of a iter, you will never dioblige mee unto any other will then to take you as a brother. This was the injunction of Doris, unto which Adrates would not promie obedience; for hee knew not whether it was in his power to obey: hee vowed to erve her eternally, and having made the ame vow long ince, hee would oberve it unto the lat minute of his life.

After this they parted; and when the God of leep did ummon them to take their ret, they diobeyed, and pent almot all the night with their own thoughts. Doris hee mued upon the diater which had hapned unto her, and in the dark deired a thouand times that the Ghot of Palemon would appeare before her eies as well as in her memory: Darknee was not o horrid unto her as the conideration of this loe, and when hee conidered that it was without a remedy, this did almot kill her with grief. Amidt thee ad imaginations, Love did ometimes repreent unto her thoughts the paion of Adrates, to make her enible of that hepherds fidelity. Then did Doris a little repent hee had commanded him to love her only in the degree of a iter: but preently thinking thoe thoughts in ome ort offenive unto the love which he ought to preerve for Palemon, and that it would be a wrong unto him, to admit of any harer with him, hee tifled all thoe thoughts in their birth, and repelled all thoe arrowes wherewith it eems Love would have wounded her the econd time. Adrates on his ide, amongt all his orrowes for the loe of his friend, hee began to conceive a ecret hope that hee hould one day enjoy that happinee for which hee had already uffered o many mieries: But for all the joyes wherewith this weet imagination did flatter him, hee diputed with himelf, whether his orrowes for the loe of Palemon were not greater then the joyes hee had in conceiving ome right of pretene unto his Mitree. Day had almot urpried him in this Combate, for it was very late before hee lept: but had hee lept only one minute, yet had hee done more then the Druid did, who was o ill atified with Merindors dicoure, that being extreamly tung with anger and pite, hee was not able to cloe an eye. Shee pent all the night in plotting how to be revenged for the injury which hee thought was done her. But Atrea and Diana reted better: For the paines they had endured the day before, and the little leep which they had of two or three nights before, did now caue, them to leep oundly untill it was broad day.

Adamas, Bellinde, Celadon, Silvander, and the ret of the Shepherds, did rie almot at the firt bluh of Aurora, and had no ooner et all things in order; but Amais came, bringing with her Roanira, Galathea, Madonthe, Daphnide; Silvia, and the afflicted Dorinde, who carried in her face all the ignes of dipleaure. A while after, Leonide, Atrea, Diana, and Phillis came out of their chamber: Likewie all the hepherds of the neighbouring townes arrived, and came purpoely to wait upon the Grand Druid. When all was ready, Amais went out the firt, and took Bellinde by the hand, with whom hee talked concerning
the worhip of the gods, which was the particular profeion unto which he was called: Dorinde, he faigned hee elf indipoed, and deired the Nymph to leave her the coach, to the end, that in cae he found her elf better, he might follow after them: Roanira, Daphnide, and Madonth • , mixed themelves with Leonide, Phillis, and Licidas: Adrates took care of Doris: Hylas and Thamires would needs wait upon Stella and Celidea; and all the ret of the Shepherds and Shepherdees did follow in a troop together. Adamas would be with Silvander, and that poor Shepherd eeing himelf forced to yield unto Paris the entertainment of Diana, he was all the way o melancholly and ilent, that the Druide could not get one good word from him. Galanthea, fully reolved to imploy well the time that he had to tay with Atrea, he took her in one hand; and becaue he would not quite take her away from her dear Celadon, he took that Shepherd in the other.

Thus all this great company went from the houe of Adamas, to hear the Oracle which the God of Love was to pronounce; and certainly it was a mot pleaant ight, to ee them in this order, and the beauty of their perons, for Atrea, who had now nothing to trouble her, he trimmed up her elf, with all the graces that either Nature or Art could ue to imbellih • face: her eyes were not red and welled as they were wont to be, when her orrows kept them in a perpetual moiture; but they were as clear, as parkling, as that Planet which gives both light and life unto the whole Univere: her hair did not hang o looe and carelely, as when all her thoughts were how to preerve Celadon: but now it was et in uch lovely order, as every curl was able to captivate a world of hearts: upon her head was a Garland of everal flowers, and though they were the fairet of the eaon, yet were they ahamed to ee themelves o far urmounted by the luter of that complexion which was in their cheeks. In fine, this Shepherdes appeared o fair in the eyes of Galathea, as that Nymph, thinking he never had een o perfect a beauty, he began to excue the didain of Celadon, and to think, that after he had burned in o glorious a fire, it was not poible he hould be touched with any other flame.

Celadon, for his part, he appeared the handomet and mot lovely Shepherd that ever was een upon the banks of Lignon; the memory of his diguiement, and many other accidents of his life, did bring uch bluhes into his cheeks, and tempered his complexion with uch luter, as Galathea had much ado to preerve that fidelity which he had worn unto Lindamor: he had never een o many charms in the eyes of that Shepherd, as he oberved now; and calling to memory the condition wherein he firt aw him and relieved him: O heavens (aid he in her elf) if this Shepherd had then had o many darts in his face as now I ee, in lieu of being in love with him, I hould have downright died. In this thought, he never removed her eye off him, unles to look ometimes upon Atrea; and when he left looking upon Atrea, it was only to admire the comelines of Celadon. Thus, in this pleaing buines, he went diputing in her elf, which of them two was mot worthy to be loved; but finding them to be equally exact and perfect, and not being able to find any difference, but in their clothes, which ditinguihed their exes, he confeed, that they had no advantage of each other; and that love was mot jut in uniting the ouls of two o fair and virtuous bodies.

Thus they went on a while without peaking one word: but whilt Galathea was ravihed in her thoughts of them, the thoughts Atrea and Celadon were no le buied. For that Shepherd conidering, that but for the Nymph, he had enjoyed the happines of holding Atreas hand, and talked unto her of his love: O Galathea (aid he to himelf) will you eternally oppoe my happinee? your preence is perpetually prejudicial unto me. Then looking upon her, and afterwards upon Atrea; and that Shepherdes eeing Galathea to be very fair, he preently began to think of the dicoure he had with Adamas, concerning this Nymphs affection unto Celadon; and amongt her joyes, to know that the fidelity of her Shepherd could not be haken, he yet rai • ed a tincture of jealouie, and feared, left he hould at that intant become enible of thoe charms which
formerly he had dipied; yet ince this thought had no good foundation, o it did not long continue, and if her ighs did tetifie any of this jealouie unto Celadon, he preently miled upon him to tetifie her repentance; probably, they had gone all the way without any entertainment but their own thoughts, if Galathea had not at lat broke this long ilence: For Celadon and Atrea, whoe tongues were out of repect tied, they durt not preume to begin any dicoure; and eeing they could not talk of their own interets, they cared not to talk of any thing ele.

But the Nymph clearing up her voice, and addreing her elf unto the Shepherd • s: Well, fair Atrea (aid he unto her) I dare ay you are in a mot pleaing rapture, ince Celadon is the ubject of it. Madam (anwered Atrea) I do not think, that where you are, one can admire any thing but you: not but the preence of that Shepherd is very dear unto me, but if you do oberve any extraordinary motion in me, I beeech you be not offended if I ay, that you only are the caue of it. I beeech you, fair Shepherdes (replied Galathea) let us lay aide all artifice, and as you ee that my habit now does not eparate me from your quality, o treat me with the ame freedome and affection that you do Phillis or Diana: be not afraid to trut me with your thoughts, for aure your elf, that be they as ecret as poible, if you make me your confident, I will never betray you.

Madam (replied Atrea) I hould think my elf extreamly bold, hould I entertain you with any of my follies, I know it to be a kind of crime, if I hould dare only to cat my eyes upon you: your high quality, and as high merit, forbids me any uch free accee; and without your expree command, I durt not tay o long near your peron. I vow unto you, dear Atrea (aid the Nymph) I would have you treat me as a Shepherdes; and you will extreamly dipleae me, if you will not let us enjoy our elves with all ingenious freedome: I came hither yeterday purpoely for it, and the accidents of the day would not let me ee you; but now, when there is nothing that interrupts, and all things contribute to this contentment, let us, my dear Atrea, enjoy; and I would not have you hide any thing from me, dicover the ecrets of your oul freely unto me. Atrea, eeing her elf obliged to atisfie the commands of the Nymph, he firt bluh'd and afterwards anwered her thus.

Alas, Madam, there is nothing in my life remarkable, but that which relates unto the love which Celadon has profeed unto me; nor do you enquire of me, but indeed of him. But alas, fair Nymph, why hould you enquire of me, ince I have more reaon to enquire of you concerning Celadon, Galathea, who had never entred into this dicoure, but only that he might have an occaion to tell her what he had done for her Shepherd he found by her anwer, that he was already informed, and never mitruting Adamas, he thought that Celadon had given her the relation of it. Turning her elf then towards him, Celadon (aid he) you are a Tattler; but good Shepherd tell me truly, when you entertained your Mitres with the dicoure of your being at Ioures, did you commend me for my aitance, or did you condemn me for my love? Celadon would have anwered, but Atrea, fearing he hould ay he never told her any thing, interupted him: Madam, replied he, when Celadon told me of the good office which you did him, he poke of you only as a Princes unto whom he was obliged for his life; and if he did at any time peak of the mind you had unto him, it was only in confeing himelf unworthy of the honour which you did him. Upon thee words, the Shepherd did undertand what was Atreas deign, and therefore interrupting them: Madam (aid he unto Galathea) how great oever my ingratitude be, I cannot deny but that your aitance did recue me out of the arms of death; and becaue that favour was no lee advantageous unto this fair Shepherdee then unto my elf, ince it preerved the life of a man, who loves and honours her above all the world, I did acquaint her with the circumtances of it, to the end, the he having the ame interet, might alo be obliged in the ame ingratitude. Indeed, fair Atrea (aid the Nymph) but for me you had never een Celadon again; and as he is a debtour unto me for his life, o are you
a debtor unto me for all the contentments you hall ever receive from his love, and ervices:

Tis true thoe admirable features in his face, that weet grace in his deportment, and all the excellent qualities of his mind, are the gifts of nature: But after that fatall accident which did precipitate him unto Lignon, if my pity, or rather my love, had not preerved him; all thoe features, and graces, and ornaments of his body and mind, had been lot, and you out of hopes ever to enjoy any of thoe delights which his fidelity did promie unto you: Madam (anwered Atrea) I am but too well informed of thoe favours which you have done unto Celadon: and though I was then rather an obtacle unto your deires, then any object to make you pity him, yet now I do acknowledge my elf infinitly obliged in the behalf of that hepherd; And I do wih it were in my power to render him unto you; for of all innes, I do mot hate, that of ingratitude; my fairet Mitree (added Celadon) the benefits which I have received from this fair Nimph are of uch a nature as can never be paid.

They are not uch (replied Galathea) but may eaily be acquitted: and if you have a mind, I will hew you how. Madam (anwered Astrea) there is nothing in the world, but I would do it, to content you, ele may I not live one munite longer: and for my part (aid Celadon) I do protet, there is no command which I will not obey unles it do contradict that love which I do bear unto the fair Atrea. That which I do require (aid Galathea) and turned her elf towards Celadon) is only to make your joyes the fuller: and therefore know hepherd, and you fair Atrea alo, that I hall think my elf fully recompenced for all I have done, if you will this day olemnly wear before me, that the union betwixt you hall be inviolable; and that no accident whatoever hall be able to eperate your wills: I have heretofore feared this alliance as the greatet misfortune that ever could happen unto me: but now I wih and deire it, as the greatet advantage I can receive from you. Great Nimph (anwered Celadon) this which you require, do only depend upon the will of that hepherdes, and not of me; and as for my part, I protet and wear by that can make an oath inviolable, that I will adore her eternally; and were I not concious of my own demerits, I would this very munite, vow my elf hers in that quality, and vow with all to oberve it for ever. I do accord unto this vow which Celadon hath made (aid Atrea,) and I wear Madam, by the power which you have over me, never to fail in what is due unto his love, and your commands. Upon this he was ilent: ince o (aid the Nimph, and embraced them both) let this be the firt tetimony of it, and Atrea, give Celadon a kis; in earnet of that ecret marriage which you have now contracted, and of which the gods, and I am witnees. Astrea would have anwered; But Celadon even ravihed with that happines which Galathea would procure for him, did withall poible hat kie her, leat he hould oppoe that felicity. Thus this hepherd did kie her, as with uch infinity delight as if he would have left his oul upon the lips of his fairet hepherdes, and Atrea was o ahamed of this favour which he had granted him as he hardly poke one word in an hovre after.

Mean time Paris entertained Diana with dicoure: and becaue he knew not any other reaon that he had to be o forward in dying then the affection he bore unto her Companion: fairet Diana (aid he unto her) is it in the happines of Atrea, that I mut expect the beginning of mine? untill now your reitance has been uch as was able to tagger the the contancy of any other but mine: but now that hepherdes may well erve for your example to accept of your ervants good will, and betow your affection upon me: upon this, he began to igh; and eeing Diana did not anwer: Oh fairet Mitree (continued he) your everity to me, is as rigorous as ever, and as inupportable; I have erved you by your own permiion, and courted you by your own commands; The gods, Adamas and Bellinde, are all conenting unto my good fortune: your own cruelty is the only impediment; Oh the torments I have endured, ince the flight of Atrea? Tortures and racks are not o harp: and yet I find no park of compaion in you, and hould I compare your heart, and marble together I
think, the marble the more enible of the two. In aying o, his eyes were ready to guh out into teares, which caued him to be ilent, and to take his handkercher: So as Diana, eeing her elf obliged in civility, and repect, to ay omething, and having no mind to drive him into dipair, as well becaue he had ome little inclination to him, as becaue he feared her denial would incene Bellinde, he turned towards him with a miling apect; age Paris (anwered he) what you are pleaed to call rigour in me, is rather an argument of that eteem I have of you, then of any ill will: I have often told you, that my conciounee of my own mall merits, is the reaon of that reervednee wherein I have lived conceiving that without too much preumption, I could not pretend unto any farther then ome hare in your friendhip: but ince what I thought to be an effect of my duty, is termed coldnee and cruelty, I will hereafter become more free, upon condition you will aure me, that for three whole dayes, you will not olicite my Mother for the accomplihment of our marriage. I do ask this term only for my conolation, after which we hal be both atisfied according to your own deires. Diana had much a do to make this anwer, but etting uch a face upon it as might bet hide her deign he perfectly contented Paris, who not knowing that he took this term only to invent ome way to deliver her elf from the tiranny of Bellinde: he verily believed that at the end of the three dayes he would conent to marry him; Therefore he gave her thanks, as for the greattet favour he could do him: and kiing her hand: fairet Mitree (aid he unto her,) not only thee three dayes, but alo all my life, I hall be yours in all love and obedience.

This was the dicoure which Diana, and Paris had together, whilt Adamas in his talk with Silvander did all that he poibly could, to dicover from whence that grief which he found in the face of that hepherd did proceed: and becaue he had already oberved ome ecret paages betwixt Diana and him, he harped much upon that tring, but found Silvander o cold, or rather dicreet, as he could gather no atisfaction from thence; Therefore he changed his dicoure: and therefore conceiving that he might give in generall that conolation which he was reolved to apply unto a perticular ubject; Sage Silvander (aid he unto him) do not think it trang if out of an inquiitive curioity I do intrude my elf into your affaires; you know that we are naturally enible of their interets whom we love; o as having a mot particular affection unto you, I mut needs be extreamly deirous to know from whence thoe dipleaures which I have oberved in you, do proceed; Revered Sir, anwered Silvander, the affection which you ay you have unto me, does proceed from that compaion which makes men enible of the mieries of one another: and though in this, you do no more for me then is common unto all mierable people, yet am I extreamly obliged unto you, and wih that the gods had as much pity upon me as you have. The gods, replied Adamas, will do according as they pleae, and not alwayes as we deire: yet not that our condition is ere the wore becaue all that they do is for our good: but commonly we do judge according unto our unruly paions, which will not let us waite with patience for that uccee which they would give unto our deires; Hence it is, that many in complaining of their misfortunes do murmure againt heaven. But as oon as the un of Properity begins to hine upon them, then they begin to repent they ever accued heaven, or dipaired of help, this makes me to ay that a well tempered pirit ought to be alwayes equall and alike, and both in adverity, and properity et the ame face: Believe it Silvander (but you know it as well as I) this leon is not o hardly learnt, as is thought: a good courage will mater all manner of paions: and remember, that to ubmit all unto the good will of the gods, is undiputably the bet document a man can learn, and the greatet ecret of life. I do know Sir (replied Silvander) how great the imbecillity of men is, nor am I ignorant of the omnipotency of the gods; I have equally had experience of both, and without looking any farther then my own elf, I can find mot remarkable examples of it: if I have not o much power over my own oul as to keep it from inking under the blows of fortune, it is not that I am ignorant of my duty, or that I do not mot humbly ubmit
unto the will of the Gods: But this great imbicelity whereof I peak, and which is almot intollerable to humanity, does make me indipoed unto any good conideration.

Upon this, Silvander was ilent, and Adamas would have poke, but upon a udden he heard a great cry, and aw Amais running to him as fat she could: This accident did very much amaze him, and enquiring to know the coue, Oh (aid the Nymph) do you not ee the Nymphs ready to divorce us; for Heavens ake let us fly away as fat as we can: In aying o, he began to run; but the Druid taying her: Madam (aid he) they cannot hurt you, and unles you be afraid of Marble, you have no reaon to ran away. How? Marble? (aid Amais) do you not ee them move near us? At this Adamas could not chue but laugh to ee what effects fear had wrought in the fancy of the Nymph: and turning himelf towards her, Madam (aid he) I will be your warrant, and I believe Galathea will warrant me.

Amais then looking upon her, and eeing that neither he, nor any of the ret were afirighted, he began to take courage; but as oon as ever Adamas told her how thoe Animals came to be metamorphized, Truly, aid he, I do not more wonder at the Miracle, then at Galathea, in her dicoure yeterday of the Inchantment, hould never acquaint me with this particular; after this he was perfectly recollected; and being but a little ditant from the Fountain, The Druid, leaving the company, he advanced almot cloe to the Cloud which hung over it: Then falling down upon on his knees, and all the company after his example doing the like, he began this Prayer unto the God of Love.

OH thou Son of Venus, adored Deity, whoe Empire is above, and over all, and inveterate enemy of confuion; We beeech thee, as thou didt Chaos, o dispel all thee diorders, and this Enchantment: It is not any curioity that brought us hither, but thy own command; o as having appointed this day, Let our obedience excue our neceity of making this voyage: Pronounce, Oh God of Love, out of pity pronounce what thou hat detined in favour of thee Groves: And as the glory of pleaing thee is the only object which we do propoe unto our elves; So let our contentment be the ubject of thy Anwers.

This Prayer being ended, Adamas returned to the place where the Troop was; and then a little wind did arie, which wated unto our ears the noie of tirredwaters: Preently after, the wind grew more boiterous, and comming only by blats, it brought with it great flahes, like to Lightning, which had but an intant between their beginning and ending; many affrightning clapps of Thunder followed: Then upon a udden, the Cloud above the Fountain opening, one might ee come out by degrees, in the midt of the water, a huge Baon of Japer, upon a Pedetal of Porphery, mot curiouly enriched, upon which the God of Love hewed himelf, in the ame form as before he appeared.

At the ight of this Deity, Reverence invited every one to look down; but afterwards, Curioity raiing up their looks, they aw that the God of Love held in his left hand a great Azure Table, in which were written thee words, in Letters of Gold.

lg.l: Since Alexis is the faithful Female Lover
Whom the Gods required; Receive Celadon that
Happines which Heaven does offer unto thee.
Atrea is the Reward of all thy Pains; And
That heart which hath o long mutinyed againt thee,
Shall never more oppoe thy Contancy.

div.p:
Adamas, and the ret of the company had no ooner read thee words, but
they heard a murmur, and a noie, like to the clapping together of many hands: It was an Emblem of that joy which all the Shepherds, and Shepherdees did reent for the happines of Atrea, and Celadon.

At that intant, the Shepherd did loe the memory of all the mieries he had endured; and not knowing how he hould enough thank the God of Love for that happines which now he aw infallible; he lifted up his eyes to Heaven, and not being able to peak one word, his face changed colour two or three times: Atrea received no les contentment; Phillis was even ravihed with joy; and Diana her elf did find ome comfort unto her orrows, in thoe delights which were promied unto her companion; But as the greatet felicities may ometimes be taken for a preage of ome future great misfortune, by reaon of that link which does ineparably tye adverity and properity together: So this joy did not long continue in their countenances: For after the God of Love had given them time to ee his pleaure in this Table, preently he turned it, and in lieu of Golden Letters written in Azure, they aw in a Silver Table written in black Characters, thee words.

q.l: THe Dooms of detiny mut be obeyed:
Silvander mut dye, and leave Diana unto Paris
And Adamas, though this Lover be dear unto thee;
Yet I command thee to acrifice this Shepherd
Tomorrow; and let him dye by thy hand.

div.p: The Heavens began to Thunder again, and upon a udden the Clouds and the Tables vanihed. This command did o extreamly atonih all the company, that it was long before one word was poken; Every one did in their very ouls lament the los of this Shepherd; for he having lived in a Country where the people et an eteem upon virtue, Silvander could ay that he never raied any envy, or enemy againt him: But a midt this common affliction which which might well be called a jut reentment of pity, Diana was moved in a far different manner: For the God of Love had dooned the death of Silvander in uch a dimal manner, as he reolved to to precede him, or at the leat not to urvive him one minute, for whoe ake he only deired to live.

Yet leat her too much tranport, hould be an obtacle unto her deigne, he conceal'd her orrows with o great a contraint, that Silvander himelf was deceived by it. This poor Shepherd, after he had een the doom which the God of Love had pronounced againt him, he mildly cat his eyes upon her, and his grief not to poes her whom he loved be • t, was a caue that he could not chue but accompany his looks with ome ighs. Diana took them with an incomparable contancy, and not o much as changing colour, he hewed him more marks of amazement in her face, then love; of which the Shepherd was no les enible, then of that entence which condemned him to dye: Yet till retaining in his memory thoe tetimonies of affection which he had hewed unto him, he found preently after, that it was no defect of love in her, ince commonly the deeret orrows end forth fewet tears.

Adamas in this extreamity, knew not what to do; ometimes he looked upon Silvander, and ometimes turned towards the Fountain, as if he hoped the God would revoke this doom I yet till eemed o atonihed as if he had thought it pronounced againt himelf, and not Silvander.

Hylas, was now put by the byas of his merry humour; and though he did not meet with any greater oppoer of himelf by way of Argument, yet did he grieve for him, and made it appear that he was a lover of virtue, and did eteem it whereoever he did meet with it.

Lycidas, Thamiros, Adrates, and the ret, did not know what countenances to put on, and Celadon himelf did forget all his caues of joy. Thus in this univeral atonihment, and common ilence, no noie was to be heard but ighs, which plainly poke the orrows of all the people: But Silvander, preing through the company, went to the Fountain; where kneeling down, and
hewing a countenance of courragious reolution. Oh God of Love, (aid he in in a loud voice) which dot envy my fedelity, I do give thee thanks for the care thou hat taken in making me to dye o gloriouly; I know very well that as death is to tryumph over me, o Paris is to tryumph over Diana; but ince my mean birth cannot dipute with him for the victory, I cannot think that any command could come from a more puiant God: Here I am, Great God, ready to obey thee; And ince the doom is irrevocable, in ordaining me to live till to morrow, may the Sun turn his hours into munites, and haten his return for my ake. After this he roe up, and whilt all the company oberved his behaviour, and whilt Paris himelf was greeved to the oul that he could not be happy but by the ruine of that Shepherd, he went unto Adamas, and eeing him in great atonihment; Father (aid he unto him) cheer up; we now know the will of the Gods, and that this Fountain mut be drenched with my blood if the Inchantment end: Come, come, why tay we here any longer? Son, anwered Adamas, with a deep igh; The Gods do hew no les rigor ununto me, in letting me live, then in hindring you: In aying o, he turned about, and all the company doing the like, they all began to et forward towards the houe.

In their return, every one went in confuion: Atrea thinking upon nothing but the misfortune of her friend, he left Celadon to the dicretion of Galathea: Phillis was o adly concerned, that Lycidas himelf deired her to go and give what aitance he could unto Diana, in that extreamity; o being about that Shepherdes, and a little eparated from the company, becaue they would not be heard, Phillis was the firt that poke, and after he had looked up to Heaven: I profes (aid he) I cannot enough admire at o many accidents by which the Gods do diturb the tranquility of our lives; we do never gut any pleaure one ingle day; but as oon as ever we have any caue of joy, ome trange diater or other does blat it. Siter, (anwered Diana very adly) the Gods have now done their wort, and ince they have thus aaulted the innocency of Silvander, it is probable they will not pare one of us: The truth is, ( • aid Atrea and interrupted) This Shepherd moves me to abundance of compaion; I have narrowly oberved the whole coure of his life; and when I do particularly conider the ucces of it, I cannot chue but admire his contancy, and think his detinies too evere. The fairet things (replied Diana, with tears in her eyes) are often oonet blated; and therefore I do not o much wonder at Silvanders fate, although I do mot adly reent it: For though (as they ay) the Gods cannot erre, yet I cannot chue but think them ometimes jealous, and do envy us mortals when we have any thing amongt us that is execllent; ele what reaon could they have to take from us this poor Shepherd: had he ever neglected their ervice; had he ever been negligent in looking to his flocks; had hee been guilty of Paricide, or had lived in a mot precie obervation of all Laws, both divine, and humane, I could not have told what to have aid: But Lignon I believe never aw a more wie Shepherd then he; You know how excellently he has often dicoured in matters of Divinity; how repective he has been unto all: his Flocks were always the bet liking in all the plain; and how could he commit Paricide, ince he never knew his Parents? No, no? my companions, they could never detect him of any crime, unles making me in love with him; but thy hould they punih him for that, ince I never complained againt him? Siter, replied Phillis, If the Gods do punih him, for winning your Love, it is only becaue that affection is contrary unto what you owe unto Paris; for you ee, it is their poitive wills you hould marry him; and were I in your condition, I would conent unto it, provided they would let Silvander live. Siter anwered Atrea, the Gods ure not to be capitulated withall; and I believe there is ome deep mytery in this, which we undertand not; and that Silvander having lived mot of his age out of Forrets, there may be ome other reaon which caueth his death: not but that I do extreamly lament him, and would with the los of my blood redeem him; but ince the misfortune is irrevocable, I conceive the bet way is to obey without murmur, whatoever the Gods ordain
and concerning either him or us. How iter? (aid Diana and was a little troubled) would you advie me to give my elf unto Paris, and betray my fidelity unto Silvander? I would advie you (aid Atrea) to give unto Silvander as much as you can, which is your reentment of his misfortune; and unto Paris what you ow unto him, which is obedience unto the commands of the gods, and Bellinde, Neither the gods, nor Belinde (anwered Diana, and was very angry) can force my will: I have learn'd, that they have given me a free will, and power, to make what choie I will: whether it be a crime or no to make ue of it, it is no matter; o I do not offend Silvander, all's indifferent, and believe it Astrea, your in is not mall, in adviing me to be perfideous: In aying o, he looked upon her with uch an eye as would have moved any unto pity; and Atrea, being touched with compaion, he was quite out of countenance: My dear Siter (aid he and broke into tears) may I never live, if I be not extreamly enible of Silvanders misfortune, and would with all my heart, I could for your ake, change his Detiny; but be my orrows never o great for him, my reentments for you are more violent, and that is the reaon of my peaking as I did, thinking that by adviing you unto a perfidy, I might give you ome conolation, epecially ince your fidelity will do him no good, becaue his death will not uffer him to reap the fruits of it: Nay, on the contrary (replied Diana) my fidelity will doubtlely caue him to have this atisfaction in dying, that he has as much as he deires, and ince it is long before we hall ee each other again, if my contancy be meritorious, he will give me leave to follow him.

This was the dicoure of Diana, by which Atrea and Phillis gathered, that after the loe of Silvander, they hould have a heard task to preerve her: yet loving her infinity well, they reolved to comfort her as well as they could: thus they went on the way, whilt Amais, being near unto (Galathea and Celadon, did caue him to relate the principal • ccurrents of Silvanders life.

Belinde, for her part, he made no quetion but Diana had an inclination to him; and infinitly admiring, with what dicretion this paion had been carryed, he alo lamented the los of that Shepherd, and condemned the too much eainee of her daughter in wihing him o well: After this, remembring that he only was the caue of Silvanders coming to dwell in Forrets, he looked upon her elf as culpable, both of his love and death. Yet ince it was not in her power to divert it now, becaue he would rather die then diobey the gods, he continued her Lamentations, which was all he could do for this unfortunate Shepherd.

Adamas alo, whom the Oracle had intereted in the death of Silvander, by commanding him to be his Sacrificer, he could not find out any reaon why this Shepherd hould be o rigorouly ued: yet for further atisfaction, he would confer with him, and taking the Shepherd by the hand: Silvander (aid he unto him) what grand in have you committed, which thus moves the gods to be greedy of your death? Their Oracles peak nothing ele, whether you conult with them in private or publick, till they have ome deign upon your life. Father (anwered Silvander) it would be a vanity in me worthy of punihment, to ay I never inned; but I mut needs confee, that I do verily believe, the greattet in I ere committed, was in preuming to pretend unto the poeion of Diana: hitherto I have concealed my paion, let there hould be too many witnees of my preumption; but ince you would have my ingenious confeion, to excue the rigour which you find in the punihment that is ordained me, I will freely tell you my offence, and beeech you to pardon me, if it hath been any obtacle to the deign of Belinde and Paris: my love unto that fair Shepherdes, began before ere he knew him, and if he did entertain his affection, only out of repect, it was perhaps, becaue he had beforehand received mine out of inclination. Yet the gods mot jut, they have found a more utable conformity between the merits of Paris and Diana, then between the perfections of the Shepherdes and my mierable condition: Upon this ground, they commanded their marriage hould be accomplihed, and that I hould die, becaue they knew, that if they had not o commanded it, yet I would never have urvived their marriage
one minute. The gods, replied the Druide, do not give Diana unto Paris becaue he deervs her; nor do I think they deny her unto you, for want of any good qualities which may intitle you to a legitimate preence unto her: I do very well know both your worths, and for all my affection unto him, I am not o partially blind, but I alo know what great advantages your wit has above his; but to tell you truly, I think the gods do thus, to hew how oft men are deceived in their judgements, and that the Laws of all humane Prudence, is far inferiour unto thoe that are etablihed in heaven: But Silvander (continued he) give me leave to part from you a little, that whilt you do joyn with the ret of the company, I may think upon ome coure which may be expedient both for you and me.

In aying o, Druide tayed, and Silvander, who was very glad to be alone, he did not wah away o fat as ordinary; but going oftly, he did nothing but think upon the Fatal doom, which had debarred him from the enjoyment of Diana, to augment the glory and triumphs of Paris: Adamas in the mean while, being come near the Altar, upon the tairs, whereof Atrea and Diana lept, when they went with a reolution to die at the Fountain of verity: there he ate down, and there beginning to think upon the office unto which he was called then upon his life, and afterwards upon the mierable condition of Silvander; and finding in himelf greater motions of affection towards him, them ever he had before: O (aid he) how apt is compaion to caue love? For I never had o great an inclination unto Silvander, as ince his misfortune forced me to pity him. Afterwards thinking upon the Oracle which commended that Shepherd to die, and that he himelf hould acrifice him: O heavens (aid he) how comes the gods to be o barbarous as to prinkle their altars with humane blood: If ome uncouth Victimes only would appeae their wrath, why then, in lieu of Bulls and Sheep, did they not command the burning of our houes? I would, with all my heart, have been the firt that would have fired mine to appeae them, and hew my obedience: But why, O god of Love, mut our houes tand, and Silvander he acrificed? and to make me the greater ufferer in his punihment, by dying daily with grief, for killing him, why mut I be his acrifice? Alas, is this the abundance of contentments which hould accompany my dayes, after I had given Celadon unto his dear Atrea? Ah Heaven, has thou deluded me? Upon this he lept, and conidering that he was a Druide: O pardon me (replied he) for accuing you of injutice: Pardon me, great gods, for being too much tranported with my rereentments: Alas, alas, I do love Silvander, and being but a man, I am ubject to humane frailties: In aying o, he began to think how he hould appeae the God of Love, o, as he might excue that Shepherd; but finding no way, he roe up, reolved to obey, and returned to his houe.

They were not gone far, before Thamires, who was near unto Hylas: I do not think (aid he) but if you would peak according to your concience, you would confee Hylas, that the death of Silvander does not o much trouble you, as you make a hew of: why do you think o! (asked Hylas) becaue, anwered Thamires, it is natural to wih ill unto thoe that vex us, and well unto uch as pleae us: now, it is Silvander only, that hath convinced you of errour, and has let the world ee the falnes of your opinions: o, as I believe, you will be very glad that this thorn is taken out of your foot: Ah Thamires (aid Hylas and ighed) how far are you from my thoughts, ince as two contraries do give a greater luter unto each other, I am confident, that my wit oppoing hier it would have been in a greater conideration and eteem amongt the Shepherds and Shepherdees; but I fear, heaven does punih him for maintaining uch evil Maximes: And if by the tranquility of our lives, it be lawful to judge of the love of the gods unto us. oberve, I beeech you, which of us two has mot reaon to think our elves in the right: Firt, he came no ooner into the world, but he was punihed for the offences which he was to commit: for the gods, unto whom future and preent are all one, were pleaed to make him feel the weight of their punihments betimes; and ince he has been the very tennis ball of Fortune, jolted to and fro, like a vagabond, whom Nature would not o much as own: if
ever he had any inclination unto any Shepherdee, there was a thouand obtacles to oppoe his contentment: and why all this? but only as a recompence of that fine contancy which he hath preached with uch zeal and devotion: Whereas, on the contrary, at my very birth, good Fortune miled upon me; health and wealth vowed never to forake me: nor have I ever been troubled with o much as a fit of the headach: as oon as ever I had any mind to a young and fair Shepherdes, he met me half way: Thus have I lived alwayes in abundance of contentment, and wimmed in all delights; and why all this? but becaue I never preached any uch evere Laws as might tyrannize over our pirits; but on the contrary, that one may love indifferently all that one finds fair, and never by tyed to dote long upon one and the ame: But Thamires (continued he) though Silvander has deerved the misfortunes which follow him, yet do I infinitly lament him; and though his humour was alwayes contrary unto mine, yet I do wih his Detinies were as kind unto him, as mine are to me. In this you hew (anwered Thamires) that you are not in all things an enemy unto reaon. I conceive it therefore our parts to lament his los, and in him the los of all the Shepherds that are to urvive him: for I am afraid, that if they be left to the mercy of your extravagant opinions, you will corrupt and debauch them, and get an Empire of their minds: That had been long ince (aid Hylas) had all things been governed by reaon.

With uch dicoure as this, they all came unto the houe of Adamas, into which they were no ooner entred, but Celadon, who hared with Silvander in his orrows, he beeeched Galatheas leave to go back and meet that Shepherd, whom he thought was till with the Druide: which the Nymph conenting unto, he went, and Licidas eeing him go, he followed him: They were no ooner out of the houe, but they met him all alone: Celadon, who did mot cordially love him, did a long while embrace him, but was not able to peak for ighing: which Silvander perceiving, Celadon (aid he unto him) for god ake let not my misfortunes be any trouble to thoe contentments which the gods would have you enjoy in the poeion of your Mitree: Take your full tate of joyes, without a mixture of any orrows; and if it be my death which only troubles you, if you love me, think it a caue rather of joy then orrow, ince the gods themelves would have it o, and ince I cannot go out of the world with more glory, then in obeying thoe Dooms which they have pronounced. However (anwered Celadon) I cannot chue but adly reent this eparation, as the only thing that was able to molet my joyes: upon this, Silvander would have anwered, but the Druide came, and interrupting them, did carry them to his houe.

Diana, on the other ide, who had Atrea and Phillis with her, was not able to reit her orrows, which every moment grew more and more violent: o as to avoid all other dicoure, but that of her companions, he would go to bed, under pretence of taking ome ret which he wanted; and certainly there needed not much artifice to perwade Belinde that he tood in need of that refrehment: for beides, now knowing what interet he had in the mifortune of Silvander, the very face of that Shepherdes, had the features of one that was not likely to live above two or three hours. She conented therefore that Diana hould retyre her elf unto her chamber; and though he was in her oul orry for the obtacles that hindred the contentment of her Daughter, and the merits of Silvander, yet did he a little comfort her elf, when he fancied, that after the death of this Shepherd, Diana could not then have any excue, but to marry Paris.

Amais alo, had not been in the houe above half an hour, but he remembred Dorinde; and knowing, that he was not at the Fountain, he ent to eek her in the Gallery, in the Garden, and every place where it was likely he hould be, but hearing no news of her, he ent to enquire of the Porter, who aid, that a little after all the company was gone, he and Merindor were together in a Coach, and went towards Bonlieu. At firt he thought, that ince he left her indipoed, he might be gone to divert her elf by walking; but afterwards, remembring, that ince the return of Merindor, Dorinde had been in a very ill humour,
he began to doubt omething. And being amidt her variety of thoughts upon a udden he heard the noie of ome hores. Upon this, he went to the window, and knowing her Coach, he ran to the tairs to meet Dorinde, but finding only Merindor, he was much amazed: and to encreae her wonder, he aw him look like a dead man, pale as ahes, his eyes red, and countenance o dejected, as he was hardly able to go. As oon as he had asked where Dorinde was, and the Cavalier made a low Conge, Madam (aid he unto her in a tone that tetified the diorder of hi oul) here is it which will inform you: In aying o, he preented a Letter unto her: which Amais receiving, and opening, he found thee words.

body.head: DORINDES Letter unto AMASIS.
body.p: NOw, Madam, the peridie of Sigimond has plainly hewed me, that there is no fidelity to be found amongt men; and his Treaon hath put me out of all hopes to govern an Empire here below, I am reolved to eek for a Crown in heaven: I mut confee, that when I firt heard the news of his change, my love did condemn his violated faith; but ince, having well conidered the tranquillity it will procure unto me, I thought that I had more reaon to commend, then complain againt him. The truth is, that having received o many favours from you, it was my duty to acknowledge them; but ince I was able to do it only in my wihes, in what place could I do it more to your advantage, then in this which I am in quet of? For, Madam, it is there, where my mind being freed from the Interests of the world, will become acquainted with the gods, who perhaps, for your ake, will o far pity me, as to grant the effecting of my deires & hopes: If you think my departure without taking leave of you, a crime, accue only the good will you ever expreed unto me, which made me fear, that if I had acquainted you with my reolution, perhaps • ou would not have it ufficient: I may ay, Madam, that Sigimonds disdain o urprized me, as made me like unto thoe who are forced to go out of the world, without o much leaure as to make their lat Will. But admit I had the leaure, alas, what was in my power to dipoe of, ince from the first minute I had the honour to be known unto you, I was wholly yours; Now, Madam. be not angry that I do not divide my poesion with any but the gods, who, unwilling I hould languih under the tyranny of a man, have permitted. that by half a ring my whole heart hould be retored unto me: If thee words need any interpretation, I leave the charge of it unto Merindor, and to tell you, Madam, that in what place oever I am, and into what condition oever I am brought, I hall be till your mot humble ervant,

div.p: Whilt Amais was reading this Letter, Merindor oberved a great alteration in her countenance; and eeing her eyes began to be moit, he thought them caued for Dorindes departure. Indeed, he had no ooner read it all, but tears trickled down right: But, O Merindor (aid he) is it certain that Sigimond has failed in his word? The faith of Princes has no priviledge above others. Madam (anwered the Cavalier) your quetion requires a long dicoure, by way of anwer; and ince Dorinde has commanded me to acquaint you with all circumtances, I hall tell you as much as he knows her elf, if your patience will be pleaed to betow the hearing in private. I will (aid Amais) I do paionately deire to know the truth of it.

Upon this he took the Cavalier by the hand: and after he had told the Druide that he had ome buines to confer upon, with Merindor, he carryed him into the Garden, and chuing out the cloet Arbour, he ate down, and commanding him to do the like, he began his dicoure thus.

div.head: The Sequell of DORINDES Hitory.
div.p: I Am to relate unto you Madam, a treaon o great, that if you do not perfectly know what power love has over a pirit, doubtles you will think me mot culpable in during to be only a complice of uch a wickednes: but becaue it is an accident which hapned ince Sigimond departed from you, I will take the tory in its order and tell you Madam that as oon as we et forward, Ligonias, dipatched a pot ecretly unto Gondebaut to advertie him of Sigimond and Godomars arrivall, and leat he hould be urpried, with the arrivall alo of Roilion, and the ret of the Cavaliers; The King therefore the next morning waited upon by almot all the nobility in the Countrey, did eem as if he would go a hunting: and taking that way which the Princes were to come, they met them about a league from Lyons. This meeting was worth the eeing; for Sigimond and Godomar, knowing the King at a good ditance off did alight from their hores, and comming on foote, he was no ooner alighted from his alo but they cat themelves at his feet, and with much humble ubmiion asked pardon for parting from him. The King received them with open arms, and with ingular expreions of joy at their return did promie to forgive, and forget all that was pat, provided they would not give any new caues of complaint. Roilion in the mean time came up, and Sigimond hewing him to the King. Gondebaut offered unto him the ervice of himelf, and Kingdom with extraordinary expreions of welcome. Afterwards, he embraced Lindamor, and Godomar telling him, that this was he whoe arms had prevailed over Polemas. I am very glad (aid he) that his valour did make to appear us the injutice of that rebell, which he had with covered a legitimate pretence: after this, he received thoe honours which Damon, Alcidon and the ret, did unto him. After which, all taking hore they rid towards the Town.
