As oon as they were come within half a league; they dicovered a great multitude of men, ranged into Battalia, as if they ready to give a battle; They were variouly armed: ome with lings: ome with bows and arrows: others with pikes, on one arme a backler, and cimiters by there ides. They were about eighteen thouand in number, which made Roilion believe that it was the ret of the Army which he had ent againt Marcellis: Gondebout, the Princes, and all the ret did pae through the midt of them: and they were no ooner through, but they were met by four thouand hore, which waited upon them into the Town.

At the gates, Clotilda waited for their comming, and with her a hundred of the fairet Ladies in all Lions, who appeared upon milk white Hores, with eemed proud to bear uch loudes of beauty. At the arrivall of the Princes, Clotilda only alighted, whom Sigimond and Godamar embraced, and whom Roilion, Damon, Lindamor, and Alcidon aluted with all poible honour and repect. Afterwards they all got up again, and went unto the Temple of Venus, where the muique of voices, and intruments received them, and helped to render thanks unto the gods for their afe return: from thence they went unto the Athenian Garden, where Gondebaut had the lodgings of Roilion, and was pleaed that Sigimond, Godamar and Clotilda, hould alo be there to keep him Company.

All this day was pent in feats, and when night came all the Court went upon the water to ee ome fireworks of joy which were prepared jut where the rone, and the Arar do contract a marriage, and from thence till they come to the Sea, do lie lovingly together in one bed; one might well imagine that this was not done without deign, but this place was purpoely choen to denote the reunion of Children and Father. But however, many fine ights were een, and the King
returned ingularly well atisfied. For my part, my greatet admiration was the diligence of the workmen, and excellence of their invention, having o hort a time for it.

Now Madam I have inited upon thee things, not as abolutly neceary to the purpoe, nor as altogether uelee: for they were no ooner returned to the Palace, but Roilion being conducted to his Chamber by the Princes, every one retired to their own Chambers to ret: But Gondebaut who could not take any, and whom the interet of Dorinde o perplixed, in lieu of goeing to bed, he thought the time would be better pent in endeavouring to know upon what terms Sigimond tood with her: and becaue he uppoed that before Clotilda, lept Sigimond would urely come and give her an accompt, he paed through ome Chambers untill he came uneen or unheard, unto the dore which was cloe by the bed of that young Princee. He had not litned there above a quariter of an hovre, but Sigimond came as uppoed: and becaue that was the place where they ordinarily retired, not to be heard by thoe that were in the room, they came thither and ate down, little dreaming of Gondebauts jealouie.

I undertood ince (for the King intending to make ue of me, freely acquainted me with all things) that Sigimond began to talk very advantageouly of you, and of Galatheas beauty, and alo if all the Nimphes about you: from thence he fell to peak of Dorinde: and becaue that was it which the King mot longed to hear, he litned more attentively, and hear Sigimond ay; But Siter (for o he called Clotilda) is it not trange the King hould be o much againt my loving her; when love will never let me depart from her ervice? were I not to blame if I d • d not follow my own inclination, and if I did obey the commands of a man before the commands of a god? I know very well, that I am obliged unto him for my being, and that I ought to die rather then dipleae him: but yet if he would have me live, he mut let me love Dorinde; For as long as I am Sigimond, it is impoible I hould do otherwie. He added unto this ome other dicoure, whith Gondebaut litned unto very attentively, and unto which Clotilda anwered with all poible modety: ometimes hinting unto him his duty unto the quality of a King, and ometimes, confeing that his paion did in ome ort render his diobedience excuable; But at lat Sigimond falling to talk of the paages in Marcelles relating to his love, he acquainted her with Dorindes ditrut of him: with the oathes of fidelity which he had worn unto her, and latly how they broke a ring, and each to keep a half: after this he put his hand into his pocket, and pulling out a little cae, he hewed her Dorindes Picture. But Gondebaut could not ee it for both the dore was hut, and there was a hanging which hindred: only he thought that Clotilda held it in her hand; at which, he was not a little contented, hoping that he would help him to break of all this correpondency.

Having by this thrick full information of all he deired to know he retired, and Sigimond alo; but the did not pae away the night in the ame manner: For the Prince reted oundly like a man that was contented: but the King did hardly leep at all; For jealouy had opened both his eyes and his judgment; and made him tudy till morning how he might divert the mind of Sigimond from Dorinde.

Day did uprie him in his muing thoughts: and when it was time to rie, he pretended to be a little ill that he might lie in bed all the morning. Yet not to trouble any one; he ent for Sigimond, and after he had commanded him to carry Roilion, and the ret of the Caveliers a hunting he aured him he would be up that their return. Sigimond obeyed the King commanded, for where his love was not concerned, he would content him in any thing; In the mean time Gondebaut ent for Clotilda into hus Chamber; whom he caued to it pown by bed, and afterwards he poke unto her in thee termes.

I will not put you in mind, Clotilda, of your obligations to me, ince you cannot remember the death of your Parents, nor how at this very intant you are beholding unto me for your life; It was my clemency that aved you from the hipwrak where upon they were lot; and though I might in jutice have made
you perih with them, yet my pity retained me, and I was pleaed to pare you: as you have hither to not he been backward in acknowledging this favour, o I hope that for the future I hall have no caue to accue you of ingratitude, but will erve me upon any occaion wherein I hall imploy you; if o, never do doubt but I hall do for you any thing within the compae of my power. To this Clotilda anwered that he would alwayes obey his commands, though to the expence if her life: and that her greatet glory would be in doeing any acceptable ervice. Then Gondebaut replied thus: that which I require of you my dear Daughter (for o he called her when he was in a good humour) is not to tell me what dicoure Sigimond, and you had ince his return, for I know that as well as your elf; but I would have you take ome paines in helping me to ruine that affection which I know has already taken too deep root. And that you may not think but I know omething of the buines I will acquaint you with mot of the particulars; upon this he cat his eyes upon the young Princee and eeing her bluh, I perceive (aid he) that my dicoure does atonih you; but you will have greater caue when you have heard all. Did not Sigimond come into your Chamber the lat night after I was retired, and by your beds ide told you all that had paed in Marcelles betwixt him and Dorinde? Did he not hew unto you half a ring which he aid was a ecret betwixt them invented to defeat all practies to eperate their wills? Upon this Clotilda was quite out of countenance, and in her atonihment, not knowing where he hould hear all thee things, he was o affraid that he would punih her for entertaining the ecrets of Sigimond that falling down upon her knees, he began to implore his mercy, and aske him pardon. But the King commanding her to rie, he took her hand, and kied her; Nay nay Daughter (aid he) never fear that you have angred me; I know what care you have taken to quench his flame, and I am ure, it is not long of you, that he has not complied with my humour; but ince neither your endeavours nor mine can bring him to that pae I conceive it expedient, to this which I will communicate unto you as the lat remedye: in aying o, he caued her to it down at his beds feet, and then he continued thus,

It is probable Clotilda that you do know what perit Dorinde is of, and that being of o ambitious a temper as he is, no doubt but though Sigimond be very amiable and hanome, yet he loves him as much for his quality as his peron. Now you mut know that when uch perons of her quality, do arrive at any high degree of honour, they alwayes become mot inufferable, and ue a mot tirannicall, and dominering authority over all: they think the Sunnes does hine only to pleae them, and charge the earth with ingratitude, if it do not produce her fairet flowers in all places where they hall honour it with their feet; Truth is, they are full of o much dangerous vanity, that (judging fally of all things) if they think any one to be an obtacle unto their fortune or ambition, they preently are plotting to ruine them; and are never quiet till they have done it. I peak this, partly in relation unto you Clotilda; to the end you may ecure your elf o, as though I hould faile you, yet, that you may never fall into uch extremities as I have mentioned, which doubtlee will come to pae, if Dorinde ever bring about her deignes: for as oon as ever Sigimond marry her, he, who as you know is only the Daughter of Arcingentorix, will become o proud to ee her elf Queen of the Burgundians, as for getting her elf, he will alo forget what is due unto your merit and quality; The vat difference that is betwixt her extraction and yours, will make her o ahamed to appear where you hould be, as perhaps will beget uch a hatred in her oul, that your life may be in danger. This is the danger, which threatens you: and if you do come to a fatall end, it is meerly your own fault, ince the remedy is yet in your own hands, which is Clotilda, by all meanes to quench this fire, which has already broken out into uch great flames.

Judge Madam, how eaily the pirit of a young lady might receive all the impreions: The King had no ooner done his dicoure but he had infued a trange mitrut in to the oul of this young Princee, that all thee misfortunes would come to pae in cae this affection continued: So as forgetting what he owed
unto the amity of Sigimond, and preparing her elf to do whatoever the King commanded againt Dorinde; Sir, anwered he, my fears of being mierable, hall not be the motive to make me obey you; but it hall be my deires to make you know that I will never be ungrateful unto your goodnes: Therefore I mot humbly beeech you to tell me what I mut do, that I may preently begin it, and by that you may judge of my affection. Truth is (aid the King) hate is very requiite in the buines; for in uch matters, delays are dangerous, and often marre all; you mut therefore of neceity get that half Ring which is in the hands of Sigimond, with all poible expedition. Oh Sir (aid Clotilda, and interrupted) I doubt it is impoible; for did you ee with what care he kept it, you would wonder; he looked upon it, he kied it, he laid to his heart, he talked to it as if Dorinde were preent; and therefore I am afraid that being o tranported with this paion, it will be a great difficulty to get it from him. It is not my deign to attempt it openly (aid the King) or by violence, you know uch ways have been already ued without effect; but I would have us go about it by cunning, and do all that poibly we can to deceive him: Oh (replied Clotilda) it is hard deceiving uch mitrutful pirits as his: you may be deceived (replied Gondebaut) o you will do as I hall direct, which doubtles will be an eaie matter to do, ince he takes you under the notion of a confident, and not as one who would divert his affection.

Clotilda promiing to do her bet, the King continued thus: You daughter have een this Ring, and you know what mettle and ize it is, get another made of the ame, and as like it as you can; then breaking it in two, keep the one half, Sigimond will certainly come to you, as he did the lat night, and will be as cerimonious to this Ring as before: when he does, take your half in one hand, and take his in the other, and when he asks for it again, in lieu of his, give him yours; it is impoible he hould perceive it; for not having the other to compare them together, nor mitruting your deign, he will beleive it the ame he brought from Marcelles, which done, we will proceed further, and to morrow I will tell you how,

Clotilda thought this invention to be excellent, and very feaable; and after he had worn to ue her bet endeavours: Well Clotilda (aid Gondebaut) you mut now give me this contentment, ince you have worn it, and I deire it: This invention is the only Remedy we have, and I will ue it: If you do your bet endeavours, you hall ere long ee how much I love you; and if on the contrary, I find you fail me, and that my deign do come to be dicovered (which can no way be but by want of good-will, or gros indicretion) be certain, I will take it as the greatet injury I ever received from any enemy. To which Clotilda anwered, that he would ooner dye then fail in the leat of his Commands: After which, the King kied her; he went out of the Chamber, and he got out of his bed.

I wil not abue your ears, Madam, with too precie a relation of every particular circumtance, which is not fully pertinent to my purpoe; It will uffice you know that all this day was pent in hunting, and part of the night in dancing, After which Sigimond failed not to accompany Clotilda in her Chamber; for in the abence of Dorinde, he took delight in nothing o much as in talking with her: Amongt other dicoure they fell into talk of the Ring; and as oon as Sigimond had taken it out of his Box, he hewed it unto the Princes, who took it into her hand as if he deired to look upon the fahion of it; whe he had it, he put both her hands behind her, he left Sigimonds Ring on the tool, and kept only that which he had provided; afterwards holding out both her hands to him hut: I hold a wager (aid he unto him) that you gues not in which it is. The Prince, who never mitruted her fallacie; I hold a wager (aid he and miled) it is in that hand: In aying o, he touched Clotildas right hand, and opening it he found only the counterfeit of that which he ought for; yet uppoing it to be the very ame which Dorinde gave him, he innocently took it, and looking upon the Princes: Oh Siter (aid he and miled) you mut know that love can do any thing, and though he be blind, yet
nothing can be hid from him: In saying o, he laid this counterfeit part of the Ring to his lips, and Clotilde eeing him kis it with o much devotion and zeal, he could not chue but mile; but preently after hearing him igh, her oul reented ome little kind of compaion; and therefore he aid unto her elf, Oh Sigimond, didt thou but know how much miery my Artifice is preparing for thee, thou wouldt turn all thy ighs of love into ighs of rage and dipair: Upon this thought he repented that ever conented unto this Treaon; but then calling to memory the dicoure of Gondebaut, and conidering how inevitable her ruine would be, if he did not purue her enterprie, he thought it bet to finih what he had o happily begun: But becaue the night was far pent, and Sigimond who would never have been weary of her company, did not think of retiring, he put him in minde of it; and when he was gone he went to bed.

The next morning, he got up betimes, becaue he imagined the King would end for her, to what he had done: And indeed he was no ooner dret, but a Meenger came according to her expectation: As oon as he came into his Chamber; Come Clotilda (aid the King unto her) have we gotten this Ring? we cannot get it (anwered Clotilde and miled) out of his hands; why? (replied Gondebaut, and began to be angry) becaue it is not there (anwered Clotilda and till miled) for it is in mine; and that you may not doubt of it, ee here the accomplihment of your deire, and my promie.

Upon this, the King took it, and eeming highly atified with the diligence of Clotilda; Do not think (aid he) that whilt you were at work, I was idle; they have promied to bring me a man hither this morning, whoe name is Squillinder, and who, if I mitake not, did formerly live in Forrets, and fled hither for refuge: Now they tell me this man is the raret in the world at counterfetting all manner of hands; which if he be, he hall write a Letter from Sigimond unto Dorinde, that will do the deed; only one thing troubles me, I cannot think upon one that is fit to execute the ret of my plot; for he mut be a man of excellent wit and judgment, and one, if poible, that has ome colour of pre •• ence with Dorinde; after that Sigimond has quitted his ininteret.

Then Clotilda began to think a little; afterwards upon a udden: There are many (aid he) who have loved her, and I know two who do at this very intant loue her, and are here; you may chue which of them you think mot fit for your purpoe: Then he named Periander, and Merindor. As oon as the King heard my name, he clapped his hands together, and eemed to be extreamly glad: I am certain (aid he) this Cavileir will do whatoever I hall bid him. There needed no more but to conult with me about him: Oh Great Gods! what Soveraign Authority has Kings over us? And how hard it is for us to reit the charms of their Commands, epecially when they come with any appearance of Jutice: Gondebaut had not ooner ent for me, but he told me all that I have told you; and after this, and a world of mountainous promies, in cae I could win Dorinde to marry me, he did inenibly engage me to do whatoever he would. He had no ooner got his promie from me, but I aw a young man enter, who, ince they told me was Nephew unto Ardilan, whom Godamar killed: he brought with him this Squillinder, whom I poke of before, and who, perhaps Madam, you have heard of, ince he lived in your Provinces: He did not only live here (anwered the Nymph) but was born here in a Town called Argental; and I know him to be a man of good wit, if he would well imploy it: However, replied Merindor, he is extreamly ubtle, and one may know it by his very looks and mind: But Madam, to hold you in this dicoure no longer: Gondebaut did make very much of him, and having imparted his mind unto him, he hewed unto him one of Sigimonds Letters; And after an injunction of eternal ilence, and a large recompence if he would but counterfeit the hand, he et him to work, he himelf dictating this Letter.

body.head: The counterfeit Letter of SIGISMOND unto DORINDE.
body.p: IT is rather thy Tyranny of Gondebaut, then any conent of my will, which has made me a Husband unto a Daughter unto the King of the Theurons: My depair is o great, that I cannot entertain you with thoe orrows which I uffer by reaon of this contraint: And this half Ring which I end you back, will tell you that there is no remedy left againt my misfortune: I wih I were able to give you any conolation; but ince I cannot comfort my elf; what can I invent to comfort you?

The Truth is Dorinde, I am married, and I wih I could alo ay that I were dead, but Heaven is pleaed to let me live only to reent our eparation with more adnes: Let that Necesity which hath forced me to violate my Faith unto you, excue my change; And if you have any inclination to oblige me, find that happines in the Arms of Merindor, which our bad detinies denies you to find from Sigimond.

div.p: Whilt the King did dictate, Squillander did write this Letter; and when hee had done, Gondebaut compared it with Sigimonds, but found them o extreamly alike, as had hee not een it written before his face, hee would have worn it to be the hand of his Son.

This done, Gondebaut dimied Squillander, and commanded Ardilan to recompence double to what the Fellow could expect: After this, hee turned himelf unto mee; See here Menandor (aid hee unto mee) now all depends upon your good management of the matter: I have already told you, that if you proceed handomly, you hall receive advantages from mee beyond your imagination, beides the atisfaction of your Love unto Dorinde: you have wit enough to manage this mater aright; and though you had no interet in it but mine, yet that is enough to make mee hope well in your proceeding, I would have you go about it as oon as poibly you can, and that you go unto Dorinde as ent from Sigimond: When you come firt to her, upon the firt opportunity of dicoures, tell her that hee is not to pretend any more unto the Crown of the Burgundians, ince it is already detiny'd from the daughter of the King of Theurons, to whose Ambaadors, Sigimond and I have igned the Articles: I know that this will much afflict her; but a man of your accomplihments will make her take this loe with little grief; epecially if you tell her, (as your Love will dictate unto you) that till hee hall be a Queen, and raign overaignly in your heart. I anwered him, That I was wholly devoted to obey his commands, but there was one obtacle in my way, which was, that I was engaged to run at the Ring with Prince Sigimond this very day; and hould I fail him, omething might perhaps be upected.

Upon this, the King cratched his head a long time together, and aid not a word: afterwards upon a udden, It is no matter (aid hee) if you go not till night; for let Roilion, Lindamor and the ret of the Cavaliers be as haty as they will to return unto Amais, I hall tay them till to morrow, to the end, that before they can tell Dorinde Sigimond is not married, you may have time enough to get her conent to marry you: and if I be not much mitaken, you will finde no great difficulty in it: For very pite to ee that Sigimond has cat her off, will make her content to what you will; and to be revenged, will give unto you that Empire which my on pretended unto. Which if it come to pae, never fear what Sigimond can do afterwards: For if hee offer to attempt any thing againt you, or againt my ervice, I hall take a coure to keep him within compae of his duty. This Madam, was the command which I received
from the King, and which Love making mee as blinde as himelf did move me to undertake: For certainly, had I not been tark blinde, I hould have foreeen the misfortune which hapned unto mee ince. But to proceed; be pleaed to know, Great Nymph, that the Coure at the Ring being ended where every one did very well, and wherein Roilion and Lindamor amongt the ret, did get a mot high eteem, I departed with a reolution to ride all the night; but it began to rain o extreamly, as I was contrained to tarry at the firt Town I came at. The next morning, which was yeterday, I got up betimes, and came unto you very early. I hall not need to tell you with what an eye Dorinde looked upon mee, for you were a witnee of it: but let mee tell you, it was with a kinder apect than hee would, had hee known the meage which, I brought, I told her, that I had a Letter to preent unto her from Prince Sigimond: and then I aw through her eyes the contentment of her oul; but becaue you were ready to it down at the Table, I did not preent it untill wee were rien. Perhaps Madam, you oberved how hee took mee aide: Indeed I did (anwered Amais) and I made a doubt whether it was for the love of Sigimond or yourelf: Then Madam you mut know (aid Merindor) that eeing none near to interrupt us, firt hee asked for the Letter which the Prince had ent; upon which, eeming to look for it, and in ome ort to prepare her for reading of it. But fair Dorinde (aid I) it eems you expect ome great contentment from this Letter: Why not? (anwered hee and miled) ince the Prince has done mee the honour to write it. I cannot tell (aid I, and eemed as if I could not yet finde it) but upon this I topped: And Dorinde looking mee in the face, hee found there uch coldnee, as hee began to fear that all was not o well as hee imagined: hee preently changed colour, and hoping that I aid o only to deceive her, It eemes Merindor (aid hee unto mee) you have a minde to make mee buy the contentment of this Letter very dear: but pray give it mee; for the favour is at o high a rate, as I hall never be able to pay it. Shee had no ooner aid o, but I found it, and preenting it unto her, Here Madam (aid I) may you finde in it as much contentment as you expect. Thee words did renew the feares of Dorinde, o as receiving the Letter with a troubled countenance, hee opened it with a trembling hand, and at lat read it: Shee had no ooner read two or three of the firt lines, but hee tryed whether or no her eyes had deceived her; and pointing with her finger at the words which were o dipleaing unto her, in hopes to find ome other ence in them, he till found the ame, and o read on to the end of this ad Letter. And when hee came to the place where Sigimond advied her to eek for happinee in my armes, anger did then urprie her, and I heard her ay in a low voice, Yes, yes, peridious man, could I but pull out of thy breat that heart which thou didt promie to preerve o faithfully: upon this, hee began to igh, and to be quite out of countenance; o as he cryed in good earnet: And chuing rather that I hould be a witnee of her teares, then you, hee turned her elf towards mee, and when hee could peak, aid thus unto mee: I cannot tell Merindor, from whence uch a udden change hould proceed; Pray tell mee, if you can? Faire Dorinde (aid I unto her) perhaps that Letter will give you a better accompt then I can: No (anwered hee) it mentions nothing at all, but onely that hee is married, and I wih to heaven I had dyed before I heard that word: Then Madam, replied I, I hall acquaint you with the Circumtances, to the end I may leen your orrowes and pardon his Infidelitie. Then I told her all that I could invent to colour this Lye: I told her that Sigimond was no ooner entered into Lyons, but Embaadours from the King of Theurons came to treat about this alliance: and that Gondebaut having found it very advantageous, had turned every tone, and ued o many arguments to perwade Sigimond unto it, as at the lat hee conented: That afterwards, the Prince would have toln away, but being prevented, Clotilda was imployed to perwade him unto this marriage: That this Princee was once out of all hopes to bring it about; but at lat, hee tampered o with him, and had uch a prevalence with him, as hee made him igne the Articles, and at the
ame time procured from him this Letter, and this half of a Ring which I come to retore unto you. To this I added a thouand ignes of orrow, that I hould be the meenger of uch ad newes: and only received the Commiion to get the opportunity of putting her in memory of my former ervices, and not to grieve her. My dicoure; and her teares did end both together, and I protet Madam, I was amuzed to ee her orrowes o oon vanih; at leat; I oberved in her countenance a mot trange alteration, and was the mot urpried man in the world, when I heard her ay; Since I mut knew the treaon of this peridious Prince, I am not orry Merindor, that you have brought mee the newes. Know therefore, that I will content you for it very hortly, and end my dayes with you. After this, hee left mee and went towards you: For my part, I was the mot atisfied man upon earth; and wihed that the night was already pat, hoping hee would perform her promie in the morning: which indeed hee did; but Madam in a farre different manner from what I expected: and ee how hee went to work. Shee feigned her elf to be • ek, to have a pretence of asking your Coach, and afterwards to take a way quite contrary unto yours. You, who never upected her deigne, did lend it unto her: but you were no ooner gone, then hee took mee unto the Coach with her, and commanded the Coachman to carry her unto Bonlieu. I, who thought upon nothing but my Love, and the promie which hee had made mee night before: But faire Dorinde (aid I unto her) what moves you to go unto Bonlieu? I am reolved (aid hee) to keep my word with you, though Sigimond has broke his: I mut confee my blood began to rie at this, and was joyed beyond all expreions. Therefore kiing her hand; I vow, fairet Dorinde (aid I unto her) that you will be the happiet of all women: I expect no lee (anwered hee) for otherwie I hould not thus dipoe of my elf.

With uch dicoure as this, wee came to the Temple which they told mee was dedicated unto a Virgin, which was to have a childe. There Dorinde caued the Coach to tay, and deired mee to tay in it whilt hee talked a little with one of the Druides which belonged to the Temple: I waited there almot two houres; and when I began to be pat all patience; I heard one call mee. Upon this I looked round about; and eeing no body, I heard a voice again which bad mee come into the Hall, the doore whereof was immediately opened unto mee. I, who knew not what belonged, or to what purpoe this was, entered in, and pyed Dorinde in great barres of iron; o cloe as one might onely ee but not come unto her: Now Merindor (aid hee unto mee) ee the performance of my promie; here will I die to all the world; and by you as I promied: Carry this Letter unto Amais; and if hee ask you the reaon of this my holy reolution, tell her it was your voyage: Ache • . Upon this hee cat a Letter at my feet; and drawing a curtain which hindered mee from the ight of her, I earnetly entreated to ee her once more; but do all I could, it was not to be obtained: Seeing then all my prayers and my teares were in vaine, I took up the Letter, and returned in your Coach to give it unto you, with an exact accompt of Gondebauts Treaon, of my owne indicretion, and of Dorindes depaire.

This was the dicoure of Merindor, at which Amais could not retrain her tears; and doubtlee her grief had been greater, had he not known; that there was a remedy. Chearing up her elf therefore, in hopes to hinder Dorinde from confi • ing her elf for ever, amongt the Carnates, he roe up, and in returning to the houe: Merindor (aid he) you have done very well in advertiing me of this accident o oon: for yet there is time to remedy it, becaue, do what Dorinde can, it will be two months before her vow will be received, to admit her amongt the ret. Madam (anwered Merindor) I make no doubt of what you ay, but I fear it will be a great difficulty to perwade Dorinde that Sigimond has not deceived her: The plot has been acted o cunningly, and they have gloed it with o many colours of truth, as it is hard to be known for a falhood: But, Madam, I am in a mot deperate condition, for now there is no place where I
can find any afe Sanctuary: Sigimond will not ooner hear of my doing, but he will with all his power ruine me, and I cannot condemn him for it: for I do acknowledge my fault, and know, that I ought not for an Empire to conent unto any wicked action. In this (aid Amais) there are many things to excue you; and though I did not bring your love to Dorinde for one, yet it was a hard task for you not to obey Gondebaut, who would himelf have ruined you, had you refued to execute his command. Still, Madam (replied Merindor) it had been more glorious to perih that way then the other, and it would have been great atisfaction to die without hame, or a tain upon my reputation. All thoe aid Amais) who know the power of a paion, when it is econded with the command of uch a King as Gondebaut, will rather find matter of excue, then matter of condemnation: However, I offer you afe retreat with me, and promie to make your peace with Sigimond, provided, that as you have contributed in the fault, • o you will be an aitant in the reparation of it, Madam, anwered the Cavalier, my deign was to go and die amongt the tranapines, under another name then my own: The glory of war invited my courage thither; but ince you conceive me neceary cure to the wound which I have made; I do in all humility accept of your offer; and promie, Madam, to pare nothing that is whithin the compas of my power, to retore unto Dorinde that contentment which I would have robbed her of.

After this, they went into, the chamber of Adamas, when Amais found beyond meaure afflicted; and after he had pent part of the day with him, he called for Roanira, Calathea, and the ret, becaue he deired to go home betimes, that he might the ooner get Dorinde out of the place; unto which he had confined her elf.

Amais did not acquaint neither Galathea, nor Roanira, with Dorindes reolution, becaue he thought to divert her from it before they hould ere know it; only he told them, that he was going to Bonlieu, and, that being deirous to viit the Temple of Carnates, he intended to pend all the whole day there. They catly believe the Nymph, and the ooner, becaue not knowing of Gondebauts plot, they did not think that Dorinde had any reaon to leave the world. But when they deired leave to wait upon the Nymph thither, and he denied them, then they began to upect omething of the buines. Yet, let they hould dipleae Amais, they preed her to further, though the orrows which they aw in the face of Merindor, and the ill humour of Dorinde ever ince that Cavalier came, had made them extreamly deirous of it.

Thus, they were no ooner come to Ioures, but Amais left them there; and without any company but Merindor, he went towards Bonlieu: he had not gone above two or three hundred paces, but he epied a man coming in great hale, and preently knew him to be the little Meril whom he had left in Marcelles: he caued then, the Coach to tay, and the little boy was no ooner come near, but kneeling down upon the ground. Madam (aid he with a laughing countenance) Lindamor will be returned within this hour, and the Princes, Rosilion, and Godomar, will come with him: They were much troubled when they found neither you nor any of your Nymphs in the Catle; but when they heard where you were, they intended to leave all their Equipage in the Town and come to urprize you: The truth is, they came preently, and I thought fit to advertie you, to the end, Madam, you might have time to put things in order for them.

Amais was very glad of the news, and little Meril knew it by her carreing of him; but Merindor, who knew himelf culpable, did preently conceit that Sigimond had dicovered his crime, and had ent Godomar to take revenge; he looked therefore for the wort, and reolved however, to die like a Cavalier: The Nymph oberved his countenance to change, and therefore asked the caue. I knew Madam (anwered Merindor) that Roilion, Lindamor, Damon, Alcicon, and the ret, did not intend to tay long after me; but I cannot undertand, why they hould bring back Prince Godomar, ince here is now no enemies to fight withal, unlee he take me for one, by reaon of the crime when I committed againt
the contentment of his brother. I believe (replied Amais) the reaon is only, becaue Lindamor has obliged him to come and ee me; but after he had commanded to drive back unto the pallace, M • rind • r (aid he) never trouble your elf, I will undertake to ecure you from all the dangers that your in does caue you to fear.

After ome other uch dicoure, the Nymph arrived at Ioures, and no ooner aw Roanira, Daphnide, Madonthe, Galathea, and the ret, but he acquainted them with the good news which Meril brought: The god of Love knows, how they all rejoyced at this; and ince Roaniras quality gave her more freedome to tetifie her reentments, he was the firt that poke and asked whether they came to Ioures; and being anwered according to her deires, he run unto the window, to ee whether they appeared: he preently heard the noie of hores in the Court, and preently after he epied Roilion, Godomar, Lindamor, and Damon: o as Amais, and the Ladies, had hardly o much time as to go unto the tairs, but they met them with expreions of extream contentment: Roilion was the firt that asked the reaon why they were all become Shepherdees, and whilt Roanira anwered, that he was incontant in nothing but that change, Godomar looked round about for Dorinde; but having long imployed both his care and time in vain, he addreed himelf unto Amais, and asked what was become of her? To whom the Nymph anwered in a low voice, that he mut have more leaure before he could atisfie his curioitie, and that the accidents which had hapned unto that fair one, ince they went away, deerved a private audience. They eparated themelves therefore, a little from the company, and preently after taking Coach, they went out of the Pallace: They were no ooner in the way to Bonlieu, but Amais told him all that he had heard concerning Gondebauts plot, and the reolution of Dorinde: Yet, before he began this dicoure, he made him promie, not to deny her a requet which he would ask: o as, requeting a pardon for Merindor, he vowed that he would never bear him any ill will.

This dicoure did entertain them till they came to the Temple, where Amais coming out of the Coach, and intreating Godomar to tay in it, he deired to ee Dorinde: The doores were immediatly opened, and he was no ooner entred in, but he was brought out by the age Cleontine, who held her by the hand. Amais could not chue but mile, when he aw her approach with uch a compoed face of gravity, as if he had been ten years amongt them: yet eeing her time hort, he took her aide, and talked to her in thee terms.

I do not come, fair Dorinde, to reit your reolution, for I will approve of it, if you hall think it legitimate; but I come only to acquaint you with the mot black and horrid plot, that ever was invented to detroy an affection: It is probable you will give credit unto my words, ince if you conider who I am, you may well think I will not authorize any lie. Let me tell you then Dorinde, that you are betrayed: I know it very well, Madam (anwered Dorinde and interrupted) Merindor has given me ufficient tetimonies of it. This is not it, replied Amais) which I mean; It is Gondebaut, and not Sigimond, who is the Authour of this Perfidie, and to put you out of all doubt, I will faithfully tell you the whole truth: Then Amais briefly related unto her the confeion of Merindor: but eeing Dorinde not at all moved at it, nay rather on the contrary, eeming by ome miles to leight and mock at what hee aid, I perceive (aid Amais) that you give no credit unto my words; but at my requet, go with mee o farr as my Coach, and I will give you undeniable tetimony of it. Dorinde, who thought this only ome trick of Amais, only to carry her away, hee proteted at firt, that hee would not tirr out of the Temple; but after, that the Nymph wore hee would bring her back again, hee contented to go: Shee was no ooner at the Gates, but Godomar came out of the Coach, and taking her in his armes, Siter (aid hee unto her) how can you think it lawfull to dipoe of your elf againt all the promies which you have made unto Sigimond? Dorinde was all amazed at this dicoure, and the more, becaue hee did not think that Godomar was returned: Yet a little recollecting her elf, Sir (aid
he unto him, I thought that his violated faith, would have dipenced me from all my oaths and promies, and that I ought not to be blamed if not being able to imitate his infidility, I make choie of a death o honourable. D • ar Dorinde (replied Godomar) you mut live long, if you do not die tell my Brother change: I protet his love was never o great as now, and I will give you a tetimony of it which perhaps you do not expect, in aying o he gave her a Letter, in which he found thee words witten with his blood.

body.head: SIGISMONDS Letter unto DORINDE.
body.p: THey ay that blood does emblem • cruelty: but I would have this be an eternall mark of my love and loyalty. Receive it, as yours, dearet Dorinde, and conider that I hall not be coveteous if I conquer your beauty by my armes, as I have already Tryumphed over your heart by my ervices.

div.p: At the ight of this Letter Dorinde was really moved; and Godomar who perceived it, did take his time o well, that his perwaions prevailed with her: he wore o many oathes in excue of Sigimond, as at lat he did believe it was only Gondebaut that had deceived her: o as not thinking her elf obliged to follow her lat reolution, he returned with Amais, and Godomar to the Palace of Ioures, where he no ooner had talked with Merindor, but he reaumed her good humour.

On the other ide, after Adamus was quite out of all hopes ever to find any remedy to appeae the anger of the gods, and make them tay the entence which they had pronounced againt the life of Silvander, he prepared himelf to obey them, and made a vow that this acrifice hould be the lat he would ever make: He therefore commanded the Eutages, and the Vaces to be in readines: and he himelf ent to erect a pile of faggots near the fountain where the body of Silvander was to be burned; And accordingly, Aurora no ooner proclamed the return of that bright Planet which was to be a witnes of this ad pectable, but Silvander aroe out of bed, and went unto the Druides Chambers, to hew that he was ready to go where his fate did call him. Adamas received him with teare, but eeing the hepherd not at all moved, and that though he had in his face the features of a man that was to die, yet of a man that was contented to die, he could not chue but add unto his orrows, his admiration to ee him o courageous.

But as the pirit of Silvander was very trong to bear out this lat blow, o Dian • s was as weak; For this hepherdes no ooner aw the day appear, but her oul was welled with mot enible afli ••• ion: but ince he could not igh freely enough he tole from Atrea, and opened the window as oftly as he could. There did he fill the air with her ad breath, and the Ecchoes all about eemed to approach her voice, and help her to lament. This ad entertainment luted a while: but afterwards looking towards the plaine, he aw the Eubages, and the Vaces goeing to the acrifice where all her joyes were to be offered in the peron of Silvander. This object did o peirce her to the heart, as never thinking that her gr •• f would wake Leonide, and Phillis who were a leep in the bad cloe by the window, oh god, cryed he out, now have I but one moment to live: Oh ye cruell executioners of the wrath of angry gods, why hould you not be myne. rather then my hepherds? Why will not the detinies be contented with my life? And ince it is their pleaure to punih innocence, what moves them to pare me? In aying o he ighed o loud that Phillis waked, who eeing Diana all in teares, did quickly guee the caue. She got up therefore, and goeing to the window where her Companion was leaning: Siter, (aid he) I do not ask what is the caue of your teares becaue this is the fatall day whereon Silvander is to be vanihed from us: Alas alas, replied Diana, though we hould loe the memory of
it, yet yonder objects are able to revive it. Do you not ee how all the hepherds, do leave their houes, to go and ee this ad ceremony? See how carefull they are to rie betimes, and how they croud in all haet, as if the fear of ome enemy had driven them from their habitations. Good gods? mut I have o many witnees of my misfortune? Upon this he topt and was ilent: and Phillis who did not think it jutice to comfort her in uch a ad affliction, he durt not open her lippes to anwer: but till holding her eyes upon the objects which Diana had hewed her, he did by little and little loe her ight: for her teares did inenibly teal it from her.

Leonide and Astrea waked almot at the ame time, and eeing Diana and Phillis up, they quickly dreed themelve:s Phillis alo he dreed her elf; But Diana who had hardly o much trength as to utain her elf, by the perwaion of her Companions he lay down upon the bed: Atrea and Phillis ate down by her, and leat Bellinde hould come and interrupt them, they beeeched Leonide to contrive it o, that he hould not come, or at the leat till after the acrifice: which the Nymph promiing, he went out, and did as he was deired: for Bellinde doubting that Diana would adly reent the loe of that hepherd, he eaily conented to let her complain by her elf. This little liberty was ome mal comfort to her: but it being almot impoible that o little water hould quench o great a fire, the eae he received was as little as nothing.

In the mean time, the Eubages were come to the houe of Adamas, and thoe whom curioity had invited unto this ad pectable, were waiting round about the houe, whilt Amais, Godomar, Roanira Galathea, Roilion Dorinde, and the ret were with the Druide. The noie of o great a Company was o loud as it reached the ears of Diana, who doubting the caue, did double the orrows of her oul: Atrea, and Phillis did quickly perceive it: but not being able to remedy it, did nothing but accompany the ighes of this ad hepherdee with theirs. They all drooped in a long ilence: but Diana upon a uddain interrupting their ilence, dearet Siters (aid he unto them) the only confidents unto whom I have communicated both my orrows and my joyes: pray tell me; Do you not think that the Sun makes more hat then ordinary, and tayes only becaue Silvander is not yet dead? Alas alas what has this poor hepherd done againt nature, that it hould have uch a deire to ee him perih? After this he was ilent: and falling into a profound tudy: but is it a ign of love (replied he upon a uddain) or a ign of ingratitude, if he hould depart before he bids me adieu. Dear Atrea (aid he and turned towards her) for pityes ake, order it o that I may ee him • tell him he need not fear to aflict me more for my orrows cannot poibly be greater: Good gods (continued he) if he do give his life to obey the detinies who are his enemyes, dares he deny to peak one ingle word to his Mitree? After this, he began to igh again, and Atrea who was glad of any occaion to pleae her, he was very willing to undertake this commiion and the ooner becaue he thought Celadon would be with him: and indeed, he was no ooner entred into the hall, which was already full of people, but he met him: and Celadon taking her hand and kiing it: now (aid he) I am ure it is day, ince my bright Sun is up: your Sun (anwered the hepherdee) will this day be ecliped and dark; for the orrows of Diana, and the misfortune of Silvander,
• do cloud her with abundance of grief; then Celadon would have replied: but Atrea addreing her elf unto Adamas, Father (aid he unto him in a low voice) Diana will eyther die, or ee Silvander: and I believe he will turn deperate, if they will not let him bid her the lat adieu. The Druide, thinking that without injutice, this conolation could not be denied, he went and preently advertied the hepherd: who having no difficulty to urmount but this, prepared himelf to overcome it. Atrea then conducted him into the Chamber of this afflicted hepherdes, and to give them the more opportunity to peak there mot ecret thoughts at this lat meeting, he took Phillis by the hand, and leaving them no other witnees but love, and pity, he carryed her into another room.

As oon as this hepherd came into the Chamber, Diana was ready to go out
of the world: at firt, he give a great cry; and raiing her elf up a little in her bed, he croed her arms, and had uch evident igns of tranport in her face, that Silvander after he had a little conidered them, began to feel all his courage and his trength to fail. That great reolved oul which he had hewed till now, was vaniht, and he was not able to reit thoe orrows which the preence of Diana caued: Thus this poor hepherd was no ooner gotten into the midt of the Chamber, but his legges failed him: upon which falling, and finding himelf to wound, he fell upon his ide ome two paces from the bed of his Mitree. Diana in the mean while, eeing him lie as if he were dead, was grieved to the oul that he could not help him: yet thinking it no time to tand upon nicities he roe out of bed in her mock, and would have helped him to rie: but finding no motion in him, he was ready to tender up her oul: her dipair was then at the lat point, and doubtles if grief could have killed her, he had dyed; but being till reerved for more mieryes, this accident did not deprive her of peech: for after he had laid her mouth cloe to the face of Silvander: Poor hepherd (aid he aloud) am not I a mot mierable woman, in being the caue of all thy misfortunes? Without me, the detinies had pared thy life, and if my interet had not been enterwoven with thine, they would never have made thee mierable. Upon this he was ilent, and love ucceeding pity, after he had looked about her, and aw none to oberve her actions, he kied him, as if he would inpire new life into his lippes, or as if he would waken him with the water of her tears: but which oever it was, the hepherd opened his eyes, as a ign he was not dead; And though Diana had not taken all that paines but only to revive him, yet was he urpried becaue of the condition wherein he was, that he roe up in all hat and went into bed; but never minding what he did, he made more hat then good peed, and knocked her head o hard againt one of the bed pots, as he fell a cros over the body of Silvander; Her crye, and the noie he made brought Atrea, and Phillis into the room, and eeing uch a pityfull pectacle, they made no quetion but they were both dead for the love of each other: yet comming nearer, they aw Silvander move his arm, as if he endeavoured to get it from under the body of Diana, and therefore they took up their Companion, and put her into bed: as they were lifting her up he returned out of her wound but becaue he lay her hand upon her forhead where he felt pain, they took a handkercher and preed it o hard to the place where he began to well, as little or no mark, appeared afterwards.

Silvander alo returned perfectly to himelf; and comming near Dianas bed, as oon as Atrea, and Phillis were gone to the window; I thought, fairet Diana (aid he unto her) I hould have been o happy as to die in your preence; But I ee the doom of heaven is irrevokable, and I mut die by the hand of Adamas; This lat action, which eems to oppoe my felicity, would not much trouble me, did I not ee a trouble unto you: But dearet Mitree of my oul, do not let it trouble you at all that I am to be acrificed, the gods would have ome part of me, as well as you: and as I have already acrificed my oul unto you, o they would have me this day acrifice my body unto them. In this diviion the bet part is yours: for you having my heart, my will, my oul, and all its faculties, they have nothing but a bare carcae which is meat for worms or crows. Oh dear (anwered Diana with a deep igh) yet in this, they take part of my happinee from me, for when you did acrifice your oul unto me, it did not imply any uch condition, that I hould not pretend unto your body: you did give it unto me, without any manner of reervation, and gave me full power to do what I would with it: and though I have no power to make you live: yet they do mot tirannically uurp it from me; but Silvander, ince they are ole Arbitrators of our lives, I will yeild this right unto them, and will not grieve for your death, if you will but grant me one conolation, the hope of which is all the happines I have. The hepherd who deired nothing but to pleae her did promie to deny her nothing. Then (aid Diana) I would have you let me die as oon as ever I hear that you are out of the world. Diana uttered thee words with great reolution, and Silvander was o charmed with this lat tetimony of her love, that for a
while he was not able to open his lips. At lat taking her hand, and kiing it; Ah my fairet, would you ign your affection and my misfortune with your blood? have you o much courage as to follow me in this fatal paage? and does it not grieve you to leave Paris and your life? Cruel Silvander (replied Diana, and interrupted) cant thou doubt, but that my paion dare attempt any thing?

In aying o, he eemed to be a little troubled; and the hepherd knowing that he had reaon to be angry with him; Dear Diana, replied he, pardon my love if any parks of jealouie eemed to appear in it: It is the will of the Gods that you hould be the wife of Paris; and if I do fear it, has not my fears a very lawful ground? I know, reylied Diana, that they have o ordained it: But in this matter, I wear that I will be my own detinies: You know Silvander that I can be no bodies but yours, and you hall never go into the Elizian fields without me. I will go then (aid Silvander) and die with content, in hopes that our abence will not be long; I will go, my fairet Diana, and offer unto the God of Love that which belongs unto you; happy hall I be in ending my days, if by my example you be not afraid to follow me. Adieu, my fairet Diana; for pities ake pend thee lat munites in remembrance of my ervices, and confes that Heaven is too barbarous in conenting to our eparation.

Then Silvander embraced Diana; ond that Shepherdes was o moved with thee lat words, that hardly being able to peak: Adieu (aid he, and broke out into tears) Adieu dear Silvander, be contant unto thy Diana, and le • her ee thy love can lat longer then life: Upon this, her voice failing, he offered to embrace him, but had not trength to lift up her Arm: Silvander in the mean time, got up; and eeing Atrea and Phillis near: Oh dear companions of my fairet Mitres (aid he unto them) I leave you poeors of all that happines which the preence of Diana afforded me: And as you have been the only Confidents of her ecrets and mine, be alo the faithful witnees of the purity of our flames: Then he • ad them the lat adieu, and went out of the Chamber, after he had ought for the door two or three times; for the pain wherein he was, and the tears which he had hed, had equally troubled both his judgment, and his ight.

In going down the tairs, he wiped his eyes, and compoed his face, as well as he could; And as oon as he came into the Hall, knowing that all things were ready, and that none would tell him it was time to go, he olicited the Druid to defer the fatal Ceremony no longer. Adamas having nothing to alledge againt it, was contrained to conent; o as giving order how all things hould be oberved, they all et forward.

All this great company was no ooner out of the houe, but Diana recollected thoe pirits which he lot in parting from Silvander; and hearing no noie at all, he preently upected the reaon; therefore riing out of bed, and running to the window; Oh my Silvander (cryed he out) whether art thou going? Oh my dearet hepherd, whither art thou going? Is this then the fatal day which puts me out of all hopes ere to ee thee again, or ever to enjoy thee? Oh ye mot cruel detinies, who do ravih him from me by the mot unjut Law, that ever was etablihed, why ince you give us but one life, do you uffer us to have o many different deaths? Poor Silvander, I am the only one for whom thou dyet, and the only one who does not accompany thee in this ad journey: In aying o, he raied her elf up in the window, the better to look upon her lover: But Atrea and Phillis fearing he would throw her elf down, catched hold of her: Siter (aid Atrea unto her) though this misfortune be without remedy, and your orrows infinite, yet I beeech you allow omething to our affection, and for our akes trive againt this dipair, which does every moment inpire you with ome fatal deign againt your elf: Ah Siter (replied Diana) thoe that are afe in the Port, may well look upon thoe that are in danger of hipwrack, and wih them well; had you the ame pain I have, you would reject all Counels that hould advie you to live: And why do you condemn that in me, which you would put in practie your elf,
were you in my room? No, no, companion, I mut follow Silvander; no conideration whatoever can divert me from it; and if you will oblige me, go both of you, and be preent at this Ceremony, where the mot amiable Victime is to be acrifized, that ever was, for having no confidents but you, I cannot expect any others will give me o faithful a relation of his lat actions.

Phillis, who conceived that Diana had ome reaon for this requet did think it bet for Atrea to take this office upon her; and turning towards Diana, Siter (aid he) you mut not imagine that both of us will accept of this commiion; I mut of neceity tay with you, for I will not leave you to the mercy of your dipair; You do oblige me (replied Diana faintly) by your cares to preerve me; but the favour which Atrea will do me, will do no les if he will take o much pains as to relate unto me me the circumtances of Silvanders death: And therefore, dear iter (aid he and turned towards her) I beeech you do not deny me this atisfaction, ince it is the only one I expect in this extreamite: Atrea durt not contradict the deires of her companion; but promiing to give her a faithful relation of all things, he departed: and becaue the great companion was not yet gone far from the houe, he quickly overtook them, and a little after found Celadon.

Diana all this while never tirred from the window; but keeping her eyes till fixed upon Silvander, he till thought what means he could invent not to be long after him. Phillis, who alo beheld the order of this Ceremony, and having no particular object whereon to fix her looks, becaue Lycidas in that multitude was not knowable, he looked one while upon one thing, and another while upon another. She aw the Eubages and the Vaces going firt, carrying Veels and other Intruments ued in Sacrifices. After them, went Adamas holding Silvander in his hand; and ome eight or ten paces after him, Amais betwixt Godamar and Roilion: A little after, he oberved Bellinde, Roanira, Galathea, Madonthe, and the ret, whom the Cavaliers led by the Arm: And becaue all the ret followed in confuion, he could not find Lycidas, which made her think; that perhaps he would not be a pectator of this ad Ceremony.

In this conideration, neither Diana, nor he, could retrain their tears: but when the ditance of place, and thicknes of Trees had inenibly taken from them the ight of this great company; Then was Diana afflicted beyond all meaure; he did not only loe her peech, but was very near looing her life: yet finding in this extremity ome ubject of conolation: Come, come (aid he upon a udden) away with thee unprofitable complaints, Silvander has no need of my tears or ighs; if I will give him any contentment in his econd life I mut accompany him with my oul. In aying o, he left the window; and by fortune cating her eye upon a little Cabinet of Ebony, he epyed a knife, which he and Atrea had ued ome two days before, when they did eat in the Chamber; he had a good deire to eize upon it, but fearing that Phillis would ee her, he let it alone, and walking up and down the Chamber, he watched till her companions eyes were off her.

Phillis no ooner turned her elf another way, but Diana went to the Cabinet, and having eized upon thee Arms, he went to bed: Phillis, he came unto her, and becaue Diana did nothing but igh; Alas, dear Diana (aid he) I ee it is vain to flatter our elves with hopes of any remedy: It is by the will of the Gods that Silvander is ravihed from us, and we have no better way then to beg as much patience as is neceary to endure this extream misfortune: For my part, replied Diana, I have already prepared my elf, and do protet, that ince I have o good a remedy with me, I find my grief nothing o violent. Phillis, who knew not that he had got a knife, did imagine that he took her for this good remedy, and therefore he anwered her thus: Certainly, dear iter, if your griefs may be eaed by my reentments, they hall quickly ceae their violence: For mine are o great, as I may afely ay they do equal yours; yet believe it, I would do any thing that would conduce unto your conolation. Dear Siter (aid Diana) I know very well that you are very enible of my ufferings;
and that your affection and compaion would make you do any thing to eae me.

With uch dicoure as this, thee two Shepherdees entertained each other in expectation of Astreas return; and in the mean time Silvander came to the place where death was to triumph over him. There was not one in all the company which did not change colour when they aw the pile of wood, he only looked upon it without the leat dimay.

As oon as the Druide was got upon it, and the Eubages and their veels and and knife, and all in readinee, he himelf got up alo; and kneeling down, after he had cat his eyes upon the cloud which covered the Fountain of Verity. King of ouls (aid he with mot admirable contancy) Puiant Deity who never had in heaven any thing o fair as the eyes of Diana: O great God of Love; ince I mut die to atisfie for the in which my preumption hath committed in adoring her: Receive weet Tyrant, this tetimony of my obedience, and what punihment oever my Crime had merited; yet let thy wrath be appeaed by my death. Upon this he roe up, and after he had put off his dublet, he made a ign to the Druide that he was ready to die: his great reolution did atonih all the pectatours, and even the leat enible did hed tears at the misfortune of this Shepherd; but above all, Atrea and Celadon appeared the mot adly afflicted: for as the one lamented the Fate of Silvander, o the other grieved no lee for the misfortune of Diana. Adamas, for his part, he doubted whether he had life enough to our-live this Sacrifice: yet conidering, that it was the will of the gods, he began to put his hand to the work.

The caffold which he had caued to be erected, was about ome two yards in height, and that it might hold the more wood, it was ix yards in length, and as much in bredth: As oon as all things were in readinee, the Druide took two great Tapers which he lighed at the fire, which one of the Bubages carried in a ilver chafingdih, and giving them unto two other Hubages; he commanded them to go nine times about the caffold. After this, but with a trembling hand, he took the knife, and addreing himelf to the Shepherd, he asked him whether he had contancy enough to die, without his eyes being blinded; and Silvander proteting, with abundance of alacrity, that the minute of his death, was the weet oft minute of all his life, he opened his bret to receive the blow: but Adamas being in ome ort offended at his forwardnee: Silvander (aid he unto him in a low voice) the hate which you make to die, is indeed an argument of your courage; but it may alo be an argument of your dipair: The gods do not like precipitate actions, and therefore I conjure you to wait with a little more patience, for the blow which you are to receive. We do ue in our Sacrifices to prinkle the caffold with ome drops of blood which we take from the Victime which is to be acrificed: and therefore, not to go againt this order, I will prinkle the wood with yours, upon which you are to die. Silvander made no anwer unto the words of Adamas; but after he had hewed him that he was ready to obey whatoever he commanded, the Druide took hold upon his arm a little above the hand, and the Shepherd himelf turned up the lieve of his hirt, left is hould be any hindrance unto his deign: an Eubage preently brought a bain to receive the blood, and Adamas lifted up his hand to make the wound: But he no ooner cat his eye upon the place which he was to cut, but a trange atonihment eized upon him: At firt, he could not o much as tir, or take his eyes off the arm of Silvander; afterwards, perceiving himelf to weaken upon a udden, he let fall the knife, and taking the Shepherd about the neck, O Silvander (cryed he out) O Paris, my on Paris: In aying o, his trength quite failed him, and Silvander himelf having not o much as to hold him up, they fell both together upon the caffold.

At the ight of this accident, thoe that tood at a little ditance gave a great cry, imagining that Silvander had received his Fatal blow; yet eeing Adamas to fall firt, they thought that the Sacrificer was himelf become the Victime: At that intant the two Tapers did miraculouly extinguih of themelves, to the amazement of the Bubages; and Paris, ravihed at this pectacle, and that he
hould be named, went preently up the caffold. He was no ooner there, but the Druide aumed his pirits and trength, and falling down upon his knees: Mot pitiful and compaionate gods (cryed he out) who never uffers us to peak any untruth, I give you mot hearty thanks for the great favour you have done me: Pardon me, if in depairing of your goodnes, I did murmure againt the greatnee of your infinite benignity: I mut confee that I have inned as a mortal man, but I will make a vow to erve you as my Soveraign Tautates, and promie to offer upon your Altars, continual Victimes: After this, he roe up; and eeing the whole Aembly was no lee atonihed then he, he took Paris in one hand, and holding Silvander in the other, he raied his voice to as loud a train as he could, and began to peak in this manner.

I mut make here a Publick confeion of a private action, and in the ight of all Forret declare that, which until now was never known unto any but the gods and my elf. I do protet, that this is Paris (aid he and hewed Silvander) this who has born that (aid he and hewed Paris) is not my on, but only by adoption, and as affection, or rather piety moved me to give him that name and title. But becaue uch a change is not ordinary, I am inpired to give you my reaons, to the end all men may learn never to depair in the goodnes and favours of heaven. Know then, that when the valour of Aetius added glory to the Grandure of the Romane Empire, and when the Prudence of this great Captain had gotten to himelf the government of Gaul, this countrey which had enjoyed a ecure peace for many ages before, did now find that it was not without enemies; and it being impoible but my Interet mut needs be involved in a misfortune which was then common unto all thee Provinces, I quickly found how barbarous the inolency of thoe are, who look after profit more then glory in their triumphs, for they delight in nothing but detruction, and in plundering all that preents it elf unto their infatiable fury. Their rage did not only reach o far as to ravih all that was precious in my houe, but alo they ravihed away my on, who was the only tay of all my hopes. I did what I could to hinder them, I told them, he could not do them any ervice, ince he was but five years of age: I beeeched them to have ome pity upon his innocency and my affliction; I ued all the expreions that either weetnes or depair could inpire: But neither compaion at my tears, nor repect which was due unto my quality, nor the horrour of their crime, were able to move them, but rather made them more furious; and do what I could, they would needs commit two faults: the one, in taking away my on, and the other in leaving me alive. After this misfortune, I remained without child, and without conolation; my cares became my food, and my tears my drink, and but for the charge which I had taken upon me to exercie, certainly I had followed thee ravihers of my on, or ele confined my elf unto ome horrid olitude: But ince I could not leave the duty of a Druide I was contrained to tay in the ame place where every object did preent my los before my eyes.

A few dayes after, I went to take the air along the banks of Lignon; there I mued upon my los, and how deplorable it was, and when I was in the depth of my melancholy thoughts, I heard the voice of a child crying very near me: preently being truck with a ecret joy, I went that way, and was not long before I found him: he was et upon the very brink of the bank, and o near, that his tears dropped into the water: for all his orrows, he eemed very fair, and I mut confee, that imagining his detiny to be like unto that of Paris, I conceived a particular affection to him, and took him along with me: I did what I could to know who were his Parents, but being, as I conceive, younger then Paris, he could not give me any atisfaction. I had no ooner brought him home, but being proud of this new prey, I began to find ome comfort in my affliction, and to thank the gods, that after the los of my on they had ent me another, unto whom I might in reaon give that title, ince I was no les then a Father unto him in preerving his life.

I commanded therefore all thoe who were witnees of my diater not to peak of it unto any; and charging them to call this Chide by the others
name, they did all o well obey mee, that none know of my misfortune: and there was not any in all Forrets, who did not think this uppoed Paris to be the ame which the Gods had given mee for a Succeor. Yet ince this day the Gods have dicovered the truth, and permitted mee to finde in Silvanders arme the only mark by which I could know him, it is mot jut, that I do declare him to be the true Paris: in aying o; hee embraced Silvander again with teares in his eyes; afterwards turning up the leeve of his hirt, hee hewed unto all thoe that were near the caffold the branch of Misleto, which hee had imprinted upon his arme, and which Atrea confeed hee had once een, when being in a wound, Phillis tole from him a bracelet which hee wore: After this Adamas beginning to peak: But (aid hee) though this uppoed Paris cannot now be called my Son, yet I doe protet I will till love him as well as if hee hee were; and marrying him unto Leonide, I will give him uch a hare in my etate as hall keep him from beating any envy unto the Fortune of the other. And to the end it may not be thought, that becaue hee was found by the water ide, lying upon the grae and abandoned of all the world, that therefore his birth was infamous; I would have you to know, that I found about him uch infallible ignes of his being decended from ome illutrious Family, as I mut needs doubt, whether in taking him to be mine I did not do an injury unto the glory hee might have had from his own original. Thoe that left him in that condition, doubtlee had not time to trip him of his cloaths, or perhaps they were not o barbarous as to do it: For I found him in a little purple gown, embroydered over with fine gold, and interwooven with flowers of ilk, o exquiitely wrought and hadowed, as they did exactly imitate the natural. At night when I caued him to be got to bed, I aw that hee wore at his breat a little Agathe hanging in a chain of gold; in which was engraved a Lion, and cloe by him a Lions Whelp which was fighting for his life againt a Tiger as big as himelf, and about him were written in great Characters thee words, Comme ne de ce Lion: and this made mee think this childe had a very generous father, who expecting actions from his Son worthy of his birth, would ignifie thereby, the great hopes that hee had in his future valour: Thee are the marks that I found about this childe, which I have afely kept; and I wih they may conduce as much unto his contentment, as thoe markes of my Son have erved to convince mee that hee is my own. Upon this Adamas was ilent; and leaving all the by tanders in a trange atonihment, Atrea above all the ret, did not know how to interpret what hee had een: ometimes hee imagined that it was only a dream, and ometimes accued her elf for not believing her own eyes; but her wonder was greater, when hee aw Bellinde advancing in great hate, and being helped up to the caffold, hee took him about the neck who had ever been taken for Paris: Deare Ergates (aid hee) is it thou my Son, whom Adamas has o carefully brought up? Ergates, my Son Ergates, let mee embrace and kie thee my dear Son Ergates. Upon this her voice failed her, but not her trength; for hee held him o cloe and hard, as hee was not able to fall downe upon his knees. As oon as hee could peak, it was only to tell the Druid, that all the marks which hee had found upon that childe were upon Ergates, and that the Figures and Motto which were upon the Agathe, were only to ignifie that it was Celion.

Adamas received abundant conolation from the Joyes of Bellinde; and whilt Ergates (for I will hereafter call them by their names) was ometimes thanking the Gods, and ometimes Adamas, for the favours which they had done him, in retoring him unto his mother; the true Paris did nothing but think upon the change which was hapned in his Fortune. In that intant, all the Oracles that had be • n given, did come into his memory; and finding them to be all true in this lat accident, hee knew very well, that hee never had any right undertanding of them: and certainly it was impoible hee could ever dive into ths ecret of this mytery: For not knowing that hee was Paris, it was not poible hee could conceive, that all thoe misfortunes wherewith Silvander was menaced, were to turn unto his own happinee and advantage.

Hee was till in thee thoughts, when hee heard Adamas begin to peak with a countenance full of adnee: yet notwithtanding (aid hee) the Gods have ordained that this Joy hall not continue long; and the finding of Paris, is but to make my loe the more intolerable, for I am ready to execute their commands: And therefore Oh Tautates, Great God of Love (aid hee, falling down upon his knees, and lifting up his eyes to heaven) Infinite Deity, who dot dipoe of all our detinies according to thy pleaure, pronounce (I beeech thee) either to my happinee or confuion the lat doom of thy divine Will; whether my Son, being already dead as a Shepherd and as Silvander, hall alo die as hee is Paris: For if it be thy divine will to have it o, though his death will mot certainly be the caue of mine, yet I do vow inviolably, that I will be no obtacle unto it.

At this Prayer, all the Company changed countenance; and the fear leat ome ad accident hould happen which might diturb the happinee of new Paris, caued every one to long and deire to know what would become of it. But they were not long in this perplexity; for the Druid had no ooner done peaking, but the Cloud which covered the Fountain did open according to its cutome, and by little and little appeared out of the water a Pillar of white Marble; upon which the God of Love appeared, not now armed with Thunder and Lightning, but with uch armes as hee ues when hee playes with the Craces. Hee had in one hand two Crownes of Mirtle, which hee did throw o dexterouly, that the one fell upon the head of Celadon, and the other upon the head of Silvander: Afterwards, hee vanihing, the Cloud cloed again; but i • did rie again in everal little Clouds, in which were abundance of little Cupids which alo threw Crownes upon the Aembly, and joyining their voices unto the harmony of Intruments, they ang thee words:

lg.l: Ceae all your cares; the Gods are pleas'd
That you hould of them all be eas'd:
Let all your Griefs be turn'd to Joy,
Let Lignon glide, and only move
In weets of Peace and charmes of Love.

div.p: This conent of Cupids having ended this Anthem, the Clouds dipered, and all the little Cupids vanihed: but Atrea was no witnee of it; for hee no ooner heard that Silvander proved to be Paris, but hee tole out of the company to carry the news unto her companions.

Phillis in the mean time went from time to time to look for her at the window; and eeing Atrea return, hee went unto Diana's bed ide, but with a face o pale and dejected, as if hee had heard of the death of Lycidas and not of Silvanders. Diana, who oberved this alteration, did ask her the caue; and Phillis anwered with a deep igh, that hee had een Atrea returning, and that her fears to hear ill newes, had o chilled her heart as made her change colour. Then Diana all in confuion: Oh God (cryed hee out) I know Silvander is dead; but let heaven and earth do what they can, they hall not hinder mee from following him.

In aying o, hee would have laid her hand upon the knife which hee had hid; but in her tranport not remembring in what place hee had laid it, hee raied her elf half out of bed, and looking about on all ides: What, (aid hee in a great urprie) have the Gods taken from mee the remedy which I had prepared againt my dipair? Upon this, he found the knife, which, unknown to her, lay cloe by: and ettling her elf again in her bed, No, no, (aid hee, and continued) they are more pitifull then to leave the mierable no refuge. Phillis, who oberved all her actions to the leat circumtance, did wonder what it
was he did, and partly upecting the truth, did et her elf to watch her from doing any harm unto her elf.

In the mean time, Atrea was come, and as oon as he entred in at the door courage Siter (aid he) Silvander is dead. Diana preently cat her eye upon her, and eeing her all in a water, did think it to be tears and not weat that had bedewed her face: o as not quetioning the misfortune which he feared: Ah Siter (anwered he) it is in vain to bid me courage, for I have as much as will help me to die and to bid you adieu: in aying o, he eized upon the knife, and lifting her arm out of bed, he offered to thrut it into her bret: But Phillis keeping alwayes an eye upon her, did preently catch hold of her: Siter (aid he) what do you mean to do? Nay Siter (aid Diana all in a fury) what do you mean to do? Oh you enemy of my contentment, why do you oppoe my reolution ince it is o jut? In aying o he trove, and endeavoured to get her hand at liberty, and Atrea who was extreamly afraid at the ight of the knif, he repented that he had given her uch a fale alarm; But Siter (aid he) Paris is till alive: what care I (replied Diana) whether Paris he alive or no, ince Silvander is dead: it does concern you o much (replied Atrea) that you will not refue him for your husband; I had rather marry a Toade, anwered Diana and interrupted: and yet aid Atrea, Silvander dyed only that it might he o: and I will die (anwered Diana) that it may not be o. But (aid Atrea) if Paris and Silvander be both one, and he whom you thought to be Paris, do prove to be Ergates the Brother of Diana, what will you ay then? Ah Siter (replied Diana) your ubtilty is out of eaon, and I will never trouble my elf to anwer it, becaue I know it to be a thing impoible: but I mut, and I will die, becaue I ought to do o, and becaue I have promied it. Upon this she began to trive again, and perhaps had been too hard for Phillis, if Atrea had not helped, and took the knife from her: afterwards with expreion of affection, and joy, Siter (aid he) I do protet, Paris is not Paris, but Ergates: and he whom you lament for as Silvander who was to die, is now the very ame Paris whom the gods have detinied for the husband of Diana. If you do make any doubt of my words, and that the wonder of the accident does require a larger dicoure, I will tell you every circumtance, upon a promie that you will hear me patiently. Atrea did peak this in uch a manner as did a little etle the mind of Diana, and made her believe there was ome truth in what he aid: and though this novelty did find but little place for belief, yet he thought it was not altogether impoible; Having therefore promied Atrea to hear her, that hepherdes related word for word, all that he had heard, and een in the ame order as they fell out: ometimes he put Diana into fears, and ometimes revived her, according as he took away or gave her any hopes; At lat, when he had told all, and had filled the mind of Diana with more amaement then before; Siter (aid Phillis) it is not enough to give credit unto Atrea, but me thinks you hould deire to be a witnes of it your elf, I conceive it bet therefore to dres your elf as oon as you can, for I believe you will hear of Bellinde very hortly; In aying o he fetched her clothes; and Diana took them with o much joy that he knew not what he did: and indeed, if Atrea had not helped her, it would have been long before he had dreed her elf. At lat, when he was ready to go out, he went betwixt Atrea and Phillis, and they had not gone a hundred paces from the houe, but they met Lycidas, whom Adamas had ent, to advertie Diana of all paages.
