At firt, Phillis was a little urpried at the ight of him, for he could not tell whether or no he went to the acrifice of Silvander; But when they were within hearing of each other, he called him luggard, and accued him for having les care, and affection then Atrea had to bring them the news of the life of Paris, and the finding out of Ergates. The hepherd excued himelf as well as he could, and conidering that he had come as fat as he could, he wondered that Atrea hould be before him. Yet hearing that he did not tay o long as to ee the dienchantment of the fountain, he made a particular relation unto them of thoe remarkable paages.

The hate which Diana made to ee thee alterations in the perons of Paris and
Ergates, was uch, as never thinking how weary Atrea was with walking before, as they came quickly to the place where all the Company was aembled, and where every one was ravihed with the wonders they had een. As oon as they were come near, the croud made away for them, untill they came to Adamas and Bellinde who were already come down from the caffold: for deiring no les a Theater then the whole plain of Forrets for the repreentation of this tragi-Comedy they went unto Amais, who deired that the knot of this buines hould he diolved in her preence.

Adamas, held Ergates, by the hand; and Bellinde, Paris: o as Diana was no ooner come unto them, but the Druide embraced her, and being hardly able to with hold his tears for the extream joy which he reented; Daughter (aid he unto her) heretofore I deired to give you this Son as a lover and as a husband: but the gods would not let my ignorance commit uch a crime, and have this day ordained that I hall preent him unto you as a Brother; In aying o he preented Ergates unto her, and afterwards continuing, take him (aid he) as the bet preent I can offer unto you, and let him find more favour as your kindred, then he could as your ervant. Diana did not hear thee lat words; for as oon as he had liberty to alute Ergates, he was inpired with o much conanguinious affection, as he embraced him a long time, and poke not a word. Ergates was no les amaed and mute, o as not being able to peak, their tongus did leat of all contribute unto the expreion of their reentments, and perhaps they had forgotten themelves in the tranport into which this new acquaintance had put them, if Bellinde had not interrupted their carrees, and aid unto the hepherdes: Diana, to pleae both the Oracles and your affection at once, I do here give you Paris not as he is Silvander, whoe ruine the gods do till deire, but as the legitimate Son of the grand Druide unto whom the gods do promie happines beyond all our deires, as it has already our hopes. Upon this Silvander, or rather Paris, advanced: and cating himelf at the feet of Diana, econd, oh fairet Mitree (aid he unto her) the favour which Bellinde hath done me: and ince I want nothing to make me compleatly happy, but your conent, give it dearet Diana to accomplih my good fortune; Yes Paris (anwered he) I will give it, ince you deerve it, and he who has the ole power of me commands it. Then he embraced, and afterwards cat her elf down at the feet of Bellinde, from whom she obtained a pardon for her former diobedience. This commune joy, appeared in the countenances and eyes of all; But Atrea, Diana and Phillis, being thoe that were mot intereted, it is eaie to imagine that their joyes were beyond all comparion or expreion: and indeed they appeared fairer then before; And that Diana had lot much of her collour in her precedent afflictions, yet being contrained to make a confeion of her love in publique, even hame did bring uch blushes into her checks, as retored unto her the fresh luter of her beauty.

On the other ide Celadons atisfaction was beyond all parralell that the good fortune both of Paris, and Ergates did ute o well with his deires; And the right Paris, ometimes looking upon the caffold, and then upon Diana, he was o ravished to ee himelf out of that danger wherein he thought to have perished as he could not enough be thankfull for his good fortune. Bellinde did not know in which she had mot caue of joy, whether in finding him whom she thought for ever lot, or in finding a means to content both the gods and Diana. Adamas eeing himelf already in Poeion of thoe favours which the Oracle promied unto him, after he had retored Celadon unto his dear Atrea, he thought himelf fully recompened for all the cares, and paynes he had taken to preerve them. Thus had every one particular coniderations of the preent happines, when the Druide knowing that omething ele was to be done, he went unto Amais, and beeeched her to command what was her pleaure to be done: and the Nymph thought fit, that after o many favours which the gods had hewed them), they could do no les, then return mot humble thanks: and in order thereunto, she commanded that ome Bulls hould be brought, and acrificed in lieu of Silvander. Which the Victimaries obeying, Adamas did acrifice them withall uuall ceremonies:
And when hee viewed the intralls, hee found them all o pure and found, as hee was very certain that the Gods were well pleaed.

This mytery being ended, the Druid did put off the habit of grand Sacrificer; and now no ignes of any enchantment remaining about the Fountain, almot all thoe that were about the Fountain were inpired with a great deire of looking into it: but above all Alcidon was the mot impatient; for the Oracle had promied that hee hould there finde an end of his paines. Hee addreed himelf therefore unto Adamas, and aid thus unto him: You do know, reverend Father, by the relation which I have formerly made unto you of my Fortunes, that the beginning of my happinee depends only upon your permitting mee to look into the Fountain of Loves veritie: And now ince there is no obtacle to hinder mee but that, I do mot humbly beeech you to let mee have recoure unto that remedy which only can give mee full contentment: Generous Alcidon (anwered the Druid) you ask mee a thing which depends only upon your elf: yet if you will take my advice, let mee tell you, that I do think the Inchantment to be quite diolved, and do conceive it fit, that (ince the Female Lover which was to die, was Alexis, and the Hee Lover Silvander; for death being only a deprivation of being, they are both dead, ince neither Alexis nor Silvander are in being, but the one become Celadon, and the other Paris my Son) ome order be oberved in it: For it is to be feared, that if every one hould follow his own fancy, ome confuion would arie amongt this great multitude, I do conceive it fit therefore, that wee hould oberve ome order, in which every one in their turnes may finde his particular Contentment.

And becaue wee ee that the God of Love is no lee pleaed to have his power admired in the homely Cottages of our Shepherds, as well as in great Palaces: Nay, to break the force of an inchantment hee cats his eye only upon them, as taking mot delight in their innocency; mee thinks it fit that they, by whoe meanes this Inchantment is diolved, hould have the firt Eay: Alcidon thought this to be but reaon; and the Druid having asked the advice of the Great Nymph, hee gave him leave to do as hee pleaed.

Adamas then went unto Celadon, and got his conent to be the firt that hould look into the Fountain: at the firt, Atrea did oppoe it, imagining that it was in ome ort, to doubt of her affection. But the Druid telling her it did much conduce unto her Glory, that Poterity hould know this Inchantment ended only for the tranquillity of this Shepherd, hee was obedient to whatoever hee pleaed. So Adamas took Celadon by the hand, and leading him unto the ide of the Fountain, both kneeled down: And the Druid having made a prayer unto the God of Love, Celadon tooped down; and hee had no ooner cat his eye upon the water, but hee aw his Mitree, as fair as imagination was able to repreent her: This ight did ravih him the more, becaue hee aw himelf alone with her, and becaue it was a full aurance of her inviolable Fidelity. Preently after, Atrea was conducted thither by Amais, who kneeling down as Adamas did before, hee made a igne unto the Shepherdee to toop down, which Atrea obeying, the Image of Celadon immediately appeared, accompanied with all the Graces that Nature could infue into his face: After this, hee yielded place unto Diana and Phillis, who never forook her in this mytery of Love, ince their affections had linked them together: So thee three fair Shepherdees, one after another, did look into the liquid Chrytal, which was then unto them the Fountain of oblivion: For at that very intant they lot the memory of all the mieries they had endured: And the ight of Celadon, Paris, and Lycidas, whoe images they aw, was a perfect remedy againt all their pat paines: Next after this, Roilion, at the deire of Amais, approached this miraculous water: and though hee had tronger arguments of Roaniras Love, then ever to doubt of it, yet hee looked in, becaue hee would be an eye-witnee of this miracle: So as hee aw himelf next his Mitree, and not being able to conceive that Roanira hould be o near him, hee turned about to ee whether hee tood behinde him; but not eeing her there, hee
looked into the water again, and remained in that contemplation, until Roanira came and took him off, that he might ee the ame which he had done. Dorinde was the next that advanced in a trembling pace, to clear her upitions of Sigimonds fidelity; and as oon as ever he looked into the Fountain, he was fully atisfied concerning the love of that Prince: o as he accued her elf of incredulity, and made a vow never to doubt again of his affection. Alcidon in the mean while, beeeched Daphnide not to deny him that remedy which the Oracle had promied unto them: To which he conenting, they went one after another to conult with the water; which preenting them with what they deired, they were infinitly well atisfied with their good Fortune.

Damon, becaue he would not be ingular, he went as the ret did, and beeeched Madonthe to do the like; but becaue they were already but one and the ame, this ight did hardly add any contentment unto them. They had no ooner left the Fountain free, but every one did cat their eyes upon Lindamor, whom, his repects unto Amais did keep from this myterious water, and becaue the great Nymph knew his mind, he made a ign unto him to go thither, whom he immediatly obeyed; but after he had received from this ight all the atisfaction he could ever hope for, he perceived his joyes to leen, when his fears of a denial did forbid him to ask what the Fountain had promied unto him: yet remembring the dicoure which Godomar and he had together as they went to Lions, he took a little heart; and therefore as oon as Amais deired to know what ucces he had, he told her clearly, that the water made him believe he had ome hare in Galatheas favour. Brave Lindamor (anwered Amais) you do deerve her better then any man in the world, and I would have you to enjoy her: Then cauing Galathea to come near, and preenting her unto the Cavalier, here Lindamor (aid he) I do give her unto you; and if this recompence do not equal your ervices, yet take it in good part, and conider that I do give you all that I can. Upon this, the Cavalier kneeled down, and even ravihed with joy, did kis her hand by way of thanks.

Delphires, Thomantes, Doriea, Filiutes, and the ret, who had all left their habitations to come unto this Sacrifice of Silvander, they had all the priviledge of this water, and found uch Dooms as ended all their differences, far better then the entence which Diana had pronounced a little before: for in depite of the pretentions and puruit of his Rival, Thomantes continued poeour of Delphire.

Ligdamon, Silvia, and after them many Shepherds and Shepherdees went to ee their Detinies in this water; and amongt the ret, Dori •
was inpired to look in: Doubtles the only thing that moved her unto it, was her hopes to ee the Ghot of Palemon; but the god of Love, who is an enemy unto the dead, was revenged of her, and preented Adrates unto her in lieu of Palemon, and this Shepherdes was o urprized at it, that though he did not much love him, yet not to diobey the ordinances of this god, he received him into the place which Palemon had ravihed from him. Thus after every one had looked into the water, Hylas was the ingular peron that approached not: which moved Amais to ask the reaon, to whom the Shepherd returned this anwer. I know, Madam, you are not to be told; and ince this Fountain bears the name of the truth of Love, I will not oblige her to commit a fault for my ake. That, replied Amais, is only to be undertood of actions that are evil; but to love one is a thing o laudable and honet, as you need not fear what the Fountain can tell you concerning that ubject. Madam (replied the incontant) I am not very inquiitive to know whether I did well or ill, in loving as I have done: I have followed the grain of my own humour, and do believe it is not to be condemned, ince it has exactly imitated Nature, which will perih and die rather then be confined alwayes to one thing. But to tell you truly, that which has much induced me to affect change, is the conideration which I have had of the lives of thoe Lovers, who like unto Celadon and Silvander, have endeavoured to get the imple irnames of faithful and contant: for I have oberved them alwayes o mierable, as I thought that Love did punih them for their fidelity and contancy, as for crimes which I ought
to hun. And yet aid Amais, you ee that on the contrary, the god of Love rather loves them, and has brought them to a higher pitch of felicity, then ever they could expect or deire. At this, Hylas was a little gravelled; but at the lat, he hook his head, I wear, Madam (aid he) they deerve all the felicity they find; and it may be aid, that it was rather old then given them, for they have paid full dear for it! But for all that, I would look into this Fountain where Love dicovers o many truths, if I had not a tronger reaon which retrains me, and which makes me think it to be impoible: Upon this, Amais asking what it was, it is Madam (anwered he) becaue this Fountain is o little, that if I hould look into it, it is impoible I hould ee half of thoe faces which I have loved: Three or four faces will fill it; and how is it then poible, that Dorinde, Carlis, Stilliana, Palanice, Aymea, Doris, Florice, Phillis, Cryeide, Stella, and as many more, hould find any room there? Amais and all the company, could not chue but laugh at the conceit of Hylas; but Adamas, telling him, that he hould ee only the peron whom he then loved, it did o perwade, with him, that he reolved to look into the Fountain; and o accordingly he ran thither immediatly, and without any kneeling, looked in: at which the god of Love was not offended, but hewed Stella unto him whom he then loved, without any other perons but Hylas and he, which did o ravih him, as knowing thereby the will of that Shepherdes, he vowed inviolably to fix himelf there.

Thee Myteries being ended, Amais deiring to memorize them unto poterity, did command all this great company to follow her unto Marcelles, where he would celebrate a feat for eight dayes together, in memory of o many remarkable uccees. None durt diobey this command; and therefore, when he et forward, every one prepared themelves to follow. They had not gone above two hundred paces, but they aw upon their left hand a Shepherd and a Shepherdee coming together, who were preently known to be Laonice and Tircis: They held each other by the hand, at which Hylas was o ravihed, that he ran to meet them; and wondering at the change which he aw in the humour to Tircis, he was extreamly glad that he had found a companion in his infidelity. Laonice in the mean while, no ooner aw Diana and Paris, whom he till took to be Silvander; but hating to them, he asked pardon for the Treaon which he had practied againt them, which he quickly obtained: for they did forgive her, and the more willingly, becaue they were now above all fears of any alteration in their Fortunes. Tircis enquired of Hylas, from whence all that great company came, and being told in few words, he would needs go and ee his Detiny as the ret had; but Laonice would not let him, and therefore they followed the ret unto Marcelles: where, during the eight dayes which Amais had devoted unto feating and pleaures, all thee Lovers did happily conummate their marriages, except Dorinde, whom Godomar carryed unto Lions, after he had heard that Gondebaut had at lat conented unto a marriage betwixt Sigimond and her. Roilion and Roanira returned unto the Queen Argires: Daphnide and Alcidon went unto their houes; and all the Shepherds and Shepherdees returned home, and talked of nothing but the happines of Celadon, and the felicity of Atrea.
